title: Introduction to Accounting I
description: Introduction to managerial and financial accounting and methods used to record and report managerial and financial information to decision makers internal and external to the firm. Part I. A-F only. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Introduction to Accounting II
description: Introduction to managerial and financial accounting and methods used to record and report managerial and financial information to decision makers internal and external to the firm. Part II. 200 (with a C- or better).

title: Intermediate Financial Accounting I
description: Accounting process and the application of GAAP to the recognition and measurement of cash, receivables, inventories, property plant and equipment, depreciation and depletion, intangibles, and current liabilities. 200 and 210, or BUS 624 (with a minimum grade of C- or better).
prerequisites: ACC 200 and ACC 210, or BUS 624 (with a minimum grade of C- or better)

title: Intermediate Financial Accounting II
description: Application of GAAP to the recognition and measurement of long-term liabilities, investments, contributed capital, retained earnings, accounting changes and errors, income recognition, accounting for income taxes, pensions, leases, and statement of cash flows. 321 with C- or better.

title: Accounting Internship
description: On-the-job experience in the accounting community. Term paper and meetings with faculty advisor required. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Reading and research of a special area in major under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by the department chair and faculty advisor.

title: Federal Individual Income Taxation
description: Examines federal income tax concepts, such as gross income, exclusions, deductions, exemptions, and tax credits, especially for sole proprietors. Introduces taxation of property transactions. Development of professional writing skills is integral to this course. 200 and 210, or BUS 624 (with a minimum grade of C- or better).
prerequisites: ACC 200 and ACC 210, or BUS 624 (with a minimum grade of C- or better)

title: Taxation of Business Entities
description: A survey of the general concepts, rules, and practices involved in the taxation of sole-proprietorships, corporations, partnerships, and subchapter S corporations. 401 with C- or better.

title: Accounting Information Systems
description: Accounting systems analysis, control and design in manual and computerized environments. Knowledge and skills of information technology for auditing AIS systems. Hands-on experience with microcomputers and a computerized accounting system. A-F only. 323 (with C- or better or concurrent) and BUS 311 (with C or better).
prerequisites: ACC 323 (with C- or better or concurrent) and BUS 311 (with C or better)

title: Law for the Accountant
description: Intensive study of areas of law of importance to accountants. Particular attention is given to principles of law relating to contracts, sales, commercial paper, secured transactions, property, legal entities, agency, securities, and accountant’s legal liability. BLAW 200 or consent.

title: Advanced Financial Accounting
description: Accounting topics relating to consolidation requirements and introduction to the fundamentals of fund accounting, including the general fund, restricted funds, debt service funds, enterprise funds, general long-term account group, general fixed assets accounting group, and accounting entries for encumbrances. 323 with C- or better.

title: Special Topics in Accounting
description: Addresses current issues impacting the accounting profession. Topics vary each semester. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits. consent.

title: Auditing
description: Auditing concepts including standards, objectives and ethics for external auditors. Emphasis on reporting standards, internal control, evidence, statistical sampling, IT audits and assurance. Development of professional writing skills is an integral part of this course. 323 and 409, both with C- or better.
prerequisites: ACC 323 and ACC 409, both with C- or better

title: Forensic Accounting
description: Theoretical and real life aspects of forensic accounting. Includes discussions of the legal environment, types of forensic engagements such as, lost earnings, business valuations, fraud, and real world forensic cases. Repeatable one time, but credit earned one time only. A-F only. 418.

title: (Alpha) Accounting Capstone
description: Integration of numerous elements of the accounting program. Current accounting issues discussed. Lectures, discussions, case analysis. (B) managerial-tax-ethics; emphasis on instruction in writing; (C) financial-auditing-accounting information systems. ACC majors only. A-F only. 401 (or concurrent) and 418 (or concurrent) for (B); 418 (or concurrent) for (C).
prerequisites: ACC 401 (or concurrent) and ACC 418 (or concurrent) for (B); ACC 418 (or concurrent) for (C)

title: CPA Review-Audit and Attestation
description: Auditing and Attestation (AUD) section covers the entire auditing process, including auditing procedures, generally accepted auditing standards, standards related to attest engagements, and the AICPA Code of Professional Conduct. CR/NC only. 418 (or concurrent).

title: CPA Review-The Business Environment and Concepts
description: The Business Environment and Concepts (BEC) section focuses on business concepts and the significance of a CPA’s professional duties and responsibilities within the larger context of the business environment. CR/NC only.

title: CPA Review-The Financial Accounting and Reporting
description: The (FAR) section focuses on U.S. GAAP, including concepts and standards for financial statements, typical items in financial statements, specific types of transactions and events, accounting and reporting for governmental and other entities. CR/NC only. 323.

title: CPA Review-The Regulation
description: The Regulation section focuses on federal taxation, especially taxation of business entities; individuals, and property taxation, but also tests on business law, business ethics, and professional and legal responsibilities. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 407.

title: International Corporate Governance
description: Understanding of complex and critical issues of international corporate governance, financial reporting, and ethical conduct. Includes corporate governance in the U.S., major European markets, and Asia. Emphasis on internal and external stakeholders, regulators, and gatekeepers. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Accounting Theory and Development
description: History and theoretical background of accounting standards. Including accounting theories, formulating and testing theories; scientific, pragmatic, syntactic and semantic theories; normative and positive theories. Literature supportive and critical of accounting theories and standards. 323 with C- or better, or consent.
prerequisites: ACC 323 with C- or better, or consent

title: Information and Assurance and Analytics
description: Focus on auditing processes, standards, and guidance specific to IT risks. Exposure to advanced IT audit software and its practical application and real world IT audit issues. 418 with C- or better, or consent.
prerequisites: ACC 418 with C- or better, or consent

title: Global Accounting
description: Theory and fundamental causes of international variations in accounting. Special emphasis on problems such variations create for financial reporting, control, and decision-making within multinational business enterprises. 323 with C- or better, or consent.
prerequisites: ACC 323 with C- or better, or consent

title: Accounting and Tax Research
description: In depth examination of tax and accounting research, IRC, and SEC procedures. Extensive practice in issue identification, reading and analyzing primary authority, and communicating results. Credit not given for both 606 and 625. 401 or 584 with C- or better, orientation program, or consent.
prerequisites: ACC 401 or ACC 584 with C- or better, orientation program, or consent

title: Tax of Partners/Partnerships
description: Examines advanced topics in federal taxation of partners and partnerships regarding the contribution, operation, and distribution from partnerships and transfers of partnership interests. 407 with C- or better, or consent.
prerequisites: ACC 407 with C- or better, or consent

title: Advanced Public Sector Accounting
description: Provides the tools necessary for understanding the principles of fiscal accountability and reporting in governmental and not-for-profit organizations. ACC majors only. 415 with C- or better, or consent.
prerequisites: ACC 415 with C- or better, or consent

title: Estate and Gift Taxation and Planning
description: Examines estate and gift tax provisions and basic estate planning techniques to save taxes and avoid probate. Overviews generation-skipping transfer taxes and income taxes on estates and trusts. 401 with C- or better, or consent.
prerequisites: ACC 401 with C- or better, or consent

title: Multijurisdictional Taxation
description: Examines international, state, and local tax issues. Topics include U.S. International taxation of in- and out-bound transactions, sourcing of income and deductions and nexus. 401 with C- or better.

title: Financial Statements Analysis
description: Analyses of a firm’s profitability, liquidity, and solvency using ratios and common size financial statements. Students are expected to find strengths and weaknesses of the firm based on their analysis. A-F only. 323 . Co-requisite: 660 .

title: Data Analytics for Accountants
description: Introduction to visual analytics. Tableau and Power BI for Excel. Introduction to data processing and blending, data visualization and other visualization techniques. Introduction to PowerQuery, PowerPivot, PowerView, and PowerMap. Repeatable two times, up to three credits.

title: Analysis and Decision-Making
description: Integrates learning through analysis and communication of comprehensive business problems. Stresses research, critical thinking, and analytical and communication skills applied to contemporary accounting and tax issues. 625 with C- or better (or concurrent), no waiver. Co-requisite: 648.
prerequisites: ACC 625 with C- or better (or concurrent), no waiver

title: Current Topics in Accounting
description: Concentration on current issues impacting the accounting profession. Topics vary each semester. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits.

title: Accounting Internship
description: On-the-job experience in the accounting community. Necessary evaluation reports and meetings with faculty advisor required. ACC majors only. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Required for Plan A candidates only; six credit hours required, one must be taken during semester that degree is being awarded. Repeatable up to six credits. ACC majors only. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only. MAcc student and School of Accountancy Director approval.
prerequisites: MAcc student and School of Accountancy Director approval

title: Financial Accounting Research
description: Provides an overview of financial accounting research. Specific research studies are examined as to their theoretical basis, design, implications, methodology, relevance, etc. Repeatable one time. A-F only. PhD students in Business Administration only. A-F only.

title: Managerial Accounting Research
description: Provides an overview of managerial accounting research. Specific research studies are examined as to their theoretical basis, design, implications, methodology, relevance, etc. A-F only. PhD students in Business Administration only. A-F only.

title: Research in Behavioral Accounting
description: Provides an overview of accounting research in behavioral accounting topics. Specific research studies are examined as to their theoretical basis, design, implications, methodology, relevance, etc. PhD students in Business Administration only. A-F only.

title: Research in Accounting Information Systems
description: Provides an overview of accounting research in accounting information systems topics. Specific research studies are examined as to their theoretical basis, design, implications, methodology, relevance, etc. PhD students in Business Administration only. A-F only.

title: Research in Auditing and International Accounting
description: Provides an overview of accounting research in Auditing and International Accounting topics. Specific research studies are examined as to their theoretical basis, design, implications, methodology, relevance, etc. A-F only. PhD student status in business administration or consent.
prerequisites: PhD student status in business administration or consent

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Reading and research in an area of accounting under the direction of faculty member(s). Repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. A-F only. PhD students in Business Administration only.
prerequisites: PhD students in Business Administration only

title: Introduction to Cinematic Digital Production
description: Introduction to the basic techniques of cinematic digital production and allows them to explore their personal voice in this process. A-F only.

title: Introduction to 3D Computer Animation
description: A basic overview of the 3D animation production process, including modeling, texturing, rigging, animation, lighting, and rendering. A-F only. 255 (or concurrent).

title: Introduction to 2D Animation
description: Introduction to traditional styles and methods of hand drawn 2D, digital, and stop motion animation through theory and practice. SCA majors only. A-F only. 255 (or concurrent) and ART 113 (or concurrent).

title: Introduction to Cinema and Digital Media
description: Introduction to the study of cinema: history, aesthetics, and cultural impact. A-F only.

title: Cinematic Narrative Production
description: Production-intensive course with collaborative as well as individual projects. Theories and application of basic digital cinema productions, including camera, lighting, sound, and editing. SCA majors only. A-F only. 255 (or concurrent).

title: Cinematography
description: Comprehensive course in visual styles supporting screen narratives through a study of principles of camera elements, operations, lighting, color and composition. Professional role and responsibilities of cinematographer. Project-oriented. SCA majors only. A-F only. 310

title: Experimental Art and Animation
description: Provides students an opportunity to experiment with new mediums while collaborating with artists from different backgrounds, such as art, theatre, dance, film, and animation. SCA, ART, THEA, DNCE majors only. 216 (or concurrent) or ART 113 or CINE/DNCE/THEA 353 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 356 (or concurrent). (
prerequisites: CINE 216 (or concurrent) or ART 113 or CINE/DNCE/THEA 353 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 356 (or concurrent)

title: 3D Modeling
description: Essential principles of 3D modeling in order to create both organic character models and hard surface models. Students will create high-quality, animation-ready 3D models with textures and poses. SCA majors only. A-F only. 215.

title: 3D Animation
description: Creating the illusion of life through the principles of animation. Repeatable one time for different alphas. SCA majors only. A-F only. 315.

title: 3D Lighting, Camera, and Rendering
description: Students develop the ability to manipulate light, shadow, and color within a virtual 3D space. Rendering and cinematography for 3D animation. SCA majors only. A-F only. 316.

title: Storyboarding and Animatics
description: Exposes students to the history, application, format, styles, and methods of creating storyboards and animatics. Visual storytelling will be analyzed by examining the foundational components of the visual language of a film. SCA majors only. A-F only. 255.

title: Visual Development for Animation
description: Visual design and development for animated characters and environments. Students will create concept art, character, and prop designs; movements styles; backgrounds; and layouts for animation -production. SCA majors only. A-F only. 216.

title: Movement Study for Animation
description: Creating the illusion of life and expressive movement through the principles of 2D animation: timing, spacing, physics, staging, anatomy, attitude, and acting. SCA majors only. A-F only. 216.

title: Motion Graphics
description: A project-based introduction to motion graphics using Adobe After Effects. SCA majors only. A-F only. 215 and 216; or 310.

title: Independent Producing
description: Fundamentals of producing for independent filmmaking, focusing on business acumen and role of the producer through various stages of production. Topics include proposal writing, script breakdowns, budgeting, scheduling, legal issues, festival strategy, and distribution. SCA majors only. A-F only. 255; and 310 or (215 and 216).
prerequisites: CINE 255; and CINE 310 or (CINE 215 and CINE 216)

title: Screenwriting
description: Introduction to the basics of writing a short narrative screenplay for film or animation. Students learn the fundamentals and format of screenwriting as well as basic elements of storytelling and character development. SCA majors only. A-F only. 255 (or concurrent).

title: Screening Asian Americans
description: Survey of Asian and Asian American representations in American film and television from the silent era to the present, with an emphasis on Orientalism and multiculturalism, as well as performance and spectatorship. SCA majors: A-F only. junior standing or consent. (

title: Scenic I: Beginning Scenic Design
description: Workshop introducing the basic principles and approaches of scenic design for theatre and dance, with emphasis on the creative process. a course in THEA or DNCE, production experience, or consent. (Consent required for production experience option) (
prerequisites: a course in THEA or DNCE, production experience, or consent

title: Oral Tradition to Screenplay
description: Adapting the stories, styles, and cultural values of oral tradition storytelling to cinematic narratives. A-F only. 350.

title: Costumes I: Beginning Costume Design
description: Basic principles and approaches to costume design for theatre and dance. Visual communication methods, creative process, historical research, and organizational practices. Repeatable one time. 240, or consent. (

title: Indigenous Aesthetics
description: Aesthetic theories and practices of indigenous cultures of the Pacific and their adaptation to the screen in cinematic storytelling. A-F only. 255 or consent.

title: Directing the Actor on Screen
description: Introduction of the screen-director to the craft of acting for the camera. Students will develop communication skills and learn practical techniques to elicit spontaneous and relaxed performances with actors from the Theatre program. SCA majors only. A-F only. 310 or (215 and 216); and 350 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: CINE 310 or (CINE 215 and CINE 216); and CINE 350 (or concurrent)

title: Editing for Cinema
description: Advanced course examining the theory, techniques, and practices of motion picture editing; use of non-linear digital editing systems; and practical experience in digital editing projects. SCA majors only. A-F only. 310; or 215 and 216.

title: Post Production Sound
description: Practical course on the theory, art, and techniques of sound recording, editing, and design for cinema. Students work on projects involving dialogue and sound effects in post-production. SCA majors only. A-F only. 372 (or concurrent).

title: Directing the Camera for the Screen
description: Detailed analysis of cinematic grammar, placement, movement, focus, and effects of the camera to create the mise-en-scene. Practical exercises to apply theory to individual creative work and in collaboration with actors from the Theatre program. ACM majors only. A-F only. (310, or 215 and 216), and 350, and 370.
prerequisites: (CINE 310, or CINE 215 and CINE 216), and CINE 350, and CINE 370

title: Genre and Narrative Theory in Cinematic Arts
description: Focus on the concept of genre, genre films, genre film criticism, and popular genres such as the Western, film noir, documentary, and Chinese martial arts. A-F only. 255 or consent.

title: Documentary Studies
description: In-depth study of the nature, history, and impact of documentary filmmaking traditions around the world, focusing on the interplay between filmmaker, subject, and audience. A-F only. 255 or consent.

title: Authors in Cinematic Arts
description: In-depth study of the auteur theory and specific application to authors in cinematic arts, such as film directors, animators, screenwriters, or game designers. A-F only. 255 or consent.

title: Study Abroad
description: Intensive study of selected topics, genres, filmmakers, or digital media production in the host country in a UH Manoa-approved study abroad location. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Topics in Cinematic Arts
description: Topics of study and critical inquiry in a variety of areas in the cinematic arts. Taught by regular and visiting faculty. Repeatable one time on different topics. SCA majors only. A-F only. 255 or consent.

title: Techniques in Cinematic Arts
description: Specialized techniques in the creation of digital media: taught by regular and *visiting faculty. Repeatable one time on different topics. SCA majors only. A-F only. 310, or 215 and 216.

title: Workshop in Cinematic Arts
description: Intensive workshop in focused area of cinematic arts production. Repeatable up to six credits. SCA majors only. A-F only. 310, or 215 and 216.

title: Independent Group Project
description: Participation in a group research or creative project under supervision of a faculty member. Only six credits of 399/499 in any combination can be applied to meet requirements for the major. A-F only. Repeatable up to six credits. SCA majors only. 350 and consent; and 310 or (215 and 216).
prerequisites: CINE 350 and consent; and CINE 310 or (CINE 215 and CINE 216)

title: Documentary Production
description: Analysis and practical knowledge of the documentary process including, but not limited to, research, organization and story structure, shooting, camera coverage, and editing. SCA majors only. A-F only. 310, 350, and one of the following: 312, 330, 370, 372, or 374.
prerequisites: CINE 310, CINE 350, and one of the following: CINE 312, CINE 330, CINE 370, CINE 372, or CINE 374

title: Advanced Cinematic Production
description: Production of a major cinematic/digital narrative project. Working in groups, each student takes on creative and technical role and responsibilities of a principle crew position. Emphasis on artistic form in narrative development; timely execution from - to post-production. Repeatable one time. SCA majors only. A-F only. 310; 350; and one of 312, 330, 370, 372, or 374.

title: Advanced Cinematography
description: Applies the basic foundations, techniques, and theory of cinematography (covered in CINE 312) to a more informed and crafted practice with Camera and Lighting Scene study workshops, and research exercises and film projects. SCA majors only. A-F only. 310 and 312.

title: Animation Production I
description: Students work independently to produce a short, animated film. Emphasis on visual storytelling and character animation. SCA majors only. A-F only. 317 or (321, 322, and 323); and 350.
prerequisites: CINE 317 or (CINE 321, CINE 322, and CINE 323); and CINE 350

title: Virtual and Augmented Reality Programming
description: Students will learn to develop virtual reality and augmented reality applications with turnkey tools as well as through programming. Prior programming experience is not required for this course. any 215 or ICS 110(Alpha) or ICS 111. (.
prerequisites: any CINE 215 or ICS 110(Alpha) or ICS 111

title: Animation Production II
description: Student teams produce a short, animated film. Prior knowledge of 2D and 3D media authoring tools and animation techniques is necessary. Repeatable one time. SCA majors only. A-F only. 317 or (321, 322, and 323); and 350.
prerequisites: CINE 317 or (CINE 321, CINE 322, and CINE 323); and CINE 350

title: Advanced Screenwriting
description: Application of narrative principles of character development, story structure, and thematic spine to screenplays for live action and animated short films, television, or transmedia projects. ACM majors only. A-F only. 350.

title: (Alpha) History and Film
description: Explores the many relationships between history and film including how film has reflected and shaped society in the past and our relationship to the past. (C) Europe: emphasis on writing as historians and film critics; (E) world/ comparative: significant attention paid to developing writing skills that involve critically comparing history-related cinematic representations across regions and cultures. Repeatable one time for different alphas. (C ; E Cross-listed as HIST 452E)

title: Indigenous Filmmaking
description: Theories and studies of indigenous films and creation of a cinematic project based in indigenous cultural and value systems. SCA majors only. A-F only. 310, 350, and one of the following; 312, 330, 370, 372, or 374.
prerequisites: CINE 310, CINE 350, and one of the following; CINE 312, CINE 330, CINE 370, CINE 372, or CINE 374

title: Ethics and Film
description: Ethical theory and dilemmas as reflected in film and filmmaking. Social responsibility for filmmakers. SCA majors only. A-F only. junior standing and 255.

title: Directing the Motion Picture
description: Students direct a narrative live-action short film from - through post-production, learning how to develop a directorial vision and how to implement it through storyboarding, scheduling, and collaborative skill sets. SCA majors only. 310, 350 and 370.
prerequisites: - through post-production, learning how to develop a directorial vision and how to implement it through storyboarding, scheduling, and collaborative skill sets

title: Screenwriting Capstone
description: Culmination of beginning and advanced screenwriting classes. Students will write a treatment and first act for a feature-length project or pilot script and series bible for a television project. Repeatable one time. SCA majors only. 350 and 450.

title: Oceanic Media and Culture
description: Involves close textual analysis of film, TV and multimedia content. The course includes cinematic and television screenings. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 255 or consent.

title: Data Visualization
description: Introduction to data visualization through practical techniques for turning data into images to produce insight. Topics include: information visualization, geospatial visualization, scientific visualization, social network visualization, and medical visualization. Junior standing or higher. 215 or ICS 110(Alpha) or ICS 111. (

title: Seminar in Cinematic Arts
description: Intellectual issues in cinematic arts. Conducted by regular and visiting faculty with extensive student participation and scholarly presentation. Repeatable one time on different topics. SCA majors only. A-F only. 255 and junior standing, or consent.
prerequisites: CINE 255 and junior standing, or consent

title: Capstone Creative Production
description: Emphasis on advanced production skills in creating a capstone project in live-action fiction film, animation, documentary, or new media. Screenwriting students may also develop a feature screenplay or television pilot and series bible. Repeatable one time. SCA majors only. 405 or 410 or 420 or 455 or 475.
prerequisites: CINE 405 or CINE 410 or CINE 420 or CINE 455 or CINE 475

title: Video Game Design and Development
description: Students will team design, build, and demonstrate video games or related interactive entertainment environments and applications. Topics will include emerging computer science techniques relevant to the development of these types of environments. Junior standing or higher. any 215 or ICS 110(Alpha) or ICS 111. (
prerequisites: any CINE 215 or ICS 110(Alpha) or ICS 111

title: Global Media
description: Close textual analysis and strategic analysis of global media dynamics with an emphasis on transnational media corporations. SCA majors only. A-F only. 255 or consent.

title: Cinematic Arts Internship
description: Internship in professional cinematic, television, animation and/or digital media production company under professional and faculty supervision. Repeatable up to six credits. SCA majors only. CR/NC only. 310 or (215 and 216); and 350.
prerequisites: CINE 310 or (CINE 215 and CINE 216); and CINE 350

title: Directed Study
description: Independent research or creative project under the supervision of a faculty member. Only six credits of 399/499 in any combination can be applied to meet requirements for the major. Repeatable up to six credits. SCA majors only. 310 or (215 and 216); and 350.
prerequisites: CINE 310 or (CINE 215 and CINE 216); and CINE 350

title: Foundations of the United States Air Force
description: Study of the total force structure, strategic offensive and defensive, general purpose, and aerospace support forces of the Air Force in the contemporary world. A-F only.

title: Initial Military Training I
description: Laboratory consists of activities that focus and promote the Air Force way of life. Instruction will include leadership and followership development, teamwork, physical fitness training, and activities designed to build camaraderie and esprit de corps. Course is open to all majors. CR/NC only.

title: Foundations of the United States Air Force
description: Continuation of 101. A-F only

title: Initial Military Training II
description: Laboratory consists of activities that focus and promote the Air Force way of life. Instruction will include leadership and followership development, teamwork, physical fitness training, and activities designed to build camaraderie and esprit de corps. Course is open to all majors. CR/NC only.

title: Evolution of USAF Air and Space Power
description: Study of Air Force heritage, Quality Air Force principles, ethics, and an introduction to leadership and group leadership problems. Application of written and verbal communication skills is included. A-F only.

title: Field Training Preparation I
description: Laboratory consists of preparing second-year AFROTC cadets with the skills needed to successfully complete AFROTC Field Training. Students will learn basic military skills, Field Training skills, and participate in physical fitness training. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Evolution of USAF Air and Space Power
description: Continuation of 201. A-F only.

title: Field Training Preparation II
description: Continuation of 201L. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Leadership Laboratory
description: Laboratory on the basic skills of leadership and followership. Lab includes application of leadership/followership skills, various field trips to military installations, group projects, and physical training. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 101 and 201; or consent. (Fall only)

title: Leadership Laboratory II
description: Continuation of 251L. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Sophomore standing or higher. Open to all majors. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 102 and 202. (Spring only)

title: Air Force Leadership Studies
description: Focuses on an examination of ethical Air Force leadership and management concepts. Continued emphasis is given to the refinement of ethical thought through writing and debate. A-F only.

title: Intermediate Cadet Leader I
description: Laboratory consists of demonstration of leadership and management skills needed to successfully function as an Air Force officer. Instruction will include lessons covering planning, organizational and communication skills, and the ability to use available resources to complete an assigned task. CR/NC only. must have completed AFROTC Field Training; or consent.
prerequisites: must have completed AFROTC Field Training; or consent

title: Air Force Leadership Studies II
description: Continuation of 301. Focuses on an examination of Air Force leadership and management concepts. Continued emphasis is given to the refinement of both written and oral communicative skills. A-F only. must have completed 301.

title: Intermediate Cadet Leader II
description: Continuation of 301L. CR/NC only. must have completed AFROTC Field Training; or consent.
prerequisites: must have completed AFROTC Field Training; or consent

title: National Security Affairs
description: Study of the national security process, regional studies, advanced leadership, ethics, and Air Force doctrine. Special focus placed on preparation for active duty and current issues affecting professionalism. A-F only. must have completed 301 and 302; or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: must have completed AS 301 and AS 302; or consent

title: Senior Cadet Leader I
description: Laboratory consists of providing prospective Air Force officers opportunities to continue to develop leadership, managerial, and supervisory skills. Instruction will include preparation for active duty. CR/NC only. must have completed 301 and 302L; or consent.
prerequisites: must have completed AS 301 and AS 302L; or consent

title: National Security Affairs
description: Continuation of 401. A-F only. 401 or consent.

title: Senior Cadet Leader II
description: Laboratory consists of providing prospective Air Force officers opportunities to continue to develop leadership, managerial, and supervisory skills. Instruction will include preparation for active duty. CR/NC only. must have completed 301 and 302L; or consent.
prerequisites: must have completed AS 301 and AS 302L; or consent

title: Biosystems Modeling
description: Introduction to system thinking, procedures for developing system models, characteristics of important agricultural system modes, computer approach to evaluation and optimization of system models. one of MATH 215, MATH 241, MATH 251A; or consent.
prerequisites: one of MATH 215, MATH 241, MATH 251A; or consent

title: Econometrics I
description: Review of probability, estimation, small sample and asymptotic properties. Bivariate and multiple regression and matrix algebra formulation. Regression diagnostics. Introduction to heteroskedastidity, autocorrelation, simultaneity, dichotomous variables, advanced topics. NREM 310 or ECON 321, and MATH 241; or consent.
prerequisites: NREM 310 or ECON 321, and MATH 241; or consent

title: Econometrics II
description: Specification, statistical estimation, inference, and forecasting of economic models. Includes advanced topics for single-equation models, pooled models, qualitative dependent variables, simultaneous systems, distributed lags, and time series. 626 and ECON 628, or consent. (

title: Elementary American Sign Language I
description: Development of basic receptive and expressive conversational skills in American Sign Language; linguistic structure introduced inductively through mix of lectures and discussion; includes discussion of history and culture of Deaf community in the U.S.

title: Elementary American Sign Language II
description: Continued development of basic receptive and expressive conversational skills in American Sign Language; linguistic structure introduced inductively through mix of lectures and discussion; discussion of history and culture of Deaf community in the U.S. 101 (or equivalent).

title: Intermediate American Sign Language I
description: Continued development of receptive and expressive conversational skills in American Sign Language; linguistic structure introduced inductively through mix of lectures and discussion; includes discussion of history and culture of Deaf community in the U.S. 102 (or equivalent).

title: Intermediate American Sign Language II
description: Continued development of receptive and expressive conversational skills in American Sign Language; linguistic structure introduced inductively through mix of lectures and discussion; includes discussion of history and culture of Deaf community in the U.S. 201.

title: Advanced American Sign Language I
description: Development of advanced receptive and expressive conversational skills in American Sign Language (ASL). 202. (Fall only)

title: Advanced American Sign Language II
description: Development of advanced receptive and expressive conversational skills in American Sign Language (ASL). 301. (Spring only)

title: Introduction to American Studies
description: Introduction to different types of college-level writing through analyses of contemporary American culture and to the main themes and approaches used in American studies and the humanities.

title: Introduction to American Studies Writing
description: Introduction to different types of college level writing and information literacy with a focus on American culture and society. A-F only.

title: America and the World
description: Examines America’s role in world history and the influence of world affairs on U.S. culture and society. Focuses on U.S. interdependence with African, European, Native American, Asian, and Polynesian civilizations, from 1492 to present.

title: America and the World
description: Examines America’s role in world history and the influence of world affairs on U.S. culture and society. Focuses on U.S. interdependence with African, European, Native American, Asian, and Polynesian civilizations, from 1492 to present.

title: American Experience: Institutions and Movements
description: Emergence and transformation of laws, ideologies, institutions, and social movements from the 17th-21st centuries. Emphasis on relationships among structures of power, representational practices, belief systems, and social action. Writing emphasis, interdisciplinary perspectives. DH

title: American Experience: Culture and the Arts
description: Literature and modern media; visual and performing arts; material culture and architecture; foodways and ritual as meaning-making processes that have shaped the diverse identities, spaces, and communities of the Americas. Writing emphasis, interdisciplinary perspectives. DH

title: American Experience: Culture and the Arts
description: Literature and modern media; visual and performing arts; material culture and architecture; foodways and ritual as meaning-making processes that have shaped the diverse identities, spaces, and communities of the Americas. Writing emphasis, interdisciplinary perspectives.

title: Contemporary American Domestic Issues
description: Current debates in the U.S. over individual rights and nationalism; civil rights, citizenship, and sovereignty; sexuality, law, and religion; economic, racial, and gender equality; public health and environmental justice. Writing emphasis, interdisciplinary perspectives.

title: Contemporary American Global Issues
description: Interdisciplinary and transnational perspectives on global issues including international law and diplomacy; war, diaspora, and refugees; economic underdevelopment and environmental racism; globalization, race, and the feminization of poverty. Writing emphasis

title: Introduction to Indigenous Studies
description: Interdisciplinary survey that examines the histories, politics, popular representations, self-representations, and contemporary issues of the indigenous peoples of the U.S. and its territories, including Native Americans, Alaska Natives, Kanaka Maoli, Chamorro, and Samoans.

title: Introduction to Indigenous Studies
description: Interdisciplinary survey that examines the histories, politics, popular representations, self-representations, and contemporary issues of the indigenous peoples of the U.S. and its territories, including Native Americans, Alaska Natives, Kanaka Maoli, Chamorro, and Samoans.

title: Art and Social Change
description: Will analyze examples from the visual and performing arts, including murals, digital art, film, poetry, and music, paying particular attention to the connections and influence upon social and political movements, both historically and today. A-F only

title: Hip-Hop and American Culture
description: Survey tracing hip-hop from its Afro-Carribean musical beginnings to contemporary adaptations and interpretations. Students will analyze various materials and will pay attention to the relationships between hip-hop and contemporary social forms. sophomore standing or consent.

title: Justice and Asian America: Social Movements and the Law in American History
description: Examination of demands for and the changing nature of justice, historical and contemporary, through court cases, legislation, presidential orders, and social movements that address legal, social, and political definitions of Asian America. Sophomore standing or higher

title: Japanese Americans: History, Culture, Lifestyles
description: Explores experiences of Japanese Americans in Hawaiʻi and the U.S.: historical and cultural heritage, biographical portraits, changing family ties, ethnic lifeways, gender relations, local identity, and the future of island living. Emphasis: oral communication skills. DH

title: African Americans: Issues, Culture, History
description: Traces the history and culture of African Americans and outlines contemporary issues. Topics include: slavery and racism, community formation and resistance, cultural expression, African American diversity, civil rights, gender and class relations.

title: U.S. Women’s History
description: History of U.S. women and gender relations. Topics include women’s work in and outside the household, women’s involvement in social movements, changing norms about gender and sexuality, and shared and divergent experiences among women. (

title: American Music and Culture
description: Analysis of a variety of American musical genres and histories through focused writing assignments (record and performance reviews, personal narratives, interviews, research proposals, research papers). second year standing or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Asian America
description: History of selected Asian immigrant groups from the 19th century to the present. Topics include: immigration and labor history, Asian American movements, literature and cultural productions, community adaptations and identity formation. junior standing or higher. (

title: America, Hawai‘i and World War II
description: Examines WWII as a watershed in American and Hawai‘i history and culture. Topics include: Pearl Harbor, Japanese American internment, sex and racial tensions, Anti-Semitism and the Holocaust, and the dawn of the Atomic Age.

title: American Environments: Survey
description: Survey of social, political, and cultural relations in diverse, contemporary American environments, including: island societies, urban centers, suburbs, Indian reservations, farming communities, and national parks. Special emphasis on contemporary environmental issues in Hawai‘i.

title: Religion and Law in the U.S.
description: Surveys church-state jurisprudence since the 1940s, with special attention to difficulty of defining religion, and applies the religion clauses to current issues. A-F only. Sophomore standing or higher. consent. (Once a year) (

title: American Folklore and Folklife
description: Examination of the history and ethics of folklore studies and the dynamics and social functions of traditional culture in diverse communities through topics such as ritual, storytelling, games, gossip, belief, music, and cultural tourism. Junior standing or higher. (

title: Digital America: Online Communities and Virtual Worlds
description: Seminar on the impact of the digital revolution and virtual communities on American culture and society, with an emphasis on questions of identity and participatory democracy. Open to non majors. one DH, DA, or DL course, sophomore standing, or consent.
prerequisites: one DH, DA, or DL course, sophomore standing, or consent

title: Religions in America
description: Examination of American religious traditions, both historical and contemporary, with an emphasis on the principles of religious liberty, non-establishment, and pluralism. sophomore standing or consent.

title: War and Media
description: Examination of a range of media, including photography, film, print journalism, television, video games, and the internet, as they have shaped popular representations and experiences of war in America from the Civil War through the present. A-F only. (Alt. years)

title: American Thought and Culture: To 20th Century
description: Politics, family, philosophy, technology, etc.; their interrelationship with the total society. -Colonial to end of Reconstruction. (

title: American Thought and Culture: 20th Century
description: Continuation of 343: 20th century. 150 or 201 or 202 or 211 or 212 or HIST 151 or HIST 152; or consent. (
prerequisites: AMST 150 or AMST 201 or AMST 202 or AMST 211 or AMST 212 or HIST 151 or HIST 152; or consent

title: Religion and Conflict in American History
description: Analyzes selected historical examples of religious conflicts in America, discerning characteristic patterns of American religious discourse, and identifying the social structures, interests, and ethical principles at stake in conflicts about religion. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: American Design: An Historical Survey
description: Examination of design in American culture over the last century. Readings in industrial, graphic, interior, architectural, landscape, and user interface design used to study issues of gender, race, and class in the U.S. Open to all class standings. A-F only. (Alt. years)

title: Contemporary American Design
description: Investigates design in contemporary American culture. Graphic, industrial, urban, and user-interface design practices are situated within broader social and economic forces. Modes of design practice, production, and consumption studied as reflection of American society today. Open to all class standings. A-F only. (Alt. years)

title: Culture and the Arts in America
description: Study of the role of the arts in American society and diverse cultural practices in historical and contemporary contexts.

title: Screening Asian Americans
description: Survey of Asian and Asian American representations in American film and television from the silent era to the present, with an emphasis on Orientalism and multiculturalism, as well as performance and spectatorship. SCA majors: A-F only. junior standing or consent. (

title: Indigenous Lands and Waters
description: Examines indigenous practices born of and located in Indigenous places. Analyzes how indigenous knowledge of place informs Indigenous cultural, linguistic, intellectual, and political survivance and sovereignty, and resistance.

title: American Travel Writing
description: Survey examines the roles that travel writing plays in American identity- and nation-formation, from early colonial history to the present. A-F only. 110, 150, 201, 202, 211, or 212. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: AMST 110, AMST 150, AMST 201, AMST 202, AMST 211, or AMST 212

title: American Cinema
description: Introductory history of American cinema from the silent to the digital era, with an emphasis on criticism, genre and style, as well as cultural and sociopolitical context.

title: American Empire
description: Examines the interplay between an “American culture of empire” and the rise of the U.S. as a superpower. Topics: imperialism and political culture, social movements and international affairs, race, gender and class relations. (

title: Filipino Americans: History, Culture and Politics
description: An introduction to the study of Filipino Americans in the U.S. and the diaspora. The course pays special attention to labor migration, cultural production and community politics. sophomore standing. (

title: Critical Research Methods
description: Overview of methods and methodologies drawn from various fields (including history, politics, literature, art, law and race, Indigenous, gender, and sexuality studies) for conducting interdisciplinary research. Models of writing from AMST faculty; emphasis on writing.

title: Filipino Americans: Research Topics
description: A research seminar on the study of Filipino Americans. Special themes in film/video/media, the performing arts, or literature may be offered. junior standing or consent. (

title: Indigenous Literature and Film
description: Interdisciplinary, comparative course examining native literary texts (novels, short fiction, poetry), films, etc. that address issues of representation and how native peoples actively resist colonial ideology.

title: Asian American Music Cultures
description: An exploration of how Asian American music making is related to community formation, labor migration, and cultural sensibilities throughout the 20th century.

title: Japanese Americans: Research Topics
description: Research and thematic seminar on Japanese American culture, issues, and history. junior standing or consent.

title: Regionalism: The South
description: Definition of a Southern identity and its relation to the larger U.S. culture, using literary and polemical works of 19th- and 20th-century.

title: Hawai‘i’s Multiculturalism
description: A multidisciplinary examination of the dynamics of the Hawaiian Islands’ racial and cultural diversity from the perspectives of historical trends, social processes, and contemporary political, social, and economic issues as they impact interracial relations.

title: American Ideas of Nature
description: The natural world in American thought from Native Americans to modern ecologists.

title: History of American Architecture
description: History of American architecture in terms of style, techniques, and symbolic meaning. (

title: American Environmental History
description: Survey history of the complex relations between American societies and diverse U.S. ecosystems, from European contact and colonization to the present. (

title: History of American Workers
description: Conditions of labor in major phases of American development; response of labor and community to changing work environment. Capitalism, unionism, race, gender, law, etc. Emphasis on 20th century. (

title: Slavery and Freedom
description: Examines the history of slavery, race, and abolition in the Americas from a comparative, global perspective, and traces the legacy of slavery in the post-emancipation societies of the New World. (

title: Islands, Empires, and the Arts
description: Colonialism, neocolonialism, and cultures of resistance in the Caribbean and its North American diaspora through literature, film, and the arts. Focus on political dissent; nation building; historical memory; construction of gender, race. Writing emphasis. Junior standing or higher. A-F only

title: Politics in Hawai‘i
description: Discussion of modern politics against the background of recent history and major contemporary issues.

title: History of Crime and Punishment
description: History of American crime and punishment from 18th century to the present. Topics: changing crime patterns, evolving punishment methods, penal reform movements, convict resistance, growth of prison industrial complex, racism, class, and gender. junior standing or consent.

title: Gender, Justice and Law
description: Exploration of landmark U.S. Supreme Court cases related to sex and gender. Topics may include sex discrimination, sexual orientation discrimination, privacy, and reproductive freedom. A-F only. one of WGSS 151, WGSS 175, WGSS 176, WGSS 202, WGSS 360, WGSS 381, or consent. (
prerequisites: one of WGSS 151, WGSS 175, WGSS 176, WGSS 202, WGSS 360, WGSS 381, or consent

title: Trans* Studies: Trans(feminine/ masculine/gender nonconforming/sexual)
description: Focus on various aspects of Trans* identities, biographies, cultural productions, and communities. It also addresses issues on racism, medical intervention, dating, societal condemnation, mental health, and incarceration. Junior standing or higher. (

title: Women and Globalization in Asia
description: History, culture, and contemporary reality of Asian women in Asia and the U.S. Includes critical analysis of American feminist methodology and theory. one of 310, 316, 318, 373, 455, POLS 339, WGSS 360, WGSS 361, WGSS 439; or consent. (
prerequisites: one of AMST 310, AMST 316, AMST 318, AMST 373, AMST 455, POLS 339, WGSS 360, WGSS 361, WGSS 439; or consent

title: Race and Racism in America
description: Racial ideas and ideologies, and their effects throughout American history. (

title: Social Movements
description: Examination of mass mobilization in U.S. history from the Revolution forward, including abolitionism, feminism, civil rights, labor, and more. Concludes with analysis of various community organizing efforts today.

title: Racism, American Culture and Film/ Media
description: An exploration of the critique of racial ideologies in American film. The course also examines how aggrieved communities develop cultural sensibilities, aesthetic choices and politicized identities through film, video and media work.

title: Gender in Action Cinema
description: Investigates gender representation in the evolving genre of American action cinema through combined stylistic and cultural analysis, with special attention to the relationship of gendered action to categories of morality, race, class, and nation. Junior standing or consent. (

title: Food, Culture, and Empire
description: Examines the cultural, historical, and political processes that have informed our understandings and practices involving food. We will analyze food and foodways in the U.S. and Hawai‘i. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. at least one course in WGSS or ES; or consent by instructor. (
prerequisites: at least one course in WGSS or ES; or consent by instructor

title: Victims, Virtue, and Violence
description: Examination of the history and significance of melodrama as a dominant mode of American cultural production from the early republic to the present, with a focus on issues of race, gender, and national identity.

title: Popular Culture
description: Major themes, modes, and media of popular or mass culture in the U.S.; emphasis on cultural trends and social implications.

title: The ’20s and ’30s
description: Novelists, painters, poets, jazz musicians as examples of culture of the 1920s and 1930s in America.

title: Culture, Society, and Literature
description: Literary and non-fictive exploration of the intellectual and moral response of Americans to institutions and culture of 20th-century marketplace economy.

title: Fashioning America
description: Examines linkages between American identity, representation, labor and capital through fashion theory, clothing discourses and other practices of textile production over history. junior standing or consent.

title: U.S. Women’s Literature and Culture
description: Reading of selected works of U.S. women’s literature and cultural texts (such as art and film). Emphasis on historical and cultural context and diverse expressions of women’s gendered identities. (

title: Art of the United States
description: Emphasis on the 18th and 19th centuries. 202 or ART 176, or consent. (

title: Museum Interpretations
description: Studies the interpretive strategies and methods used by museums to communicate with visitors in museums, art galleries, historic sites, parks, and related places. Considers how interpretations contribute to cultural knowledge. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Film in American Culture
description: Comprehensive survey of varieties of film experience from historical and contemporary points of view.

title: Sports in America
description: Sports as reflected in literature, films, and TV. Focus on ethical dimensions of sports and sporting cultures; writing emphasis.

title: Early 20th Century American Art
description: American art in the first half of the 20th century and its impact on American culture. Junior standing or higher. ART 176 or consent. (Alt. years: fall) (

title: America’s World Role
description: Examination of America’s role in modern world affairs, against the background of history, perceptions, and values.

title: America and Africa
description: American attitudes toward Africa, as well as how Africa has functioned within the dynamics of American culture and history.

title: American Experience in Asia
description: Examination of various forms of U.S. engagement with Asia, with particular attention to the role of Hawai‘i as the site, agent, and object of engagement. Emphasis on developing critical reading and expository writing skills.

title: Religion, Sex, and Gender in the U.S.
description: Examines religious and ethical conflicts about sexuality and gender nonconformity in contemporary America. Students gain knowledge, practical wisdom, and communication skills to negotiate moral disagreement in a pluralistic society. junior standing or consent.

title: Preservation: Hawai‘i, Asia, and the Pacific
description: Lectures and discussions on historic preservation issues in Hawai‘i, Asia, and the Pacific. Emphasis on indigenous and national expressions. junior standing or consent. (

title: Documentation of Historic Architecture
description: Study and documentation of existing buildings, structures, sites of historic and/or cultural significance, including field measurements and drawings, historical research, photo documentation, and preparation of archival drawings to be deposited in the Library of Congress. Documentation conducted according to standards of the Historic American Buildings Survey/ Historic American Engineering Record (HABS/ HAER). Repeatable three times, up to 24 credits. AMST, ARCH, and HIS majors only. consent. (

title: Senior Capstone Project
description: Capstone course for American studies students to undertake a major research-based project. AMST majors only. consent.

title: World Maritime History
description: Survey of world maritime history from earliest times to the present, with emphasis on the evolution of nautical technology, motives from maritime enterprises, and the impact of cross-cultural encounters between oceanic peoples. (

title: (Alpha) Topics in American Studies
description: Themes, problems, and issues not addressed in other American studies undergraduate courses, focused within these areas: (B) social structure and interaction; (D) arts and environment. Repeatable one time. junior standing or consent for (D).

title: Readings in American Studies
description: Directed readings and research for majors. consent.

title: Approaches to American Studies
description: Introductory survey of methodological issues underlying research in American studies.

title: Patterns of American Cultures
description: American cultural origins and development.

title: Advanced Research and Professional Development
description: Prepares advanced graduate students to present original research findings to colleagues, write for peer review, design undergraduate classes in their areas of expertise, and participate actively in their fields. Graduate students only. A-F only. (600 and 601) with a minimum grade of B-.
prerequisites: (AMST 600 and AMST 601) with a minimum grade of B-

title: Early America
description: Interdisciplinary approach to understanding early American culture and history. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Asian America
description: The Asian American experience from an interdisciplinary and humanities perspective. Asian American history, literature, media, and theater arts. Comparative study of Hawai‘i and the Continental U.S.

title: Women in American Culture
description: Historical/contemporary status of women in the U.S.; women’s roles as defined by legal, educational, political, economic, and social institutions; implications for social science method. (

title: Advanced Topics: American West
description: Examination of the U.S. colonization of the American West. Topics include: European-indigenous relations, migration and labor, regional literature, frontier ideology, ethnic conflict, and new community formation. A-F only. graduate standing and consent. (

title: Performance, Culture, and Theory
description: Survey of major critical works in fields of performing arts and public culture (e.g., dance, theater, music, commemoration). Topics include: theoretical application for the discipline of American studies, and the impact of social movements and labor migration on the performing arts. (

title: Gender and the African Diaspora in the Americas
description: Explores the impact of the African Diaspora on the cultures and histories of the Americas through interdisciplinary and feminist scholarship and cultural sources including fiction, foodways, film, poetry, religion, music, and dance. A-F only. Graduate standing only. (

title: Social and Cultural Diversity in America
description: Examination of selected subcultures in America.

title: American Sexualities
description: Aspects of sexual identity within the context of American culture.

title: Slavery and Modern Memory
description: Exploration of contemporary resonances of slavery in the Americas through literature, historical scholarship, memory and trauma studies, and the visual and performing arts. Graduate students only. A-F only. (

title: Indigenous Identity
description: Interdisciplinary and comparative focus on how Indigenous identity is constructed, negotiated, asserted, ascribed, and deconstructed within and without Indigenous communities with attention to the U.S. Graduate students only. graduate level standing or higher.

title: American Architecture
description: Cultural analysis of the evolution of American architecture from the Colonial period to the present involving sociopolitical and economic, as well as aesthetic, considerations. (

title: Wilderness in America
description: American wilderness as both physical setting and social construction. A-F only. graduate standing or consent

title: Material Culture
description: Physical artifacts considered as documents of American cultural and regional development.

title: Environment and Society
description: Technological development in cultural perspective; its relation to the American environment, science, capitalism, public policy, and values.

title: Mass Media
description: Appraisal of major media of communications in American society with attention to political, educational, cultural, and ethical implications.

title: Technologies of War and Media
description: Critical examination of the relationship between war and media with particular attention to the overlapping histories of technologies of perception and destruction in the modern era and to the military-entertainment complex today. Graduate students only or consent.

title: Public History and Commemoration
description: Approaches to public presentations of history and examination of various ways in which historic memory is constructed in sites such as museums, memorials, and theme parks.

title: American Punishment
description: Examines the history of American criminal punishment, from the birth of the penitentiary to the rise of the prison-industrial complex. A-F only. Graduate students only. (

title: Writing for Publication
description: Advanced seminar designed to convert graduate research projects into publishable scholarly articles. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Revolutions and Social Movements
description: Examines the role of social movements in transforming American society and culture.

title: Historic Preservation
description: Federal, state, and local laws and regulations that regulate and provide protection to significant archaeological and historical resources in Hawai‘i and the region. (Alt. years: spring only) (

title: Advanced Topics: Social/Cultural/ Intellectual
description: Readings and research on American social and intellectual history. Repeatable one time. graduate standing and consent. (

title: Advanced Topics: Business/Labor/ Technology
description: Readings and research on American business, labor, and technological history. Repeatable one time. graduate standing and consent.

title: American Intellectual Traditions
description: Examination of intellectual figures and movements in American history.

title: Field Mastery
description: Prepares students to achieve specialization in an American Studies-related academic field. Repeatable two times with different contents. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Film in America
description: Examination of various roles of motion picture film in America with particular respect to art form, cultural artifact, document, and myth.

title: Arts in America: Modern to PostModern
description: Survey of the literature of the field.

title: Transpacific Studies
description: Critical analysis of regional formation in and across the Pacific and the role of the U.S. therein; migrations within and across the Pacific; political, military, economic, cultural, and environmental dynamics of transpacific exchanges.

title: Globalization and Transnationalism
description: Examines the socioeconomic and cultural meanings of globalization and transnationalism. Emphasis on how the deployment and flows of power beyond the nation-state have an impact on regional, national, and/ or local communities and cultures.

title: Advanced Topics: America and the World
description: Historical and contemporary issues in America’s global relationships.

title: Comparative Methods in American Studies
description: Examines approaches to American studies that use comparison as a primary method. Comparison of histories, institutions, of phenomena between the U.S. and another country as well as among communities in the U.S. Graduate standing only. Co-requisite: 600 or 601 or 602, or consent. (Every 2-3 years)

title: Indigenous Curation and Museums: Practice Meets Theory
description: Seminar explores the history, evolution, and contemporary movement towards indigenous curation within museums, emphasis on the Americas and Oceania, as shaped by colonialism, globalization, multiculturalism, selfdetermination, and nationalism. (Fall only)

title: 20th Century U.S. Literature
description: Selected works of 20th-century literature as cultural documents.

title: African American Literature
description: Cultural and social imagination of blacks and whites as revealed in literature, poetry, and drama.

title: Elements of Style
description: The manifestations, visual characteristics, and social/cultural meaning of “style” in American architecture and decorative arts from the early settlement period through the present. (

title: Historic Building Technology
description: History of buildings, building technologies, materials, and finishes, including construction techniques and methods of investigating older buildings. Emphasis on North American building practices c.1600–c.1960. (

title: Vernacular Architecture
description: Methods and approaches in the study of vernacular architecture, cultural landscapes, and material culture, with an emphasis on traditions and innovations in the Americas. (

title: Museums: Theory, History, Practice
description: History and theory of museums and related institutions (art galleries, historic houses, zoos, parks). Relationship between museums, collections, and communities. Introduction to governance, planning, legal, and ethical concerns.

title: Museums and Collections
description: Work of museums and professionals (registrars, collections managers, conservators, curators and others) in the care of collections, interpretive studies of museum displays; field trips. 683 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Museums and Education
description: Overview of museum education including museum learning theories, informal learning programs, audience research, national and international policies and reports, and community projects. 683 (or concurrent) or consent. (

title: Museum Studies Practicum
description: Applies coursework in museum studies to hands-on activities under the direction of practicing professionals and university faculty. Museum studies certificate students only. A-F only. consent.

title: Indigenous Studies Practicum
description: Applies course work in Indigenous studies to hands-on activities under the direction of practicing professionals and university faculty. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Research Seminar
description: Themes, problems, and issues not addressed in other American studies graduate courses; emphasis upon research methods. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Directed Reading/Research

title: (Alpha) Unit VII Anatomy Electives
description: Advanced study of human anatomy by dissection and individual observation of surgical procedures. (C) topics in reproductive biology. Repeatable two times. CR/NC only. FMCH, MED, OBGN, PED, PSTY, SURG 531 or 532; or consent.
prerequisites: FMCH, MED, OBGN, PED, PSTY, SURG 531 or SURG 532; or consent

title: Independent Study in Anatomy
description: Elective course for advanced medical students. (B) human gross anatomy; (C) histology; (D) research in anatomy and developmental biology. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. consent for (B) and (C); MDED 551 for (D).

title: Lower Extremity, Thorax, and Abdomen
description: Human gross anatomy dissection of the lower extremity, thorax, and abdomen. Emphasis is placed on muscles, function, innervation, and vascular supply. Repeatable one time. Enrolled in DRB or KRS graduate programs (including Biomed Sci-Anat/ RepoBiol & Phys majors) only or consent. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Upper Extremity, Head, Neck, and Spine
description: Human gross anatomy dissection of the upper extremity, head, neck, and spine. Emphasis is placed on muscles, function, innervation, and vascular supply. Repeatable one time. Enrolled in DRB or KRS graduate programs (including Biomed Sci-Anat/ RepoBiol & Phys majors) only or consent. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Human Embryology
description: Systematic study of human development, including implantation, placentation, basics of development of each organ system with reference to pertinent congenital anomalies and their surgical repair. 603 or 604. Recommended: gross anatomy course.

title: Seminar in Anatomy Teaching
description: Effective teaching methods, organization of courses in anatomical sciences, development and evaluation of exams, experience in teaching with audiovisual/ computer aids. Open to graduate students in physiology or KRS. CR/NC only. Repeatable eight times, up to 32 credits. 603 and 604.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. admission to candidacy (master’s program).

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Fundamentals of Biochemistry
description: Biological chemistry stressing integration of concepts of general, inorganic, and biochemistry and application to life chemistry. beginning algebra and high school science.
prerequisites: beginning algebra and high school science

title: Elements of Biochemistry
description: Biochemical principles and concepts as applied to living systems, including sufficient organic chemistry to understand these principles. 141 with C or better, or consent.
prerequisites: BIOC 141 with C or better, or consent

title: Basic Biochemistry
description: Principles of biochemistry, applicable to medicine and real-life situations, involving metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids, and vitamins. Taught by biomedical researchers. Evaluated based on exams, quizzes, homework, and group presentation.

title: Directed Research and Reading
description: Independent research or selected reading of current literature in the area of biochemistry and biophysics. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Topics in Biochemistry
description: Fourth-year elective in which medical students take an in-depth study of selected topics in biochemistry. fourthyear medical student or consent.

title: Highlights of Organ-System Biochemistry
description: Provides highly interactive, small group discussions on concepts of biochemistry important to the various organ systems; such as cardiac, respiratory, hematology, gastrointestinal, endocrine, musculoskeletal and neurological systems, and relevant to clinical medicine. MD majors only. CR/NC only. MDED 554. (Fall only)

title: Human Physiology and Anatomy
description: Introduction to human physiology and anatomy designed to serve the needs of dental hygiene students and others interested in pursuing health-related careers.

title: Physiology and Anatomy Lab
description: Laboratory to complement 103. Co-requisite: 103.

title: Human Anatomy and Physiology
description: Anatomy, histology, physiology, biochemistry, genetics of human organ systems presented in integrated anatomy-physiology format. Priority to students in nursing. high school chemistry.

title: Human Anatomy and Physiology Lab
description: Anatomy, histology, physiology, biochemistry, genetics of human organ systems presented in integrated anatomy-physiology format. Priority to students in nursing. 141 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Human Anatomy and Physiology
description: Continuation of 141. should have an understanding of basic physiology concepts as presented in 141 or equivalent.
prerequisites: should have an understanding of basic physiology concepts as presented in PHYL 141 or equivalent

title: Human Anatomy and Physiology Lab
description: Anatomy, histology, physiology, biochemistry, genetics of human organ systems presented in integrated anatomy-physiology format. Priority to students in nursing. 142 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Advanced Anatomy and Physiology
description: Integrated presentation of human anatomy and physiology. An optional laboratory (PHYL 301L) is available separately. BIOL 171 and BIOL 172, or any PHYL course; and CHEM 161 (or higher) or any BIOC course; or consent.
prerequisites: BIOL 171 and BIOL 172, or any PHYL course; and CHEM 161 (or higher) or any BIOC course; or consent

title: Human Anatomy and Physiology Lab
description: Laboratory study of human anatomy and physiology by means of models, histology slides, experiments, and demonstrations. Co-requisite: 301 or consent.

title: Advanced Anatomy and Physiology
description: Continuation of 301. 301/301L or consent.

title: Human Anatomy and Physiology Lab
description: Continuation of 301L. 301/301L, or consent. Co-requisite: 302.

title: Human Physiology: Organ Systems
description: Basic function of the major organ systems in man. Covers cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, acid-base, and gastrointestinal physiology. 302 or equivalent with consent.

title: Human Physiology: Integrative Systems
description: Senior-level course in integrative systems (central nervous system and endocrinology). Complements 401. 401 and either BIOC 341 or CHEM 152, or consent.
prerequisites: PHYL 401 and either BIOC 341 or CHEM 152, or consent

title: Directed Reading or Research
description: Students will learn fundamental concepts and multiple techniques in molecular biology, physiology, and histology for cardiovascular research through the projects in the lab. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned to two credits only. Junior or senior standing only. CR/NC only.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Biomedical Sciences
description: Presentation and discussion of current research topics in biomedical sciences. Repeatable nine times. consent. (

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. admission to candidacy (master’s program).

title: Special Topics in Reproductive Biology
description: In-depth discussion of selected areas of reproductive biology, with special emphasis on recent research results and methodologies. May be retaken for credit. consent.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. admission to candidacy (PhD program).

title: Humans, Animals, and Agriculture
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to animal agriculture, animal science, and the use of animals by humans. Ethics and importance of human use of animals in agriculture are emphasized.

title: Principles and Practices of Animal Science
description: Biology, behavior, and management of animals of economic and social importance. Topics include physiology, genetics, nutrition, reproduction, behavior, care, and management to achieve productivity, performance, and welfare. (lecture, discussion, and field trips)

title: Comparative Nutrition
description: Digestive systems and nutrient functions, interrelationships and metabolism are compared among animal species, including humans. An intermediate, general nutrition course for Food Science and Human Nutrition and Animal Science majors. (200 (or concurrent), CHEM 161/161L or higher) with a minimum grade of C. (
prerequisites: (ANSC 200 (or concurrent), CHEM 161/CHEM 161L or higher) with a minimum grade of C

title: Anatomy of Domestic Animals
description: Micro and gross anatomical arrangements of tissues and organ systems of domestic animals. 200 (or concurrent) with a minimum grade of C. Co-requisite: 301L.
prerequisites: ANSC 200 (or concurrent) with a minimum grade of C

title: Domestic Animal Anatomy Laboratory
description: Laboratory to accompany 301, with an emphasis on teaching scientific and technical writing. Dissection and identification of anatomical arrangements of tissues and organ systems of domestic animals. A-F only. 200 (or concurrent) with a minimum grade of C. Corequisite: 301. (Fall only)
prerequisites: ANSC 200 (or concurrent) with a minimum grade of C

title: Applied Animal Nutrition
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Application of the principles of nutrition to feeding of farm animals; composition and nutritional value of feed stuffs; nutritional requirements of beef cattle, dairy cattle, horses, poultry, and swine. (201 (or concurrent), and 244 or FSHN 244) with a minimum grade of C.
prerequisites: (ANSC 201 (or concurrent), and ANSC 244 or FSHN 244) with a minimum grade of C

title: Humans, Food, and Animals: Ethics, Issues, and Controversies
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Ethical issues and other controversies related to human and animal needs; their impact on resource sustainability and quality of life are explored from scientific perspectives. A-F only. 200 or 201 or FSHN 181 or FSHN 185. (
prerequisites: ANSC 200 or ANSC 201 or FSHN 181 or FSHN 185

title: Horses and Horsemanship
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Origin of species, breeds, nutrition, care, management. Lab on management practices with work on light horses. 200, or 201 (or concurrent).

title: Laboratory Skills in Animal Science
description: Provides students with basic and essential laboratory skills required in various fields of animal science such as nutrition, genetics, reproductive physiology, meat science, clinical pathology, parasitology, and animal handling.
