ANSC majors only. A-F only. (200 or 201, and BIOL 171 and 171L and CHEM 161) with a minimum grade of D-. (Fall only)
prerequisites: (ANSC 200 or ANSC 201, and BIOL 171 and BIOL 171L and CHEM 161) with a minimum grade of D-

title: Poultry Production
description: Students will learn about poultry health and hygiene, husbandry, production, biosecurity, hands-on skills, and recent advances in poultry farming systems for meat and egg production. ANSC majors only. Junior standing or higher. 301 or 445.

title: Beef Production
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of economic beef production, including beef breeds, selection, breeding, management systems, feeding, and marketing under tropical conditions. 321 and 445.

title: Swine Production
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of efficient pork production, including comparative breed evaluation, breeding, feeding, management, marketing, and business aspects. Problems and practices associated with tropical environment emphasized. 321 and 445.

title: Tropical Dairying
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles involved in economical milk production in the tropics, including management, recordkeeping, breeds, breeding, selection, culling, feeding, housing, milking, quality control, and raising young animals. 321 and 445.

title: Genetics and Animal Breeding
description: Review and application of genetic principles to livestock, poultry, companion, aquatic, and laboratory research animals. Current practices and future developments. (BIOL 171/171L or ZOOL 101/101L, and MATH 140X or higher) with a minimum grade of C. Recommended: biochemistry and genetics or equivalent.
prerequisites: (BIOL 171/BIOL 171L or ZOOL 101/ZOOL 101L, and MATH 140X or higher) with a minimum grade of C

title: Genes and Animal Biology
description: An understanding of animal biology at the level of genes and their regulations; emphasis on gene structure, recombinant DNA, transgenic animals and functional genomics being used for agricultural, nutritional and biomedical sciences. Open to nonmajors. A-F only. (301, BIOL 171 or ZOOL 101) with a minimum grade of C; or consent.
prerequisites: (ANSC 301, BIOL 171 or ZOOL 101) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Aquaculture Production
description: Theory and practice of aquaculture: reproduction, yield trials, management, economics and business case studies of fish, crustaceans, and molluscs. Field classes held at commercial farm and hatchery. 321 and 445: or BIOL 172/L and CHEM 162/L or higher.
prerequisites: ANSC 321 and ANSC 445: or BIOL 172/L and CHEM 162/L or higher

title: Physiology of Domestic Animals
description: Functions and relationships of organs and organ systems of domestic animals excluding reproduction and lactation. Problem-based learning and case studies are emphasized. 301 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent.
prerequisites: ANSC 301 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent

title: Animal Diseases and Their Control
description: Disease problems of livestock, poultry, and companion animals; their economic significance, causes, public health implications, and control. 200 (or concurrent), and BIOL 171/L or ZOOL 101/L.
prerequisites: ANSC 200 (or concurrent), and BIOL 171/L or ZOOL 101/L

title: Meat Science and Muscle Biology
description: Development, growth, function, carcass evaluation of muscle tissue. 301 (or concurrent).

title: Meat Science and Muscle Biology Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Livestock and poultry slaughter, carcass evaluation, meat chemistry, muscle physiology and biochemistry, meat microbiology, and meat processing. 454 (or concurrent).

title: Companion Animals and Society
description: Explore human and companion animal relationships in biological, social, cultural, economic, legal, health, and welfare contexts to prepare students for careers in the various animal-related fields in Hawai‘i, the Pacific rim, and worldwide. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. BIOL 171 (with a minimum grade of C), or consent.
prerequisites: BIOL 171 (with a minimum grade of C), or consent

title: Biology and Culture of Shrimp and Prawns
description: Aspects of the biology and culture of the freshwater prawn Macrobrachium rosenbergii and marine shrimp Penaeus (sp) species. Scientific research results and case studies presented and analyzed. 450 or consent.

title: Reproduction and Artificial Insemination
description: Introductory exploration of anatomy, development, and physiology of reproduction of domestic animals and artificial insemination. Repeatable one time. 301 (with a minimum grade of C).
prerequisites: ANSC 301 (with a minimum grade of C)

title: Reproduction and Artificial Insemination Lab
description: Reproductive anatomy and physiology of domestic animals, estorus synchronization, breeding soundness, and artificial insemination laboratory, field trips. One week offisland field trip. Repeatable one time. ANSC majors or consent. 301 and 462.

title: Aquaculture Production Laboratory
description: Intensive, hands-on course involving the culture of larvae and juveniles of marine shrimp, freshwater prawns, molluscs, fish, and their food. Must have strong interest in hands-on rearing and flexible time for continuous live animal care. Lab fee required.

title: Comparative Endocrinology
description: Structure and function of endocrine systems across vertebrate groups, surveying how hormones mediate adaptive responses to dynamic environments and coordinate key aspects of growth, development, metabolism, osmoregulation, and stress. 301 (with a minimum grade of C).
prerequisites: ANSC 301 (with a minimum grade of C)

title: Aquaculture Business Planning and Entrepreneurship
description: Practical aspects of planning and developing an aquaculture business from conceptualization to a final business plan. Topics include species/technology, project planning, business structuring, permitting, contracts, production plans, financial planning and analysis, market/competition analysis, capital acquisition, intellectual property and legal issues. 450 or OCN 450. Must have strong interest in hands-on rearing aquaculture animals and flexible time for live animal care.

title: Topics in Animal Sciences
description: Study and discussion of significant topics, problems. Offered by visiting faculty and/or for extension programs. Repeatable five times, up to 18 credits. junior or senior standing.

title: Field Experience
description: Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills emphasizing professional development. Placement with an approved cooperating supervisor/employer. Writing a learning plan and field report. A-F only. senior standing in ANSC. (

title: Directed Study or Research
description: Limited to exceptional undergraduate students, generally with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or a minimum GPA of 3.0 in major. Exceptions may be granted for students with high achievement in last three semesters. Repeatable unlimited times. junior or senior standing.

title: The Science of Food Systems
description: (1 50-min Lec, 1 2-hr Discussion) Discussion of food systems as they apply to animal science, food science, and human nutrition. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent. (

title: Experimental Design
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Design of experiments and variance analyses in biological and agricultural research. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: ZOOL 632. (

title: Seminar in Animal Sciences
description: Topics of current interest and current research related to nutrition, genetics, and physiology. Repeatable three times. consent.

title: Advanced Animal Nutrition
description: An advanced course in the nutrition of mono-gastric, ruminant, avian, and aquatic species. Topics include digestive system structures, utilization of nutrients, energy metabolism, and experimental techniques used in the study of animal nutrition. A-F only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Physiology of Reproduction
description: Comparative differentiation, development, growth, and function of the reproductive systems of mammals and birds; external factors that influence response; artificial insemination. graduate standing or consent.

title: Growth Biology of Meat Animals
description: Growth and development of meat-producing animals; skeletal muscle, adipose tissue, and bone; protein turnover, lipid metabolism, and bioenergetics; regulation of animal growth. graduate standing or consent.

title: DNA and Genetic Analysis
description: Combined lecture-lab for students interested in genetic analysis of humans, animals, and other species. Molecular techniques, such as PCR, DNA marker identifications, transgenics, expression analysis and functional genomics, are included. Open to nonmajors. graduate standing or consent. (

title: Information Research Skills
description: Examines the use of libraries and information technology for scholarly investigation in support of scientific research; provides experience utilizing and critically evaluating a variety of print and electronic sources in basic and applied sciences. consent. (

title: Grant Writing for Graduate Students
description: Combined lecture/discussion on grants and grant writing. Designed to introduce graduate students to grants and grant proposal writing through lectures, class discussion, writing assignments, and peer review. Open to CTAHR graduate students only; others with consent. (

title: Advanced Topics in Animal Sciences
description: Advanced topics in animal sciences, from basic to applied research, including current issues and critical analysis of current research literature. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits. ANSC majors only. Graduate students only.

title: Advanced Laboratory Techniques
description: (1 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Advanced laboratory techniques used in food science and human nutrition research. A-F only. graduate standing or consent and MBBE 402/402L, and FSHN 477; or BIOC 441. (
prerequisites: graduate standing or consent and MBBE 402/MBBE 402L, and FSHN 477; or BIOC 441

title: Plan B Master’s Project
description: Plan B students work with their advisor to select, revise, and defend before a three-person faculty committee a report of work the student has produced in the project. Repeatable unlimited times, credit earned up to 9 credits. ANSC majors only. Graduate students only.

title: Directed Research
description: consent. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Emerging Humanity
description: Introduction to human biological evolution and the archaeology of culture in the world prior to AD 1500. Open to nonmajors, recommended for majors.

title: Emerging Humanity
description: Introduction to human biological evolution and the archaeology of culture in the world prior to AD 1500. Restricted to students in the Honors Program.

title: Culture and Humanity
description: Introduction to cultural anthropology. How humans create, understand, order and modify their natural, social, supernatural and physical environments, and make meaning and order. Open to non-majors, required for ANTH majors. A-F only.

title: Culture and Humanity
description: Introduction to cultural anthropology. How humans create, understand, order and modify their natural, social, supernatural and physical environments, and make meaning and order. Restricted to students in the Honors Program.

title: Polynesian Surf Culture
description: Examines environmental and cultural factors in the development of Polynesian surf culture, surfing’s decline due to Western influence, and its revitalization as a modern recreational activity. Business practices of the surfing industry are critically analyzed. A-F only. Co-requisite: 175L. (Fall only)

title: Polynesian Surf Culture Field Lab
description: 175 co-requisite lab. Surfing sites are visited, ancient and modern Polynesian surfing practices and surfboard design and technology are discussed. Shoreline assessments emphasize ocean safety. Social issues surrounding surfing sites in Hawai‘i are analyzed. A-F only. Co-requisite: 175. (Fall only)

title: Historical Ecology of Hawai‘i
description: The Hawaiian socio-ecosystem is the product of centuries of human land use and resource exploitation. Explores the events and processes that have shaped the islands’ ecology and future sustainability. A-F only. (

title: Archaeology
description: Introduction to prehistoric archaeology; methods and techniques of excavation and laboratory analysis; brief survey of theory in relation to change and diversity in prehistoric human groups.

title: Introduction to Biological Anthropology
description: Human evolution, primatology, human genetics, biological variation, human adaptability, growth and development. Co-requisite: 215L.

title: Introduction to Biological Anthropology Laboratory
description: Laboratory to accompany 215. Co-requisite: 215.

title: Quantitative Reasoning for Anthropologists
description: Achieve basic quantitative literacy and to familiarize them with statistical reasoning so that they are prepared to carry out anthropological (and other social science) research. A-F only.

title: Anthropology of Sports
description: Explores sports from anthropological viewpoint: biological, cultural, linguistic, and archaeological. Open to nonmajors. Sophomore standing only.

title: Anthropology of Love
description: Explores love from multiple anthropological viewpoints: biological, cultural, archaeological. (Spring only)

title: Contemporary Social Issues
description: Contemporary issues in the field of anthropology and in society, including race, ethnicity, gender, inequality, colonialism and decolonization, health disparities and environmental change, from the perspective of cultural anthropology, biological anthropology and archaeology.

title: Culture and Health
description: Social and cultural aspects of medicine; the relationship of medicine to the beliefs, social systems, ecological adaptations, and cultural changes of human groups.

title: Human Origins
description: Theory of evolution, evolutionary systematics, and taxonomy; evolutionary biology of primates; fossil records for primate and human evolution. Laboratory included. 215, ZOOL 101; or consent.

title: Visual Anthropology
description: Historical development of documentary films of non-Western peoples; critical examination of ways in which ethnographic films represent different cultures. 152 (or concurrent).

title: Sex and Gender
description: Cross-cultural theories and perceptions of sexual differences; linkage between biology and cultural constructions of gender; relationship of gender ideology to women’s status. 152
crossListings: or concurrent or 301 or concurrent. Crosslisted as WGSS 315

title: Anthropology of Tourism
description: Anthropological perspectives on the subject of the global phenomenon of tourism. Includes issues of cultural performance, identity, and commoditization. Open to nonmajors.

title: Pacific Islands Archaeology
description: Origins of Pacific peoples; chronology of settlement; sequences of culture in Australia, Melanesia, Micronesia, and Polynesia. sophomore standing or consent.

title: Origins of Cities
description: Combined lecture/ discussion on the emergence and development of ancient cities in comparative perspective and the dynamics of ()modern urban life. Examples are drawn from the Near East, Mediterranean, Africa, India, China, and the Americas. A-F only. sophomore standing or consent.

title: American Folklore and Folklife
description: Examination of the history and ethics of folklore studies and the dynamics and social functions of traditional culture in diverse communities through topics such as ritual, storytelling, games, gossip, belief, music, and cultural tourism. Junior standing or higher. (

title: Ethnohistory
description: Review of ethnohistory, i.e., the interdisciplinary, holistic and inclusive investigation of the histories of native peoples drawing not only on documented sources, but also on ethnography, linguistics, archaeology, ecology and other disciplines as an alternative to conventional Eurocolonial history. A-F only. HIST 152, or consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Food Origins, Food Culture
description: Lectures and discussion offer an anthropological introduction to how humans created and transformed food through time. Sophomore standing or higher. (Spring only)

title: Indigenous Peoples and Cultures of North America
description: Survey of Indigenous peoples of North America. Integrates documentary records, ethnography, and archaeology to explore variability among native communities. Contemporary topics include political recognition and self-determination, health and education, and natural resources and economic development.

title: Anthropology of Surfing
description: Applies cultural anthropology to assess surfing as an indigenous Hawaiian and modern globalized activity. Discusses the history of surfing, surfing culture, and the impacts of surfing tourism on coastal development, reef ecology, and ocean safety. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Climate Change and Cultural Response: Past, Present, and Future
description: Climate change is a reality, yet there is much uncertainty about how it will affect our lives. Investigates cultural response to climate change, using studies of the past to plan for the future. (Alt. years: spring) (

title: Society and Environment
description: Relationship of humans with natural environment; role of culture in ecological systems. 152. (

title: Historical Ecology
description: Examines the recursive relationship between humans and the environment across deep time. (Fall only)

title: Anthropology of Virtual Worlds
description: Anthropological study of computer mediated interaction. Focus on the ethnography of massively multiplayer online games, text-based chat rooms, and blogs. 152 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Aggression, War, and Peace
description: Biocultural, evolutionary, and cross-cultural perspectives on the conditions, patterns, and processes of violence, war, nonviolence, and peace. 152. (

title: Pacific Island Cultures
description: Introduction to cultures of Polynesia, Micronesia, and Melanesia from time of first settlement to emergence of modern nation states. sophomore standing or consent.

title: Primate Behavioral Ecology
description: As primates are our closest living relatives, studying the range of variation in areas like life history, diet, communication, and social systems within the order primates can inform on how we ourselves evolved.

title: Households in Cross-Cultural Perspectives: Home, Hale, Casa
description: Study of cross-cultural patterns in household and community level organizations in Latin America and elsewhere. Topics may include gender relations, kinship structures, political economy, impacts of colonialism, modernization, and globalization on households. Sophomore standing or higher. (

title: Household Archaeology
description: Focuses on the differences in the composition, activities, roles, and relationships to be observed archaeologically between households that comprised ancient communities and how these differences inform us about the dynamics of social change. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 210.

title: Ethnographic Field Techniques
description: Problems and techniques of social-cultural anthropological fieldwork; ethnographic literature; work with informants. Repeatable one time. 152 OR 301.

title: (Alpha) Indigenous Peoples of Latin America
description: Survey of the history and culture of the indigenous peoples of Latin America through a study of their literature, texts and practices. (B) Mesoamerica; (C) Andean South America. Repeatable one time for different alphas. sophomore standing or consent. (

title: Race and Human Variation
description: Human genetic and physical variation; latitudinal, longitudinal, and altitudinal variation across human populations; history of racism; contemporary issues in race and racism. sophomore standing, recommend 152 and 215; or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: sophomore standing, recommend ANTH 152 and ANTH 215; or consent

title: Archaeology Practicum
description: Students will gain practical archaeological experience (e.g., materials processing, analysis, documentation, conservation) under the direction of practicing archaeological professionals in the local community and in collaboration with supervising archaeological faculty. Repeatable two times, up to 6 credits. ANTH majors or minors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. 210 or consent of instructor.

title: Archaeological Lab Techniques
description: Laboratory analysis and evaluation of field data; preservation and restoration of artifacts. Preparation for publication. Repeatable two times. 210 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Archaeological Field Techniques
description: Archaeological survey and excavations; field trips, mapping, photography. May focus on terrestrial or underwater. May be taught entirely in the field at a national or international archaeological site. Repeatable one time with consent. 210.

title: How Archaeology Works
description: Uses archaeological examples to illustrate social science research techniques. Students learn how to create, analyze, and evaluate data through lab-based exercises, and examine ethical issues inherent in anthropological practice. Repeatable one time. Sophomore standing or higher. 210 or instructor consent.

title: Skeletal Biology
description: Introduction to the human skeleton and methods for analyzing archaeological human remains including age, sex, ethnicity, paleodemography, skeletal and dental variation, paleopathology, population studies. Corequisite: 384L.

title: Skeletal Biology Laboratory
description: Laboratory to accompany 384. Co-requisite: 384.

title: (Alpha) Undergraduate Seminar
description: Selected problems in current research. (B) archaeology; (C) ethnography; (D) social anthropology; (E) applied; (F) psychological; (G) biological. Repeatable nine times. consent.

title: Directed Reading or Research
description: Repeatable nine times. major or minor in Anthropology.

title: Ethics in Anthropology
description: Seminar surveying ethical cases, problems, issues and questions from the inception of anthropology to the present. Junior standing or higher or consent.

title: Museum Anthropology
description: Anthropological study of museums and related sites of cultural production (historic sites, memorials, theme parks). Junior standing or higher. (Alt. years)

title: Evolutionary Anthropology
description: Lecture discussion providing an overview of evolutionary theory in anthropology: focus on the evolution of culture, behavioral ecology, and cultural diversity; emphasis on archaeological and ethnographic research and explanatory models. 210 or 215, or consent. (Once a year)

title: Language and Gender
description: The role of language in the construction of gender and in the maintenance of the gender order. Field projects explore hypotheses about the interaction of language and gender. No previous knowledge of linguistics required. A-F only. (

title: Introduction to Linguistic Anthropology
description: Introduction to the ethnographic study of speech and language. 152. (Once a year) (

title: Wealth, Culture, and Economic Anthropology
description: Analysis of economic activities in non-Western, non-industrial societies; production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services in a variety of cultures. 152.

title: Political Anthropology
description: Character of political institutions and their development in nonWestern and non industrial societies. 152.

title: Indigenous Anthropology
description: Exploration of how anthropology studies indigenous groups throughout the world. An examination of the changing contexts of anthropological practice as calls for reflexivity lead anthropology of all backgrounds to bring insights from their “homes.” Issues include the question of objectivity, the emicetic distinction, and the ethics of different kinds of anthropological research and the role of anthropologists in indigenous self-determination. Repeatable one time. 152.

title: Communication and Culture
description: Anthropological introduction to communication; intercultural and interspecies comparisons; verbal and nonverbal. Ethnography of communication, discourse and structural analyses, ethnomethodology. 152.

title: Anthropology of Magic, Witchcraft, and Religion
description: Cults, legends, millennial movements, myths, possession, rituals, sacred healing, shamanism, sorcery, spirits, symbolism, witchcraft, and other forms of religious and symbolic expression and experience, from small scale to highly urban societies. 152. (

title: Social and Cultural Change
description: Various approaches to examples of social and cultural change in non-literate societies; evolution, diffusion, acculturation, revolution, etc. Historical features and social processes of colonialism. 152.

title: Islands as Model Systems: Human Biogeography of the Pacific
description: Applying the concept of islands as “model systems;” explores the impacts of human populations on the natural ecosystems of oceanic islands, and the reciprocal effects of anthropogenic change on human cultures. A-F only. 323 or consent.

title: The Anthropology of Sexuality
description: Explores the intersection of sexuality research and queer theory with other anthropological concerns such as identity, race, gender, religion, economy, politics, and globalization. A-F only. junior standing or consent. (

title: Food, Health, and Society
description: How human groups identify, collect, create, and transform foods; how they shape those into dietary behaviors, and the influence of those behaviors on health. junior standing or higher or consent.
prerequisites: junior standing or higher or consent

title: Anthropology of the Body
description: Exploration of the history and development of theories of the body via topics such as phenomenology, perception, bodily rituals, gender, sex, race, colonialism, power, pain, medicalization, immunology, reproductive health and cyborgs. 152 (or concurrent) or 301 (or concurrent).

title: Anthropology of Consumer Cultures
description: Examines the practices and meanings of consumption in the contemporary world. Topics include social class, branding, fandom, global-local nexus. A-F only. 152 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Indigenous Crops/Food Systems
description: Schemes for managing sequences and combinations of crops and crop production activities. Ecosystem and social determinants. Multiple cropping. Analysis of alternative cropping systems. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Junior standing or higher.

title: The Agriculture of Identity: Food and Farming in Anthropological Perspective
description: Exploration of agriculture from the perspective of anthropology, with a focus on alternatives to industrial agriculture, especially in the context of Hawai‘i. Readings include academic writing and also literary non-fiction and journalism. A-F only. 152. (Alt. years)

title: Globalization and Identity in the Himalayas
description: Examines the influence of local culture and global flows on identity formation in the Himalayan region. Topics include: Hindu caste and gender, constructions of ethnicity, Tibetans and tourists, Sherpas and mountaineers, development ideologies, and consumerism. 152 or 301 or ASAN 202 or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: ANTH 152 or ANTH 301 or ASAN 202 or consent

title: Anthropology of Buddhism
description: Selected aspects of national, regional and local manifestations of Buddhism are explored through the perspective of anthropology with an emphasis on the daily lives of monks, nuns and lay persons in their socio-cultural contexts. 422, REL 207, REL 475, or consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Spiritual Ecology
description: Lectures and seminars provide a cross-cultural survey of the relationships between religions, environment and environmentalism. Junior standing or higher. consent. (

title: Sacred Places
description: Lectures and seminars provide a cross-cultural survey of sites which societies recognize as sacred and their cultural, ecological and conservation aspects. junior standing or consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Southeast Asian Cultures
description: Cultures of Southeast Asia from hunting and gathering groups to high civilizations; kinship, economic, political, and religious systems; recent developments. junior standing or consent.

title: Polynesian Cultures
description: Analysis of Polynesian cultures from their origins to contemporary states. junior standing or consent.

title: Anthropology of Melanesia
description: Close study of cultures of Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu, Solomon Islands, New Caledonia, and Fiji through anthropological ethnography. 152 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Decolonizing Anthropology Through South Africa
description: Decolonizing approaches to anthropology explored through the archaeology and ethnography of South Africa. Topics include race, inequality, nationalism, migration, heritage, and violence. Junior standing or higher. (Alt years)

title: Forensic Anthropology
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Application of physical anthropology to problems in human identification. Determination of age, sex, ancestry, etc., of the skeleton and preparation of reports for legal medicine. 215 and 215L.

title: Extinctions
description: An extraordinary number of plants and animals have gone extinct. Delves deeply into the primary literature that focuses on extinction and conservation from the beginning of the earth to the present day. 215 or consent. (Alt. yrs: fall)

title: Asian Paleoanthropology
description: Neogene-Quaternary paleoenvironmental reconstructions; human evolution in East Asia during the Pleistocene; Out of Africa I; modern human origins. sophomore standing, recommend 310, or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: sophomore standing, recommend ANTH 310, or consent

title: Southeast Asian Archaeology
description: Prehistory and protohistory of Southeast Asia and of Southeast Asian contacts with East Asia, India, Australia, and Oceania. junior standing or consent.

title: East Asian Archaeology
description: Prehistory and protohistory of China, Japan, and Korea from earliest human occupation to historic times. Geographical emphasis may vary between China and Japan/Korea. junior standing or consent.

title: Anthropology of Global Health and Development
description: Seminar explores the definitions and histories of development and global health initiatives in developing countries from an anthropological perspective. Reading materials include scholarly and popular texts that propose and critique solutions to global poverty. Sophomore standing or higher. 152 or 301. (Alt. years)

title: Hawaiian Archaeology
description: Archaeological perspective in Hawai‘i’s past; origins of Hawaiians; early settlement and culture change; settlement patterns and material culture; historic sites preservation. junior standing and consent.

title: Science, Sex, and Reproduction
description: Explores anthropology’s critical analysis of approaches to reproductive health and procreation, primarily in developing countries. Examines sex and reproduction as sites of intervention from public health, development, and biomedical specialists, while also considering local strategies. Junior standing or higher. 152 or 301 or WGSS 151. (Alt. years) (

title: Quantitative Archaeology
description: Combined lecture/lab. Introduction to the basic principles of statistics as applied to the analysis of archaeological data. Exploratory data analysis approach. A-F only. ANTH majors only. Junior standing or higher. 210. (Alt. years)

title: Biomedicine and Culture
description: Examination of the social and cultural foundations of, and responses to, the values, technologies and practices of modern medicine. junior standing or higher, 152, or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, ANTH 152, or consent

title: Field Mapping
description: Techniques for field measurement and recording of cultural and physical data. Field sketching, Brunton surveying, plane table mapping, oblique photo compilation, topographic mapping, and representation of field data. junior standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Ceramic Analysis in Archaeology
description: Concepts, methods, and approaches used in the analysis of ancient pottery. Emphasis placed on ceramic technology, stylistic analysis. 210.

title: Lithic Artifact Assemblage Analysis
description: Combined lecture/lab on the manufacture and analysis of stone tools. Students work with experimental collections and engage in stone tool production. The ways in which lithics enlighten us about past human behavior are discussed. 210 and 380, or consent.

title: Faunal Analysis in Archaeology
description: Analysis of archaeologically recovered faunal collections with emphasis on identification and interpretation of nonhuman vertebrate remains. 210.

title: Spatial Analysis in Archaeology
description: Lecture/lab. Introduction to the use of Geographical Information Systems (GIS) and spatial statistics in archaeological research. Topics include: map creation; spatial database management; spatial analysis; image processing, data reporting; and data display. Junior standing or higher. 466 or 666, or instructor approval. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: ANTH 466 or ANTH 666, or instructor approval

title: New World Rituals and Ideologies
description: Study of cross-cultural patterns in ritual behaviors and creolization of African, indigenous, and Iberian ideological frameworks in the Americas. Topics may include syncretic religions (voodoo, candomble), Andean Christianity, spiritual conquest, conceptions of death, etc. Sophomore standing or higher. Minimum C- required grade for LAIS 360, or consent. (Fall only) (

title: Applied Anthropology
description: The application of anthropological methods and concepts to solving practical human problems such as homelessness, domestic violence, maternal morbidity, conflict over resources, and the loss of indigenous languages. Includes a significant service-learning component. 152.

title: Anthropology and the Environment: Culture, Power, and Politics
description: Investigates environmental problems from an anthropological perspective, and examines the cultural politics of contestations over resources, rights, and the meanings of nature. 152 or 415 or consent.

title: Japanese Culture and Behavior
description: Sociocultural factors in Japanese behavior. Social structure; traditional institutions

title: Japanese Popular Culture
description: Explores contemporary Japanese popular culture through themes such as gender, consumerism, globalization and nostalgia. Rather than a survey of popular culture genres, the course is organized thematically around issues and problematics.

title: Pre-European Hawai‘i
description: -European society and culture from an anthropological viewpoint. junior standing or consent.
prerequisites: -European society and culture from an anthropological viewpoint

title: Peoples of Hawai‘i
description: Critically examines the historical and contemporary experiences of various people of Hawai‘i using anthropological and ethnic studies approaches. Emphasis on cultural perspectives and values of peoples indigenous to Hawai‘i, the Pacific, and Asia. junior standing or consent. (Once a year) (

title: Anthropology of Okinawa and Its Diaspora
description: Explores the ties of identity that exist within and between Okinawa and its diasporic populations. 152. (Alt. years)

title: Chinese Culture: Ethnography
description: Critical interpretations of ethnographic and biographic texts depicting individual and family lives in different socioeconomic circumstances, geographical regions, and historical periods of modern China.

title: History of Anthropology
description: Development of anthropological ideas, focusing on theoretical issues concerning culture, society, and human nature. Required of majors. 152.

title: Special Topics in Southeast Asian Art History: Monuments and Nationalism in Southeast Asia
description: Focused study of particular periods, regions and critical themes in Southeast Asian art and architectural history. Monuments and nationalism in Southeast Asia. A-F only. ART 175, or consent. (Once a year) (

title: Oral History: Theory and Practice
description: Literature, methodology, ethics and project design of oral history research. Students develop and execute an oral history project. (

title: Senior Thesis I
description: Preparation of a major paper in anthropology with a committee of one chairperson and one other. First semester of a two-semester sequence with 496. May be taken concurrently with 496. Optional for majors. 490 and senior standing.

title: Senior Thesis II
description: Preparation of a major paper in anthropology with a committee of one chairperson and one other. Second semester of a two-semester sequence with 495. May be taken concurrently with 495. Optional for majors. 490 and senior standing.

title: Ethnology
description: Survey, in historical perspective, of theory in social and cultural anthropology, from the origin of anthropology to 1976. A course in the graduate core of anthropology. A-F only. graduate standing.

title: Linguistic Anthropology
description: Investigation of mutual influences of linguistic theory and methodology and anthropological theory and methodology. A course in the graduate core of anthropology. A-F only. graduate standing.

title: Archaeology
description: Development of critical and analytical skills in assessment of archaeological literature; emphasis on the science, theory, explanation, and paradigms that comprise archaeology. A course in the graduate core of anthropology. A-F only. graduate standing.

title: Biological Anthropology Core
description: Human evolution and human variability in extant and previously existing populations; emphasis on history of physical anthropology, evolutionary systematics, primate biology and behavior, paleontology, anthropological genetics, climatic adaptation, growth, and nutrition. A course in the graduate core of anthropology. A-F only. graduate standing.

title: Discursive Practices
description: Emphasizes linguistic, semantic, and interactional aspects of culture, exploring ways that discourse constructs social action and social realities, examining processes by which culture is produced as meaningful behavior in actual situations. graduate standing.

title: Anthropology of Infectious Disease
description: The role of human behavior, including its social and cultural determinants, in understanding the distribution of infectious diseases and in shaping preventive and therapeutic strategies. graduate standing.

title: History and Memory
description: History and collective memory as culturally formed and politically contested realities. The role of narrative, ritual, and media technologies in shaping representations of the past. graduate standing.

title: Cultural Geographies of Tourism
description: Social and cultural analysis of tourism practices, with emphasis on Hawai‘i, Asia and the Pacific. Tourism in relation to consumer culture, transnational flows of people and images, post-colonial politics, performance and identity formation. (

title: Contemporary Anthropological Theory
description: Graduate seminar that examines the history of theory in sociocultural anthropology from 1960 to present. Designed to be taken in sequence after 601. 601 or concurrent. (Once a year)

title: (Alpha) Theory in Social and Cultural Anthropology
description: Major theoretical problems in (B) kinship; (C) cognitive systems; (D) religion; (E) political institutions; (F) law and social control; (G) economics; (H) ecology; (I) other to be announced. Repeatable nine times. graduate standing.

title: Advanced Pacific Islands Archaeology
description: Advanced theoretical and methodological examination of archaeological research in Oceania, a region including the islands of Polynesia, Melanesia, and Micronesia. (Fall only)

title: (Alpha) Methods and Theory in Archaeology
description: Focused seminars pertaining to distinct areas of archaeological method and theory. (B) analytical; (C) environment/landscape; (D) applied archaeology; (E) economic/resources; (F) survey/locational. Repeatable two times. 603.

title: Historic Preservation
description: Federal, state, and local laws and regulations that regulate and provide protection to significant archaeological and historical resources in Hawai‘i and the region. (Alt. years: spring only) (.

title: Decolonizing Anthropology
description: Decolonizing approaches to anthropology with a focus on South Africa and its relevance for the Pacific and U.S. Topics include race, inequality, nationalism, migration, heritage, and violence.

title: Advances in Extinctions
description: To delve deeply into the primary literature that focuses on the subjects of extinction and conservation broadly speaking, with particular emphasis on the 6 mass extinction events, including the Anthropocene. (Alt. years)

title: Paleoanthropology of Asia
description: Survey of the Asian paleoanthropological record, particularly in its paleoenvironmental setting; Out of Africa I; modern human origins. graduate standing and relevant background in anthropology or related field. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: graduate standing and relevant background in anthropology or related field

title: Archaeological Perspectives on Southeast Asia
description: Prehistory and protohistory of Southeast Asia, and of Southeast Asian contacts with East Asia, india, Australia, and Oceania. background in archaeology or Southeast Asian history or consent.
prerequisites: background in archaeology or Southeast Asian history or consent

title: Anthropology of Global Aid
description: Examines ideologies of development, humanitarian, and global health interventions from an anthropological perspective. Explores the disjuncture between discourses that portrays global aid as easing suffering and those that accuse it of maintaining relationships of domination. A-F only. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Advanced Hawaiian Archaeology
description: An advanced theoretical and methodological examination of past and current archaeological research in the Hawaiian Islands. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Archaeological Data Analysis
description: Advanced introduction to the fundamental principles of statistics as applied to the analysis of archaeological data. (Alt. years)

title: Biomedicine and Culture
description: Examination of the social and cultural foundations of, and responses to, the values, technologies, and practices of modern medicine. graduate standing. (Alt. years)

title: Archaeology Field Methods
description: (5 7-hr Lab) Laboratory and field training in the principles and practice of methods of archaeology—survey, mapping, excavation, conservation. Repeatable one time, up to 12 credits. graduate standing.

title: Advanced Household Archaeology
description: Focus on the differences in the composition, activities, roles, and relationships to be observed archaeologically between the households that comprised ancient communities, and how these differences inform us about the dynamics of social change. Graduate students only.

title: Applied Archaeology Practicum
description: Applies course work in archaeology to handson activities under the direction of practicing professionals and university faculty. MA track in Applied Archaeology students only. Repeatable one time, up to 12 credits. consent.

title: Applied Method and Theory in Hawaiian Archaeology
description: Graduate seminar focused on method and theory in the practice of applied archaeology in Hawai‘i. graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Recording Historic and Cultural Resources
description: Techniques in recording and evaluation of historic buildings and other resources, with an emphasis on field recordings and state and federal registration procedures. Graduate students only or consent. (

title: Applied Cultural Anthropology
description: Theory, methods, and results of application of cultural anthropological concepts to practical problems. Graduate students only.

title: Applied Cultural Anthropology Practicum
description: Applies course work in cultural anthropology to hands-on activities under the direction of practicing professionals and university faculty. Repeatable one time. ANTH majors only. Graduate students only. 681.

title: Professional Skills Develop in Anthropology
description: Seminar prepares graduate students for entry into profession, including employment opportunities, research, presentations, ethics and outreach. Required of all Plan B students. graduate standing.

title: Directed Reading or Research
description: Repeatable nine times, up to 12 credits. graduate standing and consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable nine times, up to 12 credits.

title: Seminar in Research Methods in Cultural Anthropology
description: Ethnographic research methods. Introduction to the approaches and techniques of participatory research, including the collection, analysis, and interpretation of social and cultural data. Politics and ethics of research practice. Repeatable one time. graduate standing in anthropology or consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing in anthropology or consent

title: Seminar in Research Design and Proposal Writing
description: Research design and proposal writing. For students preparing for advanced research. graduate standing and consent.

title: Anthropology of Japan
description: Japan examined through three dimensions of cultural anthropology: cultural/symbolic, social/organizational, and individual/psychological. Selected topics analyzed and interpreted in terms of conjunctions of these dimensions. 483 or 484.

title: (Alpha) Research Seminar
description: Selected problems in current research. (B) archaeology; (C) medical; (D) ethnography; (E) social; (G) biological. Repeatable nine times. graduate standing.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable nine times.

title: Elementary Modern Standard Arabic
description: Designed to provide students with basic knowledge of Modern Standard Arabic. Focuses on developing proficiency in the standard written Arabic language, as well as formal spoken Arabic.

title: Elementary Modern Standard Arabic
description: Focuses on developing proficiency in the standard written Arabic language as well as formal spoken Arabic. It introduces a wide range of situation-based texts and topics that build vocabulary, grammar, and general communicative competence. 101.

title: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic
description: Designed for students who have successfully completed a year of Elementary Arabic. Focus is on acquisition of more complex grammatical structures, expanding vocabulary, and developing competence in a wide range of communicative situations. 102 or exam or consent. (Fall only)

title: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic
description: Designed for students who have successfully completed three semesters of Arabic. Focus is on intensive practice of interactive functional skills such as listening comprehension and fundamental conversation strategies. 201 or exam or consent. (Spring only)

title: Third-Level Arabic I
description: Develop proficiency in reading/listening comprehension in Modern Standard Arabic. The instructional materials consist of authentic written, visual and audio materials. Classes meet 3 hours weekly. 202 (or equivalent), or consent.

title: Third-Level Arabic II
description: Continuation of third-level Arabic I. Emphasis on developing writing and interaction ability at advanced levels of proficiency. Course includes extensive reading, composition exercises, listening skills, conversation practice and extensive review of Arabic grammar. Developing fluency is the main objective of this course. Classes meet 3 hours weekly. 301 (or equivalent), or consent.

title: Introduction to the Built Environment
description: Introduction to the breadth of design in today’s global culture. Exploration of human responses to place, climate, culture, communication, and technology, with emphasis on the impact of scientific knowledge on environmental design. Open to nonmajors. A-F only.

title: Design Fundamentals Studio I
description: Introduction to creative design processes focusing on the investigation of composition within defining perceivable space. Hands-on exploration of materials and structures as an introduction to design processes. ENVD majors only. A-F only.

title: Design Fundamentals Studio II
description: Continued exploration of design processes. Introduction to CAD technologies, material exploration, and creative exploration including the relationship between digital, physical, and materials aspects of design. ENVD majors only. A-F only. 101.

title: Collaboration in Environmental Design
description: Investigation of the various disciplines in the environmental design field, including architecture, landscape architecture, interiors, historic preservation, urban design, and construction management. Emphasis given to collaborative methods to address critical issues. Open to non-majors. A-F only. 100.

title: Beginning Design Studio I
description: Exploration of critical judgment and means to conceptualize, develop, represent, and both visually and orally communicate form and space, including freehand drawing, mechanical drawing, physical model making, diagramming, and computer graphic techniques. ENVD majors only. A-F only. 102.

title: Beginning Design Studio II
description: Development of designs and processes to study precedents and explore solutions responding to human needs in built and natural environments. Analysis and representation of architectonic space and form using hand and computer techniques. ENVD majors only. A-F only. 201.

title: Introduction to Environmental Systems A
description: Introduction to building systems, including structural, environmental, life-safety, building envelope, building materials and building assemblies. Development of design skills with emphasis on elevating skills in assessing and selecting appropriate building systems. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only. 132 or 102, and MATH 140X.

title: World Architecture and Urbanism A
description: Investigation of the history and theory of architecture in the world’s major cultural regions, from early agricultural settlements to 1500 C.E. Investigation of architecture in relationship to social, political, technological, and material forces. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only. HIST 151.

title: World Architecture and Urbanism B
description: Investigation of the history and theory of architecture from the 15th century C.E. to the present. Investigation of architecture in relationship to social, political, technological, and material forces. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only. HIST 152.

title: Introduction to Environmental Systems B
description: Introduction to environmentalism; focusing on the impact of building systems of the global environment; the role of environmental regulations/certifications, and understanding of sustainable principles (economic, social, and natural systems). ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only. 220 and PHYS 151/151L.

title: Intermediate Design Studio I
description: Building and site design with emphasis on site development, analysis, and climatic response. Introduction to sustainable design, land use ordinances, description and delineation of property and land features, and urban and community design influences. ENVD majors only. A-F only. 200 and 202.

title: Intermediate Design Studio II
description: Architectural design with emphasis on space planning, building materials, technology, climatic responses, and codes including complex functional requirements, multi-story design issues, vertical transportation, structure, and finishes. Production of complete schematic design documents. Detailed writing instruction. ENVD majors only. A-F only. 341.

title: Landscape Architecture History
description: Survey of the history of landscape architecture from Mesopotamia to present. Review of the physical, cultural, social, economic, and political factors, as well as the environmental concerns, horticultural techniques, and technological innovations of historic landscapes. ENVD and LAND majors only. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Landscape Graphics Studio
description: Basic skills of landscape graphic communication through a creative process model. Learning free hand and technical drafting techniques to creative effective landscape graphics. ARCH and ENVD majors only. consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Tropical Landscape Planting Design Studio
description: Students will develop basic skills of residential landscape graphic and design processes in order to clearly articulate the ability to think, analyze, and extend a physical solution in the proper scale. Repeatable one time. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only. (Alt. years) (

title: Design Theory
description: Examination of theories, movements, and periods in architectural history focusing on contemporary issues. Requires a minimum of 4,000 words of writing, and three oral communication assignments. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only. 201, 220, 271, and 272.

title: Landform and Water
description: Essential topographic site design concepts and skills needed to reshape the land for human use, circulation, water management, and resilience. Topics will be reinforced through problem sets and analytical, computational, graphical, and technical exercises. ENVD and LAND majors only. A-F only. 201 and 220.

title: Directed Work
description: ARCH and ENVD majors only. consent.

title: Concentration Design Studio
description: Professional experience combined with scholarly and research activity occurring in an off-campus location with a focus on architectural concentration areas. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only. 342.

title: Capstone Design Studio
description: Culminating design studio with focus on the development of a comprehensive design project integrating all major aspects of prior environmental design education. BEnvD majors only. A-F only. 415.

title: Construction Project Management
description: Introductory treatment of the management of construction. Construction supervision, contract documents, estimating and bidding, organization, planning and scheduling, administration, business methods, safety, and labor. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only. (

title: Professional Practice Law and Ethics
description: Knowledge of professional standards and a broad understanding of the practice of architecture, including professionalism; ethical conduct; public, client, consultant, contractor, and government relations; project administration, contracts, procedures, and compensation; land use and construction law. ENVD majors only. A-F only. 341.

title: Digital Design Synthesis
description: Investigation of processes for generating architectonic form using current digital technologies. Making advanced geometric models including investigation of morphological transformations. Study of design optimization, digital fabrication, information modeling, and generative algorithms. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only. 235.

title: Design Exchange
description: Seminar centered on academic and cultural exchanges, focused on advanced topics related to the design of built environments. ARCH majors only. A-F only.

title: Documentation of Historic Architecture
description: Study and documentation of existing buildings, structures, and sites of historic and/or cultural significance, including field measurements and drawings, historical research, photo documentation, and preparation of archival drawings to be deposited in the Library of Congress. Documentation conducted according to standards of the Historic American Buildings Survey/Historic American Engineering Record (HABS/HAER). Repeatable three times, up to 24 credits. ARCH, ENVD, and AMST majors only. consent. (

title: History of American Architecture
description: History of American architecture in terms of style, techniques, and symbolic meaning. ARCH and ENVD majors only. (

title: Preservation: Hawai‘i, Asia, and the Pacific
description: Lectures and discussions on historic preservation issues in Hawai‘i, Asia, and the Pacific. Emphasis on indigenous and national expressions. ARCH and ENVD majors only. junior standing or consent. (

title: Urban Ecological Analysis and Design
description: Applied urban and landscape ecology principles and strategies for analysis, design, and management of urban regions and sites; emphasis on structure, functions, and processes that form urban landscapes at multiple scales and in diverse contexts. ENVD and LAND majors only. A-F only. 381.

title: Plants in Design
description: Introduction to the use of plants as design elements in the built environment across diverse scales. Examination of the spatial, sensory, ecological, and performative qualities of vegetation through analysis of historic and contemporary examples. ENVD and LAND majors only. A-F only. 381.

title: Special Topics
description: Selected topics in any aspect of architecture. Content to be announced. Repeatable four times. ARCH and ENVD majors only.

title: Special Topics in Architecture History
description: Specialized work on the history and theory of architecture. Repeatable unlimited times. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only.

title: Special Topics in Architectural Technology
description: Specialized investigation of technological developments in structural systems, environmental control systems, or materials and methods of construction. Repeatable unlimited times. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only.

title: Special Topics in Architecture and Design
description: Work on specialized topics in the fields of architecture and design. May include research and/or studio experiences in architecture, interior architecture, computer-aided design, professional practice, advanced visual design, and architectural graphics. Repeatable unlimited times. ARCH and ENVD majors only. A-F only.

title: Explore Furniture Design
description: Exploration of design and building principles as related to furniture. Emphasis on fundamentals of practice and an understanding of materials and structure, with an intensive hands-on building experience. Repeatable one time. BEnvD majors only. A-F only. 102.

title: Special Topics in Architecture and Writing
description: Reading, research, and work on topics in architecture and design. Includes an intensive writing component. May include specialized research and/or studio experience in architecture, design, and the history and theory of architecture and design. ENVD majors only. 100 and 101.

title: American Architecture
description: Cultural analysis of the evolution of American architecture from the Colonial period to the present involving sociopolitical and economic, as well as aesthetic, considerations. (

title: Preservation: Theory and Practice
description: History and philosophy of historic preservation movement. Analysis of values and assumptions, methodologies and tactics, implications for society and public policy. (

title: Design Communication for Landscape Architects
description: Theory and application in design communication, including drawing and presentation skills; emphasis on the design process and critical thinking through analog and digital media, diagramming, three-dimensional modeling, and various other presentation techniques. LAND majors only. A-F only.

title: Computer Applications in Landscape Architecture
description: Introduction to the use of computers in landscape architecture, emphasizing two- and three dimensional computer-aided drawings and graphics suitable to landscape architectural design and practice. LAND majors only. A-F only.

title: Landscape Plants: Identification and Use
description: Introduction to the identification, recognition, and use of plants in landscape design and built environment applications. Students will be introduced to a variety of landscape plants commonly used in Hawai‘i and the tropics. LAND majors only. A-F only. (

title: Landscape Materials and Construction
description: Examination of materials and methods of landscape construction from source, extraction, and manufacturing, to use and reuse. Assignments include drawing standard construction details and a report on the history of material use, properties, and qualities. LAND majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. 381.

title: Landscape Architectural Professional Practice
description: Introduction of practices and core methods of the landscape architecture profession. Subjects include business and governmental organization, elements of contract law, business management, professional relationships, marketing, professional licensure, and ethics. LAND majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. 634 and 635.

title: Land Use Planning
description: Issues and methods of urban land use planning practice and plan making. A-F only. PLAN 640 or consent.

title: Historic Preservation
description: Federal, state, and local laws and regulations that regulate and provide protection to significant archaeological and historical resources in Hawai‘i and the region. (Alt. years: spring only) (

title: Vernacular Architecture
description: Methods and approaches in the study of vernacular architecture, cultural landscapes and material culture, with an emphasis on traditions and innovations in the Americas. (

title: Fundamentals of Landscape Design Studio
description: Theory and application of foundational landscape design principles, programming, and physical analysis to site-based design problems. Visual, formal, spatial, and functional design principles are applied to ecological and cultural influences in landscape design. LAND majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Site Design Studio
description: Landscape project design at the site scale; from concept development through detailed design. Synthesis of foundational skills into more complex, layered spatial, and functional problems. Emphasis on site research and design methods. LAND majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Environmental and Cultural Landscape Studio
description: Exploring, understanding, and implementing Hawaiian and Western cultural and environmental landscape design principles. A concentrated look at how to think about creating and respecting a sense of place through landscape design. LAND and TPSS majors only. A-F only. (

title: Environmental Landscape Technologies and Systems
description: Understanding the science and art of green landscape technologies, with a comprehensive understanding of LID
crossListings: low impact design principles and practices; to increase knowledge to help produce more viable and enduring built landscapes. LAND majors only. A-F only. Crosslisted as TPSS 658

title: Preservation Field Seminar
description: Provides participants with basic knowledge of the field of historic preservation as well as the fundamental knowledge of how to document, conserve, and preserve both tangible and intangible cultural properties. Repeatable three times. (Summer only)

title: Recording Historic and Cultural Resources
description: Techniques in recording and evaluation of historic buildings and other resources, with an emphasis on field recordings and state and federal registration procedures. Graduate students only or consent. (

title: Historic Preservation Planning
description: Local-level historic preservation, with an emphasis on historic districts, design guidelines, regulatory controls, and community consensus-building. (

title: Elements of Style
description: The manifestations, visual characteristics, and social/ cultural meaning of “style” in American architecture and decorative arts from the early settlement period through the present. (

title: Building Well-Being: Health and the Built Environment
description: History, concepts, and theories behind the relationship between health and the built environment stressing transdisciplinary understanding and collaboration through readings, discussion, and real world-based exercises. LAND, ARCH, and PLAN majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Preservation Field Study
description: On-site historic preservation field study. Site will rotate. Academic and hands-on preservation training. (B) Hawai‘i; (C) Asia; (D) Pacific. Each alpha repeatable up to 18 credits. consent.

title: Historic Preservation Practicum
description: Applies course work in historic preservation to hands-on activities under the direction of practicing professionals and University faculty. Historic preservation certificate students only.

title: Culture & Urban Form in Asia
description: Cultural and historical impact on urban form, contention of tradition and modernity in urban space, spatial expression of state and society, perception and utilization of urban design, evolution of urban form in selected Asian capitals. 341, ASAN 312, PLAN 310 or PLAN 600. (

title: Special Topics Seminar
description: Seminar on a wide range of architectural topics to be directed by both visiting and regular faculty. Repeatable three times. ARCH and LAND majors only. consent

title: Special Topics in Architectural Technology
description: Specialized investigation at an advanced level of technological developments in structural systems, environmental control systems, or materials and methods of construction. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Special Topics in Architecture and Design
description: Intensive work on specialized topics in the fields of architecture and design. May include research and/or studio experiences in architecture, interior architecture, computer-aided design, professional practice, advanced visual design, and architectural graphics. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Special Topics in Furniture Design and Fabrication
description: Exploration of design and building principles as related to furniture. Emphasis on fundamentals of practice, an understanding of materials and structure, with an intensive hands-on building experience. Additionally, a survey of 20th Century furniture design. Repeatable one time. ARCH majors only. A-F only.

title: Applied Theories of Landscape Architecture
description: Graduate seminar on discussion of central ideas and theories in landscape architecture and environmental design, drawing on primary literature and speculative or built design work over many decades of thought. ARCH and LAND majors only, or consent. Graduate students only. A-F only. (

title: Special Topics in Landscape Architecture
description: Seminar on a wide range of landscape architectural topics to be directed by both visiting and regular faculty. Repeatable three times. ARCH and LAND majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Directed Work
description: ARCH and LAND majors only.

title: MLA Thesis
description: Landscape architectural thesis research and design inquiry. Limited to MLA students under Plan A. Repeatable unlimited times. LAND majors only. Graduate students only. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only. consent.

title: Asia-Pacific Architectural History and Theory
description: Study of the history and theory of culture and the built environment with particular focus on the Asia-Pacific region. ARCH majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Architecture and Urban Design Theory
description: Detailed investigation of major theories in architecture and urban design and examination of their impact on contemporary architectural practice in varied geo-political contexts. Open to non-majors. A-F only.

title: Architecture Systems I: Introduction to Systems
description: Study of building materials, assemblies, and integrated design including structural, environmental, life-safety, and building envelope systems. Development of ability to design, analyze and assess appropriate systems. ARCH majors only. A-F only. MATH 140X.

title: Architecture Systems II: Qualitative Bioclimatic and Structural Performance
description: Introduction to the theory of bioclimatic principles and structural systems and the ability to analyze, assess, select, design, and integrate them as initial determinants into the building design. ARCH majors only. A-F only. graduate status.

title: Architecture Systems III: Quantitative Structural Analysis and Design
description: Introduction to procedures and wood, steel, concrete, and masonry material properties used for structural analysis and design of individual structural elements and building structural systems. ARCH majors only. A-F only. 723.

title: Architecture Systems IV: Environmental Technology, Sustainability, and Analysis
description: Application and analysis of highperformance building design principles. Emphasis on climate-appropriate passive design, energy-efficient lighting and conditioning strategies, innovative water systems, and renewable energy production. ARCH majors only. A-F only. 723.

title: Architecture Systems V: Building Systems Integration
description: Properties, evolution, and range of building m aterials, assemblies, and systems and their applications in integrated high-performance building design with a focus on the role of detail and systems in the design process. ARCH majors only. A-F only. 724, 725, and 733. Co-requisite: 744.

title: Advanced Design Communication I
description: (Lec, Lab) Exploration of digital technologies, their relationship to design, and their application to architectural analysis, conceptualization, design processes, communication, representation, and construction. ARCH majors only. A-F only. departmental approval.

title: Advanced Design Communication II
description: (Lec, Lab) An interdisciplinary investigation of design theory as connected to digital technology and its applications to current developments in practice and research within architecture and design. ARCH majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Forms and Frames of Practice
description: Comprehensive study of architectural practice within the global context with emphasis on the Asia Pacific region. Exploration of information technology systems, materials and design process research, construction technology, computer aided manufacturing, and entrepreneurial approaches. ARCH majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Advanced Design Communications III
description: Interdisciplinary investigation of design theory as connected to architectural presentation techniques, particularly oral and written, to current developments in architectural practice. A-F only.

title: Research Methods Seminar
description: Comprehensive assessment of objectives and function of research in architecture and landscape architecture. Lecture, seminar, independent work with emphasis on research project topic and proposal development. ARCH and LAND majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. 715 or 761.

title: Architecture Studio I: Intro to Design
description: Design theories and systematic analytic and synthetic methodologies applied to creation of building and site spaces responsive to environmental and human needs. Several individual projects. ARCH majors only. A-F only.

title: Architecture Studio III
description: Design of complex, large scale building and site engaging social, cultural, code, sustainable systems, and acoustic issues. Production of schematic and design development documents. ARCH majors only. Graduate standing only. A-F only.

title: Architecture Studio IV: Urban Design
description: Urban design focused on Asian cities investigating social, cultural, political, and technological factors; study of historical precedents, building/block typology, circulation, infrastructure, and context response. ARCH and LAND majors only. A-F only. 733 and 742, or 761.

title: Architecture Studio V: Comprehensive Design
description: Design and programming for a moderately complex building and site. Production of design development and partial construction documents describing sustainable building assemblies and construction cost. ARCH majors only. A-F only. 724, 725, 733, and 743. Co-requisite: 726.

title: Advanced Practice
description: Comprehensive study of architectural practice investigating architect’s response to global forces, including entrepreneurial practice, office organization, project delivery, compensation, and construction law. ARCH majors only. A-F only. 739 and 743.

title: (Alpha) Professional Studio
description: Scholarly and research activity combined with professional experience occurring in an off-campus location. (B) business; (C) community design; (E) alternative experience; (G) global; (H) Hawai‘i; (P) practicum; (T) China. Repeatable one time per alpha. ARCH majors only. Graduate standing only for (G), (H), and (T). A-F only. 744, and 750C or 750G for (B), (G), and (T); 744 and 745 for (H); 726, 744, 745, 750G, and 781 for (C), (E), and (P).
prerequisites: ARCH 744, and ARCH 750C or ARCH 750G for (B), (G), and (T); ARCH 744 and ARCH 745 for (H); ARCH 726, ARCH 744, ARCH 745, ARCH 750G, and ARCH 781 for (C), (E), and (P)

title: (Alpha) Research Studio in Professional Setting
description: Scholarly and research activity combined with professional experience occurring in an off campus location. (C) China; (G) global. ARCH majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. 743 for (C).

title: (Alpha) Architecture Studio
description: Urban design focused on investigating social, cultural, political, and technological factors; study of historical precedents, building/block typology, circulation, infrastructure, and context response. (C) China; (G) design research. A-F only. ARCH Global Track only. Graduate standing only. 744 for (C); 739 and 743 for (G).
prerequisites: ARCH 744 for (C); ARCH 739 and ARCH 743 for (G)

title: Research Seminar
description: Varied topics furthering knowledge and ability needed for professional design practice emphasizing communication methods for collaborative and integrated design using digital technologies. ARCH majors only. A-F only. 739.

title: Advanced Global Practice
description: Comprehensive study of architectural practice investigating architect’s response to global forces, including entrepreneurial practice, office organization, project delivery, compensation, and construction law. A-F only. 745.

title: Ecology, Community, and Design
description: Exploration of the interaction of landscape and community necessities in urban ecological design. Studio problems, design research projects, lectures, and discussion applied to the integration of ecological and social factors in urban contexts. LAND majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. 483 and 652.

title: Advanced Project Design Studio: Comprehensive
description: Design and programming for a complex, medium-scale, multi-layered urban landscape architecture project. Iterative, advanced design inquiry and materials exploration. Production of in-depth, comprehensive design development and partial construction documents. LAND majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. 634, 635, 743, and 761.

title: (Alpha) Capstone Studio
description: Advanced landscape architectural design inquiry and applied research investigation. Serves as a capstone experience, synthesizing theory, values, and practice. Limited to MLA students under Plan B. (D) design (6 credits); (R) research (3 credits). Repeatable one time per alpha, up to 18 credits. LAND majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. 743 and 763.

title: Architecture History
description: Investigation of architectural history and theory in the world from antiquity to present. Examining social, political, technological, material, and environmental forces. ARCH majors only. A-F only.

title: Advanced Research Methods and Design Inquiry
description: Individual development of a Doctorate Project or MArch Capstone proposal that advances architectural knowledge through analysis, research, scholarship, and design. ARCH majors only. A-F only. 739.

title: Case Study and Analysis
description: Individual development of a case study project that advances architectural knowledge through analysis, research, scholarship, design, and engages theoretical and architectonic propositions. ARCH majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. instructor consent.

title: (Alpha) MArch Capstone Studio
description: Advanced capstone architectural design research synthesizing theory and practice. (D) design; (R) research. MArch students only. A-F only. 716, 726, 744, and 745. Co-requisite: (R) for (D); (D) for (R).

title: (Alpha) Doctorate Project I
description: Individual development of a doctorate project with an approved chair and doctorate project committee that advances architectural knowledge through analysis, research, scholarship, and design; (H) Hawaii; (T) Tongji. Repeatable one time for (H). ARCH majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. 747C or 747P or 747E for (H); 750C or 750G for (T).
prerequisites: ARCH 747C or ARCH 747P or ARCH 747E for (H); ARCH 750C or ARCH 750G for (T)

title: (Alpha) Doctorate Project II
description: Individual development of a doctorate project with an approved chair and doctorate project committee that advances architectural knowledge through analysis, research, scholarship, design, and engages theoretical and architectonic propositions; (H) Hawaii; (T) Tongji. Repeatable one time for (H). ARCH majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. 784H for (H); 784T for (T).

title: Doctorate Project II Extension
description: Extension of the development of a doctorate project with an approved committee that advances architectural knowledge through research, scholarship, design, and engages theoretical and architectonic propositions. Repeatable one time. ARCH majors only. CR/NC only.

title: Introduction to the Visual Arts
description: Nature of the world’s visual arts and their influences on personal expression. Lectures, demonstrations, and studio practice. (Not for art majors or minors)

title: Introduction to the Visual Arts
description: Nature of the world’s visual arts and their influences on personal expression. Lectures, demonstrations, and studio practice. (Not for art majors or minors)

title: Introduction to Printmaking
description: Foundation explorations in the processes of relief, intaglio, and stencil printmaking. Direct workshop studio experience in the basic techniques and concepts of wood cut, linoleum cut, drypoint, monotype, and basic stencil processes.

title: (Alpha) Introduction to Photography
description: Studio/lecture combining history, theory and practice of photography. (B) film and darkroom, students must have 35mm film-based camera with adjustable shutter speed, aperture, and light meter; (D) digital, students must have digital camera with manual control and image editing software.

title: Introduction to Drawing
description: Descriptive, expressive, and formal aspects of visual language through drawing practice.

title: Introduction to Three-Dimensional Composition
description: Basic concepts, elements, and principles of art.

title: Introduction to Painting
description: Theory and practice of painting; material and technical procedures. A standalone course aimed at non-majors. ART majors should start with ART 223 after taking ART 113.

title: Introduction to Glass
