description: Basic techniques of working with cold and molten glass. Theory of glass studio operation and introduction to glass theory.

title: Survey of Global Art I
description: Art produced in Asia, Africa, Native America, Europe, and the Pacific Islands, from prehistory to the 15th century. Religious and philosophical ideas expressed in architecture, painting, prints, sculpture, applied art, body art, and textiles. (Fall only)

title: Survey of Global Art I
description: Art produced in Asia, Africa, Native America, Europe, and the Pacific Islands, from prehistory to the 15th century. Religious and philosophical ideas expressed in architecture, painting, prints, sculpture, applied art, body art, and textiles. (Fall only)

title: Survey of Global Art II
description: Art produced in Asia, Africa, Native America, Europe, and the Pacific Islands, from the 15th century to the present. Religious and philosophical ideas expressed in architecture, painting, prints, sculpture, applied art, body art, and textiles. (Spring only)

title: Survey of Global Art II
description: Art produced in Asia, Africa, Native America, Europe, and the Pacific Islands, from the 15th century to the present. Religious and philosophical ideas expressed in architecture, painting, prints, sculpture, applied art, body art, and textiles. (Spring only)

title: Introduction to Hawaiian Art
description: Integrated beginning studio art course, which offers students the opportunity to understand and express Hawaiian cultural perspectives through contemporary art practice. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Electronic Arts
description: Theory and practice course investigating language common to all arts activity particularly as related to the contemporary arts. any studio art course; or consent.
prerequisites: any studio art course; or consent

title: Introduction to Digital Imaging
description: Combined theory and practice examining major techniques, concepts, and aesthetics in contemporary digital image production. Direct studio experience in essential software, printing techniques and hardware necessary in producing the gallery quality inkjet print. A-F only. 113.

title: Intermediate Photo (Black and White Darkroom)
description: Black and white photography emphasizing communication and self-expression. Lectures, demonstrations, and projects. Student must supply camera and material. 107B (with a minimum grade of B).
prerequisites: ART 107B (with a minimum grade of B)

title: Intermediate Drawing
description: Extension of the observational foundation established in 113 to address contemporary conceptual and expressive approaches to drawing. 113 or consent.

title: Introduction to Life Drawing
description: Investigations of the figure concerning anatomical construction, light, space, diagramatic analysis, and thematic content. 113 or consent.

title: Intaglio Printmaking
description: Studio practice in concepts and techniques of making prints from metal plates including etching, engraving, aquatint, and drypoint. A-F only. 113.

title: Screenprinting
description: Studio practice in screenprinting on paper. Copy camera and basic photo-stencil techniques introduced. A-F only. 113.

title: Relief Printmaking
description: Studio practice in the techniques and concepts of woodblock, linoleum cut, monotype, and calligraph printmaking. Emphasis on both traditional and contemporary practices. A-F only. 113.

title: Approaches to Painting
description: Theory and practice of painting; contemporary conceptual and expressive approaches. 113.

title: Painting/Water-Based Media
description: An introduction to water-based media. Traditional transparent color, gouache and acrylics. 113 or consent.

title: Glass Casting: Sand and Metal Molds
description: Expressive explorations in glass casting with wet sand, bonded sand, and metal molds. Repeatable one time. 116 and 130.

title: Cold Glass Fabrication
description: Expressive explorations using architectural sheet glass. Development of 2D and 3D forms using engraving, sandblasting, and cold joinery techniques. Repeatable one time. 116 and 130.

title: Introduction to Ceramics
description: Three-dimensional concepts in clay; hand-building and wheel-throwing techniques. Projects, lectures, and demonstrations.

title: Sculpture—Metal Casting
description: Metal casting and development of associated practices and concepts. Repeatable one time. 116 or consent.

title: Sculpture—Carving, Mixed Media
description: Investigations of traditional and contemporary carving concepts and methods. Repeatable one time. 116 or consent.

title: Design: Studio I
description: Introduction to graphic design. Explorations of rhetorical and semiotic structures and their relationship to visual form and content. ART 176 is recommended as a A-F only. 113 or consent. Co-requisite: 265L and 266.

title: Design: Studio I Lab
description: Beginning instruction in the Macintosh computer environment, including hardware, software, and lab networking as it relates to graphic design production. ART 176 is recommended as a CR/NC only. 113 or consent. Co-requisite: 265 and 266.

title: Design: Typography I
description: Introduction to typography. Exploration of letterform and word compositions in the context of single-page structures. ART 176 is recommended as a A-F only. 113 or consent. Co-requisite: 265 and 265L.

title: (Alpha) Electronic Arts Studio
description: (6 Lec/ Lab) Combined theory and practice studio course(s) that investigate language, processes, and personalized composing systems related to the use of technological media and its application to a variety of contemporary art areas and related disciplines. (B) imaging systems; (C) sound; (D) interactive systems. 201 and one 200-level studio; or consent.
prerequisites: ART 201 and one ART 200-level studio; or consent

title: Introduction to Contemporary Critical Theory
description: Examination of the significant themes and issues in contemporary critical theory as they relate to the production and reception of art. 176 or consent.

title: Kiln-Formed Glass
description: Expressive explorations in the use of kiln-formed, fusible-sheet glasses and enameling on glass. Repeatable one time. 116 and 130.

title: Digital Imaging: Professional Printing
description: Combined theory and practice. Investigates industry standard methods for archival pigment printing. Techniques include: device calibration and profiling, black and white, coating techniques, mounting and adhesive techniques, professional portfolio presentation. A-F only. 202 (with a minimum grade of B).
prerequisites: ART 202 (with a minimum grade of B)

title: Digital Imaging: Alternative Printing
description: Combined theory and practice. Merges digital printing, mark-making, photography, and traditional printmaking. Includes image transfers, lifts, precoating techniques, as well as printing on alternative substrates such as watercolor papers, metals, and cloth. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 202 (with a minimum grade of B).
prerequisites: ART 202 (with a minimum grade of B)

title: Lost Wax Glass Casting
description: Glass kiln casting techniques, lost wax fuse casting, pâte de verre. Repeatable one time. 116 and 130.

title: Advanced Lighting
description: Emphasis on aesthetic and critical analysis. Techniques covered include continuous light, strobe and handheld flash. Repeatable one time with consent. 107D and 202 with a minimum grade of B.
prerequisites: ART 107D and ART 202 with a minimum grade of B

title: (Alpha) Advanced Photographic Techniques
description: Emphasis on aesthetic and critical analysis. (B) digital color photography and printing; (C) hand-applied emulsion. Each alpha is repeatable one time with consent. 107D and 202 with a minimum grade of B for (B); 202 and 207 with a minimum grade of B for (C).
prerequisites: ART 107D and ART 202 with a minimum grade of B for (B); ART 202 and ART 207 with a minimum grade of B for (C)

title: Sound Design and Video Art
description: Combined theory and practice studio art course examining the techniques, concepts, and aesthetics of congtemporary sound design and video art. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 202 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Advanced Drawing
description: Studio practice in drawing emphasizing contemporary developments in art. Repeatable one time. 213 or consent.

title: Intermediate Life Drawing
description: Further investigations of the figure concerning anatomical and diagramatic construction, light, space, and thematic content. Repeatable one time. 214 or consent.

title: Experimental Art and Animation
description: Provides students an opportunity to experiment with new mediums while collaborating with artists from different backgrounds, such as art, theatre, dance, film, and animation. SCA, ART, THEA, DNCE majors only. 113 or CINE 216 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 353 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 356 (or concurrent). (
prerequisites: ART 113 or CINE 216 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 353 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 356 (or concurrent)

title: Lithography
description: Studio practice in concepts and techniques of making prints from lithographic limestone and plates. (with a minimum grade of B) 215 or 217 or 218.
prerequisites: (with a minimum grade of B) ART 215 or ART 217 or ART 218

title: Intermediate Printmaking
description: Intermediate level specialization in either intaglio, lithography, screenprinting, or relief printmaking. Concentration on the techniques and formats of color printing and sequential image development. Repeatable two times. (with a minimum grade of B) two of 215, 217, 218, or 316.
prerequisites: (with a minimum grade of B) two of ART 215, ART 217, ART 218, or ART 316

title: Advanced Color
description: Theory and application of color as related to studio practice. 113.

title: Advanced Painting I
description: Studio practice in painting emphasizing contemporary developments in art. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 223 or consent.

title: Painting from Life
description: Painting from the model; a survey of the figurative tradition. Repeatable one time. 123 or 223, and 214.

title: Advanced Glass
description: Glass as an expressive medium. Individual problems; construction of studio equipment. Readings and discussions of contemporary glass issues. Repeatable one time. Two of the following: 230, 234, 303, 306.
prerequisites: Two of the following: ART 230, ART 234, ART 303, ART 306

title: Papermaking
description: Studio emphasis on handmade papermaking techniques, conceptual exploration in two and three dimensions. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 116 or consent.

title: Fiber Sculpture—Endurance and Impermanence
description: Studio exploration in contemporary dimensional fiber using both conventional and nonconventional materials and processes. Emphasis on concept development, sensitivity to the evocative potential of materials, context, surface treatment and its relationship to concept and structure. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 116 or consent.

title: Inter-woven Structures
description: Studio investigation of threads under tension. Thematic lens of environmental vulnerability and resiliency. Explores art practice as embodied knowledge. Specific attention to weaving as meaning and place-making. Engages writing as a significant tool for analysis. A-F only. 116 or consent. (Cross-listing as SUST 338)

title: Ceramics—Sculpture
description: Sculptural concepts and techniques specifically related to the medium of clay; advanced hand-building, throwing, glazing, and firing techniques. Repeatable one time. 242 or consent.

title: Ceramics—Vessels
description: Exploration of the ceramic vessel as function, metaphor, and expression. Advanced hand-building, throwing, glazing, and firing techniques. Repeatable one time. 242 or consent.

title: Ceramics—Low Temperature
description: Form and surface problems related to earthenware clay bodies and low-temperature glazes; mold-making for ceramics. Repeatable one time. 242 or consent.

title: History of Western Ceramics
description: Western ceramics history from chronological, developmental, contextual, and theoretical standpoints; influence of Asian ceramics. 242, with 175 and 176 recommended; or consent.
prerequisites: ART 242, with ART 175 and ART 176 recommended; or consent

title: Technical Ceramics
description: Clay body development, glaze development, empirical and calculation methods. Emphasis on glaze maturity, surface, and color. A-F only. 242, and one of 343, 344, or 345; or consent.
prerequisites: ART 242, and one of ART 343, ART 344, or ART 345; or consent

title: Sculpture—Figure Modeling
description: Figure modeling, mold making, and casting. Repeatable one time. 116 or consent.

title: Kinetic Sculpture
description: The design and construction of objects incorporating movement as an integral element of their content. Repeatable one time. 116 or consent.

title: Sculpture—Metal Fabrication
description: Metal fabrication and development of associated practices, concepts, and historical references. Repeatable one time. 116 or consent.

title: Sculpture—Small-Scale
description: Fabrication and casting of forms on a small scale such as jewelry. The development of related practices, concepts, and historical references. Repeatable one time. 116 or consent.

title: Utilitarian Sculpture
description: The design and construction of objects intended for use/interaction. Emphasis on wood and synthetic materials. Repeatable one time. 116 or consent.

title: Sculpture—Contemporary
description: Contextualization of late 20th/early 21st century sculptural practice, including stylistic and theoretical frameworks, with references to influences of various historical Western and Asian traditions and applying this knowledge in the creation of sculpture. 116 and 176, or consent.

title: Exhibition Design and Gallery Management
description: Design theory and techniques for presentation of artworks and mounting exhibitions. junior standing.

title: Art Museums and Preservation Practices
description: Introduction to collections management and preservation techniques, incorporating both theoretical and practical approaches, and including hands-on work with the collections of the John Young Museum. Junior standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Design: Studio II
description: Intermediate graphic design. Emphasis on communication problems involving process and analysis. Introduction to modernist precedents and information theory. A-F only. 113, 116, 175, 176, 265, 266; or consent. Co-requisite: 365L and 366.
prerequisites: ART 113, ART 116, ART 175, ART 176, ART 265, ART 266; or consent

title: Design: Studio II Lab
description: Intermediate instruction in the Macintosh computer environment, software, and peripheral devices, including intermediate layout. Introduction to graphic design industry standard multi-media and web design programs. CR/NC only. 265, 265L, and 266; or consent. Co-requisite: 365.
prerequisites: ART 265, ART 265L, and ART 266; or consent

title: Design: Typography II
description: Intermediate typographic design, exploration of word and text composition in the context of multiple-page structures. A-F only. 113, 116, 175, 176, 265, 266; or consent. Co-requisite: 365 and 365L.
prerequisites: ART 113, ART 116, ART 175, ART 176, ART 265, ART 266; or consent

title: (Alpha) Study Abroad-Studio Art
description: Intensive study of topics in studio art at a UH Mānoa approved study abroad institution. (B) introductory; (C) upper-division. Repeatable one time per alpha. A-F only. consent.

title: Medieval Art
description: Arts of Europe from early Christian era to Renaissance. 175 or consent.

title: Art of Greece and Rome
description: Minoan and Mycenaean arts; Greece and Rome. 175 or consent. (

title: Art of the 19th Century
description: Architecture, sculpture, and painting of Europe. 176 or consent.

title: Early Art of Japan
description: Major developments, prehistoric through Kamakura; architecture, painting, sculpture. 175 or consent.

title: Later Art of Japan
description: Major developments, Muromachi to modern period; painting, sculpture, architecture. 176 or consent.

title: Philippine Visual Art from Burial Jars to Burning Effigies
description: Introduction to the arts and material culture of the Philippines from the -colonial to the contemporary period through the examination of sculpture, metalwork, ceramics, textiles, and painting from various ethnolinguistic groups. Sophomore standing or higher. (
prerequisites: -colonial to the contemporary period through the examination of sculpture, metalwork, ceramics, textiles, and painting from various ethnolinguistic groups

title: Art of Korea
description: Ceramics, sculpture, painting, and architecture; neolithic through Yi periods. 175 or consent.

title: Art and Culture of Early China
description: A culturally oriented study of Chinese visual arts; emphasis on jade, bronze, secular and religious sculptures, and paintings from prehistory to the 9th century. 175 or consent.

title: Art and Culture of Late China
description: A culturally oriented study of Chinese visual arts; emphasis on the rise of literati painting and theory individualism in art and theory, garden, and architecture, and the Chinese pursuit of modernity and post-modernity in art. 176 or consent.

title: Sculpture of China
description: Thematic introduction to sculpture in China from the Neolithic period through the present day. A-F only. 175.

title: (Alpha) Study Abroad-Art History
description: Intensive study of advanced topics in art history at a UH Mānoa-approved study abroad institution. (B) introductory; (C) upper-division. Repeatable one time per alpha. A-F only. consent.

title: Art of Africa, Pacific, North America
description: Contextual study of art from selected areas in Africa, the Pacific, and North America. 176 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Art of Southeast Asia
description: Critical analysis of the historical and cultural development of Buddhist and Hindu art in Southeast Asia; (B) island Southeast Asia; (C) mainland Southeast Asia. Repeatable one time for different alphas. 175 or consent.

title: Art of India and South Asia
description: Art and architecture of South Asia in historical and cultural context. Art of India and South Asia. 175 or consent.

title: Art Historical Methodology
description: Introduction to the methods and approaches of art history. Students will develop skills in perception and comprehension of visual art forms, and a critical understanding of the methods used by art historians to analyze them. A-F only. 175 and 176 and consent.

title: (Alpha) History of Photography
description: History of photography from its beginnings to the present; emphasis on the evolution of photography as an art form; (B) nineteenth century, from the invention of photography through pictorialism; (C) twentieth century, from World War I to the present. Repeatable one time for different alphas. 176 or consent.

title: Directed Work
description: Individual projects; tutorial. Maximum: 3 credit hours per semester; total 3 for BA, 6 for BFA. two 200-level or above art courses in area of directed work, as well as consent of instructor and department associate chair
prerequisites: two ART 200-level or above art courses in area of directed work, as well as consent of instructor and department associate chair

title: (Alpha) Special Topics
description: Intensive and specialized work at advanced level in fields of special interest of visiting or resident faculty; (B) studio art; (C) art history. Repeatable three times per alpha, up to 12 credits. Junior standing or higher and instructor consent only.

title: Advanced Electronic Arts Studio
description: Tutorial studio that encourages exploration in combined and new media through independent work within an environment of theoretical and critical discourse. Repeatable one time. 301 or consent.

title: Professional Practice in the Arts: Creative, Career, and Leadership
description: Examination of the role of the artist in society, the artist as self, as community member, as teacher. Professional Practice skills in the arts; planning, grantsmanship, fundraising, budgeting, marketing, outreach, and media relations. ART majors only. Senior standing or graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Graduation Portfolio (BA)
description: Required graduation portfolio for BA Art History and Art Studio students. BA ART majors only. Undergraduates only. CR/NC only. To be taken during the semester prior to expected graduation.

title: BFA Capstone Seminar/Studio
description: In conjunction with the production of art for the BFA annual exhibition, this seminar will examine, critique, and evaluate the student’s art within the context of contemporary art, professional practices, exhibition theory, and integrate theoretical and practical issues in the life of an artist. BFA majors only. A-F only. BFA major or consent. (Spring only)

title: Use, Re-use, and Radical Re-use
description: Explores the related concepts of use, re-use, and radical re-use through an exploration of new applications of traditional fiber techniques and contexts of making. Engages writing as a significant tool for art-making and analysis. A-F only. 116 or consent. (

title: Installation/Performance–Material in Context
description: Studio investigation of the transformation of space (ecological, social, political, psychological) through artist intervention. Experiments in non-object based interventions and into the evocative potential of materials. Engages writing and oral expression as significant analytical tools. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 116 or consent. (

title: Early 20th Century American Art
description: American art in the first half of the 20th century and its impact on American culture. Junior standing or higher. 176 or consent.
crossListings: Alt. years: fall Crosslisted as AMST 460

title: Design: Studio III
description: Advanced graphic design. Emphasis on postmodernist theory, context, audience, and alternative media. BFA majors only. A-F only. 365, 365L, and 366; or consent. Co-requisite: 465L.
prerequisites: ART 365, ART 365L, and ART 366; or consent

title: Design: Studio III Lab
description: Advanced instruction in the Macintosh computer environment, including software and peripheral devices. Instruction in image manipulation and editing still video images for the web, CD, DVD, and portable interface devices. BFA majors only. CR/NC only. 365, 365L, and 366; or consent. Co-requisite: 465.
prerequisites: ART 365, ART 365L, and ART 366; or consent

title: Design: Typography III
description: Advanced typographic design. Exploration of 2D, 3D, electronic, and intermedia. Emphasis on contemporary typographic models. BFA majors only. A-F only. 365, 365L, and 366; or consent.
prerequisites: ART 365, ART 365L, and ART 366; or consent

title: Design: Production Techniques
description: Advanced techniques in design production from printed and digital media. BFA majors only. A-F only. 465, 465L, and 466; or consent. Co-requisite: 467L. (Spring only)
prerequisites: ART 465, ART 465L, and ART 466; or consent

title: Design: Production Techniques Lab
description: Advanced study of digital media for graphic designers. Focuses on skills and specific technical information to complement material covered in 467. BFA majors only. CR/NC only. 465 and 465L and 466. Co-requisite: 467. (Spring only)

title: Design: Advanced Studio
description: Individual and team investigations of complex problems in graphic design. Emphasis on projects with actual clients (when available) and/or independent investigations addressing advanced and current questions in the graphic design field. BFA majors only. ART majors only. A-F only. with a minimum grade of B- for (465 and 466) and credit for 465L. (Spring only)
prerequisites: with a minimum grade of B- for (ART 465 and ART 466) and credit for ART 465L

title: (Alpha) Renaissance Art
description: Painting, sculpture, and architecture: (B) early Renaissance in Italy; (C) northern Europe; (D) High Renaissance and mannerism in Italy. Repeatable one time for different alphas. 176 or consent.

title: Baroque and Rococo Art
description: Architecture, sculpture, and painting of Europe in the Baroque and Rococo periods. 176 or consent.

title: Art of the United States
description: Emphasis on the 18th and 19th centuries. 176 or AMST 202 or consent. (

title: Art of the First Half of 20th Century
description: Development of modern art in Europe 1900–1939. 176 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Art Since 1945
description: Art since 1945, with a focus on the global expansion of the avantgarde; (B) contemporary art 1945-2000; (C) global contemporary art since 2000. A-F only. 176 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Art of the Pacific
description: Visual form and function of the arts in cultural context: (B) Melanesia and Australia; (C) Polynesia and Micronesia; (D) North Pacific coast Indian, Eskimo. Repeatable one time for different alphas. 176 or consent.

title: Art of Tribal Africa
description: Visual form and function of arts in cultural context. Mali, Burkina Faso, Ivory Coast, Liberia, Guinea, Nigeria, Ghana, Cameroon, Congo, Zaire. 176 or consent.

title: Art of Indonesia
description: Architecture, sculpture, and textile traditions of indigenous Indonesia in cultural context. A-F only. 176.

title: Topics in Contemporary Art
description: Thematic approaches to contemporary art and visual culture. Course themes may include identity, local/global issues, and appropriation. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 176 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Art of Hawai‘i
description: Stylistic and aesthetic characteristics of art of ancient Hawai‘i; relationship to art from other parts of Polynesia. 176 or consent.

title: Museum Interpretations
description: Studies the interpretive strategies and methods used by museums to communicate with visitors in museums, art galleries, historic sites, parks, and related places. Considers how interpretations contribute to cultural knowledge. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Applied Art of Japan
description: Ceramics, metalwork, lacquer, and textiles throughout Japanese history. 175 and 176; or consent.

title: Contemporary Art and Ecology
description: Explores the recent history of environmental and ecological art; provides a critical framework for the contemporary image politics of environmentalism, ecology, sustainability, and climate change with an emphasis on writing and ethical reasoning. A-F only. 176 or consent.(

title: Contemporary Art in Hawai‘i
description: History of contemporary art in Hawai‘i: the institutions, artists, critics, and historians that have shaped it. Strong focus on oral history of Hawai‘i artists. A-F only. 176.

title: Traditional Chinese Painting
description: Stylistic and historic development of two-dimensional arts; painting and calligraphy from prehistory through 18th century. 175 or consent.

title: Modern and Contemporary Art of China
description: Introduction to the arts of China in the modern and contemporary periods, in all media and genres, from 1840 to the present. 176 or consent.

title: Genres of Japanese Cinema
description: History of Japanese cinema, including silent films, samurai films, monster films, and literary adaptations, analyzed through the lens of genre theory. Students demonstrate mastery of assigned readings and lecture content via weekly writing assignments. A-F only. 175 and 176. (Summer only)

title: (Alpha) Special Topics in Southeast Asian Art History
description: Focused study of particular periods, regions and critical themes in Southeast Asian art and architectural history. (B) Angkor & art of Khmer civilization; (C) art & architecture of Thailand; (D) monuments & nationalism in Southeast Asia. Repeatable one time for up to two different alphas. A-F only. 175, or consent. (Once a year) (D

title: Hindu Visual Culture
description: Art and architecture of South Asia in historical and cultural context. Hindu visual culture. 175 or consent.

title: Art of Islam
description: Major developments in art and architecture. 175 or consent.

title: Photography: Critical Issues
description: Seminar on theoretical, ethical and aesthetic issues relating to the practice of photography, past and present. A-F only. 396B or 396C, or consent.

title: History of Modern Design
description: Major design movements in Europe and America from late 19th century to present; arts and crafts movement, art nouveau, modernist trends of the 20th century. 176 or consent.

title: Topics in the History of Cinema
description: Specific period or national style of cinema studied in its historical context. Repeatable two times. A-F only. 176 or consent.

title: Graduate Studio Seminar in Art
description: Selected topics in art. A critique-based course with emphasis on the development of critical analysis, artistic research, and practice. Repeatable six times. ART majors only. A-F only. consent.

title: Methods in Contemporary Art
description: Examines processes of inquiry and experimentation within studio practice. Students explore a range of research methods as a way to challenge habitual methodologies and expand notions of art and art making. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Materials in Contemporary Art
description: Explores the physical, historical, symbolic, and contextual capacity of materials, as well as the mutually constitutive roles of artist and materials within the creative process. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Graduate Studio Teaching Practicum
description: Observation, analysis and participation in teaching a lower division course under the direction of an instructor in the student’s area of concentration. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 690, admitted to candidacy for MFA in art, and consent.
prerequisites: ART 690, admitted to candidacy for MFA in art, and consent

title: Art Historical Methodology
description: An introduction to art historiography, analytical techniques, and research methods and materials. consent and graduate standing.

title: Art of Oceania
description: Arts from Polynesia, Melanesia, Micronesia explored in context of issues involving belief systems and cultural change. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 475C or consent.

title: Topics in the Art of China
description: Research topics in the history of Chinese sculpture, ceramics, bronzes, jade, and textiles. A-F only. consent.

title: Seminar in Contemporary Critical Theory
description: Research and discussion seminar supporting advanced critical theory in the context of contemporary art and other creative practice. consent.

title: Seminar in Global Contemporary Art
description: Selected topics in global contemporary art history. Repeatable one time. A-F only. consent. (Alt. years)

title: Seminar in Western Art History
description: Selected topics in European and American art history. consent.

title: Directed Work
description: Advanced individual projects; advanced tutorial. Maximum: 3 credit hours per semester; total 6 for MA Plan A, 9 for MA Plan B, MFA students must petition OGE for permission to apply toward degree requirement. Repeatable unlimited times. consent of instructor and department chair.
prerequisites: consent of instructor and department chair

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Japanese Art
description: Selected topics in Japanese art history. consent.

title: Seminar in South/Southeast Asian Art History
description: Selected topics in South and/or Southeast Asian art and architectural history with an emphasis on Hindu and Buddhist traditions. Repeatable unlimited times. consent, repeatable with consent.

title: Orientalism and Visual Culture
description: Investigates artistic representations, appropriations, and exchanges constructed on the basis of East/Orient vs. West/Occident differences. Includes analysis of: Orientalizing artistic traditions throughout history, history and concept of Orient, post-colonial critique of Orientalism. A-F only. graduate standing or consent. (Alt. 2-3 years) (

title: Introduction to Asian Studies
description: Introductory course focuses on change and continuity in the history, culture, values, and political institutions of South, East, and Southeast Asia, and the region’s interrelationships with the rest of the world. A-F only.

title: Politics and Poetics of Climate Change in Asia
description: Examines the causes and impacts of, and responses to, climate change in Asia through interdisciplinary approaches: natural sciences, politics, economics, as well as legal, cultural, and creative/artistic dimensions. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Research and Writing in Asian Studies
description: Introduction to research and writing in Asian Studies provides a structured overview of the research and writing process from an interdisciplinary perspective, focused on Asia. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Introduction to Asian Studies: East Asia
description: Understanding East Asia through multidisciplinary approaches. Examines the interrelationship of policies, economy, literature, religion, the arts, and history as the basis for such an understanding.

title: Introduction to Asian Studies: South/ Southeast Asia
description: Understanding South and Southeast Asia through multidisciplinary approaches. Examines the interrelationship of policies, economy, literature, religion, the arts, and history as the basis for such an understanding.

title: East Asian Popular Cultures
description: East Asian popular culture, with a focus on Korea and Japan, as well as the Chinese language sphere. Analyzes social forces shaping pop culture industries, artists, and productions in the region from a global perspective. A-F only. (

title: Bollywood Dance, Music, and Film
description: Unique course combining mind and body, discussion and dancing. Learn and perform Bollywood dances and the richness of their Indian poetic, classical, and folk traditions. Understand “Bollywood” in the context of cross-cultural fusion and globalization. Repeatable one time. (

title: Career Pathways in Asian Studies
description: Explore the range of careers related to Asian Studies and develop skills and materials to build your academic success into a meaningful career. Students create a job search portfolio they can share with prospective employers.

title: Chinese Political Economy
description: Interdisciplinary review and analysis of the social and political issues in contemporary China, the interchange between state and society in national policies, the relationship between cultural tradition and technological modernization in the social transformation process. A-F only. Sophomore standing or higher. consent. (

title: Studying Asia Culturally
description: Multidisciplinary. Classics of literature, philosophy, and religion shaping Asian beliefs and values. 201 and 202 are recommended, but not required.
prerequisites: ASAN 201 and ASAN 202 are recommended, but not required

title: Contemporary Asia
description: Multidisciplinary examination of problems and issues affecting peoples and institutions of contemporary Asia: ethnic, language, religious, and cultural differences; population growth; public health; economic development; political and social change; environmental problems; etc. 201 and 202 are recommended, but not required.
prerequisites: ASAN 201 and ASAN 202 are recommended, but not required

title: (Alpha) Asia Past and Present
description: Multidisciplinary examination of major Asian countries; cultural, social, economic, and political lives of their peoples. (C) China; (I) South Asia; (J) Japan; (K) Korea; (O) Okinawa; (P) Philippines; (S) Southeast Asia; (Z) Other. Repeatable three times in different alphas.

title: The Way of Tea in Japanese History and Culture
description: History and culture of Japan as revealed in study and practice of the tea ceremony: Zen, aesthetics, calligraphy, architecture, ceramics, gardens, politics. Includes an emphasis on Oral Communication skills. (

title: Chado-the Way of Tea Practicum
description: Actual practice of the tea ceremony as history and culture of Japan. Repeatable one time.

title: (Alpha) Japanese Film: Art and History
description: Study and analysis of Japanese film; its history and relationship to cultural, social, philosophical, and aesthetic contexts. (B) 1900-1960; (C) 1960-present; (D) special topics. upper division standing or consent. (

title: Media, Advertising & Desire in East Asia
description: Examines concepts of beauty and desire in East Asian cultures within historical and contemporary media contexts. Uses critical theory and in-depth case studies to explore how images, language, and branding work in contemporary Asian societies. A-F only. ENG 100. (Summer only)

title: Chinese Film: Art and History
description: Study and analysis of Chinese film; its history and relationship to cultural, social, philosophical, and aesthetic contexts. (

title: Introduction to the Performing Arts of Southeast Asia
description: Introduction to the history and development of major performing arts genres in Southeast Asia: theatre, dance-drama, opera, music, puppetry, ritual, and modern spoken drama. Topics include cultural identity, multiculturalism, modernization, and tourism. Online course. (

title: Geography of Southeast Asia
description: An investigation of the development context of Southeast Asia including socioeconomic, cultural, and environmental resources. Problems and prospects for change. Sophomore standing or higher. (

title: Buddhist Philosophy
description: Survey of central thinkers and schools. (

title: Southeast Asian Literature in Translation
description: Survey in English traditional and modern literatures of Southeast Asia. A-F only. (

title: 20th-Century Chinese Women Writers
description: A survey and critical examination of contemporary Chinese women writers from China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. Traces a genealogy of women’s writing from the early 1920s up until now through novels, poetry, drama, and film. one DH or DL course, or consent.
prerequisites: one DH or DL course, or consent

title: (Alpha) Field Study in Asia
description: Students may submit proposals to have academic course work, field research, or work experience in Asia. See specific center for guidelines and procedures. (C) China; (I) South Asia; (J) Japan; (K) Korea; (P) Philippines; (S) Southeast Asia; (Z) Other. Repeatable one time. A-F only for (C), (I), (J), (S), and (Z).

title: Modern Philippines
description: Survey of major developments from -colonial through Spanish and American colonial periods, the revolution, Japanese occupation, and post-war republic. (
prerequisites: -colonial through Spanish and American colonial periods, the revolution, Japanese occupation, and post-war republic

title: Peace Processes in Philippines and Hawai‘i
description: History of Philippine Islam and the Moro struggle, the peace process in Mindanao and sovereignty movement for Hawaiian nation. 75 min. Lec, 75-min. joint online discussion with Philippine students. Junior standing only. A-F only. consent. (Fall only) (

title: Gender and Politics in U.S.-Okinawa Relations
description: Examines gender in Okinawa in relation to historical dynamics in the Asia-Pacific region with attention to issues such as militarism and violence, colonialism and memory, and tourism and commodification of indigenous culture. A-F only. WGSS 151 or consent. (

title: Comparative Muslim Societies in Asia
description: Will compare Muslim societies and cultures in Asia with each other and with the so-called “core” Middle Eastern Muslim societies. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Alt. years)

title: Resource Management in Southeast Asia
description: Challenges associated with the management of land, water resources, fisheries, forests and agriculture in modern Southeast Asia. Case studies are used to illustrate current problems and evaluate potential management solutions. A-F only. junior standing or higher. (

title: Korean Cinema
description: Develop an understanding of Korean culture and society through visual, narrative, and contextual analysis of Korean films. Topics include post-Korean War experience, compressed modernity, authoritarianism, and postauthoritarian transformation. Special attention to independent films. A-F only.

title: Contested Issues Korea and Japan
description: In-depth understanding of Korean-Japanese relations in the past and present by examining conflicting views and interpretations by Japanese, Korean, and Western scholars on important issues that divide the people of East Asia. A-F only.

title: Sustainable Asian Development: Impact of Globalization
description: Investigates the impact of globalization on sustainable development in Asia. Globalization and sustainability often contradict, raising serious planning issues. Examines how these issues affect Asian development policies and urban planning. 310 or 312 or PLAN 310, or consent. (
prerequisites: ASAN 310 or ASAN 312 or PLAN 310, or consent

title: Asian Cities: Evolution of Urban Space
description: Reviews the evolution of Asian urban space. Political history, migration, culture, and production are the determinants of urban changes. Uses visual material to illustrate the change in Asian cityscape. 310 or PLAN 310 or ASAN 312, or consent. (
prerequisites: ASAN 310 or PLAN 310 or ASAN 312, or consent

title: Southeast Asian Archaeology
description: Prehistory and protohistory of Southeast Asia and of Southeast Asian contacts with East Asia, India, Australia, and Oceania. junior standing or consent. (

title: Contested Issues in Contemporary Japan
description: Familiarizes students with public discourse in Japan by analyzing key current issues widely debated in the Japanese media and in public forums in light of their political, historical, cultural, social and economic contexts. A-F only. Previous course work related to Japan or Asia will be helpful.

title: Gender Issues in Asian Society
description: Construction of gender identities in contemporary Asia. How these interface with other aspects of social difference and inequality (e.g., with class, religion, ethnicity). (

title: K-pop and J-pop: Korean and Japanese Popular Music and Society
description: Examines modern Japan and South Korea through popular music. Examines genres from early popular music, today’s K-pop and J-pop music. A-F only. (Summer only)

title: Japan Cool: Anime, Manga, and Film
description: Focus on Japanese anime, manga, and films with an emphasis on oral communication. What can one learn about Japanese issues of gender, national identity, and race? A-F only. (Summer only)

title: Transpacific Youth Pop Culture: From K-pop to Tiktok
description: Examines ties between East Asian and Asian American digital media, including comics, movies, TV shows, music, and video games, to examine the dreams, fears, and aspirations of young Asians and Asian Americans. A-F only (Summer only)

title: Introduction to Contemporary Asian Cinema
description: Acquaint students with significant films from the major countries in Asia and how these films reflect and comment on profound social, political, and historical changes that have occurred in recent decades.

title: Topics in Chinese Cultural Studies: Visual Culture–Chinese Diaspora
description: Multidisciplinary and historically located study of Chinese culture through the examination of literary/visual texts and critical essays from cultural studies. Specific topics will depend upon term. Repeatable one time with consent. one DH or DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one DH or DL course or consent

title: Transnational Chinese Popular Culture
description: Survey of contemporary Chinese popular entertainment forms that are produced and appreciated transnationally. Examples include martial arts genres, kung fu films, commercial novels, ballroom dancing, karaoke culture, music videos and rock music. Material will be selected based upon availability and readings will include critical essays from the fields of popular culture, media studies, and literary criticism. any 300- or 400-level DL or DH course. (
prerequisites: any ASAN 300- or ASAN 400-level DL or DH course

title: Music Cultures: India
description: Approaches the cultural study of music and performance through a specific focus on South Asia. Junior standing or higher. consent. (

title: Culture and Economy of Southeast Asia
description: An exploration of the cultural and economic development of the countries of Southeast Asia from early times to the present day, with an emphasis on the effects of outside influences.

title: Film, Culture, and Modernity in Southeast Asia
description: Examines interplay between tradition and modernity; religion and secularism; individual and collective; youth, wisdom, and the world; and role of gender identification/community response as they find articulation in medium of film across Southeast Asia. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Asia Through Fiction
description: Explores core values and cultural principles of the four major Asian region as represented in major works of fiction from those regions. (Spring only)

title: Imperialism, Colonialism, and Nationalism in Southeast Asia
description: Theoretical and historical analysis of a global, nineteenth, and twentieth century phenomenon using an interdisciplinary approach organized around lectures, readings, and discussions. (Fall only)

title: Political Violence in Modern Southeast Asia
description: Why do Southeast Asian governments and political movements engage in mass killings? How do their perpetrators justify these atrocities? How do survivors deal with their trauma and get their voices heard? A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Contemporary Chinese Development
description: Development and planning in contemporary China: economic policy and institutional structure in the development and urbanization process; urban and rural transformation in a socialist economy. upper division standing or consent.

title: (Alpha) Topics in Asian Studies
description: Selected topics in Asian studies. (C) China; (G) Asia; (I) South Asia; (J) Japan; (K) Korea; (P) Philippines; (S) Southeast Asia; (Z) Other. Each alpha is repeatable two times.

title: Women and Revolution
description: Conditions under which women’s activism and participation in protest and revolutionary movements developed in the 19th- and 20th-centuries. Cross-cultural comparisons. (

title: Food, Culture, and Politics in Asia
description: Examines Asia’s role in the development of global foodways. Topics include the relationship between spices and imperialism, global popularity of Asian cuisines, Asian-influenced “hapa” cuisine in Hawai‘i, McDonaldization in Asia, and food security and sustainability. A-F only.

title: Religions of Island Southeast Asia
description: A comparative, interdisciplinary examination of indigenous beliefs, Islam, Christianity, and Hinduism in island Southeast Asia, and how they have been adjusted because of economic and social change.

title: Directed Reading
description: Repeatable three times. consent.

title: (Alpha) Approaches to Asian Studies
description: Major issues in and approaches to the interdisciplinary study of Asia and Asian regions; resources for the advanced study of Asia at UH; developing a research focus; preparing and presenting research proposals. (C) China; (I) South Asia; (J) Japan; (K) Korea; (P) Philippines; (S) Southeast Asia; (Z) Inter-Asia. graduate standing.

title: Advanced Research and Writing in Asian Studies
description: Provides a structured overview of research and writing process, focused on Asia. Topics include research questions, abstracts, literature reviews, arguments, conceptualization, incorporating evidence, research ethics, and style. Students are required to produce a research paper. 600 or consent.

title: Practicum in Asian Studies
description: Repeatable with consent up to nine credits.

title: Politics and Development: China
description: Consists of three parts: key theories for socialist transition as basis for seminar discussion, policy evolution to illustrate the radical changes, and emerging and prominent current development and practice. (

title: Comparative Muslim Societies in Asia
description: Will compare Muslim societies and cultures in Asia with each other and with the so-called “core” Middle Eastern Muslim societies.

title: Topics in 20th Century Chinese Literary and Cultural Studies
description: Critical scholarship in Chinese literature and cultural studies, broadly defined to include the People’s Republic of China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and others. Reading knowledge of Chinese desirable but not required. Repeatable one time with consent. consent. (

title: Problems/Issues of Contemporary Asia
description: Analysis from multidisciplinary perspective: rural development, urbanization, international relations, ethnicity, religion, language, etc. Repeatable one time with different topics.

title: Gender in Asian Performing Arts
description: Performance is a rich site for gender construction, critique, and articulation in Asia. This seminar examines gender reflected in traditional music, dance, and theatre, including character role and performer persona; approaches of performance and culture studies, and an “Asian way.” A-F only. (Once a year

title: Culture and Colonialism
description: Analysis of theories and debates (cultural studies, feminist writings, post-colonial issues). Case studies of the transformation and creation of “traditional” cultures under colonialism. 310 or 312, or consent.

title: Capitalism in Contemporary Asia
description: Historically grounded theoretical examination of capitalism in 20th-century Asia; multidisciplinary approach to fundamental change in political and economic structures and institutions, prospects for the future.

title: Ethnic Nationalism in Asia
description: Contemporary theories of ethnic and cultural nationalism from perspective of Asia. Issues of nationstate, power hierarchies, modernity, and identity in contemporary societies.

title: Asian Security Cultures
description: Comparative study of conceptualizations, practices and institutions of national security in Asia in light of their geographic and historic contexts. (Once a year)

title: Southeast Asia Now
description: Examines the ways global influences are shaping the cultural developments in the diverse societies of contemporary Southeast Asia. (Spring only)

title: Seafood in Southeast Asia
description: Seafood production in Southeast Asia, including both regional fisheries and aquaculture. Case studies used to illustrate challenges to the implementation of sustainable seafood production and emerging approaches, such as community supported seafood. (

title: Culture & Urban Form in Asia
description: Cultural and historical impact on urban form, contention of tradition and modernity in urban space, spatial expression of state and society, perception and utilization of urban design, evolution of urban form in selected Asian capitals. 312, ARCH 341, PLAN 310, or PLAN 600. (

title: Topics in Japanese Literature
description: Intensive study of selected topics in Japanese literature, primarily of the modern period. English translations of original texts will be provided whenever available. Repeatable unlimited times with consent. consent. (

title: Asian Cities: Historical Evolution of Urban Form
description: Examination of the impact of economy, society, and history on urban form; case studies of the evolution of Asian urban form. 312 or PLAN 310. (Once a year) (

title: Marriage and Family in East Asia
description: Examines gendered/generational practices, expectations, and ideologies of marriage, childrearing, and caregiving; state’s role in legitimizing certain kinds of families; how transnational marriage migration is changing notions of belonging, relatedness, and national identity in East Asia. Graduate standing or consent.

title: East Asia Now
description: Views East Asia as an interactive region. Examines common historical and cultural, economic and political themes including various experiences with the West. Focus upon present state of the region. A-F only.

title: Major Authors in Modern Korean Literature
description: Advanced study of major Korean fiction writers from the 1910s to the present with emphasis on critical reading of their lives and writings to arrive at informed appraisal of their contribution to modern Korean literature. Repeatable one time. KOR 494 or consent.

title: South Asia Now
description: Views South Asia as an interactive region. Examines common historical and cultural, economic, and political themes, including global interactions. Focus upon present state of the region. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Telecom and the Internet in East Asia
description: Offers interdisciplinary approach to study of internet and telecommunications in East Asia. Examines growth and development of telecommunications networks in China, Japan, South and North Korea. Focuses on contemporary social media and government policy. A-F only. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Topics and Issues in Modern Korean Literature
description: Intensive study of selected topics and issues in modern/contemporary Korean fiction, focusing on texts that problematize critical sociocultural issues in the evolving contexts of modern Korean intellectual history. Repeatable one time. KOR 494 or consent.

title: Special Topics in East Asian Literary Culture & Society
description: In-depth study of selected topics and issues in modern/contemporary East Asian literary and cultural studies using an interdisciplinary, inter-regional, and transnational approach, from an intercultural perspective. Repeatable two times in different topics, but need consent for second repeat. A-F only. consent. (

title: Southeast Asia and its Neighbors
description: Examines how Southeast Asian nations have recalibrated their international relationships in accordance with past experience and new concerns, focusing on interactions with Japan, China, and India, while integrating both global and domestic imperatives.

title: Law and Society in China
description: Overview of the historical foundations of Chinese law and introduction to the present legal system in the People’s Republic of China. Repeatable one time. (

title: Conflict and Cooperation in Asia
description: Explores conflict and cooperation among Asian nations. Topics may include economic integration, business networks, space and cyberspace, military alliances, territorial disputes, transnational crime, environmental cooperation, soft power, and regional institutional architecture. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Chinese Foreign Policy
description: Examination of China’s rise and world view, review of China’s regional relations, China and U.S. relations, formation of a new world order. 600, 608, or POLS 645C, or consent.
prerequisites: ASAN 600, ASAN 608, or POLS 645C, or consent

title: International Relations in Asia
description: How well do international relations theories explain interstate relations in Asia? How do international issues interact with domestic politics? Covers Japan, China, Korea, ASEAN nations, India, and touches on Russia, Australia, and New Zealand. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Field Study in Asia
description: With prior consent and supervision of an Asian Studies faculty, students design, conduct, and write the results of a field research project. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. Graduate students only.

title: Topics in Buddhist Studies
description: Seminar on selected topics in Buddhist studies. Repeatable three times. PHIL 360, PHIL 406, REL 475, or REL 490; or consent.
prerequisites: PHIL 360, PHIL 406, REL 475, or REL 490; or consent

title: Asian Studies Master’s Plan B Culminating Experience
description: Students work with their advisor to select, revise, and defend a portfolio of work produced in seminars before a three-person faculty committee. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. ASAN majors only. Graduate students only. any 600(Alpha) or 750(Alpha).

title: Directed Research
description: Individual problems and research. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable nine times.

title: Asian Research Materials and Methods
description: Bibliography, reference tools, and research methods in sources on Asia in Western and Asian languages. Discussion of published and archival repositories. Repeatable one time. (

title: MAIA Capstone
description: Capstone experience for MAIA students that emphasizes practical applications of Asia knowledge. Should be taken in final semester or after completion of all or most of MAIA core requirements. MAIA majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Orientalism and Visual Culture
description: Investigates artistic representations, appropriations, and exchanges constructed on the basis of East/Orient vs. West/Occident differences. Includes analysis of: Orientalizing artistic traditions throughout history, history and concept of Orient, post-colonial critique of Orientalism. A-F only. graduate standing or consent. (Alt. 2-3 years) (

title: Survey of Astronomy
description: Introduction to the astronomical universe: sky and celestial objects, planetary motion, planets and the Solar System, Sun and stars, the Milky Way and galaxies, cosmology and the universe.

title: Survey of Astronomy
description: Introduction to the astronomical universe: sky and celestial objects, planetary motion, planets and the Solar System, Sun and stars, the Milky Way and galaxies, cosmology and the universe.

title: Survey of Astronomy Laboratory
description: Observations of constellations and the night sky, the sun and moon, planets, stars, and deep-sky objects; laboratory and observational experiments illustrating basic concepts in astronomy. Offered in the evening. 110 (or concurrent), or consent.

title: Introduction to Archaeoastronomy
description: Astronomy and celestial lore in ancient cultures: Neolithic Europe, Mayan, Mesoamerican, Egyptian, Mesopotamian, American Indian, Chinese, and Polynesian. Concepts of the cosmos, calendars, eclipse predictions, motion of celestial bodies, and navigation. Construction of simple observing tools.

title: Voyage through the Solar System
description: An illustrated voyage through the Solar System based on recent scientific results. The class highlights the origin, evolution, and current knowledge of the eight planets, their moons, asteroids, comets, and one star, the Sun. Field trip. (

title: Introduction to Astronomical Research
description: Introduction to astronomical research, including literature resources, basic computing skills, software tools, data analysis, scientific communication, and research opportunities. Prepares students for effective internships and directed research projects. ASTR and ASTP majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Foundations of Astronomy
description: A rigorous overview of modern astronomy: solar system, stellar, galactic and extragalactic astronomy and cosmology. For science and engineering students. 110; PHYS 151 or PHYS 170.

title: Foundations of Astrophysics I: The Solar System
description: Solar system astrophysics. Dynamics of planets, satellite systems, asteroids and comets; planetary atmospheres and internal structure; thermal balance; the Sun as a star. Introduces numerical computing. A-F only. PHYS 170, MATH 242 or 252A, and PHYS 272 (or concurrent). (Fall only)
prerequisites: PHYS 170, MATH 242 or MATH 252A, and PHYS 272 (or concurrent)

title: Foundations of Astrophysics II: Galaxies and Stars
description: Stellar and galactic astrophysics. Stellar magnitudes, colors, distances, and spectra. Galactic structure and evolution, active nuclei, large-scale structure, Big-Bang cosmology. Stellar interiors, nuclear “burning,” main-sequence and evolved stars. Introduces computer programming. A-F only. 241, PHYS 274 (or concurrent), and MATH 243 (or concurrent) or 253A (or concurrent). (Spring only)
prerequisites: ASTR 241, PHYS 274 (or concurrent), and MATH 243 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent)

title: Evolution of the Universe
description: The Big Bang, origin of the elements, formation and evolution of galaxies and stars. 110 or 210 or 241 or 242, or consent
prerequisites: ASTR 110 or ASTR 210 or ASTR 241 or ASTR 242, or consent

title: Astrobiology
description: Are we alone in the universe? Modern astronomical, biological, and geological perspectives on this fundamental question. Searches for life on Mars, oceans on Europa, planets orbiting other stars. Space exploration and colonies, interstellar spaceflight and communication. 110 or 210, or consent. (Spring only)

title: Observational Astronomy
description: Principles and techniques of optical and near-infrared astronomical observation. Astronomical coordinate systems. Telescopes, cameras, spectrographs, and detectors. Astrometry, photometry, and spectroscopy of astronomical objects. A-F only. 210 or 242; PHYS 152 or 274; MATH 216, 242, or 252A. (Fall only)
prerequisites: ASTR 210 or ASTR 242; PHYS 152 or PHYS 274; MATH 216, MATH 242, or MATH 252A

title: Observational Astronomy Laboratory
description: Optical and near-infrared astronomy laboratory. Error analysis, properties of light, data, and image processing. Astrometric, photometric, and spectroscopic measurement. A-F only. 300 (or concurrent); PHYS 152 or 274; PHYS 152L or 274L; MATH 216, 242, or 252A. (Fall only)
prerequisites: ASTR 300 (or concurrent); PHYS 152 or PHYS 274; PHYS 152L or PHYS 274L; MATH 216, MATH 242, or MATH 252A

title: Observational Astronomy Projects
description: Astronomical observational research projects. Students use astronomical data and process telescopic observations to produce scientific results, and present these orally and in writing. Students prepare for independent research projects and present research plans orally. A-F only. 300 and 300L. (Spring only)

title: Astronomical Spectroscopy
description: Introduction to astronomical spectroscopy. Stellar atmospheres, line formation, elements of radiative transfer. Phases of interstellar medium. Emission line diagnostics. Doppler shift and kinematics. A-F only. 210 or 242; PHYS 152 or 274; MATH 216 or 242 or 252A. (Spring only)
prerequisites: ASTR 210 or ASTR 242; PHYS 152 or PHYS 274; MATH 216 or MATH 242 or MATH 252A

title: Modern Extragalactic Astronomy
description: Use of astronomical surveys to map large-scale distribution of galaxies. Internal structure & dynamics of galaxies. Evolution of galaxy populations over cosmic time. Theoretical understanding of galaxy formation in context of modern Big Bang cosmology. 210 or 242; and 300 (or concurrent); and PHYS 152 or PHYS 274. Recommended: 280. (Alt. years: spring)
prerequisites: ASTR 210 or ASTR 242; and ASTR 300 (or concurrent); and PHYS 152 or PHYS 274

title: History of Cosmology and Scientific Thought
description: History and intellectual context of astronomical discovery; the evolution of ideas of space, time, and motion from the Babylonians to relativistic cosmologies; emphasis on the interaction of astronomy with the history of ideas. any ASTR or PHYS course. (Spring only)

title: Directed Study
description: Individual reading, observation, or experimentation in astronomy and astrophysics. Repeatable four times. consent.

title: Stellar Astrophysics
description: Advanced survey of stellar astrophysics, including application of astrometry, photometry, and spectrometry to determine fundamental stellar properties; stellar structure and evolution of single and binary stars; astrophysical distance determination methods; stellar nucleosynthesis. 242 and 300, and PHYS 480.

title: Galaxies & Cosmology
description: Survey of extragalactic astronomy and cosmology, including: galaxy morphology and kinematics; luminosity functions; dark matter; properties of galaxy groups/ clusters; gravitational lensing; redshifts; cosmological models; the Big Bang; thermal history of the Universe; structure formation. A-F only. 300 (or concurrent); PHYS 152 or PHYS 274; MATH 216 or MATH 242 or MATH 252A. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: ASTR 300 (or concurrent); PHYS 152 or PHYS 274; MATH 216 or MATH 242 or MATH 252A

title: The Solar System
description: Observations and physical nature of planets and moons, asteroids, comets, and other small bodies; formation of the Solar System; discovery of other planetary systems; solar activity. 300; and PHYS 152 or 274; and MATH 216, 242, or 252A. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: ASTR 300; and PHYS 152 or PHYS 274; and MATH 216, MATH 242, or MATH 252A

title: General Relativity & Cosmology
description: Introduction to general relativity & cosmology. Spacetime metrics, geodesics, Einstein field equations, black holes. Geometry of the universe, redshift, cosmological distances. Cosmological models, dark matters, dark energy. Big Bang nucleosynthesis, recombination, cosmic microwave background, inflation. PHYS 274; MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent). Recommended: 242. (Alt. years: fall) (
prerequisites: PHYS 274; MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent)

title: Senior Research Project
description: Seminar focusing on development of professional skills for astronomical research, and on scientific writing as a tool for organizing research. A final paper describing a supervised research project is required. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 301; 399 (or concurrent) or PHYS 399 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: ASTR 301; ASTR 399 (or concurrent) or PHYS 399 (or concurrent)

title: Being a Professional Astronomer
description: Seminar for beginning graduate students focusing on professional skills needed for astronomy and discussing possible research opportunities. Repeatable one time. ASTR majors only. Graduate students only. CR/NC only. (Fall only)

title: The Interstellar Medium
description: Astrophysics of diffuse matter, HII regions, molecular clouds, etc. consent. (Alt. years)

title: Stellar Interiors and Evolution
description: Structure and evolution; energy sources, radiative processes; relations to observables. consent. (Alt. years)

title: Galaxies
description: Observations and stellar dynamics of elliptical and spiral galaxies including our galaxy, globular clusters, and dark matter. Galaxy formation and evolution. consent. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Cosmology
description: Geometry and evolution of the universe. Dark matter. Early universe. Formation of large–scale structure, galaxies, and clusters. Cosmological models. consent. (Alt. years)

title: The Solar System
description: Survey of observational data and physical concepts on planets and smaller bodies; formation of planetary systems; solar activity. consent. (Alt. years)

title: Radiative Transfer Stellar Atmospheres
description: Excitation, ionization, and radiative transfer in stellar atmospheres; model atmospheres, formation of line and continuum radiation. consent. (Alt. years)

title: Astrophysical Techniques
description: Telescopes, positional astronomy, photon detection, error analysis, photometry, spectroscopy. consent. (Fall only)

title: Astronomical Instrumentation
description: Design and operation of astronomical instrumentation. Physics of optical and infrared detectors. Wavefront sensors and adaptive optics. Radio and infrared interferometry. Optical design: methods and software. A-F only. 633 (with a minimum grade of B-). (Alt. years: spring)
prerequisites: ASTR 633 (with a minimum grade of B-)

title: Fundamentals of Astrophysics
description: Applications of fundamental physics to astrophysical situations. Elements of general relativity. Basics of hydrodynamics and shock waves. Radiative processes, high energy astrophysics. Modern dynamics. consent. (Fall only)

title: General Relativity
description: Introduction to gravity and general relativity. Tensor basics, classical scalar, vector and tensor field theories. Exact symmetric Einstein equation, gravito-magnetic weak field, and radiation solutions. consent. (Alt. years)

title: Active Galaxies
description: Phenomenology of active galactic nuclei, black holes, accretion flows and jets, emission mechanisms, host galaxies, and cosmic evolution. 635 or consent. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Astrochemistry-A Molecular Approach
description: Formation of astrobiologically important molecules and their precursors in the interstellar medium and in our solar system: first principles and latest trends. consent. (Fall only) (

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Astronomy Seminar I
description: Selected advanced topics in astronomy and astrophysics. Available for 1 to 3 credit hours by arrangement. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Astronomy Seminar II
description: Selected advanced topics in astronomy and astrophysics. Available for 1 to 3 credit hours by arrangement. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Astronomy Seminar III
description: Selected advanced topics in astronomy and astrophysics. Available for 1 to 3 credit hours by arrangement. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Astrobiology Seminar: Origin, Evolution and the Role of Water for Life in the Universe
description: Interdisciplinary research topics in astrobiology as they relate to the theme of water: formation in space, role in creating -biotic molecules, delivery to earth, and terrestrial planet habitability. Repeatable three times. graduate level sciences and ideas, or consent.
prerequisites: -biotic molecules, delivery to earth, and terrestrial planet habitability

title: Scientific Grant Writing
description: Principles of scientific grant writing are taught by working on draft proposals through a mix of lectures, discussions, and hands on activities. The final proposal will be reviewed and evaluated via a review panel. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Programming and Algorithms for Astronomers
description: Distillation of modern computer science fundamentals and paradigms, with applications to astronomy. Common algorithms and essential programming techniques. Assignments include extensive Python programming practice. Open to graduate students in any physical science. Graduate students only. (Alt. years)

title: Modern General Relativity
description: Differential geometry, special relativity, Einstein equations, gravitational phenomena, equivalence principles, black holes, gravitational waves, cosmology, relativistic stars, experimental tests, computational techniques. Graduate students only in PHYS or ASTR. (Alt. years: fall) (

title: Star Formation
description: Molecular clouds, collapse processes, physics of circumstellar disks and accretion, properties of young stars, outflows and jets, formation of binaries, extrasolar planets and planet formation, meteorites and the early solar system. graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Astro-ph Seminar
description: Seminar discussions of the most recent research papers covering all areas of astronomy. Student lead discussion sessions and discuss papers of their choice during the semester. ASTR majors only. Graduate students only. CR/NC only. (Fall only)

title: Cosmology Seminar
description: Students and researchers will review and discuss the most important and exciting cosmological results in depth. ASTR and PHYS majors only. Graduate students only.

title: Stars and Planets Lunch and Talks (SPLAT) Seminar
description: Seminar for graduate students and researchers discussing the latest results on solar, stellar, and exoplanet research. Repeatable one time. ASTR majors only. Graduate students only. CR/NC only.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times

title: Introduction to Weather and Climate
description: Introductory physical science course for all undergraduates in any major. A non-mathematical introduction to basic atmospheric variables, Earth’s past climates, global warming, air pollution, El Nino, hurricanes, tornadoes, and forecasting weather in Hawai‘i.

title: Introduction to Weather and Climate Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Exercises with meteorological data and measurement systems. Characteristics of Hawaiian winds, temperatures, and rainfall

title: Pacific Climates and Cultures
description: Highlights the interface between the observed weather and climate of the Pacific and the past and future culture of the people of the Hawaiian and Pacific islands. A-F only. (Alt. years)

title: Introduction to Quantitative Earth and Environmental Science
description: Introduction to -calculus math and physics applied to Earth and environmental science. Students work on real-world problems and engage in participatory learning. Preparatory for classes in calculus and physics. MATH 134, 161, or MATH assessment exam (with score required for MATH 140X). (Fall only) (
prerequisites: -calculus math and physics applied to Earth and environmental science

title: Introduction to MET Undergraduate Directed Research
description: Students gain familiarity with ATMO research. Students can select 1-3 credits per semester for maximum 6 credits over 4 semesters. Students must -arrange research and reading content with instructor. Repeatable three times, up to six credits. Freshman and sophomore standing only. CR/NC only. instructor approval.
prerequisites: -arrange research and reading content with instructor

title: Atmospheric Processes and Phenomena
description: Atmospheric variables, gas laws, radiation processes, thermodynamics, conservation laws, dynamic approximations, clouds and precipitation, convection, atmospheric circulations, mid-latitude and tropical weather systems, forecasting, climate. PHYS 170 (or concurrent).

title: Atmospheric Physics
description: Energy and thermodynamics, statics and stability, physical processes of cloud formation, radiation and Earthatmosphere heat balance, kinetic theory, optical effects. 200, MATH 242, and PHYS 272; or consent.
prerequisites: ATMO 200, MATH 242, and PHYS 272; or consent

title: Introduction to Atmospheric Dynamics
description: Scalar and vector development of basic laws of hydrodynamics, equations of motion, kinematics, divergence and vorticity, viscosity and turbulence, introduction to numerical weather prediction, general circulation. 302 and MATH 244.

title: Global and Local Perspectives on Severe Weather
description: Dynamics and structure of the main types of severe weather (tropical cyclones, supercell storms, tornadoes, flash floods, hailstorms, fog, etc.); future changes due to climate change; risk assessment; severe weather in Hawai‘i. ATMO, GES, GG, GEO, GES, NREM, or OCN students only. A-F only. (Alt years: Spring) (

title: Meteorological Instruments and Observations
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Each week targets a different meteorological instrument and culminates in a lab exercise and report. The focus is on accurate measurement and scientific-style writing. A-F only. 302 and PHYS 272/272L

title: Global Environmental Change
description: Global environmental change problems such as carbon dioxide and the greenhouse effect, acid rain, chlorofluorocarbons and the ozone layer, global deforestation and the effect on climate, etc. 200, OCN 201, ERTH 101, ERTH 103, or ERTH 170; or consent. (
prerequisites: ATMO 200, OCN 201, ERTH 101, ERTH 103, or ERTH 170; or consent

title: Programming for Meteorologists
description: Scientific programming in Fortran 77, graphics software and meteorological applications. A-F or Audit. 302 (or concurrent) and MATH 241; or consent.
prerequisites: ATMO 302 (or concurrent) and MATH 241; or consent

title: Undergraduate Internship
description: Experiential approach to earth science; students serve as interns to field professionals; responsibilities include supervised field work. Open to undergraduate SOEST majors. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. junior/senior standing and consent. (Fall only)

title: Undergraduate Directed Reading
description: Individual reading in Atmospheric Sciences. Repeatable one time, up to three credits. ATMO students only. Junior and senior standing only. A-F only. consent

title: Applied Atmospheric Dynamics
description: Advanced concepts in dynamics: vorticity, cyclogenesis, jet streams, fronts, mesoscale circulations. 303.

title: Synoptic Satellite Meteorology
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Satellite applications to synoptic meteorology and forecasting, including orbital elements, ephemerides, viewing geometry, radiation, satellite sensors, and interpreting satellite data. 302.

title: Tropical Meteorology
description: History; tropical clouds and hydrometeors; typhoons; monsoons; local and diurnal effects. 303.

title: Meteorological Analysis Lab
description: (2 4-hr Lab) Techniques and methods of forecasting extratropical systems with analyzing atmospheric structure and weather systems. Students will be instructed on how to communicate and discuss a weather forecast and how to present a research paper. 303 or concurrent. (Alt. years)

title: Tropical Analysis Lab
description: (2 Lec 2 3-hr Lab) Techniques of portraying and analyzing atmospheric structure and weather systems in tropical and equatorial regions; forecasting tropical systems. 303 or concurrent.

title: Climate Modeling, Data Analysis, and Applications
description: Introduction to regional and global climate modeling for environmental scientists and engineers. Learn principles of climate modeling, how to access and use climate data for sustainable engineering and environmental management solutions, and effectively communicate results. A-F only. Senior standing or higher, or consent. (

title: Undergraduate Thesis
description: Capstone for senior Meteorology majors. Undergraduate thesis project includes literature review, experiment or research design, data collection and analysis, technical writing of a final thesis paper and oral presentation of the paper. Junior and senior standing only. A-F only. 302, 303 (or concurrent).

title: Atmospheric Dynamics I
description: Governing equations for moist atmospheric motions, approximations, basic theoretical models, boundary layer dynamics, atmospheric waves, quasi-geostrophic theory for mid-latitudes. 402, and either MATH 402 or MATH 405; or consent.
prerequisites: ATMO 402, and either MATH 402 or MATH 405; or consent

title: Atmospheric Dynamics II
description: Overview of dynamic meteorology, numerical weather prediction, geophysical fluid instabilities, approximate dynamical systems, atmospheric general circulation, stratospheric dynamics. 600 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Cumulus Dynamics
description: Dynamics of convective systems: tornadoes, waterspouts, squall lines. Interactions with synoptic scale. 620 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Mesoscale Meteorology
description: Scale analysis. Observational and theoretical aspects of mesoscale circulation systems. 600 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Tropical Climate and Weather
description: Climate and general circulation of the tropics; El Niño and Southern Oscillation; intraseasonal oscillation; trade winds; tropical weather systems; energy balance; typhoons. 303 or consent.

title: Satellite Data Applications
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr. Lab) Principles and practices of satellite remote sensing as used in the atmospheric sciences, specifically clouds, aerosols, precipitation, ocean and land cover datasets from various satellites.
