Develop skills including data manipulation, analysis, and visualization using Matlab. A-F only. 620 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Tropical Cyclones
description: Lecture covering fundamentals of tropical cyclone structure, motion, and impacts on society. Observations from satellites, aircraft, ships and buoys, and numerical simulations focusing on storm structure and track. Some forecasting exercises. Repeatable one time. 600 and 610, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Monsoon Meteorology
description: Synoptic components of monsoons, regional and temporal variability, numerical models, research exercises. 610 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Physical Meteorology
description: Molecular kinetics, atmospheric thermodynamics, cloud physics, precipitation processes, atmospheric electricity, scattering and absorption of solar radiation, absorption and emission of infrared radiation, radiative transfer. 302 or consent.

title: Radar Meteorology
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Radar hardware, electromagnetic propagation and scattering, radar equation, signal processing, precipitation estimation and polarimetric applications, Multi-Doppler wind synthesis, mobile and spaceborne radars, forecasting, and data assimilation applications. A-F only. 620 (with a minimum grade of B- or higher) or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: ATMO 620 (with a minimum grade of B- or higher) or consent

title: Statistical Meteorology
description: Probability; frequency distributions of atmospheric variables; linear models; time series analysis (frequency and time domain); principal component analysis; statistical weather forecasting and verification. MATH 371. (Alt. years)

title: Advanced Statistical Methods in the Geosciences
description: Methods for numerous multivariate analyses will include singular spectrum, extended empirical orthogonal function, singular-value decomposition, canonical correlation, discriminant and cluster analysis. Other advanced topics include wavelet analysis, statistical downscaling and Bayesian analysis. A-F only and audit. 631 or consent. (Every 3rd year)

title: Paleoclimate Model-Proxy Synthesis
description: Basics of Earth System Model development, parameterizations, intermodel variability and design of paleoclimate simulations. Types of proxies, tools and techniques for paleoclimate record development and reconstructions. Hypothesis testing and methods for proxy-model comparison studies. ATMO, GEO, EPET, NREM, OCN, and ORE majors only. Graduate students only. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Small-Scale Air-Sea Interaction
description: Observations and theory of small-scale processes which couple the atmosphere and ocean boundary layers, including introduction to turbulence theory and parameterization of turbulent fluxes. MATH 402 and 403 (or their equivalents) and either 600 or OCN 620; or consent. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: MATH 402 and MATH 403 (or their equivalents) and either MATH 600 or OCN 620; or consent

title: Large-Scale Ocean-Atmosphere Interactions
description: Lecture/seminar introduces physical oceanography and meteorology students to the stateof-the-art theories and observations of large-scale ocean-atmosphere interaction, as well as conveying the fundamental understanding that has been developed during the past 30 years. Emphasis will be on phenomena such as El Niño/Southern Oscillation, the North Atlantic Oscillation, the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, and global climate change. Repeatable one time. 600 or OCN 620, or consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Numerical Weather Prediction
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Fundamental methods and techniques in numerical weather prediction: time differencing, spatial finite differencing, spectral methods, numerical stability, explicit and implicit methods. Modern operational and research forecast models. Hands-on laboratory includes simple to complex dynamic models, with a term project. Repeatable one time. 600 or OCN 620; MATH 407 or 408; or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: ATMO 600 or OCN 620; MATH 407 or MATH 408; or consent

title: Climate and Climate Variability
description: Physical basis of climate, numerical climate models, paleoclimatic indicators, modern instrumental climate records, assessment of human impact on climate, predictions of future climate. Repeatable one time. 600 or OCN 620, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Tropical Climate Dynamics and Modeling
description: Overview of current progress in tropical climate dynamics with a particular focus on large-scale atmosphere-ocean interactions; introduction of basic numerical techniques for students to construct and run immediate tropical atmosphere and ocean models. 600.

title: General Circulation of the Atmosphere
description: Theory, observations, large-scale analyses, and global model simulations that describe characteristic large-scale circulation of the Earth’s atmosphere. Includes zonally averaged climatology, asymmetric features of the general circulation, and El NinoSouthern Oscillation phenomenon. Repeatable one time. 600 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Special Topics in Meteorology
description: Concentrated studies on selected atmospheric problems. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits. 600 or consent.

title: Seminar in Meteorology
description: Participation in departmental seminars and presentation of a seminar on research results. Includes written critiques of departmental seminars. Repeatable three times. consent.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Introduction to Sustainable Engineering
description: Sustainability and its social and technical significance; global population growth; resource management and quantification; designs for sustainable society; challenges interfacing technology and culture/religion; green and ecological engineering; life cycle analyses; engineering ethics; selected case studies. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Introduction to Quantitative Biology
description: Quantitative approach to applied topics in biology including synthesis and metabolism, kinetics, physiological systems, cellular processes and signaling, informatics, and emerging technologies for health, biological production/processing, and discovery. MATH 241 (or concurrent) and CHEM 162 (or concurrent), or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: MATH 241 (or concurrent) and CHEM 162 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Introduction to Biological Engineering
description: Discussion and experimental investigation of physical and chemical principles underlying representative biological processes and systems. Bioproduction, energy conversion processes, physiological systems, biological treatment, biosensors, biomechanics, and related natural and engineered systems. A-F only. MATH 140X or consent. (Once a year)

title: Introduction to Applications in Biological Engineering
description: Discussion and investigation of special topics, problems and applications of biological engineering. consent.

title: Mass and Energy Balances
description: Introduction of the principles of mass and energy conservation; development of systematic approaches to apply these principles in calculations for design and analysis of biochemical, chemical, and physical processes. (BIOL 171, CHEM 162 or 171 or 181A, PHYS 170, and MATH 242 or 252A) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent.
prerequisites: (BIOL 171, CHEM 162 or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A, PHYS 170, and MATH 242 or MATH 252A) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent

title: Dynamic Systems Modeling
description: Introduction to analytical and numerical solutions for systems of differential equations. Modeling and computer simulation of representative dynamic systems encountered in biological engineering. A-F only. (260, ECE 110 or 160, MATH 243 or 253A, CEE 270) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent. Co-requisite: BE 350L.
prerequisites: (BE 260, ECE 110 or ECE 160, MATH 243 or MATH 253A, CEE 270) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent

title: Dynamic Systems Modeling Laboratory
description: Industry field trips and lab experiences to illustrate behavior of representative dynamic systems in biological engineering. Data acquisition and model validation. A-F only. Co-requisite: 350.

title: Transport Phenomena
description: Fundamental principles and applications relating to mass, momentum, and energy transfers in biosystems and other systems for engineers and scientists. 260, CEE 270, MATH 243 or 253A, ME 311 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: BE 260, CEE 270, MATH 243 or MATH 253A, ME 311 (or concurrent)

title: Engineering Economics
description: Economic analysis in engineering and management decision-making, interest, depreciation, income tax, cost classification, break-even analysis, economic comparisons of alternatives, benefit-cost analysis. BENG, CE, CEM, CNST, ECE, and ME majors only. A-F only. ECON 120 (with a minimum grade of C-) or 130 (with a minimum grade of C-), and senior standing. (
prerequisites: ECON 120 (with a minimum grade of C-) or ECON 130 (with a minimum grade of C-), and senior standing

title: Biomass Conversion to Biofuels and Bioenergy
description: Overview of biofuel/bioenergy production; fundamental concepts in biofuel/ bioenergy production; renewable feedstocks; thermochemical and biochemical conversions of biomass to biofuel/bioenergy; biodiesel production; environmental impacts, economics and life-cycle analysis; value-added processing of biofuel residues; selected case studies. A-F only. 373 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: BE 373 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent

title: Food Engineering
description: Principles and applications of thermodynamics, electricity, fluid mechanics, heat transfer, psychrometry, and material and energy balances of food processing and preservation. (BIOL 171, CHEM 162 or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A, MATH 243 or MATH 253A, PHYS 151 or PHYS 170) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: (BIOL 171, CHEM 162 or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A, MATH 243 or MATH 253A, PHYS 151 or PHYS 170) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Sensors and Instrumentation for Biological Systems
description: Design course focused on fundamentals of electronic interfacing, control and automation, including biological processes. Topics include sensor physics, basic instrumentation, digital communication, and programming of microcontrollers and other portable computer systems. (ECE 160, ECE 211, and BE 350 or MATH 302 or MATH 307 or ECE 326) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (
prerequisites: (ECE 160, ECE 211, and BE 350 or MATH 302 or MATH 307 or ECE 326) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Environmental Biotechnology
description: Environmental impact and control; the microorganism and its nutrition and growth conditions; microbial growth and substrate removal kinetics; bioreactors; biological treatment systems; biodegredation of xenobiotic organic chemicals; case studies. A-F only. 373 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Biosystems Unit Operations
description: Introduction to unit operations in biological, environmental, food, and manufacturing processes. Integration of biology and chemistry into engineering using basic concepts in mass and energy conservation and transport in reacting and non-reacting systems. A-F only. (373; and either CEE 320 or ME 322) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent.
prerequisites: (BE 373; and either CEE 320 or ME 322) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent

title: Bioremediation: Principles and Practices
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Soil environment, fate and transport of contaminants; microbial ecology, metabolism, and energy production; biodegradation of selected compounds. In situ treatment, solid-phase bioremediation, slurry-phase bioremediation, and vapor-phase biological treatment. Open to nonmajors. Repeatable one time. 260, CHEM 161, PHYS 170; or consent.

title: Bioreactor Design and Analysis
description: Application of mass/energy balances and reaction kinetics for the design and analysis of bioreactors for microbial, plant, and animal cell cultures. 373 or CEE 320 or ME 322; or consent. (
prerequisites: BE 373 or CEE 320 or ME 322; or consent

title: Bioprocess Design and Analysis
description: Combined lecture/computer lab on theory and practice of bioprocess design and analysis, involving biological basics and engineering principles of bioprocessing, computer-aided unit operations, process integration, and economic evaluation. A-F only. 373, or 437 (or concurrent) or 460 (or concurrent); or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: BE 373, or BE 437 (or concurrent) or BE 460 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Senior Engineering Design I
description: (1 1-hr Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) First course in a two-semester major open-ended design experience for senior students in biological engineering, with heavy emphasis on teaching written/oral engineering communication. Design process; project management; methodology; modeling; optimization; engineering economics. A-F only. (350/350L, 373, CEE 320 (or concurrent) or ME 322 (or concurrent), ME 311, ECE 211) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent.
prerequisites: (BE 350/BE 350L, BE 373, CEE 320 (or concurrent) or ME 322 (or concurrent), ME 311, ECE 211) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent

title: Senior Engineering Design II
description: (1 1-hr Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Continuation of 481 with emphasis on written/oral communication and engineering ethics. Properties of biological materials; risk and reliability; guest lectures on design by engineers; project completion with submission of a final design report. A-F only. 481 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent.
prerequisites: BE 481 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent

title: Biological Engineering Topics
description: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems. Offered by visiting faculty and/or for extension programs. Repeatable nine times.

title: Internship
description: Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills emphasizing professional development. Placement with an approved cooperating supervisor/employer. A-F only. consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Research in the area of biosystems engineering. consent.

title: Instrumentation and Measurement
description: Measurement concepts and operating principles applied to the selection and use of instruments important to scientists and engineers dealing with biological systems, including automatic data acquisition and processing. CHEM 151, MATH 241, and ME 311; or consent.
prerequisites: CHEM 151, MATH 241, and ME 311; or consent

title: Biofuel and Bioenergy
description: Overview of biofuel/bioenergy production, biorefinery concept; renewable feedstocks; thermochemical and biochemical conversions of biomass to biofuel; biodiesel production; algal-biofuel; environmental impacts, life-cycle analysis; value-added processing of biofuel residues; selected case studies; term paper and presentation. A-F only. consent. (Once a year)

title: Experimental Methods in Cause-Effect Modeling
description: Factorial designs and fractional factorial designs for screening variable and response optimization. Response surface methodology. Experimental designs appropriate to building and testing multi-variable behavior relationships. Sequential experimental designs.

title: Biological Instrumentation
description: System integration for computer-based control, automation, and study of biological systems. Topics include physical, chemical, and biological sensors, actuators, digital interfacing/communication, image analysis, and structured code for microcontrollers and other portable computers. consent. (

title: Biological Treatment
description: Fundamentals of applied microbiology and biochemical reactor engineering, quantitative description of microbial growth, operational theory and design basis of aerobic, anoxic and anaerobic treatment processes. Applications for water, wastewater, air, solid wastes, and soil. A-F only. consent. (Alt. years: spring) (

title: Biosystems Modeling
description: Introduction to system thinking, procedures for developing system models, characteristics of important agricultural system models, computer approach to evaluation and optimization of system models. one of MATH 215, MATH 241, MATH 251A; or consent.
prerequisites: one of MATH 215, MATH 241, MATH 251A; or consent

title: Hydrologic Processes in Soils
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Hydrologic properties in soils and the processes involved in water infiltration drainage and solute transport. Emphasis on key parameters required for modeling. Recommended: CEE 424 or consent. (Fall only) (

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar
description: Use of computer and video technology in technical presentation, review of current biosystems engineering research. consent.

title: Biology and Society
description: Characteristics of science, historical development of scientific concepts, and interaction of society with science illustrated by topics from biological science. Not a BIOL major elective.

title: Biology & Society Laboratory
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Explores connections between biological principles and everyday life with a focus on the environment. Topics include environmental health and sustainability with examples from Hawai‘i. Not a BIOL major elective. BIOL 101 (or concurrent). (

title: Marine Option Program Seminar
description: Overview of ocean issues and organizations involved with marine activities, management, education, research, and business. Exploration of internships, research, and career opportunities. Preparation of resumes, proposals, and professional presentations. Not a BIOL major elective. (

title: Current Topics in Biomedical Research Seminar
description: Overview of contemporary laboratory- and population-based studies of disease. Discussion of career pathways in human health sciences. Public health and epidemiology of cancer. A-F only. 171 (or concurrent). (Fall only)

title: Hawaiian Environment Science
description: Characteristics of science and interaction with society illustrated by topics in geology, astronomy, oceanography, and biology of Hawaiian Islands. Not a BIOL major elective.

title: Introduction to Biology I
description: Introductory biology for all life science majors. Cell structure and chemistry; growth, reproduction, genetics, evolution, viruses, bacteria, and simple eukaryotes. CHEM (131, 151, 161, 171, or 181A) or concurrent, and BIOL 171L (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: CHEM (BIOL 131, BIOL 151, BIOL 161, BIOL 171, or BIOL 181A) or concurrent, and BIOL 171L (or concurrent), or consent

title: Introduction to Biology I Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 171. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction, and requires a minimum of 4,000 words of graded writing. CHEM (131, 151, 161, 171, or 181A) or concurrent, and BIOL 171 (or concurrent) or consent.
prerequisites: CHEM (BIOL 131, BIOL 151, BIOL 161, BIOL 171, or BIOL 181A) or concurrent, and BIOL 171 (or concurrent) or consent

title: Introduction to Biology II
description: Anatomy, physiology, and systematics of plants and animals; behavior; ecosystems, populations, and communities. CHEM (131, 151, 161, 171, or 181A) or concurrent, and BIOL 172L (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: CHEM (BIOL 131, BIOL 151, BIOL 161, BIOL 171, or BIOL 181A) or concurrent, and BIOL 172L (or concurrent), or consent

title: Introduction to Biology II Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 172. CHEM (131, 151, 161, 171, or 181A) or concurrent, and BIOL 172 (or concurrent) or consent.
prerequisites: CHEM (BIOL 131, BIOL 151, BIOL 161, BIOL 171, or BIOL 181A) or concurrent, and BIOL 172 (or concurrent) or consent

title: Biostatistics
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to statistical approaches in biology. Students will learn how to formulate hypotheses, test them quantitatively, and present results. Students will analyze biological datasets using the computer language R. A-F only. 171 or 172 or BOT 101; MATH 134 or higher, or MATH assessment exam. (
prerequisites: BIOL 171 or BIOL 172 or BOT 101; MATH 134 or higher, or MATH assessment exam

title: Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
description: Principles of ecology and evolution for life science majors stressing integrated approach and recent advance. A-F only. C (not C-) or better in 171/171L, 172, 172L (or concurrent).
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 171/BIOL 171L, BIOL 172, BIOL 172L (or concurrent)

title: Ecology and Evolutionary Biology Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 265. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction, and requires a minimum of 4,000 words of graded writing. C (not C-) or better in 265 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 265 (or concurrent)

title: Cell and Molecular Biology
description: Integrated cell and molecular biology for life science majors. Modern advances in recombinant DNA technology. A-F only. C (not C-) or better in 171/171L and CHEM 272. (
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 171/BIOL 171L and CHEM 272

title: Cell and Molecular Biology Lab
description: (1 4-hr Lab) Laboratory for Cell and Molecular Biology. A-F only. C (not C-) or better in 275 (or concurrent) and CHEM 272.
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 275 (or concurrent) and CHEM 272

title: Service Learning for Biology Majors
description: Directed participation on tutorials and related activities in public schools and approved community and UH Mānoa organizations. A-F only. Repeatable one time. 265/265L, 275/275L, and consent.

title: Marine Ecology and Evolution
description: Ecological and evolutionary factors creating and maintaining patterns of biological diversity in major marine ecosystems. Emphasis on the biphasic life histories of many marine organisms. The development of quantitative skills and critical thinking. MBIO majors only. A-F only. C (not C-) or better in 265, 301L (or concurrent), and OCN 201; or consent.
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 265, BIOL 301L (or concurrent), and OCN 201; or consent

title: Marine Ecology and Evolution Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 301. MBIO majors only. A-F only. C (not C-) or better in 301 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 301 (or concurrent)

title: Biotechnology: Science and Ethical Issues
description: Introduction to the concepts, goals, ethical issues and consequences of biotechnology using real-life case studies of GMOs, cloning, DNA fingerprinting, gene therapy and genetical engineering. 171 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent. (
prerequisites: BIOL 171 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent

title: Ecology
description: General survey of the principles of ecology. Focus on processes influencing the distribution and abundance of organisms, interactions among organisms, and interactions between organisms and the environment. A-F only. BIOL 171; BIOL 172 or BOT 201. (

title: Ethology
description: Introduction to animal and human ethology and sociobiology; emphasis on social and interspecific behavior, its causes and adaptive significance. Lab optional. 171 and 171L and 172 and 172L or ANSC 201; or consent.
prerequisites: BIOL 171 and BIOL 171L and BIOL 172 and BIOL 172L or ANSC 201; or consent

title: Ethology Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Application of methods in the study of animal behavior by demonstrations, labs and projects. 306 (or concurrent).

title: Environmental Issues
description: Global environmental problems in historical perspective; physical, biological, sociocultural views. one of 101, 123, or GEO 101; or consent. (
prerequisites: one of BIOL 101, BIOL 123, or GEO 101; or consent

title: Biology of the Vertebrates
description: Introduction to the evolution and systematics of vertebrates, with emphasis on comparative morphology, physiology, and ecology. BIOL 171 and 172. Co-requisite: 325L.

title: Biology of the Vertebrates Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 325. 172 and 172L. Co-requisite: 325.

title: Marine Mammal Biology
description: Overview of marine mammal science, significance and roles of marine mammals in their ecosystems, and marine conservation issues. Current research topics in marine mammal science will also be covered. C (not C-) or better in 171/171L, 172/172L, and 265, 265L; or consent.
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 171/BIOL 171L, BIOL 172/BIOL 172L, and BIOL 265, BIOL 265L; or consent

title: Genetics, Evolution and Society
description: The role of genetics in evolution, medicine, behavior, plant and animal breeding and technology; its impact on today’s society. Not a BIOL major elective. one semester of biological science at college level or consent. (
prerequisites: one semester of biological science at college level or consent

title: Parasitology
description: Animal parasites of man, and domestic and wild animals; systematics, comparative morphology, life history, pathology, treatment, control. 275.

title: Sex Differences in the Life Cycle
description: Human sex differences, their biological basis and significance, ethical considerations of genetic, hormonal, and behavioral determinants of sexual differentiation; biology of gender, sexuality, parenting, menopause, and aging. one semester of biological science. (

title: Island Ecosystems
description: Characteristics of island biota; examples from Hawai‘i and the Pacific. Impact of island and continental cultures; policy and ecosystem endangerment; contemporary legislation, policy, and management practices. one semester of biological science or consent. Not a BIOL major elective.
prerequisites: one semester of biological science or consent

title: Biological Field Studies
description: Biological survey, collection, and analysis techniques will be reviewed and applied through field studies. Students will be introduced to the uniqueness of the Hawaiian environment and its diversity of life. Emphasis on diversity, evolution and ecology. Repeatable up to six credits. A-F only. C (not C-) or better in 265/265L (or equivalent), or consent.
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 265/BIOL 265L (or equivalent), or consent

title: Genetics
description: Genetic concepts at advanced undergraduate level; genetic transmission, recombination, gene action, mutation, population and evolutionary genetics. A-F only. 275 or consent.

title: Genetics Laboratory
description: (1 4-hr Lab) Experiments with a variety of organisms to illustrate principles discussed in BIOL 375. 275/275L, 375 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Communicating in Biological Sciences
description: Combined lecture/lab impart essential knowledge and skills in technical writing, poster design, and oral presentations for effective communication for life science majors. Research papers, lab reports, project proposals, conference presentations are covered. A-F only. C (not C-) or better in 171/171L, 172/172L, and ENG 100.
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 171/BIOL 171L, BIOL 172/BIOL 172L, and ENG 100

title: (Alpha) Teaching Internship
description: Teaching internship in the Life Sciences that includes the preparation and demonstration of laboratory experiments or classroom activities. (B) general; (C) oral emphasis, includes emphasis on instruction in oral communication. Repeatable one time. consent

title: Ocean Internships and Research
description: Students carry out marine-related internships, practica, research projects or field experience on-or off-campus with faculty guidance. Repeatable one time. A-F only. minimum cum GPA of 2.5, junior or senior standing in any field of study and IS 100/BIOL 104 or consent, project proposal.

title: Molecular Biotechnology
description: General principles, applications, and recent advances of the rapidly growing science of biotechnology. Topics include impact of biotechnology on medicine, animal sciences, environment, agriculture, forensics, and economic and socio-ethical issues. C (not C-) or better in 275 or consent. (
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 275 or consent

title: Molecular Biotechnology Lab-Gene Editing by CRISPR/Cas9
description: (1-hr Lec, 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 401. Students learn advanced gene editing techniques, including CRISPR/Cas9 to engineer prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Repeatable one time. 275L, or 375L, or MBBE 304, or MBBE 375; or consent. Co-requisite: 401. (
prerequisites: BIOL 275L, or BIOL 375L, or MBBE 304, or MBBE 375; or consent

title: Principles of Biochemistry
description: Molecular basis of living processes in bacteria, plants, and animals; emphasis on metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids. C (not C-) or better in 275/275L, and CHEM 273; or consent. (
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 275/BIOL 275L, and CHEM 273; or consent

title: Field Problems in Marine Biology
description: Integrated program of intensive lectures, laboratory experiments, and field research that focus on the biological processes that shape the lives of marine organisms. A-F only. Limited space; enrollment by consent; GPA considered. C (not C-) or better in 301/301L and consent.
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 301/BIOL 301L and consent

title: Advanced Topics in Marine Biology
description: Current themes in marine biology and experience in scientific assessment. Emphasis on teaching writing and oral communication. Repeatable two times. MBIO majors only. A-F only. C (not C-) or better in 301/301L or consent.
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 301/BIOL 301L or consent

title: Biology of Marine Organisms
description: Biology, physiology, and ecology of marine organisms and marine ecosystems, and the physical and chemical factors, which influence them. Cannot be used to satisfy BS-MB major requirements. Credit granted for only one of ZOOL 200, BIOL 301, or BIOL 406. Junior standing or consent. A-F only. 171 and 172. (Spring only)

title: Molecular Cell Biology I
description: Relationship between structure and function at macromolecular level. C (not C-) or better in 275/275L and CHEM 273, or consent. (
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 275/BIOL 275L and CHEM 273, or consent

title: Molecular Cellular Biology II
description: Cell structure and function. Structure, chemistry, and functions of organelles and macromolecules. C (not C-) or better in 407; or consent. (
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 407; or consent

title: Advanced Molecular and Cellular Biology Laboratory
description: (2 3-hr Lab) A laboratory to accompany 407 and 408. 407 (or concurrent) or 408 (or concurrent). (

title: Human Role in Environmental Change
description: Human impacts through time on vegetation, animals, landforms, soils, climate, and atmosphere. Special reference to Asian/Pacific region. Implications of long-term environmental change for human habitability. with a minimum grade of B, one of 101, 123 or GEO 101 and either 310 or GEO 322; or consent. (
prerequisites: with a minimum grade of B, one of BIOL 101, BIOL 123 or GEO 101 and either GEO 310 or GEO 322; or consent

title: Corals and Coral Reefs
description: The biogeography, evolution, ecology, and physiology of corals and coral reefs, and the application of this information to the management of coral reefs. Emphasis will be placed on processes such as dispersal, the evolution and operation of mutualisms, calcification, reproduction, and the maintenance of diversity. 265 (or concurrent) or 301 (or concurrent). (Spring only)

title: Wildlife and Plant Conservation
description: Principles of conservation biology and wildlife management techniques, illustrated with animal, plant, and ecosystem examples. Examination of ethical, cultural, legal, political, and socio-economic issues impinging on conservation policy and practice. Group project and field trips. C (not C-) or better in 265/265L or consent.
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 265/BIOL 265L or consent

title: The Biology of Fungi
description: Will introduce the diversity, ecology, evolution, and biology of the Kingdom Fungi. Focus on our current understanding of fungal evolution and diversity and how fungi interact with environments and hosts.
prerequisites: (BIOL 172, BOT 201) with a minimum grade of C; or consent
crossListings: 172, BOT 201 with a minimum grade of C; or consent. Spring only Crosslisted as BOT 430 and TPSS 432

title: The Biology of Fungi Lab
description: Will introduce the diversity, ecology, evolution, and biology of the Kingdom Fungi. Focus on our current understanding of fungal evolution and diversity and how fungi interact with environments and hosts. (430 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: (BIOL 430 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent

title: Psychoactive Drug Plants
description: Taxonomy, ecology, biochemistry, distribution, cultural history, and contemporary use of mind-altering drug plants; examples from primitive, traditional, and modern societies. junior standing, one semester of biological science, and either ANTH 200 or GEO 151; or consent.
prerequisites: junior standing, one semester of biological science, and either ANTH 200 or GEO 151; or consent

title: Natural History of Hawaiian Islands
description: (2 Lec, 1 1-hr Lab) Geography, geology, climatology, biotic environment of Pacific Basin and Hawaiian Islands; endemism and evolution in terrestrial and marine biota. one semester of biological sciences at college level. (
prerequisites: one semester of biological sciences at college level

title: Fish Diversity
description: Survey of fish biodiversity focusing on major lineages, their phylogenetic relationships, and their geographic distribution in light of evolutionary history. Taught spring semester in alternate years. Junior standing or higher. 171 and 172. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Fish Diversity Laboratory
description: (2 2-hr Lab) Overview of the major orders and families of fishes of the world; introduction to local Hawaiian fishes; coverage of basic fish anatomy; introduction to field and laboratory techniques in fish research. Junior standing or higher. 171, 172, and 465 (or concurrent). (Alt. years: spring)

title: The Rise of Fishes: An Evolutionary History
description: The origins and early evolution of fishes, with a focus on morphological innovations that have led to lineage divergence and adaptive radiation, and the nature of underlying processes associated with novel character trait evolution. A-F only. 265. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Evolutionary Biology
description: Process of evolution: genetic basis, natural selection, population genetics, speciation, the fossil record. 171 and 172. Recommended: a BIOL or ZOOL course at 300 or 400 level.

title: The Biology of Cancer
description: Integrative, in-depth focus on the genetics, cell biology, and molecular basis of cancer. Combination of classroom lectures and problem-based discussions in small groups. Addresses ethical implications of cancer research and treatment. A-F only. MCB or BIOL majors only. Senior standing or higher. 407 (or concurrent) and 408 (or concurrent) or consent. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: BIOL 407 (or concurrent) and BIOL 408 (or concurrent) or consent

title: Life in the Soil Environment
description: An interdisciplinary study of the diverse life in the soil beneath our feet that includes bacteria, fungi, protists, nematodes, arthropods, invertebrate, viruses, and the essential functional roles these organisms contribute to sustainability of the planet. Repeatable one time. 375 or TPSS/PEPS/SUST 371, or MICR 351, or consent. (
prerequisites: BIOL 375 or TPSS/PEPS/SUST 371, or MICR 351, or consent

title: Life in the Soil Environment Lab
description: Laboratory to accompany 480. Technical examination of bacteria, fungi, protists, nematodes, arthropods, and other invertebrate, and the essential functional roles these organisms contribute to sustainability of the planet. Repeatable one time. 171L and 172L, or MICR 351L, or consent. Co-requisite: 480.
prerequisites: BIOL 171L and BIOL 172L, or MICR 351L, or consent

title: Introduction to Bioinformatics Topics for Biologists
description: Focuses on the use of computational tools and approaches to analyze the enormous amount of biological data (DNA, RNA, protein) available today. A-F only. (171 (or equivalent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: (BIOL 171 (or equivalent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent

title: Biology of the Invertebrates
description: Body plans, development, cellular construction, physiological integration, natural history, and ecology of invertebrate animals. Emphasis on marine species, especially local ones. 172 and CHEM 161, or consent. Corequisite: 485L.

title: Biology of the Invertebrates Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) 172 and CHEM 161, or consent. Corequisite: 485.

title: Biogeography and Evolution
description: Study of the fundamental role that geography plays in evolution and maintenance of species diversity. 171 and one of BIOL 172 or BOT 101. (Fall only)
prerequisites: BIOL 171 and one of BIOL 172 or BOT 101

title: Mathematical Biology Seminar
description: Reports on research in mathematical biology, reviews of literature, and research presentation. Required for Certificate in Mathematical Biology. Repeatable one time. junior standing or higher and consent. (
prerequisites: junior standing or higher and consent

title: Biological Directed Research
description: Development and completion of a research project under the direction of a faculty advisor. Repeatable two times, up to 12 credits, up to 6 credits apply towards BA and BS BIOL major requirements. A-F only. 2.5 GPA minimum, written proposal and consent.

title: (Alpha) Biology Workshop for Science Teachers
description: Principles taught in a conceptual and/ or hands-on manner either in a laboratory setting or in the field. (B) biotechnology; (C) ecology, evolution and conservation; (D) marine biology; (F) general biology. A-F only. Repeatable unlimited times. 171/171L, 172/172L, in-service teachers; or consent.
prerequisites: BIOL 171/BIOL 171L, BIOL 172/BIOL 172L, in-service teachers; or consent

title: Life Sciences Colloquium
description: Seminars presented with the School of Life Sciences; topics will vary across the biological sciences. Repeatable up to four credits. BOT, MBIO, MICR, ZOOL graduate students only.

title: Molecular Ecology
description: Practical introduction to molecular methods used to address ecological and evolutionary questions. Advanced undergraduate/graduate level. Focus on methods and application to independent research project. A-F only. 265/265L (or equivalent) or 275/275L (or equivalent), and 375/375L, and consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: BIOL 265/BIOL 265L (or equivalent) or BIOL 275/BIOL 275L (or equivalent), and BIOL 375/BIOL 375L, and consent

title: Population Genetics
description: Mathematical, observational, experimental results on effects of mutation, selection, and systems of mating on distribution of genes. Analysis of non-experimental populations. consent. (.

title: Directed Research and Reading
description: To provide elective courses for undergraduates in the biomedical sciences specialties. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Clinical Research Review
description: Research elective for medical students. MD students only. CR/NC only. MDED 554 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Global Health and Medicine: Emerging Problems and Impact
description: Analysis of emerging problems and impact in countries on a multidimensional perspective. Repeatable one time. BIOM, NURS, PH, SPA majors only. consent.

title: Introduction to Clinical Nutrition
description: Overview of applied clinical nutrition that includes nutrients, dietary recommendations for healthy populations and medical nutrition therapies for patients with diet related diseases or conditions. Graduate students only. A-F only. BIOL 171 (or higher) or PHYL 141 or ZOOL 141 or consent.
prerequisites: BIOL 171 (or higher) or PHYL 141 or ZOOL 141 or consent

title: Introduction to Clinical Research
description: Instruction in developing clinical research questions and creating a concise protocol that includes a literature review, study design, subject recruitment and sampling, instruments, other measures and bioinformatics, sample size, consent form, budget and timetable. A-F only.

title: Legal and Regulatory Issues and Bioethics
description: Ethical dilemmas in clinical research are identified and resolved in cases, research on human subjects regulation are discussed. Research misconduct is defined. Ethical considerations in protocol developed in the Designing Clinical Research course are resolved. A-F only. (

title: Translational Research Methods
description: Lectures focus on translational research methods through selected genetic and acquired diseases including cancer, neurodevelopmental, inflammatoryimmune, and metabolic conditions with insight into analyses of DNA, RNA, genomics-proteomics, cell and animal models, and advanced imaging. A-F only. consent.

title: Clinical Protocol Development
description: Provides training in proposal development. Governance structures of funding agencies; funding opportunities and decisions; review processes; NIH application and processes; reading RFAs; compliance issues; cultural sensitivity; and types of questions using databases are addressed. A-F only.

title: Cultural Competence in Biomedical Research I
description: Introductory lecture-seminar on the conduct of multidisciplinary research from a culturally competent perspective. A-F only.

title: Foundations of Biomedical Ethics
description: Explores the foundations of biomedical ethics via small group seminars and discussion, presentations. Enrolled in MS or PhD in Biomedical Sciences program only. A-F only. (Alt. years)

title: Advanced Ethics in Biomedical Research II
description: Develop biomedical ethics through case studies to incite discussions on topics such as gene therapy, gene enhancement, genetic counseling, informed consent, health care professional/patient and investigator/student participant communication, advanced directives and living wills, clinical research in developing countries, clinical research in ethnic minority and socio-economically disadvantaged populations, and non-discrimination in health care and research settings. A-F only.

title: Cultural Competence in Biomedical Research II
description: Explore topics in cultural competence in greater depth, encouraging trainees to address issues from a unified yet flexible conceptual framework. Involves building knowledge, skills and action plans to address a range of learning styles and to appreciate and benefit from diversity. A-F only.

title: PhD Team Building Seminar
description: Seminar focuses on teaching participants to work independently and collaborate in order to accomplish specific results. Students will be exposed to group dynamics, communication, healthy competition, conflict resolution, and innovative means of crossing boundaries between departments, organizations, industries and disciplines. Repeatable two times. A-F only.

title: Medical Genetics
description: Focus on heritable disorders, genetic mechanisms, patterns of inheritance, phenotype-genotype correlations, genetic/ environmental factors, clinical diagnoses, genomic and precision medicine.

title: Mentored Research Practicum
description: Conduct research under the direction of a mentor. Participants will be responsible for submission of a proposal, acquisition of IRB approval, and conduct of the project. Repeatable five times or up to 12 credits. BIOM students only. A-F only.

title: Advanced Biostatistics for Clinical Research
description: Current methods for analyzing longitudinal and clustered, clinical data through lectures, discussions, and a group analysis. Topic areas include multi-level, multi-state, multi-process, and structural equation models. A-F only. QHS 601 and QHS 602, or consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Students may register on approval of department. CR/NC only. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable seven times or up to 8 credits. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Disasters and Pandemics: Medical and PH Management and Risk Communication
description: Assess impact on health in disasters and diseases. Enhances research skills related to management and communication. Repeatable one time. BIOM, PH, NURS, and SPA majors only. consent.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/ NC only. consent.

title: Freshman Seminar
description: Discussion of hot topics in botany, including conservation of rare plants, invasive species, marine botany, ethnobotany, poisonous plants, evolution in action, fungal networks, and careers in botany with emphasis on Hawaiian examples. Students should enroll in BOT 100 and 101/101L, or BOT 100 and BIOL 171/171L. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Corequisite: 101/101L or BIOL 171/171L. (Once a year)

title: General Botany
description: Growth, functions, and evolution of plants; their relations to the environment and particularly to humans and human activities.

title: General Botany
description: Growth, functions, and evolution of plants; their relations to the environment and particularly to humans and human activities.

title: General Botany Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Lab observations and experiments illustrating basic principles of plant biology. 101 (or concurrent).

title: Plants, People, and Culture
description: Ethnobotany. Interactions between plants and people: use in religious, medical, and shamanic traditions; roles in cultural formation, destruction, and revolution; plant domestication and food systems; roles in human migration; cultural components of plant conservation. (Fall only)

title: Plants, People, and Culture
description: Ethnobotany. Interactions between plants and people: use in religious, medical, and shamanic traditions; roles in cultural formation, destruction, and revolution; plant domestication and food systems; roles in human migration; cultural components of plant conservation. (Fall only)

title: Hawaiian Plants-Their Ecology and Cultural Significance
description: Introduction to the native flora of Hawai‘i, its origin, evolution and ecology, and the observation, identification, and systematics of the Hawaiian flora.

title: Hawaiian Plants-Their Ecology and Cultural Significance Lab
description: The exploration of concepts and the process of science through hands-on experience in studying Hawaiian and introduced plants, their ecology, and cultural significance. 130 (or concurrent).

title: Magical Mushrooms and Mystical Molds
description: Impact of fungi in nature and on humankind. Selected historical events in which fungi played a significant role, their activities as decomposers and pathogens, and their uses as sources for mind altering drugs in religious ceremonies and in food and beverage production in various societies.

title: Campus Plants
description: Nontechnical course emphasizing recognition of the many interesting tropical plants seen on campus; origin, status in Hawai‘i, and cultural and economic uses of campus plants.

title: Sophomore Seminar
description: Presentations by faculty highlighting research in tropical ecosystems. Topics include alien species, biodiversity, ecosystem services, ethnobotany, marine ecology, plant-animal interactions, and systematics of Hawaiian species. Assigned reading and writing exercises from papers in current journals. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 101/101L or BIOL 171/171L. (Once a year)

title: Plant Evolutionary Diversity
description: Significance of evolutionary trends in the plant world, including reproductive, morphological, and life history adaptations by algae, fungi, and vascular plants. 101 or college general biology. Co-requisite: 201L.

title: Plant Evolutionary Diversity Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Lab exercises in the morphology and systematics of land plants, fungi, and algae. Corequisite: 201.

title: Biostatistics
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to statistical approaches in biology. Students will learn how to formulate hypotheses, test them quantitatively, and present results. Students will analyze biological datasets using the computer language R. A-F only. 101 or BIOL 171 or BIOL 172; MATH 134 or higher, or MATH assessment exam. (
prerequisites: BOT 101 or BIOL 171 or BIOL 172; MATH 134 or higher, or MATH assessment exam

title: Conservation Ethics
description: Introduction to and discussion of ethical issues associated with biodiversity, ecology, and conservation biology. Repeatable one time. A-F only. any DB course or consent. (Once a year) (

title: Plant Conservation Biology
description: Introduction to the concepts and principles of plant conservation biology and to plant conservation-inpractice in Hawai‘i and elsewhere. A-F only. 305 or consent. (Once a year) (

title: Plant Conservation Biology Lab
description: Introduction to approaches, methods, and analyses used in the study and practice of plant conservation, with an emphasis on experimental design and problem-solving. Includes both laboratory and field components. A-F only. 305 or consent. Corequisite: 301. (Once a year) (

title: Ecology
description: General survey of the principles of ecology. Focus on processes influencing the distribution and abundance of organisms, interactions among organisms, and interactions between organisms and the environment. A-F only. BIOL 171; BIOL 172 or BOT 201. (

title: Field Botany
description: Combined lecturelaboratory with intensive field experience for observational and experimental field work in native/impacted Hawaiian ecosystems. Field experience typically held during spring break. Terrestrial, freshwater, and marine habitats considered. A-F only. 305 and consent. (Once a year)

title: Resource Management and Conservation in Hawai‘i
description: Management of native Hawaiian organisms and terrestrial ecosystems with particular attention to strategies, planning, research, and management actions necessary to control alien influences and promote native species. college general biology.

title: Tropical forest Ecology
description: Introduction to the ecological processes and principles of tropical ecosystems, and to conservation issues facing tropical forests, with a particular emphasis on the neotropics. A-F only. BIOL 171 and BIOL 172, or BOT 101; and BIOL 265.
prerequisites: BIOL 171 and BIOL 172, or BOT 101; and BIOL 265

title: Senior Seminar
description: Current research themes in botany presented in discussion format; reading current research papers. Oral presentations of primary research. Repeatable one time. BOT majors only. Senior standing and consent. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Plant Form and Function
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Lecture/laboratory to examine the anatomy, physiology, morphology, and functional ecology of plants. Labs will develop skills in microscopy, experimental techniques for studying plant physiology, and basic functional ecology. A-F only. BIOL/BOT 305; or consent. (Spring only)

title: The Biology of Fungi
description: Will introduce the diversity, ecology, evolution, and biology of the Kingdom Fungi. Focus on our current understanding of fungal evolution and diversity and how fungi interact with environments and hosts.
prerequisites: (BOT 201, BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C; or consent
crossListings: 201, BIOL 172 with a minimum grade of C; or consent. Spring only Crosslisted as BIOL 430 and TPSS 432

title: The Biology of Fungi Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to the morphology and life cycles of organisms in the Kingdom Fungi. Focus on learning how to identify a diversity of fungi based on macro- and microscopic features. Field trips to collect specimens. (430 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C. or consent. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: (BOT 430 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C

title: Medical Ethnobotany
description: Survey and theory of plants used as medicines, cultural perspectives of herbal medicine, and the botanical/ chemical basis of allopathic and naturopathic medicine. Lecture/discussion, term paper or project. 461 or consent.

title: Ethnoecology and Conservation
description: Ecological implications of cultural uses of plants. Examines the biological basis for, and ecological effects of traditional and local resource management systems. BOT 305 or BIOL 265/265L or consent.

title: Hawaiian Ethnobotany
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Methods and techniques of handling and identifying plant materials used by early Hawaiians and modern Hawaiians for house and canoe construction, clothing, household and fishing items, medicine, and food preparation. Reading, laboratory, and fieldwork. 440 or consent. (

title: Plant-Animal Interactions
description: Interdependence of plants and animals, emphasizing the influence of animals on plant fitness and evolution. Topics include pollination, fruit/seed dispersal, herbivory, and ant-plant mutualisms. 201 or 305 or BIOL 265 or BIOL 305.
prerequisites: BOT 201 or BOT 305 or BIOL 265 or BIOL 305

title: ‘Āina Mauliola: Hawaiian Ecosystems
description: Comprehensive analysis of traditional Hawaiian and modern resource management practices. Rigorous overview of the dominant physical and biological processes from the uplands to the oceans in Hawai‘i. HWST 207/SUST 217 or HWST 307/SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356.

title: Natural Resource Issues and Ethics
description: Overview of the history of land, resources and power in Hawai‘i; players and processes influencing land and natural resources policies today explored from Native Hawaiian and other viewpoints. Extensive use of case studies. HWST 207/SUST 217 or HWST 307/ SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356.
prerequisites: HWST 207/SUST 217 or HWST 307/ SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356

title: Strategies in Hawaiian Resource Use
description: Analyzing diverse land and water use strategies of O‘ahu, from traditional Hawaiian, scientific and economic perspectives, through classroom and on-site lectures. Topics include traditional Hawaiian methods, modern development, threatened ecosystems, ecotourism and scientific research. A-F only. HWST 207/SUST 217 or HWST 307/SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356.

title: Systematics of Vascular Plants
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) “Hands-on” experience with Hawai‘i’s unique tropical flora; emphasis on recognition and identification of vascular plant families and the principles and methodologies that define them; evolution of biodiversity. 101 or college general biology.

title: Plant Ecology
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Ecological principles and process that determine patterns of plant distribution and abundance. Lectures cover theory and examples from primary literature. Labs cover study design, descriptive and experimental techniques, field skills, and data analysis and interpretation. A-F only. 305 or BIOL 305.

title: Algal Diversity and Evolution
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of algal diversity, structure, and evolution. Identification of common Hawaiian algae. Develops written communication skills with significant attention paid to developing writing skills and emphasis on writing instruction. one of 101, BIOL 172, MICR 351, ZOOL 101; or consent.
prerequisites: one of BOT 101, BIOL 172, MICR 351, ZOOL 101; or consent

title: Grant Writing and Your Career in Science
description: Scientific grant writing from inception through management to completion; students will write a DDIG and participate in a panel. Professional skills including “rules,” job applications, interviews, transitioning from graduate student to academic or non-academic job. A-F only. current standing as a graduate student, or consent.
prerequisites: current standing as a graduate student, or consent

title: Foundations of Current Botany I
description: Discussion of current research and classical papers important to modern concepts in history of science, plant diversity, plant interactions with the environment, and plant integration. graduate standing in BOT or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: graduate standing in BOT or consent

title: Foundations of Current Botany II
description: Discussion of current research and classical papers important to modern concepts in ecology, plant interactions with other plants or animals, and ecosystem functioning. BOT majors only. graduate standing in BOT or consent. (Spring only)
prerequisites: graduate standing in BOT or consent

title: Darwin’s Origin of Species
description: Study and discussion of Charles Darwin’s Origin of Species, 1st edition 1859, and related current literature. Graduate students only. A-F only. BA or BS in BOT, BIOL, GEOL, or related field; or consent. (Spring only)
prerequisites: BA or BS in BOT, BIOL, GEOL, or related field; or consent

title: Graduate Research Skills
description: (1 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab Survey of major research areas in the botanical sciences with emphasis upon research opportunities in Hawai‘i and an overview of 1 skills needed by botanical researchers including writing scientific papers and proposals, practicing ethical research procedures, and collection of specimens; and 2) equipment used by botanical researchers including computers, cameras, measuring and monitoring equipment, and global positioning systems. Lecture/ discussion, laboratory. Repeatable one time. graduate standing in biological science or approval.
prerequisites: graduate standing in biological science or approval

title: Botanical Seminar
description: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems in botany. Repeatable three times.

title: Advanced Botanical Problems
description: Investigation of any botanical problem; reading and laboratory work. Repeatable nine times. consent.

title: Perspectives in Modern Botany
description: Lectures by distinguished visiting professor on contemporary botanical topics in the lecturer’s area of expertise. No more than 6 credit hours may be counted toward the MS degree requirements. Repeatable five times.

title: Ecohydrology: Theory and Modeling
description: Vegetative response to hydrologic controls and nutrient cycles; quantitative linkages between hydrological dynamics and ecological patterns/ processes. MatLab is used to develop and simulate ecohydrological models. college level calculus or consent. (Once a year)

title: Quantitative Ethnobotany
description: Modern ethnobotanical field research project design, execution, data analysis, and documentation methods. Intended for students preparing to conduct field research studies. Lecture/discussion, term paper. 105 and one of 201, 461, ANTH 200, or BIOL 172.
prerequisites: BOT 105 and one of BOT 201, BOT 461, ANTH 200, or BIOL 172

title: Ethnoecological Methods
description: Field techniques for assessing the ecological effects of cultural uses of plants. Emphasis on documenting traditional and local patterns of plant use and measuring the effects on plant individuals, populations, communities, and landscapes. previous course work in anthropology or biology.
prerequisites: previous course work in anthropology or biology

title: Conservation Ethnobiology
description: Practical field training experience for a scientific career conducting ethnobiological research. Repeatable one time. 640 or consent. (Summer only)

title: Invasion Biology
description: Theories, models, patterns, and predictive methods relating to the introduction, establishment, and spread of introduced organisms. Application of principles of invasion biology to conservation and natural resource management. 456 or MICR 485; and BIOL 375; or consent.
prerequisites: BOT 456 or MICR 485; and BIOL 375; or consent

title: Population Biology
description: Theory and applications of population biology; behavior of population models, as revealed by analytical methods and computer simulation; application to population problems such as endangered species; discussion of classical and current literature in population biology. one of 456, NREM 680, PEPS 671, ZOOL 620, ZOOL 623; or consent. (
prerequisites: one of BOT 456, NREM 680, PEPS 671, ZOOL 620, ZOOL 623; or consent

title: Population Dynamics Models with R
description: Learn advanced modeling techniques to investigate the dynamics of size-structure populations (using matrix and integral population models in R), and discuss various applications in ecology and conservation biology. Recommended: students have working knowledge of calculus. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Advances in Plant Ecology
description: A researchoriented course focusing on recent advances in all areas of plant ecology. Involves critical review of recent literature, independent research project, oral and written presentation of project results. Repeatable three times. consent.

title: Ecological Statistics with R
description: Learn how to choose appropriate statistical methods to test hypotheses in ecology, evolution, and conservation biology and applications using R as a platform. Lecture/discussion, term paper. ZOOL 631 or consent. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Hawaiian Vascular Plants
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Identification, systematics, evolution, and biogeography of native plants. Field trips. 461 or consent. (

title: High Throughput Sequencing Approaches to Ecology and Evolution
description: Fundamentals of experimental design, lab techniques and data analysis to conduct research using high throughput sequencing. Students will work in groups to conduct an amplicon sequencing study with ten samples. Repeatable one time. consent. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Nomenclature and Practical Systematics
description: Modern issues of naming and classifying of organisms, with a botanical emphasis. Includes lectures, discussions, class projects, and field trips. A-F only. 461 (or equivalent) or consent. (Once a year)

title: Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution
description: Molecular approaches to evolution, phylogenetics, and systematics. Basic use of chloroplast DNA, mitochondrial DNA, nuclear DNA, and electrophoresis. Phylogenetic analysis using parsimony, distance, and comparative methods. Repeatable two times. Recommended: 201.

title: Scientific Teaching Tools to Promote Active Learning
description: Graduate level course to train students in the pedagogical tools to enhance active learning in STEM classes. Includes discussions of the primary literature, demonstrations and practice using scientific teaching techniques. BOT or ZOOL or MBIO majors only. Graduate students only. (Alt. years: spring) (

title: Environmental Physiology Seminar
description: Environmental stress; pollution; salinity, geobotany, and other interactions between the environment and plant processes. Current literature emphasized at multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary levels. graduate status in a biological science, geosciences, etc.; consent for well-prepared undergraduates.
prerequisites: graduate status in a biological science, geosciences, etc

title: Marine Macrophytes Seminar
description: Discussion of current literature in physiological ecology, cellular and molecular adaptations to environmental factors by marine plants. Repeatable four times. 480.

title: Physiological Ecology of Marine Plants
description: Discussion of current studies in morphological, physiological, cellular, and molecular adaptation to marine environments by macroalgae, phytoplankton, and seagrasses. A-F only. upper division ecology class recommended, 480 (or equivalent), or consent. Co-requisite: 682L.
prerequisites: upper division ecology class recommended, BOT 480 (or equivalent), or consent

title: Physiological Ecology of Marine Plants Lab
description: Field and laboratory research techniques and projects in the physiological ecology of algae and seagrasses. A-F only. upper division ecology class recommended, 470L (or equivalent), 480 (or equivalent), or consent. Co-requisite: 682.
prerequisites: upper division ecology class recommended, BOT 470L (or equivalent), BOT 480 (or equivalent), or consent

title: Conservation Biology
description: Theories and concepts of ecology, evolution, and genetics for conservation of biological diversity. Topics will include restoration ecology, management planning, laws and policies, biological invasions. (

title: Directed Research
description: Research preliminary to thesis or dissertation research. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. consent of graduate committee.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. candidacy for MS degree and approval of thesis proposal.
prerequisites: candidacy for MS degree and approval of thesis proposal

title: Topics in Conservation Biology
description: Advanced topics in conservation and environmental biology. Repeatable three times, up to twelve credits. A-F only. consent. (

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. candidacy for PhD and approval of dissertation proposal.
prerequisites: candidacy for PhD and approval of dissertation proposal

title: International Exchange Study/Research
description: Study overseas in an approved international exchange or similar program. Repeatable four times. CR/NC only. consent of academic advisor.

title: Introduction to Technology-Based Innovation and Entrepreneurship
description: Introduces modern tools for launching technology-based new ventures. Teams of students engage in term projects to learn design thinking, business model generation, product development, rapid prototyping, customer validation, and pitching to investors. ENGR and BUS majors only. Freshmen only. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Introduction to Business
description: Introduction to each of the functional areas of business. Intends to help students understand the interrelationships of business functional areas and the role of business in society. Stresses written communication in business. BUS majors only. Freshman or sophomore standing only. A-F only.

title: Written Communication in Business
description: An interactive writing class stressing persuasive writing in the context of memos, letters, and business reports. A-F only. ACC 200 or ACC 210, and ENG 100. Students may not earn credit for both BUS 209 and ENG 209.

title: Applied Math in Business
description: Provides problem-solving and quantitative skills essential in business. Reviews algebra, mathematics of finance, calculus in business applications, probability, introductory statistics, and hypothesis testing. two years high school algebra.

title: Statistical Analysis for Business Decisions
description: Problem recognition and formulation; stress on cross-disciplinary complex problem solving and communication; computer intensive. Coverage of descriptive statistics, probability and hypothesis testing with emphasis on quality, productivity, and regression analysis. Must be taken in first semester of BBA program.

title: Information Systems for Global Business Environment
description: Skills and strategies for using information resources applied to local and global business issues; advanced skills in computer-based analytical techniques and information management; impact of information technology on business operations and business strategies. Must be taken in first semester of BBA program. ICS 101, or LTEC 112 and 113, or equivalent, or consent.
prerequisites: ICS 101, or LTEC 112 and LTEC 113, or equivalent, or consent

title: Principles of Marketing
description: Concepts, problems, and opportunities in marketing within its competitive, political-legal, economic, social and global environments. Social responsibility and ethics. Marketing research. Consumer and businessto-business segmentation and positioning. Strategic marketing planning. Students may not earn credit for BUS 312 and TIM 304.

title: Economic and Financial Environment of Global Business
description: International trade, financial flows, and direct investment. Public and private institutions including government policies and capital markets. Emphasis on Asia Pacific issues, with attention to the cultural differences among countries. ECON 130 and ECON 131 or consent.

title: Business Finance
description: Introduction to the theory and practice of financial management: analysis and decision making for asset management, capital budgeting, capital structure, and dividend policy. for all other finance courses. ACC 200 and ACC 210, ECON 130 and ECON 131; or consent.

title: Global Management and Organizational Behavior
description: Analysis of theories and concepts underlying domestic and global organizational management, including behavioral and personnel issues. Emphasis on leadership, team-work, cultural differences in the Asia Pacific region. to all other advanced management courses. Students may not receive credit for BUS 315 and TIM 303. PSY 100 or SOC 100.
prerequisites: to all other advanced management courses

title: Strategic Management
description: Applications of strategy to domestic and global business problems using an interdisciplinary approach. Emphasis on AsiaPacific business, assessment of risk, integration of all business core disciplines. Extensive writing expected. all core courses and graduating senior standing.
prerequisites: all core courses and graduating senior standing

title: (Alpha) Business Study Abroad
description: Study abroad experience emphasizing international business issues. Content varies with courses taught; (C) accounting; (D) management of informational systems; (F) finance; (G) management; (I) international business; (K) marketing; (M) human resources; (R) real estate. Each alpha repeatable three times, up to 16 credits. consent.

title: (Alpha) Internship
description: On-the-job experience in the business community. Term paper and meetings with faculty advisor required. (D) MIS; (F) finance; (G) management; (I) international business; (K) marketing; (M) human resource management; (R) real estate. CR/NC only. Repeatable one time. consent and RE 300 for (R) only.

title: Data Analytics for Business
description: Introduction to data analytics techniques and tools, builds on foundational business analysis and quantitative methods knowledge. Modules include preparing relevant data, conducting analysis, visualizing results, and storytelling with data. 310 and 311.

title: Asia Pacific Business
description: Analysis of business environment and business issues through study of businesses, governmental entities, and nongovernmental organizations in specific geographic areas in non-U.S. settings. Repeatable one time. A-F only. consent. (Summer only)

title: Asia Pacific Field Trip
description: Analysis of business environment and business issues through study and direct observation of businesses, governmental entities, and non-governmental organizations in non-U.S. settings. Involves group travel to selected international business cities. Travel sites will vary. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 475 and consent. (Summer only)

title: Dynamics of Asian Finance
description: Analysis of selected key industries of Asian countries: business/ economic trends, shifting product mix, technological changes, joint ventures, international competition, and productivity strategy, including contrasting management styles, worker/management relationships, and decision-making processes under different cultural settings. Industry observations conducted in Asian countries for three weeks during the summer. 6 credit hours of economics or business, PAMI participant; or consent.
prerequisites: BUS 6 credit hours of economics or business, PAMI participant; or consent

title: Professional Development
description: Professional development course designed to focus and improve the career development and leadership skills of MBA students. Students learn from guest speakers through site visits, intensive workshops, and hands-on experience. MBA students only or advisor approval. No grading.

title: Data Analytics and Statistics for Business
description: Data analytical and statistical tools for the MBA with emphasis on descriptive and predictive quantitative analytical methods, including time series and regression. Completing an additional six contacthour tutorial will be required and incorporated into the class schedule. MBA students only or advisor approval. A-F only.

title: Micro- and Macro-economic Foundations for Managers
description: Applications of micro- and macro-economic principles to managerial decisions. Microeconomic focuses on economic foundations of business strategies. Macroeconomics focuses on the external economic environment including regulatory and international trends and issues. Admission to MBA program. Complete an additional 3 contacthour tutorial will be required and incorporated into the class schedule. MBA students only or advisor approval. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Marketing Management
description: Concepts and issues in marketing within the global environment of business. Ethical dimensions and social responsibilities; market research; consumer segmentation and positioning. Strategic marketing planning. MBA students only or advisor approval. A-F only.

title: Accounting for Decision-making
description: Accounting tools for business professionals focusing on the role of accounting information in capital markets, managerial decision-making and corporate governance. A-F only. Completing an additional 12 contact-hour tutorial will be required and incorporated into the class schedule. With instructor approval, the tutorial requirement may be waived if student has successfully completed an accounting course (ex. ACC 200 (with a minimum grade of C-) or 201 (with a minimum grade of C-) or an approved online tutorial.

title: Digital Transformation with Information Systems and Technology
description: Practices, techniques, and tools for managing digital innovation in markets, firms, and enterprise systems through information technologies and applications. Repeatable unlimited times. MBA students only or advisor approval. A-F only. (619 and 620 or consent. Spring only)

title: Leadership and Organizational Behavior
description: Personal leadership and communications development and the contributions of the behavioral sciences to understanding human behavior in organizations with a focus on leading organizations in times of change. MBA students only or advisor approval.

title: Managerial Finance
description: Financial management theories and tools for business professionals; asset management; capital budgeting; capital structure and dividend policies. MBA students only or advisor approval. A-F only. 619, 620, and 624; or consent.
prerequisites: BUS 619, BUS 620, and BUS 624; or consent

title: Business Policy and Strategy
description: Integration of learning through analysis of comprehensive business problems, resolution of policy issues, and the study of competitive strategies in the international setting. MBA core courses completed or taken concurrently; or consent. MBA students only or advisor approval.
prerequisites: MBA core courses completed or taken concurrently; or consent

title: Business Study Abroad
description: Study abroad experience emphasizing international business issues. Content varies depending on course of study and educational institution selected. Course qualifies as an international business elective(s). Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. business core or permission of academic advisor.
prerequisites: business core or permission of academic advisor

title: International Business Topics
description: Analysis of the business environment and business issues through study of businesses, governmental entities, and/or non-governmental organizations in specific geographic areas, in non-U.S. settings. Repeatable one time. A-F only. consent. (Summer only)

title: International Business Field Experience
description: Analysis of the business environment and business issues through study and direct observation of businesses, governmental entities, and/or nongovernmental organizations in non-U.S. settings. Involves group travel to selected international business cities. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 675 and consent. (Summer only)

title: Field Study in Asia
description: Industry observations conducted entirely in Asian countries for three and a half weeks. A-F only. consent.

title: Internships
description: On-the-job experience in the business community. Project paper and meetings with faculty advisor required. A-F only. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: MBA Consulting Practicum
description: Final MBA requirement for those candidates not writing a thesis. Candidates will form consulting teams to perform a meaningful, strategic study for a client organization. 632 and at least 12 credits of MBA electives. MBA students only or advisor approval.
prerequisites: BUS 632 and at least BUS 12 credits of MBA electives

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Outline (including methodology or sources, results expected and means of measurement) must be prepared by student and approved by supervisor and chair of graduate programs before registration. Repeatable up to 12 credits.

title: Thesis Research
description: Required for Plan A candidates only; six credit hours required, one of which must be taken during semester in which degree is awarded. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Advanced Research Methods
description: Analysis of current theories in international business; design research studies in areas of possible dissertation research through application of scientific method; includes formation of research questions and testable hypothesis, identification of data sources, and analysis. Repeatable one time. A-F only. two graduate level courses (six credits) in statistics and methodology, or consent.
prerequisites: two graduate level courses (six credits) in statistics and methodology, or consent

title: Research Seminar in Business
description: Covers research topics including research projects currently underway by Shidler College faculty, advanced PhD students, distinguished visiting faculty, and research contemplated by new PhD students. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. student status in PhD in business administration or consent.
prerequisites: student status in PhD in business administration or consent

title: Seminar in International Business
description: Developing research and teaching skills in international business, preparation for teaching college-level courses in “international business,” give presentation on recent research in most selective business journals, integrating expectations of university teaching, research, and service. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. student status in PhD in business administration or consent.
prerequisites: student status in PhD in business administration or consent

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. PhD student status in business administration or consent.
prerequisites: PhD student status in business administration or consent

title: Legal Environment of Business
description: Introduction to the legal environment of business operations with particular attention to business law and ethics and to principles of law relating to contracts, agency, partnerships, and corporations.

title: Business Enterprise and Government
