description: Critical study of the legal environment of business administration including competition, monopolies, mergers, securities, taxation, and regulatory agencies. 200.

title: International Business Law
description: Overview of international and national law as it applies to international trade. Readings and case studies focus on the legal environment of selected areas in the Asia Pacific region and strategies for doing business overseas. 200.

title: Social and Legal Aspects of Management
description: Study of the legal environment of management with particular attention to the sources, principles, and form of the law; contracts, business organizational structures, agency, and partnership.

title: Introductory Khmer I
description: Face to face course aims to develop students’ proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing Khmer at the introductory level, with structural points introduced inductively. Meets five hours weekly.

title: Introductory Khmer II
description: Continuation of 101. Face to face course continues to develop students’ proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing Khmer at the introductory level, with structural points introduced inductively. Meets five hours weekly. 101 or exam or consent

title: Conversing in Khmer I
description: Online course aims to develop students’ proficiency in speaking and listening to Khmer at the introductory level for the purpose of communication, travel, and for enjoyment.

title: Conversing in Khmer II
description: Continuation of 103. Online course continues to develop students’ proficiency in speaking and listening to Khmer at the introductory level for the purpose of communication, travel, and for enjoyment. 101 or 103, or consent.

title: Reading/Writing in Khmer I
description: Online course aims to develop proficiency in reading and writing Khmer at the introductory level. Uses interactive multimedia web-based content and textbook to complement online instruction.

title: Reading/Writing in Khmer II
description: Continuation of 105. Online course continues to develop proficiency in reading and writing Khmer at the introductory level. Uses interactive multimedia web-based content and textbook to complement online instruction. 101 or 105, or consent.

title: Intensive Elementary Khmer

title: Intermediate Khmer I
description: Online course provides opportunities for learners to enhance their linguistic, discourse, and sociolinguistic competencies in Khmer at the intermediate level. Uses interactive multimedia web-based content and textbook to complement the online instruction. 102, 106, or 112; or consent. (Fall only) HSL
prerequisites: CAM 102, CAM 106, or CAM 112; or consent

title: Intermediate Khmer II
description: Continuation of 201. Online course provides opportunities for learners to enhance their linguistic, discourse and sociolinguistic competencies in Khmer at the intermediate level. Uses interactive multimedia web-based content and textbook to complement the online instruction. 201 or 203, or consent. (Spring only) HSL

title: Cambodian Folktales of the Hare I
description: Intermediate level online course familiarizes students with basic language, culture and customs through study of classical Cambodian folktales of the Hare, “Judge Rabbit,” one of the most famous figures in oral folktale stories. 102, 106, or 112; or consent.
prerequisites: CAM 102, CAM 106, or CAM 112; or consent

title: Cambodian Folktales of the Hare II
description: Continuation of 203. Intermediate level online course familiarizes students with basic language, cultures and customs through study of classical Cambodian folktales of the Hare, “Judge Rabbit,” one of the most famous figures in oral folktale stories. 201 or 203, or consent. (Spring only)

title: Intensive Intermediate Khmer

title: Advanced Khmer I
description: Online course provides opportunities for learners to enhance their linguistic, discourse and sociolinguistic competencies in Khmer at the advanced level. Uses interactive multimedia web-based content and textbook to complement the web-based instruction. 202, 204, or 212; or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: CAM 202, CAM 204, or CAM 212; or consent

title: Advanced Khmer II
description: Continuation of 301. Provides opportunities for learners to enhance their linguistic, discourse and sociolinguistic competencies in Khmer at the advanced level. Uses interactive multimedia web-based content and a textbook to complement the online instruction. 301 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Accelerated Third-Level Cambodian
description: Continuation of 212. Practice in idiomatic conversation and extensive reading. Integrated development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Meets 10 hours weekly. 212.

title: Fourth-Level Khmer
description: Continuation of 302. Computer assisted learning. Advanced reading in current literature; discussion of social and cultural issues; advanced conversation and composition. 302 (or equivalent), or consent.

title: Fourth-Level Khmer
description: Continuation of 401. Computer assisted learning. 401 (or equivalent), or consent.

title: Khmer Language in the Media
description: Focus on advanced reading, writing, aural comprehension and speaking skills through the study of Khmer newspaper, radio, TV, audio/video clips and film. Repeatable one time. 402 (or equivalent), or consent.

title: Genetics, Evolution and Society
description: The role of genetics in evolution, medicine, behavior, plant and animal breeding and technology; its impact on today’s society. one semester of biological science at college level or consent. Not a BIOL major elective. (
prerequisites: one semester of biological science at college level or consent

title: Human Genetics
description: Principles of human genetics. Designed for -medical or -dental students or others who require a course with emphasis on human genetics. BIOL 172 and BIOL 172L, or consent.
prerequisites: -medical or pre-dental students or others who require a course with emphasis on human genetics

title: Genetical Problems
description: Directed reading and research in genetics. Repeatable unlimited times. 351 or 411.

title: Unit V Topics in Genetics
description: First-year elective course in which medical students may take an in-depth study of genetics. Repeatable six times. first-year medical student or consent.

title: Bioethics
description: Prepare medical students to identify and resolve ethical dilemmas in medical career and biomedical research, and to maintain integrity and professionalism in accordance with relevant ethical principles, policies, and laws. Repeatable one time. MD majors only. CR/NC only.

title: Research Topics in Cell Molecular Biology
description: Research elective for medical students. MD majors only. CR/NC only. MDED 551 and consent.

title: Evolutionary Genetics
description: Genetic changes involved in the processes of adaptation and in species formation. 411. Recommended: population and/or quantitative genetics.

title: Introduction to Neurosciences
description: An interdisciplinary overview of the central nervous system, drawn from current knowledge and research on vertebrate and invertebrate neurobiology. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Public Health Biology
description: Writing intensive asynchronous computer-based course examines biological processes and challenges relevant to the public health professional. Topics include anatomical, pathophysiological, and molecular bases of public health; genetics, immunology, ethics; disease prevention, control, and management. (Once a year) (

title: Seminar in Biomedical Sciences
description: Presentation and discussion of research topics in biomedical science. Repeatable nine times. CR/NC only. graduate standing or consent. (

title: Cell Molecular Biology I
description: Molecular approaches to cell structure and function emphasizing cells in multi-cellular plants and animals. BIOL 402 or MBBE 402; and BIOC 441, BIOL 408, and graduate standing; or consent. Recommended: CHEM 351.
prerequisites: BIOL 402 or MBBE 402; and BIOC 441, BIOL 408, and graduate standing; or consent

title: Cell Molecular Biology II
description: Molecular approaches to cell structure and function emphasizing cells in multi-cellular plants and animals. 621, BIOC 441, and BIOL 408; and either BIOL 402 or MBBE 402; or consent.
prerequisites: CMB 621, BIOC 441, and BIOL 408; and either BIOL 402 or MBBE 402; or consent

title: Advanced Topics in Genetics
description: Advanced treatment of frontiers in genetics. graduate standing in genetics or consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing in genetics or consent

title: Ethics in Biomedical Research
description: Topics include responsible data management, recording, reporting, misconduct and scientific fraud, conflicts of interest, critical use of animals and human issues and subjects in research, genetic screening, stem cell and gene therapy and patenting. (

title: Research Rotations
description: Individualized research project in three laboratories of CMB faculty with a written report on each project. Faculty laboratories will be selected by consultation with student’s graduate committee and individual faculty. Repeatable two times. 621 (or concurrent), 622 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: CMB 621 (or concurrent), CMB 622 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Neuropharmacology
description: Physiology and pharmacology of central and peripheral nervous systems, focusing on synaptic chemistry and signaling. A-F only. 606, or consent from the course director. (
prerequisites: CMB 606, or consent from the course director

title: Introductory Biostatistics for the Bench Biologist
description: Lecture and example-based introduction to the critical biostatistics skills commonly required of the bench life scientist. Technical literacy and basic practical application are the goals. Problem sets will be scored. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Introductory Bioinformatics for the Bench Biologist
description: Modern biomolecular and genomic concepts are explored through brief guided hands-on web-based bioinformatic projects using public domain resources. Understanding key concepts and algorithms, technical literacy, and operational confidence are goals. Programming skill development is student-optional. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Population Genetics
description: Mathematical, observational, experimental results on effects of mutation, selection, and systems of mating on distribution of genes. Analysis of non-experimental populations. consent. (

title: Literature Analysis and Scientific Writing
description: Aims to improve the skills of graduate students in Biomedical Sciences in literature search, analysis, and management, as well as in scientific writing and other forms of scientific communication. Graduate students only or consent. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: (Alpha) Genetics Seminar
description: Research and topical literature reports in genetics. May be repeated. (B) molecular genetics; (C) molecular biology of cancer; (D) human genetics; (E) cytogenetics; (F) evolutionary genetics; (G) molecular biology of the cell; (H) drosophila genetics; (I) population/statistical genetics; (J) developmental genetics; (K) insect molecular biology; (M) genetics and molecular biology of fungi. Repeatable unlimited times for (G). graduate standing in genetics or consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing in genetics or consent

title: Essentials in Grant Writing
description: (1 2-hr Lec) Presentation and discussion of hypothesis-driven research and grant writing. Topics include the process of proposal, submission, and review. Course work includes writing, critiquing, and revising a proposal. Graduate students only. Repeatable two times. CR/ NC only. recommended 626 and consent.

title: Techniques in Genetics
description: Laboratory training in procedures used in diagnosis of genetic diseases, cytogenetics, immunogenetics, and dermatoglyphics. Repeatable three times. graduate standing in genetics or consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing in genetics or consent

title: Techniques in Genetics
description: Continuation of 671.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. graduate standing and consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times. acceptance of thesis topic.

title: Special Topics in Neurosciences
description: Advanced topics in neuroscience, from basic neurobiology to clinical neurology and psychiatry. Emphasis on current investigations at the cellular or molecular level. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. acceptance of dissertation topic.

title: Introduction to Applied Gerontology: Helping Yourself and Others to Thrive in Later Life
description: Introduction to essential information on aging and the field of gerontology. Counters ageist stereotypes, develops skills for translating research into practice, and provides an introductory survey course for the undergraduate certificate in aging. A-F only.

title: Ethics, Aging & Society
description: Addresses ethical issues in gerontology and long-term care for older adults as raised by public policy, health care problems, and social attitudes toward elders. Explores established practices and new directions for ethics in aging. A-F only. (

title: Middle Age and Aging
description: Change and continuity in midlife and late life from theoretical and applied perspectives. Written assignments communicate information about physical and psychological age-related events, as well as social attitudes, values, to scholarly and community audiences. 230. (

title: Adult Development and Aging
description: Overview from a multidisciplinary, life-span perspective. Includes research techniques, personality development, family relationships, occupational attainment, death. PSY 100. Recommended: 240. (

title: Survey of Sociology of Aging
description: Aging as a social phenomenon, including social impacts of growing elderly population and emerging social patterns among the elderly. Important theoretical perspectives and cross-national research. SOC 100 or a 200-level sociology course, or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 100 or a SOC 200-level sociology course, or consent

title: On Death and Dying
description: Aspects of death and dying; relation to our culture and society, to understanding of each other and of ourselves.

title: Directed Reading and Research for Freshmen and Sophomores
description: Individual reading or research under supervision of COA-affiliated faculty. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits. Freshmen and sophomores only. A-F only. instructor consent.

title: Aging and Disability Policy: Intersections in Health
description: Examines health programs and policies that help kupuna and persons with disabilities stay healthy and independent, including Medicare. Will engage with local community partners for meaningful intergenerational activities and project-based learning. A-F only.

title: Back to the Future: Aging in Today’s Society
description: By 2050, more than a quarter of the world’s population will be 60 years of age or older. Explores what we know about aging today to encourage a lifetime of aging well. A-F only. PH 201 or SW 360 or WGSS 305 or PSY 100 or HDFS 230 or NURS 200; or consent. (
prerequisites: PH 201 or SW 360 or WGSS 305 or PSY 100 or HDFS 230 or NURS 200; or consent

title: Gerontology, Health Care, and the Law (Elder Law)
description: Provides a basic foundation for studies at the intersection of gerontology, health care, and the law and places an emphasis on proactive and preventive law for older adults in society. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (

title: Directed Reading and Research forJuniors and Seniors
description: Individual reading or research under supervision of COA-affiliated faculty. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits. Juniors and seniors only. consent of instructor.

title: Foundations in Disability and Diversity
description: Focuses on disability as a category of diversity and identity, as well as diversity within disability. Different strategies used to increase the freedom or liberty of people with disabilities are critically examined. A-F only.

title: Accessible Learning Technology
description: Focuses on creating accessible technology and instructional media, developing long-term resources, advancing accessible social interaction between students and students with instructors, and using case studies as examples of good practices. A-F only.

title: Disability History and Culture: From Homer to Hip Hop
description: How have people over many centuries, and from broad geographical perspectives perceived and treated individuals with disabilities? An overview of the history of the conditions in which people with disabilities lived. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Research in Curriculum and Teaching
description: Classroom-based research covers the fundamentals of qualitative, quantitative, Action Research, mixed methods, and Curriculum Based Assessment. Exploratory, explanatory, and confirmatory research will be highlighted culminating in an outline for Plan B/Thesis proposal. (

title: Social Emotional Learning (SEL) Pedagogy and Practice
description: Introduces concepts, theories, and pedagogies of Social Emotional Learning (SEL), health and wellness, and trauma informed teaching with an emphasis on culture, social justice, and equity in Hawai‘i and our global community. A-F only. (Summer only) (

title: Sexuality & Health
description: Examines concepts, theories, and skills-based practices of sexuality and health. Topics on underserved populations, disability, reproductive health, family planning, and family health. Utilizes research-based curriculum/strategies to promote personal and social responsibility for health. (

title: Supporting Multilingual Learners
description: Strategies for identifying and adopting best practices that support all students in inclusive learning environments with an emphasis on STEM curriculum for English Language Learners; (B) science; (C) technology; (D) math. A-F only.

title: Practicum in Applied Behavior Analysis
description: Supervised field experience in applied behavior analysis. The format is a combination of fieldwork and seminar meetings. Repeatable four times or up to 15 credits. A-F only.

title: Disability History Through the Ages
description: A historical overview of disability that visits diverse perspectives, attitudes, and treatment toward individuals with disabilities through many centuries, societies, and cultures throughout the world; and how people with disabilities perceived themselves. A-F only.

title: Multicultural Issues in Disabilities
description: Provide background and understanding of various Pacific Rim cultural issues in the conceptualization and treatment of individuals with disabilities and their families. A-F only.

title: Special Topics in Disability and Diversity Studies
description: Explores disability and diversity across time to gain an understanding and context of issues such as difference, culture, identity, community, privilege, and oppression and how the past affects the present and future. Repeatable two times. A-F only.

title: Interdisciplinary Disability and Diversity Issues
description: Develop understanding of current issues faced by individuals with disabilities and their families within the disability paradigm and across cultures.

title: Interdisciplinary Team Development
description: Develop knowledge and skills to participate effectively on interdisciplinary teams for the common goal of promoting service integration and coordination of education, social, health, mental health, and other services with individuals with disabilities and their families. A-F only.

title: Interdisciplinary Assessment
description: Assessment methods and techniques to instructional research-based practices and supports across disciplines, cultures and PK-12 that address barriers to learning for all students with the context of the Comprehensive Student Support System (CSSS). A-F only.

title: Advanced Interdisciplinary Assessment
description: Assessment methods and techniques to instructional research-based practices and supports across disciplines, cultures and PK-12 that address barriers to learning for all students with the context of the Comprehensive Student Support System (CSSS). A-F only.

title: Seminar on Disability Issues
description: In-depth explorations of current and compelling interdisciplinary topics related to advancing the social, political, educational, and economic integration of individuals with disabilities of all ages. A-F only.

title: Portfolio/Field Work
description: Interdisciplinary community experience and portfolio in disability and diversity studies. Repeatable three times. A-F only.

title: Directed Reading and/or Research
description: Directed reading and/or research. Repeatable three times. A-F only. consent.

title: Mixed Methods Research Design
description: Mixed methods research is designed for PhD and masters students in education and social sciences considering combining qualitative and quantitative research. Covers philosophical and practical implications culminating in a mixed methods dissertation/thesis proposal. Repeatable one time. (Once a year) (

title: Elementary Chamorro
description: Introduction to Chamorro, emphasis on listening and speaking, language structure. Meets three hours weekly.

title: Elementary Chamorro
description: Listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills; emphasis on oral and reading proficiency. Meets five hours weekly. 101 (or equivalent), or consent.

title: Intermediate Chamorro
description: Continuation of 102. Emphasis on comprehension and language production (speaking). Meets five hours weekly. 102 (or equivalent), or consent.

title: Intermediate Chamorro
description: Continuation of 201. Emphasis on comprehension and language production. 201 (or equivalent), or consent.

title: Chemistry and Society
description: Introduction to chemistry for non-science majors. Discussion of basic chemistry concepts and their application to everyday life. No credit for science and engineering majors. A-F only. Students who successfully completed 110/SUST 120 with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 100 without instructor override. Students who successfully complete 100 with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 110/SUST 120 without instructor override.

title: Chemistry and Society Laboratory
description: Laboratory to accompany CHEM 100, 110, or SUST 120. Lab introduces fundamental applications of chemistry, with special emphasis on relevant topics and how chemistry relates to the real world. (For students in non-science fields.) A-F only. 100 (or concurrent), 110 (or concurrent), or SUST 120 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: CHEM 100 (or concurrent), CHEM 110 (or concurrent), or SUST 120 (or concurrent)

title: Chemistry in a Sustainable World
description: Introduction to chemistry for non-science majors. Discussion of the role of natural and manmade chemicals in everyday life, with an emphasis on sustainable and environmentally-sensitive use of chemicals to improve our world. A-F only. Students who successfully completed 100 with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 110/SUST 120 without instructor override. Students who successfully complete 110/SUST 120 with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 100 without instructor override. (

title: Elementary Survey of Chemistry
description: Nonrigorous but adequate background in fundamentals. Preparation for technical training in life sciences.

title: Elementary Survey of Chemistry Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Experiments introducing laboratory techniques and illustrating chemical principles. 151 (or concurrent).

title: Survey of Organic and Bioorganic Chemistry
description: Structure, nomenclature, properties, reactions of organic compounds emphasizing those of practical importance in related fields. 151, 162, or 171.

title: Survey of Organic and Bioorganic Chemistry Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Techniques of preparation, purification, identification of organic compounds. 151L, 162L, or 171L; and 152 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: CHEM 151L, CHEM 162L, or CHEM 171L; and CHEM 152 (or concurrent)

title: General Chemistry I
description: Basic principles of chemistry, including stoichiometry. Introduction to solution phase chemistry. Gas phase chemistry. Thermodynamics, including enthalpies of formation and reaction. Atomic structure, periodic trends, chemical bonding, molecular structure. Students who successfully completed 171 or 181A with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 161 without instructor override. Students who successfully complete 161 with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 171 or 181A without instructor override. C (not C-) in 131 or C (not C-) in 151 or successful completion of placement exam, or consent.
prerequisites: C (not C-) in CHEM 131 or C (not C-) in CHEM 151 or successful completion of placement exam, or consent

title: General Chemistry Lab I
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory experiments introducing techniques and fundamental principles of chemistry. Students who successfully completed 171 or 181A with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 161 without instructor override. Students who successfully complete 161 with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 171 or 181A without instructor override. 161 (or concurrent).

title: General Chemistry II
description: Continuation of 161. Liquids and solids. Solutions and colligative properties. Continuation of thermodynamics, including entropy and free energy. Principles and applications of chemical equilibrium, including acidbase chemistry (titrations, buffers). Kinetics. Redox reactions and electrochemistry. C (not C-) or better in 161.
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in CHEM 161

title: General Chemistry Lab II
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory experiments introducing techniques and fundamental principles of chemistry. C (not C-) or better in 161L and 162 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in CHEM 161L and CHEM 162 (or concurrent)

title: Principles of Chemistry
description: Principles, theories, elementary analytical methods of chemistry. Intended for physical science majors and engineers. Satisfactory Placement Exam score, and MATH 241 or MATH 242 or MATH 243 or MATH 251A or MATH 252A or MATH 253A. Co-requisite: 171L. Students who successfully completed 161 or 181A with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 171 without instructor override. Students who successfully complete 171 with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 161 or 181A without instructor override. (Fall only)
prerequisites: Satisfactory Placement Exam score, and MATH 241 or MATH 242 or MATH 243 or MATH 251A or MATH 252A or MATH 253A

title: Principles of Chemistry Lab
description: (1 3.5- hr Lab) Laboratory experiments illustrating fundamental principles of chemistry. Students who successfully completed 161L or 181A with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 171 without instructor override. Students who successfully complete 171L with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 161L or 181A without instructor override. Co-requisite: 171. (Fall only)

title: Honors General Chemistry
description: Rigorous, in-depth introduction to chemical principles with emphasis on experimental and applied aspects of modern chemistry. Students who successfully completed 161 or 171 with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 181A without instructor override. Students who successfully complete 181A with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 161 or 171 without instructor override. satisfactory placement exam score and MATH 215 (or concurrent) or MATH 241 (or concurrent) or MATH 251A (or concurrent) with a minimum grade of C. (Fall only)
prerequisites: satisfactory placement exam score and MATH 215 (or concurrent) or MATH 241 (or concurrent) or MATH 251A (or concurrent) with a minimum grade of C

title: Honors General Chemistry Laboratory
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory experiments illustrating chemical principles involving advanced techniques and modern instrumentation. A-F only. Students who successfully completed 161L or 171L with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 181L without instructor override. Students who successfully complete 181L with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 161L or 171L without instructor override. Corequisite: 181A.

title: Organic Chemistry I
description: Molecular structure, stereochemistry, spectroscopy, mechanisms, reactions, and synthesis of organic compounds. C (not C-) or better in 162 or 171 or 181A.
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in CHEM 162 or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A

title: Organic Chemistry I Lab
description: (1 4-hr Lab) Techniques, synthesis and qualitative analysis, applications of spectroscopy. C (not C-) or better in 162L, 171L, or 181L; and C (not C-) or better in 272 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in CHEM 162L, CHEM 171L, or CHEM 181L; and C (not C-) or better in CHEM 272 (or concurrent)

title: Organic Chemistry II
description: Continuation of 272. Molecular structure, stereochemistry, spectroscopy, mechanisms, reactions, and synthesis of organic compounds. C (not C-) or better in 272.
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in CHEM 272

title: Organic Chemistry II Lab
description: (1 4-hr Lab) Techniques, synthesis and qualitative analysis, applications of spectroscopy. C (not C-) or better in 272L and 273 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in CHEM 272L and CHEM 273 (or concurrent)

title: Principles of Analytical Chemistry
description: Selected methods and principles, e.g., phase equilibria, ionic equilibria, electrode equilibria, separations, spectroscopy, automation, and process control. C (not C-) or better in 162 or 171 or 181A, MATH 215 or MATH 241 or MATH 251A.
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in CHEM 162 or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A, MATH 215 or MATH 241 or MATH 251A

title: Principles of Analytical Chemistry Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) Phase separations, chromatography, titrimetry, spectrophotometry, etc. C (not C-) or better in 162L or 171L or 181L; and 274 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in CHEM 162L or CHEM 171L or CHEM 181L; and CHEM 274 (or concurrent)

title: Physical Chemistry I
description: Principles and theories; physico-chemical procedures. 274, 274L, PHYS 272, PHYS 272L, and MATH 243 or MATH 253A.
prerequisites: CHEM 274, CHEM 274L, PHYS 272, PHYS 272L, and MATH 243 or MATH 253A

title: Physical Chemistry II
description: Continuation of 351. 351.

title: Physico-Chemical Measurements
description: (2 3-hr Lab) Laboratory on instrumentation, measurements, and data analysis in thermodynamics, spectroscopy, and other areas of physical chemistry. Emphasis on instruction in scientific reporting writing. 274L, 351, and 352 (or concurrent).

title: Bioorganic Chemistry
description: Mechanism of biochemical reactions, biophysical structure, techniques for studying biochemical reactions. 273 (with a grade of C or better) or graduate standing with consent, or departmental approval. (Fall only)
prerequisites: CHEM 273 (with a grade of C or better) or graduate standing with consent, or departmental approval

title: Professional Ethics for Chemists
description: Student team-led discussions of contemporary ethical issues and ethical decision making in chemistry using case studies and additional examples from the media. CHEM or BIOC majors only. CR/NC only. 274 (or concurrent). (Spring only)

title: Directed Reading
description: Directed reading and discussion of scientific journal articles culminating in a written literature review. Repeatable unlimited times. CHEM or BIOC majors only.minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or minimum in-major GPA of 3.0.

title: Directed Research
description: Directed laboratory research culminating in a written research report. Repeatable unlimited times. CHEM or BIOC majors only. A-F only. minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or minimum in-major GPA of 3.0.

title: Synthesis and Analysis of Inorganic Compounds
description: Lecture on advanced methods of preparation and characterization of inorganic compounds and materials. A-F only. 351 (or concurrent) or 461 (or concurrent). (Fall only)

title: Preparation and Analysis of Inoraganic Compounds Laboratory
description: Laboratory on preparative methods and analytical techniques and instruments in inorganic chemistry. A-F only. 425 (or concurrent). (Fall only)

title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
description: Classification, description, fundamental theory. 425.

title: Experimental Methods in Materials Research
crossListings: 1 Lec, 2 2-hr Lab Common experimental techniques in materials testing and research: x-ray diffraction, optical and electron microscopy, thermal and mechanical properties, electrochemical methods—theory and hands-on experience. Pre: 351 or concurrent or ME 341. Crosslisted as ME 435

title: Synthesis and Analysis of Organic Compounds
description: Introduction to multi-step synthesis and instruments/analytical techniques used to characterize organic compounds. Retrosynthesis and diastereoselective reactions; spectroscopy (optical methods, NMR), mass spectrometry. Chromatography (GC, HPLC) and coupled techniques (GCMS, LCMS). CHEM or BIOC majors only. A-F only. 273 with a grade of C (not C-) or better, or departmental approval. (Spring only)
prerequisites: CHEM 273 with a grade of C (not C-) or better, or departmental approval

title: Preparation and Analysis of Organic Compounds Laboratory
description: Laboratory on the preparation of organic compounds and physical methods for their characterization. Includes optical methods (UV-vis, IR), chromatography (HPLC, GC), mass spectrometry (GCMS and LCMS) and NMR. A-F only. 273L with a grade of C (not C-) or better, or departmental approval. Co-requisite: 445. (Spring only)
prerequisites: CHEM 273L with a grade of C (not C-) or better, or departmental approval

title: Physical Biochemistry
description: Biochemical thermodynamics, chemical and enzyme kinetics, biomolecular structure, and biomolecular spectroscopy. A-F only. 162, PHYS 272, and MATH 242 or 252A with a grade of C or better for
prerequisites: CHEM 162, PHYS 272, and MATH 242 or MATH 252A with a grade of C or better for prerequisites

title: Advanced Biochemistry
description: Advanced topics in biochemistry including nucleic acid replication, transcription, and translation; genetic and epigenetic regulation; bioenergetics and control of metabolism; alternative metabolic strategies; and enzyme structure and mechanism. A-F only. 372 and BIOL 402. (Spring only)

title: Advanced Biochemistry Lab
description: Advanced biochemistry lab techniques: protein purification and characterization, identification of unknown proteins, enzyme kinetics, ligand binding, enzyme kinetics, protein structure, and spectroscopy, with instruction in writing scientific reports. A-F only. 274L, 372, 462 (or concurrent), and BIOL 275L.
prerequisites: CHEM 274L, CHEM 372, CHEM 462 (or concurrent), and BIOL 275L

title: Introduction to Research
description: Introduction to field-specific methods and skills needed for success in graduate research. Includes training modules for safety, ethics, and library resources. Short faculty research overviews may also be given.CHEM majors only. Graduate students only. CR/NC only. (Fall only)

title: Theory of Chemical Bonding
description: Application of quantum mechanics and symmetry principles to descriptions of chemical bonding. graduate standing in CHEM.

title: Chemical Applications of Spectroscopy
description: Introduction to magnetic resonance, infrared, UV, and visible spectroscopy, emphasizing applications to organic and inorganic chemistry. Three topics each semester–1 credit hour per topic. Repeatable unlimited times in different topics. graduate standing in CHEM.

title: Organometallics I
description: Reactivity and reaction mechanisms of compounds containing metalcarbon bonds. 352 and 427.

title: Coordination Chemistry
description: Survey of Lewis acids and bases, coordination numbers, geometries, stereochemistry, ligand field theory, formation constants, and bioinorganic chemistry. 601 and 602 (or concurrent).

title: Organometallics II
description: Introduction to the principles of catalysis and the classes of catalytic reactions effected by organometallic compounds. A-F only. 622 and a minimum required grade for of B.
prerequisites: CHEM 622 and a minimum required grade for prerequisites of B

title: Methods of Instrumental Analysis
description: Theory, instrumentation, applications. Three areas each semester-one credit hour per area. Repeatable unlimited times in different areas. 333 and graduate standing in CHEM or consent.
prerequisites: CHEM 333 and graduate standing in CHEM or consent

title: Organic Structure Determination
description: Interpretation of chemical and physical (primarily spectral) data in the identification of organic compounds. graduate standing or consent.

title: Organic Synthesis I
description: Modern synthetic methods with emphasis on the design and execution of multi-step sequences. graduate standing or consent

title: Physical Organic Chemistry
description: Theory of molecular structure, stereochemistry, and reaction mechanisms. 601 or consent.

title: Organic Synthesis II
description: Continuation of 642, and is the second half of a two-semester course in Modern Organic Synthesis. 642 and a minimum required grade for of B. (Spring only)
prerequisites: CHEM 642 and a minimum required grade for prerequisites of B

title: Chemical Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
description: Includes statistical thermodynamics, with application to chemical systems. graduate standing in CHEM.

title: Chemical Kinetics and Reaction Dynamics
description: Kinetics and chemical reaction dynamics of elementary reactions relevant to combustion processes, astrochemistry, chemical vapor deposition and planetary sciences. graduate standing in CHEM. (Spring only)

title: Quantum Chemistry
description: Rigorous introduction to quantum mechanics, including operator formalism, matrix formation, group theory, and perturbation theory; introduction to the electronic structure of atoms and molecules. graduate standing in CHEM.

title: Astrochemistry–A Molecular Approach
description: Formation of astrobiologically important molecules and their precursors in the interstellar medium and in our solar system: first principles and latest trends. consent. (Fall only) (

title: Crystallography
description: Crystal symmetry. Elementary x-ray physics. Diffraction theory and its application to crystal and molecular structure determination. 352 and MATH 244 or MATH 253A.

title: Enzyme Reaction Mechanisms
description: The chemical mechanisms of reactions catalyzed by enzymes in biochemical pathways, with an emphasis on the major types of cofactor and metal catalyzed reactions. graduate standing or consent.

title: Computational Modeling in Chemistry
description: Theory and application of computational modeling in chemistry. Statistical theory behind molecular dynamics simulations, application to modeling chemical systems, computer programming, and analysis of results. Graduate students only.

title: (Alpha) Chemistry Seminar I
description: Current topics in (D) physical; (E) organic; (Q) biochemistry; (Z) inorganic chemistry. Repeatable unlimited times. graduate standing.

title: (Alpha) Chemistry Seminar II
description: Continuation of 691. Current topics in: (D) physical; (E) organic; (Q) biochemistry; (Z) inorganic chemistry. Repeatable unlimited times. graduate standing.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. candidacy for MS degree and consent of thesis chair.
prerequisites: candidacy for MS degree and consent of thesis chair

title: Special Topics: Inorganic Chemistry
description: Theory and applications. Repeatable unlimited times in different topics. consent.

title: Special Topics: Organic Chemistry
description: Theory and applications. Repeatable unlimited times in different topics. consent.

title: Special Topics: Physical Chemistry
description: Theory and applications. Repeatable unlimited times in different topics. consent.

title: Special Topics: Biochemistry
description: Theory and applications. A-F only. Repeatable unlimited times in different topics.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. candidacy for PhD degree and consent of dissertation chair.
prerequisites: candidacy for PhD degree and consent of dissertation chair

title: Elementary Mandarin I
description: Listening, speaking, reading, writing, grammar. Meets one hour, four times a week. placement test.

title: Elementary Mandarin II
description: Continuation of 101. 101 or consent.

title: Accelerated Elementary Mandarin
description: Content of 101 and 102 covered in one semester. Meets two hours, four times a week. placement test.

title: Elementary Chinese for Business Professionals
description: Accelerated, intensive elementary course focusing on everyday listening, speaking, reading, and writing communicative needs of business professionals in the Chinese business context. consent. (Fall only)

title: Elementary Conversational Mandarin I
description: Development of basic skills (listening, speaking and grammar) of spoken Mandarin with application to some familiar everyday topics.

title: Elementary Conversational Mandarin II
description: Continuation of 111. 101 or 111 or consent.

title: Intermediate Mandarin I
description: Continuation of 101 and 102. Meets one hour a day, four times a week. 102 or 103 or 105; or consent.
prerequisites: CHN 102 or CHN 103 or CHN 105; or consent

title: Intermediate Mandarin II
description: Continuation of 201. 201 or consent.

title: Accelerated Intermediate Mandarin
description: Content of 201 and 202 covered in one semester. Meets two hours, four times a week. placement test and 102 or 103 or 105; or consent.
prerequisites: placement test and CHN 102 or CHN 103 or CHN 105; or consent

title: Intermediate Chinese for Business Professionals
description: Accelerated, intensive intermediate course focusing on everyday listening, speaking, reading, and writing communicative needs of business professionals in the Chinese business context. 105 (or equivalent) or consent.

title: Intermediate Conversational Mandarin I
description: Further development of listening and speaking skills in Mandarin. The student is expected to be able to comprehend and produce speech at the paragraph level. 102 or 103 or 112, or consent.
prerequisites: CHN 102 or CHN 103 or CHN 112, or consent

title: Intermediate Conversational Mandarin II
description: Continuation of 211. 201 or 211, or consent.

title: Reading and Writing Chinese I
description: For students who have completed the conversational Mandarin courses up through 212 and wish to continue on to 301, or others who can handle daily conversation in Mandarin but cannot read or write in the language. 212 or consent.

title: Reading and Writing Chinese II
description: Continuation of 251. 251 or consent.

title: Third-Level Mandarin I
description: Vocabulary building and extended mastery of sentence structures of modern Chinese through reading and related conversation. Meets one hour a day, three times a week. 202 or 204 or 205 or 252; or consent.
prerequisites: CHN 202 or CHN 204 or CHN 205 or CHN 252; or consent

title: Third-Level Mandarin II
description: Continuation of 301. 301 or consent.

title: Accelerated Third-Level Mandarin
description: Content of 301 and 302 covered in one semester. Meets two hours, three times a week. 202 or 204 or 205 or 252; or consent.
prerequisites: CHN 202 or CHN 204 or CHN 205 or CHN 252; or consent

title: Third-Year Chinese for Business Professionals
description: Accelerated, intensive advanced course focusing on general advanced listening, speaking, reading, and writing communicative needs of business professionals in the Chinese business context. 205 (or equivalent) or consent.

title: Mandarin Conversation I
description: Systematic practice on everyday topics of conversation. Lab work. 202 or 204 or 252; or consent.
prerequisites: CHN 202 or CHN 204 or CHN 252; or consent

title: Mandarin Conversation II
description: Continuation of 311. 311 or consent.

title: Chinese Dialect Studies
description: Advanced Cantonese or other Chinese dialects. Repeatable one time. CR/NC for native Chinese speakers. consent.

title: Advanced Chinese Listening and Writing
description: Web-based training in Chinese listening, reading, and writing to develop skills at the advanced level. Activities combine independent work with communicative activities on the course website. Features language exchange with native speakers. Repeatable one time. 301 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing
description: Web-based training in Chinese reading and writing to develop skills at the advanced level. Activities combine independent work with communicative activities on the course web site. Ideal for in-service professionals seeking language development and maintenance. Repeatable one time. 301 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Directed Third-Level Reading
description: For those who need special assistance, e.g., in reading texts in their area of specialization or at a pace more rapid than those of standard courses. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. consent.

title: Fourth-Level Mandarin I
description: Extensive reading in academic topics. Meets one hour a day, three times a week. 302 or 303 or 305; or consent.
prerequisites: CHN 302 or CHN 303 or CHN 305; or consent

title: Fourth-Level Mandarin II
description: Continuation of 401. 401 or consent.

title: Accelerated Fourth-Level Mandarin
description: Content of 401 and 402 covered in one semester. Meets two hours, three times a week. 302 or 303 or 305; or consent.
prerequisites: CHN 302 or CHN 303 or CHN 305; or consent

title: Fourth-Year Chinese for Business Professionals
description: Accelerated, intensive advanced course focusing on specialized advanced listening, speaking, reading, and writing communicative needs of business professionals in the Chinese business context. 305 (or equivalent) or consent.

title: High-Advanced Chinese I
description: Authentic reading, writing, speaking, and listening with Advanced-high and Superior level discourse, content, and genres to build Superior Chinese proficiency and broaden knowledge of Chinese culture. Significant attention paid to developing Chinese writing skills. 402 or 404 or 405, or instructor consent.
prerequisites: CHN 402 or CHN 404 or CHN 405, or instructor consent

title: High-Advanced Chinese II
description: Aims to build Superior Level Chinese proficiency in reading, speaking, writing, and listening using authentic texts covering Chinese education, and economy, philosophy, while broadening and deepening knowledge of Chinese culture. 402, 404, 405, or instructor consent. (Spring only)
prerequisites: CHN 402, CHN 404, CHN 405, or instructor consent

title: Advanced Mandarin Conversation I
description: Systematic practice on academic topics of conversation. Lab work. 302 or 303, or consent.

title: Advanced Mandarin Conversation II
description: Continuation of 411. 411 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Chinese Translation
description: Training in techniques; theory of translation. (B) Chinese–English; (C) English–Chinese. consent.

title: Media Analysis in Chinese
description: Use authentic materials, including texts, videos, and postings from social media with Advanced and Superior level discourse and content to build Superior Chinese proficiency and social media literacy, and understand society and contemporary issues. 402, or 404, or 405, or instructor consent.
prerequisites: CHN 402, or CHN 404, or CHN 405, or instructor consent

title: Fourth Year Reading and Writing: Advanced Topics
description: Asynchronous web-based course with focuses on (i) reading selected texts across a broad range of genres, and (ii) writing expository and argumentative essays by referencing and reflecting on the readings, along with interacting with peers. 401 (or concurrent) or equivalent or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: CHN 401 (or concurrent) or equivalent or consent

title: Fourth Year Reading and Writing: Contemporary Social Issues
description: Asynchronous web-based course with focuses on (i) authentic texts covering a variety of contemporary social issues, and (ii) writing expository/argumentative essays by referencing and reflecting on the readings, along with interacting with peers. 401 (or concurrent) or consent. (Spring only)

title: Chinese Language and Linguistics
description: Covers major areas of linguistic description as applied to Chinese language, with significant attention paid to developing writing skills on demonstrating knowledge of the basics of Chinese linguistic features and analyzing Chinese language phenomena. 202, 204, or 205; or consent.
prerequisites: CHN 202, CHN 204, or CHN 205; or consent

title: Structure of Chinese
description: Introduction to syntax and semantics of Mandarin Chinese; some discussion of usage and linguistic geography. 202 or 204; or consent.

title: Study of Chinese Characters I
description: Origin, structure, and evolution. 402, 461; or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Study of Chinese Characters II
description: Continuation of 453. 453 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Chinese Pragmatics and Discourse
description: Introduction to pragmatics and discourse analysis of Mandarin Chinese; some discussion of usage and linguistic geography. 202, 204; or consent.

title: Chinese Semantics and Communication
description: Study of the meaning of Chinese sentences in isolation, in discourse contexts, and in written texts. Pays equal attention to theoretical issues and practical problems in Chinese semantics and communication. 202 or 204, or consent. (Once a year)

title: Chinese Words and the Lexicon
description: Defines properties of the Chinese lexicon, introduces its principles, approaches, and methodologies in Chinese lexicology, outlines similarities and differences between the Chinese and English lexicons, and advances students’ Chinese language proficiency. 202 or 205, or consent. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Introduction to Classical Chinese
description: Analysis of basic structural patterns through selected readings in various texts. 302 or consent.

title: Language and Culture of China
description: Extensive exposure–chiefly through tape recordings, classroom conversation, and outside readings–to history, culture, and institutions. 202 or 204, or consent.

title: Professional Chinese
description: Focus on professional reading, writing, speaking, and listening in order to train students to the Superior (according to ACTFL standards) level of language proficiency. Repeatable one time when taken in China as part of the UH Chinese Flagship Program. 402 or consent.

title: Academic
description: Focus on academic reading, writing, speaking, and listening with emphasis on writing instruction in order to train students to the Superior (according to ACTFL standards) level of language proficiency. Repeatable one time when taken in China as part of the UH Chinese Flagship Program. 402 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Readings in 20th Century Chinese Literature
description: Representative works of writers from People’s Republic of China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. (B) short stories; (C) poetry and drama; (D) novels and essays. Repeatable two times. 402 or consent.

title: Flagship Rhetoric and Composition Abroad
description: Designed for students participating in the Flagship Capstone Year in China taught entirely in Chinese. Students will improve their knowledge of and ability to use Chinese to effectively communicate in writing. A-F only. 486 or consent.

title: Flagship Media and Society Abroad
description: Designed for students participating in the Flagship Capstone Year in China taught entirely in Chinese. Students will improve their knowledge of Chinese media, how it operates, and its effects on Chinese society. A-F only. 486 or consent.

title: Flagship Experience Abroad
description: Designed for students participating in the Flagship Capstone Year in China taught entirely in Chinese. Students will take two courses taught in Chinese in their field at Nanjing or Beijing Union University. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. CR/NC only. 486 or consent.

title: Oral Fluency Through Chinese Films
description: Increasing Chinese proficiency through film, which offers authentically rich cultural contexts. Focus on oral communication. 301 or consent.

title: Internship Program
description: Faculty supervised participation in the operations of an organization in a position making use of students’ Chinese language skills in Hawai‘i. Students must achieve a grade of B- in CHN 302 to take this course. Repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. CHN majors only. Junior/senior standing only. 302 (with a minimum grade of B-) or consent.
prerequisites: CHN 302 (with a minimum grade of B-) or consent

title: Overseas Internship in China
description: Supervised internships in a Chinese-speaking institution in China. Students must pass 486 with a B- or higher and be accepted to the Flagship Capstone Year in China to take this. Repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. CR/NC only. 461 and 485 and 486 (with a minimum grade of B- or better) and proficiency assessment and acceptance to Flagship Capstone year in China.
prerequisites: CHN 461 and CHN 485 and CHN 486 (with a minimum grade of B- or better) and proficiency assessment and acceptance to Flagship Capstone year in China

title: Directed Fourth-Level Reading
description: For those who need special assistance, e.g., in reading texts in area of specialization or at a pace more rapid than those of standard courses. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. Primarily for graduate students from other departments. consent

title: Introduction to Study of Contemporary Chinese Linguistics
description: Panoramic overview of major perspectives in contemporary Chinese linguistics. Readings on recent developments of fields. Report on selected research papers and present analysis of linguistic phenomena of interest. 452 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: (Alpha) Chinese Poetry
description: Critical study of major traditional Chinese poetic forms. (B) ancient (to 5th century); (C) medieval (5th–10th century). 461 or consent for (B), 610B or consent for (C).
prerequisites: CHN 461 or consent for (B), CHN 610B or consent for (C)

title: Traditional Chinese Fiction
description: Formal and thematic analysis of short stories, historical romances, and novels. Repeatable one time with consent. 402 or consent.

title: (Alpha) History of Chinese Language
description: (B) phonology; (C) syntax. 451, LING 421, or consent for (B); 452 or consent for (C).
prerequisites: CHN 451, LING 421, or consent for (B); LING 452 or consent for (C)

title: Chinese Dialects
description: Synchronic description of a Chinese dialect other than Cantonese and Mandarin; contrastive and comparative studies with Mandarin. Repeatable one time with consent. 451 and 452, or consent.

title: Chinese Syntax and Semantics
description: Verbal categories, aspects, focus devices, resultative and directional compounds, coverbial constructions. Interaction between syntax and semantics. 452 or consent.

title: Contrastive Analysis of Mandarin and English
Methods in Teaching Chinese as Second Language
description: Problems in language learning and teaching. Practice in preparing and presenting lessons with materials based on comparative linguistic analysis. Materials, teaching aids, test construction. 451 and 452, or consent.

title: Practicum: Teaching Chinese Language
description: For graduate students pursuing teaching Chinese language. Students gain practical skills and hands-on experiences in creating instructional and assessment materials and teaching an actual Chinese language class using the self-developed materials effectively. 643 or consent. (Alt. years: fall)

title: (Alpha) Topics in Chinese Language
description: Extensive studies of selected topics (B) teaching and testing: specific problems in teaching Chinese including characters and cultural elements; proficiency and communicative ability; (C) cognitive grammar. A-F only for (C). 451 and 452, or consent. Once a year.

title: Current Topics in Chinese Grammar
description: Current approaches to Chinese grammar and related issues and debates, focusing on the papers published by leading Chinese linguists employing these approaches. 452, 455, or 456; or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: CHN 452, CHN 455, or CHN 456; or consent

title: Second Semester Classical Chinese
description: Builds on the foundation laid in 461; introduces complex syntactic patterns, advanced vocabulary; teaches sophisticated reading strategies and cultural literary contexts; exposes students to a wide range of intermediate level texts. Repeatable two times. 461 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Advanced Classical Chinese
description: 660 and consent.

title: Advanced Classical Chinese
description: 661 and consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. consent.

title: (Alpha) Research Seminar in Chinese Language
description: (B) teaching methods; (C) structure; (D) classical grammar; (E) sociolinguistics. 643 for (B) and (E); 452 for (C) and (D).
prerequisites: CHN 643 for (B) and (E); CHN 452 for (C) and (D)

title: (Alpha) Research Seminar in Chinese Literature
description: Study of authors, a genre, a period, or a problem. (M) modern; (T) traditional. Repeatable one time for (M). A-F only for (M). EALL 611, WGSS 613, WGSS 615, or WGSS 650; or consent for (M); 612, or consent for (T). (
prerequisites: EALL 611, WGSS 613, WGSS 615, or WGSS 650; or consent for (M); WGSS 612, or consent for (T)

title: Surveying/Geodesy/Geomatics
description: Plane surveying for cadastral, engineering, and construction applications including taping, leveling, traverses, bearings and azimuths, areas and volumes, EDM. Geodesy, map projections, satellite geodesy (GPS), geodetic surveying and photogrammetry. Field lab in notes and procedures. Repeatable one time. Restricted to CEE majors. Sophomore standing or higher. MATH 252A or 242.

title: CAD/BIM/3D Visualization
description: Computer-aided drafting (CAD) tools using AutoCAD and Revit. AutoCAD interface, titleblocks, model/paper space, viewports, texts and annotation, dimensioning. Basics of BIM, toolbox, modeling techniques, annotating, dimensioning. CAD drafting to real-world engineering applications. Repeatable one time. Restricted to CEE majors. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Applied Mechanics I
description: Forces, resultants, and equilibrium; analysis of trusses, frames, and machines; centroids, moments of inertia; friction. A-F only. grade of C or better in all of the following: PHYS 170; MATH 242 or 252A; and either MATH 243 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent).
prerequisites: grade of C or better in all of the following: PHYS 170; MATH 242 or MATH 252A; and either MATH 243 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent)

title: Applied Mechanics II
description: Dynamics of particles and rigid bodies; force, acceleration, impulse-momentum, work-energy. CE, CNST, ENGS, ME majors only. A-F only. C or better in 270; MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent). (
prerequisites: C or better in CEE 270; MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent)

title: Applied Probability and Statistics
description: Description of sample data; correlation and regression; probability and statistical distributions; estimations of population parameters; fitting distributions to histograms; hypothesis testing. A-F only. MATH 244 or MATH 253A.

title: Fluid Mechanics Fundamentals
description: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Compressible and incompressible fluid properties; fluid statics; kinematics, energy and momentum considerations in steady flows; application of steady flow concepts to various fluid processes; with an emphasis on instruction in writing lab reports. A-F only. 271.

title: Environmental Engineering
description: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Parameters and indices of environmental quality; materials balances; chemical kinetics; ideal reactor models; water and air pollution control; solid and hazardous waste management; emphasis on instruction in writing lab reports. A-F only. 271.

title: Geotechnical Engineering I
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to geotechnical engineering: soil characterization, index properties, seepage and flow in soil, stresses in soils, compressibility, consolidation, shear strength. Substantial emphasis on writing lab reports. A-F only. 320, 370.

title: Fundamentals of Transportation
description: Transportation modes: land, air, water, pipelines. Tourist, urban transportation. Geometric design, human factors, vehicular flow models, capacity analysis. Overview: traffic impact, air quality, parking studies. A-F only. 271.

title: Mechanics of Solids
description: Introduction to analysis and design of deformable bodies subject to loading. Stress, strain, constitutive relation, axially loading, torsion, statically indeterminate systems, Mohr’s circle, failure criteria, buckling, defection due to axial, shear, torsional, and flexural loading. C or better in all of the following: 270; and MATH 244
prerequisites: C or better in all of the following: CEE 270; and MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent)
crossListings: or concurrent or MATH 253A or concurrent. Crosslisted as ME 371

title: Mechanics of Materials Lab
description: Tension, compression, and torsion of bars, and bending of beams. CEE and CNST majors only. A-F only. 370 (or concurrent).

title: Construction Materials
description: (2 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Concrete properties, role of aggregates, concrete mix design, supplementary cementitious materials, chemical admixtures, behavior of concrete, concrete testing, field practices. Emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only. 305 (or concurrent); and 370 with a minimum grade of C or better.
prerequisites: CEE 305 (or concurrent); and CEE 370 with a minimum grade of C or better

title: Structural Analysis
description: Analysis of statically determinate plane and space trusses and frames; deflections; introduction to matrix methods; computer applications. A-F only. 370 with a minimum grade of C or better.
prerequisites: CEE 370 with a minimum grade of C or better

title: Engineering Economics
description: Economic analysis in engineering and management decision-making, interest, depreciation, income tax, cost classification, break-even analysis, economic comparisons of alternatives, benefit-cost analysis. BENG, CE, CEM, CNST, ECE, and ME majors only. A-F only. ECON 120 (with a minimum grade of C-) or 130 (with a minimum grade of C-), and senior standing. (
prerequisites: ECON 120 (with a minimum grade of C-) or ECON 130 (with a minimum grade of C-), and senior standing

title: Computer Methods in Engineering Systems
description: Numerical solutions of engineering problems using digital computers. Regression analysis; numerical differentiation and integration; solutions of algebraic, transcendental, and differential equations; and analysis of large structural systems. computer programming and senior standing.

title: Engineering Hydraulics
description: Hydraulics of closed conduits and open channels with emphasis on engineering applications. Topics also include pump hydraulics, bridge hydraulics, urban drainage engineering, and flood plain management. A-F only. 320.

title: Environmental Fluid Mechanics
description: Introduction to basic concepts of pollutant transport phenomenon through theoretical modeling, lab and field experiments and observations. Specific topics include mass balance, jets and plumes, mixing and transport in rivers, reservoirs, groundwater and estuaries; non point course pollution. A-F only. 320, and MATH 244 or MATH 253A (or equivalent). (Alt. years)
prerequisites: CEE 320, and MATH 244 or MATH 253A (or equivalent)

title: Applied Hydrology
description: Surface water hydrology topics include hydrologic cycle, hydrographs, regression methods, urban rain-runoff process, flood frequency analysis, flood routing and hydrology for detention basin design. Groundwater hydrology topics include seawater intrusion, theory of groundwater flow and solutions to steady and unsteady aquifer flows. A-F only. 305 and 320.

title: Water and Wastewater Engineering
description: Hydrologic fundamentals of water demand and supply; water and wastewater distribution; collection systems; quality characterization; analytical methods for water quality management. 330.

title: Water/Wastewater Treatment Design
description: Physical operations, chemical and biological processes, design flow and process loading rates, pilot plant testing, and treatment plant design. Engineering majors only. 330.

title: Vulnerability & Adaptation on Coastal Infrastructure
description: Assessing vulnerability of coastal communities to climate change stressors and providing technical engineering solutions for adaptation. Senior standing or higher. (Spring only) (

title: Principles of Sustainability Analysis
description: Key principles of sustainability and its analysis. Quantification of environmental impact/assessment using target plots, mass/energy balances, and life cycle analyses (cradle to gate/grave) applied to products, processes, or systems. Use of SimaPro. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Infrastructure: Project Impacts, Policy and Sustainability
description: Evaluation of infrastructure impacts. Impacts regulation and mitigation. Effects of environmental and other policies on infrastructure. Infrastructure relations to sustainability. Energy consumption, transportation efficiency and infrastructure recycling. Lectures and presentations by experts and enrolled students. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. senior standing, open to engineering, science, urban planning, and economics majors. (
prerequisites: senior standing, open to engineering, science, urban planning, and economics majors

title: Climate Modeling, Data Analysis and Applications
description: Introduction to regional and global climate modeling for environmental scientists and engineers. Learn principles of climate modeling, how to access and use climate data for sustainable engineering and environmental management solutions, and effectively communicate results. A-F only. Senior standing or higher, or consent. (

title: Geotechnical Engineering II
description: Continuation of 355 field exploration, lateral earth pressures, bearing capacity theory, slope stability, use of geosynthetics. A-F only. 355.

title: Pavement Engineering
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Design principles of flexible and rigid pavements; HMA mixture design, equipment and construction; and application of life cycle cost analysis (LCCA) in pavement engineering. Includes laboratory sessions for aggregate testing and Superpave mix design. A-F only. 355 (or concurrent), 375 (or concurrent), and 361.
prerequisites: CEE 355 (or concurrent), CEE 375 (or concurrent), and CEE 361

title: Traffic Engineering
description: Design/analysis of signalized, unsignalized intersections, urban networks. Traffic impact studies; analysis steps and applications. Design/redesign options. Parking studies: demand, alternative designs (lot layouts). 361.

title: Urban and Regional Transportation Planning
description: Application of travel demand forecasting models to transportation planning. Evaluation and decision-making. Term projects. 361.

title: Construction Methods
description: Methods of construction, primarily buildings. Construction types: light and heavy wood; steel; plain, reinforced, and prestressed concrete; masonry. Foundations; associated details of frames, walls, roofs, floors, openings, finishes. Disasters, failures, and their causes. Industrialization of the building process. CE, CEM, CNST, ECE, ME majors only. 375.

title: Construction Project Management
description: Introductory treatment of the management of construction. Construction supervision, contract documents, estimating and bidding, organization, planning and scheduling, administration, business methods, safety, and labor. CE, CEM, CNST, ECE, and ME majors only. A-F only. 375. (

title: Construction Equipment and Methods
description: Methods and equipment used on horizontal/ heavy engineering projects. Available equipment, their production, and how they are used to excavate, move, process, and place the earth. 375 and senior standing.

title: Construction Estimating and Bidding
description: Estimating science; techniques of estimating quantities and pricing of work for construction contracting; classification of costs, analysis of plans and specifications for estimating; computerized estimating; cash flow, bidding strategy, preparation and submission. CEE, CNST, ECE, ME, OE majors only. A-F only. 375.

title: Construction Planning and Scheduling
description: To teach the theory and the practice of planning, scheduling, and reporting a construction project through the use of bar chart and CPM. Format to include lectures, text, outside speakers, site visits, discussions, case study, and computers. 375.

title: Construction Safety
description: Safety and health concepts, laws and requirements for civilian and contractor personnel in construction, including applications in project management and construction activities. CNST, CEE majors only. A-F only. 375.

title: Construction Law
description: In-depth exploration of the legal regimes governing construction. Construction contracts, contractors, and subcontractors. Breach of contracts, claims and litigation in construction projects. CEE, CNST majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. 375. (Spring only)

title: Undergraduate Structural Research
description: Individual research project for undergraduate students in the structures track. Topic to be determined by consultation with structural faculty advisor. A-F only. senior standing and consent.

title: Field Experience
description: CEE 483 Field Experience (1) | 2024-2025 General Catalog Skip to Main Content UHM Home A-Z Index Directory Students Faculty and Staff Parents Alumni MyUH University of Hawai‘i ® at Mānoa 2024-2025 General Catalog Menu Open Mobile Menu Search Search this site Site search About About UH President and Provost Message Campus Map Student Life Campus Policies and Information Personnel Calendar Courses Course Overview Sample Course Description Diversification Courses General Education Designations Course Numbering System Undergraduate Undergraduate Education Programs Undergraduate General Education Requirements Tuition, Fees, and Financial Aid Graduate Graduate Division Graduate Programs Tuition, Fees, and Financial Aid Degrees, Minors & Certificates Colleges, Schools & Academic Units Home Courses CEE 483 Field Experience (1) CEE 483 Field Experience (1) Civil, Environmental and Construction Engineering (CEE) , College of Engineering ← CEE 481 Undergraduate Structural Research (3) CEE 484 Structural Loads (3) → 2024-2025 General Catalog Mānoa Catalog Office 2500 Campus Road, Hawaii Hall 121 Please note: This Catalog was prepared to provide information and does not constitute a contract.
