title: Structural Loads
description: Introduction to the minimum load requirements for buildings and other structures used in current structural design codes. Derive and apply dead, live, rain, soil, snow, wind, earthquake, flood, inundation, and other loads to structural systems. CEE majors only. A-F only. 305 and 381.

title: Reinforced Concrete Design
description: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Behavior and design of reinforced concrete beams, one-way slabs and columns. Laboratory section includes design and hands-on manufacturing and testing of reinforced concrete members. A-F only. 375 and 381.

title: Structural Steel Design
description: Basic properties of steel; behavior and design of steel beams, columns, and connections; introduction to rigid frames. 381.

title: Senior Design Project & Professional Ethics
description: Design problem involving several areas of civil engineering and requiring a team approach for a solution. Oral communication skills are assessed through multiple presentations to an industry. Engineering ethics, ethical decision making and deliberation. A-F only. CEE or CNST majors only. Senior standing only. 220, 250, and 305. (Fall only)

title: Senior Design Project
description: (Lec/Lab) Design problem involving several areas of civil engineering and requiring a team approach for a solution. Oral communication skills will be assessed through multiple presentations to an industry panel. A-F only. senior standing in CEE or CNST and 489B. (Spring only)
prerequisites: senior standing in CEE or CNST and CEE 489B

title: Special Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
description: Will reflect special interests of visiting and/or permanent faculty. Repeatable one time. junior or senior standing, and consent.
prerequisites: junior or senior standing, and consent

title: Special Problems
description: Individual investigation in civil and environmental engineering topics as approved by instructor. senior standing, and minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or minimum GPA of 3.0 in engineering.
prerequisites: senior standing, and minimum cumulative GPA of CEE 2

title: Master’s Plan B/C Studies
description: CR/NC only

title: Operations Management
description: Linear programming, simplex method, graphical representation: dual; degeneracy; transportation problem; assignment problems; data envelopment analysis; applications; case studies; managerial reporting; LINDO software. Graduate students only. A-F only. 476 (or equivalent) (with a minimum grade of B-), and consent.
prerequisites: CEE 476 (or equivalent) (with a minimum grade of B-), and consent

title: Cost Engineering and Quality Control
description: Study and applications of cost/schedule control systems criteria, earned value analysis, probabilistic cost estimating, construction risk management, construction quality control, and operations research in construction. Recommended: 472 or 474, or consent.

title: Machine Learning in Civil and Environmental Engineering and Earth Science
description: Statistical machine learning and deep learning methods. Script languages for data-driven model training, validation and test. Analysis with linear algebra and statistics. Applications to engineering and earth science problems. consent; knowledge of Python Programming desirable. (Alt. years: fall)
prerequisites: consent; knowledge of Python Programming desirable

title: Risk Analysis and Decision Making
description: Risk analysis and decision making are fundamental areas of construction and project management. Students will benefit from analyzing risks and learning various decision making techniques for real-time applications. A-F only. 472 and 474 or consent. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Negotiation and Alternative Dispute Resolution
description: Lawyers negotiate settlements in almost all their cases. This class presents a “hands-on,” skill-building approach to the newest ideas, as well as centuries-old techniques, about the skill lawyers will use most often in their private practice-negotiation. The class also examines the rapidly developing field of alternative dispute resolution (ADR), including mediation, facilitation, arbitration, and court-annexed ADR. (

title: Parallel Computing for Engineers
description: Concepts and techniques in high performance parallel computing. Topics include parallel language and algorithms, parallelizing -existing serial codes, statistical analysis, and techniques up to increase computational speed and accuracy for problems requiring large memory size. A-F only.
prerequisites: -existing serial codes, statistical analysis, and techniques up to increase computational speed and accuracy for problems requiring large memory size

title: Organizations: Theory and Change
description: Explores characteristics and structural, human resources, political, and cultural frames of organizational theory. Focus on organizational change strategies and theories. Discusses how to use these frames and theories in everyday management of public service organizations. BE, CEE, ECE, ME majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Coastal Flood Mitigation
description: Design and solutions to coastal flood mitigation problems. Topics include climate adaptation; engineering solutions and best practices to mitigate coastal risk under different ocean hazard scenarios; and ecological approaches to mitigate coastal risk. consent; knowledge of AutoCAD and ORE 661 desirable. (
prerequisites: consent; knowledge of AutoCAD and ORE 661 desirable

title: Fluid Mechanics
description: Theory of fluid dynamics in differential form, covering equation of motion, vortex generation, flow in rotating frame, potential theory, laminar flow, and introduction to turbulence.

title: Groundwater Modeling
description: Introduction to the finite-difference method; steady-state and transient groundwater flow in saturated and unsaturated media; applications to groundwater recharge and aquifer evaluation. A-F only. 627 or consent. (

title: Coastal Modeling
description: Coastal modeling using the SMS Surface-Water Modeling software. Applications to solving coastal problems for different ocean hazard scenarios by applying models for tides, waves, coastal circulation, wave-current interaction, sediment transport, and/or morphology change. consent; knowledge of ORE 607 desirable. (

title: Hydrologic Processes in Soils
description: Hydrologic properties in soils and the processes involved in water infiltration drainage and solute transport. Emphasis on key parameters required for modeling. Recommended: 424 or consent. (Fall only) (

title: Surface Water Hydrology
description: Deterministic and probabilistic methods include reliability of empirical distributions, multiple regression analysis, extreme value analysis and domain of attraction. Short-memory models for stochastic simulation of streamflows include autoregressive, Markov chain and moving average models. Time series analysis of hydrologic data is discussed. A-F only. consent.

title: Groundwater Hydrology
description: Groundwater occurrence, movement, quality, and resource evaluation, development, and management. Emphasis on saltwater encroachment, well evaluation, aquifer protection, recharge with wastewater, and Hawai‘i type hydrology. Recommended: 424 or consent.

title: Physical and Chemical Treatment
description: Introduction to physical and chemical processes for water and wastewater treatment: Review of momentum and mass transfer, chemical reactions, colloidal chemistry, coagulation and flocculation, granular filtration, sedimentation, carbon adsorption, gas transfer, disinfection and oxidation. A-F only.

title: Biological Treatment
description: Fundamentals of applied microbiology and biochemical reactor engineering, quantitative description of microbial growth, operational theory and design basis of aerobic, anoxic and anaerobic treatment processes. Applications for water, wastewater, air, solid wastes, and soil. A-F only. consent. (Alt. years: spring) (

title: Environmental Chemistry
description: Basic concepts of chemistry as related to the environment, with more emphasis on water. Topics include chemical kinetics, equilibrium, acid-base, precipitation and dissolution redox reactions, sorption, organic chemicals in the environment. A-F only. consent.

title: Environmental Microbiology
description: Combined lecture-discussion on major topics in environmental microbiology, microbial ecology, and a broad understanding of microbial processes in natural and engineered environments. CEE majors only. A-F only. graduate standing in CEE or consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing in CEE or consent

title: Applied Mathematics for Engineers
description: Application of advanced mathematics to engineering phenomena; linear algebra, Eigen systems; partial differentiation and multiple integrals; vector/tensor analysis; Fourier series/transforms and Laplace transform; ordinary/partial differential equations; probability and statistics. CE, ME, ORE, and ECE majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Hazardous Waste Remediation
description: Introduces the national problems dealing with the contamination of groundwater and presents remedial measures. Such measures include pump and treat (PAT) technology, in-situ bioremediation, soil vapor extraction, air sparging, electrokinetics, hydraulic fracturing, reactive walls, and phytoremediation. A-F only.

title: Water Quality Modeling
description: Mathematical formulation of pollutant transport and mixing in the water environment. Kinetics formulation and parameter identification, model calibration and verification. Design projects. A-F only. Recommended: 422 and 431, or consent.

title: Membrane Separations
description: Applications of membrane separations to desalination, power generation, and ultrapure water systems. Discussion of reverse osmosis, osmosis-driven processes, ultrafiltration, microfiltration, electrodialysis and ion exchange technologies. Membrane fouling and concentration polarization from practical/theoretical standpoints. A-F only. 635 or consent.

title: Seepage, Drainage, and Dewatering
description: Theory of seepage, field and laboratory methods of measurement; graphical and numerical methods; design of drainage structures; construction dewatering. A-F only. 355 (with a minimum grade of D).
prerequisites: CEE 355 (with a minimum grade of D)

title: Deep Foundations
description: Analysis and design of deep foundations; driven piles and drilled shafts. A-F only. 355 (with a minimum grade of D) and 455 (with a minimum grade of D). (Alt. years)
prerequisites: CEE 355 (with a minimum grade of D) and CEE 455 (with a minimum grade of D)

title: Numerical Methods in Geotechnical Engineering
description: Finite element and finite difference formulation and analyses to solve problems in geotechnical engineering. Also covers constitutive modelling. 355 (with a minimum grade of C) and 455 (with a minimum grade of C), or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: CEE 355 (with a minimum grade of C) and CEE 455 (with a minimum grade of C), or consent

title: Advanced Soil Mechanics
description: Soil continuum mechanics principles; elastic, plastic, and Cam clay soil behavior; critical state and strength; interpretation of laboratory test results. Repeatable two times. A-F only. 355 (with a minimum grade of D). (Alt. years)
prerequisites: CEE 355 (with a minimum grade of D)

title: Slope and Earth Structures
description: Classification of landslides and triggering mechanisms; field investigation procedures; limit equilibrium slope stability methods; numerical techniques; seepage and dynamic considerations; case studies. A-F only. 355 (with a minimum grade of D). (Alt. years)
prerequisites: CEE 355 (with a minimum grade of D)

title: Marine Geotechnics
description: Principles of geotechnical engineering applied to marine environments; marine geology; surveying and sampling methods; seabed sediment types, properties, and behavior; coastal and offshore foundations. A-F only. 355 (with a minimum grade of D).
prerequisites: CEE 355 (with a minimum grade of D)

title: Earth Pressures
description: Estimation of lateral earth pressures; analysis and design of retaining walls and excavation support systems. A-F only. 355 (with a minimum grade of D) and 455 (with a minimum grade of D).
prerequisites: CEE 355 (with a minimum grade of D) and CEE 455 (with a minimum grade of D)

title: Systems Analysis for Engineers
description: Optimization used in design and management of systems for minimizing resources or optimizing outcomes. Evaluation of alternatives, economic efficiency and effectiveness analysis. Logistics. Open to engineering students. Computer applications and labs. Recommended: 462 or 464, or consent.

title: Intelligent Transportation Systems
description: Definition, technologies and their attributes. Analysis and implementation based on FHWA’s User Services. Automated incident detection algorithms. Machine vision applications to traffic engineering. A-F only. Recommended: 462 or 464, or consent.

title: Advanced Transportation Modeling and Statistics
description: Demand modeling, discrete choice and activity-based modeling. Demand forecasting by simulation. Transportation surveys and sampling methods. Application of cluster, factor, regression, logistic and ARIMA analyses to transportation. A-F only. Recommended: 305 and 464, or consent.

title: Pavement Design and Rehabilitation
description: Pavement engineering with emphasis given to understanding fundamental issues such as historical development of pavement design, approaches used for design of new pavements and overlays, understanding of construction issues and their effects on pavement performance, and various design factors: environmental, loading and materials characterization. Introduction of pavement management systems. A-F only. Recommended: 461 or consent.

title: Continuum Mechanics
description: Cartesian tensors in mechanics; coordinate transformations; analysis of stress and strain; principal values, invariants, equilibrium and compatibility equations; constitutive relations; field equations. Problems in elasticity. A-F only. Recommended: 370 or ME 371, or consent. (

title: Project Management Systems
description: Project integration and PMIS; organizational power; conflict, strategic, and life-cycle management in construction management; matrix structure compared to projectized structure; project success; team building; change and culture in construction organizations; competitive bidding. A-F only. consent.

title: Negotiation
description: Theory and practice of negotiation. Exploration of appropriate strategies, tactics, and communication techniques. Study of dyadic multi-party, cross-cultural, and assisted negotiations. (

title: Structural Dynamics I
description: Response of single and multi degree-of-freedom systems due to dynamic forces. Direct integration of equations of motion. Response spectrum analysis. Application to earthquake loading. Systems with distributed mass and elasticity. A-F only. consent.

title: Structural Dynamics II
description: Elastic and inelastic response of structures due to earthquakes. Seismic design criteria. Code design procedures. Advanced topics in time- and frequency-domain dynamic analysis of structures. A-F only. 675.

title: Smart Structures Technology
description: Fundamentals of sensor technologies for structural engineering applications. Control devices and strategies for protection of structures against extreme events, i.e. earthquakes, strong winds, etc. Structural health monitoring and smart sensor networks. Smart materials for civil structures. CE majors only. A-F only. 675.

title: Modern Structural Analysis
description: Fundamentals of modern structural analysis theory, with emphasis on frame structures. Virtual work. Member stiffness/flexibility. Matrix formulation of stiffness and flexibility methods. Computer modeling issues. A-F only.

title: Advanced Reinforced Concrete Design
description: Slender columns; biaxial bending; combined shear and torsion. Building lateral load resisting frame analysis and design—shearwalls, rigid frames. Floor system analysis and design—flat slabs, joist systems. Computer applications. A-F only. Recommended: 485 or consent.

title: Advanced Structural Steel Design
description: Load and resistance factored design (LRFD); steel building modeling and analysis; moment-resisting frames; bracing systems; beam-columns; moment connections; composite construction; and plate girders. A-F only. 486 or consent.

title: Finite Elements in Structures
description: Finite element method in structural engineering. Extension of structural theory. Virtual work. One- two-, and three-dimensional elements; axisymmetric elements; plate bending. Application to linear problems. Recommended: 681 or consent.

title: Prestressed Concrete
description: Behavior of prestressed concrete members, including prestress losses. Analysis and design of prestressed beams, slabs, and composite sections. Anchorage zone design; continuous systems. Recommended: 485 or consent.

title: Advanced Concrete Technology
description: Composition and hydration of concrete, chemical, and mineral admixtures, fresh and hardened properties, mix proportions, high performance concretes, durability and retrofitting technology, non-destructive testing, and advanced material characterization techniques. A-F only. CEE majors only. Graduate students only. 375 (with a minimum grade of C). (Spring only)
prerequisites: CEE 375 (with a minimum grade of C)

title: Seminar in Civil and Environmental Engineering
description: Discussions and reports on literature, research, developments and activities in civil engineering. One unit of all graduate students for each graduate degree. Student presentations are required. Repeatable two times. CR/NC only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Plan B Master’s Project
description: Independent study for students working on a Plan B master’s project. A grade of Satisfactory (S) is assigned when the project is satisfactorily completed. CR/NC only. graduate standing in CEE or consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing in CEE or consent

title: Selected Topics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
description: Highly specialized topics in structures, soils, hydraulics, sanitary, water resources, applied mechanics, transportation. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Directed Readings or Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times. candidacy for PhD in civil engineering.
prerequisites: candidacy for PhD in civil engineering

title: Ancient Egypt: Mummies, Pharaohs, and Gods
description: An overview of ancient Egyptian civilization through lectures and class discussion on Egyptian literature, archaeology, history, religion and society.

title: Greek, Roman, and Ancient Mythology
description: Combines readings and analyses of myths from the ancient world including Europe, Asia, Africa, and Hawai‘i, with an emphasis on comparative analysis of cultures and religions.

title: Greek and Latin Elements in English
description: Important roots, prefixes, and suffixes for building a literary vocabulary.

title: Greek and Latin Elements in Scientific Terminology
description: Important roots, prefixes, and suffixes for building a scientific vocabulary.

title: World Myth to 1500 C.E.
description: Reading and analysis of myths and legends from around the globe, from before the dawn of writing to 1500 C.E. Students will learn to interpret traditional stories from several theoretical and cross-cultural perspectives. A-F only.

title: Understanding Ancient Religions
description: Comparative and historical survey of the religious beliefs and practices in ancient times throughout Egypt, Mesopotamia, Syria-Canaan, Anatolia, Persia, Greece, and Rome. A-F only. (

title: Myth, Religion, and Society
description: Theories and methods used in the study of myth, ritual, and religion. Sophomore standing or higher. (

title: Biblical Hebrew I
description: Orthography and structure of Biblical Hebrew, history and development of Hebrew as the sacred language of Judaism, overview of religious and historical development of the Hebrew Bible. sophomore standing or consent. (Fall only) (

title: Biblical Hebrew II
description: Reading of selected prose passages from the Hebrew Bible; essay-based analysis of literary forms, with attention given both to stories important to the development of the Abrahamic religions and writing-based interpretation of religious traditions. REL/CLAS 301 with C- or better. (Spring only) (

title: Indigenous & Decolonial Approaches to Religion and Culture
description: Introduction to indigenous and decolonial approaches to the study of religion and culture. Includes a critical assessment of tools and terminology traditionally used in academia. Sophomore standing or higher. (

title: Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphics I
description: Decipherment of hieroglyphs and reading of Middle Egyptian literary texts. (Fall only)

title: Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphics II
description: Decipherment of hieroglyphs and reading of Middle Egyptian literary texts, including Tale of Sinuhe. 305 or permission of instructor. (Spring only)

title: History of the Written Word
description: A hands-on history of writing beginning in Ancient Greece and Rome. Content includes the development of the alphabet, scripts, books, libraries, and writing in ancient culture. Sophomore standing or consent.

title: Classics Ancient and Modern
description: Provides an in-depth introduction to a major work of classical literature and its impact on both ancient and modern poetry, prose, art, and intellectual history. Sophomore standing or higher. DL

title: Greek and Roman Drama
description: Survey of Greek and Roman drama, both tragedies and comedies, tracing the history of a genre that contains some of the wittiest and most agonizing moments in ancient literature. sophomore standing or higher.

title: Nature in the Ancient World
description: Study of the relationship between the Greeks and Romans and the natural environment. Particular attention will be given to the place of nature in ancient science, philosophy, literature, and “real life.” Assignments are essay-based. sophomore standing or higher.

title: Greek and Roman War Literature
description: Survey of war-related literature from Greece and Rome, its major themes, and how it reflects the wide range of social, political, intellectual, and literary perspectives on war found in the ancient world. sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: sophomore standing or higher, or consent

title: The Greek and Roman Novel
description: Survey of Greek and Roman novels, a collection of highly entertaining texts that offer windows into various aspects of life in the ancient world. sophomore standing or higher.

title: Ancient Greek Literature in Translation
description: Major writers: emphasis on Homer, drama, and philosophy. Assignments are essay-based and attention is given to developing academic writing skills. sophomore standing or higher or consent.
prerequisites: sophomore standing or higher or consent

title: Ancient Roman Literature in Translation
description: Major writers: emphasis on Vergil, satire, and novel. sophomore standing or higher or consent.
prerequisites: sophomore standing or higher or consent

title: Greek and Roman Epic
description: A survey of Greek and Roman epic literature, beginning with Homer’s Iliad and Odyssey and proceeding through the Hellenistic Greek and Roman periods. sophomore standing or consent.

title: Topics in Ancient Greek Thought
description: Explore a central aspect of ancient Greek philosophy and literature. This may be a theme, such as tragedy or emotions; a thinker, such as Aristotle; or a since monumental text, such as Plato’s Republic. one PHIL 200-level course, or consent. (

title: Archaeology of Ancient Greece
description: Introduction to the field of Greek archaeology and methods of archaeological research in the Mediterranean. sophomore standing or higher.

title: Archaeology of Ancient Rome
description: Examines the archaeology of the Roman world from the Etruscan period to the reign of the emperor Constantine. sophomore standing or higher.

title: Gender and Sexuality in the Classical World
description: Critical examination of the construction of gender identity and sexuality in ancient Greece and Rome. Junior standing or higher. (Once a year) (

title: Literatures of Ancient India
description: Survey of South Asian literature from ancient times to the early medieval period; focusing on Sanskrit, Prakrit, and Tamil poetry traditions. Readings in English translation. (

title: Art of Greece and Rome
description: Minoan and Mycenaean arts; Greece and Rome. ART 175 or consent. (

title: Persia, Greece, and Rome in the Classical Age
description: Historical examination of the interaction between the Achaemenid and Parthian empires of Persia and the classical societies of the Mediterranean, such as the Greek city-states, Macedonia, the Hellenistic, and Roman Empires. Recommended: HIST 151. (

title: Introduction to Communication
description: An overview of communication emphasizing intercultural, organizational and international communication and media arts with introduction to multimedia, ICTs, and public relations perspectives.

title: Media Arts
description: Combined lecture-discussion on theories and criticism of visual media, covering aesthetic development and delivery through multimedia and cinematic principles. A-F only. 201 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Communication and Communities
description: Combined lecture-discussion on communication within organizational communities and between organizations and their communities with attention to intercultural issues in local, global, and online interactions. 201 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Communicating Sustainability
description: Application of scientific communication theory, strategic communication, and multimedia techniques to select issues of environmental sustainability. COM majors only. A-F only. 201 or consent.

title: Information and Communication Technology Concepts
description: Combined lecture discussion on basic technical concepts related to ICTs embedded in sociocultural context. 201 (or concurrent) or consent

title: Techniques of Video and Digital Cinema
description: Orientation to techniques of production. Emphasis on history, language, and theory of the creative process and application to media productions. 310 or consent.

title: Media Arts Techniques
description: Combined lecture-lab providing an orientation to, and examination of, procedures and techniques of media arts production. Emphasis on new media literacy, human-computer interaction, and basic electronic media tools for communication design. 310 or consent.

title: Public Relations Writing
description: Enhance students’ professional writing skills in the contemporary public relations field and equip students with the foundations of essential techniques for persuasive communication. COM majors or consent. A-F only. 201 (with a minimum grade of B).
prerequisites: COM 201 (with a minimum grade of B)

title: Intercultural Communication
description: Problems and opportunities of communication in a variety of intercultural contexts. Focus on theory, research, and managing intercultural effectiveness. COM major or consent.

title: Information Technology and Health Communication
description: Combined lecture-discussion on the application of ICTs for health communication from the aspect of technologies, systems, services, and policies. COM majors only. A-F only.

title: Computer-Mediated Communication
description: Combine lecture-discussion on the evolution of computer-mediated communication from the 1970s to current day. Examines the development of online communities, technologies, and their networked online and offline social practices. COM majors only or consent.

title: Digital Cultures
description: Introduction to the social, cultural, and ethical implications of information and communication technologies by studying new and emerging media including games, interactive media, and virtual worlds. COM majors or consent. 330.

title: Esports and Society
description: Introduction to professional and collegiate esports (electronic sports) in global context, including theories related to leisure and gaming, and current academic and industry developments. No previous technical or gaming experience is required. COM majors only. A-F only. COM major or consent.

title: Media Communications and Conflict
description: Mass communication and conflict; deals with understanding the role of news media in influencing conflict, and introduces students to conflict-sensitive communications working to assist in resolving conflicts. Sophomore standing or higher. any 200-level DS course. (

title: Emerging Topics in Communication
description: Emerging communication topics of interest to faculty and students. Repeatable one time on different topics, up to six credits. COM majors only. A-F only.

title: Survey of Inquiry Methods in Communication
description: Exploration of quantitative and qualitative research methods commonly used in communication studies and related professional work. COM major or consent.

title: Communication in Multicultural Organizations
description: Cultural diversity in multicultural and multinational organizations is examined regarding communication-related aspects of working life. COM majors only or consent.

title: Public Relations Strategies
description: Exploring the practice and effects of public relations. Strategic management functions, including use of communication technologies, communication with diverse publics, ethics and social responsibility will be emphasized. COM majors only or consent. A-F only.

title: Public Relations Campaigns
description: Synthesizing and applying the principles and techniques of public relations to create comprehensive campaigns. COM majors only. A-F only. 421 or consent.

title: Filming Social Change
description: Introduction to visual documentary theory and methods. Basic instruction in using digital video technology and hands-on production to tell visual stories and examine social issues related to diverse peoples, cultures, and communities through video projects. A-F only. one DH or DS course, or consent. (
prerequisites: one DH or DS course, or consent

title: Environmental Storytelling Through an Indigenous Lens
description: Through media arts storytelling techniques, will focus on reframing perspectives and creativity from an Indigenous lens to communicate environmental-centric stories geared toward improving our communities’ quality of life. COM majors only or consent.

title: Studio Production
description: Studio production ranging from three-camera studio production to broadcast and magazine show formats to on-line web production. Fundamental knowledge of lighting, sound, blocking, and equipment competency. COM major or consent.

title: Social Media
description: Combined lecture-discussion on the sociocultural, political, psychological, historical and policy dimensions of social media for societies past, contemporary, and future. COM majors only or consent. A-F only.

title: Video Scriptwriting
description: Application of communication theory to creating and revising commercial and dramatic script material for video production. 331 or consent.

title: Media Effects
description: Social, political, economic, and cultural effects of mediated communication are examined to understand their impact on human behavior. COM majors only or consent.

title: Telecommunication in the Pacific Hemisphere
description: Development of international telecommunication, with special emphasis on the wireless communication, the internet, and emerging technologies. COM majors only or consent. A-F only.

title: Communication and Gender
description: Theories and issues related to gender and communication applied to organizational, intercultural, and technology mediated communication. COM majors only or consent.

title: Building Communication Theory
description: Major theories of communication in terms of requirements for a theory, theory development, associated research, and application. COM major and junior standing, or consent.
prerequisites: COM major and junior standing, or consent

title: Special Topics in Communication
description: Topics of relevance to the focus areas of Communication in Communities, Media Arts, and ICTs & Policy; taught by regular and visiting faculty. Repeatable on different topics to six credit hours. COM majors only or consent.

title: Political Communication in the Digital Era
description: An examination of how various aspects of digital media platforms, such as affordances and communication processes impact political outcomes. COM majors or consent. Sophomore standing or higher. (Fall only)

title: Capstone in Media Arts Design and Development
description: Design, development, and evaluation of computer-based media arts communication. Emphasizes authoring and production of such media elements as video, audio, and graphics. COM majors only. A-F only. 310 and 320 and 330 and 337, or consent.
prerequisites: COM 310 and COM 320 and COM 330 and COM 337, or consent

title: Capstone in Communication in Communities
description: Synthesize knowledge, apply research findings in service to community, and develop proposal for intervention or campaign through assignments that emphasize the development of writing skills. COM majors only. A-F only. 310 and 320 and 330; and 340 or 421; or consent.
prerequisites: COM 310 and COM 320 and COM 330; and COM 340 or COM 421; or consent

title: Capstone Project in ICTs and Policy
description: Written research or media project focused on specific ICT and policy problems, including social media, digital games, and the internet. COM majors only. A-F only. 310 and 320 and 330; and 432 or 438; or consent.
prerequisites: COM 310 and COM 320 and COM 330; and COM 432 or COM 438; or consent

title: Communication Seminar
description: Application of theoretic and methodological criteria to researchable questions. Topics will vary. 201 and senior standing, or consent.
prerequisites: COM 201 and senior standing, or consent

title: Communicating Creativity
description: The role of communication in fostering or inhibiting creativity. Exploration of theoretical bases for shared scientific or artistic creativity in communication research. COM major or consent. 201 and senior standing, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: COM 201 and senior standing, or consent

title: Senior Thesis Project
description: Completion of the thesis project appropriate to the selected focus area within the context of a seminar. Emphasis on ongoing process of writing, editing, review, and revision. COM major and senior standing, or consent.
prerequisites: COM major and senior standing, or consent

title: (Alpha) Communication Internship
description: Application of communication skills and knowledge. Under faculty supervision, interns participate in operations of an organization and analyze communication processes and effects; (B) community setting; (C) Communication program activity. Maximum of three credits per semester; six credits total toward major; each alpha repeatable up to three credits. COM major or consent.

title: Special Problems
description: Independent study of selected topics under faculty supervision. Repeatable up to three credits. COM major and junior standing, or consent.
prerequisites: COM major and junior standing, or consent

title: Master’s Plan B/C Studies
description: COM 500 Master’s Plan B/C Studies (1) | 2024-2025 General Catalog Skip to Main Content UHM Home A-Z Index Directory Students Faculty and Staff Parents Alumni MyUH University of Hawai‘i ® at Mānoa 2024-2025 General Catalog Menu Open Mobile Menu Search Search this site Site search About About UH President and Provost Message Campus Map Student Life Campus Policies and Information Personnel Calendar Courses Course Overview Sample Course Description Diversification Courses General Education Designations Course Numbering System Undergraduate Undergraduate Education Programs Undergraduate General Education Requirements Tuition, Fees, and Financial Aid Graduate Graduate Division Graduate Programs Tuition, Fees, and Financial Aid Degrees, Minors & Certificates Colleges, Schools & Academic Units Home Courses COM 500 Master’s Plan B/C Studies (1) COM 500 Master’s Plan B/C Studies (1) College of Social Sciences , Communication (COM) ← COM 499 Special Problems (V) COM 611 Communication Theories (3) → 2024-2025 General Catalog Mānoa Catalog Office 2500 Campus Road, Hawaii Hall 121 Please note: This Catalog was prepared to provide information and does not constitute a contract.
