title: Communication Theories
description: Systematic study of major theories of communication and current status of communication research.

title: Communication Inquiry
description: Introduction to inquiry and the array of quantitative and qualitative research methods commonly used in communication.

title: Strategic Organizational Communication
description: Theories, concepts, and applications of strategic communication and public relations to achieve organizational goals. 611 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Information and Communication Technologies
description: Information and communication technologies, structures, processes, and networks as an area of research and study in the social sciences. 611 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Social Media
description: Systematic study from a social science perspective of current and emerging social media. Attention to user needs and impact. 612 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Intercultural Communication
description: Problems and opportunities of intercultural communication from theory and research, consulting and training, and policy and program perspectives. 611 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Global Communication and Journalism
description: Analysis of the emerging global media landscape as digital technologies enable the sharing of news, information, and commentary across geographical and cultural borders. Focuses on causes, characteristics, and consequences. 612 (or concurrent).

title: Digital Storytelling
description: Focus on development of narrative-based creative activities in all mediums (text, audio, video, etc.) within communication contexts, i.e., journalism, film, public relations, etc. COM majors only. A-F only. instructor approval.

title: Intervention in Multicultural Organizations
description: Describes the array of communication-related intervention programs designed to enhance effectiveness in multicultural organizations at home and abroad. A-F only. 623 or 643 or consent.

title: Media Effects
description: Critical examination of major media effects theories and topic areas. Must be enrolled in one of the following majors: COM, CIS majors only. A-F only. 611 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Public Diplomacy and Communication
description: Analysis of the emerging trends in international relations from communication and public relations perspectives. Focuses on factors, characteristics, and processes. COM majors only. A-F only. 611 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: ICT Policy and Planning
description: Processes and methods of planning appropriate to the information and communication sectors, including future economic, social, political, technical, and environmental perspectives. 611 (or concurrent) or consent. (

title: Communication Topics
description: Coverage in depth of some area of theory and research. Repeatable one time. 611 or consent.

title: Communication Research Seminar
description: General research seminar in communication. In-depth coverage of specific research methods to develop, refine, or interpret graduate students’ thesis or dissertation projects. COM, CIS majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. 611 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
prerequisites: COM 611 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Communication Practicum
description: Supervised work experience, study of an organization, and career planning. Required of Plan B students in the main communication program. Repeatable up to six credits. CR/NC only. 611 and 612, or consent.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Individual reading and/or research. Repeatable up to six credits. consent.

title: Thesis
description: Repeatable up to six credits. 611 and 612, or consent.

title: Directed Reading and/or Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Communication/Information Theories of Society
description: A critical review of major theoretical and empirical traditions in communication and information sciences. Focus on European, American, Third World, and applied research. consent.

title: Communication/Information Technologies
description: Technological concepts underlying data communications; information processing and computers; communication channels and networks, information storage and retrieval, and computer hardware and software. consent.

title: Communication/Information Research Methods
description: Current research methodologies in decision sciences, computer science, library science, and communication. Emphasis on methodologies suitable for interdisciplinary analysis. consent .

title: Special Topics in Communication and Information Sciences
description: Seminar reflecting research interests of faculty and current interdisciplinary topics in communication and information sciences. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.

title: Data Science Foundations
description: All aspects of data science: the methodology and processes; ethics and regulatory issues; programming tools; data acquisition, cleaning, analysis and mining; visualization, publication, curation, and preservation; applications in various fields. Graduate students only.

title: Interdisciplinary Seminar in Communication and Information Sciences
description: Exploration of relationships between disciplines in social sciences, science and technology, and humanities. Faculty and student presentations. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Directed Reading and/or Research
description: Individualized program of directed reading and/or research outside the scope of regularly titled courses. Repeatable unlimited times. consent. Plan must include goals and rationale.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Anatomy and Physiology of the Speech and Hearing Mechanism
description: Will overview anatomy and physiology of speech and hearing. Students gain exposure to structures and functions of respiration, phonation, resonance, articulation, deglutition, and hearing systems required for normal communication and swallowing. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Phonetics
description: Introduction to the fundamentals of phonetic and phonological development. International Phonetic Alphabet Transcription of English speech sounds; phonological developments and models; cultural variations; analysis interpretation and other considerations related to speech sound development and production. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Speech and Language Development
description: Will develop an understanding of children’s acquisition of speech, language, and normal communication development from birth through adolescence. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Acoustics and Psychoacoustics of Speech and Hearing
description: Provides an understanding of the fundamental processes underlying the production and perception of speech. Students gain an understanding of the physical and psychological aspects of sound and their measurement. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Introduction to Clinical Methods in Communication Sciences and Disorders
description: Provides observation and discussion of the clinical management of individuals with communication disorders, and practical experience related to clinical procedures and requirements. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Introduction to Communication Sciences and Disorders
description: Information and theoretical foundations serve as an introduction to the field of communication disorders. Will provide an overview of the normal processes and disorders of speech, language, hearing, and swallowing. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Introduction to Audiometry and Auditory Disorders
description: Covers anatomy and physiology of the auditory system, acoustic, basic knowledge of auditory disorders and testing procedures, and introduction to rehabilitative audiology. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (Summer only)

title: Basic Statistics for Health-Related Professionals
description: Provides students from behavioral sciences and health-related professions with an overview of normal distribution, central tendency, variability, sampling, hypothesis testing, frequency distribution, correlation, regression, and t-test. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Research Methods
description: Research methods applicable to the field of speech-language pathology and audiology; analysis and reporting of data. Required of all CSD graduate students. previous coursework in inferential statistics and consent.
prerequisites: previous coursework in inferential statistics and consent

title: Neuroscience in Communication Sciences and Disorders
description: Explores the neuroanatomy and neurophysiology of the human nervous system as it relates to communication and swallowing and how neurological pathologies lead to behavioral deficits in those areas. CSD majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Audiological Foundations for SpeechLanguage Pathology
description: Instrumentation; special tests of hearing.

title: Seminar in Motor Speech Disorders
description: Provides in-depth examination of various motor speech disorders, including apraxia of speech and dysarthria. Emphasis is on assessment/treatment of these diagnoses. Review of current treatment literature, anatomy/physiology, practical exercises in treatment planning. A-F only. consent.

title: Disorders of Phonology and Articulation
description: Study of the etiology, assessment, and remediation of disorders and articulation. A-F only.

title: Child Language Disorders
description: Study of the etiology, behavioral characteristics and treatment methods for child language disorders. Examination of methods, test, and instruments employed in diagnosis of child language disorders. Includes identification of language deficits and writing intervention goals. A-F only. consent.

title: Language Development for Children with Hearing Deficiencies
description: Language acquisition by hard-of-hearing and deaf children; methods of stimulating growth. consent.

title: Advanced Practicum in Speech Pathology I
description: Clinical practice in diagnostic and therapeutic procedures with various types of speech and language problems in different clinical settings. Repeatable unlimited times, credit earned for six credits only.

title: Audiology Practicum for SpeechLanguage Pathology
description: Clinical practice in administering tests, interpreting results; counseling of individuals with impaired hearing; use of various rehabilitation techniques. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Voice Disorders
description: Contemporary development and theoretical issues in the diagnosis, evaluation, and treatment of vocal system disorders in children and adults; current literature and clinical practice issues are addressed. A-F only. consent.

title: Adult Neurogenic Language and Cognitive-Communication Disorders
description: Study of acquired adult language and cognitive communication disorders associated with stroke, traumatic brain injury, and dementia. Application of evidence-based procedures and strategies for assessment and intervention, review of current literature, and discussion of professional issues. A-F only. consent.

title: Research–Speech Pathology
description: Required of all CSD graduate students following the non-thesis (Plan B) program and emphasizing speech-language pathology. Repeatable three times. 600 and consent.

title: Research–Audiology
description: Required of all CSD graduate students following the non-thesis (Plan B) program and emphasizing audiology. 600 and consent.

title: (Alpha) Directed Study
description: To allow student and faculty advisor to design research/study units outside existing academic structure in specialized area. Repeatable unlimited times. (B) language pathology; (C) audiology. 603 for (C).

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Amplification: Assessment and Applications
description: Comprehensive study of amplification. Assessment, fitting, evaluation, electroacoustic evaluation, dispensing. Personal instruments and instructional-educational systems. 603 and consent.

title: Disorders of Fluency
description: Contemporary developments and theoretical issues in diagnosis, evaluation, and treatment of disorders of fluency such as stuttering in both children and adults.

title: Electrophysiologic Audiometry
description: Study of early, middle, and late auditory evoked potentials with emphasis on the auditory brainstem response. 603 or consent.

title: Dysphagia: Disorders of Swallowing
description: Explores the dynamics of normal and disordered swallowing across the life span with emphasis on the adult population. CSD majors only. A-F only. 601 (with a minimum grade of B-). (Summer only)
prerequisites: CSD 601 (with a minimum grade of B-)

title: (Alpha) Special Topics in Audiology and Speech-Language Pathology
description: (B) study of contemporary developments in speech/language pathology; (C) study of contemporary developments in audiology. Repeatable for credit for different alphas unlimited times. consent.

title: Advanced Practicum in Speech Pathology II
description: Clinical practice in diagnostic and therapeutic procedures with various types of speech and language problems in different clinical settings. Repeatable unlimited times, credit earned for 12 credits only

title: Advanced Practicum in Audiology II
description: Clinical practice in administering tests and interpreting results; counseling individuals with impaired hearing; use of various rehabilitation techniques. Repeatable unlimited times. 603, 617, and consent.

title: Seminar in Audiology–Diagnostic Procedures
description: Study of diagnostic procedures as reflected in current literature. 603 and consent.

title: Seminar in Audiology–Rehabilitative Procedures
description: Procedures and philosophies presented in recent literature dealing with rehabilitative phases of audiology. 603 and consent.

title: Advanced Practicum in Speech Pathology III
description: Clinical practice in diagnostic and therapeutic procedure with various types of speech and language problems in different clinical settings. Repeatable unlimited times, up to 18 credits.

title: Advanced Practicum in Audiology III
description: Clinical practice in administering tests and interpreting results, counseling of individuals with impaired hearing; use of various rehabilitation techniques. Repeatable unlimited times. 603, 617, 717, and consent.

title: Everyday Communication with Numbers: A Survival Guide
description: Understanding, communicating, and evaluating quantitative information in everyday contexts. Topics include describing and interpreting data, basic statistics, and evaluating the validity of results.

title: Personal and Public Speech
description: Develops communication skills necessary to function effectively in today’s society. Students will enhance their communication skills in one-on-one situations, public speaking, and small group situations. Ideal for new majors and non-majors.

title: Personal and Public Speech
description: Develops communication skills necessary to function effectively in today’s society. Students will enhance their communication skills in one-on-one situations, public speaking, and small group situations. Ideal for new majors and non-majors.

title: Introduction to Nonverbal Communication
description: Beginning course on the fundamental components of nonverbal communication. Aspects of body movements, facial expressions, eye behavior, physical appearance, voice, touch, space, smell, time, and environmental features will be examined in a lecture/discussion format. Extensive practice in skills.

title: Introduction to Interpersonal Communication
description: Introduction to basic principles of interaction between two people. Emphasis is on enhancement of skills in a variety of interpersonal contexts.

title: Multicultural Communication Skills
description: Expose students to practical skills needed for effective intercultural communication. Offer guidelines for improvement in diverse cultural settings such as business, education, counseling, and healthcare.

title: Principles of Effective Public Speaking
description: Combined lecture/laboratory providing extensive practice in preparing and presenting effective public speeches with special emphasis on organization, outlining, audience analysis, analytical reasoning, and delivery skills.

title: Interviewing
description: Principles and practice; training in informational, persuasive, employment, appraisal, and research interviewing. one of 151, 170, 181, 185, 251 or 301; or consent.
prerequisites: one of COMG 151, COMG 170, COMG 181, COMG 185, COMG 251 or COMG 301; or consent

title: Introduction to Communicological Theories
description: Introduction to the theoretical perspectives that are the foundations of the communication discipline. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.

title: Research Methods
description: Introduction to methods of inquiry in the field of communication. Topics include research design and problem formulation, sampling, analytic and observational techniques, and data interpretation. Ethical issues in communication research will be discussed. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.

title: Professional Presentations
description: Extends application of public speaking skills to professional contexts: group sales, press conferences, and corporate annual reports. Emphasis on organization, preparation, and delivery. 151 or 251, or consent.

title: Group Decision-Making and Leadership
description: Study of decision-making within the small group. Effects of organization, leadership, membership, and goals on achieving group purposes. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.

title: Argumentation and Debate
description: Adapting communication theory to forensic strategies for social action. Practice in formal argument. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits

title: Leadership and Organizational Communication
description: Principles and practices of organizational communication and its relationship to networks, leadership, power, conflict, cultures, and other contemporary views of organizational work, change, and development. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.

title: Persuasion
description: Theories, concepts, strategies, and processes of persuasion and social influence in contemporary society. Focus on analyzing, developing, and resisting persuasive messages. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.

title: Creating Understanding
description: Introduction to theory and research on human communication, comprehension, and creation of understanding. Discussion of information and message processing theories. Topics include prediction, inference-making, communication systems, and deception. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.

title: Family Communication
description: Focuses on the role of interaction patterns (both constructive and destructive) in the evolution of family communications. The impact of family dynamics upon these interaction patterns is given equal attention. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.

title: Interpersonal Relations
description: Theory and research on the development, maintenance, and termination of interpersonal relationships. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.

title: Culture and Communication
description: Survey of major factors affecting interpersonal communication between members of different cultures. Emphasis upon interaction between U.S. and Asian-Pacific peoples. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.

title: Special Topics in Culture and Communication
description: Contemporary research and theory on intercultural communication. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.

title: Interrogation and Interviewing
description: Survey of theory and research on the communicative demands of obtaining reliable information from others. Restricted to students with 30 or more credits.

title: Evolution and Human Communication
description: Analysis of the role of human communication in mate attraction, intrasexual competition, cooperation, family dynamics, and coalition formation; discussion on the biological function of language, laughter, yawning, and emotion expressions. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.

title: Research on Communication Behavior
description: Survey of research on communication behavior. Verbal and nonverbal data collection; analysis of research data. Students design and implement a research project. Repeatable three times. 301 and 302.

title: Internship
description: Analysis and application of communication knowledge and behaviors in organizational settings. Repeatable up to six credits. A-F only. consent.

title: Social Identity and Intergroup Communication
description: Surveys theory and research on communication between members of different social groups, highlighting how communication influences and is influenced by social identity. Applies concepts to intergenerational, health, family, educational, multilingual, and computer-mediated contexts. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.

title: Political Communication
description: Survey of interpersonal and mass communication theories in the political context. Topics may include communication in public opinion processes, elections, debates, political campaigning and advertising. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.

title: Conflict Management
description: Examination of the theories, assumptions, practices, models, and techniques of managing interpersonal conflicts. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.

title: Science Communication
description: Introduction to principles for communicating science information effectively to a variety of audiences including the general public, policy makers, and profession peers. Application of these principles to create written and oral science communication products. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits. A-F only.

title: Human Communication and Technology
description: Analysis of evolving communicative exchanges in the Internet age including how people communicate with computer technology: focus on personal, interpersonal, and cultural effects associated with technology use. 60 or more credits.

title: Theories and Research in Strategic Communication
description: An in-depth overview of theories related to strategic communication and scientific approaches to attitude formation and changes. Junior standing or higher. 301 or 364 or consent.

title: Nonverbal Communication
description: Understanding communication beyond the words themselves. Review of theory and research on gestures, facial expressions, touch, personal space, and physical appearance. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.

title: Verbal Communication
description: Roles of language in human communication and social relationships; language variation, change, and social consequences. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.

title: Deceptive Communication
description: Survey of major social scientific theories, concepts, and research findings on deceptive communication, in a lecture/discussion format. Emphasis is on how people create deceptive messages, induce deception, and strategies used to detect deception. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.

title: Relational Management
description: Survey and critical discussion of current theory and research in relational management. Focus on written analysis of the role of communication in the initiation, maintenance, decline, and dissolution of different types of relationships. 381 or consent.

title: Communicating Social Support
description: Survey of major theories, concepts, research, and application regarding communication and social support in interpersonal relationships. (

title: Teaching Speech
description: For communicology majors who lead, under supervision, a freshman seminar section of communicology. senior standing and consent.

title: Health Communication
description: Develop understanding of the process through which communication influences health outcomes, and learn how to design effective health communication programs using theory and research. Restricted to students with 60 or more credits.

title: Directed Reading
description: consent of department chair and instructor.
prerequisites: consent of department chair and instructor

title: Master’s Plan B/C Studies
description: Enrollment for degree completion. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits. A-F only. master’s Plan B candidate and consent.
prerequisites: master’s Plan B candidate and consent

title: Theories in Communicology
description: Major theoretical foundations; humanistic and social scientific perspectives. Examination of the research and the development of different models of human communication. COMG majors only. A-F only. consent.

title: Research Methods in Communicology
description: Design and analysis of quantitative research in communicology. Focus on measurement issues, research design, descriptive and inferential statistics. COMG majors only. A-F only. consent.

title: Advanced Research Methods in Communicology
description: Advanced focus on survey, laboratory, and field study design, data collection, and data analysis. Emphasis on control of variance through design and statistical analysis. Appropriate preparation for graduate theses and dissertations. A-F only. 602 or consent.

title: Practicum for Instructional Communication
description: Combined seminar and lecture/ discussion format on techniques and procedures for teaching communication skills and their related components in a laboratory setting. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. COMG majors only. COMG GTA or consent.

title: Business Communication
description: Analysis of communication issues in business through discussion of verbal/nonverbal messages, interpersonal relationships, conflict, and persuasion. Focus on interviewing, group communication, and public speaking skills. A-F only. 601 (or concurrent) or 602 (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: COMG 601 (or concurrent) or COMG 602 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Persuasion and Social Influence
description: Theories of persuasion and resistance to persuasion; assessment of attitudes and measurement of change. A-F only. 601 (or concurrent) or 602 (or concurrent) or consent.
prerequisites: COMG 601 (or concurrent) or COMG 602 (or concurrent) or consent

title: Creating Understanding
description: Theory and research on human communication, social cognition, comprehension, and creation of understanding. Discussion of information and message processing theories, metacognition, prediction, inference-making, and communication systems. A-F only. 601 (or concurrent) or 602 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: COMG 601 (or concurrent) or COMG 602 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Relational Communication
description: Major models and theories of interpersonal communication; research on interpersonal relationships; interaction and functions of human communication. A-F only. 601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: COMG 601 (or concurrent) and COMG 602 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Foundations of Intercultural Communication
description: Major models, theories, and concepts of intercultural communication; basic methodological and analytical issues of research related to intercultural communication; research on intercultural communication. Graduate standing only. A-F only. 601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: COMG 601 (or concurrent) and COMG 602 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. Only three credits can count toward degree.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable three times. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only.

title: Approaches to Instructional Communication
description: Seminar on communication theories and models in instructional environment; emphasis on message processing, classroom dynamics, cognitive and metacognitive processes associated with learning, and learning assessment. A-F only. 601 (or concurrent) or 602 (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: COMG 601 (or concurrent) or COMG 602 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Research in Intergroup Communication
description: Theory, concepts, research, and application of communication processes between members of different social groups. A-F only. 601 (or concurrent) or 602 (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: COMG 601 (or concurrent) or COMG 602 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Seminar in Special Topics in Communicology
description: Substantive areas in communication that are of current interest and the focus of research, but not addresed in other COMG courses. Topics vary each semester. Content to be announced. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (601 (or concurrent and 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B), or consent.
prerequisites: (COMG 601 (or concurrent) and COMG 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B), or consent

title: Seminar in Persuasion and Influence
description: Contemporary research in persuasion and influence. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent.
prerequisites: (COMG 601 (or concurrent) and COMG 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent

title: Issues in Message Processing
description: Contemporary research in verbal and nonverbal message processing. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent.
prerequisites: (COMG 601 (or concurrent) and COMG 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent

title: Seminar in Relational Communication
description: Contemporary research in interpersonal relations. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent.
prerequisites: (COMG 601 (or concurrent) and COMG 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent

title: Research on Intercultural Communication
description: Functional approach to the study of communication in intercultural settings. Examination of culture-based variables and their impact on social influence, relational management, and message processing. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent.
prerequisites: (COMG 601 (or concurrent) and COMG 602 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent

title: Artificial Intelligence and Communication
description: Comprehensive understanding of the role and function of computer technology (including. A.I.) within the field of communication. Basic methodological and analytical issues of research related to semi-intelligent artifacts as information source or receiver. COMG majors or consent. Graduate students only. A-F only. 601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: COMG 601 (or concurrent) and COMG 602 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Seminar in Health Communication Research
description: Contemporary interpersonal and/ or public communication issues in health communication research. Topics include communication functions such as information management, interpersonal influence, relational management, emotional management, social influence. A-F only. 601 (or concurrent) and 602 (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: COMG 601 (or concurrent) and COMG 602 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Mindfulness Meditation and Stress Reduction
description: Practice mindfulness meditation to reduce burnout and live life in the present moment. Learn life skills to handle life better and be more resilient. Respond rather than react to life. No experience necessary. Repeatable nine times.

title: Clinical Nutrition
description: Overview of applied clinical nutrition that includes nutrients, dietary recommendations for healthy populations, and medical nutrition therapies for patients with diet related diseases or conditions. Repeatable one time. Junior standing and higher. CHEM 151 (or higher) or PHYL 141 or BIOL 171 or approval from instructor; highly encouraged: FSHN 185 or any other basic nutrition course.
prerequisites: CHEM 151 (or higher) or PHYL 141 or BIOL 171 or approval from instructor; highly encouraged: FSHN 185 or any other basic nutrition course

title: Introduction to Integrative Medicine
description: Overview of integrative (complementary) medicine covering Traditional Chinese Medicine, Ayurvedic medicine, naturapathy, traditional healing practices, homeopathy, nutrition and diet, herbs and dietary supplements, environmental health, mind-body, energy, spiritual, and positive psychology. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher.

title: Nutrition for Clinicians
description: Provides in-depth lectures and case studies reviewing the role of nutritional therapy in health and illness. MD majors only. CR/NC only. MDED 554 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Fundamentals of Biostatistics
description: Fundamental biomedical statistics concepts and tools will be introduced, as well as their applications to biomedical data. Students will perform hands-on analysis using statistical software and learn to interpret and present the results. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Generalized Linear Model
description: Statistical theory of Linear Model and Generalized Linear Model, algorithms use for estimation, inference concepts, and assessment of goodness-of-fit. Covers Proportional Hazard Model and Generalized Estimating Equations. A-F only. 601 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
prerequisites: QHS 601 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Bioinformatics I
description: Provides fundamental concepts in bioinformatics with strong emphasis on hands-on training. Topics such as molecular biology, sequence alignment, biological databases, phytogeny, and genomics including microarray and RNA-sequence analysis. Repeatable one time, but credit earned one time only. Open to nonmajors. A-F only.

title: Bioinformatics II
description: Focus on bioinformatics approaches for functional genomics related to DNA, RNA, and protein. It will provide of virus, bacteria, and human genome and bioinformatics approaches to human disease. A-F only. 610 (or equivalent) (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
prerequisites: QHS 610 (or equivalent) (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Introduction to Clinical Trials
description: Introduction to clinical trials. Topics include history, definitions/terminology, adverse events, FDA and government regulatory agencies, ethics; monitoring committees, recruitment, introduction to protocol development, basis designs. A-F only.

title: Design and Analysis of Clinical Trials
description: Covers basic and advanced statistical methods utilized in clinical trials design, conduct, and data analysis. Topics cover statistician’s role in drug development and DSMB, statistical theory in phases I-IV clinical trial designs and analysis. A-F only. 601 (or equivalent) with a minimum grade of B or consent.
prerequisites: QHS 601 (or equivalent) with a minimum grade of B or consent

title: Secondary Data Analysis Practicum
description: Introduces students to issues in working with complex data sets and adds the hands-on experience needed to conduct individual research using secondary databases. A-F only. (601 (or equivalent) and 650) with a minimum grade of B, which can be taken concurrently.
prerequisites: (QHS 601 (or equivalent) and QHS 650) with a minimum grade of B, which can be taken concurrently

title: Special Topics in Quantitative Health Sciences
description: Special topics in quantitative health sciences. Reflects special research interest of QHS faculty or guest lecturers. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only.

title: Biostatistical Consulting
description: Investigate the roles and responsibilities of the biostatistician as both consultant and collaborator with biomedical researchers, guide students in enhancing problem-solving and communication skills, and provide opportunity to observe real-life biostatistical consultations. A-F only. 601 and 602 (or equivalent) with minimum grades of B, and consent.
prerequisites: QHS 601 and QHS 602 (or equivalent) with minimum grades of B, and consent

title: Biostatistical Consulting Practicum
description: Under the supervision of biostatistics faculty members, students will have the opportunity to provide statistical consultations to biomedical researchers and gain hands-on experience conducting biostatistical analysis in solving real-life analytic problems. Repeatable two times, up to six credits. A-F only. 675 (or concurrent) with a minimum grade of B.
prerequisites: QHS 675 (or concurrent) with a minimum grade of B

title: Directed Research
description: Directed research in quantitative health sciences. Students will work closely with a QHS faculty member or mentor who will guide them through the process of conducting a research study. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only.

title: Foundations in the Field of Early Childhood Education (Birth to 8 Years)
description: Emphasizes interrelated historical and philosophical roots and socio-cultural context and their influence on policy and practice in early childhood education settings. A-F only. HDFS 331 or consent.

title: Foundations in the Field of Early Childhood Education (Birth to 8 Years) Lab
description: Direct experience with children in early childhood settings in order to apply concepts from 415 and gain perspective on the role of the practitioner in ECE settings.

title: Teaching and Learning for Diverse Young Children
description: Continuation of 415: focuses on the design, implementation, evaluation of meaningful, challenging integrated curriculum that promotes comprehensive developmental and learning outcomes for diverse young children (pK-3). 415 or consent. (

title: Teaching and Learning for Diverse Young Children Lab
description: Continuation of 415L. Co-requisite: 416. (

title: STEM Pedagogy
description: Introduction to STEM education pedagogy with emphasis on ethical issues and effective oral communication. Designed to integrate educational theory, pedagogy, content, and practical concerns into teaching practices in the STEM fields. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits.

title: Collaborative Language and Learning
description: Examination of language (talking, reading, and writing) processes within a collaborative teaching framework in the secondary curriculum. Field experience may be required. A-F only.

title: Adolescent Literature and Literacy
description: Selection and interpretation of young adult literature, including multicultural literature for middle level and high school students. Theory and teaching strategies for integrating literacy instruction in the literature program for diverse student populations. A-F only.

title: Interdisciplinary Science Curriculum
description: Conceptual schemes and processes for integrating science curricula within the sciences and with subject areas. Methods and models of curricular integration such as interdisciplinary, culturally relevant, place and community-based learning. Repeatable one time. (

title: Multicultural and Social Justice Education
description: Exploring social justice and multilingual, multicultural education with attention to Hawai‘i as our place of learning and teaching. (

title: Methods and Materials in Science
description: Selecting and using methods and materials, demonstrations and simulations, open-ended experimentation, inquiry and discovery, task analysis measurement tools and techniques, activities from various curricula, opportunity for individualized goals and projects. Repeatable one time. STE 323, STE 404(H), teaching experience; or consent.
prerequisites: STE 323, STE 404(H), teaching experience; or consent

title: Programs for Infants/Toddlers
description: Examination of current theory, research, issues, and models in programs for infants and toddlers, including criteria for evaluation and planning. A-F only. (HDFS 230 (or concurrent), HDFS 331 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B-; or consent. (
prerequisites: (HDFS 230 (or concurrent), HDFS 331 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of B-; or consent

title: Gender Issues in Education
description: Examines historical and current gender issues in education as they intersect with ethnicity and class. We pay close attention to the writing process and the skills needed to compose a well-written research paper. WGSS 151 or consent. (

title: Issues in Computer Education
description: Integration of microcomputers into school curriculum and key issues related to microcomputer use in education. LTEC 442 or consent. (

title: Problem Solving in Mathematics Education
description: Experiencing and learning to teach heuristics of solving mathematical problems; designing curricula, classroom organization, evaluative measures for problem solving. consent.

title: Difficulties in Learning Mathematics
description: Identification, analysis, and remediation of difficulties in learning mathematics. consent.

title: Language, Learning and Teaching
description: Examines the role that language plays in the social construction of knowledge within various disciplines, K–adult. Collaborative group learning strategies will be modeled. A-F only. student teaching or teaching experience or consent.
prerequisites: student teaching or teaching experience or consent

title: Advanced Topics in Reading
description: Current theories and teaching strategies of reading throughout the lifespan within various social contexts. Topics include psychological, sociological, and cultural foundations of reading; 21st century literacies; emergent literacy; diversity; multilingual learners, formative assessment; state/national initiatives. student teaching or teaching experience or consent.
prerequisites: student teaching or teaching experience or consent

title: Advanced Topics in Writing and Oral Language
description: Current theories and teaching strategies of writing and oral language throughout the lifespan within various social contexts. Focus on teaching writing and oral language as tools for learning and to demonstrate learning. student teaching or teaching experience or consent.
prerequisites: student teaching or teaching experience or consent

title: Children’s Literature in the Elementary Curriculum
description: In-depth examination of traditional and current books/media, birth through young adult, with emphasis on applications in schools or other educational contexts. Focus on use of narrative, exposition, and other genres across the curriculum. A-F only. student teaching or teaching experience or consent.
prerequisites: student teaching or teaching experience or consent

title: Effective Writing Practices
description: Analysis and practical application of principles and strategies of effective writing and informed writing instruction in K-12 classrooms. teaching experience and consent. (Summer only)

title: Literacy Coaching and Leadership
description: Exploration and application of literacy specialist roles. Includes teaching, coaching, providing resources, advocating for all students, and collaborating with other professionals. A-F only. consent.

title: Introduction to Research in Curriculum and Teaching
description: Classroom-based research covers the fundamentals of qualitative, quantitative, action research, mixed methods, and curriculum based assessment. Exploratory, explanatory, and confirmatory research will be highlighted culminating in an outline for Plan B/Thesis proposal. (

title: New Literacies Leadership +
description: New approaches to analyzing 21st century literacies K-12, including visual, media, digital, and critical literacies as well as developing leadership practices in multi-literacies pedagogy. A-F only.

title: Literacy Across the Disciplines
description: Explores theoretical and practical principles of literacy and sustainability across academic disciplines, investigating the role of language and literate practices of reading, writing, speaking, visualizing, and representing in social, cultural, and educational contexts. Graduate students only. A-F only. (

title: Early Career Teaching, K-12
description: Focuses on research and practice related to the first five years of teaching. Especially recommended for beginning teachers and graduate students interested in this stage of teaching development. Repeatable one time.

title: Early Literacy and Language Development
description: Theory and practice for PK-3 early literacy and language development. Focus is on content knowledge and pedagogical strategies that support the optimal development of oral language, reading, and writing skills in PK-3 classrooms. A-F only.

title: Early Childhood Education: Advanced Topics
description: Analysis and practical application of selected early childhood education program and/ or instructional materials. Restricted to majors. Repeatable two times. A-F only. 415 and 416, or consent.

title: Social and Cultural Constructions of Childhood
description: Seminar examines the interrelated socially constructed concepts of children and childhood and places them in the larger contexts informed by sociological, anthropological, historical, critical, and technological perspectives. A-F only. Graduate students only.

title: (Alpha) Curriculum Leadership
description: Foundation for critical study of curriculum development and improvement from the perspective of teacher leaders. Online/hybrid sections available; (B) early childhood; (D) middle school; (G) K-14. teaching experience or consent.

title: Science and Science Curriculum, PK-12
description: Application of recent developments in science, sustainability, curriculum development, and learning theory to -kindergarten through secondary school. Science philosophy, content and methodology stressed, including inquiry, nature of science, sustainability, and science literacy. Repeatable one time. (

title: School Mathematics Curriculum
description: Analysis of research related to teaching and learning school mathematics, application of research to classroom practices. Appraisal of recent curriculum trends; critical examination of assumptions underlying proposed curriculum changes. teaching experience or consent.

title: Social Studies Curriculum
description: Examination and evaluation of social science content, societal values and research findings as basis for development and revision of social studies materials, texts, curriculum guides, methodology. STE 322 or equivalent, social studies teaching experience, or consent.
prerequisites: STE 322 or equivalent, social studies teaching experience, or consent

title: Art Education K-12
description: Principles, goals, and objectives in teaching and learning art K-12; curriculum, instruction, and assessment in art education; laboratory experiences in art media. student teaching or teaching experience.

title: Teaching and Learning with Art Objects, Museums, Collections, and Site Visits
description: Interdisciplinary inquiry and examination of the role of physical objects and site visits in schools and other educational contexts, through visits to local art museums and related sites.

title: Function of Play in Early Childhood Education
description: Review of research and theory illuminating the nature, purposes, and meaning of play as a critical aspect of early childhood education. (Summer only)

description: Examines issues, theories, perspectives and practices in multicultural education and promotes awareness, encourages knowledgeable reflection and develops skills necessary for multicultural practitioners. A-F only. (

description: Exploration and application of autoethnography as a self-reflexive research method that utilizes the retelling of lived experience and emotion to examine historical, critical, and social topics. Graduate students only.

title: (Alpha) Curriculum and Instruction in Studio Art
description: Understanding art methods and materials related to art education for teachers grades K-12. Writing curricula, integrating visual arts across the curriculum, developing evaluation methods observing stages of artistic growth among students of multiple ages/abilities. (B) painting, drawing, printing; (C) fiber arts, ceramics, sculpture; (D) photography, technology, collage; (E) Combination of any three of B, C, and/or D. Previous BA, BS, BEd, and BFA only. Repeatable two times. A-F only. teaching experience or consent. (Once a year)

title: Business and Marketing Education Curriculum
description: Theory, philosophy, objectives, and development of business and marketing education curriculum. STE 390D or consent.

title: (Alpha) Seminar
description: Study in trends, research, and problems of implementation in teaching field. (C) English; (H) mathematics; (I) literacy; (J) science; (K) social studies; (M) interdisciplinary education; (N) art; (P) place-based education. Each alpha repeatable two times. COE-related majors only for (P). teaching experience or consent for all alphas except for (P); graduate and/or undergraduate courses in education and/or social sciences or consent for (P). (K
prerequisites: teaching experience or consent for all alphas except for (P); graduate and/or undergraduate courses in education and/or social sciences or consent for (P)

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Foreign Language
description: Study in trends, research, and problems of implementation of language education instruction. (B) French; (C) German; (D) Japanese; (F) Spanish. teaching experience, and consent.

description: Examination of principles in multicultural education and diversity. (D) middle level; (G) K-14; (R) reading K-12. Each alpha repeatable five times. A-F only. consent.

title: Multilingual/EL Pedagogy
description: Examines practices, theories, research, and perspectives on multilingual/EL teaching approaches. Topics include culturally and linguistically responsive approaches, collaboration, lesson planning, and adapting materials to promote the growth and development of multilingual/ EL learners. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Seminar In Multicultural Literacy
description: Interdisciplinary examination of research and issues in the teaching and learning of literacy in diverse multicultural settings. A-F only. course in teaching language arts of multicultural education, teaching experience, or consent.
prerequisites: course in teaching language arts of multicultural education, teaching experience, or consent

title: Literacy Assessment, Instruction, and Intervention
description: Application of formative assessments to better monitor/guide struggling readers and writers. Topics include diversity and state/national initiatives. A-F only.

description: Advanced use of formative and summative assessments to monitor/lead classroom and school literacy programs. Focus on diversity, leadership, state/national initiatives, and practical applications in schools or other educational contexts. (B) general; (C) multilingualism. May take each alpha one time only.

title: Reading for English Language Learners
description: Presents key concepts and theories in teaching reading to K-12 English language learners. Topics include instructional decisions in teaching reading to ELLs, the interrelationship of language skills, strategies, and teaching academic content. A-F only. 601 or consent.

title: Theory/Practice in Cooperative Occupational Education
description: Theory and practices of coordinating cooperative education in high school and community college. teaching experience or consent.

description: Introduces concepts, theories, and pedagogies of Social Emotional Learning (SEL), health and wellness, and trauma informed teaching with an emphasis on culture, social justice, and equity in Hawai‘i and our global community. A-F only. (Summer only) (

title: (Alpha) Mathematics in the Schools
description: School mathematics, K-12 content, curricula, pedagogy, and standards; trends and issues; theory and research. (B) number and operation; (C) patterns, functions and algebra; (D) geometry and measurement; (E) probability and statistics; (F) integrated math content. Each alpha represents a different K-12 content area. Repeatable three times for (F). teaching experience or consent.

title: Ethnomathematics
description: Research and practice in ethnomathematics from an interdisciplinary framework. Analysis of ethnomathematics content knowledge and pedagogy; connections among curriculum, standards, and classroom practice; examination of theory and research; and building sustainable campus-community networks. Topics vary. Repeatable three times. A-F only. teaching experience or consent.

title: Seminar in Issues in ECE

Study and discussion of topics and problems presented in required summer courses and by invited experts in early childhood education. Restricted to masters in Early Childhood Education. Repeatable six times. A-F only. (Two times a year)

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Curriculum
description: Curriculum trends and issues related to school organization, program, administration, faculty. Required for Plan B MEd candidates in their final semester or summer session. Repeatable one time. (B) early childhood; (D) middle-level; (G) K-14. 622 (any alpha), and 606 or EDEF 678 or EDEP 408, and 632 or EDEA 604 or EDEP 429 or EDEA 608; or consent.
prerequisites: EDCS 622 (any alpha), and EDCS 606 or EDEF 678 or EDEP 408, and EDEP 632 or EDEA 604 or EDEP 429 or EDEA 608; or consent

title: Indigenous and Postcolonial Perspectives in Education
description: Examination of historical impacts of U.S. and European imperialism and Western education on Indigenous communities across the globe. Additional emphasis on contemporary Indigenous efforts towards cultural reclamation and educational sovereignty.

description: Explores the landscapes, purposes, successes, and challenges of contemporary Native Hawaiian education. Emphasizes educational kīpuka, resurgence, liberation and educational sovereignty. Topics include Hawaiian immersion education, Hawaiian-focused charter schools, ‘āna and community education, and virtual learning.

title: Curriculum Design in Early Childhood Education
description: Designed to help classroom teachers understand sources and principles of curriculum in early childhood education and to provide experience in evaluating, selecting, and developing appropriate curriculum for young children.

description: ) Overview of museum education including museum learning theories, informal learning programs, audience research, national and international policies and reports, and community projects. AMST 683 (or concurrent) or consent. (

description: Process approach to teaching information retrieval, analysis, and use. Emphasizes concepts, practices ineffective instructional design, selection of resources that meets learning needs. Required for Librarian HDOE licensure. A-F only. consent. (

title: School and District Literacy Leadership
description: Exploration and application of school and district-wide roles of the literacy specialist, such as collaborating with other educators to: (1) design and implement literacy programs, and (2) provide research-supported professional development. A-F only. 605 or consent.

description: Basic principles of radiation and fundamental information to understand and safely use radiation in dental radiography. A-F only. 231. Co-requisite: 281L.

title: Dental Radiography Lab/Clinic
description: (1 3-hr Lab/Clinic) Preparation and evaluation of radiographic survey of patients with varying dentition; methods, and indications of safety considerations in clinical application of roentgen rays. A-F only. 231. Co-requisite: 281.

title: Health Education and Promotion
description: Provides an overview of the concepts and application of health education and health promotion theories and principles as applies to individuals, groups and the larger public. open to non-nursing majors with consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: open to non-nursing majors with consent

title: General Pathology
description: The study of the nature and causes of diseases, the progress and termination or associated alterations of tissue with emphasis on diseases an tissue alterations associated with the human body organ systems. 250 and 251 (or concurrent). (Spring only)

title: Oral Pathology
description: The study of the nature and causes of diseases, the progress and termination or associated alterations of tissue with emphasis on diseases affecting the teeth and the structures of the oral cavity. 366. (Fall only)

title: Dental Materials
description: Science of dental materials and its application to dentistry and dental hygiene. A-F only. 231. Co-requisite: 369L.

title: Dental Materials Lab/Clinic
description: Laboratory and clinical application of concepts in the science of dental materials. A-F only. 231. Co-requisite: 369.

title: Expanded Functions in Dental Hygiene
description: Basic concepts of expanded functions in dental hygiene. A-F only. 369. Co-requisite: 370L.

title: Expanded Functions in Dental Hygiene Lab/Clinic
description: (2 1.5-hr Lab/Clinic) Application of basic concepts of expanded functions in dental hygiene. A-F only. 369. Co-requisite: 370.

title: Clinical Dental Hygiene I
description: Development of dental hygiene concepts and skills; emergency procedures; team approach to dentistry, planning, implementing and evaluating total oral hygiene care of patients; review and critical analysis of current dental periodicals and research. A-F only. 240, 240L, 281, 281L, and 389. Co-requisite: 375L.
prerequisites: DH 240, DH 240L, DH 281, DH 281L, and DH 389

title: Clinical Dental Hygiene I Clinic
description: Clinical instruction and application of dental hygiene concepts and skills; emergency procedures; team approach to dentistry; planning, implementing, and evaluating total oral hygiene care of patients; review and critical analysis of current dental periodicals and research. A-F only. 240, 240L, 281, 281L, and 389. Co-requisite: 375.
prerequisites: DH 240, DH 240L, DH 281, DH 281L, and DH 389

title: Clinical Dental Hygiene II
description: Continued development of dental hygiene concepts, skills, emergency procedures, team approach to dentistry, planning, implementing and evaluating oral hygiene care of patients. Review and analyze dental periodicals and conduct a case study. Emphasis on writing. 375, 375L, and 389. Co-requisite: 380L. (Spring only)

title: Clinical Dental Hygiene II Clinic
description: Continuation of 375. Clinical application of dental hygiene concepts and skills; emergency procedures; team approach to dentistry; planning, implementing and evaluating total oral hygiene care to patients. A-F only. 375, 375L, and 389. Co-requisite: 380.

title: Pain Control and Local Anesthesia in Dentistry
description: Basic concepts of pain control and local anesthesia in dentistry with appropriate emphasis on psychological preparation, pharmacological preparation, and safe and effective administration of anesthesia in the practice of dental hygiene. 231, 250 and PHRM 203. Co-requisite: 240, 251, and 366. (Spring only)

title: Periodontology I
description: Normal periodontium, etiology, pathogenesis, clinical manifestations and epidemiology of periodontal diseases, and mode of periodontal therapy. Emphasis on writing. A-F only. 240, 251, and 366. (Fall only)

title: Periodontology II
description: Continuation of DH 390. Normal periodontium, etiology, pathogenesis, clinical manifestations and epidemiology of periodontal diseases, and mode of periodontal therapy. Emphasis on writing. A-F only. 390. (Spring only)

title: Community Health
description: Introduction and application of the principles of health education and dental public health into practice in schools, community agencies, and private dental offices (inclusive of problem assessment, planning, implementation and evaluation processes); epidemiology and biostatistics. A-F only. 361. (Fall only)

title: Advanced Clinical Dental Hygiene I
description: An in-depth knowledge and clinical application of expanded function in periodontics with emphasis on principles, techniques, procedures in pain-anxiety control, soft tissue curettage, host factors, and modification of behavior. A-F only. 380, 380L, 389, and 391. Co-requisite: 475L.

title: Advanced Dental Hygiene I Clinic
description: Application of knowledge of expanded functions in periodontics with emphasis on principles, techniques, procedures in pain-anxiety control, soft tissue curettage, host factors, and modification of behavior. A-F only. 380, 380L, 389, and 391. Co-requisite: 475. (Fall only)

title: Advanced Clinical Dental Hygiene II
description: In-depth knowledge, communicated via oral delivery, on development of expanded functions in periodontics with emphasis on principles, techniques, procedures in pain-anxiety control, soft tissue curettage, host factors, and modifications in behavior. A-F only. 475 and 475L. Co-requisite: 480L. (Spring only

title: Advanced Clinical Dental Hygiene II Clinic
description: Application of knowledge of expanded functions in periodontics with emphasis on principles, techniques, procedures in pain-anxiety control, soft tissue curettage, host factors, and modification of behavior. A-F only. 475 and 475L. Co-requisite: 480. (Spring only)

title: Pediatric Growth and Development
description: Focus on the normal growth and development of children based on current clinical practice guidelines and evidence in pediatric research. DH majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Advanced Health and Diagnostic Assessment for Pediatric Patients
description: Focus on advanced health and diagnostic assessment for pediatric patients. Includes behavior management techniques as well as oral habits and subsequent malocclusions and speech difficulties. DH majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Pharmacological Principles and Clinical Therapeutics in Pediatric Dental Care
description: Focus on pharmacological principles and clinical therapeutics in pediatric dental care. DH majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Interprofessional Collaborative Practice Simulation Lab
description: Focus on interprofessional practice principles and competencies while providing students an opportunity to participate in interprofessional team simulations to address health care issues of children. DH majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Dental Hygiene Pediatric Training Clinical I
description: Field experience. Clinical application and knowledge in the care of pediatric patients 0-5 years of age. DH majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Management of Pediatric Dental Emergencies
description: Focus on the management of dental emergencies in children. DH majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Community-Based Dental Hygiene Care of Vulnerable and Special Needs Children
description: Emphasizes community-based oral health promotion, dental disease risk reduction and management in children 0-5 years of age with a focus on vulnerable and special needs populations. DH majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Community-Based Practice Capstone
description: Provides an opportunity to synthesize, analyze, and develop solutions to an oral health care problem affecting children ages 0-5 years. Requires one credit to be spent in fieldwork to meet course requirements. DH majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Dental Hygiene Pediatric Training Clinical II
description: Advanced clinical application and knowledge in the care of pediatric patients 0-5 years of age. DH majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Directed Reading, Field Work, or Research
description: Individualized program of directed reading, field work, or research for major under supervision in related areas of dentistry and dental hygiene. consent.

title: Fertilization and Early Development
description: Lecture on the basics of vertebrate and invertebrate fertilization and early embryonic development. Open to all graduate students. (Fall only)

title: Seminar in Developmental and Reproductive Biology I
description: Presentations of current research carried out by developmental and reproductive biology graduate program faculty.

title: Developmental and Reproductive Biology Scientific Investigations
description: Discussion of current research in developmental and reproductive biology. A-F only.

title: Stem Cell Biology
description: Seminar designed to teach graduate students and advanced undergraduate students about current topics relating to stem cell biology, as well as the application of stem cells to modern medicine. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Applied Developmental and Reproductive Biology
description: Combined lecture-lab on current technologies and methods for mammalian reproduction and developmental biology. A-F only. 601 (or concurrent), 613/614 (or concurrent); or consent. (Spring only)
prerequisites: DRB 601 (or concurrent), DRB 613/DRB 614 (or concurrent); or consent

title: DRB Research Rotation
description: Introductory laboratory research experience under the supervision of faculty. Repeatable two times. A-F only.

title: Directed Research
description: Research experience in developmental and reproductive biology. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Space Exploration
description: Introduction to science and engineering of Solar System exploration with laboratory exercises. Covers planetary science, model-based systems engineering, mission planning, constraints on payload and spacecraft design, human spaceflight technology. Research projects emphasize written communication. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Space Science and Instrumentation
description: Essential techniques for remote compositional analysis of planets; understanding spectroscopy, mineralogy, and geochemistry of planetary surfaces and their measurement. Design of space flight instrumentation. A-F only. 201, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 101L and ERTH 105, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 107; and CHEM 161 and PHYS 272.
prerequisites: EPET 201, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 101L and ERTH 105, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 107; and CHEM 161 and PHYS 272

title: Introduction to Human Spaceflight
description: Effects of spaceflight conditions on human physiology and psychology. Astronaut selection, training, crew composition. Ethics of space exploration. Politics & sociology of public and private human space flight. Selection of capstone project. Significant written communication. A-F only. EPET/ME 201 and PHYS 272. (Fall only)

title: Space Mission Design
description: Covers all aspects of spacecraft design, subsystems, science payload, systems engineering, project management, budgets, and ethical issues that are important to consider in producing a fully successful mission. A-F only. 301. (Spring only) (

title: Capstone Project: Producing a Science Satellite
description: Develops a space mission with a multidisciplinary team of engineers and scientists. Will build a small spacecraft and payload and seeks to answer important science questions. Emphasizes review report and proposal writing. A-F only. 400. (Fall only) (

title: Human Spaceflight Mission Elements
description: Engineering aspects of spacecraft design, subsystems, science payload, systems engineering, project management, and budgets for human spaceflight missions. Design of environmental control and life support systems. Capstone project design. Significant oral and written communication. A-F only. 321. (Spring only)

title: Dynamic Earth
description: The natural physical environment; the landscape; rocks and minerals, rivers and oceans; volcanism, earthquakes, and other processes inside the Earth; effects of human use of the Earth and its resources. Field trip. (

title: Dynamic Earth
description: The natural physical environment; the landscape; rocks and minerals, rivers and oceans; volcanism, earthquakes, and other processes inside the Earth; effects of human use of the Earth and its resources. Field trip.

title: Dynamic Earth Laboratory
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Hands-on study of minerals, rocks, and topographic maps. Examine volcanism, hydrology, coastal processes and hazards, geologic time and earthquakes. Field trips to investigate landslides, beaches and O‘ahu geology. A-F only.

title: Quantifying Global and Environmental Change
description: Introductory mathematical approaches to quantifying key aspects of global and environmental change. Includes data analysis, graphical representation and modeling of population growth, greenhouse gas emissions and fate, sustainable resource utilization, and sea level change. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Geology of the Hawaiian Islands
description: Hawaiian geology and geologic processes: origin of Hawaiian islands, volcanism, rocks and minerals, landforms, stream and coastal processes, landslides, earthquakes and tsunamis, groundwater, geologic and environmental hazards. Field trip.

title: Volcanoes in the Sea
description: Lecture with field trips covering the manner in which geological conditions, resources, and events have affected past and present circum-Pacific societies.

title: Voyage through the Solar System
description: An illustrated voyage through the Solar System based on recent scientific results. The class highlights the origin, evolution, and current knowledge of the eight planets, their moons, asteroids, comets, and one star, the Sun. Field trip. (

title: Humans and the Environment
description: Prepares students to make decisions such as where to build/buy a house, sustainable use of natural resources, and what environmental actions relevant to society and Earth’s ecosystem are appropriate on a local and global scale. A-F only. (

title: Solar System Studio
description: Explore the wonders of the Solar System through hands-on experience of science. Will study satellite images, evaluate planetary surface observations, analyze data of objects in our Solar System, conduct experiments, and communicate their findings. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Volcanoes
description: Examines the origin and classification of volcanoes, volcanic eruptions, and volcanic deposits. Includes the history of volcanic studies, myths, and legends. Emphasis on volcanic eruptions, eruptive products, volcanic hazards, and risk management. (Spring only)

title: Geological Hazards
description: Introductory course covering the causes of, and effects from, earthquakes, tsunami, volcanic eruptions, landslides, rockfalls, and other natural geologic phenomena. Open to non-majors. Field trips. (Alt. years)

title: Natural Disasters and Human History
description: Examines how natural hazards have affected the course of human culture and societies from -history to the present in Hawai‘i/Oceania, Asia, Africa, Europe, and the Americas. A-F only. (Spring only)
prerequisites: -history to the present in Hawai‘i/Oceania, Asia, Africa, Europe, and the Americas

title: Introduction to Quantitative Earth and Environmental Science
description: Introduction to -calculus math and physics applied to Earth and environmental science. Students work on real-world problems and engage in participatory learning. Preparatory for classes in calculus and physics. MATH 134, 161, or MATH assessment exam (with score required for MATH 140X). (Fall only) (
prerequisites: -calculus math and physics applied to Earth and environmental science

title: Physical Geology
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Structure, composition and evolution of Earth; processes responsible for formation, deformation and transformation of rocks; plate tectonics. Emphasis on quantitative methods, problem solving and critical thinking to geology. Laboratory and field trips required.

title: Introduction to Directed Research
description: Lower division reading and research in any area of ERTH under the direction of a faculty member. Repeatable four times or up to six credits. CR/NC only.

title: Geological Inquiry
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Origin and age of the solar system and earth: interior of the earth; plate tectonics and records of biological evolution and past environments. Development of critical thinking and writing skills. 101L and one of 101, 103, 104, 106, or 130; or consent. 101L may be taken concurrently. ERTH and GEOL majors only. Consent required for all non-majors.
prerequisites: ERTH 101L and one of ERTH 101, ERTH 103, ERTH 104, ERTH 106, or ERTH 130; or consent

title: Climate Change
description: Introduction to the science of climate change focusing on Earth’s past, present and future, specifically, the causes, consequences, and record of past changes; future projections, mitigation, and adaptation. Appropriate for both science and non-science majors. 101 or 103 or 104 or 106 or 111 or 130 or ATMO 101 or GES 102, or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: ERTH 101 or ERTH 103 or ERTH 104 or ERTH 106 or ERTH 111 or ERTH 130 or ATMO 101 or GES 102, or consent

title: Scientific Programming
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to solving scientific problems by computer programming. Overview of the MatLab programming language and environment. Emphasis placed on good style, logical reasoning, and applied mathematics. MATH 241 (or concurrent).

title: Physical Volcanology
description: Volcanic eruptions and their consequences. Includes models for volcanic eruptions including explosive eruptions and lava flows, monitoring of active volcanoes, evaluation and impacts of volcanic hazards, and mitigation of volcanic risk. Field trips. Normally fall. ERTH and GEOL majors or consent. (200 or 201) with a minimum grade of B+ or consent
prerequisites: (ERTH 200 or ERTH 201) with a minimum grade of B+ or consent

title: Mineralogy
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to the chemistry, crystalline structure, geologic occurrence, and physical properties of minerals. Development of critical thinking and writing skills. 200 or 201 and (CHEM 162/162L or CHEM 171/171L). or consent.
prerequisites: ERTH 200 or ERTH 201 and (CHEM 162/CHEM 162L or CHEM 171/CHEM 171L)

title: Igneous Petrology
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Survey of composition, classification, and occurrence of igneous rocks. Hand-specimen identification and optical petrography of igneous rocks. Development of critical thinking and writing skills. 301 or consent.

title: Natural Hazards & Geomechanics
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Dynamic behavior of Earth’s surface, physical processes driving geohazards, and the risks posed to society. Theory, practical techniques, and data visualization to measure, analyze, and interpret hazards and implications. ERTH 101 or 103 or 104 or 106 or 130, MATH 215 or MATH 241 or MATH 251A, and PHYS 151 or PHYS 170; or consent.
prerequisites: ERTH 101 or ERTH 103 or ERTH 104 or ERTH 106 or ERTH 130, MATH 215 or MATH 241 or MATH 251A, and PHYS 151 or PHYS 170; or consent

title: Geological Field Methods
description: Methods used in geological investigations in the field. Eight hours on Saturday in the field. 333; or consent. (Spring only)

title: Work of Water
description: Physical properties of water, geological aspects of surface water and ground water occurrence, surface water and groundwater resources, use, and problems. 200 or 201, or consent. (Spring only)

title: Sedimentary Processes and Environments
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Modern and past terrestrial and oceanic processes and environments that form sediments and sedimentary rocks, and their interpretation in Earth history. Incorporates properties, principles and applications of sedimentology, sedimentary petrology, geochemistry and stratigraphy. Repeatable one time. 200 or 201 or consent, and 333 or consent. (Spring only)
prerequisites: ERTH 200 or ERTH 201 or consent, and ERTH 333 or consent

title: Advanced Mathematics for Scientists and Engineers I
description: Advanced mathematical methods with emphasis on application to the earth and ocean sciences and engineering. Topics include linear algebra, vector calculus, ordinary differential equations, and numerical methods. MATH 242 or consent. (

title: Plate Tectonics and Geodynamics
description: Mechanics of lithosphere deformation related to plate convergence, rifting and strike-slip faulting, and the evolution of mountain belts. Use of theory and skillbuilding techniques to measure, describe, analyze, and interpret structures on Earth. A-F only. 200 or 201; and 250; and MATH 241 or MATH 251A; and PHYS 170. (Fall only)
prerequisites: ERTH 200 or ERTH 201; and ERTH 250; and MATH 241 or MATH 251A; and PHYS 170

title: Physics of Earth and Planets
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Essentials of geophysics: application of physics understanding Earth, planetary, and solar dynamics. Topics include heat flow, gravity, geodesy, electromagnetism, seismology. Applications to core and mantle dynamics, plate tectonics, volcanoes, hydrology, environmental concerns, and archaeology. 250, 303, 313, MATH 242, and PHYS 272, PHYS 272L; or consent.
prerequisites: ERTH 250, ERTH 303, ERTH 313, MATH 242, and PHYS 272, PHYS 272L; or consent

title: Geochemistry
description: Theory and applications of chemical principles and chemical analysis to Earth, ocean and environmental sciences; chemistry of hydrosphere-geosphere-biosphere system, origin/ differentiation of Earth/Solar system, volcanic processes, natural radioactivity, organic/inorganic chemistry. 200 or 201, and MATH 241 or MATH 251A, and CHEM 162 (or concurrent); or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: ERTH 200 or ERTH 201, and MATH 241 or MATH 251A, and CHEM 162 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Earth Materials and Structures
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Lecture and lab that covers formation, occurrence, and identification of common minerals, rocks, and geologic structures. Lab work will include study of hand-samples, thin-sections, and field experiences. A-F only. 200 or 201. (Fall only)

title: Undergraduate Internship
description: Experiential approach to earth science; students serve as interns to field professionals; responsibilities include supervised field work. Open to undergraduate SOEST majors. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. junior/senior standing and consent.

title: Undergraduate Research in Earth Sciences
description: Research experience for Earth Science undergraduates. Under the guidance of a mentor, the student will conduct research and write a report on the background, methods, data, interpretations, and conclusions of the work. Repeatable one time only. Earth Sciences majors only. Junior standing or higher. CR/NC only.

title: Directed Reading
description: Directed reading in earth sciences. Repeatable up to six credits. Junior/ Senior standing only. consent.

title: Introduction to mineral Physics
description: Scientific study of the materials that make up the Earth. Properties of minerals on micro- and macro-scales; their properties and behavior. 302 and PHYS 272, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Hawaiian Geology
description: Consists of lectures, discussions, and field trips on the geologic processes and geologic history of the Hawaiian islands, with emphasis on writing communication. 302 and 303; or consent.

title: Remote Compositional Analysis: Spectroscopy, Mineralogy, and Geochemistry of Planetary Surfaces
