description: Essential techniques for remote compositional analysis of planets; understanding spectroscopy, mineralogy, and geochemistry of planetary surfaces. Comparative studies of fundamental planetary science phenomena. Planetary surface science discoveries. Sustainability of planetary environments. Repeatable one time. (101 or 105 or 107 or ASTR 150; and CHEM 161; and MATH 241 and 242 and PHYS 272) with a minimum grade of C+; or consent.
prerequisites: (ERTH 101 or ERTH 105 or ERTH 107 or ASTR 150; and CHEM 161; and MATH 241 and MATH 242 and PHYS 272) with a minimum grade of C+; or consent

title: Natural Disasters: Geoethics and the Layman
description: Evaluates ethical practice of geoscience as it relates to studies of natural disasters that result from geological and meteorological phenomena and the means that earth scientists interact with the laymen. 101, 103, 104, or 170. (Once a year)

title: Energy and Mineral Resources
description: Lecture and discussion on the origin, distribution and exploitation of fossil fuels, renewable energy resources and ore deposits. Coverage and detail will depend partly on student interest and background. consent.

title: Undergraduate Seminar
description: Gain professional training and practical experience giving scientific presentations emphasizing Earth and planetary sciences, including analysis of associated ethical issues. Grading is distributed 60/40 between three oral communication assignments and related ethics content. 200 or 201 or consent

title: Introduction to Statistics and Data Analysis
description: Exploratory data analysis, error propagation, probability theory and statistics, curve fitting, regression, sequence and spectral analysis, multivariate analysis, and analysis of directional data. 250 and MATH 242 (or concurrent) or consent.
prerequisites: ERTH 250 and MATH 242 (or concurrent) or consent

title: Beaches, Reefs, and Climate Change
description: Global and local aspects of climate change and paleoclimate; beach and reef processes and response to climate change; management of coastal environments; field study local sites. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher, or consent. (

title: Marine Geology
description: Sediments, structure, geophysics, geochemistry, history of ocean basins and margins. 200 and 302 or consent. (

title: Environmental Geochemistry
description: Theory and applications of contaminant/pollutant distribution in the hydrosphere-geosphere-biosphere-atmosphere system, remediation methods, prevention, industrial/agricultural best practices. Topics include aqueous geochemistry, organic, inorganic, gas phase, and ecosystem impacts of environmental contaminants. CHEM 161 and CHEM 162, or consent. (Spring only) (

title: Coastal Geochemistry
description: Covers aqueous geochemistry at the land-ocean interface, including the distribution of major and minor ions, trace metals, organic chemicals, and nutrients. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 200 or 201, CHEM 162, and MATH 241 or MATH 251A; or consent. (Alt. years: spring)
prerequisites: ERTH 200 or ERTH 201, CHEM 162, and MATH 241 or MATH 251A; or consent

title: Plate Tectonics
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Quantitative geometrical analysis techniques of plate tectonics theory; instantaneous and finite rotation poles; triple-junction analysis; plate boundary stresses. 200 or consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Earthquakes and Crustal Deformation
description: Earthquakes and crustal deformation through modern seismological and geodetic observations; elastic properties of rocks, seismic waves, causes, detection, and location of earthquakes; crustal motions of the earthquake cycle; tsunami generation, liquefaction, and planetary observations. MATH 241 and PHYS 170, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Engineering Geology
description: Solutions of geotechnical problems by geologists and engineers through recognition, characterization, evaluation, and assessment of geologic processes that impact people, engineering structures, and engineering operations. Group format. ERTH, GEOL, and CEE majors only. Junior standing and higher. consent. (Spring only)

title: Hydrogeology
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Occurrence, characteristics, movement, quality, development, and contamination of water in the Earth’s crust.

title: Geological Remote Sensing
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Combined lecture-lab on the concepts behind, geologic uses for, and techniques of satellite and airborne remote sensing. Lab work will consist of computer image processing. Field trips. Open to non-majors. 200 or 201 or consent. (Alt. years: Spring)

title: Geospatial Information
description: Combined lecture/lab covering the collection, analysis and use of geospatially registered field data. (200 or 201) or equivalent. (Fall only)

title: Planetary Geology
description: Comparative geology of the terrestrial planets (moon, Mars, Mercury, Venus, and Earth); impact cratering, volcanism, tectonism, geomorphology, weathering; manned and unmanned space exploration. any 100-level ERTH course.

title: Lunar Geology
description: Introduction to the basics of the geology and spectroscopy of our Moon. A-F only. Senior standing or higher. 101. (Fall only)

title: Origin of the Solar System
description: Exploration of the origin and evolution of our solar system. Understanding the composition of the universe and its constituents (planets, asteroids, stars, comets, and meteorites). A-F only. 101 or 103 or 104 or 106 or 130 and CHEM 161 and PHYS 170. (Alt. years: spring)
prerequisites: ERTH 101 or ERTH 103 or ERTH 104 or ERTH 106 or ERTH 130 and CHEM 161 and PHYS 170

title: Undergraduate Thesis
description: Directed research in which the student carries out a scientific project of small to moderate scope with one or more chosen advisors. The student must complete a document in the style of a scientific journal article. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Earth and Planetary Sciences Workshops
description: Designed for in-service school professionals to learn new approaches and concepts in the fields of earth and planetary sciences. Repeatable for credit. Credits earned in these courses cannot be applied for graduate degrees.

title: Equations of Geophysics
description: Least-square approximation of functions by orthogonal series; potential, wave heat flow equations; boundary value problems; Bessel Hankel functions, spherical harmonics, potential theory, plane waves, spherical waves; emphasis on geophysics application. MATH 244 or MATH 253A, PHYS 400, or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 244 or MATH 253A, PHYS 400, or consent

title: Explosive Volcanism
description: Explosive volcanic eruptions: from causes to consequences. Review of current physical volcanology including ascent and fragmentation of magma, transport and deposition processes in pyroclastic eruptions, volcanic crisis management and volcanic eruption scenarios. Seven-day field trip. A-F only. 300 or consent.

title: Theoretical Petrology
description: Derivation of phase diagrams from basic thermodynamics principles. Equilibria of natural silicate systems. Crystal chemistry, kinetics, diffusion, etc., Applied to igneous and metamorphic petrology. 302, 325, and CHEM 351 (or concurrent); or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: ERTH 302, ERTH 325, and CHEM 351 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Petrology of Ocean Lithosphere
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Petrogenesis of the oceanic lithosphere, including mantle processes and rocks from mid-ocean ridges, seamounts, oceanic hotspots, back-arc basins, and intra-oceanic arcs. 302 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Disaster Science: Understanding Hazards and Disasters
description: Combined lecture/ discussion focusing on the scientific understanding of the forces and processes underlying natural hazards; and human attempts to respond to these through mitigation and planning. PLAN 670 or consent. (Once a year) (

title: Lava Flow Rheology and Morphology
description: Effusion eruptions: from eruption to final flow form. Includes: rheology, effusion rate, heat loss, and field measurements, followed by inflation, flow forms, lava lakes, domes, flow hazard and modeling. Field trips to Kilauea and Makapuu. A-F only. 300 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Current Events in Volcanology
description: Discussion of active areas of volcanism and new publications on volcanology. Repeatable four times. 300 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Submarine Volcanoes
description: Seminar exploring different aspects of submarine effusive and explosive volcanism, hydrothermal activity, and volcano-hosted ecosystems. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 300 or consent. (Alt.years: fall)

title: Isotopes and Trace Elements
description: Principles of radiogenic and stable isotope, and trace element geochemistry as applied to igneous petrology, mantle dynamics, plate tectonics, and terrestrial evolution. 302 and 325. (Alt. years)

title: Graduate Teaching Geology
description: For ERTH graduate students who lead, under faculty supervision, a scheduled class in Geology and Geophysics. The instructor will define the student’s responsibilities when offering ERTH 609, and these responsibilities must be met for a passing grade. As the consent to take the class must also be granted by the department chair, the chair will also review the responsibilities required by the instructor. ERTH graduate students only. CR/NC only. consent of instructor and department chair.
prerequisites: consent of instructor and department chair

title: Graduate Seminar
description: Seminar in which students present a 15- to 20-minute talk on their research or a related topic. Meets once a week with two to three talks per meeting. Graduate students are required to register for this course once per year. Repeatable eight times.

title: Accelerated Introduction to Earth Sciences I
description: Lecture presenting a rapid-paced survey of earth sciences for graduate students. Includes origin of the Solar System, tectonics, volcanology, whole-earth composition, phase transformations, petrology (igneous, metamorphic, and sedimentary), historical geology, and hydrology. Saturday field trips. (Fall only)

title: Introduction to Statistics and Data Analysis
description: Exploratory data analysis, error propagation, probability theory and statistics, curve fitting, regression, sequence and spectral analysis, multivariate analysis, and analysis of directional data. Credit earned only one time for either 413 or 613. 250 and MATH 242 (or concurrent), or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: ERTH 250 and MATH 242 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Advanced Field Study
description: Shipboard and land-based projects. Repeatable eight times. consent.

title: Literate Programming With R and RStudio
description: Literate programming with R, RStudio, and R Markdown for data analysis and research. Introduction to Matlab for rapid modeling. Emphasis on the preparation of research papers for scholarly publication in the Earth and environmental sciences. competence in basic differential and integral calculus. (Fall only)
prerequisites: competence in basic differential and integral calculus

title: How to Write a Scientific Paper
description: Designed for students who have collected data and want to know how to publish their work in a scientific journal. Covers the essential parts of paper preparation and submission. ERTH students only. A-F only. consent. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Summer Fieldschool Program: Hydrogeophysics in Volcanic Environments
description: Will cover the full hydrogeophysical workflow including theory, acquisition design, field data acquisition, data processing, data inversion, and hydrogeological interpretation. Methods include ambient seismic, 3D electrical resistivity tomography and induced polarization, and self-potential. consent. (Summer only)

title: Coastal Geology
description: Geological history and geologic framework of the Hawaiian shoreline. Modern climate change, paleoclimate, focus on sea level change. Modern coastal management and problems in the coastal environment. Coastal planning. Repeatable one time, credit earned one time. (Spring only) (

title: Electron Microprobe Analysis
description: Combined lecture-lab on the principles of geochemical analysis by electron microprobe and X-ray fluorescence. Hands-on experience with the electron microprobe. Required to operate the UH electron microprobe. 301 or consent.

title: Advanced Environmental Geochemistry
description: Theory and applications of contaminant/pollutant distribution in the hydrosphere-geosphere-biosphere-atmosphere system and remediation methods. Topics include aqueous geochemistry, organic, inorganic, gas phase and isotope chemistry of environmental contaminants. 325 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Numerical Modeling of Physical Systems
description: Finite difference, finite element, and other modeling techniques applied to geological and geophysical problems. Physical modeling of heat flow, molecular diffusion, solidification and melting, deformation, fluid flow, wave propagation, and other phenomena. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Geophysics–Solid, Fluid, and Wave Mechanics
description: Continuum mechanics in geophysics, as applied to the deformation of Earth materials (elastic, viscous, viscoelastic, and plastic deformations) and seismic wave propagation (body waves, surface waves, anisotropy, and attenuation). (with a minimum grade of B-) for PHYS 170, PHYS 272, and MATH 307 or ERTH 312 (or equivalent). (Fall only)
prerequisites: (with a minimum grade of B-) for PHYS 170, PHYS 272, and MATH 307 or ERTH 312 (or equivalent)

title: Geophysics–Gravity, Magnetics, and Heat Transfer
description: Fundamental theory and practical applications of the use of gravity, magnetics, and heat conduction to probing the structure of the Earth; heat transfer via mantle convection is a major control on Earth’s internal structure. (with a minimum grade of B-) for PHYS 170, PHYS 272, and MATH 307 or ERTH 312 (or equivalent). (Spring only)
prerequisites: (with a minimum grade of B-) for PHYS 170, PHYS 272, and MATH 307 or ERTH 312 (or equivalent)

title: Seismology
description: Elasticity, wave equations, body waves, surface waves, free oscillations, seismometry, seismogram interpretation, tectonics, inversion, source theory, and waveform modeling. 600 or consent.

title: Earth System Science and Global Change
description: Global view of the planet and how it functions as an integrated unit. Biogeochemical processes, dynamics, and cycles, and analysis of natural and human-induced environmental change. Chemical history of ocean-atmospheric-sediment system and co-evolution of the biota. Repeatable one time. BS in environmentally related science or one year of chemistry, physics, and calculus; or consent. (
prerequisites: BS in environmentally related science or one year of chemistry, physics, and calculus; or consent

title: Stable Isotope Biogeochemistry
description: Stable isotope geochemistry applied to questions of biogeochemical cycling in the oceans, sediment diagenesis, paleoceanography, environmental geochemistry and ecology. 325 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Coastal Geochemistry
description: Geochemistry at the land-ocean interface: coastal hydrology, subterranean estuaries and coastal mixing and their importance in governing the distribution of selected radiotracers, trace metals and nutrients. Combined lecture-lab with field trips and group projects. CHEM 162, and MATH 241 or MATH 251A; or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: CHEM 162, and MATH 241 or MATH 251A; or consent

title: Origin of Sedimentary Rocks
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Environment of deposition and subsequent diagenesis of modern and ancient sediments. Petrogenesis of siliciclastic, carbonate and orthochemical rocks. Sedimentology, sedimentary petrography and geochemistry. Repeatable one time. consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Elemental Composition Changes
description: Changes in the chemical composition of meteorites, bulk Earth, Earth’s mantle and crust, sedimentary rocks, hydrosphere and biosphere, and underlying principles. consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Sedimentary Geochemistry
description: Geochemical thermodynamics and kinetics and their use in interpreting the origin of sediments, sedimentary rocks, and natural waters over a range of pressure-temperature conditions. CHEM 171, or CHEM 161 and CHEM 162; PHYS 152; and MATH 242 or MATH 252A; and consent. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: CHEM 171, or CHEM 161 and CHEM 162; PHYS 152; and MATH 242 or MATH 252A; and consent

title: Geomagnetism and Cosmic Magnetism
description: Magnetic fields of Earth, planets, stars, and galaxies; dynamo theories; paleomagnetism; terrestrial and lunar rock magnetism; planetary, regional, and local geomagnetic sounding. consent. (Alt. years)

title: Groundwater Contamination
description: Principles of groundwater chemistry; chemical evolution in natural groundwater flow systems; sources of contamination; mass transport processes; hydrochemical behavior of contaminants. 455.

title: Groundwater Modeling
description: Introduction to the finite-difference method; steady-state and transient groundwater flow in saturated and unsaturated media; applications to groundwater recharge and aquifer evaluation. A-F only. CEE 627 or consent. (

title: Astrochemistry–A Molecular Approach
description: Formation of astrobiologically important molecules and their precursors in the interstellar medium and in our solar system: first principles and latest trends. consent. (Fall only) (

title: Planetary Surfaces
description: Comparative geology of terrestrial planets (moon, Mars, Mercury, Venus, and Earth); impact cratering, volcanism, geomorphology; remote sensing; manned and unmanned space exploration. 601, ASTR 630; or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Cosmochemistry
description: Formation and evolution of planets as astrophysical objects, geologic bodies, and abodes of life; current understanding from studies of the Solar System, star formation, meteorites, exoplanets; theory of formation and dynamics; atmospheres, oceans, habitability, biosignatures. 325 or CHEM 351 (or equivalent); or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: ERTH 325 or CHEM 351 (or equivalent); or consent

title: (Alpha) Remote Sensing
description: Spectroscopic, radar, thermal, and other methods for remote sensing applied to geologic problems; instrumental design and data analysis. (B) planets; (C) volcanoes. 666 or consent.

title: Seminar in Tectonics
description: Evolution of ocean basins, margins, foldbelts, and platforms, from plate tectonics and regional syntheses of structure, petrology, geophysics, and stratigraphy. Repeatable eight times. (Alt. years)

title: (Alpha) Extraterrestrial Material
description: Mineralogical and compositional characteristics of extraterrestrial matter and the implications for the origin and history of the solar system. The subject is treated in two full-semester courses: (B) meteorites; (C) petrology of the Moon and Mars. consent.

title: Paleoceanography
description: Study of the paleoceanographic and paleoclimate evolution of the Earth’s oceans, atmosphere and biosphere. Repeatable one time. consent. (Alt. years) (

title: The Generic Mapping Tools
description: Introduction to the Generic Mapping Tools (GMT). Processing of scientific data and the automated preparation of maps and illustrations using GMT on UNIX workstations, with introduction to UNIX and the C shell environment.

title: Data Exploration and Processing
description: Time- and frequency analysis, filtering, factor and cluster analysis, interpolation, quantitative map analysis, and introduction to wavelets and fractals. 413 or consent.

title: Bayesian Data Analysis
description: Linear and nonlinear techniques for model selection, parameter estimation, simulation and forecasting, from Bayesian principles with particular attention to large data sets and sparse noisy data. 600 or 691. (Alt. years)

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Physics of the Earth’s Interior
description: Interpretation of geophysical and laboratory data to understand elastic and anelastic properties, composition, phase relationships, temperature distribution in the Earth. consent. (Alt. years)

title: Fractures and Faults
description: Lecture on elasticity theory, fracture mechanics and boundary element modeling, with application to faults and fractures in the Earth. consent.

title: Selected Topics in Earth and Planetary Sciences
description: Content to be announced. Repeatable eight times. consent.

title: Special Topics in Earth and Planetary Sciences
description: Content to be announced. Repeatable eight times. consent.

title: MGeo Seminar
description: Seminar to improve student awareness of trends and practices in geoscience professions, and develop ability to prepare, deliver, and evaluate a professional scientific presentation. Targets abstract writing, oral presentation, and technical criticism. Repeatable two times. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: MGeo Professional Project
description: Practical hands-on professional experience, typically with a local company or agency, and involving a final written report and an oral presentation. A grade of credit is assigned when the internship presentations are satisfactorily completed. Repeatable up to six credits. MGEO majors only. CR/NC only.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Writing East Asia
description: An introduction to writing analytically and cross-culturally about East Asia (China, Japan, Korea) and various aspects of East Asian culture. (Fall only)

title: Introduction to Chinese Language and Culture
description: Provides students with interesting perspectives on and some general knowledge of Chinese language, literature, and culture.

title: Japanese Literature in Translation– Traditional
description: Survey of all major forms from the earliest era to mid-19th century.

title: Japanese Literature in Translation– Modern
description: Survey from mid-19th century to present; emphasis on fiction.

title: Survey of Japanese Literature–KIC
description: Survey of traditional and modern Japanese literature in translation, covering all major genres. Only offered at Konan University in Japan. Not open to students with 271 or 272.

title: Korean Literature in Translation– Traditional
description: Survey of Korean literature from earliest times with emphasis on development and cultural context; all readings in English translation. Students write essays about the readings.

title: Korean Literature in Translation– Modern
description: Survey of 20th-century Korean literature with emphasis on development and cultural context; all readings in English translation. Students write essays about the readings.

title: Topics in Korean Culture
description: Multi-disciplinary and historically-located study of Korean culture through the examination of literary and visual texts. Topics will depend upon the term. Repeatable one time with consent. Sophomore standing or higher. (Spring only)

title: (Alpha) Japanese Film: Art and History
description: Study and analysis of Japanese film; its history and relationship to cultural, social, philosophical, and aesthetic contexts. (B) 1900-1960; (C) 1960-present; (D) special topics. upper division standing or consent. (

title: Chinese Film: Art and History
description: Study and analysis of Chinese film; its history and relationship to cultural, social, philosophical, and aesthetic contexts. (

title: Literary Traditions of East Asia
description: Selected works of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean literature in English; relationships and parallels. one DH or DL course, or consent.
prerequisites: one DH or DL course, or consent

title: Chinese Literature: Ancient
description: Survey of all major genres from antiquity until the ninth century. one DH or DL course, or consent.
prerequisites: one DH or DL course, or consent

title: Chinese Literature: Pre-modern
description: Survey of all major genres from the ninth century till the end of the Qing. one DH or DL course, or consent.
prerequisites: one DH or DL course, or consent

title: (Alpha) 20th-Century Chinese Literature and Culture
description: Survey of 20th-century Chinese literature in translation. Includes a variety of genres from China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong: (B) 1919–1949; (C) 1949–present; emphases on writing instruction. one DH or DL course, or consent
prerequisites: one DH or DL course, or consent

title: 20th-Century Chinese Women Writers
description: A survey and critical examination of contemporary Chinese women writers from China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. Traces a genealogy of women’s writing from the early 1920s up until now through novels, poetry, drama, and film. one DH or DL course, or consent.
prerequisites: one DH or DL course, or consent

title: (Alpha) Traditional Chinese Fiction in Translation
description: Survey of -modern Chinese fiction in translation. (B) short story; (C) novel. one DH or DL course, or consent.

title: The City in Modern Chinese Literature and Visual Arts
description: Study of the fictional and visual representations of the city in the changing contexts of Chinese modernization from the late imperial age to the beginning of the 21st century. one DH or DL course, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: one DH or DL course, or consent

title: Topics in Traditional Japanese Literature
description: Reading and analysis of English translations of selected important works in the classical tradition. No knowledge of Japanese required. Repeatable two times in different topics with consent.

title: Topics in Modern Japanese Literature
description: Reading and analysis of English translations of selected important works in modern Japanese literature. No knowledge of Japanese required. Repeatable two times in different topics with consent.

title: Topics in Japanese Cultural Studies
description: Multi-disciplinary and historically located study of Japanese culture through the examination of literary and visual texts. Specific topics will depend upon the term. Repeatable one time with consent. one DH or DL course, or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: one DH or DL course, or consent

title: Modern Korean Women Writers and Culture
description: Study of fiction by modern Korean women writers in the changing context of Korean culture. A-F only. sophomore standing or higher.

title: East-West Cultural Encounters
description: Critical examination of encounters between Western and East Asian cultures across time. In addition to literary texts, the course may use sources from other media, and focus on a specific era, region, or genre. an EALL course at 200 level or above; or a DH or DL course at 200 level or above; or consent.
prerequisites: an EALL course at EALL 200 level or above; or a DH or DL course at EALL 200 level or above; or consent

title: Topics in Chinese Cultural Studies: Visual Culture–Chinese Diaspora
description: Multidisciplinary and historically located study of Chinese culture through the examination of literary/visual texts and critical essays from cultural studies. Specific topics will depend upon term. Repeatable one time with consent. one DH or DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one DH or DL course or consent

title: Transnational Chinese Popular Culture
description: Survey of contemporary Chinese popular entertainment forms that are produced and appreciated transnationally. Examples include martial arts genres, kung fu films, commercial novels, ballroom dancing, karaoke culture, music videos and rock music. Material will be selected based upon availability and readings will include critical essays from the fields of popular culture, media studies, and literary criticism. any 300- or 400-level DL or DH course. (
prerequisites: any EALL 300- or EALL 400-level DL or DH course

title: Perspectives on Chinese Cinema
description: Introduction to Chinese cinema studies, with emphasis on the theoretical and critical approaches to Chinese film. one DH or DL course, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: one DH or DL course, or consent

title: Senior Colloquium in East Asian Literature
description: Comparative perspectives; some works studied in the original. third-level East Asian language.

title: Current Issues in East Asian Language Pedagogy
description: Survey on East Asian language pedagogy designed to develop students’ familiarity with and facility in addressing the major issues, initiatives, and innovations in the field. graduate standing or consent.

title: Introduction to East Asian Linguistics
description: Introduction to cross-linguistic comparison of the writing systems, dialects, history, phonology, morphology, and syntax of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean. CHN 451 and 452, or JPN 451, or KOR 451 and 452; or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: CHN 451 and CHN 452, or JPN 451, or KOR 451 and KOR 452; or consent

title: (Alpha) Bibliographical and Research Methods
description: Traditional and modern references and other library materials basic to research in all areas of East Asian studies: (C) Chinese; (J) Japanese; (K) Korean. CHN 402 for (C); JPN 407 (alpha) for (J); KOR 402 for (K).
prerequisites: CHN 402 for (C); JPN 407 (alpha) for (J); KOR 402 for (K)

title: Topics in 20th Century Chinese Literary and Cultural Studies
description: Critical scholarship in Chinese literature and cultural studies, broadly defined to include the People’s Republic of China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and others. Reading knowledge of Chinese desirable but not required. Repeatable one time with consent. consent. (

title: Contemporary Chinese Documentary: Record, Expression, Cultural Space
description: Introduction to contemporary Chinese independent documentary with these goals: to achieve in-depth understanding of Chinese society through documentary; be familiar with theoretical debates on documentary form; and understand documentary as a cultural discourse. 473 or 476, or instructor consent. (Alt. years: fall)
prerequisites: EALL 473 or EALL 476, or instructor consent

title: Special Topics in East Asian Literary Culture & Society
description: In-depth study of selected topics and issues in modern/contemporary East Asian literary and cultural studies using an interdisciplinary, inter-regional, and transnational approach, from an intercultural perspective. Repeatable two times in different topics, but need consent for second repeat. A-F only. consent. (

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Comparative East Asian Literature
description: Comparison of authors, modes, topics, and genres in poetry and prose; theoretical and practical criticism. consent.

title: Seminar in Comparison of East Asian Languages
description: Comparison of lexicon, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, etc., of two or more East Asian languages, contact influence on them. CHN 451, CHN 452, or JPN 451; or consent.
prerequisites: CHN 451, CHN 452, or JPN 451; or consent

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Elementary Japanese, Special
description: Same material as 101, covered more quickly for students with some language background. placement test.

title: Elementary Japanese I
description: Listening, speaking, reading, writing, grammar. Meets one hour, four times a week, plus lab work.

title: Elementary Japanese II
description: Continuation of 100 or 101. 100 or 101, or consent.

title: Accelerated Elementary Japanese
description: Content of 101 and 102 covered in one semester. Meets two hours, four times a week. consent.

title: Elementary Japanese for Oral Communication I
description: The first of a series of courses focusing on speaking and listening skills necessary to performing in common situations in Hawai‘i and Japan. consent.

title: Elementary Japanese for Oral Communication II
description: Continuation of 111. 100 or 101 or 111, or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 100 or JPN 101 or JPN 111, or consent

title: Intermediate Japanese I
description: Continuation of 101 and 102. Meets one hour, four times a week, plus lab work. 102, 105, or placement test; or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 102, JPN 105, or placement test; or consent

title: Intermediate Japanese II
description: Continuation of 201. 201 or placement test; or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 201 or placement test; or consent

title: Accelerated Intermediate Japanese for Pre-Professionals
description: Content of 201 and 202 covered in one semester. Emphasis on practical Japanese used in professional contexts. Meets two hours, four times a week. 102, 105; or consent.

title: Intermediate Japanese for Oral Communication I
description: Continuation of 111-112. 102 or 105 or 112; or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 102 or JPN 105 or JPN 112; or consent

title: Intermediate Japanese for Oral Communication II
description: Continuation of 211. 201 or 211, or consent.

title: Introduction to Japanese Reading and Writing with Basic Kanji
description: For students who have completed the oral communication courses up through JPN 212 and wish to continue on to JPN 301. Also appropriate for semi-bilingual students who lack literacy skills. 212 or consent.

title: Intermediate Japanese Abroad
description: Intensive course of formal instruction on the second-year level in Japanese language and culture in Japan. 102 or 105.

title: Intermediate Japanese Abroad
description: Continuation of 258. 201 or 258, or consent.

title: Third-Year Japanese I
description: Transitional course employing four skills (listening, speaking, reading, writing) and grammar training to prepare students to address academic content in Japanese. Meets one hour, four times a week, plus lab work. 202, 205, 217, or placement test; or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 202, JPN 205, JPN 217, or placement test; or consent

title: Third-Year Japanese II
description: Continuation of 301. 301 or placement test, or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 301 or placement test, or consent

title: Accelerated Third-Year Japanese
description: Content of 301 and 302 covered in one semester. Meets two hours, four times a week, plus lab work. 202, 205, 217, or consent.

title: Third-Year Japanese for Professional Communication I
description: Training in oral communication skills essential for operating in a Japanese-speaking professional environment or workplace, focusing on activities such as first-time meetings, small talk with coworkers, and making/handling requests and invitations. 202, 205, 212, or placement test; or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: JPN 202, JPN 205, JPN 212, or placement test; or consent

title: Third-Year Japanese for Professional Communication: Business Etiquette and Hospitality
description: Training in oral communication skills essential for operating in a Japanese-speaking professional environment or workplace, focusing on activities such as telephone conversations, customer service, and daily interaction with coworkers. 202, 205, 212, or placement test; or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 202, JPN 205, JPN 212, or placement test; or consent

title: Third-Year Japanese Aural Comprehension
description: Training in strategies for listening to various types of spoken material presented in narrations, interviews, news broadcasts, and lectures, etc. 302 or consent.

title: Oral Fluency Through Film
description: Training in oral communication and comprehension skills utilizing the spoken text and visual segments from Japanese film and television dramas. 301 or consent.

title: Linquistic Analysis of Manga & Anime
description: Study of basic linguistic concepts and phenomena through manga and anime (and other Japanese fiction). Class activities will consist of lecture, discussion, and analysis of linguistic data. 202, 205, 217, or consent.

title: Advanced Japanese Reading and Writing
description: Web-based training in Japanese reading and writing to develop skills at the advanced level. Course activities combine independent work with communicative activities on the website. Ideal for in-service professionals seeking language development and maintenance. Repeatable one time. 301 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Introduction to Japanese Linguistics
description: Introduction to major areas of linguistic description as applied to Japanese language. 301 or 307, or consent.

title: Third-Level Japanese Abroad
description: Intensive course of full-time formal instruction on the third-year level in Japanese language and culture in Japan. 202, 205, 217, or consent.

title: Third-Level Japanese Abroad
description: Continuation of 358. 301 or 358.

title: Japanese Language Abroad Electives
description: Students will directly enroll in Japanese language courses at J.F. Oberlin University or Konan University. Repeatable two times for different topics, up to nine credits. A-F only. instructor consent.

title: Language in Japanese Society
description: Introduction to basic concepts and issues surrounding language in Japanese society. Covers historical, cultural, and sociolinguistic dimensions of the Japanese language. Topics are closely linked with contemporary ethical issues. 301 or consent.

title: Directed Third-Level Reading
description: For those who need special assistance, e.g., reading texts in area of specialization or at a pace more rapid than those of standard courses. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. consent.

title: Fourth-Year Japanese I
description: Continuation of 302 and 305 emphasizing all four skills. Transition to longer and more complex written and spoken Japanese. Meets 50 minutes, four times a week. 302, 305, or placement test; or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 302, JPN 305, or placement test; or consent

title: Fourth-Year Japanese II
description: Continuation of 401. Transition to longer and more complex written and spoken Japanese. Meets 50 minutes, four times a week. 401 or placement test; or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 401 or placement test; or consent

title: Fourth-Year Japanese for Advanced Speakers
description: 4th-year Japanese language course that provide bilingual and other advanced speakers with language training in formal Japanese with a focus on reading and oral communication skills. placement or consent.

title: Fourth-Year Japanese for Advanced Written Communication
description: 4th-year Japanese language course that provide bilingual and other advanced speakers with language training in formal Japanese with a focus on reading and writing skills. placement or consent.

title: Fourth-Level Japanese Reading: Accelerated
description: Content of 401 and 402 covered in one semester. Meets two hours, four times a week. 302, 305, or placement test.

title: (Alpha) Readings in Original Texts
description: (D) academic and journalistic texts; (E) modern literature. Repeatable one time in different alphas. 401, 403, 404, or 405; or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 401, JPN 403, JPN 404, or JPN 405; or consent

title: Japanese Aural Comprehension
description: Training in comprehension of spoken material presented in news broadcasts, documentary narration, formal lectures, etc. 402, 405; or consent. May be concurrent with 407.

title: Fourth-Level Spoken Japanese
description: Training in oral communication skills in varied social contexts. 402 or 405.

title: Japanese Composition
description: Writing skills refined through practice in various styles (essays, letters, etc.). 401, 404, or 405; or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 401, JPN 404, or JPN 405; or consent

title: Advanced Listening and Speaking
description: Training in listening and speaking for bilingual and other advanced learners. Emphasis on formal Japanese such as academic lectures, news, exchanges in business settings, public speaking, etc. 421 or consent.

title: English to Japanese Translation
description: Training in techniques of translating English in Japanese. 407D or 407E, or consent.

title: Japanese to English Translation
description: Training in techniques of translating Japanese into English. 407D or 407E, or consent.

title: Advanced Business Writing
description: Training in advanced business writing for bilingual and other advanced learners. Japanese writing intensive. 421 or consent.

title: Structure of Japanese
description: Introduction to phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics of modern colloquial Japanese. 302 or 305; and 350 or LING 320; or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 302 or JPN 305; and JPN 350 or LING 320; or consent

title: Introduction to Japanese Pedagogical Grammar
description: Introduction to teaching of basic Japanese grammatical patterns. 350 or LING 320, and 401, 403, 404 or 405; or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 350 or LING 320, and LING 401, LING 403, LING 404 or LING 405; or consent

title: Introduction to Teaching Japanese as a Foreign Language
description: Introduction to instructional approaches for Japanese language classroom teaching that focus on everyday language use. Students develop instructional materials, pedagogical practices, and assessment tools for engaged and effective teaching and learning of Japanese. 350 (or concurrent) and 401, 403, 404, or 405 (or concurrent); or instructor’s consent.
prerequisites: JPN 350 (or concurrent) and JPN 401, JPN 403, JPN 404, or JPN 405 (or concurrent); or instructor’s consent

title: Fourth-Level Japanese Abroad
description: Intensive course of full time instruction on the fourth-year level in Japanese language and culture in Japan. 302, 305, 359, or consent.

title: Fourth-Level Japanese Abroad
description: Continuation of 458. 401 or 458.

title: Introduction to Classical Japanese
description: Basic classical Japanese grammar to develop reading skills. 302 or consent.

title: Readings in Classical Japanese
description: Introduction to major genres of prose and poetry. Repeatable one time with permission. 461 or consent.

title: Okinawan Language and Culture
description: Focuses on the language, heritage, and folk culture of Okinawa. 202, 205, or consent.

title: Okinawan Language and Literature
description: Focuses on Okinawan literature across various genres and periods. Will require weekly reaction papers, the midterm reading/writing project, and a final research project report. 202, 205, or consent.

title: Introduction to Japanese Sociolinguistics
description: Application of general linguistics to social phenomena such as group identity, language and gender, dialects and intercultural communication. 350 and 370, or consent.

title: Advanced Readings in Modern Japanese Literature
description: Advanced course to foster speed, accuracy and attention to stylistic issues in modern Japanese literature. 407D and 407E, or consent.

title: Advanced Readings in Modern Japanese Contemporary Topics
description: Advanced course to foster speed, accuracy, and attention to content in reading modern discursive texts. 407D and 407E, or consent.

title: Advanced Japanese Language Study
description: Advanced course in spoken and written Japanese stressing intensive research using the Internet, electronic mail in Japanese and conventional media. Oral presentations, written reports and journal writing. Repeatable one time. 485 or equivalent and consent.

title: Project Work in Japanese
description: Enhances Japanese language skills through a field-based research project on a topic of the individual student’s choice. Interviews, surveys, observations, written materials and A/V-assisted oral presentations. Repeatable one time. 402 or 405 or equivalent, or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 402 or JPN 405 or equivalent, or consent

title: (Alpha) Internship Program
description: Analysis of intercultural communication processes under faculty supervision through participation in an organization serving native speakers of Japanese. (B) business, repeatable one time; (C) travel industry internship. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 370 or consent for (C); 431 for (B).
prerequisites: JPN 370 or consent for (C); JPN 431 for (B)

title: Directed Fourth-Level Reading
description: For those who need special assistance, e.g., in reading texts in area of specialization or at a pace more rapid than those of standard courses. Primarily for graduate students from other departments. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. consent.

title: Japanese Phonology and Morphology
description: Introduction to the phonology and morphology of modern colloquial Japanese. 451 or consent.

title: Japanese Syntax and Semantics
description: Introduction to theories of syntax, sentence structure, parts of speech, constituency, grammatical relations and case marking, word order, passives, causatives, tense, aspect, and embeddings. 451 or consent.

title: Introduction to Japanese Language Pedagogy
description: Training in the identification and analysis of general problems in Japanese language learning, teaching, and testing by examining theoretical issues and conducting classroom research. 407 or equivalent, and 451; or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 407 or equivalent, and JPN 451; or consent

title: Research Methodology in Japanese Linguistics and Language Teaching
description: Japanese-specific training in the formulation of testable hypotheses, in basic statistical and other evaluation techniques, and in the organization and presentation of ideas and data in paper, abstracts, etc. 407 or equivalent.

title: Japanese Sociolinguistics
description: Introduces theories of language use and provides training in the methodology and analysis of Japanese sociolinguistics. 407 and 475 or equivalent, or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 407 and JPN 475 or equivalent, or consent

title: (Alpha) Japanese Poetry
description: Historical survey of major poetic types. Repeatable one time with consent. (B) classical; (C) medieval and Edo; (D) modern. 466 or consent for (B) and (C); 485 or consent for (D).
prerequisites: JPN 466 or consent for (B) and (C); JPN 485 or consent for (D)

title: (Alpha) Modern Japanese Literature
description: Representative literary works, emphasis on fiction; (B) Meiji–Taisho (1868–1926); (C) Showa–Heisei (1926–present). Each alpha repeatable one time with consent. 485 or consent

title: Edo Literature
description: Critical reading and analysis; emphasis on prose. Repeatable one time with consent. 466 or consent.

title: Medieval Japanese Literature
description: Critical reading and analysis of Kamakura and Muromachi literature, emphasis on prose. Repeatable one time with consent. 466 or consent.

title: Classical Japanese Literature
description: Critical reading and analysis of Heian literature; emphasis on prose. Repeatable one time with consent. 466 or consent.

title: Practicum: Teaching Japanese Language (Alpha)
description: For graduate students who are planning to teach Japanese as a foreign language. Through lectures and discussions on language learning and teaching, and through observation and teaching of a Japanese language class, students will learn to make informed decisions about curriculum and instruction, and will develop instructional skills and practices for analyzing their teaching experiences. (B) beginning level Japanese instruction; (C) advanced level Japanese instruction. Each alpha may be taken one time. 604 or EALL 601, or consent. (Once a year for (B) and (C)).

title: Introduction to Japanese Manuscripts and Xylographs
description: Introduction to Classical Japanese writing system as found in the xylographs and manuscripts of the Heian and Kamakura periods; reading and analysis of the texts in original script. Repeatable one time. 461 or 466, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: History of the Japanese Language
description: Survey, theories of origin; related topics in linguistic methodology. 461 and 601, or consent.

title: Teaching Japanese as a Second Language
description: Practical overview of major problems; motivation; adult second language learning; communicative and linguistic competence; practical classroom techniques of teaching and testing. 604 or consent.

title: Advanced Japanese Sociolinguistics
description: Variations in language form and use depending on social factors. 601 or 602 (or concurrent), and 606; or consent.
prerequisites: JPN 601 or JPN 602 (or concurrent), and JPN 606; or consent

title: Advanced Japanese Syntax and Semantics
description: Theoretical problems in description of Japanese; contributions of Japanese linguistic study to syntactic theory. 602 or consent.

title: Topics in Japanese Literature
description: Intensive study of selected topics in Japanese literature, primarily of the modern period. English translations of original texts will be provided whenever available. Repeatable unlimited times with consent. consent. (

title: Traditional Literary Theory
description: Reading and analysis of major works of literary theory and criticism from the classical, medieval, and Edo periods. A-F only. 466 or consent.

title: Kambun
description: Introduction to kambun [the Japanese manner of reading and writing classical Chinese], with critical reading of kambun by Japanese authors. A-F only. 461 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Topics in Japanese Linguistics
description: (C) Japanese/English contrastive analysis; (G) structure; (H) historical change; (K) history of Japanese language studies (Kokugo-gaku-shi); (M) morphophonemics; (P) pedagogy; (S) sociolinguistics. 601 and 602 for (C); 634 for (G); 631 for (H) and (K); 601 for (M); 632 for (P); 633 for (S).
prerequisites: JPN 601 and JPN 602 for (C); JPN 634 for (G); JPN 631 for (H) and (K); JPN 601 for (M); JPN 632 for (P); JPN 633 for (S)

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. consent of chair.

title: (Alpha) Research Seminar in Japanese Literature
description: (M) modern; 611 (P) -modern; 612, 613, or 614.
prerequisites: JPN 611 (P) pre-modern; Pre: JPN 612, JPN 613, or JPN 614

title: (Alpha) Research Seminar in Japanese Linguistics
description: (C) Japanese/English contrastive analysis; (G) structure; (H) historical change; (K) history of Japanese language studies (Kokugo-gakushi); (M) morphophonemics; (P) pedagogy; (S) sociolinguistics. 451, or 601 and 602 for (C); 634 for (G); 631 for (H) and (K); 601 for (M); 632 for (P); and 633 for (S).
prerequisites: JPN 451, or JPN 601 and JPN 602 for (C); JPN 634 for (G); JPN 631 for (H) and (K); JPN 601 for (M); JPN 632 for (P); and JPN 633 for (S)

title: Elementary Korean I
description: Listening, speaking, reading, writing, grammar. Meets one hour, four times a week, plus lab work. consent.

title: Elementary Korean II
description: Continuation of 101. 101 or consent.

title: Accelerated Elementary Korean
description: Content of KOR 101 and 102 covered in one intensive course. Four 2-hour sessions per week, Monday-Thursday, plus daily lab work. placement test or consent. (Fall only)

title: Elementary Conversational Korean I
description: Development of basic skills (listening, speaking and grammar) of spoken Korean, with application to some familiar everyday topics. consent.

title: Elementary Conversational Korean II
description: Continuation of 111. 101 or 111, or consent.

title: Intermediate Korean I
description: Continuation of 101 and 102. Meets one hour, four times a week, plus lab work. 102 or placement test; or consent.
prerequisites: KOR 102 or placement test; or consent

title: Intermediate Korean II
description: Continuation of 201. 201 or placement test; or consent.
prerequisites: KOR 201 or placement test; or consent

title: Accelerated Intermediate Korean
description: Content of KOR 201 and 202 covered in one intensive course. Four 2-hour sessions per week, Monday-Thursday, plus daily lab work. 102, 105, 112, placement test; or consent. (Spring only)
prerequisites: KOR 102, KOR 105, KOR 112, placement test; or consent

title: Intermediate Conversational Korean I
description: Further development of listening and speaking skills. The student is expected to be able to comprehend and produce speech at the paragraph level. 102 or 112, or consent

title: Intermediate Conversational Korean II
description: Continuation of 211. 201 or 211, or consent.

title: Third-Level Korean I
description: Continuation of 201 and 202. Major emphasis on comprehension of modern written Korean. Chinese characters. 202 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Third-Level Korean II
description: Continuation of 301. 301 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Accelerated Third-Level Korean
description: Content of 301 and 302 covered in one intensive summer course. Five 3-hour sessions per week, Monday-Friday. 202, 205, placement test, or consent. (Summer only)
prerequisites: KOR 202, KOR 205, placement test, or consent

title: Readings in Chinese Characters I
description: Training intermediate and advanced learners of Korean to master the reading, writing and usage of some 250 basic Chinese characters as they are used in a wide variety of Korean reading texts. 202 or consent.

title: Readings in Chinese Characters II
description: Continuation of 307, covering an additional 250 basic Chinese characters. 307 or consent.

title: Reading and Translating Korean Poetry
description: Introduction to modern Korean poetry and translation for students with third-year level Korean abilities. Students will learn how to interpret poems and translate them from Korean to English. 301 or consent.

title: Korean Proficiency Through TV Drama
description: Increasing Korean proficiency to advanced level through TV drama, which provides culturally and situationally rich contexts. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing. 302 or consent.

title: Directed Third-Level Reading
description: For those who need special assistance, e.g., in reading texts in area of specialization or at a pace more rapid than those of standard courses. Offered if staff available. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. consent.

title: Fourth-Level Korean I
description: Continuation of 302. 302 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Fourth-Level Korean II
description: Continuation of 401. 401 or consent. (Spring only)

title: High-Advanced Korean: Korean Society
description: Emphasis on highest level of listening, speaking, reading and writing, with application to Korean society, using authentic materials. 402 or consent. (Fall only)

title: High-Advanced Korean II
description: Continuation of 402. Emphasis on highest level of listening, speaking, reading and writing, with application to Korean culture using authentic materials and focusing on training in oral presentation skills. 402 or consent.

title: Advanced Oral Communication in Korean
description: Fourth-year advanced Korean course to increase learners’ oral fluency and accuracy; with an emphasis on formal speaking. Covers linguistic proficiency as well as social and cultural proficiencies. 402 or consent.

title: Korean Composition
description: Training in modern structural and stylistic techniques; writing on designated themes. Repeatable one time. 402 or consent.

title: Media Analysis in Korean: Contemporary Korean Culture
description: Focus on analyzing, comparing, and evaluating current media materials in South Korea to develop professional language skills and to deepen knowledge and understanding of contemporary Korean society. A-F only. 402, or consent. (Once a year)

title: Media Analysis in Korean: Contemporary Ethical Issues in Korea
description: Focus on analyzing, comparing, and evaluating current ethical issues in South Korea and North Korea using media materials to develop professional language skills and to deepen knowledge and understanding of contemporary North Korea. A-F only. 402 or consent.

title: Selected Readings in Korean
description: Selected readings in various disciplines. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing. Repeatable one time with consent. 402 or consent.

title: Structure of Korean: Phonology/Morphology
description: Introduction to phonology, morphology, and history. 302 or consent.

title: Structure of Korean: Syntax
description: Introduction to syntax and semantics. 302 or consent.

title: Language and Culture of Korea
description: Relation of Korean language to literature, history, philosophy, social structure, values, and interpersonal relationships; social and regional varieties. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing. 302 or consent.

title: Korean Proficiency Through Film
description: Study of Korean culture through films to elevate students’ Korean proficiency level and improve their knowledge of Korea. Emphasis on writing instruction. Requires a minimum of 16 pages of graded writing. 402 or consent.

title: Korean for Academic Purposes: Humanities
description: Focus on expanding students’ Korean literacy and cultural knowledge in various Humanities disciplines, including history, religion, language, education, and literature. Taught entirely in Korean. 402 or consent.

title: Korean for Academic Purposes: Social Science & Others
description: Focus on expanding students’ Korean literacy and cultural knowledge in Social Science and other disciplines, including politics, economy, society, writing in Korean. 402 or consent.

title: Introduction to Traditional Korean Literature
description: Critical readings from earliest times and presentations that emphasize genre, style, and context. 402 or consent.

title: Introduction to Modern Korean Literature
description: Critical Korean-language readings of 20th-century literature that emphasize context and the development of style. Includes an emphasis on writing instruction. 402 or consent.

title: Internship Program
description: Supervised internship with Korean professional hosts on O‘ahu or in Korea. Students will also attend an on-campus preparatory and follow-up language class. A-F only. 486, diagnostic assessment procedures; or consent.
prerequisites: KOR 486, diagnostic assessment procedures; or consent

title: Korean Abroad
description: Supervised internship with Korean professional hosts in Korea. Students also undergo a one-week training module designed to prepare them to maximize the benefits of the overseas internship. Repeatable up to 3 times. CR/ NC only. 495, diagnostic assessment procedures; or consent.
prerequisites: KOR 495, diagnostic assessment procedures; or consent

title: Directed Fourth-Level Reading
description: For those who need special assistance, e.g., in reading texts in area of specialization or at a pace more rapid than those of standard courses. Primarily for graduate students from other departments. CR/NC only. Repeatable three times. consent of department chair.

title: (Alpha) Korean Verse
description: Intensive and analytical reading of selected works of Korean lyric and didactic verse (e.g., hyangga, changga, hanshi, sijo, kasa , free form): (M) modern; (T) traditional. Repeatable one time with instructor consent for (M). 494 or consent for (M), 493 or consent for (T).
prerequisites: KOR 494 or consent for (M), KOR 493 or consent for (T)

title: (Alpha) Korean Narrative
description: Intensive and analytical reading of selected works of Korean narrative (e.g., myth, p’ansori , shaman song, essay, biography, fiction): (M) modern; (T) traditional. Repeatable one time with instructor consent for (M). 494 or consent for (M), 493 or consent for (T).
prerequisites: KOR 494 or consent for (M), KOR 493 or consent for (T)

title: (Alpha) Korean Drama
description: Intensive and analytical reading of selected materials in Korean performing arts (e.g., spectacle, farce play, mask dance, staged narratives, theatrical drama): (M) modern; (T) traditional. 494 or consent for (M), 493 or consent for (T).
prerequisites: KOR 494 or consent for (M), KOR 493 or consent for (T)

title: Media Research in Korean
description: Focuses on searching, analyzing, and evaluating media data for research in areas of student specializations. Students are required to write short analysis papers and a final research paper. diagnostic assessment (equivalent to ILR Level 2) or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: diagnostic assessment (equivalent to ILR Level KOR 2) or consent

title: Comparative Studies of Contemporary South and North Korean Language
description: Comparing and analyzing language data to investigate language heterogeneity problems, its causes, and importance of comparative studies in NK/SK language differences; differences in language policy, grammar, and vocabulary, pronunciation, and discourse style. 621 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Interdisciplinary Research in Korean
description: Combined lecture-discussion on preparing students to be able to conduct interdisciplinary research in Korean. Require advanced-level Korean proficiency. diagnostic assessment (equivalent to ILR Level 2) or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: diagnostic assessment (equivalent to ILR Level KOR 2) or consent

title: (Alpha) Analysis of Korean Academic Discourse
description: Co-taught by Korean faculty of professional schools and Korean instruction in domain of (B) economics; (C) political science; (D) computer science; (E) travel industry management; (G) business; (H) law; (I) medicine; (J) nursing and public health; and (K) others. Exclusively in Korean. Repeatable one time. 485 or 623 or consent. (Once a year)

title: History and Dialects of Korean Language
description: Survey of various hypotheses on the genetic relationship of Korean; evolution of Korean from the 15th century to the present; Korean dialects. 451 and 452, or consent.

title: Korean Phonology and Morphology
description: Review of Korean vocalic and consonantal phonology. Phonological and morphological analysis of Korean derivation and inflection. 451 or consent.

title: Korean Syntax and Semantics
description: Review of theoretical problems in Korean syntax and semantics; different approaches; and contributions of Korean linguistic study to syntactic and semantic theory. 452 or consent.

title: Korean Sociolinguistics
description: Variations in form and use depending on sociocultural factors. Role of language in politics, mass media, group identity, bilingualism, and intercultural communication. 470 or consent.

title: Pedagogy of Teaching Korean as a Second Language
description: Identification and analysis of major problems in Korean language learning, teaching, testing, and materials development by examining theoretical issues and conducting classroom research; practical techniques of teaching and testing skills in listening, reading, speaking, writing and culture. 451 and 452; or consent.

title: Korean Conversation Analysis
description: Theoretical framework of conversation analysis and review of Korean conversational structures, such as turn-taking, sequence organization, and repair organization; training for data collection, transcription, and data analysis. 451 and 452; or consent.

title: Literary Translation of Korean
description: The art and craft of translating traditional and modern Korean literary works into English. Repeatable four times. 493 and 494, or consent.

title: Research in Korean Language Acquisition
description: Integrating the conceptual aspects of statistics and scientific analysis of human language behavior into the study of Korean as a foreign language. 635 or consent.

title: Major Authors in Modern Korean Literature
description: Advanced study of major Korean fiction writers from the 1910s to the present with emphasis on critical reading of their lives and writings to arrive at informed appraisal of their contribution to modern Korean literature. Repeatable one time. 494 or consent.

title: Practicum: Teaching Korean as a Second Language
description: Designed for graduate students pursuing Korean language teaching, while developing practical teaching skills through class observation, action research and discussion under supervision. 635 or consent.

title: Topics and Issues in Modern Korean Literature
description: Intensive study of selected topics and issues in modern/contemporary Korean fiction, focusing on texts that problematize critical sociocultural issues in the evolving contexts of modern Korean intellectual history. Repeatable one time. 494 or consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Research Seminar in Korean Literature
description: Advanced study of an author, school, period, genre, or problem leading to a research paper. Repeatable four times. consent.

title: Research Seminar in Korean Language
description: Advanced study in history and dialects, phonology and morphology, syntax and semantics, sociolinguistics, or pedagogy, leading to a research paper. Repeatable four times. consent.

title: Introduction to Economics
description: One semester survey of the principles of microeconomics and macroeconomics to enable students in all disciplines to understand current economic events.

title: Principles of Microeconomics
description: Examination of the decision-making process of both households and firms. Analysis of the functioning of a competitive market system, using supply and demand models and the role of government in cases where the market system fails. Additional topics include the effects of international rate on the welfare of a nation and the effects of different competitive market structures on society.

title: Principles of Microeconomics
description: Examination of the decision-making process of both households and firms. Analysis of the functioning of a competitive market system, using supply and demand models and the role of government in cases where the market system fails. Additional topics include the effects of international rate on the welfare of a nation and the effects of different competitive market structures on society.

title: Principles of Macroeconomics
description: An introduction to macroeconomics–the study of the overall economy. Topics include the determination of national income, causes and effects of inflation, unemployment, and income inequality; causes and consequences of international differences in economic growth; sources of business cycle expansions and contractions; role of government policy in stabilizing the economy and promoting long-term growth; financial markets and monetary policy; taxes, spending, consequences of budget deficits, determination of trade imbalances, exchange rate fluctuations, and balance of payment crises.

title: Principles of Macroeconomics
description: An introduction to macroeconomics–the study of the overall economy. Topics include the determination of national income, causes and effects of inflation, unemployment, and income inequality; causes and consequences of international differences in economic growth; sources of business cycle expansions and contractions; role of government policy in stabilizing the economy and promoting long-term growth; financial markets and monetary policy; taxes, spending, consequences of budget deficits, determination of trade imbalances, exchange rate fluctuations, and balance of payment crises.

title: Data Analysis and Visualization
description: Develops basic techniques of data analysis and visualization. Introduces sources of economic data; methods of preparing data from various file/data formats for analysis; methods of visualization: bubble plots, scatterplot matrices, heatmaps, hexbins, rug plots, etc. A-F only.

title: Intermediate Macroeconomics
description: Develops basic techniques and fundamental concepts used to study the overall macroeconomy and policies that affect it. Study the determinants of national income and long-run growth; causes and consequences of unemployment, inflation, and business cycle fluctuations; determination of foreign exchange rates and current account imbalances, and the role of government policy in various settings. 131 or consent.

title: Intermediate Microeconomics
description: Develops basic techniques and fundamental concepts of microeconomic theory. Learn to use economic reasoning to understand the social consequences of decisions made by individual consumers, producers, and governments. Analyze the nature of market outcomes under alternative market structures, and further discuss possible welfare-improving government policies when markets fail to be efficient. Special attention is paid to the analysis of strategic behavior and markets with public goods and externalities. 130 or consent.

title: The Economy of Hawai‘i
description: Descriptive understanding of the history of development of Hawai‘i’s economy; current economic problems; future prospects. Emphasizes the written communication of the intuition behind economic concepts in practice in Hawai‘i. 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
prerequisites: ECON 120, ECON 130, or ECON 131; or consent

title: The Japanese Economy
description: Analysis of Japan’s growth past and present. Does Japan’s economy look different in terms of its international trade structure, industrial structure, labor market, savings patterns, government policies, etc.? Does it matter? 120 or 130, or consent.

title: Introduction to Tourism Economics
description: Examines tourism from an economic perspective. Topics include: the determinants of consumer demand for leisure travel, structure of competition among suppliers of tourism services, benefits and costs of tourism development to the host community, government’s role in the taxation, subsidy, regulation and protection of the tourism industry, tourism’s impact on the environment, and sustainable tourism development. 120 or 130 or 131; consent. (
prerequisites: ECON 120 or ECON 130 or ECON 131; consent

title: Introduction to Statistics
description: Basic elements; descriptive statistics, probability, inference, distributions, hypothesis testing, regression, and correlation analysis.

title: Economics of Global Climate Change
description: Nature and causes of global climate change and economic solutions. Topics include valuing climate change impacts, energy solutions, environmental implications, societal adaptation, and international cooperation. A-F only. 120 or 130 or 131, or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: ECON 120 or ECON 130 or ECON 131, or consent

title: Energy Economics and Policy
description: Analysis of economic and policy aspects of energy use, and interactions of markets for various nonrenewable and renewable energy options. Evaluations of policies to develop alternative energy sources. 120 or 130 or 131. (

title: Financial Markets and Institutions
description: The determination of asset prices; the risk and term structure of interest rates; efficient markets hypothesis; risk management and financial derivatives, asymmetric information models of financial market structure, innovation, regulation and deregulation; and financial crises. 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
prerequisites: ECON 120, ECON 130, or ECON 131; or consent

title: Comparative Economic History
description: Comparative historical study of economic ideas and change since around 1700. Considers the histories of capitalism, poverty, industrialization and labor in Europe, Asia, the U.S., and other regions. (

title: The History of Economic Thought
description: Introduces major western economic theorists and ideas since around 1700. Considers the history of views on work, poverty, the market and government, and the relationship of those doctrines to society, philosophy, and public policy. (Alt. years) (

title: Sustainable Development
description: Transdisciplinary introduction to sustainable development. Interactions between environment, economy, and public policy, especially in Hawai‘i. Topics include: curse of paradise, global warming, energy use, health, poverty, population, water resources, traffic congestion, biodiversity, pollution controls. 120 or 130 or 131, or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: ECON 120 or ECON 130 or ECON 131, or consent

title: Network Economics
description: Fundamental questions about the connections in the social, economic, and technological worlds. Topics include: matching markets, traffic, financial and social networks; and the political and economic consequences of the internet and other large networks. 120 or 130 or 131.

title: Games and Economic Behavior
description: Introduces students to the study of strategic behavior with applications to economics, business, and public policy. Simple economic models of strategic decision making are used to analyze provision of public goods; competition, cooperation, and coordination among firms; bargaining between employers and labor unions; international trade negotiations; reputation as a competitive advantage, and others. 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
prerequisites: ECON 120, ECON 130, or ECON 131; or consent

title: Environmental Economics
description: Nature and causes of environmental degradation/economic solutions, with emphasis on relevant ethical issues and decision-making. Topics include air and water pollution, toxic waste, deforestation, soil erosion, biodiversity, global warming, and sustainable development. 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
prerequisites: ECON 120, ECON 130, or ECON 131; or consent

title: Seminar: Women and International Development
description: Women’s role, status, work and treatment in the Third World; economic development, changing work/family roles, and improvement/ deterioration in gender equity across the Third World; global feminization of poverty; efforts to promote gender equity. Open to non-majors. a 100 level economics course or any women’s studies course; or consent. (
prerequisites: a ECON 100 level economics course or any women’s studies course; or consent

title: Trade Policy and Globalization
description: Political economy of the world trading system. Case studies of trade cooperation and conflict under the World Trade Organization and other institutions. Future challenges, including investment policies, environmental and labor standards. 120, 130 or 131; or consent.
prerequisites: ECON 120, ECON 130 or ECON 131; or consent

title: Internship for Economics
description: Economics majors and minors work at paid positions with public agencies, private companies, and campus organizations. Students combine academic work with practical experience. Repeatable two times. consent.

title: Cooperative Education
description: Economics majors and minors, under the supervision of faculty members, work at paid positions with public agencies, private companies, and campus organizations. The Econ Co-op integrates academics with practical work experience. Repeatable two times. consent.

title: Contemporary Topics in Economics
description: Economic analysis of current events. Topics announced each semester. Repeatable unlimited times. 120 or 130 or 131.

title: Directed Reading
description: Economics majors and minors participate in faculty supervised reading of economic literature. Enables students to self-study topics not covered in the department’s scheduled course offerings. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: The Ocean Economy
description: Examination of society’s interaction with the ocean. Topics include: ocean recreation, shipping, boat building, ports, offshore energy production, aquaculture, fishing, coastal construction, and coral reef protection. 120 or 130, or consent. (Once a year) (

title: Economic History of the United States
description: U.S. economy from colonial times: government policies, institutions, industries, financial markets, economic growth, economic crises. 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
prerequisites: ECON 120, ECON 130, or ECON 131; or consent

title: Global Economic Crisis and Recovery
description: Causes and consequences of financial and economic crises: crisis origins and global transmission; macroeconomic and regulatory policy responses; recovery challenges. 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
prerequisites: ECON 120, ECON 130, or ECON 131; or consent

title: Asian Economic Development
description: History and economic development. Resources, population, and income, saving, investment, and consumption patterns. Role of government and private enterprise. 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
prerequisites: ECON 120, ECON 130, or ECON 131; or consent

title: The Chinese Economy
description: The Chinese economy during the imperial and republican periods, under Mao, and into the present reform era, with a brief comparison to Taiwan and Hong Kong. 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
prerequisites: ECON 120, ECON 130, or ECON 131; or consent

title: Pacific Island Economies
description: Historical and current economic development of the Pacific islands (excluding Hawai‘i). Analysis of selected economic issues such as tourism, population growth, etc. 120, 130, or 131; or consent.
prerequisites: ECON 120, ECON 130, or ECON 131; or consent

title: Mathematical Economics
description: Mathematical techniques applied to theories of the consumer, the firm, markets. Linear programming, input-output analysis. 300, 301; MATH 203, MATH 215, MATH 241, or MATH 251A.
prerequisites: ECON 300, ECON 301; MATH 203, MATH 215, MATH 241, or MATH 251A

title: Introduction to Econometrics I: Data Exploration and Regression Analysis
description: Types of data, exploratory data analysis, generalizing from random samples, simple and multivariate regression, non-linear relationships, measurement error, extreme values, weights, correlated and heteroskedastic errors, instrumental variables, models for binary or discrete dependent variables. A-F only. 321 or MATH 241 or BUS 310 or NREM 310 or (MATH 251A and NREM 203) or (MATH 371 and MATH 373) or (MATH 471 and MATH 472); or consent.
prerequisites: ECON 321 or MATH 241 or BUS 310 or NREM 310 or (MATH 251A and NREM 203) or (MATH 371 and MATH 373) or (MATH 471 and MATH 472); or consent

title: Introduction to Econometrics II: Prediction and Causal Inference
description: Prediction types, error measures, training and test data, cross validation, machine learning, regression trees, random forests, boosting, classification, forecasting time series, modelbased versus design-based causality, potential outcomes framework, matching, difference-in-differences, panel data, synthetic controls. A-F only. 425 (with a minimum grade of B- or better).
prerequisites: ECON 425 (with a minimum grade of B- or better)

title: Spreadsheet Modeling for Business and Economic Analysis
description: Introduction to quantitative decision-making methods for effective agribusiness management in resource allocation, scheduling, logistics, risk analysis, inventory, and forecasting. Emphasis on problem identification, model formulation and solution, and interpretation and presentation of results. 130 or NREM/SUST 220, and 321 or NREM 310; or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: ECON 130 or NREM/SUST 220, and NREM 321 or NREM 310; or consent

title: Labor Economics
description: Economic analysis of labor market. Investment in human capital, education, health, migration, etc. 301 or consent.

title: Economics of Population
description: Determinants and consequences of growth and structure of human populations. Relationships between economic factors and fertility, population growth and economic growth. 301 (or concurrent).

title: Health Economics
description: Private and public demand for health, health insurance, and medical care; efficient production and utilization of services; models of hospital and physician behavior; optimal public policy. 301 or consent.

title: Monetary Theory and Policy
