description: Micro-foundations and critical analysis of monetary and macroeconomic theory and policy. Topics include the causes and consequences of inflation, optimal monetary policy and international monetary systems, bank risk and insurance, and national debt and taxation. 300 or 301 or consent.

title: Development Economics
description: Theoretical foundation and empirical evidence for analyzing key issues facing today’s developing world. Topics include characteristics of underdeveloped economies, economic growth, structural change, poverty, inequality, education, population growth, foreign aid and financial sector. 300 or 301, or consent.

title: Economics of Happiness
description: Topics covered include: measuring happiness, what individual and country characteristics contribute to individual well-being, what are the consequences of happiness on behavior, and whether happiness is a cause or an effect. 301, 321, or consent.

title: Public Economics
description: Welfare economics, public expenditure and policy evaluation, public finance by debt and taxes. 301.

title: State and Local Finance
description: Fiscal institutions, operations, and policy questions within state and local governments in U.S. grant programs and other links with central government. 301.

title: Project Evaluation and Resource Management
description: Principles of project evaluation and policy analysis. Shadow pricing, economic cost of taxes and tariffs; public policy for exhaustible, renewable, and environmental resources. 301. (

title: International Trade and Welfare
description: Theory of international specialization and exchange; general equilibrium, tariffs, quotas, common markets. 301.

title: International Macroeconomics
description: The determination of output, price levels, exchange rates and the balance of payments for economies that are integrated with the global economy; theory and application to historical and/or contemporary policy issues. 300.

title: Industrial Organization
description: Theoretical and empirical analysis of contemporary topics in industrial organization. Uses economic theory to analyze important issues facing firms, and examines the practical challenges of empirical applications of theory. 301.

title: Law and Economics
description: Legal issues of property rights, contracts, torts, and crime. Efficiency of U.S. legal process. Economics of law enforcement, juries, prosecutors; evolution of legal rules. 301.

title: Land and Housing Economics
description: Microeconomics explains urban land and housing phenomena, and analyzes selected land and housing issues relevant to Honolulu. 301 or consent.

title: Contemporary Economic Issues
description: Economic analysis of current events. Topics announced each semester, e.g., environmental pollution, crime control, racial discrimination, traffic congestion. 300 or 301 or consent

title: Advanced Directed Research
description: Economics majors and minors conduct research, under faculty supervision, on a topic of their choice. Repeatable one time. A-F only. minimum GPA of 3.0 in economics and consent.

title: Master’s Plan B/C Studies
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Microeconomics for Business and Policy Analysis
description: Theory of the consumer, firm, and market. Perfect competition and efficiency. Market power and firm strategy. Market efficiencies. Role of the government. consent.

title: Macroeconomics for Business and Policy Analysis
description: Topics on production, consumption, labor market, asset market, economic growth, and business cycles are discussed with emphasis on real-economy applications and policy analysis. Implications of monetary, fiscal, and international finance and economic policies are explored. (Spring only)

title: Microeconomic Theory I
description: Theory of the firm: production, costs, duality; theory of the market: competition, monopoly, oligopoly, monopolistic competition; theory of the consumer: preferences, expenditures, duality; expected utility theory.

title: Macroeconomic Theory I
description: Neoclassical theory of real and monetary equilibrium, economics of J. M. Keynes, standard IS/LM models and aggregate demand/supply analysis in the closed and open economy, theory of rational expectations.

title: Microeconomic Theory II
description: General equilibrium analysis: production, consumption and Walrasian equilibria; Pareto efficiency, fundamental theorems of welfare economics; externalities; public goods; game theory; information theory. 606 or consent.

title: Macroeconomic Theory II
description: Models of economic growth and fluctuations; stochastic and dynamic macroeconomic models; econometric testing of rational expectations models; theory of public debt; current topics in macroeconomic theory. 607 or consent.

title: Economic Development
description: Nature and causes of economic growth and structural change. Roles of macroeconomic policy and foreign trade. 606 and 607, or consent.

title: Economic Development Policy
description: Analysis of policies for the promotion of industrial and agricultural development. Project evaluation, industrial regulation, public administration, investment and capital market policies, land-use policies, trade policies, pricing, and stabilization. 604 or 606; or consent.

title: Economic Development of Japan
description: Analysis of growth from Meiji period to present. Problems of population change, capital formation, income distribution, industrial structure. 610 or consent.

title: Microeconomic Theory III
description: Game theory and strategic behavior. Economics of information and incentives principal-agent theory. Economic design. Applications include: theory of contracts; incentive compatible mechanism for provision of public goods; auction theory. 608 or consent.

title: Macroeconomic Theory III
description: Will equip students with the ability to understand, undertake, and critically evaluate theoretical and quantitative research in modern macroeconomics with a focus on the application of the search and matching methodology. 607 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Mathematics for Economics
description: Sets, functions, limits, convexity, continuity; constrained and unconstrained optimization; difference and differential equations; matrix algebra; simultaneous equations; comparative statics; Kuhn-Tucker theory; game theory; mathematical programming.

title: Econometrics I
description: Review of probability, estimation, small sample and asymptotic properties. Bivariate and multiple regression and matrix algebra formulation. Regression diagnostics. Introduction to heteroskedastidity, autocorrelation, simultaneity, dichotomous variables, advanced topics.

title: Econometrics II
description: Specification, statistical estimation, inference and forecasting of econometric models. Includes advanced topics for single-equation models, pooled models, qualitative dependent variables, simultaneous systems, distributed lags, and time series. 628, AREC 626, or consent. (

title: Econometrics III
description: Will equip students with the ability to undertake, understand, and critically assess empirical research using state-of-the-at econometric methods. 628 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Disasters and Economic Policy
description: Economic analysis of disasters. The economics of prevention and mitigation, as well as post-disaster economic consequences and policy, will be examined. Graduate students only.

title: Renewable Energy Economics and Policy
description: Analysis of economic and policy aspects of renewable energy use, and interactions of markets for renewable energy and other energy options. Evaluations of policies to develop renewable energy options. college calculus and principles of microeconomics; or consent. (
prerequisites: college calculus and principles of microeconomics; or consent

title: Resource Economics
description: Analysis of problems of development and management of natural resources with emphasis on resources in agriculture and role in economic development. 608 and 629. (

title: Environmental Resource Economics
description: Principles of policy design and evaluation for environmental resources management, forestry and watershed conservation, and sustainable economic development. 604 or 606; or consent. (

title: Marine Resource Economics
description: Seminar on the economics of the marine environment. Topics include fisheries management, ocean recreation, shipping, and coral reef protection. 606 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Foundations of Public Policy
description: Microeconomic principles for expenditure and tax policies. Externalities, public goods, non-convexities, regulation; cost-benefit analysis, general equilibrium, shadow-pricing; rent-seeking, corruption; optimal taxation, incidence, excess burden; dynamic public finance, national debt, social security. 604 or 606; or consent.

title: Public Economics
description: Theoretical and empirical analysis of public-sector allocation. Adverse selection, moral hazard, networks, auctions, public choice and political mechanisms; tax and mandate incidence; economics of education and local public goods; social insurance programs. 606 or consent.

title: International Trade and Welfare
description: Classical and new theories of international trade: why nations trade, gains from trade, patterns of trade, and trade policy effects under perfect and imperfect competition. Empirical trade and other special topics. 606 or consent.

title: Advanced International Trade and Investment
description: Surveys theoretical and empirical research on topics such as regionalism and multilateralism, trade and wages, foreign direct investment and multinational firms, trade and the environment, and trade and economic growth. Repeatable unlimited times. 660 or consent.

title: International Macroeconomics
description: Advanced international monetary and macroeconomic theory: balance of payments, output, price and exchange rate determination, international aspects of growth and economic fluctuations, alternative exchange rate regimes, international capital flows. 607 or consent.

title: Applied International Finance
description: Surveys empirical research in international macroeconomics, finance and econometric methods: including balance of payments adjustment, international equilibrium, international prices, interest rates and exchange rates, models of exchange rate determination, capital flows, balance of payments crises. 607 and 629 (or concurrent), or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: ECON 607 and ECON 629 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Labor Economics and Policy
description: Supply of and demand for labor; implications for labor markets and unemployment level. 606 or consent.

title: Economics of Population
description: Economic determinants and consequences of population change. consent.

title: Health Economics and Policy
description: Economic analysis of health-care policy; efficient design of health-care financing schemes; private and public demand for health, health insurance, and medical care; provider behavior. 604 (or concurrent) or 606 (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: ECON 604 (or concurrent) or ECON 606 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Strategic Behavior and Experimental Economics
description: Experimental economics: methodology. Experimental game theory. Market experiments. Applications include: topics in industrial organization, provision of public goods, asset markets, auctions. Repeatable one time. 606 and 608, or consent.

title: Advanced Topics in Economics
description: Reflects interests of visiting and permanent faculty, focusing on specialized methods or topics in economics. Repeatable unlimited times. 606 or 607, or consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent of department chair

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Research Seminar
description: Selected issues emphasizing research techniques. Required for students who have passed the two theory qualifying exams and have not passed the comprehensive exam. CR/NC only. consent.

title: MA Capstone Research
description: Student applies theoretical and quantitative techniques, critical thinking, and communicative skills to prepare a written and oral presentation of original research on a topic of his or her choice. A-F only. 606, 607, 627, 628, and consent of graduate chair.
prerequisites: ECON 606, ECON 607, ECON 627, ECON 628, and consent of graduate chair

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Action Research in Education
description: Theory and practice in collaborative action research; critical inquiry into current educational work in schools with goals of improvement of teaching and participation in school and curriculum reform.

title: Professional Doctorate Practicum: Consultancy Project
description: Practicum in the EdD program in professional practice; involves a group consultancy project requiring independent research and reflective activity embedded in a group project dealing with a problem of practice. Repeatable three times. Restricted to students in the Doctoral Degree in Professional Educational Practice. A-F only. other approval.

title: Professional Doctorate Practicum: Individual Applied Research Project
description: Practicum in conducting individual practitioner research within the EdD. Includes the formulation of individual applied research project, developing a plan of action, selection of appropriate methods, implementation of plan and composition of practitioner research report. Repeatable three times. Restricted to students in the Doctoral Degree in Professional Educational Practice. A-F only.

title: EdD Conference
description: Capstone for the Doctoral Degree in Professional Education Practice. Involves a conference presentation of research project results to an audience of faculty, fellow graduate students, and interested members of the public. Restricted to students in the Doctoral Degree in Professional Educational Practice. CR/NC only. other approval.

title: Field Project
description: Practicum experience in area of specialization. Variable credit: minimum of 3 credit hours, maximum of 6 credit hours. Repeatable two times. A-F only. consent.

title: Internship in College Teaching
description: Introduction to college-level teaching; doctoral students serve as apprentices to professors; responsibilities include supervised teaching, planning and evaluation. Repeatable up to six credits. CR/NC only. admission to PhD candidacy and consent.
prerequisites: admission to PhD candidacy and consent

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation.

title: Dynamics of Student Leadership
description: Theoretical approaches and an experimental orientation toward leadership in student organizations via classroom activities and practicum experiences with student organizations.

title: Peer Leadership Education and Mentoring
description: Theoretical explorations and a supervised practicum experience in student peer leadership education and mentoring in a variety of curricular and co-curricular contexts. 360 (or equivalent) and consent.

title: (Alpha)Topics in Emergent Paradigms of Leadership
description: Exploration, application, analysis and synthesis of advanced leadership concepts including emergent theories, issues, trends and empowering approaches. (B) survey of emergent paradigms; (C) Asian Pacific American leadership; (D) gender and leadership; (E) ethics and leadership; (K) issues and problems in leadership. Repeatable one time per alpha. 360 (or equivalent) and consent.

title: Directed Reading
description: Planned individualized study, reading, research, teaching, and/ or projects under direct supervision of instructor. A-F only. Repeatable up to six credits. consent.

title: Introduction to Education Administration
description: Develops view of administrative process and organization elements in context of system of personal, social, and physical variables. Emphasis on role and functions of school administrator. Repeatable one time.

title: Research in Education Administration
description: Develops basic concepts of research on educational administration: methodology, status of particular topics, communication, and application of findings to problems of school administration. (Meets PhD common core inquiry methods requirement.) Repeatable one time.

title: Qualitative Research Methods in Education
description: Introduction to methods of qualitative research in education. (Meets PhD common core requirement.) (

title: Survey Research Design and Analysis
description: Survey study designs, survey sampling, questionnaire construction, interviewing, -tests, pilot studies, logic of measurement and association, table construction, and elaboration models. consent. (
prerequisites: -tests, pilot studies, logic of measurement and association, table construction, and elaboration models

title: School-Community Relations
description: Application of principles, techniques, policies, organization of school-community information program. Repeatable one time.

title: (Alpha) Education Finance
description: Educational revenues, apportionments, budgetary procedures, costs, business management, economics of education, measures of productivity. (H) higher education: specific for higher education students; (K) K-12: specific for K-12 students. A-F only. consent.

title: Administration in Kinesiology
description: Current problems, trends, and strategies in the administration of athletic training, physical education, recreation, sport and fitness programs in school and non-school settings. Repeatable one time. consent. (

title: Educational Statistics
description: Statistical inference including applications of parametric and nonparametric methods to educational problems.

title: (Alpha) Education Law
description: Status and functions of educational institutions and personnel relative to their legal rights and responsibilities. Includes interpretation of important court decisions, statutes, equity measures. (H) higher education: specific for higher education students; (K) K-12: specific for K-12 students. A-F only. consent.

title: Principles of School Leadership
description: Examine the emergent theories, issues, practices, and problems relevant for educational leaders in school organizations. Integrates the aspects of management and administration within the context of leadership.

title: College Student Development Theory
description: Study of psycho-social characteristics of the American college student and college environment, from viewpoint of student personnel work. Repeatable one time. EDEA majors only.

title: Organizational Leadership in Education
description: Analysis of the nature of organizations, human nature and needs, and their relationship to leadership, staffing, and staff development. Implications of group structure and human conflict, communications, and supervision and evaluation considered. Repeatable one time.

title: Conflict Management for Educators
description: Conflict resolution theory and practice for administrators, faculty and staff in educational organizations. K-12, community colleges and universities. Application and theory of negotiation, mediation, facilitation and hybrid ADR processes. Repeatable one time. 601 or 650, or consent. (

title: Intercultural Interactions
description: Theory-based frameworks and training methods of intercultural interaction and their applications to educational administration situations. Repeatable one time.

title: Introduction to Higher Education
description: Salient historic, social, and organizational aspects of higher education; history, philosophy, purposes, governance, administration, structures, financing, faculty and student selection, curricula, legal and social issues. Repeatable one time.

title: Leadership in Higher Education
description: Trends, research, and problems in college and university management. Repeatable one time. EDEA majors only. 657 or consent.

title: Leadership in Student Affairs
description: Philosophy, history, organization, and administration of student personnel services at college and university levels, including admissions, housing, student activities, financial aids, placement, counseling, health services. Repeatable one time. 657 or consent.

title: Curriculum in Higher Education
description: Traditional and contemporary curriculum issues. Development of performance competencies in curriculum design and evaluation using systems and design theory as central paradigms. Repeatable one time. 657 or consent.

title: Community College Leadership
description: Development and changing missions of community colleges; in-depth study of emerging leadership issues: planning, financial management, decision-making, governance, and student personnel. Repeatable one time. 660 or consent.

title: Teacher Development and Evaluation
description: The role of teacher evaluation in the development of teachers and learning communities and to support effective teaching. Repeatable one time.

title: Introduction to Educational Policy Studies
description: Examines theories and models of educational policy and policy-making and the contribution of policy analysis to the policy-making and change processes. A-F only. consent. (

title: The Politics of Education
description: Examination of the ways in which education can be viewed as political, arising from its connection to the larger political system including local, state, and federal governments. A-F only. 675, EDEF 675; or consent. (

title: Curriculum Administration
description: Master’s level course in curriculum administration and leadership, focusing on fundamental theories underlying curriculum development, as well as the implementation of curriculum policy at the school level. consent.

title: Capstone Project in Educational Administration
description: Required for higher education Plan B option. 3 credits required for program completion. Taken in final semester or second to last semester in program. A-F only. 602 and 657, and consent of instructor and chair.
prerequisites: EDEA 602 and EDEA 657, and consent of instructor and chair

title: Directed Reading and/or Research
description: Individual reading and/or research. Repeatable unlimited times. consent of instructor and department chair.
prerequisites: consent of instructor and department chair

title: Thesis Research
description: Research master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Advanced Qualitative Research
description: Study in trends, research, and problems. 604 or comparable, or consent.

title: Internship in Education
description: Supervised intern experience in school and university administration. Emphasizes the development of leadership skills through program and project management. A-F only. approval of cooperating agencies and department.
prerequisites: approval of cooperating agencies and department

title: Creative Learning Strategies for Adults
description: Analysis of psychology of adult learner; forces that affect learning in dynamics of individual, group, and organizational behavior; concept of lifelong learning vis-a-vis development of creative strategies that assist maturing, self-directed persons to develop their potentialities. (

title: Seminar on the Educational System
description: Examination of structure and dynamics of the educational system. Particular focus on how educational policy interacts with principles that explain educational system behavior. A-F only. 675 or EDEF 675, or consent. (

title: Seminar on the Principalship
description: Series of planned seminar experiences on problems and issues confronting school principals, such as contract administration, program planning and budgeting systems (PPBS), teacher evaluation. Topic to be announced. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: (Alpha) Seminar
description: Study in trends, research, and problems. (B) policy formulation; (C) organizational change; (D) evaluation and research management (meets PhD common required advanced methodology course); (G) school governance; (H) college student affairs administration; (I) higher education administration; (J) administrative theories; (K) administrative problems and issues; (M) engaging diverse student populations; (N) exploring Indigeneity in higher education. (K) is repeatable two times in different topics. EDEA majors only for (I) and (K). A-F only for (M). consent.

title: Education in American Society
description: Interrelated historical, philosophical, and sociocultural contexts of education with an emphasis on identifying, analyzing, and deliberating on contemporary ethical issues, problems, and applications. Students enrolled in colleges other than the College of Education are asked to confer with the College of Education director of student services before enrolling in 310. A-F only.

title: The History of Education in Hawai‘i From Pre-contact to Statehood
description: History of educational though and practices from -contact Hawaii through statehood. Social, intellectual, political, and cultural influences on indigenous, territorial, and state educational institutions; emphasis on white-settler colonialism, multiculturalism, assimilation, resistance, indigenous, and immigrant experiences. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Spring only.

title: The History of Education in Hawai‘i From Pre-contact to Statehood
description: History of educational though and practices from -contact Hawaii through statehood. Social, intellectual, political, and cultural influences on indigenous, territorial, and state educational institutions; emphasis on white-settler colonialism, multiculturalism, assimilation, resistance, indigenous, and immigrant experiences. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Spring only

title: Introduction to Multicultural Education
description: Concepts and methods to develop sensitivity and awareness of cultural influences on behavior as these relate to the schooling process. A-F only.

title: Directed Reading
description: Individual reading or research. senior majors with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or a minimum GPA of 3.0 in education, and consent of instructor and department chair.
prerequisites: senior majors with a minimum cumulative GPA of EDEF 2

title: Community and Culture
description: Theoretical and practical approaches to understanding the constitution of community life. A focus on the social construction of normative values, social dynamics of organizations, and school-community relations. A-F only.

title: Sociology of Education
description: Introduction to sociological frameworks of analysis of the institutional, cultural and social dynamics of schooling, classroom management, school reform, social group and individual role behavior. A-F only.

title: Gender Issues in Education
description: Examines historical and current gender issues in education as they intersect with ethnicity and class. We pay close attention to the writing process and the skills needed to compose a well-written research paper. WGSS 151 or consent. (

title: Ethnic Groups and Education in Hawai‘i
description: Identity and learning within and among Hawai‘i ethnic groups; study of prejudice and inter-ethnic hostilities as these impact education and teaching. College of Education majors only. A-F only. consent.

title: Anthropological Applications
description: Education as cultural and cross-cultural learning; universal aspects of the process. Ethnographic study. Applied anthropological theory and practice for educators. A-F only.

title: Foundations of Educational Theory
description: An in-depth review of social, philosophical, and historical views underlying various theories of education and their applications in teaching and learning. A-F only.

title: Cultural Diversity and Education
description: Examines issues, theories, perspectives and practices in multicultural education and promotes awareness, encourages knowledgeable reflection and develops skills necessary for multicultural practitioners. A-F only. (

title: Field Studies in Educational Foundations
description: Field-based participant research projects, including analysis of educational problems and issues. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only.

title: Education in the Classical Tradition
description: Classical European, Chinese, Indic, and Islamic traditions in the history of education; emphasis on ways in which they shift, interact, and collide from the early modern period to the present.

title: History of Education in America
description: History of educational thought and practice from European colonialism to revolutionary nationalism to the present. A-F only.

title: History of Education in Hawai‘i
description: From -contact, ancient Hawai‘i to the present. Social and intellectual influences on the development of national, local, and indigenous educational institutions; emphasis on multicultural as well as monocultural directions in Hawai‘i’s schools. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Higher Education
description: Salient historic, social, and organizational aspects of higher education; history, philosophy, purposes, governance, administration, structures, financing, faculty and student selection, curricula, legal and social issues.

title: Philosophy of Education
description: Readings of the original texts of major philosophers impacting American education. Considerations about the conditions of knowing and their extension in everyday practices in education. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Educational Foundations-Selected Topics
description: Multi-disciplinary (historical, philosophical, social/cultural and comparative/international focus on topical issues in education. (B) general; (C) leadership and governance in education; (D) educational reform; (E) foundations of teaching; (F) foundations of curriculum; (G) globalization in education; (H) moral political education. Repeatable one time for (H). A-F only for (H). graduate standing and departmental approval.

title: Introduction to Comparative/ International Education
description: Introduction to basic methods of comparative studies, focusing on schooling, but also treating broader educational issues. A-F only.

title: Topics in Comparative Education
description: Educational institutions, structures, processes, policies, and problems viewed within the context of political, social, and cultural milieus. Geographic region or theme focus. Repeatable three times. A-F only. consent.

title: Introduction to Educational Policy Studies
description: Examines theories and models of educational policy and policy-making and the contribution of policy analysis to the policy-making and change processes. A-F only. consent.

title: The Politics of Education
description: Examination of the ways in which education can be viewed as political, arising from its connection to the larger political system including local, state, and federal governments. A-F only. 675, EDEA 675, or consent. (

title: Approaches to Educational Inquiry
description: Overview of different research methods in educational inquiry with an opportunity to explore through practice one or more methods (ex: case study, interviewing, narrative construction, practitioner inquiry. Preparation for MEd or PhD proposals.

title: Seminar on Race, Law, and Education
description: Introduction to educational law and the way it relates to issues of race and ethnicity. Particular focus on how the U.S. courts have dealt with the question of educational inequality in a multiracial/multiethnic society. A-F only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Social and Cultural Contexts of Education
description: Focuses on the interplay of class, race, gender and ethnicity in school and community settings. Social praxis, educational reform and policy are considered. A-F only.

title: Education and World Order
description: Focuses on the challenges educators face in identifying appropriate pedagogical frameworks and practices in global education that address the impact of globalization in our society today. A-F only. consent.

title: International Development Education
description: Introduction to international development education in Asian and Pacific nations. Students explore links between education and development. Emphasis is on cross-cultural perception of development.

title: Environmental Education
description: Focuses on the development of an ecological consciousness through a cultural and environmental approach to teaching and learning in schooling and everyday life.

title: Directed Reading and/or Research
description: Individual reading and/or research. Repeatable unlimited times. consent of department chair.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Education and Social Change
description: Study of classical and contemporary theories of social change as these relate to school, the profession of teaching, planning of change, and social stability. consent

title: Recent History of American Education
description: Contemporary American education in recent historical perspective; focuses on the educational changes brought about by WW II, the Cold War, civil rights and other social movements. A-F only. consent.

title: History of American Higher Education
description: Genesis and evolution of college and university from

title: Seminar on the Social and Cultural Contexts of Education
description: Examination of social, political, and cultural issues affecting educational policy with special emphasis on methods of inquiry and theoretical constructs. A-F only. consent.

title: Advanced Seminar in Philosophy of Education
description: Advanced studies in philosophical inquiry. Examination of philosophically based methods of analysis and interpretation and their influence in educational research and practice. A-F only. consent.

title: Seminar in History of Education
description: Aspects of the history of education. Application of historiography to educational problems and policy. Repeatable with different content. A-F only. 651 or 652, or consent.

title: Seminar on the Educational System
description: Examination of the structure and dynamics of educational system. Particular focus on how educational policy interacts with principles that explain educational system behavior. A-F only. 675 or EDEA 675, or consent. (

title: Seminar in Comparative/International Education
description: Advanced reading, research and writing in selected topics dealing with comparative and international education, including such themes as policy studies, minority education and educational reform. A-F only. consent.

title: Introduction to Teaching as a Career
description: An experience-based introduction to teaching as a career. Repeatable one time.

title: Introduction to Educational Psychology
description: Psychology applied to education, including cognitive, sociocultural, and multicultural approaches to teaching, learning, development, and research. Develops knowledge and written communication skills through an introduction to classroom, assessment, instruction, motivation, classroom management, and standardized testing. (

title: Self-Regulated Learning
description: Theory and use of self-regulated learning strategies in academic contexts.

title: Directed Reading
description: Individual reading or research. consent.

title: Fundamentals of Research in Education
description: Introduction to the methodology of systematic study of problems in education: principles of research design, data processing, technical writing, and evaluation of research proposals and reports.

title: Seminar in Contemporary Perspectives in Educational Psychology
description: In-depth analysis of contemporary issues in education from the theoretical and methodological perspectives of the faculty in educational psychology. Focuses on oral communication and intensive writing skills. Repeatable one time.

title: Student Assessment
description: Introduction to basic concepts and issues in assessment and measurement, development of formative and summative assessment procedures, descriptive statistics, scales of measurement, and standardizing testing.

title: Introductory Statistics
description: Introduction to concepts and logics of statistical reasoning and statistical literacy. Topics include descriptive statistics, sampling distribution, and inferential statistics such as z-test, t-tests, correlation, and one-way ANOVA.

title: Human Motivation and Education
description: Application of motivation theory and research to understanding and increasing human motivation for education.

title: Applied Psychology: Advanced Topics
description: Coverage in-depth of some areas of theory and research. Repeatable to six credit hours. PSY 100.

title: Introduction to Quantitative Methods
description: Introductory graduate-level statistics in education and social sciences. Topics on descriptive and inferential statistics including central tendency, variability, sampling distribution, z-test, t-test, correlation, simple linear regression, and one-way ANOVA. (Meets PhD common inquiry methods requirement or elective.)

title: Survey Research Design and Analysis
description: Survey study designs, survey sampling, questionnaire construction, interviewing, -tests, pilot studies, logic of measurement and association, table construction, and elaboration models. consent. (
prerequisites: -tests, pilot studies, logic of measurement and association, table construction, and elaboration models

title: Design and Analysis of Psychological Experiments
description: Analysis of variance and other models of assessing results of experiments. Relation of analysis to design.

title: Applied Regression and Analysis of Variance
description: Introduction to linear statistical models as principle of data analysis. Topics include multiple regression models with continuous and categorical predictors. ANOVA with multiple factors, ANOVA with repeated measures, and ANCOVA. 601 or EDEA 629 (with a grade of B+), or consent.
prerequisites: EDEP 601 or EDEA 629 (with a grade of B+), or consent

title: Multivariate Methods
description: Builds on prior knowledge of multiple regression and will include applications of MANOVA, canonical correlation, logistic regression, discriminant function analysis, cluster analysis, multidimensional scaling, and mixture models. 604 or PSY 610, or consent.

title: Nonparametric Methods for Behavioral Science
description: Conditions for valid applications of nonparametric statistical techniques in education and behavioral sciences; theoretical and methodological perspectives.

title: Introduction to Educational Research
description: Fundamental design and evaluation procedures in educational research. Topics include an introduction to qualitative and quantitative research, the review of literature, developing research questions, research design, instrumentation, data collection, and writing a research proposal. 601 (or concurrent) (with a minimum grade of B or higher) or consent.
prerequisites: EDEP 601 (or concurrent) (with a minimum grade of B or higher) or consent

title: Graduate Introduction to Educational Psychology
description: Graduate level introduction to educational psychology theories, research, and topics.

title: Multilevel Modeling for Cross-Sectional and Longitudinal Data
description: Theories and applications of multilevel model to analyze cross-sectional and longitudinal data. Topics include two-level and three-level models, growth models, and multilevel logistic regression. 604, PSY 610, 612 (with a minimum grade of B or higher), or consent.
prerequisites: EDEP 604, PSY 610, PSY 612 (with a minimum grade of B or higher), or consent

title: Qualitative Research Methods in Education
description: Introduction to methods of qualitative research in education. (Meets PhD common core requirement.) (

title: Measurement in Education and Social Sciences
description: Measurement and psychometric theories and applications using psychometric programs. Topics include classical test theory, reliability, validity, exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis, item bias, and item response theory. 604 or consent.

title: Categorical Data Analysis
description: Theories and methods for data analysis with categorical and discrete variables; analysis of contingency tables, loglinear models, introduction to generalized linear models for binary, nominal, ordinal, and count outcomes in cross-sectional and longitudinal data sets. 604, PSY 610, or consent.

title: Structural Equation Modeling
description: Theories and applications to test models with manifest and latent variables. Topics include path analysis, factor analysis, latent variable model, multi-group analysis, latent means model, and other advanced topics in SEM. 606, PSY 610, PSY 614, or consent.

title: Psychometric Methods
description: Theories and applications of modern psychometrics. Topics include item response theory, detecting biased items, measurement invariance, and current issues in psychometrics. 604 (with a minimum grade of B+) or consent.
prerequisites: EDEP 604 (with a minimum grade of B+) or consent

title: Adolescence and Education
description: Discussion-based course presenting an overview of educational psychology applied to teaching adolescents, including theory and research on human learning, adolescent development and its social context, and student assessment.

title: Introduction to Program Evaluation
description: Introduction to concepts and issues related to program evaluation. Topics include preparing for an evaluation, formative and summative uses, and qualitative and quantitative design approaches. A-F only. 608 (or equivalent).

title: Development and Learning
description: Theories and research on learning and development and their educational applications. Analysis of how learning and development are interrelated.

title: Social Context of Learning
description: Analysis of the social context in the learning process and education, including peer, family, community, and cultural influences.

title: Models of Cognitive Learning
description: Cognitive models of knowledge acquisition, organization, and utilization; theory and research relating learning and cognition to interactive instructional models.

title: Instructional Psychology
description: Application of learning theory and cognitive skills training in instructional settings.

title: Social Cognition and Competence
description: Systematic analysis of social reasoning abilities conjunctive with or to effective social interaction in educational settings.
prerequisites: to effective social interaction in educational settings

title: Capstone Project in Educational Psychology
description: To be taken in the final semester or the second to last semester to complete the certificate. Students are expected to integrate, extend, critique and apply knowledge learned in the certificate program. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits.

title: Directed Reading and/or Research
description: Individual reading and/or research. Repeatable ten times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable seven times.

title: Educational Research Methods
description: Research techniques and thesis development.

title: Practicum in Educational Psychology
description: Supervised practicum in teaching or program evaluation as each is reflected by professional activities of the members of the faculty. Repeatable six times. consent of supervisory professor.

title: Creative Learning Strategies for Adults
description: Analysis of psychology of adult learner; forces that affect learning in dynamics of individual, group, and organizational behavior; concept of lifelong learning vis-à-vis development of creative strategies that assist maturing, self-directed persons to develop their potentialities. (

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Educational Psychology
description: Current issues and problems in the context of education: (B) general; (C) learning; (D) measurement; (E) statistics; (F) psycho-social development; (G) educational evaluation; (H) research methodology. Repeatable nine times. consent. Seminar may be repeated for credit as topics vary.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Electrical Engineering Skills
description: Electrical engineering subjects in a skill acquisition context at the freshman level. Learning, creative problem solving, brainstorming, technical information assimilation, and presentation skills development. Repeatable two times. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Engineering Computation
description: Engineering problem solving using MATLAB. Basic programming concepts include input/output, branching, looping, functions, file input/output, and data structures such as arrays and structures. Matrix operations for solving linear equations. Engineering computations and visualization. ECE and CENG majors only. A-F only. MATH 241 (or concurrent) or MATH 251A (or concurrent) or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 241 (or concurrent) or MATH 251A (or concurrent) or consent

title: Programming for Engineers
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to computer programming and modern computing environments with an emphasis on algorithm and program design, implementation, and debugging. Includes a hands-on laboratory to develop and practice programming skills. BENG, CE, CENG, ECE, ME, PREN, CNST, and ENGS majors only. A-F only. MATH 241 (or concurrent) or MATH 251A (or concurrent) or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 241 (or concurrent) or MATH 251A (or concurrent) or consent

title: Freshman Project
description: Freshman level individual or team project under ECE faculty direction and guidance. This project provides early student entry into ECE hands-on project activity providing practical skills, ECE subject exposure and experience. Second semester freshman standing required. Repeatable unlimited times. CENG, ECE, and PREN majors only. A-F only. consent.

title: Object Oriented Programming
description: Second programming for computer engineers. System programming language, such as C. Object-oriented programming paradigm, definition and use of classes, fundamentals of object-oriented design, such as C++. Common data structures. Common searching and sorting algorithms. CEE, ECE, ME, PREN majors only. A-F only. 160 or consent.

title: Basic Circuit Analysis I
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Linear passive circuits, time domain analysis, transient and steady-state responses, phasors, impedance and admittance; power and energy, frequency responses, resonance. BENG, CE, CENG, ECE, ME, PREN, and ENGS majors only. A-F only. MATH 243 (or concurrent) or MATH 253 (or concurrent), and PHYS 272 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 243 (or concurrent) or MATH 253 (or concurrent), and PHYS 272 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Basic Circuit Analysis II
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Laplace transforms and their application to circuits, Fourier transforms and their applications to circuits, frequency selective circuits, introduction to and design of active filters, convolution, and state space analysis of circuits. A-F only. 211, and MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: ECE 211, and MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent); or consent

title: Introduction to Digital Design
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to the design of digital systems with an emphasis on design methods and the implementation and use of fundamental digital components. 160 or 110 or ICS 111 or consent.
prerequisites: ECE 160 or ECE 110 or ICS 111 or consent

title: Sophomore Project
description: Sophomore level individual or team project under ECE faculty direction and guidance. The project provides design experience and develops practical skills. Repeatable unlimited times. CENG, ECE, and PREN majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. (

title: Signal and Systems Analysis
description: Discrete-time and continuous time signals and systems, linear systems, convolution, Fourier series, Fourier transform, sampling. 213 and either MATH 244 or MATH 253A; or consent.
prerequisites: ECE 213 and either MATH 244 or MATH 253A; or consent

title: Microelectronic Circuits I
description: Semiconductor structures, operating principles and characteristics of diodes and amplifying devices. Their application as circuit elements in building basic digital, analog, and integrated circuit subsystems. 213.

title: Microelectronic Circuits I Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Experiments on linear and logic properties of diodes and transistor networks. 213. Co-requisite: 323.

title: Physical Electronics
description: Review of quantum mechanics fundamentals, H-atom, and chemical bonding. Introduction to band structure models and materials. Semiconductor doping, charge carrier statistics and charge transport, including ambipolar transport. Metal-semiconductor and PN junctions. MATH 243 or MATH 253A, and PHYS 274; or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 243 or MATH 253A, and PHYS 274; or consent

title: Microelectronic Circuits II
description: Principles and design of linear electronic circuits including differential, operational, feedback, and tuned amplifiers; integrated circuits, current mirrors, signal generators, filters, and stability. 323.

title: Microelectronic Circuits II Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory for 326, experiments on linear and analog electronics. Includes an emphasis on writing laboratory reports. 323L. Co-requisite: 326.

title: Theory and Design of IC Devices
description: Band structure models and carrier transport physics review. Theory and design of semiconductor IC devices: Schottky diodes, bipolar devices (PN junction diodes, BJTs), FETs (MOSFETs, JFETs, and MESFETs). 324 and either MATH 243 or MATH 253A; or consent.
prerequisites: ECE 324 and either MATH 243 or MATH 253A; or consent

title: Microcircuit Fabrication
description: Technology principles, materials, and methods for the design and fabrication of semiconductor devices, integrated circuits, and microelectromechanical systems. 327 or consent. Co-requisite: 328L.

title: Microcircuit Fabrication Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Hands-on laboratory where students make various electronic and electromechanical micro-devices using IC technology. Devices are also tested and analyzed. 324 or consent. Co-requisite: 328.

title: Probability and Statistics
description: Probability, statistics, random variables, distributions, densities, expectations, limit theorems, and applications to electrical engineering. 315 (or concurrent) and either MATH 244 or MATH 253A; or consent.
prerequisites: ECE 315 (or concurrent) and either MATH 244 or MATH 253A; or consent

title: Introduction to Communication Systems
description: Signal representation, Fourier analysis; amplitude and angle modulated systems; sampling theorems, pulse and digital modulation systems; carrier modulation by digital signals. 342 (or concurrent) and 315.

title: Communication Systems Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Experiments illustrating the basic principles of communication systems. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing laboratory reports. 315. Co-requisite: 343.

title: Networking I
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Covers 4 semesters from the Cisco Networking Academy plus supplementary material; hands-on experience with routers and switches; prepares students for the CCNA. Topics include TCP/IP, LANs, WANs, routing protocols, network security; PPP; ISDN, frame relay. A-F only. 160 or consent.

title: Linear Algebra and Machine Learning
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Mathematical and algorithmic fundamentals of linear algebra and their applications and illustrations to machine learning. Lab introduces programming with data and uses machine learning libraries for an introduction to commonly used technologies. MATH, ECE, CENG, CECE, ME, ICS majors only. A-F only. MATH 242 or MATH 252A or consent.

title: Linear Feedback-Control Systems
description: Analysis/design of feedback systems. Compensator design via root locus and Bode analysis. Routh/Nyquist stability. State space representation and introduction to MIMO formulation. Controllability/observability. Application to physical dynamic systems such as industrial robots. 315 or ME 375 or consent.

title: Linear Feedback-Control Systems Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Provides experience in applying theoretical tools to analyze linear systems. Extensive use is made of computer-aided analysis and design packages study system performance. 315. Co-requisite: 351.

title: Digital Systems and Computer Design
description: Design methodology, processor design, control design, memory organization, system organization. 205 and 260, or consent.

title: Digital Systems and Computer Design Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory for 361, experiments on digital systems and interfacing. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing laboratory reports. Co-requisite: 361.

title: Discrete Math for Engineers
description: Logic, sets, number theory, properties of functions, properties of relations, methods of proofs, recursion, counting, probability, trees, graphs, analysis of algorithms, finite state autonoma. 160 and 260 and MATH 242.

title: CMOS VLSI Design
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to the design of very large scale integrated (VLSI) systems and use of CAD tools and design languages. Lab includes hands-on use of CAD tools and experiments with field programmable logic devices. 260.

title: Computer Data Structures and Algorithms
description: Design and analysis of data structures and algorithms, including correctness and performance. Topics include time complexity, hash tables, sorting, search trees, self-balancing trees, greedy algorithms, dynamic programming, and graph algorithms. (205 or ICS 212) and (362 or ICS 241).

title: Computer Data Structures and Algorithms Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory for 367. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing laboratory reports. 367 (or concurrent).

title: Cyber-Physical Systems and the Internet of Things
description: Topics include General Purpose Input/Output (GPIO), serial communications, sensors, actuators, low-power wireless communications. TCP/IP networking, dynamic service discovery, distributed network messaging, machine-to-machine communication and cloud-computing interaction. A-F only. Engineering majors only. 205.

title: Computational Media Systems
description: Intermediate object-oriented programming within the context of interactive media systems and video game development. Topics: classes, objects, inheritance, polymorphism, abstract classes, interfaces, event-driven programming, vectors, geometric primitives, game mechanics, and relevant design patterns. ECE, CENG, ICS, CM, CSCI, THEA, DNCE majors only. A-F only. 160 or ICS 111 or instructor approval. (
prerequisites: ECE 160 or ICS 111 or instructor approval

title: Engineering Electromagnetics I
description: Transient and steady-state waves on transmission lines. Plane wave solutions of Maxwell’s equations. Application of Maxwell’s equations under static and time-varying conditions. 213.

title: Engineering Electromagnetics II
description: Solution of Maxwell’s equations under various boundary conditions. Introduction to radiation, guided waves, and principles of optics. 371 and PHYS 274 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: ECE 371 and PHYS 274 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Engineering Electromagnetics Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Experiments illustrating the basic principles of electromagnetics and optics. 371 and PHYS 274 (or concurrent), or consent. Co-requisite: 372.
prerequisites: ECE 371 and PHYS 274 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Junior Project
description: Junior level individual or team project under ECE faculty direction and guidance. The project provides design experience and develops practical skills. It may be a continuation of ECE 296 or a new project. Repeatable unlimited times. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 296 or consent. (

title: Introduction to Computer and Network Security
description: Review basic network mechanisms, introduce basic cryptography concepts, and study algorithms and protocols used in computer and network security. Discuss practical security mechanisms. A-F only. 361 or ICS 312 or ICS 331 or instructor consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: ECE 361 or ICS 312 or ICS 331 or instructor consent

title: Digital Signal Processing
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Discrete-time signals and systems, sampling, Z-transform, transform, transform analysis of linear time-invariant systems, filter design, discrete Fourier transform, and computation of discrete Fourier transform. 315 and 342 (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: ECE 315 and ECE 342 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Introduction to Digital Image Processing
description: Digital image representation, intensity transformations, spatial filtering, filtering in the frequency domain, image restoration, color spaces and transformations, the fast wavelet transform, image compression. 315 (or equivalent) or consent.

title: Introduction to Optimization
description: Application of linear, nonlinear and integer optimization models and algorithms to communications, control, signal processing, computer networking, financial engineering, manufacturing, production and distribution systems. CE, ECE, ME, or CBA majors only. MATH 307 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Sensors and Instrumentation for Biological Systems
description: Design course focused on fundamentals of electronic interfacing, control and automation, including biological processes. Topics include sensor physics, basic instrumentation, digital communication, and programming of microcontrollers and other portable computer systems. (160, 211, and BE 350 or MATH 302 or MATH 307 or ECE 326) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (
prerequisites: (ECE 160, ECE 211, and BE 350 or MATH 302 or MATH 307 or ECE 326) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Instrumentation Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory for 422. Co-requisite: 422.

title: Computer-Aided Analysis and Design
description: Algorithms and techniques used in computer-aided analysis and design of electronic circuits. Circuit simulation with interactive computers. 326 or consent.

title: Electronic Instrumentation II
description: Instrumentation systems and circuits for measurement, control, signal processing, transmission, and detection. Noise and interference, ADC/DAC, modulation demodulation, high-frequency and high-speed techniques, IC applications. 422 and 422L, or consent.

title: Advanced Si IC and Solid State Devices
description: State of the art Si-based devices including advanced bipolar and MOS devices, heterojunction devices, new device trends. Topics from the most current literature included. 327 and either MATH 243 or MATH 253A, or consent.
prerequisites: ECE 327 and either MATH 243 or MATH 253A, or consent

title: Computer-Aided Circuit Design
description: Application of the computer to the analysis, design, simulation, and construction of analog and digital circuits. 326 and 326L, or consent.

title: Electric Power Systems
description: Design/operation of “the grid.” History of electric power systems, three-phrase power, real and reactive power, transformers, transmission, distribution, circuit analysis, protection, load flow, load frequency control, optimal power flow, and renewable energy integration. MATH 243 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent). (Fall only)

title: Renewable Energy
description: Fundamentals of power, electric power grid and conventional electricity generation. Wind and solar power systems. Photovoltaic materials and systems. Distributed generation and energy storage. ENGR majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 213 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Digital Communications
description: Baseband transmission, intersymbol interference and pulse shaping, partial response signaling, equalization, bandpass modulation and demodulation, channel coding, synchronization, multiplexing and multiple access, spread spectrum techniques. 342 and 343, or consent.

title: Introduction to Machine Learning
description: Foundation for algorithms, practice, and theory behind common machine-learning applications. Includes projects, statistical programming, and an introduction to the unique challenges of high-dimensional problems. ECE, CENG, CEE, ME, MATH, ICS majors only. A-F only. 342 (or equivalent) and MATH 307 (or equivalent).

title: Information Theory and Coding
description: Models of communication systems. Channel noise, measurement, and coding of information. Intrinsic limits of performance of communication systems. 342 and 343, or consent.

title: Computer Communication Networks
description: ISO Reference Model. Physical Layer, Data Link Layer, Network Layer and Transport Layer protocols. Wired and wireless local-area networks. Structure and operation of the Internet including routing, congestion control and flow control. 315 and one of 342, or MATH 371 or MATH 471; or consent.
prerequisites: ECE 315 and one of ECE 342, or MATH 371 or MATH 471; or consent

title: Digital Control Systems
description: Sampling/reconstruction, Z-transform, DT transfer function. Reachability/observability. State and output feedback, observer design, input-output models, diophantine equations. Implementation procedures. 315 and 351, or consent.

title: Modern Control Theory
description: Analysis and synthesis of nonlinear control systems by means of Lagrange’s equation, state space techniques, maximum principle. Lyapunov’s theorems, the phase plane, and Z-transform techniques. Optimization and adaptation by means of gradient methods, calculus of variations, dynamic programming. 351.

title: Design of Intelligent Robots
description: Study of the design principles of computer-controlled, intelligent robots such as roving vehicles, hand-eye systems. 351 and 367.

title: Computer Architecture
description: Structure of stored program machines, data flow machines, pipelining, fault-tolerant computing, instruction set design, effects of compilation on architecture, RISC vs. CISC architecture, uses of parallelism. 361.

title: Object-oriented Software Engineering
description: Introduction to advanced techniques for designing, implementing, and testing computer software with a particular focus on using object-oriented design, analysis, and programming to produce high-quality computer programs that solve non-trivial problems. A-F only. 367 or consent.

title: Introduction to Operating Systems
description: Computer system organization; multiprocessor systems, memory hierarchies, assemblers, compilers, operating systems, virtual machine, memory management, processor management; information management. Emphasis on written communication through written assignments on relevant topics. 361 (or concurrent) and 367 or consent.
prerequisites: ECE 361 (or concurrent) and ECE 367 or consent

title: Wireless Data Networks
description: Mobile agent’s platforms and systems, mobile agent-based service implementation, middleware, and configuration, wireless local area networks, wireless protocols, network architecture supporting wireless applications, routing protocols in mobile and wireless networks, handoff in mobile and wireless networks. 344 and 367, or consent.

title: Physical Optics
description: Fundamentals of classical physical optics emphasizing linear systems theory, including optical fields in matter, polarization phenomena, temporal coherence, interference and diffraction (Fourier optics). Specialized applications include Gaussian beams, laser resonators, pulse propagation, and nonlinear optics. 372 (or concurrent with a minimum grade of C-) or PHYS 450 (or concurrent with a minimum grade of C), or consent. (
prerequisites: ECE 372 (or concurrent with a minimum grade of C-) or PHYS 450 (or concurrent with a minimum grade of C), or consent

title: Computational Techniques in Electromagnetics
description: Introduction to computational methods used to simulate/solve engineering design problems focusing on electromagnetics. Finite difference, method of moments, and finite elements methods will be described; students will write computer programs in each. A-F only. BE, ECE, ENGR majors only. 371 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Microwave Engineering
description: Passive and active microwave devices and circuits for RF and wireless applications. Scattering parameters, signal-flow graphs, and computer-aided design. 371.

title: Antennas
description: Electromagnetic wave propagation in free space and ionized media. Geomagnetic and solar effects on the ionosphere. Absorption and dispersion. Antenna arrays, apertures, horns, impedance. Design of antenna systems. 371.

title: Optical Communications
description: Principles and applications of optical fibers and waveguides. Fundamentals of optical communication systems (optical links, high-speed systems, wavelength-division-multiplexing networks, and network elements) and optical components (guided-wave circuits, lasers, detectors, and optical amplifiers). System and network integration issues. A-F only. 372 or consent.

title: Fundamentals of Radar, Sonar, and Navigation Systems
description: Discussion of basic radar detection and position- and velocity-measurement principles. Applications to various types of radar and sonar systems. Modern navigation aids. 371 (or equivalent), and familiarity with waveguides or waveguide theory.
prerequisites: ECE 371 (or equivalent), and familiarity with waveguides or waveguide theory

title: Introduction to Biomedical and Clinical Engineering
description: Application of engineering principles and technology to biological and medical problems. Introduction to human anatomy, physiology, medical terminology, clinical measurements. Systems modeling, physiological control systems, computer applications, health-related problems. 213 and either MATH 244 or MATH 253A.
prerequisites: ECE 213 and either MATH 244 or MATH 253A

title: Biomedical Engineering Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Measurement of bioelectrical signals, computer and electronic simulation of biological systems, design and evaluation of electronic circuits for biomedical measurements, evaluation of instruments for patient safety. 323 and 323L. Co-requisite: 480.

title: Bioelectric Phenomena
description: Study of electrical phenomena in living systems. Mechanisms underlying bioelectric activity. Membrane and transepithelial potentials, skin impedance, electrocardiography, neuroelectric signals, diagnostic considerations, laboratory demonstrations. 480 or consent.

title: Biomedical Instrumentation
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles, applications, and design of biomedical instrumentation. Transducers, IC and microcomputer applications, patient safety. 326, 480; or consent.

title: (Alpha) Special Topics in Electrical Engineering
description: Content will reflect special interests of visiting/permanent faculty; to be oriented toward juniors and seniors. (B) artificial intelligence; (C) circuits; (D) communications; (E) computer hardware; (F) computer software; (G) computer vision; (H) control; (I) devices; (J) fields; (K) power. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Provisional Topics
description: Upper division course with subject matter to be announced.

title: Ethics in Electrical Engineering
description: Equip electrical engineers with the necessary background for ethical reasoning, as it pertains to technology, society, workplace issues, and the environment. ECE majors only. A-F only. senior standing or consent. (Once a year)

title: Capstone Design Project
description: Significant project integrating the design content of previous courses and incorporating engineering standards and realistic constraints. Written report must document all aspects of the design process: reliability, safety, economics, ethics. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. 396 or consent.

title: Directed Reading
description: Investigation of advanced engineering problems. Repeatable unlimited times. senior standing and consent.

title: Graph Theory and Its Applications
description: Graphs and subgraphs, trees and treelike graphs, planar graphs, connectivity and edge-connectivity, applications. MATH 311 or consent.

title: Algorithm I
description: Design and evaluation of machine representations, techniques and algorithms for sorting, pattern processing, computational geometry, mathematical computations, and engineering applications. Introduction to computational issues of time, space, communication, and program correctness. 367 or consent.

title: Artificial Intelligence
description: LISP for machine intelligence applications, or related constraint object and logic-oriented languages. 467 or knowledge of LISP/PROLOG.

title: Intelligent Autonomous Agents
description: Theory, methods and practical applications of autonomous agent systems, including common applications of both software and hardware (robotic) agents. In-depth practical experience with autonomous agents through programming assignments and projects. 467 or ICS 313 (or equivalent), graduate standing; or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: ECE 467 or ICS 313 (or equivalent), graduate standing; or consent

title: Advanced Network Algorithms
description: Network algorithms, protocols, and packet switching systems for the internet including TCP/IP, routing algorithms, transmission scheduling, link management, buffer management, and simple network management. 367 or consent.

title: Optical Networks
description: Propagation of signals in fibers, components, modulation and demodulation, transmission system engineering, network systems and architectures, network design, control and management and packet switching. 342, 367, and 371; or consent.
prerequisites: ECE 342, ECE 367, and ECE 371; or consent

title: Computer and Network Security
description: Basic security theory, current practices, and emerging research issues. First covering the fundamentals of computer and network security, then will work on research projects on computer and network security.

title: Advanced Digital Signal Processing
description: An advanced course in digital processing. Topics include fast DFT algorithms, multirate systems and filter banks, power spectrum estimation, linear prediction, optimum linear filters, and adaptive filtering. A-F only. Open to nonmajors for CR/NC only. 415 or 640, or consent.

title: Digital Image Processing
description: Human visual perception, image formation, sampling and quantization, enhancement and restoration, color image processing, wavelets and multiresolution representations, image and video compression. 415 or equivalent.

title: Linear and Convex Optimization
description: Algorithms for linear, nonlinear, and convex optimization. Emphasis is on methodology and the underlying mathematical structures. Topics include simplex method, network flow methods, optimality conditions, duality, Newton’s method and interior point methods. ECE, ME, MIS and MATH majors only. MATH 311 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Dynamic Programming and Stochastic Control
description: Sequential decision-making via dynamic programming. Optimal control of stochastic dynamic systems. Applications in linear-quadratic control, inventory control, resource allocation, scheduling, and control of queues. Rollout and other suboptimal methods. Value and policy iteration. 342 or MATH 371 or MATH 471, or consent.
prerequisites: ECE 342 or MATH 371 or MATH 471, or consent

title: Advanced Electronic Circuits
description: Electronic circuits for precision measurement, computation, and signal processing. Low noise and interference reduction techniques. High-frequency and high-speed techniques. Micro-processor and biomedical applications. 422.

title: Advanced Solid-State Devices
description: Advanced physical principles and design of modern solid-state electronic devices. Heterostructures, photodetectors, LED, junction lasers, and other devices of current importance identified from the current literature. A-F only. 327.

title: Optical Electronics I
description: Fundamentals of optical radiation, including stimulated and spontaneous processes. Optical electronics including optical resonators, lasers, optical detectors, light-guiding, and applications. A-F only. 327 or consent.

title: Optical Electronics II
description: Electro-optics, noise detection, light and sound dielectric waveguide phenomena, lasers, optics, phase conjugation. 622 or consent.

title: Microsensors and Microactuators I
description: Technology methods and physical principles of microsensors and microactuators. Vacuum technology, thin film deposition and characterization techniques, solid mechanics, micromachining, acoustics, piezoelectricity and principles of current microtransducers. 327 or consent.

title: Rapid Prototyping of Electrophysical Devices
description: Hands on experience in designing, fabricating, testing, and iterating according to rapid-prototyping principles. Students learn state-of-the-art equipment for making their designs, software for simulating designs, and working in design teams. ECE majors only. Graduate students only. (Spring only)

title: Advanced Topics in Physical Electronics
description: Recent developments in phenomena and devices of physical electronics. 327.

title: Analysis and Design of Integrated Circuits
description: Fabrication constraints and design guidelines for integrated circuits. Nonlinear model of integrated circuit transistor. Design and analysis of integrated logic circuits and linear circuits. 323.

title: Smart Grids and Renewable Energy Integration
description: Challenges and solutions for integrating intermittent renewable energy sources into the power system, with a focus on “smart grid” approaches and demand-response. Using linear programming and other modeling techniques to answer policy-relevant questions. Graduate students only. 435. (Spring only)

title: Applied Random Processes
description: Random variables, multivariate distributions, random sequences, stochastic convergence, stationary and nonstationary processes, spectral analysis, Karhunen-Loeve expansion, Markov processes, mean square estimation, Kalman filters. 342 or MATH 471 (or equivalent).

title: Queueing Theory
description: Poisson, Markov, and renewal processes, M/G/1 queue, G/M/1 queue, queueing networks, simulation, and performance evaluation of computer systems and communication networks. ECE, ICS, MATH majors only. 342, 640 (or concurrent), or consent.

title: Detection and Estimation Theory
description: Fundamentals of signal detection and estimation theory. Hypothesis testing, parametric and nonparametric detection, sequential detection, parametric estimation, linear estimation, robust detection and estimation, and applications to communication systems. 640.

title: Communication System Performance
description: Fundamental performance limits, signal detection and estimation, modulation, intersymbol interference, equalization adaptive filtering, sequence detection, synchronization, fading multipath channels, spread spectrum. 640.

title: Computer Communication Networks
description: Fundamentals of computer communication networks including modeling, performance evaluation, routing, flow control, local area networks, distributed algorithms, and optimization algorithms. 342, MATH 471; or consent.

title: Machine Learning
description: Learning theory, pattern recognition and regression; gradient based algorithms and least square algorithms; Kernel methods; Bayesian learning algorithms; ensemble learning and boosting; principal component analysis; independent component analysis, and clustering; reinforcement learning and approximate dynamic programming. ECE, ME, ICS, MATH majors only. 342.

title: Advanced Information Theory
description: Measure of information, coding for discrete sources, discrete memoryless channels and capacity, the noisy channel coding theorem, source coding with fidelity criterion, rate-distortion theory, multiuser channels. 640.

title: Source Coding
description: Theory and applications of source coding, rate-distortion theory, companding, lattice coding, tree coding, trellis coding, entropy-constrained coding, asymptotic theory, predictive and differential encoding, combined source/channel coding, vector quantization. 640.

title: Error-Control Coding I
description: Linear block codes, soft and hard decision decodings, correction of random errors, cyclic codes, BCH codes, Reed-Solomon codes, majority logic decodable codes, burst-error correcting codes, concatenated codes. MATH 311 or consent.

title: Error-Control Coding II
description: Convolutional codes, Viterbi algorithm, coded modulation, multistage decoding, concatenated coded modulation, probabilistic decoding, turbo codes, low density parity check codes and iterative decoding. 648.

title: Linear System Theory
description: State space theory of linear systems, controllability, observability, stability, irreducible realizations. 452.

title: Nonlinear Control Systems
description: Digital simulations, phase-plane analysis, limit cycles and amplitude bounds, Lyapunov’s theorem, circle criterion of stability, lure systems, Popov’s stability theorem. 650.

title: Optimal Control Systems
description: Optimal controls introduced through parametric optimization, calculus of variations, Euler-Lagrange and Hamilton-Jacobi equations, Pontryagin’s maximum principle, minimum-time and minimum-fuel problems, dynamic programming, applications. 650 or consent.

title: Robust Control
description: Multivariable frequency response design, signals and systems, linear fractional transformations, LQG Control, Full Information H-infinity Controller Synthesis, H-infinity filtering, model reduction, the four-block problem. 453 and 650.

title: Computer Architecture I
description: Models of computation, high-performance processors, pipelined machines, RISC processors, VLIW, superscalar and fine-grain parallel machines. Data-flow architectures. Hardware/software tradeoffs. CECE, ECE, and ME majors only. 461. (

title: Computer Systems
description: Modern operating system software, process communication, distributed systems, device drivers. Software development and maintenance, integration of software packages. Projects reflecting special interests of faculty. 461 and 468.

title: Telecommunication Networks
description: Telecommunication-network architecture; switching, broadcast, and wireless networks; protocols, interfaces, routing, flow- and congestion-control techniques; intelligent network architecture; service creation capabilities; multimedia, voice, data, and video networks and services. 468 or consent.

title: Wireless and Mobile Security
description: Security and privacy design principles and application in wireless and mobile devices, networks, and services, as well as research methodology in wireless and mobile security. A-F only. 406 or instructor approval.

title: Electromagnetic Theory and Applications
description: Solutions of Maxwell’s equations and applications to radiation and propagation of electromagnetic waves. 372 or consent.

title: Advanced Microwave Engineering
description: Advanced RF and microwave circuit design for wireless applications. 473 or consent.

title: Advanced Computational Techniques in Electromagnetics
