description: Develop comprehensive understanding of computations techniques for solving engineering electromagnetic problems formulated in terms of integral or differential equations. Eigenvalue problems, radiation, and electromagnetics scattering problems will be discussed and computer programming is required. ECE, BE, and CENG majors only. A-F only. 471 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent. (Spring only)
prerequisites: ECE 471 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Biomedical Engineering Systems
description: Systems analysis and electronic instrumentation methods in biomedicine. Network and control-loop modeling, computer simulation, biological transducers, and analysis of electronic and physiological systems. 326, 326L, and 371; or consent.
prerequisites: ECE 326, ECE 326L, and ECE 371; or consent

title: Biosensors and Bioelectronics
description: Advanced topics in the design of biological detection technologies. Topics include fundamentals of electrochemistry, electrochemical biosensors, DNA and protein biochips, and bioelectronics for bio-signal conditioning and processing. 324 and 326, or consent. (Once a year)

title: Biomedical Microdevices
description: Design and fabrication of micro- and nanodevices for biomedical applications. Topics include micro- and nanoscale physics, microfluidic physics and microfluidic devices, and micro- and nanoscale fabrication techniques. ENG majors only. A-F only. 324 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Biomedical Signal Processing and Analysis
description: Biomedical signals, digital filters and filter banks, spike train analysis, time-scale and time-frequency representations, nonlinear techniques, Lomb’s algorithm and the Hilbert transform, modeling, Volterra series, Wiener series, Poisson-Wiener series, multichannel data, causality. CE, ECE, ME, ICS majors only and any graduate student in JABSOM who has a suitable technical background. 415 or consent. (Spring only)

title: (Alpha) Special Topics in Electrical Engineering
description: Content will reflect special interests of visiting/permanent faculty. (B) artificial intelligence; (C) circuits; (D) communications; (E) computer hardware; (F) computer software; (H) control; (I) devices; (J) fields; (K) power. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Directed Reading or Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. graduate standing and consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times. candidacy for MS in electrical and computer engineering.
prerequisites: candidacy for MS in electrical and computer engineering

title: Directed Instruction
description: Student assists in classroom instruction under direction and close supervision of faculty member. CR/NC only. admission to PhD candidacy.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times. candidacy for PhD in electrical and computer engineering.
prerequisites: candidacy for PhD in electrical and computer engineering

title: Engineering Freshman Seminar
description: Overview of the engineering field, the different disciplines, and opportunities. Success strategies for studying engineering. Repeatable one time. Engineering majors only. CR/NC only.

title: Introduction to Engineering
description: Topics include the engineering disciplines, the development of problem solving and technical communication skills, the design process and analysis methods using a team design project, and introduction to programming in Matlab for engineering applications. ENGR majors only. Freshman standing only.

title: Introduction to Technology-Based Innovation and Entrepreneurship
description: Introduces modern tools for launching technology-based new ventures. Teams of students engage in term projects to learn design thinking, business model generation, product development, rapid prototyping, customer validation, and pitching to investors. ENGR and BUS majors only. Freshmen only. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Freshman Vertically Integrated Project
description: Team-based research project for freshman-level students. Project topic varies by instructor. Students are expected to continue working in this project as a sophomore (ENGR 296). Repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only. consent.

title: Personal Development for Effective Teams
description: Exploration and application of basic leadership theories and processes which foster personal and interpersonal development via cognitive experiential classroom methods and mentoring relationships with experienced peer leaders. (

title: Sophomore Vertically Integrated Project
description: Team-based research project for sophomore-level students. Project topic varies by instructor. Students are expected to continue working in this project as a junior (ENGR 396). Sophomore standing or higher. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. consent. (

title: Career Development Seminar
description: Introduction to career development as it pertains to engineering and business industry; client relations, networking, job skills, career assessment and direction. Repeatable one time. (Fall only)

title: Junior Vertically Integrated Project
description: Team-based research project for junior-level students. Project topic varies by instructor. Students are expected to continue working in this project as a senior. Repeatable unlimited times. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 296 or consent. (

title: Engineering Management
description: Introduction to engineering management of projects and its outcomes. Development of professional skills for the systematic formulation of problems and solutions to efficiently deduce project viability. Emphasis on collaborative teamwork and performance evaluations and improvements. Senior standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Field Experience
description: Supervised internship in engineering practice under professional and faculty direction. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. junior standing in engineering and consent.
prerequisites: junior standing in engineering and consent

title: Composition I
description: Introduction to the rhetorical, conceptual and stylistic demands of writing at the university level; instruction in composing processes, search strategies, and writing from sources. Students may not earn credit for both ENG 100 and 190. placement.

title: Composition I
description: Introduction to the rhetorical, conceptual and stylistic demands of writing at the university level; instruction in composing processes, search strategies, and writing from sources. Students may not earn credit for both ENG 100 and 190. placement.

title: Composition for Transfer Students to UHM
description: Introduction to the rhetorical, conceptual and stylistic demands of writing at the university level; instruction in composing processes, search strategies, and writing from sources. Restricted to students with more than 24 credits. Students may not earn credit for both ENG 100 and 190. A-F only. placement.

title: Composition II
description: Further study of rhetorical, conceptual, and stylistic demands of writing; instruction develops the writing and research skills covered in Composition I. FW.

title: Business Writing
description: Practice in informative, analytical, persuasive writing. FW. Students may not earn credit for both ENG 209 and BUS 209.

title: Introduction to Literature: Literary History
description: Study of significant works of selected historical periods. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction. Repeatable one time. Requires a minimum of 4,000 words of graded writing. FW.

title: Introduction to Literature: Genre
description: Study of significant works of selected genres. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction. Repeatable one time. Requires a minimum of 4,000 words of graded writing. FW.

title: Introduction to Literature: Culture and Literature
description: Study of significant works of selected cultures and cultural formations. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction. Repeatable one time. Requires a minimum of 4,000 words of graded writing. FW.

title: Introduction to Literature: Creative Writing and Literature
description: Study of significant works through analytical and creative writing. Repeatable one time. FW. No waiver.

title: Introduction to Literature: Rhetoric and Literature
description: Study of significant works of literature and rhetoric through a rhetorical analytical lens. A significant portion is dedicated to writing instruction. Requires a minimum of 4,000 words of graded writing. Repeatable one time. FW

title: (Alpha) Introduction to Rhetoric
description: History of theory and practices of rhetoric from Classical to contemporary periods; e.g., Plato, Aristotle, Cicero, Quintilian, Augustine, Sidney, K. Burke, DeMan; (B) Classical-Renaissance; (C) EnlightenmentContemporary. Repeatable one time for different alphas. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: History of the English Language
description: Basic concepts and methods for the study of the English language; general history of the language; grammar and usage, issues of language diversity and standardization; English as a world language. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Modern English Grammar
description: Introduction to the structure of present-day English for native speakers and others with advanced competency. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Argumentative Writing
description: Theory and practice of written argument; emphasis on the role of invention in argumentative discourse and on the nature of rhetorical proof. FW and either 200 or one ENG DL course, or consent.
prerequisites: FW and either ENG 200 or one ENG DL course, or consent

title: Rhetoric, Composition, and Computers
description: Introduction to computer-based writing and reading technologies. Study of principles of traditional and online composition. Writing traditional and multimedia essays. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Technical Writing
description: Combined lecture/ lab preparing students to write about technical subjects for specialists and laypersons. Introduces theory of technical communication and document design and teaches students to make use of relevant technology. A-F only. FW and either 200 or one ENG DL course; or consent.
prerequisites: FW and either ENG 200 or one ENG DL course; or consent

title: Autobiographical Writing
description: Writing clear, effective prose based on the writer’s own experiences and ideas with a focus on the ethical questions such writing entails. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Creative Writing
description: Basic principles of the craft as developed through writing in two of the following genres: fiction, poetry, drama, screenwriting, and creative nonfiction. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Introduction to English Studies
description: Introduction to English Studies, including reading and writing about the purpose, practice, and potential of literary and rhetorical study of texts; consideration given to Hawaiian and/or Pacific texts in cultural and historical context. Restricted to ENG majors/minors and Secondary Education-English majors only. to 400-level work for ENG majors. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: to ENG 400-level work for ENG majors

title: Backgrounds of Western Literature
description: Sources of European and American literary themes and allusions; myth, legend, and folklore of Western cultures; e.g., Classical texts, Arthurian romances, King James Bible. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Literatures of the World
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the transhistorical, transnational, and/or comparative study of literatures in English and in translation from regions around the world. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Medieval Literature
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of literature before 1500. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Renaissance British Literature
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of prose, poetry, and drama in English from 1500 to 1660. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Restoration/18th Century British Literature
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of prose, poetry, and drama in English from 1660 to 1780, exclusive of Milton. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: 19th Century British Literature
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of 19th century prose and poetry in English. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: British Literature After 1900
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of prose, poetry, and drama in English from 1900 to the present. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: American Literature to Mid-19th Century
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of prose, poetry, and drama in American literature through the middle of the 19th century. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: American Literature Mid-19th to Mid20th Century
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of prose, poetry and drama in American literature from the middle of the 19th century to the middle of the 20th century. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: American Literature Since Mid-20th Century
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of American literature since approximately 1950. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Film, Literature, and Adaptation
description: Comparative analysis of literary texts and their screen adaptations. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Poetry
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the analysis of imagery, sound, language, form, and structure in poems. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Drama
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of the form, function, and development of the genre of drama. Emphasis on types of writing and revision, and oral presentation. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Film
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of the form, function, and development of cinematic narrative techniques. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Non-fiction
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of non-fiction such as essays, biographies, autobiographies, speeches, political and legal documents, conversion and captivity narratives, testimonials, science writing, and travel writing. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Fiction
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of the form, function, and development of fiction genres such as short story and the novel in English. Repeatable one time for different topics. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Film History
description: Introduction to the history of film as art, industry, and socio-cultural representation from the invention of the moving picture to 1965. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Literatures of Hawai‘i
description: Writings of various ethnic groups in Hawai‘i, ancient to contemporary. Songs, stories, poetry, fiction, essays that illustrate the social history of Hawai‘i. one ENG DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Literature of the Pacific
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of the literature of the Pacific, including Pacific voyagers and contemporary writings in English by Pacific Islanders. one ENG DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Asian American Literature
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of Asian American literature by writers from a variety of backgrounds. one ENG DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: African American Literature
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of African American literature by writers from a variety of backgrounds. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Race, Ethnicity, and Literature
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of race and ethnicity as the basis for literary inquiry. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Philippine Contemporary Literature in English
description: Critical survey of 20th-century Philippine literature written in English; cultural values. one ENG DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Philippine Literature and Folklore in Translation
description: Philippine folk literature translated into English: epics, myths, legends, and other folklore. Classic works of vernacular writers. one ENG DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Native Hawaiian Literature in English
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of Native Hawaiian literature, ancient to contemporary, in translation and in English, that demonstrate the depth and breadth of the Native Hawaiian literary tradition. one DL course.

title: Folklore, Wonder Tales, and Oral Traditions
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of folktales, legends, ballads, wonder tales, and other folklore genres in various cultures; consideration given to folklore/literature relationships. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Popular Literature
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of popular literature genres, such as detective fiction, science fiction, the thriller, the romance, and westerns. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Gender, Sexuality and Literature
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of literary constructions of gender and sexuality; emphasis on teaching gender and sexuality through writing and oral communication. one ENG DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Children’s Literature
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of children’s literature; may include study of children’s book illustration. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Fairy Tales and Their Adaptations
description: Comparative analysis of selected tales of magic and their adaptations across history, cultures and media such as book illustration and film. one ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Literature and the Environment
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of intersections between literature and the environment, including issues such as climate change, technology, pollution, land and land use, interspecies relationships. One ENG DL course or consent.
prerequisites: One ENG DL course or consent

title: Theories and Methods of English Studies
description: Intensive study of questions, issues, traditions, and movements in the field of English Studies. Recommended for students planning to pursue postbaccalaureate degrees. ENG 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: English in Hawai‘i
description: English language in Hawai‘i viewed historically and in a multicultural context, with attention to politics, religion, race, and education, from 1820 to present. two ENG DL courses or consent.
prerequisites: two ENG DL courses or consent

title: Teaching Composition
description: Theory, observation, and practice in teaching writing, especially the use of one-on-one and small group instruction. two ENG DL courses; or consent. Recommended: 306.
prerequisites: two ENG DL courses; or consent

title: Advanced Argumentative Writing
description: Advanced study of both the philosophical and practical dimensions of written reasoning. Emphasis on argument as a process of inquiry. FW and either 200 or one ENG DL course, or consent.
prerequisites: FW and either ENG 200 or one ENG DL course, or consent

title: Writing for Digital Media
description: Combined lecture/lab on writing and rhetoric in computermediated communication. May include online technical writing, courseware development, social media content creation. two ENG DL courses or consent.
prerequisites: two ENG DL courses or consent

title: Professional Editing
description: Discussion and practice in the professional editing of articles, reports, books; logic, clarity, coherence, consistency of tone and style, grammar and punctuation. 303, 306, 311, 313, or 405; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 303, ENG 306, ENG 311, ENG 313, or ENG 405; or consent

title: Studies in Composition/Rhetoric/ Language
description: Intensive study of selected topics, questions, themes, issues, and/or writers in composition, rhetoric, and/or English language. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Form and Theory of Poetry
description: Poetic theories and techniques for students interested in writing poetry. 313 or consent.

title: Poetry Workshop
description: Writing, evaluating poems. Repeatable one time. 313 or consent.

title: Nonfiction Writing
description: Workshop analysis of nonfiction as a literary form. Significant attention paid to developing writing skills. Repeatable one time. 306, 311, or 313; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 306, ENG 311, or ENG 313; or consent

title: Form and Theory of Fiction
description: Narrative techniques for students interested in writing fiction. 313 or consent.

title: Fiction Workshop
description: Writing, evaluating fiction. Repeatable one time. 313 or consent.

title: Studies in Creative Writing
description: Intensive study of selected topics, questions, themes, writers, or modes of creative writing in a workshop setting. Repeatable one time. 313 or consent.

title: Studies in Literature and Culture
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in regard to cultural studies and the reading and interpretation of cultural texts. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in Comparative Literature
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in the field of comparative literature. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in Medieval Literature
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in Old/Middle English literature from 500-1500, including works in modern translation. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in 16th and 17th Century Literature
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in texts written during the period 1500-1700. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in 18th Century Literature
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in texts written during the period 1660-1830, the “long” 18th century. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in 19th Century Literature
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in texts written during the 19th century. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in 20th and 21st Century Literature
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, writers, traditions, or movements in texts written from the 20th century to the present. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Single Author
description: Intensive study of the works and literary milieu of a single author considered significant by most scholars in English Studies. The English Department maintains a list of versions focusing on specific authors. Repeatable one time for a different author, with consent. two ENG DL courses or consent.
prerequisites: two ENG DL courses or consent

title: Geoffrey Chaucer
description: Intensive study of the works and literary milieu of Geoffrey Chaucer. two ENG DL courses or consent
prerequisites: two ENG DL courses or consent

title: William Shakespeare
description: Intensive study of the works and literary milieu of William Shakespeare. Repeatable one time. two ENG DL courses or consent.
prerequisites: two ENG DL courses or consent

title: John Milton
description: Intensive study of the works and literary milieu of John Milton. two ENG DL courses or consent.
prerequisites: two ENG DL courses or consent

title: U.S. Women’s Literature and Culture
description: Reading of selected works of U.S. women’s literature and cultural texts (such as art and film). Emphasis on historical and cultural context and diverse expressions of women’s gendered identities. (

title: Studies in Film
description: Intensive study of selected topics in film, e.g.: genres, major filmmakers, film theory/criticism, or film and literature. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in Life Writing
description: Intensive study of forms and theories of life writing in forms such as biographies, autobiographies, oral histories, diaries, journals, letters, film, drama, and portraiture with a focus on the ethical questions these materials present. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in Literary Forms, Genres, and Media
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, or movements in literary forms, genres, and media. Repeatable one time. ENG 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in Asian American and Asian Diaspora Literatures
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, genres, or writers relating to Asia. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in Postcolonial Literature
description: Intensive study of postcolonial literatures and of historical, cultural, and theoretical issues such as colonialism, migration, assimilation, national identity, or transnationalism. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in Cultural Identities and Literature
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, genres, and writers in relation to cultural identities such as race, ethnicity, class as the basis for literary inquiry. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level course; or consent

title: Studies in Cultural and Literary Geographies
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, genres, or writers relating to space and place as the basis for literary inquiry. Topics may include migration, diaspora, and local histories. Repeatable one time. ENG 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in Hawaiian and/or Pacific Literature
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, writers, movements, and genres in the field of Hawaiian and/or Pacific literature. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course. (
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course

title: Studies in Literature and Folklore
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, or genres in folklore and oral traditions and their performance and transformations within specific social and cultural contexts. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in Literature and Popular Culture
description: Intensive study of selected problems, issues, traditions, writers, movements, or genres in the field of popular literature and/or popular culture. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Studies in Literature and Sexuality and Gender
description: Intensive study of selected questions and issues in the construction and representation of sexuality and gender in specific genres, social and cultural contexts, or thematic/figurative clusters. Repeatable one time. 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent. (
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Study Abroad
description: Intensive study in the English language of selected topics, issues or writers from the host country in a UH Mānoa-approved study abroad location. Repeatable one time. A-F only. two ENG DL courses or consent.
prerequisites: two ENG DL courses or consent

title: Internship
description: Faculty supervised participation in the operations of an organization. A-F only. two ENG DL courses, junior standing, or consent.
prerequisites: two ENG DL courses, junior standing, or consent

title: Directed Reading
description: Repeatable up to six credits. A-F only. two ENG DL courses or consent.
prerequisites: two ENG DL courses or consent

title: HWP Summer Writing Institute
description: Repeatable one time.

title: HWP Summer Institute WAC
description: Practicum in the current best approaches to teaching writing across the curriculum. Participants write, read published theory and research in composition, and demonstrate effective writing lessons. Repeatable one time.

title: Old English
description: Structure of the language, relation to present English; reading of selected prose and poetry.

title: Theory and Practice of Teaching Composition
description: Major contemporary theorists and classroom practices that evolve from their theories; observation and applications. A-F only.

title: Elements of Creative Writing
description: Intensive discussion of the craft and technique of creative writing through readings in poetry, fiction, creative nonfiction, and creative writing pedagogy. A-F only. graduate standing or consent. (Fall only)

title: (Alpha) Graduate Writing Workshop
description: Advanced practice and critical evaluation of the writing of poetry, fiction, or creative nonfiction. (B) poetry; (C) fiction; (D) nonfiction. Repeatable one time in each English graduate degree. graduate standing plus 411 for (B); 414 for (C); 412 for (D); or consent
prerequisites: graduate standing plus ENG 411 for (B); ENG 414 for (C); ENG 412 for (D); or consent

title: (Alpha) Theories and Methods
description: Required course in the MA student’s area of concentration. (B) theories and methods of literary study; (C) introduction to composition and rhetoric; (D) foundations of creative writing; (E) theories in cultural studies. Repeatable in different alphas. ENG majors only. A-F only. graduate standing or consent. (Fall only)

title: (Alpha) Literary Theory and Criticism
description: (B) classical period through 18th century; (C) Romantic and post-Romantic.

title: Biography
description: Study of one or more authors, English or American literature. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent.

title: MA Final Project
description: Individual reading and research towards preparation of MA project. 3 credit hours required. CR/NC only. Repeatable one time. 625 and consent.

title: Supervised Practicum
description: Applies course work in literature, creative writing, cultural studies, or composition and rhetoric to hands-on activities engaging publics outside of the university under direction of practicing professionals and university faculty. ENG majors only. A-F only. graduate standing and consent.

title: Directed Reading
description: Individual reading or research. Repeatable with consent of Graduate Director. graduate standing and consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. graduate standing and consent.

title: Seminar in Composition Studies
description: Intensive study of selected issues in composition studies. Repeatable one time. 625C or consent.

title: Seminar in Rhetoric
description: Intensive study of selected topics in the history of rhetoric, rhetorical theory, or rhetorical criticism; topic to be announced. Repeatable one time. 625C or consent.

title: Seminar in Creative Writing
description: Advanced study in creative writing focused on thesis and dissertation projects. Repeatable one time in each English graduate degree. 613 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Techniques in Contemporary Literature
description: The study, from the point of view of the creative writer, of works written within the last 25 years. (B) techniques in fiction; (C) techniques in poetry; (D) techniques in creative nonfiction. Repeatable one time in each ENG graduate degree. 613 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Seminar in Literary Criticism
description: Intensive study of selected topics in literary theory and its practical application; topics to be announced. Repeatable two times. graduate standing or consent.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in English Literature
description: Study of authors or a period. (C) re-reading Chaucer; (N) 14th century poetry; (P) extended Victorian lyric; (Q) modern British fiction; (R) early 17th century poetry; (S) dominant Victorians: the 1840s; (T) Baroque and English literature; (U) literature and social change; (X) literature and history; (Y) studies in satire. Repeatable one time.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in American Literature
description: Study of authors or a period. (B) American modernism; (C) race in American literature; (D) 19th century American poetry; (E) American literature naturalism; (F) African American literature and theory; (G) American transcendentalism; (H) 19th century American novel; (J) contemporary American poetry; (N) poetry by 20th century American women; (P) women writers and multiculturalism; (Q) Asian American literature and theory; (R) relocating American literature; (S) early American literature; (T) H. Melville and T. Morrison. Repeatable one time for different alphas.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Major Author
description: Study of one or more authors, English or American. (C) George Eliot; (D) Emily Dickinson; (M) Milton; (S) Chaucer and his backgrounds; (T) Austen; (U) Yeats and his circle; (X) Beowulf; (Y) Faulkner’s narrative; (Z) Virginia Woolf. Repeatable one time for different alphas. A-F only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Seminar in Shakespeare
description: Intensive study of Shakespeare.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Literary Genres
description: Study of one or more authors, English or American literature. (C) neoclassicism; (D) tragedy; (E) modern American short story; (F) sonnet and sonnet sequences; (G) Rest., 18th century dramatic comedy; (H) 18th century literature and art; (I) medieval drama; (J) narrative theory and criticism; (K) reinventing the author; (M) laughter and the comic arts; (N) nature of romance; (O) Victorian novel; (P) Jacobean drama; (Q) science fiction; (R) essay, past and present; (S) Eng. hymn in Western culture; (W) 18th century British women novelists; (Y) English romanticism; (Z) English novel and criticism. Repeatable one time. A-F only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Seminar in Film Theory and Criticism
description: Classic theories of representation and aesthetics; modern and contemporary cultural, psychoanalytic, and aesthetic theories as they apply to film.

title: Seminar in Life Writing
description: Intensive study of critical and theoretical issues raised by various forms of life writing (biography, autobiography, oral history, diaries, etc.) and of their history and methodology. Repeatable one time.

title: Seminar in Cultural Studies in Asia/ Pacific
description: Intensive study of selected issues in cultural studies in Asia and the Pacific; topics to be announced. Repeatable one time.

title: Seminar in Pacific Literatures
description: Intensive study of selected issues in the literatures of the Pacific in English, or translated into English. Topics to be announced. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent. (Spring only)

title: Seminar in Literatures of Hawai‘i
description: Introduction to comparative literature; relationship of Hawaiian to other literatures; sources and influences. Repeatable one time.

title: Seminar in Hawaiian Literature
description: Intensive study of selected issues, genres, and traditions in Hawaiian literature written in English or translated from Hawaiian into English. Repeatable one time. HAW 102 (or concurrent) or consent. (Fall only)

title: Seminar in Cultural Studies
description: Intensive study of selected issues in cultural studies and cultural and social theory; topics to be announced. Repeatable one time.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Comparative Literature
description: Introduction to comparative literature; relationship of English to other literatures; sources and influences. (B) African lit. and literary theory; (F) folklore and literature; (G) theory/practice of poetry; (H) contemporary drama; (I) mythic method; (J) postmodern fiction; (M) modernism; (N) colonial/ postcolonial; (P) postmodernism and postcolonialism; (W) medieval women writers. Repeatable one time for different alphas.

title: Seminar in Special Topics
description: Content to be announced. Repeatable five times.

title: Dissertation Research
description: graduate standing and consent. Repeatable nine times.

title: Composition I for Second Language Writers
description: Extensive practice in writing expository essays; linguistic devices that make an essay effective. (Fulfills composition requirement for nonnative speakers of English only.)

title: Intermediate Academic Listening and Speaking
description: Introduction to the academic English language listening/speaking demands required at the university. Instruction and practice of effective note-taking skills, listening strategies, delivery of presentations, and participation in academic discussions. Designed as a bridge to ELI 080. CR/ NC only.

title: Intermediate Academic Literacy
description: Introduction to the academic English-language literacy demands required at the university. Extensive practice in academic reading, writing, and vocabulary development. Designed as a bridge to advanced-level ELI courses in reading and writing. CR/NC only.

title: Advanced Academic Listening and Speaking
description: Further development of the academic English-language listening/speaking skills and strategies required at the university. Instruction and practice of effective note-taking skills, critical listening strategies, delivery of effective academic presentations and leading of academic discussions. 070 or placement by examination.

title: Advanced Academic Reading
description: Further development of skills and strategies for dealing with the high demands of academic reading by focusing on becoming efficient and autonomous readers. Instruction and practice of developing critical reading strategies and building field-specific vocabulary. 075 or placement by examination. CR/NC only.

title: Advanced Academic Writing for Graduate Students
description: Introduction to academic writing conventions common at the graduate level. Students explore academic writing in their disciplines, develop clarity of written expression, and improve command over textual, rhetorical, and discursive conventions common in academic writing. 075 or placement by examination.

title: Practicum for International Teaching Assistants
description: Extensive practice for international teaching assistants in speaking in classroom situations with emphasis on oral skills, American cultural expectations and classroom management. CR/NC only. 080.

title: Introduction to Ethnic Studies
description: Concepts and theories analyzing ethnic group experiences in relation to colonization, immigration, racism, and social class. Emphasis on cultural perspectives and values rooted in the experiences of peoples indigenous to Hawai‘i, the Pacific, and Asia.

title: Introduction to Ethnic Studies
description: Concepts and theories analyzing ethnic group experiences in relation to colonization, immigration, racism, and social class. Emphasis on cultural perspectives and values rooted in the experiences of peoples indigenous to Hawai‘i, the Pacific, and Asia.

title: Race, Class, Gender in Popular Culture
description: Contemporary issues of race, class, and gender in popular culture (film, television, music, social media, sports, etc.). Introduction to critical media analysis and social science theories and methods.

title: Introduction to Race and Ethnic Relations
description: Race and ethnic relations in world perspective; social, economic, and political problems associated with perception, existence, and accommodation of these groups within the wider society. (

title: Hawaiians
description: The sustainable social system, culture, spirituality, language, land stewardship, and governance of Native Hawaiians. Transformation of the sustainable Hawaiian social system by a capitalist economy. Resiliency, land issues, and Native Hawaiian quest for sovereign governance. (

title: Filipinos in Diaspora
description: Introduction to Filipinos in diaspora. Topics include: race, empire, migration, representation, cultural production, identity formation, and decolonization.

title: Ethnic Identity
description: Individual and group problems of identity, identity conflict, culture conflict, inter-ethnic relations. Critical review of available material on Hawai‘i. one DS or DH course.

title: African American Experience I
description: Afrocentric perspective. Analysis of the black political/cultural diaspora, including ancient African kingdoms, the slavery experience, organized resistance, emancipation struggles, the Civil War and Reconstruction. one DS or DH course.

title: African American Experience II
description: Black sociopolitical perspectives of the Reconstruction period, Jim Crow, intellectual and cultural awakenings, civil rights movements, and contemporary issues as examined through students’ written analysis and creative projects. one DS or DH course.

title: Race, Indigeneity, and Environmental Justice
description: Introduction to environmental justice, explores the premise that all people have a right to a life-affirming environment. Will examine environmental racism, and the geographical dimensions of race and indigeneity. one DS or DH course, or consent. (
prerequisites: one DS or DH course, or consent

title: Ethnicity and Community: Hawai‘i
description: Site visits to museums, social welfare units, etc., as well as guest lecturers from the community including police, health, education. one DS or DH course. (Summer only)

title: Asian America
description: History of selected Asian immigrant groups from the 19th century to the present. Topics include: immigration and labor history, Asian American movements, literature and cultural productions, community adaptations and identity formation. junior standing or higher. (

title: Hawai‘i and the Pacific
description: Hawai‘i as part of the Pacific community: selected historical and contemporary problems of Pacific areas; cultural and economic imperialism, land alienation, and the impact of development on Pacific peoples. one DS or DH course. (

title: Japanese in Hawai‘i
description: Issei roots in Japan; the role of Japanese in labor, politics, and business; sansei and perspectives on local identity and culture. The Japanese in light of changing economic, social, and political conditions in Hawai‘i today. one DS or DH course.

title: Power and Place: Chinatowns
description: Historical and contemporary experiences of Chinese in Hawai‘i and the U.S. continent with a focus on Chinatowns; urbanization; economic development, community organizing; comparative racialization. one DS or DH course.

title: Filipinos in Hawai‘i
description: Historical and contemporary experiences; immigration; traditional culture and values; plantation experience; labor organizing; development of Filipino community; racism; discrimination; and ethnic identity. one DS or DH course.

title: American Indian Experience
description: Provides a comprehensive look at the indigenous foundation of life and society in the Americas and elaborates on historical and contemporary importance of American Indian rights issues. one DS or DH course.

title: South Asian Migrants: Culture and Politics
description: Historical and contemporary experiences of South Asian migrants in North America, Pacific, Caribbean, and/or African diasporas; causes and patterns of migration, inter-ethnic relations policies; role of race, gender, culture in community, identity formation. A-F only. one ES or WGSS course in the 100, 200 or 300 level; or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: one ES or WGSS course in the ES 100, ES 200 or ES 300 level; or consent

title: Land Tenure and Use in Hawai‘i
description: Dynamics of change: indigenous Hawaiian land tenure; Great Mahele and Kuleana Act; ethnic succession of land ownership; concentration of ownership today; effects of land development on ethnic communities. one DS or DH course. (

title: The Sounds of Race and Inequality
description: Explore inequality as manifested and contested in silence, music, dialect, nature, voice, and acoustic space by listening through a matrix of race, ethnicity, gender, class, and sexualities. Combination of hands-on work and current scholarship.

title: Economic Change and Hawai‘i’s People
description: Hawai‘i’s economic transformation from sustainable communal subsistence through mercantile capitalism, plantation capitalism, and global finance capital and impact on its people. Alternative sustainable enterprises for a self-sufficient island economy. one DS or DH course. (

title: Immigration to Hawai‘i and U.S.
description: Historical overview: “push and pull factors”; effect of changing economy; experiences of various ethnic groups; problems of recent immigrants; immigration policies in the U.S. and Hawai‘i. one DS course.

title: Pacific/Asian Women in Hawai‘i
description: Adaptive strategies of Hawaiian, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Filipino, Samoan, and Southeast Asian women in Hawai‘i; feminist anthropological and historical analysis. one ANTH, SOC, or WGSS course. (
prerequisites: one ANTH, SOC, or WGSS course

title: Literatures of Hawai‘i
description: Writings of various ethnic groups in Hawai‘i, ancient to contemporary. Songs, stories, poetry, fiction, essays that illustrate the social history of Hawai‘i. one ENG DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Asian American Literature
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of Asian American literature by writers from a variety of backgrounds. one ENG DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Filipino Americans: History, Culture and Politics
description: An introduction to the study of Filipino Americans in the U.S. and the diaspora. The course pays special attention to labor migration, cultural production and community politics. sophomore standing. (

title: Issues of Diversity in Higher Education
description: Examines issues of diversity within higher education. Examines different dimensions of diversity including ethnicity, gender, national origin, age, and sexual orientation. Will utilize national and local case studies. Junior class standing or higher. one DS or DH course.

title: Fieldwork in Ethnic Studies
description: Supervision of individual student research projects pertinent to ethnic studies, including service learning, civic engagement, internship, oral history, or supervised practicum experience in teaching select ethnic studies courses. Repeatable to total of 6 credit hours. consent.

title: Social Movements in Hawai‘i
description: Examines, through writing and collaboration, interethnic movement building among Native Hawaiian, other Pacific Islander, and Asian peoples of Hawai‘i through intersectional theories of social change to evaluate strategies to create just and sustainable futures. one DS or DH course.

title: Gender and Race in U.S. Society
description: Historical and sociological studies of race and gender in U.S. society; grassroots feminist and racial/justice activism on the continent and in Hawai‘i. A-F only. 101 or WGSS 151 or junior standing. (
prerequisites: ES 101 or WGSS 151 or junior standing

title: Oceanic Gender, Sexual, and Kinship Identities
description: Oceania-centric perspective. Analysis of imperialism, colonialism, gender, sexuality, race, ethnicity, and queer(ed) relations and identities in Hawai‘i and the Pacific. Junior standing or higher. one DS or DH course, or consent. (
prerequisites: one DS or DH course, or consent

title: Change in the Pacific—Polynesia
description: Impact of cultural and physical change and their interrelationship. one DS or DH course.

title: Multiethnic Popular Culture: Hip Hop
description: Historical, social, cultural, and political aspects of the formation and development of Hip Hop culture in Hawai‘i and other Pacific islands. Special attention to the significance of Hip Hop in facilitating cultural interactions. Junior standing or higher. one DS or DH course or consent.
prerequisites: one DS or DH course or consent

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Repeatable up to 6 credits. consent only.

title: Ethnic Studies in the Digital World
description: The digitally networked world mediates race and ethnicity–and vice-versa. We will challenge racism and discrimination manifested in social media, changing notions of identity and group belonging, ewaste, gaming, big data, and more.

title: Race, Class, and the Law
description: Historical context and implications of landmark court decisions and legal issues affecting social change in ethnic communities in Hawai‘i and the continental U.S. one DS or DH course or consent.
prerequisites: one DS or DH course or consent

title: Women and Work
description: Gender and race of paid and unpaid work in the formal and informal sectors of the economy; carework in households; unemployment; ethics of revaluing feminized work; labor rights: scope: local and global. one 300-level ES or WGSS course, or SOC 300; or consent. (
prerequisites: one ES 300-level ES or WGSS course, or SOC 300; or consent

title: American Ethnic and Race Relations
description: Surveys ethnic and race relations in the U.S. Focus on historical conflicts and critical issues such as racism, immigration, affirmative action, changing economic structures, and the role of government. one DS or DH course.

title: Mixed Race Identities, Multiracial Experiences
description: Critically examines historical and contemporary issues surrounding mixed race identities and experiences through themes that resonate in localized contexts within the continental U.S. and Oceania. one DH or DS course, or consent.
prerequisites: one DH or DS course, or consent

title: Filming Social Change
description: Introduction to visual documentary theory and methods. Basic instruction in using digital video technology and hands-on production to tell visual stories and examine social issues related to diverse peoples, cultures, and communities through video projects. A-F only. one DH or DS course, or consent. (
prerequisites: one DH or DS course, or consent

title: Contemporary Diasporas in Comparative Perspective
description: Compares the circumstances under which contemporary Asian, Pacific Islander, or African migrants form diasporas across the globe; focus on a particular ethnic group to examine its site-specific experiences. A-F only.

title: Filipino Americans: Research Topics
description: A research seminar on the study of Filipino Americans. Special themes in film/video/media, the performing arts, or literature may be offered. junior standing or consent. (

title: Food, Culture, and Empire in U.S. and Hawai‘i
description: Examines the cultural, historical, and political processes that have informed our understandings and practices involving food. We will analyze food and foodways in the U.S. and Hawai‘i. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. at least one course in WGSS or ES; or consent by instructor. (
prerequisites: at least one course in WGSS or ES; or consent by instructor

title: Raciolinguistics
description: Theory and applications of critical race studies, ethnic studies, and linguistic anthropology as they pertain to the science of language, language behavior, language attitudes, and language in the public sphere. (

title: (Alpha) Topics in Comparative Ethnic Conflict
description: Causes and dynamics of ethnic conflicts with attention to problem resolution; (B) Middle East; (C) Hawaiian sovereignty in Pacific context. one DS or DH course, or consent for (C). ((C)
prerequisites: one DS or DH course, or consent for (C)

title: Racism and Ethnicity in Hawai‘i
description: The historical and contemporary social processes involved in inter-ethnic relations in Hawai‘i. SOC 300 or one ES 300 level course, or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 300 or one ES 300 level course, or consent

title: Politics of Men and Masculinity in U.S. Culture
description: Examines American understandings of man, manhood, and masculinity, at the intersection of gender, race, class, and sexuality in the context of American nation and empire building in the 19th and 20th centuries. A-F only. one of WGSS 151, WGSS 175, WGSS 176, or WGSS 202; or consent. (
prerequisites: one of WGSS 151, WGSS 175, WGSS 176, or WGSS 202; or consent

title: Global Ethnic Conflict
description: Ethnic conflicts cause most wars on our globe today. Examines causes of ethnic conflict, including climate change. Will evaluate approaches to building peaceful relations between groups and developing sustainable relationships with the environment. Junior standing or higher. one DS or DH course or consent.
prerequisites: one DS or DH course or consent

title: Latinx Experience in Hawai‘i
description: Examines historical, socio-cultural, and contemporary Latinx presence; relations among Latinx, other immigrant, and Indigenous communities; causes and patterns of immigration; racism and discrimination; ethnicity and identity issues; struggles for justice. one DH or DS course, or consent.
prerequisites: one DH or DS course, or consent

title: Practices and Methods in Oceanic Ethnic Studies
description: Engagement with theoretical elements and qualitative and quantitative research methods of Oceanic Ethnic Studies: theories of class, race, indignity, migrancy, diaspora and political economy; community-based and participatory research methods. A-F only. one upper division ES or SOCS course or consent.
prerequisites: one upper division ES or SOCS course or consent

title: Peoples of Hawai‘i
description: Critically examines the historical and contemporary experiences of various people of Hawai‘i using anthropological and ethnic studies approaches. Emphasis on cultural perspectives and values of peoples indigenous to Hawai‘i, the Pacific, and Asia. junior standing or consent. (Once a year) (

title: Politics of Multiculturalism
description: The development of ethnic relations and political approaches to multiculturalism in two multiethnic nations: Canada and the U.S. A-F only. SOC 300 or one 300 level ES course, or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 300 or one SOC 300 level ES course, or consent

title: Oral History: Theory and Practice
description: Literature, methodology, ethics and project design of oral history research. Students develop and execute an oral history project. (

title: Hawai‘i’s Labor History
description: Conditions of work under varying political, social, and economic transformations in Hawai‘i; anthropological, sociological, and historic data. one DS or DH course or consent.
prerequisites: one DS or DH course or consent

title: Special Topics in Ethnic Studies
description: Selected themes in ethnic studies exploring current issues and new topics; taught by regular and visiting faculty. Repeatable two times. one 300-level DS or DH course.
prerequisites: one ES 300-level DS or DH course

title: Learner in the Environment I: Social and Cultural Contexts for Learning
description: Knowledge and skills related to the context of teaching. Teacher candidates will examine the impact of culture, family, school, classroom, and individual characteristics on learning, and orally present, in varied formats, acquired knowledge and competencies. A-F only.

title: Learner in the Environment II: Classroom and Behavior Management
description: Teacher candidates explore the ethical implications for establishing, maintaining, and restoring the classroom as an effective environment for teaching and learning. A-F only.

title: Learner in the Environment III: Behavior Project Implementation
description: Teacher candidates demonstrate the ability to establish, maintain, and (when necessary) restore the classroom as an effective environment for teaching and learning. Candidates demonstrate ability to identify maladaptive student behaviors and implement effective, research-based interventions. A-F only.

title: Assessment I: Foundations of Assessment
description: Introduction to foundational aspects of assessment and emphasizes the importance of linking assessment with planning and instruction. Candidates develop knowledge, skills, and dispositions important for designing, implementing, and analyzing effective assessments for diverse learners. A-F only.

title: Assessment II: Formal Assessment
description: Understand techniques in the assessment, planning, and instructional process appropriate for students with mild/moderate disabilities. Inclusion of students with disabilities in the general education environment is stressed. Significant instruction on writing individualized education programs. A-F only.

title: Planning and Instruction: Introduction to Inclusive Teaching
description: Teacher candidates engage in reflective, procedural, and research writing to differentiate instruction based on learner needs, planning to facilitate inclusion of students with disabilities in the general education environment through evidence-based practices. A-F only.

title: Planning and Instruction: Science
description: Examination of content, processes, strategies, and issues related to the teaching and learning of science in elementary settings, K-6. Candidates learn to differentiate instruction based on learner needs, using evidence-based practices. A-F only.

title: Planning and Instruction: Mathematics in Inclusive Settings
description: Prepares beginning elementary school teachers of mathematics, K-6. Candidates learn to differentiate instruction based on learner needs, planning to facilitate inclusion of students with disabilities in the general education environment through evidence-based practices. A-F only.

title: Planning and Instruction: STEM
description: Examination of content, processes, strategies, and issues related to teaching and learning of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) content for inclusive elementary classrooms, K-6. Teacher candidates focus on planning, teaching, and assessing STEM. A-F only.

title: Planning and Instruction: Integrating Social Studies and the Performing Arts
description: Social Studies and Performing Arts integrated content in diverse K-6 classrooms. Teacher candidates engage with social issues through collaborative, expressive, aesthetic, creative, and critical pedagogy. Candidates perform, present, and teach to develop oral communication skills. A-F only.

title: Planning and Instruction, Literacy I: Teaching Children to Read in Inclusive Settings, K-3
description: Overview of principles and practices for teaching reading (phonemic awareness, phonics, fluency, vocabulary, comprehension) to diverse students, grades K-3; including planning, instruction, and assessment. Writing assignments include lesson reflections, case studies, modules, and reading responses. A-F only.

title: Planning and Instruction, Literacy II: Teaching Children to Read in Inclusive Settings, Grades 4-6
description: Teacher candidates demonstrate essential reading comprehension strategies, engaging students in complex text by planning, instructing, and assessing elementary students in grades 4-6, in inclusive settings. Emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only.

title: Planning and Instruction, Literacy III: Writing and Visual Arts in Inclusive Settings, K-6
description: Methods, programs, and strategies for planning, teaching, and assessing writing for elementary students in inclusive settings, grades K-6. Visual arts methods are integrated to develop visual literacy. A-F only.

title: Field Experience I: Response to Intervention in Reading
description: Teacher candidates in this field based course will use an evidencebased practice in reading within a response to intervention (Rtl) framework. Supervision provided by participating site personnel and college supervisor. A-F only.

title: Field Rounds
description: Field-based course engages teacher candidates in a variety of purposeful observation and reflection activities aligned with course work. Field settings are appropriate to concurrent classes; supervision provided by participating site personnel and college supervisor. A-F only.

title: Field Experience II: Elementary and Special Education Classroom Settings
description: Teacher candidates are immersed in a general education, inclusion, or a self-contained special education field setting. A mentor teacher and a field supervisor from the university provide support and oversight. A-F only.

title: Field Experience III: Elementary and Special Education Classroom Settings
description: Teacher candidates are immersed in a general education, inclusion, or a self-contained special education field setting. A mentor teacher and a field supervisor from the university provide support and oversight. A-F only.

title: Student Teaching in Elementary and Special Education Classrooms
description: Full-time student teaching in grades K-6 in an elementary school inclusion classroom, or a combination of general education and special education settings. The experience is directed by a qualified mentor teacher and has university-provided supervision. A-F only.

title: Seminar for Student Teaching
description: Seminar to support student teaching experiences and prepare teacher candidates to transition into a full time teacher, examine ethical issues in the field, prepare for employment, and demonstrate ability to meet professional standards. A-F only.

title: Family Medicine and Community Health Longitudinal Clerkship
description: 5.5-month ambulatory clerkship. Students learn history taking, physical exam skills, and management of family medicine patients. Emphasis on behavioral care, caring for the underserved, sports medicine, preventive care, and common acute/chronic ambulatory problems. Repeatable one time. Co-requisite: third-year standing and concurrent registration in 532 courses.

title: (Alpha) Electives in Family Medicine and Community Health
description: Fourth-year elective in which medical students may do study of selected topics within the field of family medicine and community health: (B) primary care preceptorship; (C) topics in community health; (D) sub-internship in family medicine; (E) extramural elective in family medicine and community health-miscellaneous; (F) sports medicine preceptorship; (G) longitudinal underserved care preceptorship (6). MED majors only for (G). CR/NC only. 531 or 532. (Spring only for (G))

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Introduction to the Fashion Industry
description: Introduction to the fields of apparel design and merchandising including theories of fashion change, apparel industry operations, current industry issues, literature of the field, professional competencies, careers in apparel and related businesses. A-F only.

title: Culture, Gender, and Appearance
description: Social construction of gender within culture and its visual expression through appearance. Analysis of role, identity, conformity, and deviance in human appearance. Repeatable one time. Open to nonmajors. (

title: Basic Apparel Construction
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles, concepts, and procedures for quality construction and custom fitting of clothing.

title: Western World Fashion History
description: Historic study of dress as related to customs and cultures in the Western world, in sociohistorical and contemporary contexts. Emphasis on 19th and 20th centuries. 101.

title: Flat Pattern Design
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of pattern making for women’s apparel through manipulation of pattern blocks. 205.

title: Fashion Illustration
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles and techniques of sketching the fashion figure including garment details and fabric drape. Development of a personal style of illustration. Introduction to use of computers for illustration. 101.

title: Textiles I
description: Introduction to fibers, fabric structure, and finishes related to selection and care. Interrelationship between textile characteristics, properties, and end uses. Open to non-majors. A-F only.

title: Costumes/Cultures of East Asia
description: Development of ethnic dress of China, Japan, and Korea as a visual manifestation of culture. Students will be trained in written communication skills to describe and report important designs of these ethnic dresses related to culture.

title: Fashion Forecasting/Marketing
description: Principles and practices in fashion trend forecasting, including environment in analysis, consumer research, competitive analysis, color and textile forecasting, style directions, and digital marketing trends. Adapting fashion trend forecasts to apparel lines. Sophomore standing or higher. one FW or FG course, or consent.
prerequisites: one FW or FG course, or consent

title: Draping Essentials
description: Principles of pattern making through draping muslin models on standard garment forms. 205 and 215. (Spring only)

title: Specialty Market Design: Group Collection Development
description: Advanced study in the specialty market design, pattern making, and construction for fashion design majors. Different specialty designs, such as swimwear, menswear, or others, will be offered each semester. Repeatable five times. 215, 221, and 301. Recommended: 315, 330. (Spring only)

title: Textiles Quality Assurance
description: Chemical nature and structure of fibers and fabrics, their properties and finishes. FDM majors only. A-F only. 221 or consent. Co-requisite: 321L. (Spring only)

title: Textiles Quality Assurance Laboratory
description: Examination of textile properties through standardized textiles testing laboratory equipment. FDM majors only. A-F only. 221 or consent. Co-requisite: 321. (Spring only)

title: Advanced Apparel Design and Construction Techniques
description: Principles of advanced techniques for garment construction with emphasis on new, difficult-to-handle fabrics. Repeatable one time. 205 and 215.

title: 2D/3D Computer Aided Design
description: Exploration of CAD applications from the design to the pattern-making process. Use of Adobe Illustrator and Photoshop for fashion illustration. Use of OptiTex PDS pattern design software featuring 2D and 3D CAD. Repeatable one time.

title: 3D Retail Store Design
description: Visual merchandising concepts and planning; use of a virtual 3D store modeling software package. Visual Retailing/ Mockshop, to design store interiors, fixtures, lighting, signage, window displays, and planograms. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Writing for the Fashion Industry
description: Analysis and creation of different types of writing in the fashion industry, with emphasis on creating a professional writing style. A-F only. 101, 200 or 210, and 221.
prerequisites: FDM 101, FDM 200 or FDM 210, and FDM 221

title: Branding
description: Study of principles and practices in brand architecture and effective brand-building strategies; analysis of a case study and application of the concepts of brand management. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 101. (Spring only)

title: Retail Buying and Merchandising
description: Theories and procedures in selecting, buying and selling apparel and textiles. Types of merchandising organizations, analysis of consumer demand, brick-and-click opportunities and challenges, development of an image, operation location, store and floor layout. FDM majors only. 101 and 221.

title: Merchandise Planning and Control
description: Theories, problems, and procedures of financial and assortment planning and control of merchandise inventories. FDM majors and merchandising minors only. 371.

title: Product Lifecycle Management
description: Application of principles of apparel production management, including methods engineering (detail construction for ordering), story boards and color tables, production measurements, costing, and PLM computer applications. A-F only. 338 (Once a year)

title: Runway Design Collection Studio
description: Development of runway collection. Topic includes: inspirational research, developing aesthetic design, sketching, draping, drafting, patternmaking, muslin proofs, fittings, garment construction, and portfolio. FDM 420 enrollment required to showcase a collection in an annual fashion show. Repeatable three times. 210, 221, 315, 316, and 330. (Spring only)
prerequisites: FDM 210, FDM 221, FDM 315, FDM 316, and FDM 330

title: Fashion Show Production
description: Application of principles and procedures related to the promotion of fashion apparel. Preparation and presentation of fashion information through shows, displays, media, and written communications. Repeatable one time. 101. (Spring only)

title: Entrepreneurship in Retail
description: Application of principles, procedures and techniques of organizing a small retail business in a brick-and-click world. Students develop, write, and evaluate business plans creatively using low and high tech resources and oral communication skills. Junior standing or higher. FDM majors only; open to non-majors with instructor’s consent. one FS or FQ course, or consent.
prerequisites: one FS or FQ course, or consent

title: Costume Museum Management
description: Investigation of skills and techniques needed for handling textile and apparel artifacts in museums and other collections. Active involvement in documenting, researching, interpreting, and exhibiting costumes and textiles. Involves written work and oral presentations. Repeatable one time. FDM majors only. A-F only. 210, 269, or 418.

title: International Apparel Trade Issues
description: Theories, concepts, problems of international trade of textile and apparel products. Issues of importing and exporting apparel products globally. Social, economic, and ethical factors affecting textile and apparel trade.

title: Topics in Fashion
description: Study and discussion of special topics, problems. Offered by staff and visiting faculty. Repeatable five times.

title: Internship
description: Examination of issues and opportunities associated with careers in fashion and related businesses and industries. Topics include interpersonal skills development, job search and interview strategies, and ethical issues in the workplace. FDM majors only. A-F only. Junior standing or higher. consent.

title: Capstone Portfolio
description: Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills emphasizing professional development. Includes extensive instruction in writing and communication. 492 and senior standing.

title: Field Study in the Fashion Industry
description: Study tours to various centers of the world to examine historical and modern apparel and textiles. Merchandising and design methods and operations examined. Repeatable up to 12 credits. consent.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Repeatable up to 15 credits. consent.

title: Beginning Filipino
description: Listening, speaking, reading, writing skills. Structural points introduced inductively. Meets four hours weekly, includes one hour out-of-class field experience (Co-curricular cultural activities) weekly.

title: Beginning Filipino
description: Continuation of 101. 101 or consent.

title: Intermediate Filipino
description: Continuation of 102. Meets four hours weekly, includes one hour out-of-class field experience (Co-curricular cultural activities) weekly. 102 or consent.

title: Intermediate Filipino
description: Continuation of 201. 201 or consent.

title: Filipino for Education
description: Continuation of 102. Lessons focus on various aspects of Philippine culture and specialized topics that cater to the needs of teachers intending to teach Filipino immigrant students or teach Filipino as a second language. Meets five hours a week; daily lab work. 102.

title: Filipino for Education
description: Continuation of 202 or 224.

title: Third-Level Filipino I
description: Conversation, advanced reading and composition on traditional culture and indigenous knowledge. Includes emphasis on developing oral communication and written skills. Meets three hours weekly. 202 or 225, or consent.

title: Third-Level Filipino II
description: Conversation, advanced reading, and composition on contemporary issues. Meets three hours weekly. 202 or 225, or consent.

title: Accelerated Third-Level Filipino
