title: Filipino Aural Comprehension
description: Training in comprehension of spoken authentic/ simulated authentic materials presented in news broadcasts, songs, documentary narration, formal lectures, radio and television soap operas, etc. 202 or consent.

title: Filipino Film: Art and History
description: Study and analysis of Filipino films: its history, forms, development and relationship to cultural, social, philosophical, and aesthetic context. 202 or consent.

title: Fourth-Level Filipino I
description: Advanced reading in traditional literature; discussion of cultural implications; advanced oral communication and composition. Meets three hours weekly. 302 or consent.

title: Fourth-Level Filipino II
description: Advanced reading in current literature; discussion of cultural implications; advanced conversation and composition. Meets three hours weekly. 302 or consent.

title: Advanced Filipino Aural Comprehension
description: Continuation of 315. Training in comprehension and analysis/criticism of spoken authentic materials through films. 315 or consent.

title: Filipino Translation Techniques
description: Techniques of bilingual translation: Filipino to English and English to Filipino. A-F only. 302 or consent.

title: Structure of Filipino
description: Introduction to phonology, morphology, syntax. 202 or consent.

title: Filipino Contemporary Literature
description: Selected readings in poetry, short stories, and plays from early 1900s to present. Co-curricular cultural activities included. 302 or consent.

title: Personal Financial Planning
description: Focuses on principles and techniques for handling personal financial decisions, including: personal budgeting, obtaining credit, life and casualty insurance, buying a home, buying an automobile, savings and investments, and retirement planning.

title: Problems of Business Finance
description: Application of financial principles to cases involving important financial decisions; emphasis on writing. BUS 314.

title: Corporate Financial Management
description: Development and analysis of modern financial theory and its implications for management decisions: market efficiency, capital asset pricing, firm investment decisions, capital structure, dividend policy, and cost of capital. BUS 314.

title: Investments
description: Introduction to various investment media and capital markets. Topics include the analysis of security returns using techniques such as beta, filter rules, and portfolio theory. BUS 314 or consent.

title: International Business Finance
description: Financial management of foreign and international business operations: the regulatory environment of international finance, financing international transactions, international capital markets, taxation. Financial decision-making in the firm. BUS 314 or consent.

title: International Banking
description: Commercial, investment, and merchant banking. Includes theory and practical applications. Topics include international lending, Euromarkets, global gap management, Forex activities, and global risk management. BUS 314 or consent.

title: Financial Aspects of New Ventures
description: Examination of underlying business models for new ventures, how to determine corresponding financial requirements, and approaches to resource acquisition. Students explore a range of financing sources and related issues of valuation and deal structure. College restriction: Shidler students only. junior standing and BUS 314, or consent.
prerequisites: junior standing and BUS 314, or consent

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Reading and research in a special area of major under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by the department chair and the faculty advisor. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Options and Other Derivatives
description: Options and other derivatives. Equity options, index options and options on futures. Black-Scholos Model. Trading strategies and tactics. Contemporary developments in financial engineering. A-F only. 311 or consent.

title: Security Analysis and Portfolio Management
description: Security analysis and portfolio management from standpoint of the professional analyst and institutional investor. Recent advances in security valuation models, portfolio selection, and techniques for appraising portfolio performance. College restriction: Shidler students only. A-F only. 311.

title: Bank Financial Management
description: Analysis of financial institution management within the domestic economy and regulatory environment. Topics include federal reserve activities, interest rates, regulation, lending, investments, and asset/liability management. BUS 314.

title: Banking and Capital Markets
description: Covers the analytical skills necessary to work in the financial services industry, in particular in the bank treasury department or the fixed income capital market sector. A-F only. BUS 314 or consent. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Asian Finance
description: Financial systems, regulatory structure over financial institutions in the Asia-Pacific region. Major financial policy issues for financial sector reforms in the region. Seminar format. A-F only. BUS 314 or consent.

title: Enterprise Risk Management
description: Overview analyzing various primary risks faced by corporations and developing important risk management techniques with an emphasis on enterprise risk management. Combined lectures, case studies, and discussions. BUS majors only. A-F only. BUS 314 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Sustainable Finance
description: Explores criticism and defense of the traditional profit maximization business model. Economic theory, recent trends, and case studies will refine students’ understanding of this cutting-edge field. Repeatable one time. BUS 314 or TIM 305, or consent.

title: Special Topics in Finance, Real Estate or Insurance
description: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems in the field of finance and finance-related fields. Repeatable two times in different topics. BUS 314 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
prerequisites: BUS 314 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Seminar in Financial Planning
description: A capstone course for financial services and planning track. This is a case study course intended to provide students the opportunity to integrate concepts from earlier courses and develop a comprehensive view of the financial planning process. A-F only. 301 and 311 and two of the following courses: 490E, 490F, ACC 401, INS 300.
prerequisites: FIN 301 and FIN 311 and two of the following courses: FIN 490E, FIN 490F, ACC 401, INS 300

title: (Alpha) Advanced Topics in Finance
description: In-depth analysis of selected current practices and issues in finance. (B) equity research and corporate valuation methods; (C) Japanese financial management; (D) financial analysis; (E) retirement and employee benefit planning; (F) finance estate planning. Repeatable four times for (D). Shidler College of Business students only. A-F only for (E) and (F). 311 and BUS 314 for (B); BUS 314 or BUS 629 for (C); 311 or 629, or consent for (D); 301 for (E) and (F). (Fall only for (B))
prerequisites: FIN 311 and BUS 314 for (B); BUS 314 or BUS 629 for (C); BUS 311 or BUS 629, or consent for (D); BUS 301 for (E) and (F)

title: International Monetary Systems and Global Financial Markets
description: Supply and demand for capital in national and international markets. Nature of capital movements and role of capital in industrialization of regions and nations.

title: Problems in Business Finance
description: Application of financial principles and analytical techniques to financial problems. Case method. BUS 629 or consent.

title: Investment Analysis and Management
description: Techniques of security analysis, theories of investment, and the analysis of investment decisions related to portfolio planning. BUS 629 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Advanced Topics in Finance
description: Major current financial issues and problems. (C) Japanese financial management; (D) portfolio management theory; (F) stocks, bonds, and modern instruments. BUS 629 or consent.

title: Financial Analysis and Valuation
description: Introduces the standard financial analysis framework and develops skills in analysis of financial information, evaluation of firms’ business risks and earnings prospects, and related applications in valuation. Repeatable one time. BUS 629 or consent.

title: International Financial Management
description: Financial decision-making in an international setting: analysis of direct foreign investment; economic, accounting, and regulatory environments, including taxation; international money and capital markets; import and export financing; multinational working capital management; and risk aspects of international finance. BUS 629 or consent.

title: International Banking
description: Commercial, investment, and merchant banking in the international arena. Includes international lending, Euromarkets, global gap management, Forex activities, and international risk management. BUS 629 or consent.

title: Entrepreneurial Finance
description: Assessment of financial needs, arranging venture financing, assessing value to the entrepreneur and the investor(s), financial aspects of strategic planning, analyzing the tradeoffs between alternative financing choices and flexibility and control, harvesting the investment. BUS 629 or consent.

title: Advanced Capital Markets
description: Regulatory structure over capital market institutions, market developmental issues, market microstructure issues, and corporate governance, and creation of capital market infrastructure. Seminar format. BUS 629 or consent.

title: PDEs and Stochastic Calculus
description: Covers PDEs (Partial Differential Equations) and calculus in a stochastic environment. A-F only. graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent

title: Programming in Finance
description: Addresses programming principles, and programming languages used in financial modeling. A-F only. graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent

title: Portfolio Optimization
description: Introduces students to principles of capital markets, classical portfolio theory, and focus on portfolio optimization. A-F only. graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent

title: Financial Derivatives
description: Will familiarize the students with the mathematical foundation and the application of Futures, Swaps, and Options. A-F only. graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent

title: Financial Forecasting
description: Focus on financial forecasting and financial econometrics as volatility and correlation modeling. A-F only. graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent

title: Insurance and Risk Management
description: Introduces students to topics in the actuarial science and latest developments in risk management. A-F only. graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent

title: Interest Rate/Credit Models
description: Addresses specific properties of interest rate modelling as mean reversion as well as latest developments in credit risk modelling. A-F only. graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent

title: Financial Modelling
description: Addresses advanced techniques in financial modelling and related fields. A-F only. graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent

title: Mortgage/Weather Derivatives
description: Covers the real estate market, mortgage backed securities (MBSs) and real estate derivatives. Focuses on modelling weather, climate change, and weather derivatives. A-F only. graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent

title: Seminar in Finance
description: In-depth analysis of selected current practices and issues in finance. BUS 629 or consent. May be repeated with change in topic.

title: Research Seminar
description: Students either program a model or write a paper with high practical or scientific merit. Outcome enhances the chances for employment. Represents the culminating experience for students in this program. A-F only. graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in Financial Engineering program, or consent

title: Healthcare Financial Management
description: Focus on important accounting and financial management principles relevant to management of health services organizations. Designed around a series of cases that examine the issues that confront healthcare managers. A-F only. BUS 629. (Alt. years: fall only)

title: Foundations of Finance
description: First PhD course in finance. Covers basic theory and empirical methodology in asset pricing, provides a concise framework of conceptual knowledge to understand the literature on financial theory and related empirical evidence. A-F only. graduate students only.

title: Seminar in Investments
description: Covers research issues in investments. Topics include empirical asset pricing tests, characteristics of asset returns, behavioral finance, and investment issues that overlaps with corporate finance, accounting, and economics, etc. A-F only. PhD student status in business administration, or consent.
prerequisites: PhD student status in business administration, or consent

title: Corporate Finance
description: Covers research issues in corporate finance and financial markets. Topics include capital structure theory, corporate governance, corporate innovations, and mergers and acquisitions, etc. Student develop academic research papers that lead to dissertation work. A-F only. student status in PhD in business administration, or consent.
prerequisites: student status in PhD in business administration, or consent

title: Asian Finance
description: Provides in-depth review of scholarly journal articles and working papers relevant to Asian-Pacific financial markets to prepare PhD students for scholarly research work focusing on market microstructure, corporate finance, investments. A-F only. PhD student status in business administration, or consent.
prerequisites: PhD student status in business administration, or consent

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Reading and research in a special area of major under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by department chair and the faculty advisor. A-F only. PhD student status in international management, or consent.
prerequisites: PhD student status in international management, or consent

title: Principles of Insurance
description: Risk management and insurance application to business and personal financial decision-making. Introduction to basic risk management concepts and techniques. Analyze various types of insurance: including life, property, casualty, liability, health, disability, and long-term care.

title: Property and Casualty Insurance
description: Treatment of risk of financial loss of personal and business property and resulting loss of income occasioned by fire and allied perils. Forms of insurance used by individual business executives and firms including crime, transportation, liability, and worker compensation. 300.

title: Life Insurance
description: Treatment of the risk of premature death through use of various life insurance policies. Policy forms, calculation of premiums, reserves, non-forfeiture values, underwriting, regulation of policy provisions, related coverage. 300.

title: Principles of Real Estate
description: Principles affecting the allocation and utilization of real estate resources, including legal, physical, economic elements; valuation; market analysis; finance; investments, and public and private externalities affecting the allocation and utilization of real estate resources.

title: Real Estate and Environmental Law
description: Property rights, land tenure, agency, contracts and negotiation theory, title conveyancing and escrow, mortgage instruments, fair housing, state and federal environmental policy.

title: Real Estate Appraisal/Analysis
description: Analysis of real property, including feasibility analysis, market analysis, income property capitalization, and general real estate valuation techniques.

title: Administration of Real Property Assets
description: How business firms and investors manage their real property assets in terms of the legal, financial, and physical dimensions of real property. Case studies in hotels, condominiums, and office buildings in the environment in Hawai‘i. Business majors only.

title: Current Topics in Real Estate Analysis
description: Consideration of various special concepts and problems in real estate. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Reading and research in a special area within the major field under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by the department chair and faculty advisor. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Real Estate Finance and Investment
description: Financial and investment techniques used to evaluate real property and real estate security investments.

title: Real Estate Investment Analysis
description: Development of strategic business plans for the optimization of a firm’s real property assets. Includes facilities utilization audits, contingency planning, and the impact of new techniques.

title: Food Service Safety and Sanitation
description: Principles and procedures of sanitation and safety in the food service industry, including the study of foodborne illnesses, biological, chemical, physical hazards and cross-contamination as they may occur during the flow of food.

title: Culture and Cuisine: The Global Diversity of Food
description: A timeline of the world history of food and how it relates to culture, diversity, ethnicity, and religion. International food demonstrations and tastings included.

title: Introduction to Food Preparation
description: Lectures, discussions, and demonstrations on how food components contribute to the functional, sensory, and safety characteristics of foods, and what changes occur in foods due to preparation, processing, and storage. Co-requisite: 181L.

title: Food Preparation Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Experiments in foods emphasizing ingredient function and standard preparation methods for food groups. Co-requisite: 181.

title: The Science of Human Nutrition
description: Integration of natural science concepts basic to the study of human nutrition. Emphasis on nutrient requirements of healthy individuals, food sources, functions of nutrients.

title: Comparative Nutrition
description: Digestive systems and nutrient functions, interrelationships and metabolism are compared among animal species, including humans. An intermediate, general nutrition course for Food Science and Human Nutrition and Animal Science majors. (ANSC 200 (or concurrent), CHEM 161/161L or higher) with a minimum grade of C. (
prerequisites: (ANSC 200 (or concurrent), CHEM 161/CHEM 161L or higher) with a minimum grade of C

title: Food Service Systems Management
description: Critical and essential aspects of management and effective leadership practices to direct and delivery quality foodservices. Focus on the role and competencies of the Registered Dietitian (RD) working in these environments. (181 and 181L (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent.
prerequisites: (FSHN 181 and FSHN 181L (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent

title: Food Service Production and Operations
description: Principles and procedures of menu planning, quantity food production, production scheduling, recipe adaptation, equipment operation, and formula costing. Principles of procurement including purchasing, selection, storage of equipment and quantity foods. (181 and 181L) with a minimum grade of C, or consent.
prerequisites: (FSHN 181 and FSHN 181L) with a minimum grade of C, or consent

title: Marketing Nutrition and Food
description: (1 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Fundamental marketing principles applied to nutrition and food. Will include concepts such as the psychology of food purchasing decisions and consumer behavior. Field trips and group projects included. Open to non-majors. 181/181L, 185, 312; or consent.

title: Humans, Food, and Animals: Ethics, Issues, and Controversies
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Ethical issues and other controversies related to human and animal needs; their impact on resource sustainability and quality of life are explored from scientific perspectives. A-F only. 181 or 185 or ANSC 200 or ANSC 201. (
prerequisites: FSHN 181 or FSHN 185 or ANSC 200 or ANSC 201

title: Applied Professional Skills in Nutrition
description: Will apply skills in technology, research, and career development to nutrition. Students will identify evidence-based nutrition information and demonstrate their academic skill sets for future professional success through technology. 185 (with a minimum grade of B). (Summer only)
prerequisites: FSHN 185 (with a minimum grade of B)

title: Lifespan Nutrition
description: Physiological changes and nutritional requirements during human life stages: prepregnancy, pregnancy, infancy, childhood, adolescence, adulthood, and older adulthood. Includes an emphasis on writing instruction. B or better in 185; C or better in CHEM 161/161L; C or better in PHYL 142/142L (or concurrent)
prerequisites: B or better in FSHN 185; C or better in CHEM 161/CHEM 161L; C or better in PHYL 142/PHYL 142L (or concurrent)

title: Experimental Foods
description: Experimental approach to study food preparation problems. Applying basic food science research design to conduct experiments, interpret data and write reports. Subject matter used to practice critical thinking and problem solving skills. A-F only. (181/181L, CHEM 161/161L) with a minimum grade of C. Co-requisite: 381L.
prerequisites: (FSHN 181/FSHN 181L, CHEM 161/CHEM 161L) with a minimum grade of C

title: Experimental Foods Laboratory
description: Experimental approach to study food preparation, food formulation, and sensory evaluation with laboratory exercises in a certified kitchen environment. Applying basic food science research design to conduct experiments, interpret data and write reports. A-F only. (181/181L, CHEM 161/161L) with a minimum grade of D. Co-requisite: 381.
prerequisites: (FSHN 181/FSHN 181L, CHEM 161/CHEM 161L) with a minimum grade of D

title: Nutritional Assessment
description: Addresses concepts and uses of nutrition assessment tools at individual and community levels. Students will be introduced to national surveys and new, more sophisticated body composition measurements. Includes an emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only. (185 and 370 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C.
prerequisites: (FSHN 185 and FSHN 370 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C

title: Microbiology of Foods
description: Microorganisms encountered in foods; types of food spoilage; microbial hazards in food; methods of food preservation. (MICR 130 and MICR 140L, or MICR 351 and MICR 351L) with a minimum grade of C; or consent.
prerequisites: (MICR 130 and MICR 140L, or MICR 351 and MICR 351L) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Food Engineering
description: Principles and applications of thermodynamics, electricity, fluid mechanics, heat transfer, psychrometry, and material and energy balances of food processing and preservation. (BIOL 171, CHEM 162 or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A, MATH 243 or MATH 253A, PHYS 151 or PHYS 170) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: (BIOL 171, CHEM 162 or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A, MATH 243 or MATH 253A, PHYS 151 or PHYS 170) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Sensors and Instrumentation for Biological Systems
description: Design course focused on fundamentals of electronic interfacing, control and automation, including biological processes. Topics include sensor physics, basic instrumentation, digital communication, and programming of microcontrollers and other portable computer systems. (ECE 160, ECE 211, and BE 350 or MATH 302 or MATH 307 or ECE 326) with a minimum grade of C; or consent.
prerequisites: (ECE 160, ECE 211, and BE 350 or MATH 302 or MATH 307 or ECE 326) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Food Chemistry
description: Chemical properties of food constituents studied in relationship to their effects on processing, nutrition, and spoilage. CHEM 161 and 161L or consent.

title: Food Chemistry Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Application of different chemical methods in the study of food constituents—proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, pigments, enzymes, etc. 430 (or concurrent).

title: Food Safety
description: Discussion of potential microbiological, parasitic, chemical, and natural food hazards; food laws and standards; and related aspects of consumer protection. (181, BIOL 171, and CHEM 272) with a minimum grade of C; or consent.
prerequisites: (FSHN 181, BIOL 171, and CHEM 272) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Food Quality Control
description: Fundamental principles of quality control in the food industry: measurement of quality parameters, utilization and integration of the individual test procedures into grades and standards of quality, sampling, and reporting results.

title: Community Nutrition and Nutrition Education
description: (4 Lec) Concepts and methods of nutrition program planning and nutrition education; analysis of nutritional problems of local, national, and international communities; strategies used to educate groups or individuals. A-F only. (370 and either HDFS 380 or NREM 310) with a minimum grade of C; or consent.
prerequisites: (FSHN 370 and either HDFS 380 or NREM 310) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Foundation of Childhood Obesity Prevention in the Pacific
description: Provide students with a basic overview of the causes and effects of childhood obesity, evidence-based approaches, community-based research, and policies to prevent childhood obesity as it relates to the Pacific region. 185 (with a minimum grade of B). (Summer only)
prerequisites: FSHN 185 (with a minimum grade of B)

title: Childhood Anthropometric and Dietary Assessment Field Techniques
description: Teaches techniques for measuring anthropometry and collecting dietary intake in children. Online course imitates hands-on training through partnering with local organizations and the use of technology. Repeatable one time. 185 (with a minimum grade of B). (Summer only)
prerequisites: FSHN 185 (with a minimum grade of B)

title: Child Health and Nutrition Monotiring
description: Covers topics related to health and nutritional status monitoring and surveillance, including epidemiology, biostatistics, health and nutrition surveillance systems, and the uses of technology for conducting these activities. Repeatable one time. 185 (with a minimum grade of B). (Summer only)
prerequisites: FSHN 185 (with a minimum grade of B)

title: Culture and Child Health in the Pacific
description: In-depth study of Pacific culture, land, people, and history and its relationship to child health. Explores cultural competency, cultural safety, and multidisciplinary approaches to promote a healthy Pacific. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing. 185 (with a minimum grade of B). (Summer only)
prerequisites: FSHN 185 (with a minimum grade of B)

title: Food Processing Operations
description: Principles and applications of food dehydration, thermal processing, low temperature preservation, chemical and biochemical preservation, irradiation, packaging, manufacturing, plant sanitation, water and waste management. 403 and 430, or consent.

title: Medical Nutrition Therapy I
description: Development of dietary, anthropometric and clinical lab assessment skills measuring nutritional status. Understanding pathophysiology of disease processes, medical terminology and nutritional intervention, utilizing case studies. Dietetics majors only. (389 and 486) with a minimum grade of C or consent.
prerequisites: (FSHN 389 and FSHN 486) with a minimum grade of C or consent

title: Medical Nutrition Therapy II
description: Understanding of the pathophysiology of disease processes and nutritional intervention, using medical terminology and case studies. Dietetics majors only. 467 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent.
prerequisites: FSHN 467 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent

title: Nutrition Counseling Skills
description: Theory and practice in nutritional counseling. Combined lecture and discussion on nutrition/dietary counseling. Knowledge and theories. Application through lab experiences including role playing, case presentations, and performing actual counseling sessions. A-F only. 467 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Applied Human Nutrition
description: Application of basic nutrition principles; includes sources and functions of essential nutrients and food patterns compatible with nutrient needs, health, disease prevention, and sustainability. Intended for undergraduate and graduate students. CHEM 161 (or higher) or BIOC 241 (or higher); PHYL 141, BIOL 171; or consent.
prerequisites: CHEM 161 (or higher) or BIOC 241 (or higher); PHYL 141, BIOL 171; or consent

title: Cultural Aspects of Food Habits
description: Study of eating from behavioral perspectives. Implications for health practitioners and health education. two classes from ANTH 151 or higher or SOC 100 or higher or PSY 100 or higher.
prerequisites: two classes from ANTH 151 or higher or SOC 100 or higher or PSY 100 or higher

title: Food Analysis
description: Principles of sample preparation and chemical and physical analysis of food components using current methodology. 430; and CHEM 162 or higher; and BIOL 402 or MBBE 402 or PEPS 402.
prerequisites: FSHN 430; and CHEM 162 or higher; and BIOL 402 or MBBE 402 or PEPS 402

title: Food Analysis Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) Application of different chemical and physical methods for the identification and quantitation of food components. Co-requisite: 477.

title: Nutrition in Exercise and Sport
description: Effects of physiologic demands of exercise on nutrition. Emphasis on physiologic and biochemical basis for nutrition recommendations to enhance exercise participation and optimize athletic performance. (185, and PHYL 103 or 141 or 301) with a minimum grade of C. (
prerequisites: (FSHN 185, and PHYL 103 or PHYL 141 or PHYL 301) with a minimum grade of C

title: Nutritional Biochemistry I
description: Metabolism and biochemistry of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins, including chemical structure, digestion, absorption, transport, cellular/molecular functions in human nutrition; integration of metabolic pathways; energy metabolism and balance, including relevance to chronic disease. 185; PHYL 142/142L or PHYL 302/302L; BIOC 341 or higher (or concurrent) or MBBE 402 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: FSHN 185; PHYL 142/PHYL 142L or PHYL 302/PHYL 302L; BIOC 341 or higher (or concurrent) or MBBE 402 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Nutritional Biochemistry II
description: Metabolism and biochemistry of vitamins, minerals, and dietary fiber, including chemical structure, digestion, absorption, transport, and cellular/ molecular functions in human nutrition; relevance to establishing nutrient requirements and to mechanisms of chronic disease. 485 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent.
prerequisites: FSHN 485 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent

title: Obesity, Science, and Issues
description: In-depth study of obesity, including research, etiology, treatment, and prevention. 485 with a minimum grade of C.
prerequisites: FSHN 485 with a minimum grade of C

title: Topics in Food Science and Human Nutrition
description: Study and discussion of significant topics, problems, or laboratory experiments. Repeatable unlimited times. instructor approval.

title: Field Experience
description: Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills emphasizing professional development. Placement with an approved cooperating supervisor/employer. Writing a learning plan and field report. A-F only. senior standing in FSHN. (

title: Food Science Capstone
description: Field practicum designed to integrate knowledge from previous FSHN courses to develop novel and innovative food products. Students deal with shelflife, marketing, packaging, labeling, sensory evaluation, and quality assurance. Repeatable one time. FSHN majors only. A-F only. (381 and 460) with a minimum grade of C, or consent.
prerequisites: (FSHN 381 and FSHN 460) with a minimum grade of C, or consent

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: The Science of Food Systems
description: (1 50-min Lec, 1 2-hr discussion) Discussion of food systems as they apply to animal science, food science, and human nutrition. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent. (

title: Advanced Food Science I
description: Advanced topics in chemical and physical characteristics of foods as well as their role in human nutrition. Repeatable one time. A-F only. graduate student status with undergraduate courses in organic chemistry, microbiology, additional biological science, physics, and biochemistry. Basic knowledge of food science is expected; or consent. (
prerequisites: graduate student status with undergraduate courses in organic chemistry, microbiology, additional biological science, physics, and biochemistry

title: Advanced Food Science II
description: Advances in sensory quality and evaluation, deterioration of foods and food safety, as well as food processing technology. Repeatable one time. A-F only. graduate student status with undergraduate courses in organic chemistry, microbiology, additional biological sciences, physics, and biochemistry. Basic knowledge of food science is expected; or consent.
prerequisites: graduate student status with undergraduate courses in organic chemistry, microbiology, additional biological sciences, physics, and biochemistry

title: Advanced Food Safety
description: Real and perceived food hazards, their ethical issues and implications, advanced emerging topics in food safety, and controls, including laws and regulations of food safety issues and public perception of food safety will be discussed. A-F only. graduate student status with undergraduate courses in biochemistry, microbiology, food processing, physics and organic chemistry. Basic food science knowledge is required; or consent.
prerequisites: graduate student status with undergraduate courses in biochemistry, microbiology, food processing, physics and organic chemistry

title: International Nutrition
description: Analysis of major nutrition problems in developing countries. Comparative review of the design, implementation, and evaluation of programs to intervene in the development of malnutrition. 185 or consent.

title: DNA and Genetic Analysis
description: Combined lecture-lab for students interested in genetic analysis of humans, animals, and other species. Molecular techniques, such as PCR, DNA marker identifications, transgenics, expression analysis and functional genomics, are included. Open to nonmajors. graduate standing or consent. (

title: Information Research Skills
description: Examines the use of libraries and information technology for scholarly investigation in support of scientific research; provides experience utilizing and critically evaluating a variety of print and electronic sources in basic and applied sciences. consent. (

title: Grant Writing for Graduate Students
description: Combined lecture/discussion on grants and grant writing. Designed to introduce graduate students to grants and grant proposal writing through lectures, class discussion, writing assignments, and peer review. Open to CTAHR graduate students only; others with consent. (

title: Dietetics Supervised Practice
description: ISPP activities and assignments completed at designed facilities in community, clinical, food service, and other settings that stress planning, delivery, and evaluation of dietetics services to individuals and populations. Repeatable two times. MS Nutritional Sciences students only. Graduate students only. A-F only. admission to the Individualized Supervised Practice Pathway program and consent.
prerequisites: admission to the Individualized Supervised Practice Pathway program and consent

title: Advanced Topics in Dietetics
description: Advanced topics in professional dietetics practice. Students will further their knowledge and skills in professional practice areas of dietetics; including clinical, community, and food systems management. Repeatable one time. MS Nutritional Sciences students only.

title: Seminar in Food and Nutritional Sciences
description: Student presentation of literature reviews and research. Repeatable five times. consent.

title: Topics in Nutritional Sciences
description: Advanced topics in nutritional sciences, from basic to applied research, including current issues in nutrition and critical analysis of current research literature. Repeatable three times, up to 12 credits. consent.

title: Global Nutrition
description: Examination of global food and nutrition problems, programs, issues, policies, and strategies for improvement. A-F only. statistics and consent. (Alt. years: fall) (

title: Supplemental and Nutritional Approaches in Disease Prevention and Treatment
description: Examines a variety of issues associated with nutritional and supplemental approaches to reduce disease incidence, morbidity, and mortality in relation to public health prevention strategies. PH majors only. (

title: Nutrition and Disease: Cellular and Molecular Aspects
description: In-depth lecture, discussion, and student presentations on selected topics relating nutrition to the etiology and prevention of chronic diseases at the cellular and molecular level. Repeatable one time. (485 and 486) with a minimum grade of C; statistics; or consent.
prerequisites: (FSHN 485 and FSHN 486) with a minimum grade of C; statistics; or consent

title: Advanced Child and Adolescent Nutrition
description: Addresses nutrition, growth, and development in children and adolescents and nutrition-related issues, such as childhood obesity and chronic disease risk factors, with a focus on current research in the Pacific region. 370 or consent. (Fall only) (

title: Advanced Lab Techniques
description: (1 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Advanced laboratory techniques used in food science and human nutrition research. A-F only. graduate standing or consent and 477 and MBBE 402/402L; or BIOC 441. (
prerequisites: graduate standing or consent and FSHN 477 and MBBE 402/MBBE 402L; or BIOC 441

title: Indigenous Peoples’ Food Systems, Environment and Health
description: Explores Indigenous Peoples’ food systems as local food resources Indigenous People acquire through specific cultural knowledge of traditional territories. Global forces transforming these food systems and their impact on population health and nutrition are explored. Graduate students only. (

title: Nutritional Epidemiology
description: Dietary, biochemical, anthropometric and clinical methods used for evaluating nutrition and diet in the etiology and epidemiology of disease. 685 and PH 663, or consent. (

title: Plan B Master’s Project
description: Independent study for students working on a Plan B Master’s project. A grade of Satisfactory (S) is assigned when the project is satisfactorily completed. A-F only. graduate standing in nutritional sciences.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Topics in Food Science
description: Advanced topics in food science and technology, from basic to applied research, including current issues in food science and technology and critical analysis of current research literature. Repeatable one time. A-F only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Epidemiology of Diabetes and Obesity
description: Provides an overview of the epidemiology and prevention of metabolic syndrome, diabetes, and associated complications. Discusses methodological issues associated with evaluating these in epidemiologic studies. A-F only. 663 (with a minimum grade of B-) or consent. (
prerequisites: FSHN 663 (with a minimum grade of B-) or consent

title: Dietary Fiber, Bioactive Food Components and Health
description: Lecture/discussion of current research on gut physiology, gut microbes, dietary fiber, bioactive food components, and their impact on health, including colorectal cancer, inflammatory bowel disease, heart disease, diabetes, and immune function. 485 and 486 (or equivalent), statistics, physiology; or consent.
prerequisites: FSHN 485 and FSHN 486 (or equivalent), statistics, physiology; or consent

title: Diet and Cancer Seminar
description: Presentation-discussion of selected research topics in the field of diet-cancer relationships including: nutritional epidemiology of cancer, diet and supplement intervention trials, and cellular/molecular effects of diet on cancer pathophysiology. Repeatable one time. 685 and 689, or consent.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation in nutrition. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate standing only. Satisfactory/ Unsatisfactory only. candidacy for PhD in Nutrition.

title: Elementary French
description: Conversation, grammar, and reading.

title: Elementary French
description: Conversation, grammar, and reading. 101 or consent.

title: Intensive French-Elementary
description: Content of 101-102 covered in one semester.

title: Intermediate French
description: Reading, conversation, laboratory drill, composition. 102 or 110 or consent.

title: Intermediate French
description: Continuation of 201. 201.

title: Intensive French-Intermediate
description: Content of 201-202 covered in one semester. 102 or 110 or consent.

title: Intermediate French Abroad
description: Intensive course of full-time formal instruction on the second-year level in French language and culture in a French-speaking country. 102 or 110 or consent.

title: Intermediate French Abroad
description: Continuation of 258.

title: French Phonetics
description: Analysis of phonological system; methods of teaching pronunciation; understanding various types of spontaneous speech. Drills in pronunciation, intonation, stress, and rhythm. 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
prerequisites: FR 202 or FR 210 or FR 259 or consent

title: Reading in French
description: Development of language skills through reading of cultural and literary texts. 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
prerequisites: FR 202 or FR 210 or FR 259 or consent

title: Structure of French
description: Structure of contemporary French as analyzed by descriptive linguists. 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
prerequisites: FR 202 or FR 210 or FR 259 or consent

title: Business French
description: Reading and writing commercial materials. 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
prerequisites: FR 202 or FR 210 or FR 259 or consent

title: Conversation
description: Systematic practice for control of spoken French. Further development of vocabulary for accurate, mature expression. 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
prerequisites: FR 202 or FR 210 or FR 259 or consent

title: Composition
description: Emphasis on strengthening facility with language through further training in syntax, structure, and composition writing. 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
prerequisites: FR 202 or FR 210 or FR 259 or consent

title: Advanced Conversation
description: Systematic and advanced practice for control of spoken French, advanced development for accurate, mature expression. 311 or consent.

title: Survey of French Literature
description: Major authors and movements. 311 (or concurrent) and 312; only 311 may be concurrent.
prerequisites: FR 311 (or concurrent) and FR 312; only FR 311 may be concurrent

title: Survey of French Literature
description: Continuation of 331. 311 (or concurrent) and 312; only 311 may be concurrent.
prerequisites: FR 311 (or concurrent) and FR 312; only FR 311 may be concurrent

title: Third-Level French Abroad
description: Intensive formal instruction at the third-year level in French language skills: reading, writing, grammar, or conversation in a French-speaking country. 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
prerequisites: FR 202 or FR 210 or FR 259 or consent

title: Third-Level French Abroad
description: Continuation of 358.

title: Intensive Third-Level French Abroad
description: Intensive formal instruction at the third-year level in French language skills: reading, writing, grammar, or conversation in a French-speaking country. 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
prerequisites: FR 202 or FR 210 or FR 259 or consent

title: Contemporary French Civilization
description: Survey of culture and institutions of modern France. 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
prerequisites: FR 202 or FR 210 or FR 259 or consent

title: Survey of French Civilization
description: A historical survey of the development of French culture. The course is interdisciplinary, focusing on the relations between politics, literature, science, and the arts. A-F only. 202 or 210 or 259 or consent.
prerequisites: FR 202 or FR 210 or FR 259 or consent

title: (Alpha) Topics in French Literature
description: (B) French film; (C) the Fantastic; (D) Francophone literature. Repeatable two times with consent. 311 or 312, or consent.

title: Directed Reading
description: Independent study of approved reading with faculty supervision. Repeatable two times. A-F only. consent.

title: Advanced Oral and Written Expression
description: Further development of listening, comprehension, speaking, and writing skills through viewing of French videotapes, reading French newspapers, frequent oral and written reports. 311 and 312, or 306, or 358, or 360; or consent.
prerequisites: FR 311 and FR 312, or FR 306, or FR 358, or FR 360; or consent

title: French-English Translation
description: Practice in techniques based on contrastive linguistics. Translation of texts from various fields from French into English and the reverse. 306 or 309, and 312; or consent.
prerequisites: FR 306 or FR 309, and FR 312; or consent

title: Masterpieces of Medieval Literature
description: Samplings from epic, novel, verse and prose, tale, lyric poetry, chronicle, theater, didactic literature. Elementary readings in original text in editions giving modern French translation. 331 or consent.

title: Advanced Language Study: French
description: Advanced course in spoken and written French with intensive review of alternative grammatical structures and shades of meaning in the modern language. Graduates who have not taken may request consent. 306 or 405 (or equivalent); or consent.

title: Masterpieces of 16th-Century Literature
description: Samplings from all major writers of the period. Readings in original text in editions giving modern French equivalents for difficult words. 331 or consent.

title: Masterpieces of 17th-Century Literature
description: Principal works of major dramatists: Corneille, Moliere, Racine. Principal movements and major authors of non-dramatic prose and poetry. 331 or consent.

title: Masterpieces of 18th-Century Literature
description: 332 or consent.

title: 19th Century French Prose and Poetry
description: Study of representative prose and poetry of the major trends of 19th century France: romanticism, realism, symbolism, aestheticism. 332 or consent.

title: 20th-Century French Theater
description: Major French playwrights and their works: Claudel, Giraudoux, Anouilh, Sartre, Camus, etc. 332 or consent.

title: 20th Century French Prose and Poetry
description: Study of representative prose and poetry of the major trends of 20th century France: modernism, surrealism, existentialism, postmodernism and multiculturalism. 332 or consent.

title: Fourth-Level French Abroad
description: Intensive course of full-time formal instruction on the fourth-year level in French linguistics, civilization, culture, and literature in a French-speaking country. 359 or 360 or equivalent.

title: Fourth-Level French Abroad
description: Continuation of 458.

title: Intensive Fourth-Level French Abroad
description: Intensive course of formal instruction on the fourthyear level in French language, culture and literature in a French-speaking country. For semester programs only. 360 or equivalent.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in French Literature
description: (B) French literature by period; (C) Francophone literature; (D) French film; (E) topic in French literature. Repeatable two time per alpha. 331 (or concurrent) and 332 (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: FR 331 (or concurrent) and FR 332 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Independent study of approved readings and research with faculty supervision. Repeatable two times. A-F only. consent.

title: French for Reading Proficiency
description: Reading of scholarly and technical French for graduate students; open to undergraduates with consent of department chair. Not applicable to undergraduate language requirement. Repeatable two times with consent. CR/NC only.

title: Seminar in 20th-Century French Literature
description: Authors and movements of modern period.

title: French Renaissance
description: Poetry, theater, prose. Emphasis on Montaigne and Rabelais. Lectures, discussions, reports.

title: Masterpieces of the 17th Century
description: Dramatic or prose works of the classical period.

title: Philosophic Currents in 18th Century
description: Philosophic movements and their impact on the social, political, and literary life of the period and the modern era.

title: Advanced French-English Translation: Practice and Theory
description: Advanced practice in translation into French and from French to English in various fields (literature, business, medicine, other), with reflection on choices. Readings in translation theory. Repeatable one time.

title: History of the French Language
description: Origins and development of French language in its cultural context. Contrastive analysis.

title: Seminar in Medieval Literature
description: Genesis and evolution of literary genres from the 12th to 15th centuries. Epic, romance, lyric poetry, prose, and drama.

title: Seminar: The Novel in France
description: Novels which have influenced movements or established techniques. Repeatable two times with consent.

title: The Theater in France
description: Historical development; major dramatists who have influenced movements or established techniques. 6 credit hours at 400 level.
prerequisites: FR 6 credit hours at FR 400 level

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent of department chair.

title: Seminar in French Literature
description: Study of authors or a period. Repeatable two times with consent. consent of instructor and French graduate advisor.
prerequisites: consent of instructor and French graduate advisor

title: The Natural Environment
description: Introduction to physical geography including weather, climate, vegetation, soils, geology, and landforms. Environmental issues and natural hazards. (

title: The Natural Environment Lab
description: A survey of field and laboratory methods commonly used by physical geographers. 101 (or concurrent). (

title: World Regional Geography
description: World’s major cultural regions; geographic aspects of contemporary economic, social, political conditions.

title: Digital Earth
description: Cartographic representation and meaning in a digital age. Earth models, map projections, coordinate systems, scale, distance, and direction. Data types and transformations in graphic and digital representation. Manual, automated, and web-based map making and analysis.

title: Geography and Contemporary Society
description: Elements of economic geography and resource management, population and urban geography; application to current problems of developed and underdeveloped worlds.

title: Introduction to Climatology
description: Elements and controls of climate. World patterns of insolation, temperature, evaporation, precipitation, atmospheric circulation. Climatic classifications. 101 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200, or consent.
prerequisites: GEO 101 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200, or consent

title: Global Environmental Issues
description: Use and abuse of natural resources and humanity’s progress toward developing a sustainable relationship with its supporting environment. A-F only. (Once a year) (

title: General Geomorphology
description: Introduction to geomorphological concepts, process mechanics, and relationships between forms and processes. Emphasis on various subdisciplines of geomorphology: coastal hillslopes, fluvial, aeolean, and glacial. 101 and 101L, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 101L.
prerequisites: GEO 101 and GEO 101L, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 101L

title: Water and Society
description: Interaction of people with water at household, community, regional, national, and international scales, from cultural, political, economic, and biophysical perspectives. sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: sophomore standing or higher, or consent

title: Introduction to Biogeography
description: Introduction to ecosystem concept; environmental adaptations for energy and nutrient transfer; characteristics, dynamics, productivity, and distribution of principal vegetation communities. Human dominance. sophomore standing or higher, or consent.
prerequisites: sophomore standing or higher, or consent

title: Introduction to Planning
description: Perspectives on planning; planning tools and methods; specific Hawai‘i planning–research problems from a multidisciplinary approach. junior standing or consent.

title: Tropical Agrarian Systems
description: Analysis of environmental potential and constraints and of spatial organization of economy and society of tropical agrarian systems. Emphasis on change through colonial and post-colonial periods.

title: Economic Geography
description: Examines how factors of production like land, labor and capital; economic activities like consumption, trade, production, and investments; and institutions like state, markets, and corporations alter economic space. A-F only. 102 or 151. (Fall only)

title: Globalization and Environment
description: Debates on globalization and development, population and resources; root causes of environmental degradation; impacts of globalization on environmentalism and environmental change; social approaches to managing environmental change. Junior standing or higher. (

title: Geography of Global Tourism
description: Tourist landscape in relation to resources, spatial patterns of supply and demand, impacts of tourism development, and models of tourist space. Flows between major world regions. Sophomore standing or higher. consent. (

title: Geography, Environment, and Society
description: Examines the geography of resources and environmental change with a holistic and multi-scale perspective. Social approaches to resolving environmental problems. (

title: Culture and Environment
description: Critically examines changing views of nature, nature-culture relationships, and perceptions of the environment across different cultures. (

title: Islands and Archipelagos
description: Applies an island studies perspective to critically evaluate the commonalities and differences across islands and archipelagos in several world regions. Examines how island geographies influence social identities and movements and are impacted by environmental conditions. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. (

title: Politics, Nations, and States
description: Examines the political organization of space in the sovereign state system. Contemporary and historical analyses of boundaries, geopolitics, homelands, nations, nationalism, and territory. sophomore standing or higher, or consent.
prerequisites: sophomore standing or higher, or consent

title: Geography of North America
description: Overview of the physical and cultural geography. Regions and characters. Patterns of population, natural resources, industry, agriculture, and transportation/ communication networks. 101 or 102 or 151, or consent.
prerequisites: GEO 101 or GEO 102 or GEO 151, or consent

title: Intersectional Feminist Geographies
description: Explores space and place from intersectional feminist perspectives including Indigenous, Black, island, post-colonial and queer geographies. Focuses on contemporary case studies in gender and sexuality. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Geography of Japan
description: Regional synthesis of physical and cultural features; economic, social, political geography; origins and development of cities.

title: Geography of China
description: Topics: environmental parameters and resource base, ecological control and resource management, institutional and technological transformation of agriculture, industrial potential and industrial location, settlement patterns and rural urban symbiosis.

title: Geography of South Asia
description: Introduction to physical and human geography of India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Himalayan kingdoms. Environmental, economic, social, cultural, and political factors in development.

title: Geography of Southeast Asia
description: An investigation of the development context of Southeast Asia including socioeconomic, cultural, and environmental resources. Problems and prospects for change. (

title: Geography of the Pacific
description: Physical character of the Pacific; cultural, political, economic geography of Melanesia, Micronesia, Polynesia (except Hawai‘i).

title: Geography of Honolulu
description: Development of Honolulu and O‘ahu from 1778. Evolution of function, land use, and social patterns. Contemporary planning and environmental issues arising from urban growth.

title: Geography of Hawai‘i
description: Regional, physical, cultural geography. Detailed study of people and resources.

title: UAV and Aerial Photography
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to UAV (unmanned aerial vehicle systems) and the measurement, interpretation, analysis, and use of photography acquired by UAV and other aerial systems.

title: Introduction to Cartography and Air Photo
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of cartography: compilation and measurement from aerial photographs, alternate forms of data presentation, symbolism, design, and map projection.

title: Map Design and Production
description: (3 2-hr Lab) Compilation, design and production of maps for presentations, research, and illustration using artists and mapping software. junior standing or higher, or consent.
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Statistical Methods in Geography
description: Quantitative statistical methods will be explored for describing and interpreting geographic/environmental phenomena. Topics will include data display, measurement, sampling, spatial statistics, dimensional analysis, nonparametric and parametric models. 101 or 102 or 151 (or concurrent) or consent.
prerequisites: GEO 101 or GEO 102 or GEO 151 (or concurrent) or consent

title: Introduction to GIS
description: Design, implementation, and use. Database construction and documentation. Techniques for spatial data manipulation and display. Evaluation of existing systems. Student research projects.

title: Directed Reading
description: Limited to senior majors with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or a minimum GPA of 3.0 in geography.

title: Vegetation and the Climate System
description: Role of vegetation in the climate system; links to hydrology and biogeochemical cycling; vegetation and climate history; evolution of terrestrial ecosystems; effects of global warming. 101 or 300 or 401 or 402 or 405 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200 or ATMO 302 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310, or consent.
prerequisites: GEO 101 or GEO 300 or GEO 401 or GEO 402 or GEO 405 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200 or ATMO 302 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310, or consent

title: Climate Change
description: Approaches to the study of past and future climate change. 101 or 300 or 401 or 402 or 405 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200 or ATMO 302 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310, or consent.
prerequisites: GEO 101 or GEO 300 or GEO 401 or GEO 402 or GEO 405 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200 or ATMO 302 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310, or consent

title: Agricultural Climatology
description: Analyzing climatic data; relation to photosynthesis, phenological development, and crop yields. Crop-weather models as guides to improved land-use planning and agronomic practices. 101 or 300 or 400 or 401 or 405 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200 or ATMO 302 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310, or consent.
prerequisites: GEO 101 or GEO 300 or GEO 400 or GEO 401 or GEO 405 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200 or ATMO 302 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310, or consent

title: Fluvial Geomorphology
description: Introduction to the single most important geomorphic agent shaping the terrestrial environment. Focus on fluvial process, fluvial dynamics, fluvial landforms, and sediment transport. 101/101L or 303 or ERTH 101/101L.

title: Climate, Air Quality, & Policy
description: Examination of air quality problems from scientific and policy perspectives. Includes case studies that explore economic, political, technical, and legal aspects of pollution control. junior standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Water in the Environment
description: Water fluxes in the environment. Occurrence and movement of water; methods of quantification. Water balance of soil-plant system: precipitation, interception, infiltration, runoff, soil moisture, evapotranspiration, and groundwater recharge. 101 or 300 or 400 or 401 or 402 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200 or ATMO 302 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310, or consent.
prerequisites: GEO 101 or GEO 300 or GEO 400 or GEO 401 or GEO 402 or ATMO 101 or ATMO 200 or ATMO 302 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310, or consent

title: Conservation and Evolutionary Biogeography
description: Theories and techniques for the analysis of spatial microevolutionary patterns, taught from an interdisciplinary perspective. Examples and readings emphasize Hawai‘i and the Pacific region. either 309, BIOL 265 or BIOL 487, or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: either GEO 309, BIOL 265 or BIOL 487, or consent

title: Cultural Biogeography
description: Coevolution of human societies and plants over the last 10,000 years. Foraging, farming and urban societies economies; spread and modification of selected plants; issues of preservation of genetic resources and traditional plant knowledge. The form and function of gardens. A-F only. junior standing or higher, or consent.
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Human Role in Environmental Change
description: Human impacts through time on vegetation, animals, landforms, soils, climate, and atmosphere. Special reference to Asian/Pacific region. Implications of long-term environmental change for human habitability. with a minimum grade of B, one of 101, BIOL 101, BIOL 123 and either 322 or BIOL 310; or consent. (
prerequisites: with a minimum grade of B, one of GEO 101, BIOL 101, BIOL 123 and either BIOL 322 or BIOL 310; or consent

title: Past Global Change and the Human Era
description: Study of past environments to understand present and future global change. Focus on terrestrial Quaternary environments and global processes. junior standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Environmental Impact Assessment
description: Introduction to analytical methods for identifying, measuring, and quantifying the impacts of changes or interventions in resource, human-environment, and other geographic systems. junior standing or higher, or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Resource Management in Southeast Asia
description: Challenges associated with the management of land, water resources, fisheries, forests and agriculture in modern Southeast Asia. Case studies are used to illustrate current problems and evaluate potential management solutions. A-F only. junior standing or higher. (

title: Environmental Hazards and Community Resilience
description: Investigation of the forces behind natural and technological hazards, and human actions that reduce or increase vulnerability to natural disasters. Junior standing or higher.

title: Nature-Based Tourism Management
description: Principles of nature-based tourism, including a survey of impacts, objectives, planning, and management systems. Junior standing or higher. 324/TIM 324 or TIM 101. (

title: Urban Geography
description: Origins, functions, and internal structure of cities. Problems of urban settlement, growth, decay, adaptation, and planning in different cultural and historical settings. Dynamics of urban land use and role of policies and perceptions in shaping towns and cities. 102 or 151 or 330, or consent. (
prerequisites: GEO 102 or GEO 151 or GEO 330, or consent

title: Agriculture, Food and Society
description: Examines historical and contemporary development of the global agro-food systems. The impacts of technological, political and economic changes to food security, environment and development. Open to non-majors. junior standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Marine Policy
description: Introduction to the law and policies concerning the marine environment, commerce and security. Role of science, law and politics in historical and current policies for maritime trades, navigation safety, marine resources, and marine exploration. junior standing or higher, or consent.
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Regional Analysis
description: Spatial dynamics and environmental implications of urban and rural development. Concepts of regions, process of regional development, patterns of spatial interaction, and theoretical bases for development strategies; emphasis on Hawai‘i. junior standing or higher, or consent.
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Geographies of Popular Culture
description: Examines contemporary geographical debates related to concepts of discourse, identity, space/place, power, representation, and popular culture. Considers various landscapes of popular culture and how popular culture mediate a sense of place, geopolitics, and identity formation. junior standing or higher, or consent.
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Environment, Resources and Society
description: Human interaction with the environment. How market, property institution, and technological change affect the environment. Epistemological basis of environmental policies. Debates on controversial environmental issues. 102, 151, or consent. (

title: Tea and Culture
description: Examines cultural practices of tea in different parts of the world, focusing on history and culture of tea in China, Japan, and England. Also includes changing technologies and economies of tea worldwide. Junior standing or higher.

title: Gender, Fashion, & Globalization
description: Explores ethics of the present and historic expansions of the fashion industry and its environmental impact globally. Examines how gender/race/class shape garment production and consumption and fashion activism in world regions. Emphasis on oral/written communication. A-F only. Junior standing or higher. (

title: Political Geography of Oceans
description: The geopolitics of the oceans and the law of the sea as applied to regions of conflict and cooperation in marine resource development and preservation. Focus on Indo-West Pacific, South China Sea, Arctic Ocean. junior standing or higher, or consent.
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Geography of Peace and War
description: Geographical factors underlying conflict in the world. sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: sophomore standing or higher, or consent

title: Environment and Society in China
description: Explores the relationship between environment and society in the Chinese society, including both traditional nature-culture connections and modern human-environmental issues. Examines China’s long-range cultural change, environmental transformations, and modern development challenges. 102 or 151, or consent.

title: Topics in Geography
description: Selected topics in geography not offered in the regular geography curriculum. 101 or 102 or 151, or consent.
prerequisites: GEO 101 or GEO 102 or GEO 151, or consent

title: Remote Sensing
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to the principles of remote sensing and image processing skills. Topics include electromagnetic spectrum, sensors, aerial photo and satellite imagery interpretation, geometric and radiometric correction, digital image processing. Research project, lab. 370 or consent.

title: 3D Mapping and Analysis
description: Environmental mapping and analysis using 3-dimensional geographical data acquired from high resolution remote sensing systems. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Field Mapping
description: Techniques for field measurement and recording of cultural and physical data. Field sketching, Brunton surveying, plane table mapping, oblique photo compilation, topographic mapping, and representation of field data. junior standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Web Mapping
description: (3 2-hr Lab) Introduction to interactive web mapping techniques for sharing and visualizing various forms of geospatial data. Requires basic knowledge about GIS. consent.

title: GIS and Spatial Analysis for Social Sciences
description: Introduction to spacial analysis and GIS for social science studies, using open-source GIS tools to collect, visualize, and analyze social data; public health, socio-economic and social media data. Requires basic knowledge about GIS.

title: GIS for Environmental Sciences
description: (2 Lec, 1 2-hr lab) Applications of GIS technologies to solve real-world problems in natural and environmental sciences. Research project, lab. 388 or consent.

title: Senior Thesis
description: Preparation of research paper under individual faculty supervision. Recommended for admission to graduate program. senior GEO major and consent.

title: Practicum in Geography
description: Internship in applied geography under professional and faculty supervision. Field placement integrated with academic study. Repeatable up to six credit hours maximum. senior major and consent.

title: Capstone Undergraduate Seminar
description: Current and historical geographic literature provides a background for local and global issues. Through discussion, written reviews, and research reports, the geographic perspective in modern life will be explored. senior GEO major.

title: Directed Research
description: Geography majors conduct research under faculty supervision on a topic of their choice. Minimum GPA of 3.0 and consent. Repeatable two times, up to six credits. GEO majors only. Senior standing only.

title: Seminar in Climatology
description: Methods of determining energy budget and water balance; applications in agriculture, hydrology, climatic classifications. Theory of climatic change. Bibliography. 300 or 400 or 401 or 402 or 405 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310 or ATMO 320; or consent.
prerequisites: GEO 300 or GEO 400 or GEO 401 or GEO 402 or GEO 405 or ATMO 303 or ATMO 310 or ATMO 320; or consent

title: Cultural Geographies of Tourism
description: Social and cultural analysis of tourism practices, with emphasis on Hawai‘i, Asia and the Pacific. Tourism in relation to consumer culture, transnational flows of people and images, post-colonial politics, performance and identity formation. (

title: Human Environment Systems
description: Role and potential of systems science in analysis of human environment interaction, especially resource management. Framework and methodology for problem structuring; overview of techniques. graduate standing or advanced undergraduate standing with consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing or advanced undergraduate standing with consent

title: Theories and Policies of Development
description: Will critically examine what constitutes progress, advancement, or betterment in this highly uneven world, where inter-regional, inter-class, inter-group, and inter-gender differences in development are expanding. Graduate standing only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Coastal Planning and Management
description: Theory and practice of coastal planning and management in the U.S. and abroad. Case studies investigate topics such as coastal land conservation, marine protected areas, coastal hazards, fisheries, and aquaculture. Repeatable one time with consent.

title: Advanced Environmental Impact Assessment
description: Theory and practice of environmental impact assessment. Policy and planning frameworks supporting environmental assessment in the U.S. and abroad. Cumulative environmental effects and strategic environmental assessment. (

title: Seafood in Southeast Asia
description: Seafood production in Southeast Asia, including both regional fisheries and aquaculture. Case studies used to illustrate challenges to the implementation of sustainable seafood production and emerging approaches, such as community supported seafood. (

title: Environment and Development
description: Theories and practice of development; how changing development paradigms shape different ideas concerning the environment and the management of natural resources; emerging debates in development and environment in post-modern era. (

title: Community-based Natural Resource Management
description: Concepts and theories of community, resource access, and governance. Practical challenges to CBNRM in contemporary political economy. Graduate students only. (

title: Seminar in Geography of Southeast Asia
description: Repeatable with consent of instructor. consent.

title: Seminar in Geography of the Pacific
description: Investigation of geographic problems of Melanesia, Micronesia, Polynesia. Repeatable with consent of instructor. consent

title: Geospatial Analysis of Natural Resource Data
description: The application of geostatistics to estimate spatial dependence to improve soil and regional sampling; provide insight into underlying soil, geographic, and geologic process, and to provide quantitative scaling up of point measurements to fields, regions, and watersheds. State-space modeling also will be included. A-F only. 388 or ZOOL 631; or consent. (

title: Human Geography Research Methods
description: Introduction to research methods in human geography. Explores and provides guided practical experience with research methods and analysis.

title: Faculty Seminar Series
description: Graduate seminar required of all department MA students and PhD students. Single credit course in which faculty present ongoing research in their fields. consent. Co-requisite: 695.

title: Technology and Natural Risks Methods of Analysis
description: Survey of tools for evaluating risks to human health from technological and natural hazards. Historical and international context of methods.

title: Concepts and Theories in Geography
description: Concepts, theory, models. Geographic approaches to spatial and environmental problems. Required of entering graduate students unless waived by department. consent.

title: Research Design/Methods in Geography
description: Elements of research design, practical field experience, exposure to research and ideologies, broad exposure to heritage and ethos of the discipline. 695.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Geomorphology
description: Current understanding of geomorphological concepts, processes, and the dynamic relationship between human landscape modification and system response. consent.

title: (Alpha) Special Topics
description: Study and discussion of significant topics, problems. (B) regional and locational analysis; (C) geography, environment, and culture; (H) Multi-objective decision analysis. Repeatable two times.

title: Political Ecology
description: Introduction to political ecology. Content will examine the historical development of and contemporary scholarship in political ecology from a human and environmental geography perspective.

title: Seminar: Resource Management in Asia-Pacific
description: Examination of resource management problems in Asia and the Pacific. Problems of resource use—agriculture, forestry, energy, minerals, ocean, air quality. graduate status.

title: Seminar: Political Geography
description: Topics vary; may include borders, boundaries, geopolitics, homelands, identity politics, nations and nationalism, social categorization, the sovereign state system, territoriality. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent. (Once a year)

title: Seminar: Geographies of Migration
description: Topics vary; may include immigration, borders, refugees, asylum, climate change, and displacement. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Society and Space
description: Advanced seminar on social production of space. Topics include spatial metaphor in social theory; western spatiality from the renaissance through the enlightenment, modernity and post modernity; and geography of the body, home, landscape, and nation. graduate standing or consent.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Geriatric and Palliative Care
description: Provides an overview of geriatric and palliative medicine in the outpatient, inpatient, homecare, and long-term care settings. Various instructional methods are utilized, including clinical experiences, workshops, and case discussions using a range of interdisciplinary teachers.

title: Geriatric Medicine Research
description: Medical students will have the opportunity to complete a research project in the field of epidemiology of aging, and present an abstract at a local meeting. Basic principles of epidemiology and statistics will be taught. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. departmental approval.

title: Geriatric and Palliative Medicine Elective
description: F\Provides an overview of geriatric and palliative medicine in the outpatient, inpatient, homecare, and long-term care settings.
