Various instructional methods are utilized, including clinical experiences, workshops, and case discussions using a range of interdisciplinary teachers. CR/NC only.

title: Medical Student Training in Aging Program
description: Introduces medical students to clinical, research, and academic experiences in geriatrics, under the mentorship of faculty members. MD majors only. CR/NC only. MDED 554 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: One-on-one independent study for students interested in geriatrics and/or palliative medicine. Students will work with a faculty mentor to define an area of interest and meet regularly for guidance and feedback. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.

title: Elementary German
description: Conversation, grammar and reading.

title: Elementary German
description: Conversation, grammar and reading. 101.

title: Intensive Elementary German
description: Combined content of 101 and 102 covered in one intensive course. (Summer only)

title: Intermediate German
description: Conversation, grammar, reading and writing. 102.

title: Intermediate German
description: Conversation, grammar, reading and writing. 201.

title: Intensive Intermediate German Abroad
description: Intensive course of formal instruction on the second-year level in German language and culture in Germany. 102.

title: Phonetics and Pronunciation Practice
description: Analysis of the German phonological system and practice in pronunciation. 202 (or concurrent with consent) or 260.
prerequisites: GER 202 (or concurrent with consent) or GER 260

title: Structure of Modern German
description: Study of syntactic and morphological structures and basic pragmatic principles. Focuses on spoken and written Modern German. 202 or 260.

title: Reading and Writing
description: Further development of reading and writing skills through the study of short texts, focusing on modern German short stories, fairy tales, poems and song lyrics. 202.

title: Business German
description: Advanced German conversation, reading, and writing with a special emphasis on the vocabulary and cultural context of the German business world. 202 or consent.

title: Contemporary Topics in Media
description: Development of listening and speaking, reading and writing skills through analysis and discussion of media: newspaper articles, radio, and television programs and online sources. 202 or consent.

title: Conversation
description: Intensive practice in spoken German designed to increase vocabulary and improve oral proficiency. 202 (or concurrent with consent) or 260.
prerequisites: GER 202 (or concurrent with consent) or GER 260

title: Modern Readings: Wanderlust, Love, and Desire
description: Development of reading skills through the study of authentic modern texts (short stories; articles from newspapers, magazines, and the internet) with topics relating to culture, society, and history. 202 or consent.

title: Modern Readings: Freedom, Happiness and Free Body Culture
description: Further expansion and improvement of reading skills through the study of authentic modern texts (short stories; newspaper articles, and internet) with topics relating to culture, society, and history, e.g., FKK Freikörperkultur, or ‘free body culture’. 202 or consent.

title: Introduction to German Literature 1750- 1914:
description: Reading and discussion of representative works of German literature from 1750 to 1914. 303 or consent.

title: Introduction to German Literature 1914-Present
description: Reading and discussion of representative works of German literature from 1914 to present. 303 or consent.

title: German Cinema
description: Study of German film history, film analysis, film theory, and film study. Lecture/discussion. Repeatable one time, or take LLEA 320 one time, for different topics. 6 cr. limit on GER/LLEA 320 courses. 303 or 306.

title: Intensive Third-Level German Abroad
description: Intensive course of formal instruction on the third-year level in German language and culture in Germany. 202 or 260.

title: Germanic Civilization to World War II
description: German cultural heritage and history in Germany, Austria, and Switzerland until World War II. 202 or consent.

title: Modern German Culture
description: Modern culture in post-World War II Germany, Austria, and Switzerland. 202 or consent.

title: Practical German for use in Hawai‘i
description: Use of German in practical situations in Hawai‘i, e.g., in travel industry. 202.

title: Enlightenment—Sturm und Drang
description: Lessing and his contemporaries; early dramas of Goethe and Schiller; Goethe’s early lyrics. 306 or consent.

title: Classicism
description: Classical writings of Goethe and Schiller; some reference to other writers. 306 or consent.

title: Romanticism
description: Novalis, Tieck, E. T. A. Hoffmann, Eichendorff, etc. 306 or consent.

title: Culture of Two Germanies: 1945-1989
description: (taught in German) Literature, culture, and film of East and West Germany, 1945-1989. Credit cannot be earned for both LLEA 415 and GER 415. 306 or consent.

title: German Literature, Culture and Film: 1989 to Present
description: Study of German literature, culture and film, 1989 to present. Credit cannot be earned for both 416 and LLEA 416. 303 or 306 or consent.

title: Intensive Fourth-Level German Abroad
description: Intensive course of formal instruction on the fourth-level in German language and culture in a German-speaking country. 360 or equivalent.

title: Global Environmental Science Seminar
description: Seminar to introduce new GES majors to the research interests of GES faculty and the research facilities available within SOEST. Restricted to GES majors. CR/NC only. (Fall only) (

title: Introduction to the Environment, Climate Change, & Sustainability
description: Introduction to the environment, climate change, and sustainability as they apply to ecosystems. Sustainability will be introduced through active learning exercises that address sustainable development and the three pillars of sustainability. Repeatable one time. A-F only. ((

title: Introduction to the Environment and Sustainability Lab
description: Introduction to a variety of quantitative and qualitative approaches and methodologies to describe and assess key components to the environment. A-F only. 102 (or concurrent) or OCN 102 (or concurrent) or SUST 112 (or concurrent). (
prerequisites: GES 102 (or concurrent) or OCN 102 (or concurrent) or SUST 112 (or concurrent)

title: GES Thesis Proposal
description: Supports GES majors in producing a thesis proposal that outlines and describes the timeline, required resources, etc. of the degree-required project. CR/NC only. GES majors only. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Global and Local Perspectives on Severe Weather
description: Dynamics and structure of the main types of severe weather (tropical cyclones, supercell storms, tornadoes, flash floods, hailstorms, fog, etc.); future changes due to climate change; risk assessment; severe weather in Hawai‘i. ATMO, GES, GG, GEO, GES, NREM, or OCN students only. A-F only. (Alt years: Spring) (

title: The Changing Earth and Climate System
description: Covers the Earth system, including mass and energy transfers, biogeochemical cycles, natural and anthropogenic changes on regional and global scale. GES majors only. MATH 241, and GES 302 (or concurrent) and OCN 201 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: MATH 241, and GES 302 (or concurrent) and OCN 201 (or concurrent)

title: Global Environmental Change Laboratory
description: (2-hr Lab) Laboratory to supplement GES 311. Quantitative aspects of global environmental change will be addressed through problem-solving and computer modeling. GES majors only. A-F only. 311, MATH 242, PHYS 170/170L, and CHEM 161/161L; or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: GES 311, MATH 242, PHYS 170/PHYS 170L, and CHEM 161/CHEM 161L; or consent

title: Aquatic Pollution
description: Pollution of freshwater and marine systems by human activities. Causes, consequences, and correctives. GES majors only. 201, CHEM 161, BIOL 171. (

title: Environmental Data Science
description: Provides an introduction to environmental data science by applying python-based programming techniques to Earth science datasets. GES majors only. A-F only. MATH 242, and ICS 110P or ICS 110C or ERTH 250. (Spring only)
prerequisites: MATH 242, and ICS 110P or ICS 110C or ERTH 250

title: Directed Reading
description: Directed reading in earth system science, oceanography, or environmental science. Repeatable up to 6 credits. GES majors only. consent. (

title: Biogeochemical Systems
description: Relationship of biogeochemical cycles in the atmosphere, lithosphere, and biosphere to global chemical cycles and planetary climatic conditions. GES degree foundation and capstone course with an emphasis on improving student writing skills. GES majors only. Senior standing only. A-F only. OCN 201, GES 311, BIOL 172/172L, CHEM 162/162L, ERTH 101/101L, GES 319L (or concurrent), ATMO 200 (or concurrent), and GES/OCN 499 (or concurrent); or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: OCN 201, GES 311, BIOL 172/BIOL 172L, CHEM 162/CHEM 162L, ERTH 101/ERTH 101L, GES 319L (or concurrent), ATMO 200 (or concurrent), and GES/OCN 499 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Earth’s Microbiome
description: Lecture on the diversity and function of the Earth’s microbiomes, inclusive of terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems, symbiotic and free living microorganisms with a focus on the microbial underpinnings of the Earth’s biogeochemistry. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. OCN 102 or OCN 201 or BOT 305 or BIOL 305, or BIOL 171 and BIOL 172. (Alt years: Fall) (
prerequisites: OCN 102 or OCN 201 or BOT 305 or BIOL 305, or BIOL 171 and BIOL 172

title: Earth’s Microbiome Lab
description: Lab on the diversity and function of the Earth’s microbiomes, inclusive of terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems, symbiotic and free living microorganisms with a focus on the microbial underpinnings of the Earth’s biogeochemistry. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. OCN 102 or OCN 201 or BOT 305 or BIOL 305, or BIOL 171 and BIOL 172. (Alt years: Fall) (
prerequisites: OCN 102 or OCN 201 or BOT 305 or BIOL 305, or BIOL 171 and BIOL 172

title: Data Analysis in Earth Science
description: Combined lecture, discussion, and laboratory on global Earth system databases and satellite instrumentation, including computer laboratory. GES majors only. A-F only. MATH 242; or consent. (

title: Advanced Environmental Data Science
description: Advanced applications of environmental data science: combine data with Bayesian inference, make predictions using artificial neural networks, and analyze data in space and time using the Python language with biological and geophysical datasets. GES majors only A-F only. 302 and 371 and MATH 242. (Fall only)

title: Communication of Research Results
description: Lecture/discussion to provide instruction and experience in oral and written presentation of scientific results and material. GES majors only in their final semester. A-F only. GES/OCN 499 (or concurrent). (

title: Undergraduate Thesis
description: Directed research in which the student carries out a scientific project of small to moderate scope with one or more chosen advisors. The student must complete a document in the style of a scientific journal article. Repeatable up to six credits. GES majors only. consent. (

title: Elementary Greek
description: Grammar and vocabulary, with reading of simple Greek.

title: Elementary Greek
description: Continuation of 101. 101.

title: Intermediate Greek
description: Development of reading and translation skills. Emphasis on prose. 102 or equivalent.

title: Intermediate Greek
description: Continuation of 201: emphasis on poetry. 201.

title: Greek Historians
description: Selections from Herodotus, Xenophon, and others. 201 and 202, or consent.

title: Greek Epic
description: Selections from Homer, Hesiod, and others. 201 and 202, or consent.

title: Greek Philosophy
description: Selections from Plato, Aristotle, and others. 201 and 202, or consent.

title: Greek Drama
description: Selections from Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripides. 201 and 202, or consent.

title: Greek Lyric
description: Selections from Sappho, Alcaeus, and others. 201 and 202, or consent.

title: Seminar in Greek Studies
description: Study of an author or phase in Greek studies. Repeatable unlimited times with consent. any two 300-level GRK courses, or consent.
prerequisites: any two GRK 300-level GRK courses, or consent

title: Language in Hawai‘i: A Microcosm of Global Language Issues
description: Survival kit for life in Hawai‘i: Introduction to Hawaiian and language related issues enhancing communicative experience in Hawai‘i. Examination of social, cultural, political, and linguistic cross-cultural interaction locally and globally. Taught in English/Hawai‘i Creole English.

title: Elementary Hawaiian I
description: Introductory course in Hawaiian language focused on the foundational skills of language acquisition: speaking, listening, comprehension, reading, writing, and cultural understanding.

title: Elementary Hawaiian II
description: Continuation of 101. 101 or exam or consent.

title: Intensive Elementary Hawaiian
description: Content of 101 and 102 (Elementary Hawaiian I & II) covered in one semester.

title: I Ka ‘Olelo No Ke Ola
description: Accelerated lecture/lab to bridge fluent speakers mainly from Kula Kaiapuni into Kawaihuelani’s system of Hawaiian that reflects a Hawaiian worldview, including HAW 101-201 content, grammar, writing, and spelling conventions. Students matriculate into HAW 202. instructor consent required. (Spring only)

title: Intermediate Hawaiian I
description: Continuation of 102 with continued development in the foundational skills of language acquisition: speaking, listening, comprehension, reading, writing, and cultural understanding. Increased emphasis on reading or traditional texts. 102 or 105 or exam or consent.
prerequisites: HAW 102 or HAW 105 or exam or consent

title: Intermediate Hawaiian II
description: Continuation of 201. 201 or exam, or consent.

title: Intensive Intermediate Hawaiian
description: Content of 201 and 202 covered in one semester. Meets two hours daily, plus lab work. 102 or 105, or exam.

title: Hawaiian Literature in Translation
description: Survey of Hawaiian literature, including prose narration and poetry with reference to Polynesian and Western themes and forms.

title: Papa Mele I (Mele in the Hawaiian Language Classroom)
description: The incorporation of mele and the performance thereof for the enhancement of second language acquisition in Hawaiian. 102.

title: Third-Level Hawaiian I
description: Continuation of 202 with emphasis on increasing proficiency in speaking/conversation, listening, comprehension, reading, writing, and cultural understanding. Conducted in Hawaiian. 202 or 206 or exam, or consent.
prerequisites: HAW 202 or HAW 206 or exam, or consent

title: Third-Level Hawaiian II
description: Continuation of 301. 301 or exam, or consent.

title: Hawaiian Conversation
description: Systematic practice on various topics for control of spoken Hawaiian. Repeatable up to six credit hours. 202 or consent.

title: Mo‘olelo Pōkole
description: Development of reading comprehension, pronunciation, vocabulary, and Hawaiian cultural knowledge through reading of Hawaiian language short stories. Short stories are from primary and secondary sources written by a variety of authors across different time periods. 202 or consent.

title: Hawaiian Composition
description: Intensive work in the grammatical, semantic, and pragmatic dimensions of composition writing in Hawaiian. 202.

title: Listening Comprehension and Transcription
description: Development of listening comprehension through transcription and discussion of tape recordings. 202.

title: Ulu ka Hoi
description: Lecture offering focused study and creation of Hawaiian language newspapers with a concentration on the characteristics of writing in this genre. Students will produce a monthly newsletter in Hawaiian. Repeatable one time. 302 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Ka Mo‘omeheu Hawai‘i
description: A survey course on the study of traditional Hawaiian culture including origins, the socioeconomic system, land tenure, religion, values, and the arts. The course will be taught in Hawaiian. 302 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Hana ‘Oe a Kani Pono-Hawaiian Radio Broadcasting
description: Combined lecture/lab involving students in the planning and production of a weekly Hawaiian language radio broadcast. Includes research, writing, and voicing of mele and their stories on live radio. Repeatable one time. 302 or 384 (or concurrent with consent), or consent.
prerequisites: HAW 302 or HAW 384 (or concurrent with consent), or consent

title: Ka Haku Mele
description: Composers and Their Compositions. Provides a venue which will allow students to analyze, dissect and discuss mele (song, poetry and chant), paying close attention to the style of composition by identifying reoccurring nuances found in mele composed by the same as well as various authors. completion of 202 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Fourth-Level Hawaiian I
description: Advanced speaking/conversation, discussion, listening comprehension, reading, writing, and cultural understanding. Conducted in Hawaiian. Transcribing and translating recordings of native speakers in Hawaiian. 302 or exam, or consent.

title: Fourth-Level Hawaiian II
description: Continuation of 401. 401 or exam, or consent.

title: Mo‘olelo Hawai‘i
description: Survey of the major works by Hawaiian scholars writing about the history and culture of Hawai‘i including David Malo, Kamakau, Kepelino, and John Papa Î‘i. 302.

title: Ka‘ao Hawai‘i
description: Survey of the core literature written by Hawaiian scholars, including both historical and mythological epics and folk tales. 302.

title: I Le‘a Ka Hula I Ka Ho‘opa‘a (Mo‘olelo, Ka‘ao, Mele and Hula)
description: The incorporation of mele and hula performance with mo‘olelo and ka‘ao. 302 or consent.

title: Ka Mana‘o Politika Hawai‘i–Political Thought in Hawaiian
description: Intensive study of Hawaiian political thought in writing and speech. 302 (or concurrent) or consent. (

title: Ka Hō‘ike Honua
description: Study of Hawaiian land tenure practices through readings and discussions of audiotapes, written primary sources, maps, wind names, rain names, ‘Ōlelo no‘eau (wise sayings), and mele (poetry). Readings are drawn from 19th and 20th century Hawaiian newspapers and other primary sources. 302 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Ma Ka Hana Ka ‘Ike
description: Study of traditional Hawaiian language and cultural practices through hands-on applications and lectures. 302 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Haku Mo‘olelo–Creative Writing in Hawaiian
description: Study and composition of written works in various creative genres of Hawaiian storytelling, with a focus on the adaptation and maintenance of a Hawaiian voice and worldview in writing. 302 and 331.

title: I Pa‘a Ke Kahua
description: An experiential approach to the acquisition of vocabulary, which will allow students to broaden and deepen their knowledge of language and the range of domains to perpetuate Hawaiian as a living language. Repeatable one time. 302 (or concurrent), or consent.

title: E Pū Pa‘akai Kākou: A Study of Traditional Hawaiian and Contemporary Food Culture
description: A study of traditional Hawaiian and contemporary food culture through hands-on applications and lectures. 302 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: (Alpha) Problems in Translation
description: Problems in translation of: (B) legal documents; (C) newspapers; (D) religious writings. 302 or consent.

title: Na Politika ma ka Nuhou Hawai‘i– Politics in Hawaiian Language Media
description: Study of Hawaiian news media with emphasis on political content. Includes field trips to various archives. 302 (or concurrent), or consent. (

title: Structure of Hawaiian
description: Descriptive linguistic analysis. Intensive exercises in advanced grammar. 302 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: ‘Ōlelo Ni‘ihau I
description: Basic study of ‘Olelo Ni‘ihau. Speaking and listening comprehension will be developed through listening to audio recordings, watching video recordings, and participating in faceto-face conversations with Ni‘ihau native speakers. 402 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: History of the Hawaiian Language
description: Development from proto-Polynesian. Phonology, morphology, and grammar; history of research. 302 (or concurrent) and 452, or consent.
prerequisites: HAW 302 (or concurrent) and HAW 452, or consent

title: (Alpha) Ha‘uki: Sports Education Through the Medium of Hawaiian
description: Provide Hawaiian language students with linguistic tools necessary to provide sports education to Hawaiian immersion schools and for basic intergenerational use of Hawaiian in the linguistic domain of sports. (B) basketball; (C) volleyball; (D) football; (E) baseball. Repeatable for other topics.

title: Language for the Classroom
description: Examination of language needs in various classroom settings and introduction to new vocabulary in school content areas. 302, 452, and consent.

title: Kuleana Kula Kaiapuni
description: Examination of the political struggles of the Kula Kaiapuni (Hawaiian Immersion Program)–past and present. Special attention given to federal and state governments, Department of Education, and internal political struggles. 401 (or concurrent with consent).

title: Ho‘omōhala Ha‘awina Kaiapuni Curriculum Development
description: Examination of curricular issues of indigenous language programs; weekly participation in an immersion classroom; development of materials. Repeatable one time. 302 or consent.

title: Teaching in Hawaiian Language Immersion Program
description: Explore the knowledge base needed for teaching in the Hawaiian Language Immersion Program and initiate inquiry into the nature and social context of teaching, learning and schooling. 302 or consent.

title: Teaching Residency
description: Full-time student teaching in a Hawaiian language classroom. CR/NC only. 302 and 463; or consent. Co-requisite: 476.

title: Seminar in Teaching Residency
description: Analysis and resolution of issues in teaching residency; teaching strategies and techniques; curriculum planning, professional growth and development. 302 and 463; or consent. Co-requisite: 475.

title: Papa Mele Wahi Pana
description: Will provide students with the opportunity to learn mele, mainly poetry and song, composed specifically for a certain area of Hawai‘i. 302 or consent.

title: Hawaiian Poetry
description: Historical survey and analysis of poetry found in traditional chants, folk songs, modern poetry written in Hawaiian. Interpreting and composing Hawaiian poetry. 302 and consent, or 401.

title: Haku Hanakeaka–Hawaiian Language Playwriting
description: The creation and authoring of Hawaiian language play scripts based on traditional motifs. Repeatable one time. 402 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Kahua Hanakeaka (Hawaiian Medium Stage Production)
description: From design to performance, students mount an original production based on traditional motifs. Repeatable one time. 402 (or concurrent), or consent.

title: ‘Ōlelo No‘eau
description: Survey and analysis of traditional proverbs and their kaona or symbolic meanings. A-F only. 402 or consent.

title: Ka Mākau‘Ōlelo A‘o Kula Kaiapuni Hawai‘i
description: Assess the linguistic competence of prospective Hawaiian language immersion teachers to assure that all teachers entering the state DOE Hawaiian Immersion Program meet the requirements of the program with respect to Hawaiian language proficiency. CR/NC only. 402 (or concurrent), and 463 (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: HAW 402 (or concurrent), and HAW 463 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Analyzing Immersion Hawaiian
description: Analysis and acquisition of features in Hawaiian spoken by Hawaiian speaking children in Hawaiian immersion education. 302 and 452, or consent.

title: Learning Hawaiian Through Immersion
description: Learning Hawaiian in the immersion setting: cultural context, behavioral patterns, and learning concerns. 302, and either 435 or 484; or consent.
prerequisites: HAW 302, and either HAW 435 or HAW 484; or consent

title: Directed Studies
description: Study of Hawaiian language through vernacular readings in various academic fields. Repeatable up to 6 credits. 302 and consent.

title: Kākau Mo‘olelo
description: Analyzes various genres of written Hawaiian literature. HAW majors only. graduate standing and 402, or consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing and HAW 402, or consent

title: Kākā‘ōlelo Oratory
description: A survey of oral performance styles to build increased oral skills. graduate standing and 601, or consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing and HAW 601, or consent

title: Haku Palapala Noi Laeo‘o/Writing a Hawaiian Master’s Proposal
description: Seminar to select and develop students’ research topic, proposal, and organizational plan for Plan A or B completion. Majors are encouraged not to take this course in their first semester of the program. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Ka Hana Noi‘i (Research Methods)
description: Research methodology course utilizing active research in the major repositories of Hawaiian language materials and Hawaiian-related knowledge. A-F only. 604 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Nā Mana‘o Politika Hawai‘i (Hawaiian Political Thought)
description: Study of Hawaiian political thought in writing from ca. 1825 to the present, with emphasis on theory and research methods. 402, 428, and POLS 303; or consent. (
prerequisites: HAW 402, HAW 428, and POLS 303; or consent

title: Kuana‘ike
description: The examination of Hawaiian ways of speaking, as contrasted with English focusing on those features that are uniquely Hawaiian and can be said to constitute a Hawaiian worldview. Section 1 taught in Hawaiian; Section 2 taught in English. 402 or consent for Section 1.
prerequisites: HAW 402 or consent for Section HAW 1

title: Mo‘olelo Hawai‘i
description: Intensive study, research, and analysis of Hawaiian history. Repeatable two times with consent of advisor. 402 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Nā Mea Kākau/Nā Haku Mo‘olelo
description: Intensive study of an individual author, his/her works and nuances of his/her works. (E) J. H. Kanepu‘u; (I) S. M. Kamakau. 601 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Ke A‘o ‘Olelo Hou ‘Ana (Teaching Hawaiian As a Second Language)
description: Survey of existing texts and teaching resources; analysis of student clientele and needs; review of pedagogical approaches for heritage and non-heritage learners; syllabus and materials development; practicum. 401 and 452 or consent.

title: Pilina ‘Ōlelo
description: In-depth examination and research into the grammar of Hawaiian including discussion of theories of language and incorporation of meta-language. 452 or consent. (Once a year)

title: ‘Ōlelo Ni‘ihau
description: Intensive, advanced study and analysis of traditional Hawaiian Ni‘ihau dialect through face-to-face conversations with Ni‘ihau native speakers, listening to audio recordings and watching video recordings of Ni‘ihau native speakers. (402 and 453) with a minimum grade of B- or consent.
prerequisites: (HAW 402 and HAW 453) with a minimum grade of B- or consent

title: Noi‘i Mele
description: Intensive study focusing on original compositions of Hawaiian poetry and song. 402 and 484, or consent.

title: Papahana Laeo‘o
description: Research for Plan B project/non-thesis. May include but not limited to internship with cultural practitioner. Repeatable up to six credits. HAW majors only. CR/NC only. consent of graduate advisor.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. consent of instructor and graduate chair.
prerequisites: consent of instructor and graduate chair

title: Noi‘i Pepa Laeo‘o (Thesis)
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only.

title: Hawai‘i: Center of the Pacific
description: An introduction to the unique aspects of the native point of view in Hawai‘i and in the larger Pacific with regards to origins, language, religion, land, art, history, and modern issues.

title: Hawai‘i: Center of the Pacific
description: An introduction to the unique aspects of the native point of view in Hawai‘i and in the larger Pacific with regards to origins, language, religion, land, art, history, and modern issues.

title: Hawaiian Perspectives in Ahupua‘a
description: Examination of the ahupua‘a system as it was conceptualized by the ancient Hawaiians, and exploration of its relevance in modern society; an introductory class to the mālama ‘āina track designed to build critical writing skills. A-F only. 107. (

title: ‘A‘a Ka Hula: Introduction to Hula
description: Introductory-level, performance-based Hula (Dance) exploring Kanaka Maoli identity and world view through ancestral knowledge as presented in Mele (Song, Poetry) and Moʻolelo (History and Literatures). A-F only. 107, and HAW 100 or HAW 101.

title: Kūnihi Ka Mauna: Introduction to Oli
description: (2 1-hr Lec, 1 2-hr Lab/practice) Introductory-level, performance-based Oli (Chant) exploring Kanaka Maoli identity and world view through ancestral knowledge as presented in Mele (Song, Poetry) and Moʻolelo (History and Literatures). 107, and HAW 100 or HAW 101.

title: Introduction to Hawaiian Visual Culture Studio
description: Introduction to a variety of material (fiber, bone, wood, and stone) and skills in the media used in the Hawaiian culture. Research and explore basic techniques within the media with emphasis on cultivation, preparation, uses, and conservation. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 107 or consent.

title: Introduction to Hawaiian Fiber Arts Studio-Hana No‘eau Ma‘awe
description: (2 cr. Lec, 2 cr. Lab) Introduction to a variety of fibers used in the Hawaiian culture. Emphasis on cultivation, preparation, uses and conservation of the fibers. Areas explored are kapa, plaiting, netting and twining. A-F only. 107 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Introduction to Hawaiian Painting and Drawing Studio
description: Research and express personal relationship to specific Hawaiian paradigms through Hawaiian visual culture. Introduction to painting and drawing media and exploration of various materials and techniques as applied to individual student styles. A-F only. 107 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Introduction to Hawaiian Printmaking Studio
description: (2 cr. Lec, 2 cr. Lab) Introduction to Native Hawaiian perspective and world view in images used in print and the basic material, technical, and conceptual aspects of hand printed imagery through the indigenous eyes. A-F only. 107 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Introduction to the Literature of Native Hawaiians and Other Indigenous People Written in English
description: Surveys literature of Native Hawaiians and other Indigenous Peoples, especially to focus on the situational impetus from which these texts were created. 107. (Fall only)

title: Native Hawaiian Composition
description: Focus on studying and Applying Native Hawaiian composition practices from the nineteenth century into the present day. 107 and HAW 100.

title: Hawaiian Mythology
description: Survey of gods, ‘aumākua, kupua, mythical heroes, heroines, and their kinolau as the basis of traditional Hawaiian metaphor. 107 and HAW 102.

title: Papahulilani Hawaiian Astronomy I
description: Introduction to Hawaiian ancestral understandings of the movements of the sun, moon and stars, and their use in ordering the Hawaiian year in planting, fishing, and ceremony. Repeatable one time. (107 and 270) with a minimum grade of B.
prerequisites: (HWST 107 and HWST 270) with a minimum grade of B

title: Ho‘okele I: Hawaiian Astronomy
description: Introduction to Hawaiian views of astronomy and the stars used by Polynesian Voyaging Society navigators. Introduction and comparison to various Pacific island non-instrument navigation systems and star names. Restricted to majors.

title: Ho‘okele I Laboratory
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Stargazing laboratory to accompany 281. 281 (or concurrent).

title: Ho‘okele II: Hawaiian Navigation
description: Hawaiian and other Oceanic canoe design, navigation, Pacific weather, sailing dynamics for canoes, and sail planning strategies used by Polynesian Voyaging Society navigators for long voyages.

title: Ho‘okele II Laboratory
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Hands on experience on voyaging skills and sailing canoes to accompany 282. 282 (or concurrent).

title: Lā‘au Lapa‘au: Hawaiian Medicinal Herbs
description: Presentation of Hawaiian medicinal herbs including basic philosophy, identification, utilization, and preparation of such herbs for human ailments. 107 or consent.

title: Perspectives in Hawaiian Studies
description: Interdisciplinary lectures and discussions examining traditional and contemporary experiences in Hawaiian society and setting; resources, methods, and techniques. Repeatable one time. HAW 202 or consent.

title: Malama ‘Āina Resource Management Visual Technologies
description: Requires a broad set of knowledge systems. Will introduce students to a variety of visual technologies for use in resource management and the ethical application of these technologies. 107. (

title: Kū Ka Pūnohu: Intermediate Oli
description: Intermediate-level, performance-based Oli (Chant) course exploring Kanaka Maoli identity and world view through ancestral knowledge as presented in Mele (Song, Poetry) and Moʻolelo (History and Literatures). A-F only. 214, and HAW 201 (or concurrent).

title: Advanced Art Media
description: Examine and explore advance techniques within the media and the customary and contemporary uses of a variety of material and skills used in traditional Hawaiian everyday life. Repeatable six times. A-F only. 107 or 220, or consent. (Once a year)

title: Advanced Hawaiian Fiber Arts Studio-Hana No‘eau Ma‘awe
description: (2 cr. Lec, 2 cr. Lab) Examine the customary and contemporary use of fiber materials and the skills used in Hawaiian culture. Research and explore advanced techniques within the media used in traditional Hawai‘i. A-F only. Repeatable one time. 107 and 222, or consent. (Once a year)

title: Advanced Hawaiian Painting and Drawing Studio
description: Advanced research and expression of personal relationship to specific Hawaiian paradigms through visual culture and language. Students will further their definitions, analysis skills, research, and understandings through painting and drawing media. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 107 and 224, or consent. (Once a year)

title: Advanced Hawaiian Printmaking Studio
description: (2 cr. Lec, 2 cr. Lab) Advanced Native Hawaiian perspective in imagery in print and the material, technical, and conceptual aspects of hand printed imagery. Lecture-lab with studio work time. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 107 and 225, or consent. (Once a year)

title: Native Hawaiian Traditions in Literature
description: Discusses theoretical frameworks, main features, and cultural contexts of Hawaiian literature. 107, 270, and HAW 202; or consent.
prerequisites: HWST 107, HWST 270, and HAW 202; or consent

title: Hawaiian and Indigenous Digital Media
description: Focus on studying, analyzing, and creating various forms of Hawaiian and Indigenous digital storytelling. 107 and 234 and HAW 100.

title: Hawaiian Genealogies
description: Survey of major Hawaiian chiefly lineages from the four main islands: Hawai‘i, Maui, O‘ahu and Kaua‘i. Political history from the Kumulipo to Western contact. 270 and HAW 202.

title: Chiefs of Post-Contact Hawai‘i
description: Survey of Hawaiian chiefs from 1778 to the present, including genealogy, political function, and historical impact. 107, 341, or HAW 201.

title: Myths of Hawaiian History
description: Thematic exploration of some common myths of Hawaiian history, including infanticide, slavery, feudalism, constant warfare, human sacrifice, and a limited -contact population, to determine the role of myth making in perceptions of Hawaiian history. Junior standing or higher. 107 and HAW 202.
prerequisites: -contact population, to determine the role of myth making in perceptions of Hawaiian history

title: Mahi‘ai Kalo I: Taro Cultivation
description: Historical, cultural and philosophical foundations of the cultivation and uses of taro. A-F only. 107 and 207/SUST 217. (Once a year)

title: Mahi‘ai Kalo II: Advanced Taro
description: In depth-study of taro cultivation techniques and systems. A-F only. 351.

title: Mālama Loko I‘a
description: Study of traditional Hawaiian fishpond management with hands-on experience at He‘eia fishpond near Kāne‘ohe, merging traditional Native knowledge and ways of seeing with Western science. A-F only. 107 and 207/SUST 217. (Once a year)

title: Aloha Kanaloa-Marine Resources and Abundance
description: Undergraduate course exposing students to the resources and processes of the ocean, research, and management approaches, as well as a Hawaiian worldview of oceanic elements. Junior standing or higher. 107. (

title: Pana O‘ahu: Famous Place Names
description: A survey of the famous place names in each ahupua‘a of O‘ahu, including accounts of mythical heroes, heiau, fishponds, wind, rain names, and their metaphoric value in Hawaiian literature. 270, 341, and HAW 202

title: Pana Paemoku o Kanaloa: The Northwestern Hawaiian Islands
description: Will look at the use of the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands during -contact times, the historical period of the Kingdom of Hawai‘i, after the islands were ceded to the U.S., and the contemporary politics that surround the region today. A-F only. 107 or consent.
prerequisites: -contact times, the historical period of the Kingdom of Hawai‘i, after the islands were ceded to the U

title: La‘au Lapa‘au: Ho‘i Ka Mana i Loko
description: (3 Lec, 1 Lab) Advanced study and preparation of Hawaiian medicinal herb combinations. 107 and 285; or consent.

title: Issues in Modern Hawai‘i
description: Cultural and political aspects of the current Hawaiian movement; historical colonization; conflicts over tourism, the military, and agriculture; forms of native self-determination. Junior standing or higher. 107 and HAW 202.

title: Native Hawaiian Rights and Practices
description: Students will strengthen their cultural, political, and legal foundations by: (1) reviewing Hawai‘i’s historical traditions and customs, (2) learning legal analysis techniques, and (3) applying those techniques to issues that govern native Hawaiian “rights” today. Sophomore or higher standing. 107, 270, and 341 (or concurrent) and HAW 102. (Fall only)
prerequisites: HWST 107, HWST 270, and HWST 341 (or concurrent) and HAW 102

title: Visiting Artist Seminar
description: (2 cr. Lec, 2 cr. Lab) Explore indigenous concepts through the media of a visiting indigenous master artist by looking at traditional media in indigenous cultures, and the possibilities for contemporary expression in other media. Repeatable one time. HWST majors only. A-F only. 107, one course in 220 level (222, 224, 225), one course in 320 level (322, 324, 325); or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: HWST 107, one course in HWST 220 level (HWST 222, HWST 224, HWST 225), one course in HWST 320 level (HWST 322, HWST 324, HWST 325); or consent

title: Ka Mana Mo‘olelo: Topics in Hawaiian and Indigenous Mo‘olelo
description: Advanced course of study focusing on pressing topics connected with Hawaiian and Indigenous literatures, such as land struggle, climate change, or issues of governance and sovereignty. Repeatable unlimited times. 234 or 235, and 330.

title: Mâhele Land Awards
description: Practical guide to the researching of land awards and change in title for a single ahupua‘a, 1848 to present. Focus on field trips. 342.

title: Ceded Lands: Focus on Crown and Government Lands (1848 to Present)
description: Inventorying “Ceded Lands” in Hawai‘i with emphasis on historical, legal, and cultural changes from the Kingdom through statehood. A-F only. 440 or consent.

title: Introduction to Indigenous Research Methods
description: Survey course introduces students to a range of methods by beginning with a critical analysis of dominant research methodologies from the perspective of Indigenous scholars. Junior/senior standing only.

title: Hawaiian Institutions
description: Comprehensive analysis of institutions like Bishop Estate/Kamehameha Schools, OHA, Lili‘uokalani Trust, Department of Hawaiian Home Lands and The Queen’s Hospital. 342.

title: Wehe Ka ‘Āina: Cultivating a Sovereign Land Base
description: A Mālama ‘Āina and Kukulu ‘Aupuni course that identifies modern options in land access for reestablishing or resuming Hawaiian traditional and customary practices relating to food sovereignty and self-sustainability. HWST majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 207/SUST 217 and 343 and 351; HAW 202 (or concurrent). (Alt. years)
prerequisites: HWST 207/SUST 217 and SUST 343 and SUST 351; HAW 202 (or concurrent)

title: Ola I Ka Wai; Water and Sovereignty in Hawai‘i
description: Focus on Hawaiian relationships with Ka Wai Ola a Kane (water), traditional and contemporary water management practices, as well as contemporary resource management issues and native Hawaiian community advocacy for water. 307 and HAW 202 (or concurrent) or consent.
prerequisites: HWST 307 and HAW 202 (or concurrent) or consent

title: Kia‘i Kanaloa–Guarding Our Ocean Resources
description: Students will actively monitor and practice coastal and ocean stewardship in support of local communities and practitioners while also exploring how the Hawaiian worldview can plan a role in aloha ‘âina conservation movements. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 207/SUST 217 or 307/SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356. (Spring only)

title: ‘Āina Mauliola: Hawaiian Ecosystems
description: Comprehensive analysis of traditional Hawaiian and modern resource management practices. Rigorous overview of the dominant physical and biological processes from the uplands to the oceans in Hawai‘i. 207/SUST 217 or 307/SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356. (

title: Natural Resource Issues and Ethics
description: Overview of the history of land, resources and power in Hawai‘i; players and processes influencing land and natural resources policies today explored from Native Hawaiian and other viewpoints. Extensive use of case studies. 207/SUST 217 or 307/SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356 (

title: Strategies in Hawaiian Resource Use
description: Analyzing diverse land and water use strategies of O‘ahu, from traditional Hawaiian, scientific and economic perspectives, through classroom and on-site lectures. Topics include traditional Hawaiian methods, modern development, threatened ecosystems, ecotourism and scientific research. A-F only. 207/SUST 217 or 307/ SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356. (
prerequisites: HWST 207/SUST 217 or SUST 307/ SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356

title: Hui Konohiki Practicum
description: A “hands-on” internship in an environmental or resource-management organization in Hawai‘i. The experience will be broadened and supplemented by classroom lectures, discussion and analysis from traditional Hawaiian, scientific and economic perspectives. A-F only. 207/SUST 217 or 307/SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356. (Spring only) (

title: Hawai‘i & Indigenous Economies
description: Students will map out indigenous economies by articulating cultural similarity and diversity between academic experience and professional experiences. A-F only. 107 or consent.

title: Mālama ‘Āina Field Methods Course
description: Intensive field methods program to research Mālama ‘Āina strategies. Introduces students to a variety of field techniques including land research, historical documents, ecological surveys, and Papakūmakawalu. Repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. Junior standing or higher. 207/SUST 217 or 307/SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356, or consent. (Summer only)
prerequisites: HWST 207/SUST 217 or SUST 307/SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356, or consent

title: ‘Ike Akua Papakū Makawalu: Ancestral Understanding of Elements
description: Uses Dr. Pualani Kanahele’s Papakū Makawalu methodology to analyze akua as elements and as a paradigm for understanding ancestral knowledge. Senior standing or higher. 270, 372 (or concurrent), and HAW 301 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: HWST 270, HWST 372 (or concurrent), and HAW 301 (or concurrent)

title: Mele Au Hou: Music and Native Identity
description: Presents Hawaiian music as it has been an avenue for native social, cultural and political expression in traditional and contemporary society. A-F only. 107 or 343 or 390; or consent.
prerequisites: HWST 107 or HWST 343 or HWST 390; or consent

title: Mahi Lā‘au Lapa‘au: Hawaiian Medicinal Horticulture
description: The science of planting and harvesting Hawaiian medicinal plants and exploring production and marketing strategies. 107, 285 and 385; or consent.
prerequisites: HWST 107, HWST 285 and HWST 385; or consent

title: Hawaiian Aquatic Medicine
description: Identification, extraction and preparation of complexes of aquatic herbs to formulate a healing combination to contribute to maintaining overall health. A-F only. 107, 285; or consent. (Fall only)

title: Senior Seminar in Hawaiian Studies
description: Critical examination of existing research; individual or team development, execution, and evaluation of selected projects. Repeatable three times. senior major in Hawaiian studies or consent.
prerequisites: senior major in Hawaiian studies or consent

title: Senior Capstone Project in Hawaiian Studies
description: Capstone seminar designed to provide a culminating academic experience through in-depth examination, analysis, articulation, and projects relevant to a HWST area of concentration. Repeatable one time. HWST majors only. Senior standing only. A-F only. 341, 342, [343 or 390 or 490 (or concurrent)] and [207/SUST 217 or 285 or 307/SUST 317 or 356/SUST 356] and [222 or 224 or 225 or 372 or 478]. (Fall only)
prerequisites: HWST 341, HWST 342, [HWST 343 or HWST 390 or HWST 490 (or concurrent)] and [HWST 207/SUST 217 or SUST 285 or SUST 307/SUST 317 or SUST 356/SUST 356] and [SUST 222 or SUST 224 or SUST 225 or SUST 372 or SUST 478]

title: Hawaiian Political Speech: Ha‘i ‘Ōlelo Ku‘e
description: Senior seminar in short, extemporaneous speeches in persuasive, passionate and dynamic styles of Native Hawaiian orators. A-F only. 107, 270, 341, 342, or HAW 202; or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: HWST 107, HWST 270, HWST 341, HWST 342, or HAW 202; or consent

title: Modern Pacific Women’s Poetry
description: Critical examination of modern indigenous women’s poetry from the Pacific Islands. Thematic concentration on land, family, sexual and national oppression. 107, 270, or consent.

title: Kumu Kānāwai: Western Law and Hawai‘i
description: The rise of Western law in Hawai‘i, its contribution to nation building and colonialism. 342 or 343 or 390; or consent.
prerequisites: HWST 342 or HWST 343 or HWST 390; or consent

title: Kānāwai II: Practical Application of Rights
description: Historical analysis of land use, race and self-determination; introduced to legal case briefing, analysis of legal precedent, practical impacts of rules and regulations and the sociopolitical factors that influence law and law enforcement. A-F only. 390 or consent.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Individual reading/research. instructor consent.

title: Indigenous Research Methodologies
description: Reading seminar for developing a Native Hawaiian epistemology from sources in comparative indigenous thought. A-F only. 107, 270, 341 (or concurrent), 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: 343 (or concurrent) or 390 (or concurrent) or 490 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: HWST 107, HWST 270, HWST 341 (or concurrent), HWST 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: HWST 343 (or concurrent) or HWST 390 (or concurrent) or HWST 490 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Hawaiian Archival Research
description: Research seminar aimed at familiarizing students with the rich historical primary sources existent in various archives in Honolulu. A-F only. 107, 270, 341 (or concurrent), 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: 343 (or concurrent) or 390 (or concurrent) or 490 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: HWST 107, HWST 270, HWST 341 (or concurrent), HWST 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: HWST 343 (or concurrent) or HWST 390 (or concurrent) or HWST 490 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Review of Hawaiian Literature
description: Seminar in review of Hawaiian literature to understand the significance of secondary sources in Hawaiian subjects. This makes up part of the Hawaiian Studies graduate core. A-F only. 107, 270, 341 (or concurrent), 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: 343 (or concurrent) or 390 (or concurrent) or 490 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: HWST 107, HWST 270, HWST 341 (or concurrent), HWST 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: HWST 343 (or concurrent) or HWST 390 (or concurrent) or HWST 490 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Writing a Hawaiian Thesis
description: Seminar to help fashion student’s research and thesis proposal. To be taken by all HWST MA students as they begin designing their capstone project. Course will be team-taught by HWST faculty. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 601 and 602; 603 (or concurrent).

title: ‘Ike Pono-Visual/Cultural Interpretations
description: Graduate seminar and visual studio that examines (from a Kanaka Maoli viewpoint) colonial imaging; collecting and site of contestation; resilience and resistance; and re-righting. A-F only. 107, and one course from 220-225, and one course from 320-325; or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: HWST 107, and one course from HWST 220-HWST 225, and one course from HWST 320-HWST 325; or consent

title: ‘Ike Maka-Visual/Cultural Knowledge
description: Graduate seminar and visual studio that carefully examines and develops critical consciousness–from a Kanaka Maoli viewpoint–visual hegemony, rhetorical tropes; and representation–imag(in)ing and reimag(in)-ing. HWST majors only. A-F only. 620 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Pono Science: Ethical Implications of Science in Hawai‘i
description: Support student dialogue on the foundations of pono science. Through discussions and structured guidance, students will explore Hawaiian ethics, implications of research, and decolonizing methodology. Repeatable three times. Graduate students only.

title: Mo‘olelo ‘Ōiwi: Historical Perspectives
description: Research seminar for developing interpretations of the past from Native Hawaiian and foreign world views with particular emphasis on understanding the meaning of culturally-based knowledge systems. A-F only.

title: Mele Hawa‘i: Mele as Systems of Knowledge
description: Seminar on Mele Hawai‘i (Songs, Poetry, Chants) as systems of knowledge that record, communicate, and critique historical, political, environmental, and cultural information. Will include learning and analysis of mele, culminating with a research project. HAW 302 and (HWST 478 or HAW 384 or HAW 484).
prerequisites: HAW 302 and (HWST 478 or HAW 384 or HAW 484)

title: Hawaiian Geography and Resource Management
description: Seminar in geography of Hawai‘i from a Native Hawaiian perspective that will enable the researcher to define and develop resource management methods consistent with Native Hawaiian understandings and traditions. A-F only. 107, 270, 341 (or concurrent), 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: 343 (or concurrent) or 390 (or concurrent) or 490 (or concurrent). (Once a year)
prerequisites: HWST 107, HWST 270, HWST 341 (or concurrent), HWST 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: HWST 343 (or concurrent) or HWST 390 (or concurrent) or HWST 490 (or concurrent)

title: ‘Āina Waiwai: Water, Food Sovereignty, and Ancestral Abundance
description: Topical graduate seminar focuses on indigenous perspectives on water, food sovereignty, Hawaiian terrestrial and marine food production systems, and ancestral abundance. Seminar perspective to change each term. Repeatable two times. 207/SUST 217 and HAW 202 or consent.

title: Kānāwai Lawai‘a: Hawa‘i’s Ocean and Fisheries Laws
description: Seminar on -contact, customary laws on fishing and ocean stewardship, their codification in written laws during the Hawaiian Kingdom period, and changes and impacts through U.S. annexation and statehood, including current models of ocean governance. (Alt. years: Fall) (
prerequisites: -contact, customary laws on fishing and ocean stewardship, their codification in written laws during the Hawaiian Kingdom period, and changes and impacts through U

title: Historic Preservation Law
description: Introduction to the protection of cultural, archaeological, and historical resources with emphasis on key federal and state laws. (Once a year) (

title: He Ali‘i Ka ‘Āina; Land, Resources, and Leadership
description: Seminar focused on leadership challenges in MVâlama ‘Āina to bridge ancestral and contemporary systems to better steward resources, produce abundance, work with and in community, and pivot large institutions for a better Aloha ‘Āina future. (

title: Kumu Kahiki: Comparative Hawaiian and Tahitian Cosmogonies
description: Seminar comparing Gods/myths from Ancient Tahiti by Teiura Henry (600 pages) with the six volumes of Hawaiian historians Kamakau and Malo. A-F only. 341 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Kumu Kahiki: Pacific Life Narratives in Mixed Media and Literature
description: Research seminar in relevant literary traditions, histories of interaction, colonization, and literary politics in the Pacific region through the examination of life narratives in mixed media and literature. A-F only. HWST majors only. 603 (or concurrent) or consent. (Once a year)

title: Indigenous Futurisms: Hawaiʻi, Polynesia, and Beyond
description: Seminar on Indigenous Futurisms as developed in Hawaiʻi, Polynesia, and other Indigenous contexts, and expressed through art, literature, film, music, and scholarship.

title: Huaka‘i Huli Heiau Hawai‘inuiākea: Study Abroad on Polynesian Temples
description: Comparative study of Hawaiian/Polynesian temple design taught over a 3-week period in Hawai‘i and Polynesia. Travel costs to be paid by student. 670 (with a minimum grade of B) and HAW 302 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent. (Summer only)
prerequisites: HWST 670 (with a minimum grade of B) and HAW 302 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Kūkulu Aupuni: Envisioning the Nation
description: A research seminar designed to provide an overview of community activism and Native Hawaiian empowerment in Hawai‘i in contexts that range from local to international, and to provide a foundation for further study and professional growth. A-F only. 107, 270, 341 (or concurrent), 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: 343 (or concurrent) or 390 (or concurrent) or 490 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: HWST 107, HWST 270, HWST 341 (or concurrent), HWST 342 (or concurrent), and one of the following: HWST 343 (or concurrent) or HWST 390 (or concurrent) or HWST 490 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Kūkulu Aupuni: Sovereign Hawaiian State, Domestic Kingdom Law, Governance and Politics
description: Research seminar on the subject of domestic law, governance, and politics of the Hawaiian Kingdom and the historical relevance of this to the contemporary case for independent, sovereign state continuity under public international law. A-F only. (Alt. years)

title: Practicum Research Plan B
description: Practicum for Plan B. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. (F) Full-time. S/U for (F) only. Repeatable up to six credits; Repeatable unlimited times for (F). 700 for (F).

title: Southeast Asian Cultures in Health/ Social Welfare
description: The study of cultures and their implications in the health and social welfare context for a number of countries in Southeast and South Asian region.

title: Pacific Cultures in Health/Social Welfare
description: The study of cultures and their implications in the health and social welfare context for a number of countries in the Pacific region.

title: Elementary Hindi I
description: Learn to express yourself in Hindi-a language that comes with a beautiful script, ancient philosophy, spicy food, and Bollywood! The course is communicative, creative, flexibly personalized for student interests. No textbook to buy.

title: Elementary Hindi II
description: Build on your 101 skills. Content includes Bollywood Film Festival at Honolulu Museum of Art. Create your own audiovisual projects–make movie trailers, write children’s books, or perform at South Asian events.

title: Intermediate Hindi I
description: Improve your communicative and cultural proficiency. Make Bollywood your language coach. Talk about cross-cultural values and practices of food, family, and friendship. Project-based course that builds bridges to your majors, minors, and other interests. 102.

title: Intermediate Hindi II
description: Prepare your proficiency for traveling to India. Create audio-visual presentations, documentaries, movie parodies, poetry, plays, dance, or projects from your majors/minors. Develop critical, cross-cultural, and creative skills. Bollywood built into course content. 201.

title: Third-Level Hindi: Culture
description: Continuation of 202. Advanced listening, reading, writing, conversation skills, language structure, and culture integrated in a variety of communicative and creative activities based on selected cultural themes. 202 or consent.

title: Third-Level Hindi: Film
description: Continuation of 202. Advanced listening, reading, writing, conversation skills, language structure, and culture integrated in a variety of communicative and creative activities based on selected Hindi-Urdu films. 202 or consent.

title: World History to 1500
description: Historical narratives and global perspectives on human societies and cross-cultural interactions from prehistory to 1500; includes ways to think about the past and ways to use primary sources.

title: World History since 1500
description: Continuation of 151. Historical narratives and global perspectives on human societies and cross-cultural interactions from 1500 to present; includes ways to think about the past and ways to use primary sources.

title: Issues in World History
description: In examining aspects of the histories of Africa, Asia, the Americas, Europe and Oceania, this course highlights the myriad ways in which global contact has transformed our world and narratives of the past.

title: World History of Human Disease
description: Examines how disease has affected humans in terms of society, culture, politics, religion, and economics. Explores the impact over a broad range of time periods, from -history to the present/future.

title: Global Environmental History
description: Explores the influence of nature–climate, topography, plants, animals, and microorganisms–on human history and the way people, in turn, have influenced the natural world around them. (

title: Global History of Food
description: Exploration of food and eating from historical, cultural, economic, and geopolitical perspectives. Includes both historical and contemporary issues.

title: World Cultures in Perspective
description: Development of civilizations from prehistoric origins to 1500. Offered as discussion and/or problems course. Alternative for 151 and 152; students in Honors program only.

title: World Cultures in Perspective
description: Continuation of 161A. Development of civilization from 1500 to the present. Offered as discussion and/ or problems course. Alternative for 151 and 152; students in Honors program only.

title: Early European Civilization
description: Political evolution and major economic, social, and cultural development of European states before 1500, including classical and medieval eras. A-F only. (Alt. years)

title: European Civilization 1500-1800
description: Political evolution and major economic, social, and cultural development of European states. 1500–1800.

title: Modern European Civilization 1800-
description: Continuation of 231. Major political, social, economic, and cultural trends from Napoleon to the present.

title: Civilizations of Asia
description: Survey of major civilizations of Asia from earliest times to 1500; East Asia, Southeast Asia, South Asia.

title: Civilizations of Asia
description: Continuation of 241. Survey of major civilizations of Asia from 1500 to the present; East Asia, Southeast Asia, South Asia.

title: Atlantic History: Colonies to Revolutions
description: Comparative and historical survey of colonialism and revolutions in the Atlantic World from 1500 to 1830. (Alt. years)

title: Introduction to American History
description: Interpretive survey from earliest settlement to 1865. A-F only.

title: Introduction to American History
description: Interpretive survey from 1865 to the present.

title: History of the Hawaiian Islands
description: Survey of state and local history from Polynesian chiefdoms to Hawaiian Kingdom to American territory and state.

title: Oceania Survey
description: Survey of major events, themes, and issues that make up the diverse histories of Oceania, including Hawai‘i, from ancestral origins to the present, with an emphasis on instruction in writing.

title: History of the Philippines
description: Traces developments in Philippine history and society from precolonial to contemporary times and explores ways in which the peoples of the Philippines embraced, resisted or negotiated new modes of thought, behavior and social organization influenced by the Spanish, American, and Japanese regimes as well as the postcolonial global order.

title: Topics in History
description: Introduction to methods of historical inquiry; current issues in World, American, European, or Pacific history. Emphasis on teaching writing. Repeatable one time. A-F only

title: History of Early India
description: Historical survey of India and South Asia from Mohenjo-Daro to the Mughal Empire, tracing political, social, religious, economic, cultural, and intellectual developments from ancient times to the 18th century. (

title: History of Modern India
description: Historical survey of India and South Asia from the Mughal Empire to the new millennium, tracing political, social, religious, economic, cultural, and intellectual developments from the 18th century to the present.

title: Early Modern Southeast Asia
description: Traces the development of Southeast Asia from early beginnings to the 19th century. Ethical issues and effective writing based on essays and ethical responses will form an important part of the course. DH

title: Modern Southeast Asia
description: Continuation of 305, from 18th century to the present.

title: East Asian Civilizations
description: Characteristics of East Asian civilizations as they developed in -modern China; variant patterns in Japan and Korea; the modernization process to 1500.
prerequisites: -modern China; variant patterns in Japan and Korea; the modernization process to HIST 1500

title: East Asian Civilizations
description: Continuation of 309. Period after 1500.

title: History of China
description: Chinese civilization to the 17th century.

title: History of China
description: Continuation of 311. Period since the 17th century.

title: History of Japan
description: Survey of culture, government, economics, and institutions, to 1700.

title: History of Japan
description: Continuation of 321. Period from 1700.

title: Way of Tea in Japanese History and Culture
description: History and culture of Japan as revealed in study and practice of the tea ceremony: Zen, aesthetics, calligraphy, architecture, ceramics, gardens, politics. Includes an emphasis on Oral Communication skills. (

title: The Samurai of Japan
description: A social, military, and cultural history of Japan’s samurai (warrior) class.

title: History of Premodern Korea
description: Survey of political, economic, social, and cultural developments from earliest times to 1400. Ethical issues in nationhood, central hegemony, myth-making, warfare, and memory politics are discussed.

title: History of Modern Korea
description: Continuation of 327. From 1400 to the present.

title: History of North Korea
description: History of North Korea in terms of industrialism, militarism, nationalism, and state power, from 1945 to today. Focus on construction of national sovereign identity and comparison with postcolonial world.

title: Ancient Greece I
description: Political, social, and cultural history of the Minoan, Mycenean, and Archaic periods.

title: Ancient Greece II
description: Political, social, and cultural history of the Classical and Hellenistic periods.

title: Ancient Rome: The Republic
description: Political, social, cultural history from the Etruscans to Augustus. Emphasis on discussion of literary and archaeological materials. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Ancient Rome: The Empire
description: Political, social, and cultural history from Augustus to 476 A.D. Emphasis on literary and archaeological materials. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Early Medieval Europe 300–1050
description: Formation of European societies in relation to Byzantine and Islamic cultures. Writing exercises develop historical thinking and the analysis of primary sources through workshops with peer and instructor feedback on drafts and revisions.

title: Medieval Europe 1050–1350
description: Main trends in European economy, society, religion, politics, thought, and the arts; interactions with Byzantine and Islamic worlds.

title: European Intellectual History
description: Undergraduate seminar on great debates in Western thought. Discussion of primary source materials; the scientific revolution and Enlightenment.

title: European Intellectual History
description: Continuation of 337. European thought from French Revolution to the present.

title: Renaissance and Reformation
description: Political, social, cultural, and intellectual developments in Europe from 1300 to 1600. Emphasis on cultural and intellectual history and its impact on social and political developments; humanism and its influence on thought and reforming movements, Protestant and Catholic Reformations. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Comparative Economic History
description: Comparative historical study of economic ideas and change since around 1700. Considers the histories of capitalism, poverty, industrialization and labor in Europe, Asia, the U.S., and other regions. (

title: The History of Economic Thought
description: Introduces major western economic theorists and ideas since around 1700. Considers the history of views on work, poverty, the market and government, and the relationship of those doctrines to society, philosophy, and public policy. (Alt. years) (

title: Reacting to the Past
description: Exploration of moments of crisis and the clash of ideas in their historical context through the use of simulation games. Junior standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Modern Germany
description: Political, social, economic, and cultural history since 1547. Rise of Austria and Prussia, unification, Bismarckian era, World War I and Weimar Republic, Hitler’s Third Reich, post-World War II.

title: France in the Old Regime
description: Major social, political, and intellectual developments: Renaissance, Reformation, religious wars, Richelieu, Louis XIV, Enlightenment, and Revolution.

title: Modern France
description: Political, social, economic, cultural, and intellectual developments in France from Revolution and Napoleon to the present. Assignments emphasize engagement with course concepts through oral communication and individual and group presentation.

title: Tudor-Stuart Britain
description: Traces major developments in British politics, society, and culture between the late Medieval and Modern Eras.

title: Modern Britain 1688-1945
description: Interaction of 17th-, 18th-, and 19th-century intellectual, political, economic, and social changes, which together produced the British Empire and modern Britain.

title: British Empire
description: Origins and expansion of the British empire between the seventeenth and twentieth centuries. Includes imperial policies affecting Britain, Australia, India, Ireland, and Southern Africa. Open to non-majors.

title: Iberia in Asia and the Pacific
description: Comparative exploration of the Iberian empires–Spain and Portugal–and their political, economic, and cultural interactions with indigenous societies in Asia and the Pacific. A-F only.

title: France and Empire
description: Lecture/discussion exploring the history of France’s relationship with imperialism from the Renaissance to the present.

title: Introduction to Islamic History
description: Muhammad, the Arab conquests, the Caliphate; fundamentals of Islam; classical Islamic civilization; development of Islam into modern times with emphasis on the Middle Eastern heartland.

title: The Making of the Modern Middle East
description: Survey of developments that created the system of nation-states in the Middle East. History of the Ottoman Empire and the Republic of Turkey; Egypt; the Arab world; Israel and Iran. Recommended: 354.

title: Survey of African History
description: The history of Africa from earliest times to the present: the rise of indigenous civilizations, European and Muslim impact, colonialism and nationalism, and current issues.

title: The World of Mekong
description: Historical survey, from BC period to present, of the peoples of the Mekong region, an area covering southwestern China, Thailand, Cambodia, Laos, and southern Vietnam. Open to nonmajors.

title: U.S. Women’s History
description: History of U.S. women and gender relations. Topics include women’s work in and outside the household, women’s involvement in social movements, changing norms about gender and sexuality, and shared and divergent experiences among women. (

title: Gender and Sexuality in the Classical World
description: Critical examination of the construction of gender identity and sexuality in ancient Greece and Rome. Junior standing or higher.
crossListings: Once a year Crosslisted as CLAS 362

title: Women in Oceania
description: Uses research and writing to explore historical processes that have impacted the lives of Indigenous women in Oceania and women’s engagements with those processes over time, with a focus on women’s voices, agency, and empowerment.

title: Global History of Sport
description: Explores the relationship between sport and society in historical perspective. Analyzes global processes of imperialism, nationalism, globalization, and international relations, and studies themes such as the politics of race, class, and gender.

title: U.S. Foreign Relations to 1898
description: Survey of U.S. foreign relations from initial encounters between Europeans and Native Americans through the 1890s.

title: U.S. Foreign Relations From 1898
description: Survey of U.S. foreign relations from the wars of 1898 to the present.

title: American Thought and Culture: To 20th Century
description: Politics, family, philosophy, technology, etc.; their interrelationship within the total society. -Colonial to end of the 19th century. (
prerequisites: -Colonial to end of the HIST 19th century

title: American Thought and Culture: 20th Century
description: Continuation of 373: the 20th century. (

title: History of American Business
description: The evolution of business enterprise from colonial times to the present. Emphasis on entrepreneurship, technological change, labor-management relations, government-business relations, and economic thought. Case studies of industrial development. (

title: American Empire
description: Examines the interplay between an “American culture of empire” and the rise of the U.S. as a superpower. Topics: imperialism and political culture, social movements and international affairs, race, gender and class relations. (

title: Caribbean History
description: Survey of the history of the Caribbean region from 1500 to the present.

title: The Asia-Pacific War
description: Explores WWII in the Asia-Pacific region, focusing on the intersection of the grand strategy, military operations, and war crimes. Involves source analyses and discussions.

title: History of Warfare to 1850
description: Classical and guerrilla warfare, revolution, and military systems and institutions.

title: War and Peace Since 1850
description: Continuation of 391, from 1850 to present.

title: U.S. Military History
description: Survey of development of American military forces from War of Independence to war in Vietnam.

title: History of Science to 1700
description: Evolution of scientific thought and its cultural context. Antiquity to 1700.

title: History of Science Since 1700
description: Continuation of 394; science, technology, and society since 1700.

title: (Alpha) Historical Theories and Methods
description: Examination of the nature of historical understanding, research, and writing, and of recent trends in historical scholarship; preparation for senior thesis, including significant discipline-specific writing instruction and a minimum of 4,000 words of graded writing. (B) historiography; (C) education. any 300- or 400-level HIST course.
prerequisites: any HIST 300- or HIST 400-level HIST course

title: Digital History in the Global Village
description: History of the digital age in global perspective connecting people, media, and technology. Faculty and students will use digital media to introduce innovative approaches to doing history. (Fall only)

title: History of the Indian Ocean World
description: Explores the transnational history of the Indian Ocean world, especially the region connected by the western monsoon. Topics include travel, trade, religion, colonialism, nationalism, diaspora, and globalization, including actors like slaves, sailors, women, and merchants. (Alt. years) (

title: Vietnam: History and Memory
description: Survey of Vietnamese history with particular attention to the multiple ways that the Vietnamese past has been remembered and represented by different peoples. Open to non-majors.

title: Rivers, Seas, and Society in Southeast Asia
description: The rivers, seas, and extensive coastlines are a dominant environmental feature in Southeast Asia. Focuses on the dynamic interaction of water and society in shaping the history of the region.

title: Themes of War in History
description: Explores cross-cutting themes of war from ancient times to the present, such as concepts of just war and unjust war, valor and heroism, and war trauma among combatants and civilian populations in conflict zones.

title: Modern Philippines
description: Survey of major developments from -colonial through Spanish and American colonial periods, the revolution, Japanese occupation, and post-war republic. (
prerequisites: -colonial through Spanish and American colonial periods, the revolution, Japanese occupation, and post-war republic

title: Modern Malaysia
description: History of Malay peninsula and northern Borneo, emphasizing developments since 18th century: trade, commerce, foreign migrations, pluralism, nationalism, and Islam.

title: Modern Indonesia
description: Indonesia from 14th century to present. Emphasis on period from late 18th-century Western colonial impact to struggle for independence and problems of nationhood.

title: History of Islamic Southeast Asia
description: History of the coming of Islam to Southeast Asia, the spread of its ideas, and its role in the lives of Muslim communities living in the region. GPA of 2.0 or higher. (Spring only)

title: Twentieth-Century China
description: An examination of the political, intellectual, economic, cultural, and social transformations of China in the twentieth century. This lecture studies critical events in the making of modern China and explores important issues in the modernization of Chinese life in the twentieth century.

title: Society and Culture in Traditional China
description: Ch’ing government and Chinese society from local and regional perspectives; modes of control and disorder during the 19th century.

title: Local History of 20th-Century China
description: Sociopolitical change and continuity at local and regional levels since 1900, stressing provincial reform, Hsien and sub-Hsien politics, warlordism, Kuomintang tutelage, and the Chinese Communist movement and rule.

title: Chinese Intellectual History
description: An interpretive survey of Chinese ideas and values in their cultural, social and political settings from classical age to 1600.

title: Chinese Intellectual History
description: Interpretive survey of Chinese thought from 1600 to the contemporary period, with special emphasis on the themes of cultural collision and change.

title: China’s Foreign Relations
description: Systematic review from traditional times, with emphasis on modern and contemporary history, analyses of foreign policy formulation, objectives, and implementation. Recommended: 312.

title: The Search for Modern China
description: Origins, development, and meaning of modern revolution in China, 19th century to People’s Republic. Recommended: 311 and 312.

title: People’s Republic of China
description: Salient developments from 1949 to the present. Social revolution and modernization, critically relevant foreign relations. Recommended: 312 or 419.

title: China in World History
description: Interpretative survey of China’s changing position, significance, and function in the evolution of world history as a way to provide a better understanding of its past and present.

title: Tokugawa Japan
description: Japanese history and culture, 1600–1867. Recommended: 321.

title: Okinawa
description: Survey of social, cultural, economic, and political history from earliest times to present.

title: Twentieth Century Japan
description: Problems of Japan’s political, economic, and social development since institutional consolidation of Meiji state (c.1890).

title: Women in East Asian History
description: Survey of the changing political, social, economic, and cultural positions of women in China, Japan, and Korea from ancient times to the present.

title: History of Japanese Cuisine and Foodways
description: Explores the history of Japanese cuisine and investigates the cultural, economic, and geopolitical aspects of food-ways in Japanese domestic and international identity.

title: Topics on Transitional Justice
description: Explores how societies in the wake of armed conflict, repression, or mass human rights abuses build institutional capacities for promoting justice, human rights, and the rule of law

title: War Crimes Trials in History
description: Explores war crimes trials in history since the end of WWII to the present. Involves extensive source analysis, discussion, research, and writing. Repeatable one time.

title: Persia, Greece, and Rome in the Classical Age
description: Historical examination of the interaction between the Achaemenid and Parthian empires of Persia and the classical societies of the Mediterranean, such as the Greek city-states, Macedonia, the Hellenistic, and Roman Empires. Recommended: 151. (

title: Crisis and Conflict in the Middle East
