description: In depth study and analysis of major crises and conflicts in the Middle East since World War II: the Arab–Israeli Wars, revolutions in the Arab countries, the Turkish experiment with secularism, the Iranian/ Islamic revolution, Afghanistan, the Gulf War. Recommended: 354 or 355.

title: Medieval Cultures
description: Topical study of cultural and cross-cultural issues in the medieval period (circa 300-1500). Class discussion and written work emphasize analysis of primary source documents using cultural and world history theories. Regional focus and readings vary by semester. Repeatable one time.

title: History of Christianity to 1500
description: Historical analysis of the main traditions of Christianity and elements of diversity within Europe and in relation to other parts of the world. Focus on the interpretation of primary sources and discussion of cultural issues. (Alt. years: spring)

title: World Environmental History, 1500 to Present
description: Explores interactions between humans and the natural world from early modern era to the present. Topics include invader species and biotic exchange; environmental politics; and the ecological impact of industrialization, urbanization, science, technology, war, etc.

title: The Darwinian Revolution
description: Social and intellectual origins of evolutionary thought and its continuing impact; emphasis on Darwin and the Victorian scientific community.

title: 20th-Century Europe
description: Contemporary problems and their historical background.

title: Expansion of Europe
description: Historical processes in modern European colonization from 16th to 20th century; impact on non-Europeans in Asia and Africa. (Alt. years: fall)

title: War and Violence in Early Modern Europe
description: History of the intellectual, social, and cultural causes and consequences of violence, including military conflicts.

title: Nazi Germany
description: Origins, establishment, and impact of Hitler’s Third Reich. Recommended: 344. (Alt. years: spring)

title: The History of the Holocaust
description: The origins and progression of the Holocaust, the almost complete destruction of European Jews, and other Nazi genocidal policies. Open to non-majors.

title: French Revolution and Napoleon
description: Causes, course, and conduct of the Revolutionary and Napoleonic periods, their impact upon Europe; emphasis on the conflict of ideologies inherent in the Revolutionary process.

title: Europe, 1914-1945: War, Peace, and Revolution
description: Explores war and peace in Europe, from the start of the Great War through the formal end of World War II. Topics include key battles, civilians, peace movements, treaties, the Shoah, Fascism, and Soviet Revolution.

title: Imperial Spain and Portugal
description: The influence of Spain and Portugal on people and cultures in Europe, Africa, America, and Asia; Portugal’s captivity and the defeat of the Spanish Armada.

title: Topics in African History
description: Selected themes important in African history, including, for example, the politics, economics, societies, and cultures of -colonial, colonial, or modern Africa. Topics to be -announced. Repeatable one time. (Once a year)

title: (Alpha) History and Literature
description: Explores the many relationships between history and literature, including how literature has reflected and shaped society in the past and our relationship to the past; (B) United States; (C) Europe; (D) Asia/ Pacific; (E) World/Comparative; (F) Provisional topics. Repeatable one time for different alphas, not repeatable for (C).

title: (Alpha) History and Film
description: Explores the many relationships between history and film including how film has reflected and shaped society in the past and our relationship to the past. (B) United States; (C) Europe: emphasis on writing as historians and film critics; (D) Asia/Pacific; (E) world/ comparative: significant attention paid to developing writing skills that involve critically comparing history-related cinematic representations across regions and cultures. Repeatable one time for different alphas. (Once a year for (D))(C ; (E Cross-listed as CINE 452E)

title: Colonial Medicine
description: Evolution of Western medical traditions; challenges created by European expansion and colonial interactions; development of modern racial and gender theories. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Modern Russia
description: Creation of the Soviet Union, Stalinization, the Cold War, the collapse of the empire, the post-Soviet era.

title: Russia in Asia and the Pacific
description: Russian/Soviet Siberia and Central Asia; Russian American Company and the Pacific; evolving relations with Asian and Pacific powers.

title: The American Revolution
description: Lecture/ discussion on the origins, development, and consequences of the American Revolution, explored within the context of the broader revolutionary Atlantic world.

title: African American History
description: Lecture/ discussion on the origins of racial slavery, slave and free black culture, slave resistance and antislavery, post-emancipation black life, the rise of Jim Crow, the Harlem Renaissance, and the Civil Rights Movement.

title: Native American History
description: Lecture/ discussion on the history of North American Indians from the seventeenth century to the present. Open to non-majors.

title: Early America
description: Lecture/discussion on Native Americans, Africans, and Europeans in North America from contact to independence. Social, cultural, and economic themes and intersections of race, class, and gender explored.

title: The Early American Republic
description: Lecture/discussion on the Constitution, the growth of partisan politics, the market revolution, religious revivalism, abolitionism and the expansion of slavery in the U.S. during the age of Jefferson and Jackson.

title: American Civil War Era 1841–1877
description: The crisis of the Union: antebellum society and culture, slavery, reform, sectionalism, the Civil War and Reconstruction.

title: Transformation of America 1877–1920
description: Selected themes that explain major changes in American life during the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including the westward movement, consolidation of capitalism, world power diplomacy, popular culture, progressivism, and World War I.

title: The United States 1920–1948
description: The Roaring Twenties, the Depression, New Deal, coming of World War II, America during the war, origins of the Cold War.

title: The U.S.: 1948 to the Present
description: The atomic age and the Cold War, the age of anxiety, the 1960s, the Vietnam War, the Reagan-Bush era, and beyond.

title: American Television History
description: Lecture/discussion examining the impact of television on American society, culture and politics. Analyzed in depth are family sitcoms, presidential politics, Vietnam and the presentation of gender and ethnicity. Open to non-majors.

title: Viva Las Vegas!
description: Upper-division lecture on the historical and cultural significance of Las Vegas in twentieth-century America. Open to non-majors.

title: The Cold War
description: Cold War as a global struggle. Topics will include U.S.-Soviet economic and political rivalry, Capitalism vs. Communism as practical policy and ideology, and the force of Third World anti-colonial nationalism.

title: Music, Industry, and Society
description: History of U.S. music and recording industry. How industry relates to economy as a whole, and how it reflects broad patterns and trends in American culture and society. (

title: Slavery and Freedom
description: Examines the history of slavery, race, and abolition in the Americas from a comparative, global perspective, and traces the legacy of slavery in the post-emancipation societies of the New World. (

title: The American West
description: Lecture/ discussion surveying the conquest, colonization, and consolidation of North American frontiers and the post-frontier development of the American West.

title: Constitutional History of the U.S.
description: Origins, development of Constitution, Colonial to modern times.

title: Race and Racism in America
description: Racial ideas and ideologies, and their effects throughout American history. (

title: History of American Workers
description: Conditions of labor in major phases of American development; response of labor and community to changing work environment. Capitalism, unionism, race, gender, law, etc. Emphasis on 20th century. (

title: Colonial Latin America
description: PreColumbian civilizations: Spanish and Portuguese colonization; political, economic, social, and religious evolution to 1810; independence. (

title: Latin America Since Independence
description: Political, economic, and social development since 1825; case studies from Brazil, Mexico, and Cuba.

title: American Environmental History
description: Survey history of the complex relations between American societies and diverse U.S. ecosystems, from European contact and colonization to the present. (

title: Histories of Oceania I
description: Explores the diverse, interconnected histories of Oceania from ancestral origins through the early colonial period. Topics include voyaging, orality, land, gender, power, exchange, cross-cultural encounter, disease, colonization, resistance, and historiography. Additional focus on oral communication. DH

title: Histories of Oceania II
description: Examines Oceania’s histories of protest during the colonial and post-colonial eras as responses to empire expansion. Explores ethical issues concerning these movements, emphasizing Hawai‘i experiences and their intersection with those across Oceania.

title: United States in the Pacific
description: Growth of economic and political interests and policies.

title: The Hawaiian Kingdom 1819–1893
description: Transformation of Hawai‘i into a state influenced by American and European ideas and institutions and Asian peoples, with an emphasis on instruction on writing.

title: History of 20th-Century Hawai‘i
description: Formation of an American Hawai‘i with its unique local culture from 1898 to the present. upper division standing.

title: World Maritime History
description: Survey of world maritime history from earliest times to the present, with emphasis on the evolution of nautical technology, motives from maritime enterprises, and the impact of cross-cultural encounters between oceanic peoples. (

title: Women and Revolution
description: Conditions under which women’s activism and participation in protest and revolutionary movements developed in the 19th- and 20th-centuries. Cross-cultural comparisons (

title: Library Treasures: Exploring Special Collections & Archives
description: Conduct original research using general library materials, special collections, rare books, archives, and manuscripts, maps, and other historical documents that are uniquely available at libraries and archives at UH and beyond. Repeatable one time.

title: (Alpha) History Colloquium
description: Extensive or intensive treatment of special problems. (B) Philippines and Indonesia; (C) U.S. foreign relations; (D) history in Oceania; (E) Chinese traditional government. Recommended for honors students. 372 (or concurrent) or consent for (C); consent for (B) and (E).
prerequisites: HIST 372 (or concurrent) or consent for (C); consent for (B) and (E)

title: Senior Tutorial in History
description: Analysis of sources and evaluation of methods of historical writing. Students undertake a major research and writing project in field of special interest. Capstone course requires a 20-25 page minimum final research paper. A-F only. 396(B or C).

title: Directed Reading
description: Individual projects in various fields. History majors with consent. Maximum 5 credit hours. (1) American; (2) Pacific; (3) Japanese; (4) European; (5) English; (6) Chinese; (7) Russian; (8) Hawaiian; (9) South Asian; (10) Southeast Asian; (11) Korean.

title: Seminar in Historiography
description: History of history and historians; philosophies of history.

title: Seminar in Digital History
description: Examines the various ways that the production, presentation, and learning of history through digital media is changing the way people access and process information about the past. Graduate standing only.

title: Advanced Topics in Environmental History
description: Introduction to leading themes, methodologies, and topics in world environmental history. Drawing on new and influential scholarship, readings explore the diverse forces that shape humans’ adaptation to and impact on the natural world. Repeatable one time. (Alt. years)

title: Seminar on Water in History
description: Explores how various forms of salt, fresh, and brackish water have played transformative roles in the evolution of human communities throughout history. (

title: Seminar in World History
description: Analysis, research, and discussion of themes and issues in study of history of humankind. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent.

title: Topics in World History
description: Selected themes— feudalism, economic and industrial development, etc.— important in global history. Topics -announced. Repeatable one time.

title: (Alpha) Advanced Readings in European History
description: Selected topics for advanced reading; (B) ancient; (C) medieval; (D) early modern; (E) modern; (G) intellectual. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years: spring for (D)); (Alt. years: fall for (E))

title: Ethnographic History
description: Critical inquiry into historical representations of the “other” and ways in which modern historians have used culture and other anthropological concepts to write and think about the past.

title: Introduction to Cultural Studies
description: Graduate seminar designed to introduce history students to the multidisciplinary theories that are appropriate to cultural studies. A-F only. Repeatable one time.

title: (Alpha) Research in European History
description: Selected topics for advanced research. (B) ancient; (C) medieval; (D) early modern; (E) modern; (G) intellectual. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent. (Once a year)

title: (Alpha) Topics in European Colonialism
description: Selected topics for comparative advanced reading and research. (D) early modern; (E) modern. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Topics in Historical Methods and Theory
description: Seminar covering one specific approach to historical methods or theory. The goal is a deep engagement with a particular historical approach via research and reading not bounded by region, time, or specialty. Repeatable one time. Graduate standing only.

title: Atrocity Crimes: Law and History
description: Seminar on history of mass atrocity and international justice in the modern world. Topics include postWWII Allied war crimes prosecution, post-cold war ad hoc international criminal tribunals, and contemporary international law and national legal systems. Repeatable one time.

title: (Alpha) Advanced Readings in Russian History
description: (B) early Russia; (C) modern. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent.

title: Slavery and Modern Memory
description: Exploration of contemporary resonances of slavery in the Americas through literature, historical scholarship, memory and trauma studies, and the visual and performing arts. Graduate students only. A-F only. (

title: (Alpha) Advanced Readings in American History
description: Interpretations and literature of important themes and problems. (B) early America; (C) the Republic to 1877; (D) industrial America; (E) recent America. Repeatable one time per alpha. appropriate 400-level U.S. history course or consent for (D) and (E); graduate standing or consent for (B) and (C). (Alt. years for (B)) ((B)

title: (Alpha) Research in American History
description: (B) early America; (C) the Republic to 1877; (D) industrial America; (E) recent America; (F) foreign relations. Repeatable one time. appropriate 400 level course or consent
prerequisites: appropriate HIST 400 level course or consent

title: (Alpha) Advanced Topics in American History
description: Seminar in advanced research and readings: (B) social and intellectual; (C) foreign relations; (F) the West; (K) business, labor, and technology. Repeatable one time for (B), (C) and (K). graduate standing and consent. ((B) ; ((F) Cross-listed as AMST 614); ((K) Cross-listed as AMST 647)

title: Seminar: Comparative Asia
description: This reading seminar in the comparative history of modern Asia will introduce graduate students to themes, particularly in social, cultural, and intellectual history, which lend themselves to comparison across the region. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Topics in Southeast Asia
description: Reading and research seminar on themes about the past and present of Southeast Asia in a comparative framework. graduate standing or consent.

title: Historiography of Southeast Asia
description: Examination of contested boundaries of Southeast Asia, the various historiographic traditions, the colonial legacy, and the current issues emerging from a dialogue of historians from the “region” and the outside world. Repeatable one time.

title: Seminar in Modern Southeast Asian History
description: Graduate level reading seminar in modern Southeast Asian history. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent.

title: The Seas in Southeast Asian History
description: Seminar on the seas in Southeast Asian history. (Alt. years)

title: Seminar: Vietnamese History
description: Reading and research seminar on Vietnamese history. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years)

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Chinese History
description: Problems and readings in political, social, and cultural history. (B) early; (C) middle; (D) modern. Repeatable one time.

title: Seminar: Islam and Islamic Civilization
description: Readings on the rise, spread, and development of Islamic cultures and civilizations throughout the world down to modern times. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 354.

title: Seminar in South Asian History
description: Graduate-level reading and research seminar on topics in Indian and South Asian history. Repeatable one time.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Japanese History
description: Problems, principal sources of bibliographic information. (B) traditional period to c.1600; (C) early modern 1600–1868; (D) 1868 to present; (E) 20th-century diplomatic. Repeatable one time per alpha.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Korean History
description: Reading major interpretive works, and research in selected topics. (B) reading; (C) research. Repeatable one time per alpha. graduate standing or consent.

title: Topics on War in History
description: Research seminars on topics on war in history. Repeatable one time.

title: Topics in Histories of Oceania
description: Reading and research on major issues, topics, and themes in the history of Oceania. Repeatable three times. graduate standing or consent. (

title: Seminar in History of Hawai‘i
description: Reading seminar with short papers required. Covers Kingdom of Hawai‘i and 20th-century Hawai‘i in alternate years. Repeatable one time. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Hawaiian Historical Research: Documents and Methods
description: Research and writings emphasizing the interpretation of Hawaiian and English language primary sources. Development of source materials, approaches, and methods in Hawaiian history. A-F only. Graduate standing only. HAW 301 with a B or better, or instructor consent.
prerequisites: HAW 301 with a B or better, or instructor consent

title: Directed Research
description: Individual research topics. (1) American; (2) Pacific; (3) Japanese; (4) European; (5) English; (6) Chinese; (7) Russian; (8) Hawaiian; (9) South Asian; (10) Southeast Asian; (11) Korean. Restricted to plan A (thesis) students. Maximum 2 credit hours. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Institutional History of Korea
description: Major political, economic, and social institutions. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Chinese Historical Literature
description: Reading and use of numerous genres of Chinese historical literature and documents. Chinese bibliography. Knowledge of Chinese required. Repeatable one time.

title: Teaching History
description: HIST 100-level faculty supervisors mentor their Teaching Assistants who teach the discussion labs. Course addresses issues of teaching strategy, grading and historical content. Enrollment limited to current Teaching Assistants in the World History Program. Repeatable seven times. History graduate Teaching Assistants assigned to 151-152.
prerequisites: History graduate Teaching Assistants assigned to HIST 151-HIST 152

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Introduction to Research and Creative Work at Mānoa
description: Combines lectures by instructors and faculty guests with workshops and hands-on experience in small group projects, including bibliographic searches, laboratory science, social surveys and interviews. A significant portion is dedicated to writing instruction. Honors Program students only. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Sophomore Seminar
description: Special inquiry-based study of multi-disciplinary topics in particular historical, cultural, geographical, environmental, or other contexts. Emphasis on primary sources and/or fieldwork and extensive instruction in writing. (B) biological science; (H) humanities; (P) physical science; (R) arts; (S) social science; (T) literature. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (; DH for (H); DP for (P); DA for (R); DS for (S); DL for (T)

title: Transformational Research Experiences for Early Undergraduates
description: Introduction to exploring discover-based investigation, with hands-on experiences in a wide range of science fields. Divided into 4-week learning modules led by researchers at several UH Mānoa research facilities on and off campus. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. (

title: Public Policy-Making
description: Students develop understanding of theory, practice, and ethical issues of public policy-making. Combines lecture/discussion and fieldtrips. Students develop policy analysis and strategic plans that identify issues, interests, and methods of influence. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 101 or 291(Alpha), or departmental approval. (
prerequisites: HON 101 or HON 291(Alpha), or departmental approval

title: Civic Engagement and Social Justice
description: Seminar on history, theory, and practice of civic engagement in the U.S. and abroad. Involves comparative study of social justice movements, historically and today. Focus on role of university students in social justice movements. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 101 or 291, or departmental approval. DS
prerequisites: HON 101 or HON 291, or departmental approval

title: Off Campus Study Project
description: Honors students participating in off campus study (via Study Abroad Center, MIX, or NSE) enhance their experience through a project at the host site, designed with and approved with consultation with Honors advisor. Repeatable one time, up to three credits. Honors students only. consent of Honors director and Study Abroad director.
prerequisites: consent of Honors director and Study Abroad director

title: Experiential Learning and Scholarly Engagement
description: Students develop an understanding of theory and practice of experiential learning through direct engagement and focused scholarly reflection while assimilating and synthesizing new knowledge and developing critical thinking skills. Repeatable two times. Honors Program approval only. A-F only.

title: From Ideas to Page: Learn The Publication Process
description: Learn the publication process through a “hands on” experiential learning, emphasizing diverse knowledge systems, writing, and ethics. Learn how to solicit contributions, review, and edit articles as part of the Horizons Undergraduate Journal publication cycle. Repeatable one time. Honors students only. consent of Honors director and instructor. (Spring only)
prerequisites: consent of Honors director and instructor

title: Peer Mentoring
description: Students develop understanding of dynamics of leadership skills within the contexts of paired to large groups. Significant portion is dedicated to writing and oral communication instruction. Honors Program students only. -semester training sessions, on-going training and supervision. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 101 or departmental approval.
prerequisites: -semester training sessions, on-going training and supervision

title: Junior Seminar
description: Project-based experiential learning involving community-based research or creative work. Focus on project design, practical skills, and teamwork. Significant portion is dedicated to writing instruction. Multi-disciplinary topics vary each semester. Honors Program students only. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Honors Colloquium
description: Weekly meetings for discussion of enduring issues and problems of an interdisciplinary nature. Limited to candidates for Honors degree. CR/NC only.

title: Honors Workshop
description: Supplemental workshop for students beginning independent work on their senior honors thesis. HON students only. Junior or senior standing only. CR/NC only.

title: Honors Thesis Proposal
description: Library research skills; scholarship of research and creative work; methodological and ethical issues; development of individual proposal or prospectus for Senior Honors Project. Limited to candidates for the Honors degree. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only.

title: Senior Honors Project
description: Original research, creative work, performance or other form of scholarly project appropriate to a major and supervised by a faculty member. Limited to candidates for Honors degree. Repeatable one time for each major. A-F only.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Directed reading and/or research. Repeatable 3 times or up to 12 credits.

title: Digital Tools for the Information World
description: Fundamental information technology concepts and computing terminology, productivity software for problem solving, computer technology trends and impact on individuals and society. Emphasizes the utilization of operating systems and the production of professional documents, spreadsheets, etc.

title: Introduction to Computer Science I
description: Overview of the fundamentals of computer science emphasizing problem solving, algorithm development, implementation, and debugging/testing using an object-oriented programming language. Recommended: computer experience.

title: Introduction to Computer Science II
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr. Lab) Reinforce and strengthen problem-solving skills using abstract data types and introduce software development practices. Emphasize the use of searching and sorting algorithms and their complexity, recursion, object-oriented programming, and data structures. grade of “B” or higher in 111 or consent.
prerequisites: grade of “B” or higher in ICS 111 or consent

title: Accelerated Calculus I
description: Basic concepts; differentiation with applications; integration. Compared to 241, topics are discussed in greater depth. assessment and consent, or a grade of A in 140X and consent.
prerequisites: assessment and consent, or a grade of A in MATH 140X and consent

title: Accelerated Calculus II
description: Integration techniques and applications, series and approximations, differential equations, introduction to vectors. 251A (with a minimum grade of B) or 241 (with a minimum grade of A and consent).
prerequisites: MATH 251A (with a minimum grade of B) or MATH 241 (with a minimum grade of A and consent)

title: Accelerated Calculus III
description: Vector calculus; maxima and minima in several variables; multiple integrals; line integrals, surface integrals and their applications. 252A.

title: Microbiology Laboratory
description: (2 2-hr Lab) Primarily for students in nursing and dental hygiene. 130 (or concurrent).

title: Music in World Cultures
description: Folk, popular, and art music from major regions of the world, with emphasis upon Asia and the Pacific; representative styles and regional characteristics.

title: Introduction to Philosophy: Survey of Problems
description: Introduction to the kinds of problems that concern philosophers and to some of the solutions that have been attempted.

title: Introduction to Philosophy: Morals and Society
description: Philosophical attempts to evaluate conduct, character, and social practices.

title: Asian Traditions
description: Universal themes and problems from Asian perspective.

title: Introduction to Deductive Logic
description: Principles of modern deductive logic.

title: Honors General Physics I
description: Special format for topics: mechanics of particles and rigid bodies, wave motion, thermodynamics and kinetic theory. MATH 242 (or concurrent) or MATH 252A (or concurrent). MATH 216 may be substituted with consent. Co-requisite: 170L

title: Honors General Physics II
description: Special format for topics: electricity and magnetism and geometric optics. A-F only. 151 or 170 and MATH 242 or MATH 252A, MATH 216 may be substituted with consent. Co-requisite: 272L.
prerequisites: PHYS 151 or PHYS 170 and MATH 242 or MATH 252A, MATH 216 may be substituted with consent

title: Introduction to Political Science
description: Discussion of politics as an activity and of political problems, systems, ideologies, processes.

title: History of Political Thought
description: Theories, approaches, concepts, and issues developed or raised in history of political philosophy and thought. any 100- or 200-level POLS course, or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100- or POLS 200-level POLS course, or consent

title: Survey of Psychology
description: An overview of the field: psychophysiology, perception, learning, cognition, stress, personality, social psychology.

title: Religion and the Meaning of Existence
description: Basic ideas and issues in contemporary religious thought about the meaning of existence.

title: Introduction to Sociology
description: Basic social relationships, social structures, and processes.

title: Principles of Sociological Inquiry
description: (3 Lec, 2 50-min Lab) Basic methods of sociology for production and analysis of data. Foundations for understanding research and for advanced courses in methods and statistics. Restricted to students in the honors program and required for students taking the honors track in sociology. A-F only.

title: Street Science: Evaluating and Applying Evidence in Daily Life
description: Develops necessary tools for effective reasoning and problem-solving through use and application of analytic techniques, including question formation, understanding/interpreting data presented in the public sphere, and evaluating the validity of sources. A-F only.

title: Food and World Cultures
description: An integrated cross-cultural approach to the study of foods and cultures. Examine history, concepts, principles of cultures and cuisines, the background of food tradition including habitat, social status, religious beliefs, gender, and other environmental considerations. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Women’s Studies
description: Introduction to feminist interdisciplinary analysis from global and critical perspectives; relationships between women and men from Asia-Pacific, Hawaiian, and other cultures. Focus on gender, race, class, sexual dynamics, and women’s negotiations with institutional dynamics. Honors students only. A-F only. departmental approval.

title: Human Development
description: Concepts, issues, theories of human growth and development from conception to death; systems approaches to inquiry into factors affecting growth and development.

title: Infancy and Early Childhood
description: Growth and development from prenatal period to age 5. Historical and current issues and research based on ecological, cross-cultural perspective. Focus on optimal development. 230 or consent.

title: Childhood
description: Intensive investigation into developmental aspects of 6–12 year old children. Historical and current issues, research, and examination of the role of schools and other community resources. Focus on optimal development. 230 or consent.

title: Adolescence and Early Adulthood
description: Problems, concepts, and research related to development from puberty through early adulthood. Examination of biological, cognitive, social, and cultural factors affecting the individual. 230 or consent.

title: Middle Age and Aging
description: Change and continuity in midlife and late life from theoretical and applied perspectives. Written assignments communicate information about physical and psychological age-related events, as well as social attitudes, values, to scholarly and community audiences. 230. (

title: Intimacy, Marriages and Families
description: Study of intimate relationships, marriages and families, their dynamics, strengths, growth and development, challenges, choices and opportunities, in the context of social change and cultural diversity. 230 or PSY 100 or SOC 100; or consent
prerequisites: HDFS 230 or PSY 100 or SOC 100; or consent

title: Parenting
description: Parenting theories, methods, skills, issues, and resources; parent-child relations in various cultural contexts. 340 or consent.

title: Leadership and Group Process
description: Exploration of leadership research and theories and their application to leadership development; designed to enhance personal and interactive leadership. any FG course.

title: Community Needs and Resources
description: Theory and practice in determining community needs and resources; community resources development based on needs identification. any FG course.

title: Family Resource Management
description: Concepts, principles, and practices in managing family and household resources. 230 or consent.

title: Family Financial Planning
description: Analytical approach to family financial planning from the perspective of changing family demands over the life cycle. 360 or an ECON course, or consent.
prerequisites: HDFS 360 or an ECON course, or consent

title: Consumer Economics
description: Consumer rights, responsibilities, and resources; consumer decision-making; factors affecting consumer functioning within economy. 360 or an ECON course, or consent.
prerequisites: HDFS 360 or an ECON course, or consent

title: Soft Skills for Success in the Workplace
description: Employers regard soft skills as key criteria when hiring and retaining employees. Students learn critical skills essential to work place success. This class prepares students to be work ready.

title: Research Methodology
description: Fundamental scientific methodology, design and data collection; introduction to statistics and program evaluations, analysis of ethical issues. FDM, HDFS, or TPSS majors only. 230 or FDM 200 or TPSS 200/SUST 211, or consent. Co-requisite: 380L.
prerequisites: HDFS 230 or FDM 200 or TPSS 200/SUST 211, or consent

title: Research Methodology Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Test design, computer use, data analysis. FDM, HDFS, or TPSS majors only. Co-requisite: 380.

title: Partnerships with Families and Professionals
description: Lecture, discussion and hands-on course, prepares students for direct, educational work with parents and children and for continued graduate work in child and family studies, counseling, psychology, social work and/or family life education. A-F only. 341 or consent.

title: Mindfulness and Skillful Living
description: Lecture, discussion, and experiential activities of principles and practice of an evidence-based contemplative science discipline. Focuses on development of writing skills and ethical applications to daily life, with implications for youth, families, and society. completed DS course (with a minimum grade of C).
prerequisites: completed DS course (with a minimum grade of C)

title: Marriage Development
description: Marital interaction and development; divorce and remarriage; resources and techniques for marital adjustment, enrichment, and growth. 340.

title: Contemporary Family Issues
description: Investigation of current issues with impact upon family quality of life, with emphasis on the interdependent nature of families and their environments. A-F only. 340 or consent.

title: Family Life Education Methodology
description: Lecture, discussion and hands-on course, with service learning on Family Life Education Methodology. Repeatable one time. 341 or 442, or consent.

title: Community Program Development
description: Concepts and theories of community program development; principles, practices, and procedures in administration and supervision of volunteer services surveyed and analyzed. 352.

title: Family Public Policy
description: Cross-national survey of family public policy; analysis, revision, and development of family public policy; impacts of policy on consumers and families. 352.

title: Consumer Communications
description: Development, production, analysis, and evaluation of consumer materials for print media. Use of desktop publishing computer programs. 360 or an ECON course, or consent.
prerequisites: HDFS 360 or an ECON course, or consent

title: Family Economics
description: Study of personal family resources and its interaction with the economy. Focuses on contemporary economic problems that affect the welfare of families. 360 or an ECON course, or consent.
prerequisites: HDFS 360 or an ECON course, or consent

title: Topics in Family Resources
description: Study and discussion of significant topics, problems. Offered by visiting faculty and/or for extension programs. Repeatable.

title: Internship
description: Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills in supervised work at an approved internship site and through analytical writing assignments and class discussions. Repeatable one time. HDFS majors only. A-F only. (230, 340, 360, 380, and 380L) with a minimum grade of C.
prerequisites: (HDFS 230, HDFS 340, HDFS 360, HDFS 380, and HDFS 380L) with a minimum grade of C

title: Capstone Portfolio
description: Preparation of a senior portfolio to be used as assessment of competence relative to national FCS standards. Includes extensive instruction on writing. HDFS majors only. (230, 340, 360, 380, 380L, and 492 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C.
prerequisites: (HDFS 230, HDFS 340, HDFS 360, HDFS 380, HDFS 380L, and HDFS 492 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Independent reading and research on a topic, done under supervision of a faculty member; outcomes contracted in writing with faculty member at beginning of semester. Repeatable two times or up to nine credits. consent.

title: Career Development
description: HRM 200 Career Development (1) | 2024-2025 General Catalog Skip to Main Content UHM Home A-Z Index Directory Students Faculty and Staff Parents Alumni MyUH University of Hawai‘i ® at Mānoa 2024-2025 General Catalog Menu Open Mobile Menu Search Search this site Site search About About UH President and Provost Message Campus Map Student Life Campus Policies and Information Personnel Calendar Courses Course Overview Sample Course Description Diversification Courses General Education Designations Course Numbering System Undergraduate Undergraduate Education Programs Undergraduate General Education Requirements Tuition, Fees, and Financial Aid Graduate Graduate Division Graduate Programs Tuition, Fees, and Financial Aid Degrees, Minors & Certificates Colleges, Schools & Academic Units Home Courses HRM 200 Career Development (1) HRM 200 Career Development (1) Human Resources Management (HRM) , Shidler College of Business ← HDFS 499 Directed Reading and Research (V) HRM 351 Human Resource Management (3) → 2024-2025 General Catalog Mānoa Catalog Office 2500 Campus Road, Hawaii Hall 121 Please note: This Catalog was prepared to provide information and does not constitute a contract. title: Human Resource Management
description: Survey of the field covering recruitment, selection, training, appraisals, grievance handling, communications, discipline, safety, compensation, and benefits.

title: Leadership and Group Dynamics
description: Explore frameworks leaders can use to get things done in their teams. Examine how leaders can engage employees, improve decision-making, manage interpersonal dynamics, and adapt to changing internal and external contexts. Emphasis on writing instruction.

title: Organizational Change and Effectiveness
description: Identify and evaluate methods to promote an effective change transition through efficient integration of corporate goals with the organizational culture.

title: Labor Problems
description: Problems and economics of labor; history, structure, government, activities of trade unions.

title: Labor and Social Legislation
description: Evolution, interpretation, and application of labor and social welfare legislation with special emphasis on impact of labor-management relations.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Reading and research in a special area within the major field under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by the department chair and faculty advisor.

title: Personnel Compensation
description: Selected topics. Emphasis on trends, recent issues, job evaluation, incentive systems, salary administration, executive compensation, profit sharing, benefit programs, retirement plans. 351.

title: The Staffing Process
description: Contemporary practices and trends in personnel planning for a competent work force; legal constraints, recruitment and selection, differential placement, training, career programming. 351.

title: Negotiation and Workplace Dispute Resolution
description: Theory and practice in negotiating; design and operation of different kinds of workplace dispute resolution (such as mediation, arbitration, and various alternatives); features exercises on bargaining and negotiation and advocacy and decision skills. (Spring only)

title: Labor Management Relations
description: Review and analysis of basic factors that distinguish employment relations; examination of the development of recent legislation and programs at federal, state, and municipal levels. Specific consideration given to current problems on the mainland and Hawai‘i. consent.

title: Training and Development
description: Analysis of the current concepts and practices in the design, delivery, and assessment of training. A-F only.

title: Seminar in HRM
description: In-depth analysis of selected current practices and trends in HRM. Repeatable one time for different topics. consent.

title: Human Resource Management
description: Analysis and critical evaluation of basic issues, policies, and trends in personnel administration. HRM majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Training and Development
description: Covers issues in design, delivery, and assessment of training, theoretical background of training and development process, types of training process, cross cultural and other types of diversity training and development of training modules. HRM majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Advanced Organizational Behavior
description: Organizational development (OD) and major concepts in organizational behavior. MHRM majors only. A-F only.

title: Finance for Human Resource Management
description: Intends to give HR professionals a basic overview of the vocabulary and concepts of financial decision-making. Topics include: understanding financial information, budgeting, the finance of retirement and employee benefit and business valuation. MHRM majors only. A-F only.

title: Compensation
description: Survey of compensation methods and procedures including job evaluations, incentive systems, salary administration, fringe benefits, appropriate legislation, policies and strategy issues of compensation systems. HRM majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: The Staffing Process
description: Recruiting and selection to optimize organizations including job design, job analysis, recruitment and selection methods, such as types of interviews and assessment centers, within legislative environment. HRM majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Negotiations and Labor Relations
description: Theory and practice of negotiation. Exploration of appropriate strategies, tactics, and communication techniques. Study of dyadic multi-party, cross-cultural, and assisted negotiations. MHRM majors only. A-F only.

title: International Human Resources
description: Exploring global trends in human resources with focus on the Asia Pacific region. HRM majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Human Resource Management-Topics
description: In-depth analysis of selected current practices and trends in human resources. Repeatable four times with change in topics. MHRM majors only. A-F only.

title: Human Resource Management Capstone
description: The final course in the MHRM curriculum. It provides students opportunity to integrate and apply previous course content to their professional organization offering a value-added opportunity to enhance organizational performance. MHRM majors only. A-F only.

title: Human Resources Leadership in Healthcare Organizations
description: Builds on previous leadership and management courses, focus on development of individual leadership skills emphasizing ethical and critical decision making, effective working relationships, and a systems-perspective relevant to healthcare organizations. A-F only. BUS 626. (Alt. years)

title: Beginning Ilokano
description: Listening, speaking, reading, writing. Structural points introduced inductively. Meets four hours weekly.

title: Beginning Ilokano
description: Continuation of 101. 101 or consent.

title: Ilokano for Health Sciences
description: Development of listening, speaking, reading, writing and other communication skills designed specifically for Nursing, Dentistry, Dental Hygiene, Public Health and Social Work students. Culture integrated with language study.

title: Intermediate Ilokano
description: Continuation of 102. Meets four hours weekly; three of four hours devoted to drill and practice. 102 or consent.

title: Intermediate Ilokano
description: Continuation of 201. 201 or consent.

title: Third-Level Ilokano
description: To further acquire and develop Ilokano language skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, utilizes ethnographic and sociolinguistic approaches in order to further examine and interrogate the relationship of language and culture. 202 or exam, or consent.

title: Third-Level Ilokano
description: Continuation of 301. 301 or exam, or consent.

title: Ilokano Aural Comprehension
description: Training in listening comprehension of different authentic and simulated materials as presented in documentaries, soap operas, radio and television news and other broadcasts, formal lectures, plays, natural conversations, songs, and student-created sitcoms and dramas. 202 or consent.

title: Contemporary Ilokano Literature
description: Conducted in Ilokano, this course explores the literary landscape of Ilokano literature from the perspective of Ilokano writers based in the Philippines as well as those outside of the country. 301 or consent.

title: Fourth-Level Ilokano
description: Continuation of 302. Conducted in Ilokano. Advanced reading, writing, and conversation. Contemporary Ilokano literature; cultural and historical topics. 302 or equivalent.

title: Fourth-Level Ilokano
description: Continuation of 401. 401 or exam, or consent.

title: Introduction to Ilokano for Interpreters
description: Techniques for interpreting Ilokano into English and vice versa. A-F only. 302 or consent.

title: Ilokano Interpretation Field Practicum
description: Provide extensive practical training in consecutive, simultaneous, sight and telephonic interpreting. It requires observation and study of interpretation strategies and techniques in relevant situations. 301 or consent.

title: Structure of Ilokano
description: Introduction to phonology, morphology, and syntax. 202 or consent.

title: Ilokano for the Mass Media
description: Ilokano as the medium for print journalism, for radio show programming, and for television production. 302 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Directed Elementary Language Study
description: Directed study of a South Asian, Southeast Asian, or Pacific language not regularly listed by the department. consent.

title: Directed Elementary Language Study
description: Continuation of 101.

title: Introductory Language Study
description: Introductory study of a South Asian, Southeast Asian, or Pacific language. Contact hours and credits determined by student interests and faculty resources. Repeatable up to eight credit hours. consent.

title: Directed Intermediate Language Study
description: Continuation of 102. consent.

title: Directed Intermediate Language Study
description: Continuation of 201.

title: Topics in Indo-Pacific Literature/Culture
description: Study of a literature or culture of the Indo-Pacific area through readings in various fields in English. Repeatable up to six credit hours. consent.

title: (Alpha) Introduction to Indo-Pacific Language and Culture
description: Introduction in English to language(s) and culture(s) of Indo-Pacific country or region. (B) Indian; (C) Southeast Asian; (D) Polynesian; (E) Philippines. Sophomore standing or higher for (C). 101 and 102 courses in relevant language or consent for (B), (D), and (E).
prerequisites: IP 101 and IP 102 courses in relevant language or consent for (B), (D), and (E)

title: Intermediate Language Study
description: Intermediate study of a South Asian, Southeast Asian, or Pacific language. Contact hours and credits determined by student interests and faculty resources. Repeatable up to eight credit hours. at least six credit hours of elementary study in the same language.
prerequisites: at least six credit hours of elementary study in the same language

title: History of Early India
description: Historical survey of India and South Asia from Mohenjo-Daro to the Mughal Empire, tracing political, social, religious, economic, cultural, and intellectual developments from ancient times to the 18th century. (

title: Directed Third-Level Language Study
description: Continuation of 202. consent.

title: Directed Third-Level Language Study
description: Continuation of 301.

title: Bollywood Dance, Music, and Film
description: Unique course combining mind and body, discussion and dancing. Learn and perform Bollywood dances and the richness of their Indian poetic, classical, and folk traditions. Understand “Bollywood” in the context of cross-cultural fusion and globalization. Repeatable one time. (

title: (Alpha) Southeast Asian Food, Music, and Rituals
description: Study and analysis of the art and culture of Southeast Asian food, music, and rituals—history, forms, social development, influences, and impact, with an emphasis on oral and written communication. (P) Philippine; (V) Vietnamese. Sophomore standing or consent for P. A-F only.

title: Southeast Asian Literature in Translation
description: Survey in English of traditional and modern literatures of Southeast Asia. (

title: Philippine Drama: History, Art, Culture
description: Survey of Philippine drama from the perspective of sociocultural and historical experiences of the people in the country and in the diaspora. Emphasis is on ethical inquiry and the teaching of writing and oral communication. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Philippine Contemporary Literature in English
description: Critical survey of 20th-century Philippine literature written in English; cultural values. one ENG DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Philippine Popular Culture
description: Explores the ethics of Philippine popular culture forms; teaches students how to produce, act, and perform in a select media form; and engages students in writing a critical analysis of these pop cultural expressions. A-F only. sophomore standing or consent.

title: South Asian Literature in Translation
description: Survey of traditional and modern literatures of South Asia; literature written originally in English.

title: Literatures of Ancient India
description: Survey of South Asia literature from ancient times to the early medieval period; focusing on Sanskrit, Prakrit and Tamil poetry traditions. Readings in English translation. (

title: Introduction to South/Southeast Asian Film, History, Theory and Appreciation
description: Study and analysis of South/Southeast Asian films– history, forms, development, theoretical framework and relationship to cultural, social, philosophical and aesthetic context. (B) Filipino. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent. A-F only for (B).

title: (Alpha) Study Abroad
description: (B) Samoa; (C) Tahiti; (E) Vietnam. Repeatable one time for (B) and (C). instructor consent for (C).

title: (Alpha) Southeast Asian Travelogue: People, Places, and Practices
description: A virtual guided tour of Southeast Asia that explores its multiculture diversity through its people, places, and practices. (P) Philippines; (V) Vietnam. Sophomore standing or consent. A-F only.

title: Vedic Hindu Mythology
description: Study of major Hindu myths of the Vedic Sanskrit literature within the perspective of ancient Indian civilization. Literary sources will be tapped for understanding creation, cosmogony and celestial, atmospheric and terrestrial divinities. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Classical Hindu Mythology
description: Study of major myths of Epic Sanskrit literature, primarily with focus of the Ramayana and Mahabharata. Literary sources will be tapped for appreciating myths and epics, especially with reference to dharma, karma, ways of life. Sophomore standing or consent. (Spring only) (

title: Philippine Games, Sports and Martial Arts
description: Introduces an experiential approach in the study of Philippine traditional games, sports, and martial arts. It also focuses on the historical and socio-cultural aspects of games, sports, and martial arts. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Philippine Diasporic Literatures
description: Appreciation, reexamination, and analysis of Philippine literature of exile; a reevaluation of Philippine writing from the diaspora. Sophomore standing or higher or consent.

title: Critical Discourses in IPLL Studies: Philippines
description: Revaluation and analysis of critical discourses in Philippine languages and literatures and an examination of alternative perspectives to the prevailing studies on Philippine culture; an appreciation of emerging knowledge on the Philippines. sophomore standing or higher, or consent.
prerequisites: sophomore standing or higher, or consent

title: Philippine Visual Art from Burial Jars to Burning Effigies
description: Introduction to the arts and material culture of the Philippines from the -colonial to the contemporary period through the examination of sculpture, metalwork, ceramics, textiles, and painting from various ethnolinguistic groups. Sophomore standing or higher. (
prerequisites: -colonial to the contemporary period through the examination of sculpture, metalwork, ceramics, textiles, and painting from various ethnolinguistic groups

title: Theories in Ilokano Studies
description: Examines the various theories employed in the study of Ilokano society, language, and culture from a variety of historical periods. A-F only. Junior standing or higher, or consent. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Literary Cultural Relations (Philippines and Southeast Asia)
description: An appreciation, a reexamination, and an analysis of the literary and cultural relations among the various nation states of Southeast Asia. Various texts are examined to establish the connections of these nation states. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Philippine Sociolinguistics: Language Use, Ideologies, and Identities
description: Examines the intersection between language and society, specifically Philippine languages in various communities. Explores how language policies, discourses, and ideologies shape people’s use of language. Emphasis on developing oral communication and written skills. Sophomore standing or higher. (

title: Polynesian Folklore in Translation
description: Traditional Polynesian genres (legends, myths, folktales, fables, proverbs, songs, riddles, jokes) examined in translation and culturally and structurally interpreted. one of ENG 270-272.

title: Philippine Literature and Folklore in Translation
description: Philippine folk literature translated into English: epics, myths, legends, and other folklore. Classic works of vernacular writers. one ENG DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Third-Level Language Study
description: Third-level study of a South Asian, Southeast Asian, or Pacific language. Contact hours and credits determined by student interests and faculty resources. Repeatable up to six credits. at least 6 credits of intermediate study of the same language.
prerequisites: at least IP 6 credits of intermediate study of the same language

title: Directed Fourth-Level Language Study
description: Continuation of 302. consent.

title: Directed Fourth-Level Language Study
description: Continuation of 401.

title: Ilokano Literature in Translation
description: Overview of Ilokano literature from the early writings to the major works of contemporary writers. A-F only. ILO 201 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Topics in Samoan Literature
description: (B) Writings of Albert Wendt; (C) Samoan women writers. SAM 227 or one of ENG 270-272; or consent for (B). SAM 227 or one of ENG 270-273 or WGSS 245; or consent for (C).
prerequisites: SAM 227 or one of ENG 270-ENG 272; or consent for (B)

title: Rizal’s Literary Works in Translation
description: Interpretation and analyses of Rizal’s novels Noli and Fili as they relate to the social, political, and historical context of the Spanish regime in the Philippines. one DL course, or consent.

title: The Writings of Carlos Bulosan
description: Intensive study of the major writings of Carlos Bulosan; his literary and cultural milieu with thematic concentration on aesthetics and the issues of diasporic experiences (e.g., immigration, assimilation, nation, etc.) and transnationalism. 361 or 363 or 396 or 431 or any ENG DL.
prerequisites: IP 361 or IP 363 or IP 396 or IP 431 or any ENG DL

title: (Alpha) Hawaiian and Indo-Pacific Teaching Practicum
description: An experienced-based introduction to various approaches in language teaching methodologies and techniques. Students’ skills in teaching the Hawaiian or an Indo-Pacific language are developed through supervised teaching, class planning and evaluation. (B) Southeast Asian languages. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. 402-level of the language practicum or consent; (B) CAM 402 or IND 402 or THAI 402 (or concurrent) and consent of instructor or equivalent language skills.
prerequisites: IP 402-level of the language practicum or consent; (B) CAM 402 or IND 402 or THAI 402 (or concurrent) and consent of instructor or equivalent language skills

title: Folklore
description: Theory and method of comparative and analytical folklore study, with special applications to Pacific traditions. ANTH 152 or consent.

title: Directed Studies
description: Study of a Pacific, South Asian, or Southeast Asian language through vernacular readings in various academic fields. Repeatable. third-level language and consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Elementary Indonesian I
description: First semester of elementary Indonesian. Emphasis on the development of communicative competence in both oral and written language and exposes students to the culture of Indonesia.

title: Elementary Indonesian II
description: Second semester of elementary Indonesian. Emphasis on the continued development of communicative competence in both oral and written language. 101.

title: Intermediate Indonesian I
description: The first semester of intermediate Indonesian. Emphasis on the continued development of competence in both oral and written language for more advanced communication and travel. 102 or equivalent.

title: Intermediate Indonesian II
description: Second semester of intermediate Indonesian. Emphasis on the continued development of competence in both oral and written language for more advanced communication, travel, and further study. 201.

title: Third-Level Indonesian
description: Continuation of 202. Conducted in Indonesian. Meets three hours a week. Reading, discussion, composition, and projects. 202 or consent.

title: Third-Level Indonesian
description: Continuation of 301. 301.

title: Third Level Indonesian
description: Online course consists of modular, thematic, proficiency-based units exploring the language of the contemporary Indonesian media with an emphasis on reading, writing, and listening comprehension. Not open to students who have taken IND 301. 202, 204, or consent.

title: Third Level Indonesian
description: Online course consists of modular, thematic, proficiency-based units exploring colloquial and formal Indonesian with a strong emphasis on listening and writing comprehension. Not open to students who have taken 302. 301 or 305 (or equivalent), or consent. (Spring only)
prerequisites: IND 301 or IND 305 (or equivalent), or consent

title: Third Level Indonesian Conversation
description: Topic-based course aimed to enhance student’s listening and speaking skills in the Indonesian language. Not open to students who have taken 301. 202, 204, or consent. Co-requisite: 305. (Fall only)

title: Third Level Indonesian Conversation
description: Topic-based course aimed at enhancing students’ listening and speaking skills in the Indonesian language. Not open to students who have taken 302. 301 or 307, or consent. Co-requisite: 306. (Spring only)

title: Fourth-Level Indonesian
description: Continuation of 302. Conducted in Indonesian. Meets three hours a week. Readings in various materials; speaking in various settings. 302 or 308, or consent.

title: Fourth-Level Indonesian
description: Continuation of 401. 401 or 405.

title: Fourth Level Indonesian
description: Online course consists of modular, thematic, proficiency-based units exploring the language of the contemporary Indonesian media with an emphasis on reading, writing, and listening comprehension. 302, 306, or consent. (Fall only)

title: Fourth Level Indonesian Conversation
description: Topic-based course aimed to enhance students’ listening and speaking skills in the Indonesian language. 302, 306, or consent. Co-requisite: 405. (Fall only)

title: Structure of Indonesian
description: Introduction to grammar; some sociolinguistic background. 302 or equivalent, or consent.

title: History of Indonesian
description: Social and linguistic development of Indonesian from roots in earlier Malay to contemporary form and function. 202 and 452, or consent.

title: Modern Indonesian Literature
description: Selected readings, 1900 to present. Discussion and composition. 402 or consent.

description: Listening, speaking, reading, writing, grammar. Meets three hours weekly.

description: Advanced Maori language and culture. 202, no waiver. (Fall only)

title: Advanced Maori Language and Culture

description: Survey of modern Maori and Hawaiian literature and culture from the mid-twentieth and early twenty-first centuries. 261 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Fourth-Level Maori II

description: Continuation of 381.

description: Continuation of 201. 201 or consent.

description: Continuation of 202. Advanced reading and composition with development of language structure integrated in a variety of communicative and creative activities based on selected traditional cultural topics. Meets three times weekly; additional lab work. 202 or consent.

title: Third-Level Samoan: Contemporary Culture
description: Continuation of 202. Advanced reading and composition with development of language structure integrated in a variety of communicative and creative activities based on selected contemporary cultural topics. 202 or consent.

title: Samoan Conversation: Contemporary Contexts
description: Systematic practice on various topics for control of spoken Samoan in modern contexts. 202 or equivalent; or consent.

description: Development of oratory skills in Samoan ceremonial speech. Emphasis on institutionalized applications such as the kava ceremony and formal speechmaking. 302 or 322, or consent.

description: Continuation of 401. 401 or consent.

description: First semester of elementary Thai. Emphasis on the development of communicative competence in both oral and written language and exposes students to the culture of Thailand.

title: Third-Level Vietnamese
description: Continuation of 301. 301 or consent.

title: Fourth-Level Vietnamese
description: Continuation of 302. Emphasis on cultural understanding through modern literary Vietnamese. 302 or equivalent.

title: Fourth-Level Vietnamese
description: Continuation of 401. 401 or consent.

title: Introduction to Vietnamese Literature
description: Selected readings in major genres; emphasis on analysis. Modern literature. 402 or consent.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Digital Tools for the Information World
description: Fundamental information technology concepts and computing terminology, productivity software for problem solving, computer technology trends and impact on individuals and society. Emphasizes the utilization of operating systems and the production of professional documents, spreadsheets, etc.

title: Introduction to Data Science
description: Overview of the field of data science. Introduction to subjects such as data format, processing, visualization, and storage. Special emphasis on historical and wider context, and simple practical examples. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Computer Science Principles
description: General course that provides a broad overview of computer science. Will address abstraction, data and information, algorithms, programming, the Internet and the global impact of computers.

title: (Alpha) Introduction to Computer Programming
description: Basic concepts needed to write computer programs. Simple program design and implementation using a specific programming language; (C) C; (D) through animations; (P) Python. Each alpha repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. ((P)

title: Introduction to Computer Science I
description: Overview of the fundamentals of computer science emphasizing problem solving, algorithm development, implementation, and debugging/testing using an object-oriented programming language. Recommended: computer experience.

title: Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science I
description: Includes logic, sets, functions, matrices, algorithmic concepts, mathematical reasoning, recursion, counting techniques, and probability theory. MATH 215 or 241 or 251A.

title: Information Systems in Society
description: Lecture/discussion critically explores sociopolitical dimensions of Information and Communication Technology (ICT), and the information professions. A-F only. departmental approval. (Once a year)

title: Introduction to Computer Science II
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr. Lab) Reinforce and strengthen problemsolving skills using abstract data types and introduce software development practices. Emphasize the use of searching and sorting algorithms and their complexity, recursion, object-oriented programming, and data structures. 111 or consent.

title: Program Structure
description: Program organization paradigms, programming environments, implementation of a module from specifications, the C and C++ programming languages. 211 or consent.

title: Introduction to Scripting
description: Introduction to scripting languages for the integration of applications and systems. Scripting in operating systems, web pages, server-side application integration, regular expressions, and event handling for languages such as Perl, JavaScript, PHP, Python, shell scripting. A-F only. 211 (or concurrent), or consent. (Once a year)

title: Basic Concepts of Computer Science
description: What is the subject of computer science? What is a computer? Understand the basic models of computation and the concepts of computability, complexity, and network computation, and learn to use them in practice. A-F only. 141 (or concurrent).

title: Machine Learning Methods
description: Introduction to contemporary mathematical methods for empirical inference, data modeling, and machine learning. A-F only. MATH 241, MATH 203, MATH 215, or MATH 251A. (Fall only) (

title: Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science II
description: Includes program correctness, recurrence relations and their solutions, relations and their properties, divide and conquer relations, graph theory, trees and their applications, Boolean algebra, introduction to formal languages and automata theory. 141 or consent.

title: Computer Science Careers: An Exploration of the Specialties of Computer Science
description: Exploration of the specialties of computer science. Meets every two week for 2.5 hours to explore specific areas in computer science. CR/NC only. (Once a year)

title: Sophomore Project
description: Part of a multi-year project-based courses sequence where students will work in teams on acquiring experience in a beginner-level design of a software project expected to be continued in ICS 396. CS majors only. A-F only. 111.

title: Algorithms
description: (4 1-hr Lec) Design and correctness of algorithms, including divide-and-conquer, greedy and dynamic programming methods. Complexity analyses using recurrence relations, probabilistic methods, and NP-completeness. Applications to order statistics, disjoint sets, B-trees and balanced trees, graphs, network flows, and string matching. 211, and [(241 or ECE 362) and (MATH 216 or 242 or 252A)] or (MATH 301 and 372); or consent.
prerequisites: ICS 211, and [(ICS 241 or ECE 362) and (MATH 216 or MATH 242 or MATH 252A)] or (MATH 301 and MATH 372); or consent

title: Machine-Level and Systems Programming
description: Machine organization, machine instructions, addressing modes, assembler language, subroutine linkage, linking to higher-level languages, interface to operating systems, introduction to assemblers, loaders and compilers. (212 or ECE 205) (or concurrent), (311 or ECE 367), and 314; or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 212 or ECE 205) (or concurrent), (ECE 311 or ECE 367), and ECE 314; or consent

title: Programming Language Theory
description: Syntax, semantics, control structures, variable binding and scopes, data and control abstractions. Programming in functional (LISP) and logic (Prolog) programming styles. (212 or ECE 205), (311 or ECE 367), and 314; or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 212 or ECE 205), (ECE 311 or ECE 367), and ECE 314; or consent

title: Software Engineering I
description: Problem analysis and design, team-oriented development, quality assurance, configuration management, project planning. These topics are covered in the sequence 314-414. (211 or ECE 205) and [241 or ECE 362 or (MATH 301 and 372)]; or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 211 or ECE 205) and [ECE 241 or ECE 362 or (MATH 301 and MATH 372)]; or consent

title: Database Systems I
description: Introduction to relational database systems, data modeling, query processing, transaction processing, storage, and indexing. (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314, or consent

title: Logic Design and Microprocessors
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Basic machine architecture, microprocessors, bus organization, circuit elements, logic circuit analysis and design, microcomputer system design. (212 or ECE 205), (311 or ECE 367), and 314; or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 212 or ECE 205), (ECE 311 or ECE 367), and ECE 314; or consent

title: Operating Systems
description: Operating system concepts and structure, processes and threads, CPU scheduling, memory management, scheduling, file systems, inter-process communication, virtualization, popular operating systems. A-F only. (311 or ECE 367) and 314.

title: Network Design and Management
description: Overview of the internet and its capabilities; introduction to HTTP, TCP/IP, ethernet, and wireless 802.11; routers, switches, and NAT; network and wireless security; practical experience in designing and implementing networks. (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: (ICS 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314, or consent

title: Security and Trust I: Resource Protections
description: Security and trust in computers, networks, and society. Security models. Access and authorization. Availability and Denial-of-Service. Trust processes and network interactions. 241 or (MATH 301 and 372).

title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence Programming
description: Introduction to the theory of Artificial Intelligence and the practical application of AI techniques in Functional (Common LISP and/or Scheme) and Logic (Prolog) programming languages. Students gain practical experience through programming assignments and projects. A-F only. (215 or 212 or ECE 205) and (311 or ECE 367) and 314; or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 215 or ICS 212 or ECE 205) and (ECE 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314; or consent

title: Computational Media Systems
description: Intermediate object-oriented programming within the context of interactive media systems and video game development. Topics: classes, objects, inheritance, polymorphism, abstract classes, interfaces, event-driven programming, vectors, geometric primitives, game mechanics, and relevant design patterns. ECE, CENG, ICS, CM, CSCI, THEA, DNCE majors only. A-F only. 111 or ECE 160 or instructor approval. (
prerequisites: ICS 111 or ECE 160 or instructor approval

title: Computing Ethics for Lab Assistants
description: A lecture/discussion/internship on ethical issues and instructional techniques for students assisting a laboratory section of ICS 101. The class uses multiple significant writing and oral presentation activities to help students learn course content. consent.

title: Junior Project
description: Part of a multi-year project-based courses sequence where students will work in teams on acquiring experience in intermediate-level design, implementation and presentation of a software project that may have been initiated in ICS 296. CS majors only. A-F only. 314 or concurrent.

title: Software Engineering II
description: Continuation of 314. Project management, quality, and productivity control, testing and validation, team management. Team-oriented software-implementation project. (311 or ECE 367) and 314.

title: Introduction to Programming for the Web
description: Introduction to emerging technologies for construction of World Wide Web (WWW)-based software. Covers programming and scripting languages used for the creation of WWW sites and client-server programming. Students will complete a medium-sized software project that uses languages and concepts discussed in class. (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314, or consent

title: The Science, Psychology and Philosophy of Systems Design
description: Scientific, psychological and philosophical bases of systems design, including a survey of human-factors and ergonomic standards; the nature of innovation and creativity as it relates to systems design. Web-enhanced course. (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: (ICS 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314, or consent

title: Database Systems II
description: Very large database systems, data integration, data warehousing, designing big data systems, parallel query processing, distributed transactions. 321 or consent.

title: Network Science Methodology
description: Computational and statistical methods for analyzing network models of social, technological, information, and biological networks. Introduction to relevant data analytics and graph analysis software packages. (311 or ECE 367) or consent. (

title: Data Security and Cryptography I
description: Secret communication and confidentiality data storage. Elements of cryptography and cryptanalysis. Classical ciphers. Symmetric key cryptography. Public key cryptography. Data security in cyber space. 222 and 355.

title: Application Frameworks
description: Experience producing applications with at least two different applications frameworks. A-F only. (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314, or consent

title: Computer Security and Ethics
description: Theoretical results, security policy, encryption, key management, digital signatures, certificates, passwords. Ethics: privacy, computer crime, professional ethics. Effects of the computer revolution on society. A-F only. 355 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Computer System Security
description: Information flow, confinement, information assurance, malicious programs, vulnerability analysis, network security, writing secure programs. A-F only. 355 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Programming Approaches to Software Quality Assurance
description: Examination of best practices associated with developing and supporting software applications with respect to potential security risks. Will augment software engineering practices learned in other courses with the basic principles of cybersecurity. 314 or consent.

title: Digital Forensics
description: Provides students with the knowledge of underlying principles and skills to identify, preserve, and extract electronic evidence for further analysis. 355 or consent.

title: Computer Architecture
description: Memory management, control flow, interrupt mechanisms, multiprocessor systems, special-purpose devices. 331 or ECE 361/361L.

title: Concurrent and High-Performance Programming
description: Principles of concurrent and high performance programming. Multi-threading in C and Java for shared-memory programming. Distributed memory programming with Java. Introduction to cluster computing. A-F only. (212 or ECE 205) and 332 and (311 or ECE 367) and 314; or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: (ICS 212 or ECE 205) and ECE 332 and (ECE 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314; or consent

title: Data Science Fundamentals
description: Introduction to critical statistical and probabilistic concepts that underlie data science as well as tools that play a central role in the daily work of a data scientist. A-F only. 211 or consent. (

title: Machine Learning Fundamentals
description: Introduction to machine learning concepts with a focus on relevant ideas from computational neuroscience. Information processing and learning in the nervous system. Neural networks. Supervised and unsupervised learning. Basics of statistical learning theory. 235, or consent. Recommended: MATH 307. (Once a year) (
