title: Big Data Analytics
description: Concepts, tools, and techniques for analyzing and mining massive data sets. Data cleaning and -processing. Data analysis and mining techniques. Big Data platforms. Big Data visualization. 321.

title: Theory of Computation
description: Grammars, sequential machines, equivalence, minimalization, analysis and synthesis, regular expressions, computability, unsolvability, Gödel’s theorem, Turing machines. (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314, or consent

title: Analytical Models and Methods
description: Applications of mathematical methods in computer science with emphasis on discrete mathematics, numerical computation, algebraic models, operations research. (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314, or consent

title: Parallel Algorithms
description: Introduction to parallel models of computation and design and analysis of parallel algorithms. (311 or ECE 367) and 314. (Fall only)

title: Data Networks
description: Network analysis, architecture, digital signal analysis and design; circuit switching, packet switching, packet broadcasting; protocols and standards; local area networks; satellite networks; ALOHA channels; examples. (212 or ECE 205) and (311 or ECE 367) and 314; or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 212 or ECE 205) and (ECE 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314; or consent

title: Software Design for Robotics
description: Sensors, actuators, signal processing, paradigms of robotic software design, introduction to machine learning, introduction to computer vision, and robot-to-human interaction. A-F only. two ICS 300-level courses or consent. Recommended: 312 and 313. (Once a year: spring)

title: Security and Trust II: Information Assurance
description: Channel security. Trojan and noninterference. Basic concepts of cryptology. Cryptographic primitives. Protocols for authentication and key establishment. 222 and 355.

title: Artificial Intelligence
description: Survey of artificial intelligence: natural language processing, vision and robotics, expert systems. Emphasis on fundamental concepts: search, planning, and problem solving, logic, knowledge representation. (311 or ECE 367) or consent.

title: Artificial Intelligence for Games
description: Techniques to stimulate intelligence in video games: movement, pathfinding with A* search, decision/behavior trees, state machines, machine learning, tactics. Extend games with your own AI implementations; experience “shootout” contests for the best AI algorithm/implementation. (212 or ECE 205) and (311 or ECE 367) and 314 and (PHYS 151 or PHYS 170). (Alt. years)
prerequisites: (ICS 212 or ECE 205) and (ECE 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314 and (PHYS 151 or PHYS 170)

title: Human Computer Interaction I
description: Application of concepts and methodologies of human factors, psychology and software engineering to address ergonomic, cognitive, and social factors in the design and evaluation of human-computer systems. (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314, or consent

title: Introduction to Hypermedia
description: Basic issues of interactive access to information in various formats on computers. Available hardware and software: editing, integration, programming. Implementation of a sample information system. (311 or ECE 367) and 314.

title: Design for Mobile Devices
description: Lecture introducing design issues, programming languages, operating systems and mark-up languages for internet-enabled mobile devices, such as cell phones and PDAs. A-F or Audit. (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent. (Spring only)
prerequisites: (ICS 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314, or consent

title: Cognitive Science
description: Introduces basic concepts, central problems, and methods from cognitive science. Identifies contributions from disciplines such as cognitive psychology, linguistics, artificial intelligence, philosophy, and neuroscience. (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314, or consent

title: Probability, Statistics, and Queuing
description: A hands-on introduction to probability, statistical inference, regression, Markov chains, queuing theory. Use of an interactive statistical graphics environment such as R. (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent.
prerequisites: (ICS 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314, or consent

title: Introduction to Bioinformatics Sequences and Genomes Analysis
description: Introduction to bioinformatics to computer sciences students by focusing on how computer sciences techniques can be used for the storage, analysis, prediction and simulation of biological sequences (DNA, RNA and proteins). A-F only. (311 or ECE 367) and 314, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: (ICS 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314, or consent

title: Bioinformatics Algorithms and Tool Development
description: Study of commonly used bioinformatic algorithms, with an emphasis on string, tree, and graph algorithms. Presentation of probabilistic and clustering methods. Implementation of the studied algorithms and design of applications. 475 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Introduction to Computer Graphics
description: Fundamentals of computer graphics including graphics hardware, representation, manipulation, and display of two- and three-dimensional objects, use of commercial software. MATH 307 or MATH 311; or consent.

title: Topics in Computer Graphics
description: Review of selected graphics literature, with a software development project based on a topic of interest. A-F only. 481.

title: Computer Vision
description: Introductory course in computer vision. Topics include image formation, image processing and filtering, edge detection, texture analysis and synthesis, binocular stereo, segmentation, tracking, object recognition and applications. A-F only. (212 or ECE 205) and (311 or ECE 367) and 314; or consent. Once a year.
prerequisites: (ICS 212 or ECE 205) and (ECE 311 or ECE 367) and ECE 314; or consent

title: Data Visualization
description: I ntroduction to data visualization through practical techniques for turning data into images to produce insight. Topics include: information visualization, geospatial visualization, scientific visualization, social network visualization, and medical visualization. Junior standing or higher. 110(Alpha) or 111 or CINE 215. (

title: Video Game Design and Development
description: Students will team design, build, and demonstrate video games or related interactive entertainment environments and applications. Topics will include emerging computer science techniques relevant to the development of these types of environments. Junior standing or higher. any 110(Alpha) or 111 or CINE 215. (
prerequisites: any ICS 110(Alpha) or ICS 111 or CINE 215

title: Virtual and Augmented Reality Programming
description: Students will learn to develop virtual reality and augmented reality applications with turnkey tools as well as through programming. Prior programming experience is not required for this course. any 110(Alpha) or 111 or CINE 215. (.
prerequisites: any ICS 110(Alpha) or ICS 111 or CINE 215

title: Digital Content Creation I
description: Principles, techniques, and history of 3D computer graphics. Modeling and animation techniques will be covered, as well as basic lighting and rendering. A-F only. 481.

title: Digital Content Creation II
description: Software development within a commercial 3D application with a focus on scripting and plugin development for procedural modeling, animation, and shading. A-F only. 487.

title: Software Techniques for Computer Visual Effects
description: Principles, techniques, and history of visual effects and underlying software techniques for computer visual effects. Project-based course involving the merging of computer generated imagery with live action footage. A-F only. 487.

title: Special Topics
description: Reflects special interests of faculty. Oriented toward juniors and seniors. Repeatable one time for BS/CS students. at least two 300-level ICS classes or consent.
prerequisites: at least two ICS 300-level ICS classes or consent

title: Special Topics in Security
description: Special topics in security oriented toward juniors and seniors. Repeatable unlimited times. at least two 300-level ICS courses or consent.
prerequisites: at least two ICS 300-level ICS courses or consent

title: Capstone Project
description: Project-based course where students work in teams on a software project. Knowledge acquired in the computer science curriculum will be applied to design and implement a software product with potential real-world applicability. Repeatable one time. CS majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. (311 or ECE 367) and 314.

title: Computer Project
description: Individual or small group projects in system design or application under faculty supervision. consent.

title: Intelligent Autonomous Agents
description: Theory, methods and practical applications of autonomous agent systems, including common applications of both software and hardware (robotic) agents. In-depth practical experience with autonomous agents through programming assignments and projects. 313 or ECE 467 (or equivalent), graduate standing; or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: ICS 313 or ECE 467 (or equivalent), graduate standing; or consent

title: Compiler Theory and Construction
description: Design and implementation of compilers, syntactic and semantic descriptions of programming languages, algorithms for syntactic analysis and object code generation. 312 or consent.

title: Theory of Operating Systems
description: Advanced study in operating systems theory and design with emphasis on case studies and distributed systems.

title: Advanced Software Engineering
description: Fundamental software engineering procedures, including planning, estimation, design, testing, process definition and improvement, and software quality assurance. Measurement techniques are used to support empirically-driven software process improvement throughout the course. graduate standing, or consent.

title: Medical Informatics I
description: Introduction to the field of medical informatics, which is found at the intersection of clinical science, public health, information science, computer technology and communications technology. Concentration on current issues. consent.

title: Software Quality and Maintenance
description: Introduction to software quality concepts and the major activities involved in software maintenance. A-F only.

title: Information Architecture and Web Design
description: User-centered design of websites; survey Information Architecture (IA) systems (organization, navigation, labeling, searching); gain experience in methodologies for creating IA, tools for IA, web standards and usability tests. ICS and LIS majors only. A-F only. graduate standing in ICS or LIS or related field or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in ICS or LIS or related field or consent

title: Analysis of Algorithms
description: Analysis and design of algorithms: modeling, comparison, measures, applications. graduate standing, or consent.

title: Network Science
description: Modeling human-made and natural systems as networks to understand their structure and dynamics. Computational and statistical methods and research results they enabled. Use of network analysis software. Applications to topics of interest to students.

title: Advanced Cryptography
description: Taxonomy of security properties: methods for defining and proving security. Randomness, pseudorandomness, and indistinguishability. Functional encryption and obfuscation. Zero knowledge. graduate standing, or consent.

title: Advanced Data Management
description: Exploration of information retrieval and object-relational tools and methods for the management of distributed multimedia database systems. graduate standing, or consent.

title: Principles of High Performance Computing
description: Principles of high performance computing for single-processor and parallel architectures. Detailed coverage of parallel architectures and exposure to shared-memory, distributed-memory, and hybrid parallelism. Hands-on experience with message-passing and multithreaded programming. A-F only. graduate standing in computer science or closely related field, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in computer science or closely related field, or consent

title: Machine Learning
description: Introduction to key theoretical concepts of machine learning. Practical experience with decision free methods, artificial neural networks. Bayesian belief networks and contemporary statistical methods including regression, clustering and classification. consent. (Once a year)

title: Information Theory in Machine Learning
description: Basics of information processing and learning in the brain; neural networks; learning algorithms based on information maximization; applications in molecular biology and bioinformatics. A-F only. graduate standing in computer science or mathematics background, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in computer science or mathematics background, or consent

title: Deep Learning with Neural Networks
description: Graduate course on deep learning with artificial neural networks. Provides practical techniques for modeling image, video, text, and graph data with supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning approaches. Includes instruction in the latest software frameworks. Graduate students only. 635 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence
description: Covers the latest developments in human-centered artificial intelligence, including ethics, bias, explainability, privacy, fairness, and usability. Involves discussion, writing assignments, and a final project. A-F only.

title: Advanced Theory of Computation
description: Advanced topics in formal languages, automata, computability, computational complexity. 441 or consent.

title: Advanced Parallel Algorithms
description: Design and analysis of parallel algorithms, with emphasis on advanced techniques and latest advances in parallel algorithms. graduate standing, or consent.

title: Computer Networks
description: Elementary principles of modern computer networking. Detailed coverage of overall architecture and the physical, data link, and network layers, with emphasis on the network layer. ICS majos only. graduate standing in ICS, or consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing in ICS, or consent

title: Security and Trust III: Cyber Security and Commerce
description: Tools and methods for security managers. Tools and methods to secure and monetize services and applications. Network as a computer and as a market. Problems of cyber war, cyber crime, cyber bullying. Graduate students only. (Spring only)

title: Computer Architecture I
description: Models of computation, high-performance processors, pipelined machines, RISC processors, VLIW, superscalar and fine-grain parallel machines. Data-flow architectures. Hardware/software tradeoffs. ECE 461. (

title: Advanced Artificial Intelligence
description: Current issues in artificial intelligence, including expert systems, knowledge representation, logic programming, learning, natural language processing. graduate standing, or consent.

title: Pattern Recognition
description: Nature of the problem in pattern recognition and clustering; explanation of various algorithms. graduate standing, or consent.

title: Human-Computer Interaction II
description: Studies of human performance in designing and using information systems. Emphasizes concepts and methodologies from human factors, psychology, and software engineering relating to human performance. graduate standing, or consent.

title: User Interfaces and Hypermedia
description: Advanced concepts in construction of interfaces between computers and their users. Hypermedia information structures, guidelines, problems, and tradeoffs. Discussion of selected readings, implementation of prototypes. 465 or consent.

title: HCI Design Methods
description: Advanced analytical and empirical methods for the design and evaluation of usable, useful, and robust human computer interfaces. Students will apply selected methodologies to a major system design project. 464 or 465, or consent.

title: Social Informatics
description: An advanced introduction to the design of human-computer systems and other technological artifacts for supporting human collaboration in learning, work and social contexts, and to theoretical perspectives and empirical studies of collaboration that inform such design. A-F only. 464 or 465 or 664 or 665 or 667 or LIS 677; or consent.
prerequisites: ICS 464 or ICS 465 or ICS 664 or ICS 665 or ICS 667 or LIS 677; or consent

title: Social Computing
description: Participative analysis of online communities and user-generated content collections. Theoretical and practical aspects of online interaction, identity, trust, and virtual social capital. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Evolutionary Computation I: Survey of Methods
description: Evolutionary computation surveys in the field to prepare students for research. Topics include diverse engineering applications, theory, and concepts including search spaces, representation, objective functions, variation operators, selection, and population based search. 211 (B or better) and 241 (C or better) and admitted to a graduate program or capable of graduate-level work in computer sciences, or consent. (Once a year: fall)
prerequisites: ICS 211 (B or better) and ICS 241 (C or better) and admitted to a graduate program or capable of graduate-level work in computer sciences, or consent

title: Bioinformatics: Sequences Analysis
description: To expose students to bioinformatics at the biological sequences analysis level (DNA, RNA, proteins). Several bioinformatics methods and algorithms are introduced. Students are required to present one paper and to participate in a small group project. A-F only. . graduate standing, or consent. (Once a year)

title: Bioinformatics: Microarrays
description: Introduction to the basic principles of biology relevant for microarray gene expression data and to Bio-conductor. Collaborative open-source project to develop a modular general framework for the analysis of cDNA arrays and gene chips. A-F only. 311 or background in biology, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: ICS 311 or background in biology, or consent

title: Computer Graphics
description: Selected advanced topics in computer graphics. Substantial project required. 481 or consent.

title: Numerical Computation
description: Selected topics in numerical analysis, mathematical software, and scientific computation; examples include sparse matrix methods, finite element methods, mathematical programming. consent.

title: Advanced Computer Vision
description: Fundamental problems and core concepts and techniques in computer vision, covering both theoretical and practical issues in the field. A-F only. graduate standing, or consent. (Once a year)

title: Advanced Data Visualization
description: Explores advanced techniques in data visualization by surveying visualization techniques from the past 5-10 years, and designing and developing data visualizations leveraging those techniques. Graduate students only. (Fall only)

title: Virtual and Augmented Reality
description: Students will learn the science, engineering, art, and applications of virtual reality and augmented reality, with an emphasis on the construction of working virtual environments. Graduate students only. (Fall only)

title: Digital Video Information
description: Principles and techniques of technical and context analysis of digital video information. Video capture and editing tools, compression and analysis algorithms, visual culture, narrative structure, juxtaposition of multimedia elements and their effects on information transmission. graduate standing or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Seminar in ICS
description: Series of talks on advanced research topics. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.

title: (Alpha) Topics in Computer Science
description: Reflects special interests of faculty in various areas of computer science. (B) area 1; (C) area 2; (D) area 3; (E) area 4; (G) general. Repeatable unlimited times in different topics and different areas. consent.

title: Special Topics Seminar
description: Seminar discussing special topics in information and computer science. Topics and number of credits vary. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Advanced Special Topics in Security
description: Current topics and upcoming issues relevant to the field of information assurance and cyber security. Repeatable unlimited times. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. graduate standing and consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable eight times. candidacy for PhD in computer science.
prerequisites: candidacy for PhD in computer science

title: Using Computers and Applications
description: Using Windows computers browsers, Microsoft Office (or equivalent) and other applications. A-F only.

title: Project Management
description: Project management application and techniques such as planning methods; PERT/CPM forecasting; risk analysis; application in information technology projects and other areas. BUS 310 and 311.

title: Supply Chain Processes
description: Improving organization productivity with an emphasis on analyzing supply chain processes and principles in terms of scheduling, inventory, quality control techniques, through most current practices. BUS 310 and 311.

title: Programming Application Systems
description: Introduction to applications programming. Fundamentals, essential logic, file handling, report writing. Emphasis on systems development and disciplined programming. A-F only. ICS 101, or LTEC 112 and 113, (or equivalent), or consent.
prerequisites: ICS 101, or LTEC 112 and LTEC 113, (or equivalent), or consent

title: Information Systems Analysis and Design
description: Analysis and design of systems in organizations. Includes role of general systems concepts, systems development life cycle, identifying systems requirements, logical and physical design. A-F only. 352 and BUS 311.

title: Database Systems
description: Introduction to database management and data structures, including database planning and design, normalization, relational and network data models, and physical organization and implementation. A-F only. 353.

title: Current Topics in ITM
description: Repeatable three times with permission of department chair. varies with topic.

title: Information Systems in Organizations
description: Practice of information systems in organizations. Capstone course for MIS majors. A-F only. 353 and 354 (or concurrent), and BUS 311.
prerequisites: ITM 353 and ITM 354 (or concurrent), and BUS 311

title: Electronic Commerce
description: Survey of electronic commerce technologies and business strategies, with an emphasis on technology and application development. The development of web-based and multimedia applications; the impacts of EC on business strategy; legal and ethical issues. A-F only. BUS 311 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Advanced Topics in Information Systems
description: Computerized management information systems, operations research or business statistics: (B) software systems economics; (C) advanced topics in programming; (D) web-based application development; (E) advanced technology in MIS; (F) systems development; (G) database systems; (H) advanced business applications; (J) ethics of technology; (K) business intelligence. Repeatable with permission of department chair. varies with topic.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Reading and research in special area of major under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by the department chair and the faculty advisor.

title: Networking and Security
description: Basic concepts in networking and security. Network standards and technologies. Network planning and design. LANs and WANS, wireless networking. Security threats and countermeasures. Security planning and policies. A-F only.

title: Advanced Security
description: Designed around the plan-protect-respond cycle. Security threats, cryptographic security, access control, identity management, firewalls, intrusion detection systems, host hardening, and application security. Repeatable one time. 431 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Current Topics in Information Systems
description: Selected current practices and trends in decision sciences and MIS. Repeatable three times. ACC, CIS, and BUS majors only.

title: Project Management, Information Technology and Change
description: Lectures and discussions to contextualize knowledge and techniques of project management in organizational change, globalization and outsourcing, global teamwork, intercultural awareness, negotiation and leadership. Semester long group project. Open to all graduate students. (Once a year)

title: Enterprise Data and Information Management
description: Framework of policies, people, processes, and technologies to control, protect, deliver, and enhance the organizational data assets; best practices and technologies for database management, data warehousing, and data curation; support of enterprise data governance. MIS, ICS, MIS-BBA majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Business Intelligence and Data Analytics
description: Addresses business intelligence and data analytics at operational, tactical, and strategic levels using basic data science techniques, including visual, descriptive, diagnostic, predictive, and prescriptive analytics methods and hands-on learning using current software tools. A-F only. 619 or consent.

title: Enterprise System Architecture and Management
description: Foundations of enterprise information systems design and architecture to support business strategy, processes, data, and IT/IS services; integrating cloud-based and loT infrastructure; management and maintenance of organizational IS/IT infrastructure and operations. MIS, ICS, MIS-BBA majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Digitally-Enabled Business Processes
description: Business process analysis, design, and implementation of new business processes enabled by digital platforms. Concepts, methods, and techniques to support prototyping and user interface design are considered. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Management of Health Information Technology and Population Health
description: Covers latest trends/innovations in HIT designed to reduce costs, improve quality/access, and reduce outcome disparity through population health management. Includes management of financial, organizational, and professional barriers to effective HIT. A-F only. Graduate students only. (Alt. years)

title: Capstone Course
description: Individual- or team-based project with a client organization, conducted under faculty supervision, as capstone project to complete masters level work in the Masters of Science in Information Systems. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. Graduate students only. A-F only. students must complete 15 semester hours and core masters courses before capstone.
prerequisites: students must complete ITM 15 semester hours and core masters courses before capstone

title: Directed Research
description: Reading and research in ITM under the direction of a faculty member. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only.

title: Doctoral Seminar in Information Systems
description: Extensive and critical review of the IS research literature. Can be retaken for credit. Repeatable three times. A-F only. CIS 703 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Research Seminar in E-Business in the Asia Pacific Region
description: Overview of the current research issues in e-business with focus on the Asia Pacific region. A-F only. PhD student status in international management or consent.
prerequisites: PhD student status in international management or consent

title: International IT Organizational Research Methods
description: Overview of current survey methodology and analysis in global information systems research. A-F only. PhD student status in international management or consent.
prerequisites: PhD student status in international management or consent

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Reading and research in an area of information technology management under the direction of faculty member(s). A-F only. PhD student status in international management or consent.
prerequisites: PhD student status in international management or consent

title: Dynamic Earth
description: The natural physical environment; the landscape; rocks and minerals, rivers and oceans; volcanism, earthquakes, and other processes inside the Earth; effects of human use of the Earth and its resources. Field trip. (

title: The Natural Environment
description: Introduction to physical geography including weather, climate, vegetation, soils, geology, and landforms. Environmental issues and natural hazards. (

title: The Natural Environment Lab
description: A survey of field and laboratory methods commonly used by physical geographers. GEO 101 (or concurrent). (

title: An Introduction to Integrative Systems Biology: Hawaiian Biomes as a Framework
description: Lecture/discussion introduces students to the field of biology through the integration of microbiology and macrobiology into a single, comprehensive systems biology with a focus on Hawaiian biomes and ecosystem sustainability. (Spring only) (

title: Biology & Society Laboratory
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Explores connections between biological principles and everyday life with a focus on the environment. Topics include environmental health and sustainability with examples from Hawai‘i. Not a BIOL major elective. (

title: Introduction to the Environment, Climate Change, & Sustainability
description: Introduction to the environment, climate change, and sustainability as they apply to ecosystems. Sustainability will be introduced through active learning exercises that address sustainable development and the three pillars of sustainability. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (

title: Introduction to the Environment and Sustainability Lab
description: Introduction to a variety of quantitative and qualitative approaches and methodologies to describe and assess key components to the environment. A-F only. 112 (or concurrent) or GES 102 (or concurrent) or OCN 102 (or concurrent). (
prerequisites: SUST 112 (or concurrent) or GES 102 (or concurrent) or OCN 102 (or concurrent)

title: Quantifying Global and Environmental Change
description: Introductory mathematical approaches to quantifying key aspects of global and environmental change. Includes data analysis, graphical representation and modeling of population growth, greenhouse gas emissions and fate, sustainable resource utilization, and sea level change. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Sustainable Cities
description: How do we plan cities to meet long-term social, economic, and environmental needs? Students will learn about sustainability as it relates to issues like energy, transportation, housing, land, water, and food. Emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only. (

title: Sustainability in a Changing World
description: Environmentally sustainable and non-sustainable practices, and the impacts of climate change, on the development and spread of human societies from -history to the 1500s in Asia, Africa, Europe, the Americas, and Hawai‘i/Oceania. Active learning environment. (
prerequisites: -history to the SUST 1500s in Asia, Africa, Europe, the Americas, and Hawai‘i/Oceania

title: Humans and the Environment
description: Prepares students to make decisions such as where to build/buy a house, sustainable use of natural resources, and what environmental actions relevant to society and Earth’s ecosystem are appropriate on a local and global scale. A-F only. (

title: Chemistry in a Sustainable World
description: Introduction to chemistry for non-science majors. Discussion of the role of natural and man-made chemicals in everyday life, with an emphasis on sustainable and environmentally-sensitive use of chemicals to improve our world. A-F only. Students who successfully completed CHEM 100 with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 120/CHEM 110 without instructor override. Students who successfully complete 120/CHEM 110 with a grade of C or better will not be allowed to enroll in 100 without instructor override. (

title: Sustainable Food and Energy Field Course
description: Examines the nexus of food, energy, and water in Hawai‘i for sustainable development. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits. (

title: Global Environmental History
description: Explores the influence of nature–climate, topography, plants, animals, and microorganisms–on human history and the way people, in turn, have influenced the natural world around them. (

title: Religion and the Environment
description: Examines the roles contemporary religious groups play in ground movements for sustainability. Introduces students to key scholars, religious leaders, and activists who are implementing sustainable solutions to pressing environmental problems. A-F only. (

title: Climate Change
description: Introduction to the science of climate change focusing on Earth’s past, present and future, specifically, the causes, consequences, and record of past changes; future projections, mitigation, and adaptation. Appropriate for both science and non-science majors. ERTH 101 or ERTH 103 or ERTH 104 or ERTH 106 or ERTH 111 or ERTH 130 or ATMO 101 or GES 102, or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: ERTH 101 or ERTH 103 or ERTH 104 or ERTH 106 or ERTH 111 or ERTH 130 or ATMO 101 or GES 102, or consent

title: Historical Ecology of Hawai‘i
description: The Hawaiian socio-ecosystem is the product of centuries of human land use and resource exploitation. Explores the events and processes that have shaped the islands’ ecology and future sustainability. A-F only. (

title: Introduction to Environmental Science
description: Analysis of our environment with emphasis on understanding relationships and interactions of physical, biological, technological, and political components using scientific methods of inquiry. Food supply and safety, water quality, pollution control, biodiversity, environmental policy. Open to nonmajors. (

title: Agriculture, Environment, and Society
description: Relationship of plants, soils, and the environment, and how they relate to cultural practices and society in agroecosystems with an emphasis on Hawai‘i as a model system. (

title: Hawaiian Perspectives in Ahupua‘a
description: Examination of the ahupua‘a system as it was conceptualized by the ancient Hawaiians, and exploration of its relevance in modern society; an introductory class to the malama ‘aina track designed to build critical writing skills. A-F only. 107. (

title: Agricultural and Resource Economics
description: Introduction to basic economics concepts, including demand, supply, exchange, market price and market failure. Economic evaluation and policy for the uses of various natural resource endowments, especially in production agriculture, is included. A-F only. (

title: Organic Food Crop Production
description: Combined lecture/lab on the theory and practice of certified organic food production. Field visits to organic farms/markets included. Open to nonmajors. (Fall only) (

title: Hawaiians
description: The sustainable social system, culture, spirituality, language, land stewardship, and governance of Native Hawaiians. Transformation of the sustainable Hawaiian social system by a capitalist economy. Resiliency, land issues, and Native Hawaiian quest for sovereign governance. (

title: Introduction to Sustainability from Social Science Perspectives
description: Introduction to key concepts and theories in social sciences in relation to sustainability issues. (

title: Scientific Principles of Sustainability
description: Introduction to the scientific principles of sustainability, including the ecology of managed and natural ecosystems, global change biology, ecological principles of natural resource management, renewable energy technologies, and the environmental impacts of humans. (

title: Introduction to Environmental Humanities
description: Introduction to the environmental humanities, which rests at the intersection of the arts, humanities, and environmental studies. (

title: Global and Local Perspectives on Severe Weather
description: Dynamics and structure of the main types of severe weather (tropical cyclones, supercell storms, tornadoes, flash floods, hailstorms, fog, etc.); future changes due to climate change; risk assessment; severe weather in Hawai‘i. ATMO, GES, GG, GEO, GES, NREM, or OCN students only. A-F only. (Alt years: Spring) (

title: Environmental Issues
description: Global environmental problems in historical perspective; physical, biological, sociocultural views. one of BIOL 101, BIOL 123, or GEO 101; or consent. (
prerequisites: one of BIOL 101, BIOL 123, or GEO 101; or consent

title: Conservation Ethics
description: Introduction to and discussion of ethical issues associated with biodiversity, ecology, and conservation biology. Repeatable one time. A-F only. any DB course or consent. (Once a year) (

title: Natural Resources Management
description: Biological and physical science aspects of natural resource management at local, national, and global scales. Topics covered include resource management of soil, water, forests, wetlands, coasts and wildlife. A-F only. (NREM/TPSS 251 or 210; CHEM 151 or higher; and BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: (NREM/TPSS 251 or NREM 210; CHEM 151 or higher; and BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent

title: Natural Resource and Environmental Policy
description: Introduction to natural resource and environmental public policy at U.S. federal, Hawai‘i state, local, and international levels. Policy principles, legal structure, governmental agencies, statutes and programs, analytical techniques, program assessments, and contemporary ethical issues. A-F only. SUST/ NREM/PEPS 210 or or NREM/SOCS/TPSS 251 or (BIOL 101 or higher) or GEO 101 or (ERTH 101 or higher); and NREM/SUST 220 or one ECON course or two DS courses. (
prerequisites: SUST/ NREM/PEPS 210 or or NREM/SOCS/TPSS 251 or (BIOL 101 or higher) or GEO 101 or (ERTH 101 or higher); and NREM/SUST 220 or one ECON course or two DS courses

title: Plant Conservation Biology
description: Introduction to the concepts and principles of plant conservation biology and to plant conservation-inpractice in Hawai‘i and elsewhere. A-F only. BOT/ BIOL 305 or consent. (Once a year) (

title: Plant Conservation Biology Lab
description: Introduction to approaches, methods, and analyses used in the study and practice of plant conservation, with an emphasis on experimental design and problem-solving. Includes both laboratory and field components. A-F only. BOT/BIOL 305 or consent. Co-requisite: BOT 301. (Once a year) (

title: Global Environmental Issues
description: Use and abuse of natural resources and humanity’s progress toward developing a sustainable relationship with its supporting environment. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. (Once a year) (

title: Water and Society
description: Interaction of people with water at household, community, regional, national, and international scales, from cultural, political, economic, and biophysical perspectives. sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: sophomore standing or higher, or consent

title: Environmental Ethics
description: Application of traditional moral theories to environmental issues. Development and evaluation of specific environmental ethical theories. Application of ethical theories to environmental decision-making. A-F only. 210 or GEO 101 or PHIL 101 or PHIL 103. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: SUST 210 or GEO 101 or PHIL 101 or PHIL 103

title: Malama ‘Āina Resource Management Visual Technologies
description: Requires a broad set of knowledge systems. Will introduce students to a variety of visual technologies for use in resource management and the ethical application of these technologies. 107. (

title: Race, Indigeneity, and Environmental Justice
description: Introduction to environmental justice, explores the premise that all people have a right to a life-affirming environment. Will examine environmental racism, and the geographical dimensions of race and indigeneity. one DS or DH course, or consent. (
prerequisites: one DS or DH course, or consent

title: Environment and Agriculture
description: Overview of environmental issues related to agriculture, specifically pest management issues, and options for environmentally responsible management and amelioration of these impacts. Ethical issues on impact of agriculture on the environment will be discussed. (

title: Hawai‘i and the Pacific
description: Hawai‘i as part of the Pacific community: selected historical and contemporary problems of Pacific areas; cultural and economic imperialism, land alienation, and the impact of development on Pacific peoples. one DS or DH course. (

title: Globalization and Environment
description: Debates on globalization and development, population and resources; root causes of environmental degradation; impacts of globalization on environmentalism and environmental change; social approaches to managing environmental change. Junior standing or higher. (

title: Applied Principles of Environmental & Energy Policy
description: Introduction to the methods and techniques of environmental and energy policy in relation to energy systems. Analysis of enacted policies from case studies to understanding the effectiveness, challenges, contradictions, and limitations of each. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. any 100 or 200 level OCN course, or consent. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: any SUST 100 or SUST 200 level OCN course, or consent

title: Global Environmental Politics
description: Evolution of international politics, law and decision-making on a variety of environmental concerns; from endangered species to pollution to climate change. Interaction of population, development, and environment in global governance. (

title: Communicating Sustainability
description: Application of scientific communication theory, strategic communication, and multimedia techniques to select issues of environmental sustainability. COM majors only. A-F only. COM 201 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent. (
prerequisites: COM 201 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Geography, Environment, and Society
description: Examines the geography of resources and environmental change with a holistic and multi-scale perspective. Social approaches to resolving environmental problems. Sophomore standing or higher. (

title: Culture and Environment
description: Critically examines changing views of nature, nature-culture relationships, and perceptions of the environment across different cultures. (

title: Economics of Global Climate Change
description: Nature and causes of global climate change and economic solutions. Topics include valuing climate change impacts, energy solutions, environmental implications, societal adaptation, and international cooperation. A-F only. 120 or 130 or 131, or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: SUST 120 or SUST 130 or SUST 131, or consent

title: Climate Change and Cultural Response: Past, Present, and Future
description: Climate change is a reality, yet there is much uncertainty about how it will affect our lives. Investigates cultural response to climate change, using studies of the past to plan for the future. (Alt. years: spring) (

title: Society and Environment
description: Relationship of humans with natural environment; role of culture in ecological systems. 152. (

title: Energy Economics and Policy
description: Analysis of economic and policy aspects of energy use, and interactions of markets for various nonrenewable and renewable energy options. Evaluations of policies to develop alternative energy sources. ECON 120 or ECON 130 or ECON 131. (

title: Inter-woven Structures
description: Studio investigation of threads under tension. Thematic lens of environmental vulnerability and resiliency. Explores art practice as embodied knowledge. Specific attention to weaving as meaning and place-making. Engages writing as a significant tool for analysis. A-F only. ART 116 or consent. (Cross-listing as ART 338)

title: Human Values and the Environment
description: Examination of nature-culture dynamic over a range of contexts–literary ecology, systems ecology, political ecology, eco-feminism, environmental ethics–in order to articulate new possibilities for interdisciplinary understanding of the human place in nature. A-F only. any ENG DL or PHIL or GEO course, or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: any ENG DL or PHIL or GEO course, or consent

title: Land Tenure and Use in Hawai‘i
description: Dynamics of change: indigenous Hawaiian land tenure; Great Mahele and Kuleana Act; ethnic succession of land ownership; concentration of ownership today; effects of land development on ethnic communities. one DS or DH course. (

title: Sustainable Development
description: Transdisciplinary introduction to sustainable development. Interactions between environment, economy, and public policy, especially in Hawai‘i. Topics include: curse of paradise, global warming, energy use, health, poverty, population, water resources, traffic congestion, biodiversity, pollution controls. 120 or 130 or 131, or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: SUST 120 or SUST 130 or SUST 131, or consent

title: Economic Change and Hawai‘i’s People
description: Hawai‘i’s economic transformation from sustainable communal subsistence through mercantile capitalism, plantation capitalism, and global finance capital and impact on its people. Alternative sustainable enterprises for a self-sufficient island economy. one DS or DH course. (

title: Aloha Kanaloa-Marine Resources and Abundance
description: Undergraduate course exposing students to the resources and processes of the ocean, research, and management approaches, as well as a Hawaiian worldview of oceanic elements. Junior standing or higher. HWST 107. (

title: Basic Environmental Benefit Cost Analysis
description: Fundamentals of benefit-cost analysis with extensions to environmental impacts and projects; case studies. 220/NREM 220 or ECON 130 or consent. (

title: Sustainability, Technoscience, and Social Justice
description: Examines politics of sustainability and technoscience with an explicit attention to social justice and power relations in society. A-F only. WS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course, or SOC 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or consent.
prerequisites: WS 151 or any WS 200- or WS 300-level WS course, or SOC 100 or any SOC 200-level SOC course, or consent
crossListings: Fall only Crosslisted as SOC 367 and WS 367

title: Genetics: Theory to Application
description: Fundamentals of genetic theory using traditional breeding and biotechnological procedures in insect and plant pathogen management for sustainable agricultural production. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (

title: Environmental Law and Politics
description: Focuses on theories, laws, policies, ethics, and sustainable futures of Hawai‘i and the U.S. Sophomore standing or higher. any 100 or 200 level POLS course, or consent. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: any SUST 100 or SUST 200 level POLS course, or consent

title: Politics of the Ocean
description: Study of the ocean as a political place. Engagement with theories, policies, and lived-experiences of the ocean through a political lens, including literature and experiential learning. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. any 100 or 200-level POLS course, or consent. (
prerequisites: any SUST 100 or SUST 200-level POLS course, or consent

title: Internship for Sustainability and Social Justice
description: Internship in public, private, or non-profit organizations providing opportunity for practical experience in addressing sustainability issues. Repeatable one time. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent. A-F only. Consent of instructor. (

title: History of the Indian Ocean World
description: Explores the transnational history of the Indian Ocean world, especially the region connected by the western monsoon. Topics include travel, trade, religion, colonialism, nationalism, diaspora, and globalization, including actors like slaves, sailors, women, and merchants. (Alt. years) (

title: Climate, Air Quality, & Policy
description: Examination of air quality problems from scientific and policy perspectives. Includes case studies that explore economic, political, technical, and legal aspects of pollution control. junior standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Sustainable Soil and Plant Health Management
description: Provides knowledge and understanding of soils, agroecology, and sustainable approaches for plant health management, and prepares students for applied research in various tropical cropping systems. A-F only. (Alt. years: spring) (

title: Methods in Wildlife Management & Conservation
description: Introduces fundamental techniques for wildlife management and conservation. In addition to hands-on training, students will learn underlying biological and ecological principles, as well as quantitative skills, with an emphasis on sustainable management. Repeatable one time. A-F only. BIOL 171. (Spring only) (

title: The Ocean Economy
description: Examination of society’s interaction with the ocean. Topics include: ocean recreation, shipping, boat building, ports, offshore energy production, aquaculture, fishing, coastal construction, and coral reef protection. 120 or 130, or consent. (Once a year) (

title: Past Global Change and the Human Era
description: Study of past environments to understand present and future global change. Focus on terrestrial Quaternary environments and global processes. junior standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: The Ethics of Climate Change and Geoengineering
description: Provide a scientific basis to examine the consequences of climate change and the proposed geoengineering solutions, and examine the fundamental ethical basis that underlies environmental policies. A-F only. OCN 310. (Alt. years: spring) (

title: Nature-Based Tourism Management
description: Principles of nature-based tourism, including a survey of impacts, objectives, planning, and management systems. Junior standing or higher. TIM 101 or GEOG/TIM 324. (

title: Community and Natural Resource Management
description: Theory and tools for working with groups and communities in the management of natural resources is presented using a participatory format. Topics include sustainable development, extension programming, participatory learning and communication, evaluation, and conflict management. two social science courses (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: two social science courses (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent

title: Sustainable Tourism Policies and Practices
description: Seminar examining the social, environmental, economic factors of sustainable tourism development. Emphasis on methods and processes and the role of stakeholders (government, industry, host community, tourists). Group projects. A-F only. 101 and departmental approval. (

title: Biocontrol of Invasive Species
description: Biological control of invasive insects and weeds using natural enemies; biological control as a cornerstone of sustainable pest management; contributions of biocontrol to economic, environmental, and societal sustainability; reduced dependence on pesticides; increased sustainability of pest management. PEPS 363 or consent. (

title: Agriculture, Food and Society
description: Examines historical and contemporary development of the global agro-food systems. The impacts of technological, political and economic changes to food security, environment and development. Open to nonmajors. junior standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Environmental Geochemistry
description: Theory and applications of contaminant/pollutant distribution in the hydrosphere-geosphere-biosphere-atmosphere system, remediation methods, prevention, industrial/agricultural best practices. Topics include aqueous geochemistry, organic, inorganic, gas phase, and ecosystem impacts of environmental contaminants. CHEM 161 and CHEM 162, or consent. (Spring only) (

title: Environment, Resources and Society
description: Human interaction with the environment. How market, property institution, and technological change affect the environment. Epistemological basis of environmental policies. Debates on controversial environmental issues. 102, 151, or consent. (

title: Beaches, Reefs, and Climate Change
description: Global and local aspects of climate change and paleoclimate; beach and reef processes and response to climate change; management of coastal environments; field study local sites. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher, or consent. (

title: Interdisciplinary Science Curriculum
description: Conceptual schemes and processes for integrating science curricula within the sciences and with subject areas. Methods and models of curricular integration such as interdisciplinary, culturally relevant, place and community-based learning. Repeatable one time. (

title: Use, Re-use, and Radical Re-use
description: Explores the related concepts of use, re-use, and radical re-use through an exploration of new applications of traditional fiber techniques and contexts of making. Engages writing as a significant tool for art-making and analysis. A-F only. ART 116 or consent. (

title: Installation/Performance–Material in Context
description: Studio investigation of the transformation of space (ecological, social, political, psychological) through artist intervention. Experiments in non-object based interventions and into the evocative potential of materials. Engages writing and oral expression as significant analytical tools. Repeatable one time. A-F only. ART 116 or consent. (

title: Vulnerability & Adaptation on Coastal Infrastructure
description: Assessing vulnerability of coastal communities to climate change stressors and providing technical engineering solutions for adaptation. Senior standing or higher. (Spring only) (

title: Principles of Sustainability Analysis
description: Key principles of sustainability and its analysis. Quantification of environmental impact/assessment using target plots, mass/energy balances, and life cycle analyses (cradle to gate/grave) applied to products, processes, or systems. Use of SimaPro. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Environmental Management Systems
description: Introduction to the process of developing Environmental Management Systems that address the principles outlined in ISO14001:2015. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Infrastructure: Project Impacts, Policy and Sustainability
description: Evaluation of infrastructure impacts. Impacts regulation and mitigation. Effects of environmental and other policies on infrastructure. Infrastructure relations to sustainability. Energy consumption, transportation efficiency and infrastructure recycling. Lectures and presentations by experts and enrolled students. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. senior standing, open to engineering, science, urban planning, and economics majors. (
prerequisites: senior standing, open to engineering, science, urban planning, and economics majors

title: Ethnoecology and Conservation
description: Ecological implications of cultural uses of plants. Examines the biological basis for, and ecological effects of traditional and local resource management systems. BOT 305 or BIOL 265/265L or consent. (

title: Hawaiian Ethnobotany
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Methods and techniques of handling and identifying plant materials used by early Hawaiians and modern Hawaiians for house and canoe construction, clothing, household and fishing items, medicine, and food preparation. Reading, laboratory, and fieldwork. BOT 440 or consent. (

title: Climate Modeling, Data Analysis and Applications
description: Introduction to regional and global climate modeling for environmental scientists and engineers. Learn principles of climate modeling, how to access and use climate data for sustainable engineering and environmental management solutions, and effectively communicate results. A-F only. Senior standing or higher, or consent. (

title: Natural History of Hawaiian Islands
description: (2 Lec, 1 1-hr Lab) Geography, geology, climatology, biotic environment of Pacific Basin and Hawaiian Islands; endemism and evolution in terrestrial and marine biota. one semester of biological sciences at college level. (
prerequisites: one semester of biological sciences at college level

title: Wildlife Ecology and Management
description: Lecture-based overview of the history, ecology, and management of wildlife species from around the world and Hawai‘i. BIOL 172 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: BIOL 172 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent

title: Hawaiian Sovereignty in Pacific Context
description: Causes and dynamics of ethnic conflicts with attention to problem resolution; (B) Middle East; (C) Hawaiian sovereignty in Pacific context. one DS or DH course, or consent for (C). (
prerequisites: one DS or DH course, or consent for (C)

title: Natural Resource Issues and Ethics
description: Overview of the history of land, resources and power in Hawai‘i; players and processes influencing land and natural resources policies today explored from Native Hawaiian and other viewpoints. Extensive use of case studies. HWST 207/SUST 217 or HWST 307/ SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356 (
prerequisites: HWST 207/SUST 217 or HWST 307/ SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356 ()

title: ‘Āina Mauliola: Hawaiian Ecosystems
description: Comprehensive analysis of traditional Hawaiian and modern resource management practices. Rigorous overview of the dominant physical and biological processes from the uplands to the oceans in Hawai‘i. 217/HWST 207 or 317/HWST 307 or SUST/HWST 356. (

title: Project Evaluation and Resource Management
description: Principles of project evaluation and policy analysis. Shadow pricing, economic cost of taxes and tariffs; public policy for exhaustible, renewable, and environmental resources. 301. (

title: Strategies in Hawaiian Resource Use
description: Analyzing diverse land and water use strategies of O‘ahu, from traditional Hawaiian, scientific and economic perspectives, through classroom and on-site lectures. Topics include traditional Hawaiian methods, modern development, threatened ecosystems, ecotourism and scientific research. A-F only. 217/HWST 207 or 317/HWST 307 or SUST/HWST/356. (.

title: Hui Konohiki Practicum
description: A “hands-on” internship in an environmental or resource-management organization in Hawai‘i. The experience will be broadened and supplemented by classroom lectures, discussion and analysis from traditional Hawaiian, scientific and economic perspectives. A-F only. 217/HWST 207 or 317/HWST 307 or SUST/HWST 356. (Spring only) (

title: Global Ethnic Conflict
description: Ethnic conflicts cause most wars on our globe today. Examines causes of ethnic conflict, including climate change. Will evaluate approaches to building peaceful relations between groups and developing sustainable relationships with the environment. Junior standing or higher. one DS or DH course or consent. (
prerequisites: one DS or DH course or consent

title: Applied Forest Ecology
description: Application of ecological theory to sustainable management of forest resources in Hawaii and beyond, including silviculture (production of timber and nontimber forest products), restoration (restoring damaged or degraded forests), and conservation (conserving existing forest resources). A-F only. (311/NREM 310 and NREM 380) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: (SUST 311/NREM 310 and NREM 380) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent

title: American Environmental History
description: Survey history of the complex relations between American societies and diverse U.S. ecosystems, from European contact and colonization to the present. (

title: Anthropology and the Environment: Culture, Power, and Politics
description: Investigates environmental problems from an anthropological perspective, and examines the cultural politics of contestations over resources, rights, and the meanings of nature. ANTH 152 or ANTH 415 or consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Contemporary Art and Ecology
description: Explores the recent history of environmental and ecological art; provides a critical framework for the contemporary image politics of environmentalism, ecology, sustainability, and climate change with an emphasis on writing and ethical reasoning. A-F only. ART 176 or consent.(

title: Environmental Problem Solving
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Senior-level capstone for NREM and related majors. Ecosystem management within problemsolving context. Applications of research and analytical methods, management tools to case studies. Focus on student teamwork and oral communications. NREM majors only. A-F only. Senior standing or consent. (

title: Sustainability Capstone
description: Capstone for undergraduate students in interdisciplinary studies focusing on sustainability. The capstone experience provides an opportunity for students to gain knowledge and research experience in an applied setting. Repeatable one time. IS majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Sustainability & Resilience Seminar
description: Weekly seminar covering research, processes, and initiatives related to sustainability and resilience in practice. The intent is to foster intellectual engagement and to help and encourage students to spawn their own original research ideas. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.

title: Literacy Across the Disciplines
description: Explores theoretical and practical principles of literacy and sustainability across academic disciplines, investigating the role of language and literate practices of reading, writing, speaking, visualizing, and representing in social, cultural, and educational contexts. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Seminar on Water in History
description: Explores how various forms of salt, fresh, and brackish water have played transformative roles in the evolution of human communities throughout history. (

title: Resource and Environmental Policy Analysis
description: Exploration of institutional and policy dimensions of natural resource development, management, allocation, markets and pricing, focusing on their environmental impacts. Emphasis on policy analysis using case studies and empirical findings. Original paper required. A-F only. grade of Cor above in ECON 130 or NREM/SUST 220, or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: grade of Cor above in ECON 130 or NREM/SUST 220, or consent

title: Predicting and Controlling Degradation in Human-Dominated Terrestrial Ecosystems
description: Historic, present, and projected trends in understanding and managing human-dominated ecosystems; predicting, measuring and mitigating degradation especially in terrestrial ecosystems with a focus on small volcanic islands in tropical settings. A-F only. NREM 301/ SUST 311 and NREM 304 (or equivalent) and NREM 600. Recommended NREM 461, or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: NREM 301/ SUST 311 and NREM 304 (or equivalent) and NREM 600

title: Advanced Methods in Wildlife Management & Conservation
description: Introduces advanced techniques for wildlife management and conservation. In addition to hands-on training, students will learn underlying biological and ecological principles, as well as quantitative skills, with an emphasis on sustainable management. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Environmental Planning and Policy
description: Overview of urbanization and environmental change. An examination of environmental laws, policies, planning and urban design strategies designed to minimize and mitigate urban impacts. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (

title: Coastal Flood Mitigation
description: Design and solutions to coastal flood mitigation problems. Topics include climate adaptation; engineering solutions and best practices to mitigate coastal risk under different ocean hazard scenarios; and ecological approaches to mitigate coastal risk. consent; knowledge of AutoCAD and ORE 661 desirable. (
prerequisites: consent; knowledge of AutoCAD and ORE 661 desirable

title: Science and Science Curriculum, PK-12
description: Application of recent developments in science, sustainability, curriculum development, and learning theory to -kindergarten through secondary school. Science philosophy, content and methodology stressed, including inquiry, nature of science, sustainability, and science literacy. Repeatable one time. (

title: Coastal Modeling
description: Coastal modeling using the SMS Surface-Water Modeling software. Applications to solving coastal problems for different ocean hazard scenarios by applying models for tides, waves, coastal circulation, wave-current interaction, sediment transport, and/or morphology change. consent; knowledge of ORE 607 desirable. (

title: Climate Change, Energy and Food Security in the Asia/Pacific Region
description: Analysis of planning responses to human-induced climate change and related environmental problems. Part of the Asia/Pacific Initiative taught in collaboration with universities throughout the region via videoconferencing. (

title: Coastal Geology
description: Geological history and geologic framework of the Hawaiian shoreline. Modern climate change, paleoclimate, focus on sea level change. Modern coastal management and problems in the coastal environment. Coastal planning. Repeatable one time, credit earned one time. (Spring only) (

title: Urban Environmental Problems
description: Seminar that examines environmental problems associated with urbanization. Reviews strategic approaches and collaboration among key actors to address such problems. (

title: Planning in Hawai‘i and Pacific Islands
description: Urban and regional planning in island settings. Experiences in Hawai‘i, Polynesia, Melanesia, and Micronesia. Graduate students only. (

title: Renewable Energy Economics and Policy
description: Analysis of economic and policy aspects of renewable energy use, and interactions of markets for renewable energy and other energy options. Evaluations of policies to develop renewable energy options. college calculus and principles of microeconomics; or consent. (
prerequisites: college calculus and principles of microeconomics; or consent

title: Resource Economics
description: Analysis of problems of development and management of natural resources with emphasis on resources in agriculture and role in economic development. ECON 608 and 629. (

title: Environmental Resource Economics
description: Principles of policy design and evaluation for environmental resources management, forestry and watershed conservation, and sustainable economic development. ECON 604 or 606; or consent. (

title: Land Systems Science
description: Through discussion of primary land systems science literature and use of environmental modeling software, this interdisciplinary course explores how drivers, states, and trends in human appropriation of land affect socio-ecological system function. NREM 477 or NREM 677 or GEO 470 or GEO 476 or ERTH 460 or ERTH 461. (Alt. years: Fall) (
prerequisites: NREM 477 or NREM 677 or GEO 470 or GEO 476 or ERTH 460 or ERTH 461

title: (Alpha) Seminar
description: Study in trends, research, and problems of implementation in teaching field. (P) place-based education. Each alpha repeatable two times. COE-related majors only. graduate and/or undergraduate courses in education and/ or social sciences or consent. (
prerequisites: graduate and/or undergraduate courses in education and/ or social sciences or consent

title: Urban and Regional Planning for Sustainability
description: Focus on ideology, conceptual models, accounting frameworks, appropriate technologies, and indicators of planning for sustainability. Central and local policies, plans, and best practices in various countries and settings will be covered. Graduate students only. A-F only. (

title: Kānāwai Lawai‘a: Hawa‘i’s Ocean and Fisheries Laws
description: Seminar on -contact, customary laws on fishing and ocean stewardship, their codification in written laws during the Hawaiian Kingdom period, and changes and impacts through U.S. annexation and statehood, including current models of ocean governance. (Alt. years: Fall) (
prerequisites: -contact, customary laws on fishing and ocean stewardship, their codification in written laws during the Hawaiian Kingdom period, and changes and impacts through U

title: Advanced Environmental Benefit Cost Analysis
description: Advanced environmental benefit-cost analysis will require that proficiency be demonstrated on fundamentals and address topics related to sustainability, including income equality, non-market goods, risk, cost of public funds, and the social discount rate. (

title: He Ali‘i Ka ‘Āina; Land, Resources, and Leadership
description: Seminar focused on leadership challenges in Mālama ‘Āina to bridge ancestral and contemporary systems to better steward resources, produce abundance, work with and in community, and pivot large institutions for a better Aloha ‘Āina future. (

title: Hawaiian Vascular Plants
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Identification, systematics, evolution, and biogeography of native plants. Field trips. 461 or consent. (

title: Sociology of Sustainability
description: Analyses of sustainability, environmental, and technoscience issues from sociological perspectives. Graduate students only. (Fall only) (

title: Marine Renewable Energy
description: Ocean thermal energy conversion (OTEC) systems: applicability, thermodynamics, design challenges; wave energy converters: floating devices, oscillating water column, optimal hydrodynamic performance; current, tidal, and offshore wind power. ORE 607; basic knowledge of thermodynamics desirable. (
prerequisites: ORE 607; basic knowledge of thermodynamics desirable

title: Applied Theories of Landscape Architecture
description: Graduate seminar on discussion of central ideas and theories in landscape architecture and environmental design, drawing on primary literature and speculative or built design work over many decades of thought. Graduate students only. A-F only. (

title: Sustainability & Resilience Seminar
description: Weekly seminar covering research, processes, and initiatives related to sustainability and resilience in practice. The intent is to foster intellectual engagement and to help and encourage students to spawn their own original research ideas. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.

title: Mānoa International Exchange
description: Designed for students accepted for participation in an international exchange program while enrolled at UH Mānoa. Repeatable unlimited times, credit for 12 credits only. CR/NC only. admittance to an international exchange program.
prerequisites: admittance to an international exchange program

title: Marine Option Program Seminar
description: Overview of ocean issues and organizations involved with marine activities, management, education, research, and business. Exploration of internships, research, and career opportunities. Preparation of resumes, proposals, and professional presentations. Not a BIOL major elective. (

title: Introduction to Applied Gerontology: Helping Yourself and Others to Thrive in Later Life
description: Introduction to essential information on aging and the field of gerontology. Counters ageist stereotypes, develops skills for translating research into practice, and provides an introductory survey course for the undergraduate certificate in aging. A-F only.

title: Personal Development for Effective Teams
description: Exploration and application of basic leadership theories and processes which foster personal and interpersonal development via cognitive experiential classroom methods and mentoring relationships with experienced peer leaders. (

title: Introduction to Environmental Humanities
description: Introduction to the environmental humanities, which rests at the intersection of the arts, humanities, and environmental studies. (

title: (Alpha) Sophomore Seminar
description: Special inquiry-based study of multi-disciplinary topics in particular historical, cultural, geographical, environmental, or other contexts. Emphasis on primary sources and/or fieldwork and extensive instruction in writing. (B) biological science; (H) humanities; (P) physical science; (R) arts; (S) social science; (T) literature. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (; DH for (H); DP for (P); DA for (R); DS for (S); DL for (T)

title: Field Study
description: -arranged systematic field investigation of selected topics. written proposal approved by Honors director and appropriate faculty member. Repeatable up to 16 credits.
prerequisites: -arranged systematic field investigation of selected topics

title: Ethics, Aging & Society
description: Addresses ethical issues in gerontology and long-term care for older adults as raised by public policy, health care problems, and social attitudes toward elders. Explores established practices and new directions for ethics in aging. A-F only. (

title: Independent Study Tutorial
description: Independent study tutorial. A-F only.

title: Native Americans and Native Hawaiians
description: Comparative-contrastive examination of similarities and differences between Native Americans and Native Hawaiians as the only indigenous peoples of the U.S. with special attention to sociohistorical parallels and mutual contacts since contact with Europeans. Perspective is explicitly interdisciplinary by drawing not only on sociology and history, but also on archaeology, ethnology, linguistics and still other disciplines. A-F only. HIST 152 and an introductory course in cultural anthropology, political science or sociology; or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: HIST 152 and an introductory course in cultural anthropology, political science or sociology; or consent

title: Ethnohistory
description: Review of ethnohistory, i.e. the interdisciplinary, holistic and inclusive investigation of the histories of native peoples drawing not only on documented sources, but also on ethnography, linguistics, archaeology, ecology and other disciplines as an alternative to conventional Eurocolonial history. A-F only. HIST 152, or consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Information Technology and Culture
description: Investigation of the impact of information technologies on contemporary culture from a variety of perspectives. A-F only. upper division or consent.

title: Science and Culture
description: Cultural studies of science from historical, philosophical, sociological and literary perspectives. Examination of intersections of science, race, gender and environment. A-F only. upper division or consent.

title: Human Values and the Environment
description: Examination of nature-culture dynamic over a range of contexts–literary ecology, systems ecology, political ecology, eco-feminism, environmental ethics–in order to articulate new possibilities for interdisciplinary understanding of the human place in nature. A-F only. any ENG DL or PHIL or GEO course, or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: any ENG DL or PHIL or GEO course, or consent

title: Pidgin and Creole Languages
description: Nature, history, structure, and geographic distribution of pidgins and creoles. LING 102 or consent. (Alt. years) (

title: One Health: Preparing for the Next Pandemic
description: Focuses on the COVID-19 pandemic as a case study of a global health problem that is optimally approached from a One Health perspective. A-F only. ANSC 200, BIOL 101, MICR 130, PH 201, or consent of instructor. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: ANSC 200, BIOL 101, MICR 130, PH 201, or consent of instructor

title: People, the Ocean and the Environment
description: People’s impact on quality of coastal and ocean environments, especially Hawaiian; scientific, legal, socioeconomic aspects. Ocean pollution, ocean technology. OCN 201, ORE 202, or ZOOL 200; or consent.
prerequisites: OCN 201, ORE 202, or ZOOL 200; or consent

title: British Life and Culture
description: For Study Abroad Program students participating in the UH Mānoa Semester in London. Emphasis is placed on understanding within historical contexts important issues for contemporary British society—particularly those of class, power, gender, and race. A-F only. participation in London Semester Program.

title: One Health Journal Club
description: Students gain critical reading skills in the presentation and discussion of published literature on One Health-related topics. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. PH 441. (Fall only) (

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Directed reading and research. Repeatable two times.

title: Ocean Internships and Research
description: Students carry out marine-related internships, practica, research projects or field experience on-or off-campus with faculty guidance. Repeatable one time. A-F only. minimum cum GPA of 2.5, junior or senior standing in any field of study and IS 100/BIOL 104 or consent, project proposal. (

title: The Humboldt Brothers’ Legacy
description: Life and thought of the two Humboldt brothers. Alexander (1769-1859) helped to lay the foundations of modern science, including geology, geography, botany, zoology, physiology and anthropology. Older, less well-known Wilhelm (1767–1835) was an influential statesman, classical scholar, man of letters, humanist, political philosopher, anthropologist and linguist, and founded the University of Berlin. Review of the two polymaths’ impact on modern science in the Americas, the Pacific and Asia. A-F only. upper-division or consent.

title: Introduction to Linguistic Anthropology
description: Introduction to the ethnographic study of speech and language. ANTH 152. (Once a year) (

title: One Health Practicum
description: Provide certificate students with real-world experience and opportunity to integrate and apply classroom learning in a professional environment. Intended for students who prefer to pursue a supervised, practical experience rather than a research-based project. A-F only. PH 441. (

title: Environmental Practicum
description: Field experience in study and abatement of environmental problems under faculty direction. Project proposal, narrative activity log, and documentary report are required. upper division standing, courses in appropriate discipline, and consent.
prerequisites: upper division standing, courses in appropriate discipline, and consent

title: One Health Seminar
