description: Weekly presentations and discussions on current events and research in the field of One Health. Presentation topics may include research progress, literature reviews, or research proposals. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. PH 441. (Spring only) (

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Directed reading and research. Repeatable one time.

title: Field Study in Gerontology
description: Individually designed field experience for advanced certificate in gerontology students. Placements arranged at community programs, research sites, and special projects at the Center on Aging. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Integrative Seminar in Gerontology
description: Integrative seminar. A-F only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Principles of Applied Evolutionary Ecology: Biodiversity Loss, Biological Invasions and Emerging Disease
description: Combined lecture-discussion on the ecological and evolutionary underpinnings of the coupled process of biological invasion, disease emergence and biodiversity loss. A-F only. consent. (Once a year)

title: Laboratory A in Applied Evolutionary Ecology: Biodiversity Loss, Biological Invasions and Emerging Disease
description: Combined lecture-laboratory on the ecological and evolutionary underpinnings of the coupled process of biological invasion, disease emergence and biodiversity loss. A-F only. consent. (Once a year)

title: Laboratory B in Applied Evolutionary Ecology: Biodiversity Loss, Biological Invasions and Emerging Disease
description: Practical laboratory/ field rotation on the ecological and evolutionary underpinnings of the coupled process of biological invasion, disease emergence and biodiversity loss. Continuation of 650 and 651L. A-F only. 650 and 651L, or consent. (Once a year)

title: Topics in Biocultural Diversity and Conservation
description: Biological, cultural, and linguistic conservation are intimately linked, but rarely studied simultaneously. Adopts a trans-disciplinary view of diversity and conservation of nature, cultures, and languages, along with issues in anthropology, law, and ethics. (Fall only)

title: Faculty Seminar Series
description: Seminar consists of a series of presentations by certificate faculty on topics of ongoing research. Presentations will open current debates about theory and method in cultural studies. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: International Cultural Studies: History and Theory
description: Seminar on the history and theory of interdisciplinary cultural studies. The politics of culture are examined in comparative perspective, focusing on their significance for identity formation, intercultural relations, and global flows of images, people and capital. Approaches to the study of media and popular culture are taken up in terms of their relevance for contemporary issues, especially in Hawai‘i and the Asia/Pacific/U.S. region. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: International Cultural Studies: Research Project
description: Directed reading and research culminating in a project that engages issues in international cultural studies. Types of projects include scholarly essays, community-based projects, performances or exhibitions. Written statement of purpose and selfevaluation required. A-F only. 609 and 610.

title: Elementary Italian
description: Conversation, grammar, and reading.

title: Elementary Italian
description: Conversation, grammar, and reading. 101 or consent.

title: Immersion Italian-Elementary
description: Combined content of 101 and 102 covered in one summer session. (Summer only)

title: Intensive Elementary Italian Abroad
description: Intensive course of formal instruction on the first-year level in Italian language and culture in Italy.

title: Intermediate Italian
description: Reading, conversation, composition. 102 or 110.

title: Intermediate Italian
description: Continuation of 201. 201.

title: Intermediate Italian Abroad
description: Intensive course of full-time formal instruction in Italy on the second-year level in Italian language and culture. 102 or 110 or 160.

title: Intermediate Italian Abroad
description: Continuation of 258.

title: Conversation
description: Systematic practice for control of spoken Italian. Further development of vocabulary for accurate, mature expression. 202 or consent.

title: Third-Level Italian Abroad
description: Intensive formal instruction at the third-year level in Italian language skills: reading, writing, grammar, or conversation in an Italian-speaking country. 202 or 259 or equivalent.

title: Third-Level Italian Abroad
description: Continuation of 358.

title: Intensive Third-Level Italian Abroad
description: Intensive formal instruction at the third-year level in Italian language skills: reading, writing, grammar, or conversation in an Italian-speaking country. 202 or equivalent.

title: Fourth-Level Italian Abroad
description: Intensive course of full-time formal instruction in Italy on the fourth-year level in Italian language, linguistics, culture, and literature. 359 or 360 or equivalent.

title: Fourth-Level Italian Abroad
description: Continuation of 458.

title: Intensive Fourth-Level Italian Abroad
description: Intensive course of formal instruction on the fourth-year level in Italian language and culture in Italy. For semester programs only. 360 or equivalent.

title: Evidence-Based Medicine
description: Critical appraisal track designed to improve the student’s ability to seek and evaluate new medical knowledge. MD majors only. CR/NC only. (Spring only)

title: Unit 8 Block Selective
description: Through lectures, self-assessments and independent study, second-year medical students will consolidate their knowledge of the application of the biological sciences to patient care. CR/NC only. 557.

title: Clinical Skills Assessment
description: Required comprehensive interdepartment multidisciplinary assessment program for fourth-year medical students. CR/NC only. FMCH, MED, OBGN, PED, PSTY, SURG 531 or 532.
prerequisites: FMCH, MED, OBGN, PED, PSTY, SURG 531 or SURG 532

title: (Alpha) Senior Interdisciplinary Electives
description: Fourth-year elective in which students study selected interdisciplinary topics. CR/NC only. (B) medical education elective; (C) complementary and alternative medicine; (D) leadership in underserved care; (E) Junior PBL course director. MED majors only for (D). CR/NC only for (D) and (E). FMCH, MED, OBGN, PED, PSTY, SURG 531 or 532. (Spring only for (D) and (E))
prerequisites: FMCH, MED, OBGN, PED, PSTY, SURG 531 or SURG 532

title: MD 1 Health and Illness
description: Introduction to concepts of health and disease through lectures, laboratories, and colloquia intended to broaden the learning from MD 1 health care problems in tutorials. MD majors only. CR/NC only. consent. Co-requisite: 551L. (Fall only)

title: MD 1 Health and Illness Tutorials
description: Introductory series of problem-based learning tutorials for first-year medical students focusing on concepts of health and disease through MD 1 health care problems. MD majors only. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 551. (Fall only)

title: MD 2 CV/Pulmonary
description: Concepts focusing on cardiovascular and pulmonary systems through integrated basic science lectures, laboratories, and colloquia intended to broaden the learning from MD 2 health care problems in tutorials. CR/NC only. 551 and 551L. Co-requisite: 552L. (Fall only)

title: MD 2 CV/Pulmonary Tutorials
description: Advanced series of problem-based learning tutorials for first-year medical students focusing on cardiovascular and pulmonary health care problems. CR/NC only. 551 and 551L. Co-requisite: 552. (Fall only)

title: MD 3 Renal/Hematology
description: Concepts focusing on renal and hematologic systems through integrated basic science lectures, laboratories, and colloquia intended to broaden the learning from MD 3 health care problems in tutorials. CR/NC only. 552 and 552L. Co-requisites: 553L. (Spring only)

title: MD 3 Renal/Hematology Tutorials
description: Advanced series of problem-based learning tutorials for first-year medical students focusing on renal and hematology health care problems. CR/NC only. 552 and 552L. Co-requisite: 553. (Spring only)

title: MD 4 GI/Endocrine
description: Concepts focusing on gastrointestinal and endocrine systems through integrated basic science lectures, laboratories, and colloquia intended to broaden the learning from MD 4 health care problems in tutorials. CR/NC only. 553 and 553L. Co-requisite: 554L. (Spring only)

title: MD 4 GI/Endocrine Tutorials
description: Advanced series of problem-based learning tutorials for first-year medical students focusing on gastrointestinal and endocrine health care problems. CR/NC only. 553 and 553L. Co-requisite: 554. (Spring only)

title: MD 6 Locomotor System, Nervous System and Behavioral Problems
description: Concepts focusing on the locomotor/neurological systems and behavioral problems through integrated basic science lectures, laboratories, and colloquia intended to broaden the learning from MD 6 health care problems in tutorials. CR/NC only. 554 and 554L. Co-requisite: 556L. (Fall only)

title: MD 6 Locomotor System, Nervous System, and Behavioral Problems
description: Advanced series of problem-based learning tutorials for second-year medical students focusing on neurological/ locomotor systems and behavioral health care problems. CR/NC only. 554 and 554L. Co-requisite: 556. (Fall only)

title: MD 7 The Life Cycle
description: Concepts focusing on the life cycle through integrated basic science lectures, laboratories, and colloquia intended to broaden the learning from MD 7 health care problems in tutorials. CR/NC only. 556 and 556L. Co-requisite: 557L. (Spring only)

title: MD 7 The Life Cycle Tutorials
description: Advanced series of problem-based learning tutorials for second-year medical students focusing on the life cycle health care problems. CR/NC only. 556 and 556L. Co-requisite: 557. (Spring only)

title: Third Year Colloquia
description: A series of lecture-discussions intended to broaden the perspectives of the Unit VI experiences and healthcare problems. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. 551 and 557.

title: (Alpha) Senior Seminars
description: Review of topics and issues that will prepare senior students for the end of their undergraduate training and the start of their internship. (B) Week 1; (C) Week 2; (D) Week 3. CR/ NC only. (Fall only for B); (Spring only for C and D)

title: Introduction to Clinical Skills
description: Introductory lectures and laboratories on history taking and physical exam skills. Repeatable one time. MD majors only. CR/NC only. consent. Co-requisite: 551. (Fall only)

title: Unit 2 Clinical Skills
description: History and physical exam skills pertinent to the health care problems in Unit 2. MD majors only. CR/NC only. 571 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Unit 3 Clinical Skills
description: History and physical exam skills pertinent to the health care problems in Unit 3. MD majors only. CR/NC only. 572 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Unit 4 Clinical Skills
description: History and physical exam skills pertinent to the health care problems in Unit 4. MD majors only. CR/NC only. 573 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Unit 6 Clinical Skills
description: History and physical exam skills pertinent to the health care problems in Unit 6. MD majors only. CR/NC only. 574 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Unit 7 Clinical Skills
description: History and physical exam skills pertinent to the health care problems in Unit 7. MD majors only. CR/NC only. 576 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Unit 1 Community Health
description: Field experience placing students in community settings to work with health care professionals as they provide services to patients. Repeatable two times. MD majors only. CR/NC only. consent. Co-requisites: 551 and 571. (Fall only)

title: Unit 2 Community Health
description: Field experience placing students in community settings to work with health care professionals as they provide services to patients. Repeatable two times. MD majors only. CR/NC only. 581 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Unit 3 Community Health
description: Field experience placing student in community settings to work with health care professionals as they provide services to patients. MD majors only. CR/NC only. 582 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Unit 4 Community Health
description: Field experience placing student in community settings to work with health care professionals as they provide services to patients. MD majors only. CR/NC only. 583 or consent. (Spring only)

title: (Alpha) Preclinical Electives
description: Elective for first and second year medical students. (B) projects in medical education; (C) healer’s art; (D) introduction to student research; (E) health and wellness; (F) quality improvement; (G) introduction to ultrasound. Repeatable one time, up to two credits. MD majors only for (G). CR/NC only. 551.

title: (Alpha) Topics in Medical Education
description: Summer selectives in medical education for second-year medical students. (B) rural health preceptorship; (C) health issues of the Pacific Basin; (D) projects in medical education; (E) manikin simulations; (F) learning resources; (G) cardiovascular case maps; (H) pulmonary case maps; (I) clinical skills preceptors; (J) global health perspectives. Repeatable up to four credits. MD majors only. CR/NC only. 554. (Fall only)

title: Research in Medical Education
description: An elective for medical students to work on research projects related to improving medical education, student wellness, and community health under the direction of a faculty member in the Office of Medical Education. Repeatable nine times, up to six credits.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Internal Medicine Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Six-month long clerkship in ambulatory setting, and four-week hospital-based experience. Repeatable one time. third-year standing and concurrent registration in 532 courses.
prerequisites: third-year standing and concurrent registration in MED 532 courses

title: Advanced Medicine Clerkship
description: Required 4 weeks duration for fourth-year medical students. Advanced experiences in ambulatory and hospital-based medical care. Proficiency in this course may be established by examination. CR/NC only. fourth-year standing and completion of 531, or consent.
prerequisites: fourth-year standing and completion of MED 531, or consent

title: (Alpha) Electives in Medicine
description: Fourth-year electives in which students study selected topics within field of medicine. (B) allergy/immunology; (C) cardiology; (D) medicine elective in Asia; (E) dermatology; (F) endocrinology; (G) gastroenterology; (H) general internal medicine: ambulatory care; (I) general internal medicine: inpatient; (K) hematology; (M) nephrology; (N) neurology; (O) nuclear medicine; (P) oncology; (Q) pulmonary diseases; (R) research in medicine; (S) rehabilitation medicine; (T) rheumatology; (U) heart failure/electrophysiology; (W) internal medicine sub-internship. MD students only for (U). CR/NC only. 531 or 532 for (C), (E), (F), (G), (H), (K), (M), (N), (O), (Q), (R), (S), and (T); 532 for (U); 541 for (D) and (W).
prerequisites: MED 531 or MED 532 for (C), (E), (F), (G), (H), (K), (M), (N), (O), (Q), (R), (S), and (T); MED 532 for (U); MED 541 for (D) and (W)

title: (Alpha) Electives in Medicine
description: Fourthyear electives in which students study selected topics within field of medicine. (B) extramural electives in medicine (miscellaneous); (C) internal medicine seminar; (D) infectious disease; (E) internal medicine sub-internship; (F) research in bioethics; (G) neurology critical care; (H) medical informatics; (O) obesity medicine. Repeatable one time for (C)–(E); not repeatable for (F); repeatable two times for (B), (C) and (H); repeatable three times for (G). CR/NC only. 531 or 532 for (B), (C), and (O); 541 for (E) and (H).
prerequisites: MED 531 or MED 532 for (B), (C), and (O); MED 541 for (E) and (H)

title: Directed Research
description: consent.

title: Introduction to Medical Technology
description: Designed to acquaint students to the field of medical technology (clinical laboratory science). Repeatable one time.

title: Introduction to Medical Technology II
description: Basic principles and lab skills in medical technology (medical lab science). Required for second bachelor’s degree students (not MLT credentialed) wishing to major in medical technology. Second bachelor’s degree students only. A-F only. 151, CHEM 161/CHEM 161L, BIOL 171/BIOL 171L (or concurrent)

title: The Clinical Laboratory
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Theory and clinical application of medical laboratory methods and healthcare professional relationships. MEDT majors only. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: The Clinical Laboratory II
description: Theory and clinical application of medical technology methods and healthcare professional relationships. Companion course to MEDT 301; and required, for second bachelor’s degree students who were admitted to MEDT major. MEDT majors only. Second Bachelor’s degree standing or higher. A-F only. 251 or consent.

title: Clinical Lab Management
description: Student will become familiar with fundamental administration of a clinical laboratory to include technical, personnel, and financial management areas. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Clinical Parasitology
description: (1 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Modern diagnostic practices in parasitology. Repeatable one time. MICR 351 or consent.

title: Hematology
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Fundamental study of blood in normal and pathological states: formation, development, and classification of blood cells. MEDT majors only. consent.

title: Hematology Lab
description: Laboratory to accompany MEDT 451. Emphasis on writing to study content. MEDT majors only. consent. Co-requisite: 451.

title: Immunohematology
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Antigen-antibody relationships in human blood, study of blood groups, clinical problems in transfusion. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. MICR 461 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Clinical Biochemistry I
description: Biochemical processes in human health and disease states. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. CHEM 273 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Clinical Biochemistry II
description: Continuation of 471. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. 471 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Clinical Lab Methods and Analyses I
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Lab experiments illustrating fundamental principles and methods of clinical laboratory analyses. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. A-F only. 471.

title: Clinical Lab Methods and Analyses II
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Continuation of 477. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. A-F only. 477.

title: Professional Issues in Medical Lab Science
description: Discussions about various professional issues through oral presentations and critiquing of peer presentations. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. CR/NC only. 451L.

title: Special Topics in Medical Technology
description: Acquaints student with role of the medical technologist and overlap of major sciences in clinical situations to help student develop qualities unique to med technology. Repeatable one time. MEDT majors only. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Repeatable one time.

title: Clinical Microbiology Preceptorship
description: Clinical training for students with bachelor’s degree in microbiology to be able to qualify as clinical microbiologists in a healthcare setting. Includes specimen procurement, processing, detection and identification, susceptibility testing, and other diagnostic technology. CR/NC only. departmental consent.

title: Clinical Training in Medical Technology
description: Application of theory and simulated laboratory experiences in immuno-hematology, clinical chemistry, microbiology, parasitology, hematology, coagulation, urinalysis, immunology, to meet stated career entry-level competencies. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. BS in MEDT.

title: Seminar in Medical Technology
description: Analysis of research and recent literature pertaining to various aspects of medical technology. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Applied Health Disparities Research
description: Instruction on social determinants of health, issues of health equity, and how these issues can be addressed through research. Discussions and activities promote a greater understanding of health disparities research. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Individual reading and/or research. Repeatable unlimited times. Junior standing or higher. consent.

title: Humanities in Medicine I
description: Introduction to medical science stressing key historical figures and significant events to exemplify the development of scientific methods. Special emphasis on writing skills, health team concept, and culture and contributions of the Pacific. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. admission to Imi Ho‘ola PostBaccalaureate Program.
prerequisites: admission to Imi Ho‘ola PostBaccalaureate Program

title: Humanities in Medicine II
description: Continuation of 501. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. 501.

title: Medical Biology I
description: (2 Lec, 2 Tutorial, 1 3-hr Lab) Foundation in medical sciences, including anatomy, physiology, microbiology, pathology, and pharmacology (focus on respiratory, cardiovascular, and urinary systems); develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills. Includes lectures, problembased tutorials, and histology and gross anatomy labs. CR/NC only. admission to Imi Ho‘ola PostBaccalaureate Program.
prerequisites: admission to Imi Ho‘ola PostBaccalaureate Program

title: Medical Biology II
description: (2 Lec, 2 Tutorial, 1 3-hr Lab) Continuation of 503. CR/NC only. 503.

title: Medical Biochemistry I
description: Provide background knowledge of chemistry, biochemistry, and molecular biology with emphasis in principles of biochemical processes as well as clinical correlations to medical conditions; develop critical thinking, standardized test taking skills, and problem-solving skills. CR/NC only. admission to Imi Ho‘ola Post-Baccalaureate Program.
prerequisites: admission to Imi Ho‘ola Post-Baccalaureate Program

title: Medical Biochemistry II
description: Continuation of 505. CR/NC only. 505.

title: Native Hawaiian Health and Traditional Healing
description: Introduction to Native Hawaiian health issues and traditional healing practices. MD majors only. CR/NC only. MDED 551 or consent.

title: Native Hawaiian Health Care
description: Clinical experience in the Native Hawaiian Health Care System and community health care centers, incorporating both western and traditional Hawaiian medicine. Open to fourth year medical students interested in Native Hawaiian Health Care. CR/NC only. clinical clerkships.

title: Seminar in Issues of Social Justice in Health
description: Social justice provides an analytical and prescriptive framework to understand health inequities; understand connections between social forces and health outcomes, and the role of the individual student in improving social justice in the health system. Graduate standing only. CR/NC only. MDED 551. (Spring only)

title: Clinical Skills Preceptorship in the Lau Ola Clinic of the Department of Native Hawaiian Health
description: Provides a focused experience in clinical medicine with opportunities to practice the history and physical examination in Lau Ola, the clinical setting of the Department of Native Hawaiian Health. Repeatable one time. MD majors only. CR/NC only. MDED 574 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Directed Reading/Research in Native Hawaiian Health
description: Instruction of medical students in the social determinants of health, issues of health equity, specifically in Native Hawaiians, Pacific Islanders and/or disadvantaged people and teach them how these issues can be addressed through research. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.

title: Advanced Applied Health Disparities Research
description: Instruction on social determinants of health, issues of health equity, and how these issues can be addressed through research. Discussions and activities promote a greater understanding of health disparities research. Repeatable two times, or up to 27 credits. consent.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Individual reading and/or research. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate standing only. consent.

title: Obstetrics and Gynecology Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Year-long clerkship in outpatient setting, covering assessment, diagnosis, treatment, and/or management of common gynecologic problems and normal and complicated pregnancies. Emphasis on prevention and health maintenance. Repeatable two times. third-year standing, and concurrent registration in 532 courses. Co-requisite: FMCH, MED, PED, PSTY, and SURG 632.
prerequisites: third-year standing, and concurrent registration in OBGN 532 courses

title: (Alpha) Electives in OB/GYN
description: Opportunities for advanced study of selected topics. (B) labor and delivery; (C) outpatient clinic at Queen’s; (D) Sub-internship in family planning; (E) high-risk OB; (F) endocrinology; (G) oncology; (H) topics with individual preceptor; (I) extramural electives; (J) urogynecology and pelvic reconstructive surgery. Repeatable twice for each alpha. CR/NC only. 531 or 532.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: consent.

title: Immunopathology Seminar
description: Autoimmune diseases and transplantation immunity. consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Pathology of aging, nutrition, alcoholism, and immunology. Open to selected undergraduate students. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Unit II Concurrent Elective
description: Elective course for first-year medical students. CR/NC only. BIOM 551 and consent.

title: Unit V Concurrent Elective
description: Elective course for second-year medical students. CR/NC only. BIOM 551 and consent.

title: Unit V Block Elective
description: Required elective for second-year medical students, objectives to be determined by contract. One option is a review of USMLE Part I. CR/NC only. BIOM 551.

title: Pathology Practicum
description: Required autopsy experience involving dissection and microscopic examination of tissues and detailed evaluation of disease process. CR/NC only. third-or fourth-year standing.

title: (Alpha) Unit VII Electives in Pathology
description: Individualized instruction in laboratory medicine for the practicing physician, clinical and anatomic pathology: (B) advanced topics in clinical immunology; (C) anatomic pathology; (D) clinical pathology; (E) pathologic aspects of aging, nutrition, and/or alcoholism; (F) extramural elective in pathology. Repeatable four times. CR/NC only. BIOM 555.

title: Introduction to Pathology and Laboratory Medicine
description: Provides an introduction to the practice of pathology and laboratory medicine and the role pathologists and the laboratory play in the diagnosis and management of disease. MD students only. CR/NC only. MDED 554 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Electives in Pathology
description: Individualized instruction in clinical and/or anatomic pathology. Third-year elective. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Pediatric Seminars
description: Interactive weekly lecture/seminar designed to teach topics in pediatrics and supplemented by small group 2-hour encounters with faculty clinicians in pediatric emergency medicine, inpatient pediatric, and enonatology to gain exposure in pediatric hospital care. Repeatable one time. Medical students only. CR/NC only. MDED 551.

title: Pediatric Shadowing Encounters
description: Clinical Shadowing – Students are paired with Pediatric Subspecialists in chosen area(s) for 8-10 half days. Required: Log book file describing one concept that the student learned during each of the sessions. CR/ NC only. Field experience.

title: Introduction to Research Methodology, Biostatistics, and Epidemiology
description: Interactive seminar series to cover the following topics: data types, descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, selecting a statistical test, data distributions, measures of data spread, statistical test assumptions, standard deviation vs. standard error, etc. Repeatable one time. Medical students only. CR/NC only. MDED 551.

title: Pediatrics Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Year-long clerkship in ambulatory setting, covering evaluation, diagnosis, and treatment of childhood diseases. Emphasis on primary prevention, normal growth and development of the neonate to adolescent, and arrangement of pediatric care, including outpatient, inpatient, and emergency room experiences. Repeatable two times. third-year standing and concurrent registration in 532 courses. Co-requisite: MED, OBGN, PED, PSTY, and SURG 532.
prerequisites: third-year standing and concurrent registration in PED 532 courses

title: (Alpha) Electives in Pediatrics
description: Fourth-year elective in pediatric sub-specialty areas in which medical students may receive clinical experiences and an in-depth study of selected sub-specialty areas within the field of pediatrics. (B) adolescent medicine; (C) ambulatory pediatric care; (E) clinical genetics; (F) Sub-Internship in neonatology; (G) pediatric cardiology; (H) Sub-Internship in pediatric emergency medicine; (I) Sub-Internship in pediatric hematology/ oncology; (J) Sub-Internship in infectious diseases; (K) Sub-Internship in pediatrics–general ward in pediatrics; (M) extramural electives in pediatrics; (N) pediatric rheumatology; (P) developmental behavioral pediatrics; (Q) pediatric international preceptorship (3 cr.); (R) Sub-Internship in pediatric critical care;. (S) pediatric radiology; (T) pediatric ultrasound; (U) pediatric nephrology; (V) pediatric sports medicine. CR/NC only. Repeatable two times per alpha, up to 36 credits; not repeatable for (Q). 531 or 532.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Introduction to General Pharmacology
description: Drugs discussed with emphasis on sites and mechanism of action, toxicity, fate, and uses of major therapeutic agents. mammalian physiology and dental hygiene major.
prerequisites: mammalian physiology and dental hygiene major

title: General Pharmacology
description: Similar to 201 but wider in scope of drugs discussed. Intended for undergraduates in the health sciences and related fields. mammalian physiology.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Directed reading and research in experimental pharmacology. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Selected Topics in Pharmacology
description: Elective for medical students in Pharmacology. Repeatable up to 12 credits. CR/NC only. MDED 551.

title: Principles of Pharmacology
description: Pharmacology elective course for medical students. MD students only. CR/NC only. MDED 554 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Research in Pharmacology
description: Pharmacology research elective for medical students. MD majors only. CR/NC only. MDED 551 or consent.

title: General Pharmacology
description: Pharmacodynamics, receptor theory, modeling, clinical trials and the FDA will be covered. Concepts in ADME/T and clinical research are also considered. consent.

title: Systemic Pharmacology
description: Provides instruction at an organ systems/functional level covering major organ and functional systems of the human body. Concepts in pharmacological research at the animal, organ system and whole human level will also be considered. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Neuropharmacology
description: Physiology and pharmacology of central and peripheral nervous systems, focusing on synaptic chemistry and signaling. A-F only. CMB 606, or consent from the course director. (
prerequisites: CMB 606, or consent from the course director

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Individualized directed readings and/or research in mental health and psychiatry under the supervision of an instructor. Open to non-majors. Repeatable up to four times. A-F only. consent.

title: Psychiatry Longitudinal Clerkship
description: Year-long clerkship in ambulatory setting, including knowledge, skills, attitudes for assessment, diagnosis, and management of psychiatric problems in medical practice, inpatient, and emergency room settings. Emphasis on development and application of psychosocial cultural formulations in all areas of psychiatric and medical practice. Repeatable two times. MD majors only. third-year standing and concurrent registration in 532 courses. Co-requisites: FMCH, MED, OBGN, PEDS, SURG 532 and SURG 535.
prerequisites: third-year standing and concurrent registration in PSTY 532 courses

title: (Alpha) Electives in Psychiatry
description: Senior medical student elective providing advanced instruction on the theory and methods of mental health research as well as supervised participation in an assigned research project in the Department of Psychiatry. (B) adult inpatient PSTY; (C) child PSTY; (D) forensic PSTY; (E) journal editing; (F) community mental health; (G) PSTY aspects of OBGN, PED, MED, SURG; (H) sub-internship in adult PSTY; (I) substance abuse; (J) PSTY aspects of rehab medicine; (K) PSTY aspects of SURG; (M) PSTY consult liaison; (N) post-traumatic stress disorder; (O) extramural elective in PSTY; (Q) geriatric PSTY; (R) rural child PSTY; (S) public and rural PSTY; (T) mental health research. CR/NC only. 531 or 532, and fourth-year standing.
prerequisites: PSTY 531 or PSTY 532, and fourth-year standing

title: Philosophy & Human Suffering
description: To see how various philosophies and religions have tackled the question, “why is there suffering in the world?” Read short excerpts from “classic” texts and discuss in a welcoming atmosphere and draw own conclusions. Medical students only. CR/NC only. (Fall only)

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: consent.

title: Mathematic Preparation for Quantitative Health Sciences
description: Mathematics preparation for quantitative health sciences. Includes selective topics in linear algebra, advanced calculus and probability theory. A-F only.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Directed reading/research in quantitative health sciences. Students will work closely with a QHS faculty member or mentor who will guide them through quantitative methodologies and/or the process of conducting a research study. Repeatable three times or up to 12 credits. A-F only.

title: Biostatistics Concepts for Clinical Researchers
description: Provide biostatistical concepts to clinical researchers. Students will obtain the ability to demonstrate an understanding of key biostatistical concepts in clinical research; and interpret statistical findings most commonly reported in clinical and healthcare literature. Graduate students only.

title: Data Management and Visualization for Health Sciences
description: Data management and visualization is essential to all aspects of health sciences. Through hands-on experiences in R, will introduce data processing, manipulation, visualization and reproducibility, with an emphasis on clinical, medical, and health science problems. A-F only.

title: Quantitative Health and Clinical Research Seminar
description: Provides overview of research related to health in Hawai‘i and advances in quantitative health and clinical research. Topics include ethnic disparities in health, social and cultural factors, ethics, biostatistics and bioinformatics. Repeatable six times. CR/NC only. consent

title: Cultural Competence in Biomedical Research I
description: Introductory lecture-seminar on the conduct of multidisciplinary research from a culturally competent perspective. A-F only.

title: Secondary Data Analysis
description: Will allow students who are new to using secondary data to become comfortable with accessing the data, forming hypotheses, and designing study proposals. Will introduce examples with basic and advanced techniques. A-F only. 601 (or equivalent) with a minimum grade of B- .
prerequisites: QHS 601 (or equivalent) with a minimum grade of B-

title: Surgery Longitudinal Clerkship
description: A clinically based, year-long, introductory in general surgery and selected subspecialties. Outpatient-conducted one day per week for six months in a community-based, ambulatory care facility. Inpatient-conducted for four weeks in an acute-care hospital facility. Repeatable one time.

title: Emergency Medical Care
description: Clinical experiences in management of medical, surgical, and psychiatric problems requiring urgent care. 532 and fourth-year standing.

title: (Alpha) Electives in Surgery
description: Advanced clinical experience in: (B) urology; (C) ophthalmology; (D) otolaryngology; (E) plastic surgery; (F) neurosurgery; (G) orthopaedics; (H) anesthesia; (I) surgical intensive care; (J)Sub-I – general surgery; (K) Sub-I – pediatric surgery; (M) diagnostic radiology; (N) radiation oncology; (O) EM Sub-I; (P) extramural elec in surg; (Q) Sub-I – cardiovascular; (R) surgical research; (S) surgical anatomy; (T) preceptorship in Asia; (U) biomedical technology design; (X) transplant surgery; (Y) bedside ultrasounds; (Z) laparoscopic skills. Repeatable one time for all except (U), (X), (Y), and (Z); repeatable two times for (U) and (X). Medical students only for (U), (X), (Y), and (Z). CR/NC only. 532 for all except (M), (U), and (Y); and consent for (R) and (S); admission into JABSOM for (U) and (Y).
prerequisites: SURG 532 for all except (M), (U), and (Y); and consent for (R) and (S); admission into JABSOM for (U) and (Y)

title: One Health: Preparing for the Next Pandemic
description: Focuses on the COVID-19 pandemic as a case study of a global health problem that is optimally approached from a One Health perspective. A-F only. ANSC 200, BIOL 101, MICR 130, PH 201, or consent of instructor. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: ANSC 200, BIOL 101, MICR 130, PH 201, or consent of instructor

title: One Health Journal Club
description: Students gain critical reading skills in the presentation and discussion of published literature on One Health-related topics. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. PH 441. (Fall only) (

title: Principles of Medical Parasitology
description: Epidemiology, pathogenesis, immunobiology and diagnostic aspects of human parasitic infections; principles of host-pathogen interactions; public health aspects of parasitic infections. Repeatable one time. A-F only. MICR 351 with a grade of B or higher or equivalent. (Spring only)
prerequisites: MICR 351 with a grade of B or higher or equivalent

title: International Training in Biosciences Research
description: Combines weekly lectures by faculty for discussion of the 9 Steps of Research and completion of training courses for working with human subjects, including research ethics, laboratory safety, blood-borne pathogens, and principles of health disparity. MHIRT cohort only. A-F only. (Summer only)

title: Health Disparities
description: Overview of biosciences research related to health and health disparities in a global setting as well as in Hawai‘i. Workshop topics include health research, Native Hawaiian health, global health, and cultural competency. MHIRT cohort only. A-F only. (Summer only)

title: Summer Research Experience
description: Hands-on research experience at assigned international sites. Students learn research and analytical skills in the field and laboratory setting, and present data to peers and faculty upon completion of the training. MHIRT cohort only. A-F only. (Summer only)

title: Medical and Urban Entomology
description: (2 Lec, 1-3-hr hybrid Lab) Biology, ecology, health and economic impacts, and control of urban insect pests and medically important arthropods that act as vectors of diseases. (PEPS 363 or BIOL 265) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (
prerequisites: (PEPS 363 or BIOL 265) with a minimum grade of C, or consent

title: One Health Practicum
description: Provide certificate students with real-world experience and opportunity to integrate and apply classroom learning in a professional environment. Intended for students who prefer to pursue a supervised, practical experience rather than a research-based project. A-F only. PH 441. (

title: One Health Seminar
description: Weekly presentations and discussions on current events and research in the field of One Health. Presentation topics may include research progress, literature reviews, or research proposals. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. PH 441. (Spring only) (

title: Reading and Research
description: Directed reading and research in laboratory; diagnostic aspects of bacterial, parasitic, and viral infections. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Topics in Tropical Medicine
description: Elective for fourth-year medical students for advanced study of selected topics within the field of tropical medicine and medical microbiology. fourth-year standing or MD degree.

title: Selected Topics in Tropical Medicine and Infectious Diseases
description: Elective for medical students in Tropical Medicine and Infectious Diseases. Repeatable six times, up to 12 credits. Medical students only. CR/NC only. consent.

title: (Alpha) Selected Topics in Infectious Diseases
description: Elective for medical students; (B) infectious diseases; (C) parasitology; (D) epidemiology; (E) immunology. MD majors only. CR/NC only. MDED 554 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Selected Research Topics in Infectious Diseases
description: Research elective for medical students; (B) infectious diseases; (C) parasitology; (D) epidemiology; (E) immunology. MD majors only. CR/NC only. MDED 554 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Tropical Medicine Journal Club
description: Students gain experience in the presentation and discussion of topics of current interest in the fields of tropical medicine and infectious diseases. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.

title: Laboratory Methods in Tropical Medicine
description: Microbiologic methods and techniques for identification of pathogenic viruses, bacterial, and parasitic organisms including specimen handling, culturing, and laboratory safety. Repeatable one time. Graduate standing only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Infectious Disease Microbiology I: Medical Parasitology
description: Epidemiology, pathogenesis, immunobiology and diagnostic aspects of human parasitic infections; principles of host-pathogen interactions; public health aspects of parasitic infections. Repeatable one time. A-F only. MICR 351 or equivalent. (Fall only)

title: Concepts in Immunology and Immunopathogenesis
description: Immunological concepts relating to infectious diseases and host pathogen interactions. Repeatable one time. A-F only. MICR 461 (or equivalent) or consent. (

title: Infectious Disease Micro II
description: Will cover different families of animal viruses of importance to human diseases. The genome, structure, replication, as well as host immune responses, epidemiology, clinical features, and animal models will be presented. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 604 and MICR 351, or consent. (

title: Tropical Medicine Laboratory Rotations
description: Practical experience in use of equipment and procedures in infectious disease and immunology research; introduction to research in tropical medicine. Repeatable unlimited times. 604 (or concurrent), or consent.

title: Neurovirology
description: Seminar on neuroinvasive viruses giving basics of viruses causing nervous system diseases and discussing recent advances in the research field of neurovirology. MICR 351 or equivalent; or consent. (Fall only)

title: Infectious Disease Microbiology III
description: Basic structure, physiology, epidemiology, and genetics of pathogenic bacteria as well as the host response to these organisms. Correlation of these characteristics to disease pathogenesis in humans and animal models. A-F only. 604 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Advances In Medical Immunology
description: Presentations/discussions of current literature concerning recent advances in immunology relevant to disease and to disease processes. consent. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Infection and Immunity
description: Combined lecture/discussion of interactions of pathogens with the innate and acquired immune systems. Topics will include the role of novel receptors in pathogen detection, inflammation in disease pathogenesis, pathogen immune evasion, and neuroimmunology. Repeatable two times. A-F only. 604, MICR 461, or consent. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Ecological Epidemiology
description: Applications of population biology, pathogen/host life history, and population genetics to infectious disease epidemiology, including micro- and macroparasites, and implications to disease control and prevention of strategies. A-F only. consent. (Alt. years: spring) (

title: Vaccinology
description: History/evolution of vaccines, current and next generation vaccines, vaccine immunology, adjuvants, vaccine strategies, vaccines for viral, bacterial, and parasitic diseases, vaccine-proof-of-concept and downstream developmental studies; vaccine safety production processes. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. A-F only. (604 and 605) with a minimum grade of B. (Spring only
prerequisites: (TRMD 604 and TRMD 605) with a minimum grade of B

title: Advanced Genetics and Evolution of Infectious Diseases
description: An evolutionary perspective to examine the interactive responses between infectious agents and the immune system. Topics will include natural selection, life history evolution, population genetics of pathogens and hosts, and anti-microbial resistance. A-F only. 604 (or concurrent) and 605 (or concurrent), or consent. (Alt. years: spring)
prerequisites: TRMD 604 (or concurrent) and TRMD 605 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Bioinformatics I
description: Provides fundamental concepts in bioinformatics with strong emphasis on hands-on training. Topics such as molecular biology, sequence alignment, biological databases, phytogeny, and genomics including microarray and RNA-sequence analysis. Repeatable one time, but credit earned one time only. Open to nonmajors. A-F only.

title: Advances in HIV/AIDS
description: History of HIV, basic biology and virology, epidemiology, HIV pathogenesis and immunology, clinical features, and co-morbidities. Treatment and prevention of HIV/ AIDS, including research methods, statistics, cultural competence, genetics, pathophysiology, drug and vaccine development. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. 604 and 605, or consent. (Fall only)

title: Fundamentals of Biostatistics
description: Fundamental biomedical statistics concepts and tools will be introduced, as well as their applications to biomedical data. Students will perform hands-on analysis using statistical software and learn to interpret and present the results. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Advanced Medical Parasitology
description: Consideration of ultrastructure, physiology, biochemistry, in-vitro cultivation and host-parasite relationship of parasites of medical importance. A-F only. consent. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Advanced Medical Virology
description: In-depth study of the major groups of viruses pathogenic for human; virus replication, host range, pathogenesis, immunology, and epidemiology. 605 or equivalent, or consent. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Advanced Medical Bacteriology
description: Role of bacteria in infectious diseases, with emphasis on clinical aspects and identification of etiological agents. 605 or equivalent, or consent.

title: Epidemiology of Tropical Infectious Diseases
description: Epidemiology of infectious diseases as it relates to tropical medicine. Lecture/seminar format. A-F only. TRMD graduate standing or consent. (Spring only)

title: Seminar in Tropical Medicine and Public Health
description: Weekly discussion and reports on current advances in tropical medicine and public health. Repeatable unlimited times. (

title: Plan B Master’s Project
description: Independent study for students working on a Plan B master’s project. A grade of Satisfactory (S) is assigned when the project is satisfactorily completed. A-F only. graduate standing in TRMD.

title: Directed Research
description: Directed research in medical microbiology (bacteriology, parasitology, virology). Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Approval of department faculty required. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Special Topics in Tropical Medicine
description: Advanced instruction in frontiers of tropical medicine and public health. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. (

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral thesis. Approval of department faculty is required. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Journalism and Society
description: News literacy, and the role of journalism in society–its influence, rights and responsibilities; issues and trends.

title: Introduction to Multimedia Journalism
description: Fundamentals of multimedia reporting: finding and developing story ideas, photojournalism, audio storytelling, design, infographics, and cross-platform digital convergence. A-F only.

title: Media Writing
description: Fundamentals of writing for various news media and public relations; ethics. A-F only.

title: Reporting
description: Theory and practice of information gathering using a variety of primary and secondary sources, finding information online, use of databases and interviews for news stories, with emphasis on writing. JOUR majors only, or consent. A-F only. 250.

title: Governing, Policy, and Political Journalism
description: Survey of the institutions of democratic governance and the role of journalism in covering and analyzing public policy. A-F only. (

title: Photojournalism
description: Production, selection, and use of digital photographs for publications. Storytelling action and feature photography with digital cameras, worked up through Adobe Photoshop and InDesign programs. Students must have a digital camera. A-F only.

title: Advanced Editing
description: Intensive training in editing, planning, and organizing stories and visual elements for publication; news judgment; managing projects. JOUR majors only, or consent.

title: Visual Journalism: Multimedia
description: Fundamentals of visual journalism; visual theory, principles, and tools to create multimedia journalism projects for online, emerging media, and print platforms. JOUR majors only, or consent. A-F only.

title: Sports Media
description: A practice-based writing approach to the production of sports media in contemporary mediums of all types (written, audio, video, etc.) for various communication contexts (e.g., journalistic, public relations, etc. A-F only.

title: Magazine Writing
description: Writing nonfiction articles for magazines, newspapers, and newsletters; preparing material for specific audience; marketing articles. 250.

title: Interpretive Journalism
description: Writing articles of news analysis, editorials, and critical reviews.

title: Video Journalism
description: Fundamentals of video journalism using digital video cameras for writing, reporting, editing, and producing news stories, with significant attention to oral communication skills. A-F only. 200.

title: Journalism History and Trends
description: Development of the news media and trends that may affect the future of journalism.

title: Communication and Law
description: An exploration of key legal issues related to the practice of journalism in Hawaiʻi, including comparisons with other jurisdictions in the United States and elsewhere. JOUR majors only, or consent. Junior standing or higher.

title: (Alpha) Journalism Workshops
description: Intensive workshops in practice-based journalism, focused on building skills and making public projects in: (B) emerging media; (C) reporting; (D) editing; (E) multimedia journalism; (F) public relations. Repeatable in different alphas up to 6 credits. JOUR majors only, or consent.

title: Advanced Photojournalism
description: Computer experience in the creation, manipulation, and editing of color news, feature, sports, and documentary images. Study of the ethical and legal dimensions of electronic imaging. 307 or consent.

title: Publication Layout and Design
description: Visual display concepts and procedures for newsletters, brochures, newspapers, magazines. upper division standing.

title: Special Topics
description: Topics of interest to faculty and students; taught by regular and visiting faculty. Repeatable one time for different topics. JOUR majors only. Junior standing or higher.

title: Media Ethics
description: Ethics and social responsibility for media professionals. Application of ethical theories and principles to case studies and research projects through writing assignments. JOUR majors only. one DS course. (

title: Broadcast Projects/Production
description: Applied, problem-based application of skills and knowledge of visual story telling to the production of broadcast newscasts. JOUR majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 250, 300, 330; and ICS 101 or ICS 110 or ICS 111 or LTEC 112.
prerequisites: JOUR 250, JOUR 300, JOUR 330; and ICS 101 or ICS 110 or ICS 111 or LTEC 112

title: Advanced Multimedia Journalism
description: Advanced fundamentals of multimedia writing and reporting, including finding and developing journalistic story ideas, photojournalism, audio storytelling, design, infographics, and cross-platform digital convergence. JOUR majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 250, 300, and 330.

title: Global Communication
description: Problems and opportunities of communication in a variety of international contexts, focused on journalistic issues. JOUR majors only, or consent.

title: Advanced Video Journalism
description: Advanced experience in field and studio production of short and long form video journalism; with emphasis on social media fundamentals and content distribution across multiple digital platforms. A-F only. 330 or instructor consent.

title: Innovation and Entrepreneurship in Journalism
description: Exploration of the leading edge of the journalistic ideology today as well as a projection of future forms, styles, and strategies, with writing skills as the foundation of such exploratory activities. JOUR majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 150, 200, 250, 300, and 330.
prerequisites: JOUR 150, JOUR 200, JOUR 250, JOUR 300, and JOUR 330

title: Internship
description: Internship in media or PR operations under professional and faculty supervision. Repeatable two times. JOUR majors only. CR/NC only. 300 and 330, or consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Individual research projects. senior standing and consent of department chair.
prerequisites: senior standing and consent of department chair

title: Physical Fitness
description: Conditioning exercises and activities to develop and maintain physical efficiency. Motor fitness tests administered to measure status and progress. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Aerobic Fitness
description: Aerobic fitness improvement upon completion of course by regularly attending and practicing safe workout routines. Learn fitness components, names of muscles and exercises associated with each one. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Swimming: Beginning
description: Adjusting to and immersing in water, floating, sculling; correct arm stroke, leg kick, breathing techniques and their coordination. (Student to provide own swimming attire approved by instructor.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Swimming: Intermediate
description: Perfecting and integrating basic strokes with added emphasis for speed and distance. (Student to provide own swimming attire approved by instructor.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. 103.

title: Swimming: Advanced
description: Correct techniques used in competitive swimming, racing starts, correct turning techniques, long-distance swimming. (Student to provide own swimming attire approved by instructor.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. 104 or consent.

title: SCUBA Diving: Beginning
description: Learning watermanship, equipment handling skills, and the knowledge to become safe divers. Additional costs for equipment, diver manual, dive tables, and certification fee. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Aqua-Aerobic Fitness
description: Combined lecture-lab-physical activity with emphasis on aerobic fitness improvement through total body aquatic workouts with music, and development of individualized aquatics fitness program. Open to all students. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Golf: Beginning
description: Rules, etiquette, grip, stance, drive, normal iron shots, approach shots, putting. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Golf: Intermediate
description: Corrective work on basic swing mechanics and rhythm; adjustments for bunker play, uphill lies, downhill lies, short game around and on the green; handicapping and match play competition. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. 110 and consent.

title: Golf: Advanced
description: Improving drive, fairway wood shots, long iron shots, control shots, trouble shots, putting, course management, competitive strategy, problems in rules. Greens fees paid by students for play on courses. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. 111 and consent.

title: Bowling
description: Rules, etiquette, arm swing, approach, execution, scoring, spare pickups. Students pay charge for use of alley. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Badminton
description: Rules, etiquette, grip, forehand and backhand strokes, serving, smash, drive, net play, offensive and defensive strategy; singles and doubles play. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Folk and National Dances
description: Popular dances of various national groups, including square dances. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Dances of Hawai‘i
description: Background and fundamentals of hula. Selected dances with and without instruments. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Dances of Hawai‘i: Advanced
description: Advanced techniques in hula movements. Selected dances taught will be more complex, including work with instruments. Individual choreography will be emphasized. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. 124 or consent.

title: Social Dance: Ballroom
description: Social dances including fox trot, waltz, swing, and other popular dances. Basic steps, rhythm pattern, styling, and variations are taught. Social etiquette is stressed. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Social Dance: Latin
description: Social dances of a Latin flavor including rhumba, cha-cha, tango, samba, and others. Basic steps, rhythm pattern, styling, and variations are taught. Social etiquette is stressed. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Tennis: Beginning
description: Rules, etiquette, grip, forehand and backhand strokes, serving, volleying; singles and doubles play. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Tennis: Intermediate
description: Corrective work in three basic strokes and in net play; the lob, drop shot, overhead smash, and half-volley; applying spin in basic strokes; basic strategy in singles and doubles play. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. 130 or consent.

title: Tennis: Advanced
description: Improving upon the strokes introduced in 130 and 131; advanced competitive strategy; problems in rules; officiating; elements of tournament play. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. 131 or consent.

title: Volleyball: Beginning
description: Combined lecture-lab-physical activity with emphasis on beginner skills and knowledge relative to serving, passing, spiking, digging, blocking, and offensive and defensive strategy. Open to all students. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Volleyball: Intermediate
description: Combined lecture-lab-physical activity with emphasis on improving skills and knowledge through practice and cognitive activities relative to serving, passing, spiking, digging, blocking, and offensive and defensive strategy. Open to all students. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. 135 or consent.

title: Basketball
description: Rules, passing, shooting, dribbling, rebounding, individual defensive and offensive maneuvers; team offense and defense. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Adapted and Prescribed Exercises
description: Small group and individual guidance and instruction for students recommended by student health service. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. consent.

title: Weight Training
description: Kinesiology of lifting and weight training, various types of exercises and methods of training with resistance. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. KRS majors only.

title: Olympic and Power Lifting
description: Exercise technique and prescription with an emphasis on anaerobic exercise. Explores advanced periodization models and their utilization, mastery of Olympic lifts, and plyometric programs. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. KRS majors only. 152 or consent.

title: Tumbling and Rebound Tumbling
description: Single and combination stunts on tumbling mats and trampoline, balancing stunts; techniques of spotting; safety procedures. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Heavy Apparatus
description: Single and combination stunts on side horse, horizontal bar, parallel bars, still rings; techniques of spotting; safety procedures. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Judo
description: Rules, etiquette, method of falling and breaking the fall, simple throws and their counters, simple holds and breaking of such holds, randori. (Student to provide own gi.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Aikido
description: Rules, etiquette, basic rolls, simple holds and the breaking of such holds, specific physical conditioning exercises. (Student to provide own gi.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: T’ai Chi Ch’uan
description: Classic forms of t’ai chi ch’uan. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Karate: Beginning
description: Rules, etiquette, basic stances, blocks, thrusts, kicks, ippon kumite, and selected kata. (Student to provide own gi.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Karate: Intermediate
description: Emphasis on improving the basic techniques (stances, punches, kicks, forms, and sparring); introduction to combination techniques. (Student to provide own gi.) Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. 164.

title: Wrestling: Beginning
description: Rules: fundamental defensive and offensive maneuvers and competitive strategy, i.e., takedowns, reversals, escapes, and pinning combinations; conditioning exercises. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Yoga: Beginning
description: Experiencing yoga and its effects on body, mind and consciousness of individual. Encompasses exercise, breathing techniques, deep relaxation, meditation, practice in concentration, and yogic postures. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. KRS majors only.

title: Yoga: Intermediate
description: Corrective work and improvement of basic techniques. Exercise sets and combinations designed to develop endurance, flexibility, muscle and nerve strength, meditation, and deep relaxation technique. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. 170 or consent.

title: Water Polo
description: Fundamentals of basic water polo skills, namely, ball handling, passing, shooting, dribbling plus a brief introduction into beginning techniques of individual offense and defense. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. 104 or consent. (Student to provide own swimming attire approved by instructor.)

title: Sport Proficiency I: Invasion
description: Knowledge, skill development, and strategy of various invasion type games and sports. Sports like basketball, soccer, ultimate frisbee and/or others are introduced within a tactical framework. KRS majors only. A-F only.

title: Sport Proficiency II: Net, Field, and Target
description: Knowledge, skill development, position, and strategy of net, field and target sports. Sports like volleyball, tennis, softball, and golf are introduced within a tactical framework. KRS majors only. A-F only.

title: Floor Exercise Gymnastics
description: An entry-level course designed to develop students’ knowledge of men’s and women’s gymnastics floor exercise routines, including injury prevention, skill progression, spotting techniques, and routine choreography. Primarily for KRS majors; others admitted on space-available basis. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Track and Field for Physical Education
description: Knowledge, skills, and rules of various track and field events. Organization of track meets and strategy in competition. Primarily for KRS majors; others admitted on space-available basis. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: Softball
description: Combined lecture-lab-physical activity with emphasis on basic skills, rules, etiquette, offensive and defensive strategies, position play, and game situations. Open to all students. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only.

title: School Health Problems: Elementary
description: Responsibilities of elementary school teacher in recognizing and meeting pupils’ needs, emphasizing teacher’s role in health instruction, health services, school health policies. Repeatable one time.

title: School Health Problems: Secondary
description: Responsibilities of secondary school teacher in recognizing and meeting pupils’ needs, emphasizing health instruction, health services, healthful school living, school health policies. Repeatable one time.

title: Introduction to Kinesiology
description: Kinesiology as a professional field. Overview of history, philosophy, and current trends in kinesiology. Survey of psychological and sociological foundations of kinesiology, exercise, fitness and sport. KRS majors or approval. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Recreation Services in Contemporary Society
description: Theories and philosophies in recreation: history; contemporary issues; roles in modern society; relationship to health, physical education, and exercise science. A-F only.

title: Human Development
description: Developmental processes across the life span. Life span perspective on psychological, social, and physical development. Human growth and development from conception to death with major theories and related research on maintaining healthy lifestyles. Repeatable one time.

title: Safety and Risk Management
description: Understanding the fundamental principles and techniques of safety and accident-prevention programming emphasizing school, home, public places, on the job, and motor vehicle situations. Repeatable one time.

title: Outdoor Recreation Management
description: Objectives and values of outdoor recreation; characteristics and determinants of programs; planning, organization, leadership, and facilities for recreational uses of natural environments. Repeatable one time. 208 or consent.

title: Health Education Curriculum
description: Objectives of school health program, emphasizing scope and sequence of health instruction; critical examination of health curriculum guides from various states. Repeatable one time. 201 or 202.

title: Programming and Leadership
description: Factors in planning and leading recreation programs; characteristics and responsibilities of leadership in relation to nature, scope, and resources of a variety of programs. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 208 or consent.

title: Introduction to Health and Physical Education
description: Introduction to foundational knowledge for effective teaching, history, philosophy, and current practices in physical education. Provides the basis for later coursework in K-12 physical education. Required field experience. A-F only. consent. (Fall only)

title: Performance Based Assessment in Health and Physical Education
description: Assessment and evaluative techniques applied to health and physical education, including test construction, performance-based assessment, measurement criteria and instruments, interpretation of data and content, as well as program evaluation.

title: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
description: Understanding standards-based planning, teaching, and assessment in health with a focus on advocacy, as well as the incidence, prevalence, and prevention of disease within sub-topics of health (mental, social, emotional, environmental, financial, etc.). KRS majors only.

title: Principles of Sports Medicine
description: Examines with some depth, principles of risk management and pathology of athletic injuries, major musculoskeletal structures, and concepts of evaluative skills, treatment, and rehabilitation for common athletic injuries. KRS majors only. A-F only.

title: Coaching of Football
description: Theory and strategy of offensive and defensive football coaching. Emphasis on coaching philosophy, selecting and developing an offense and defense, organizing practices, special situations, scouting, and training and conditioning. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Coaching of Basketball
description: Theory and strategy of offensive and defensive basketball coaching. Emphasis on coaching philosophy, selecting and developing an offense and defense, organizing practices, special situations, scouting, and training and conditioning. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Coaching of Baseball
description: Theory and strategy of offensive and defensive baseball coaching. Emphasis on coaching philosophy, selecting and developing an offense and defense, organizing practices, special situations, scouting, and training and conditioning. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Coaching of Volleyball
description: Theory and strategy of offensive and defensive volleyball coaching. Emphasis on coaching philosophy, selecting and developing an offense and defense, organizing practices, special situations, scouting, and training and conditioning. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Music and Rhythm in Physical Education
description: Use of music in physical education programming (K-12), emphasizing selection of appropriate music for specific activities as expressive or creative movement, movement exploration, rhythmic gymnastics, and dancing. A variety of strategies for teaching dance will be shared. A-F only. consent. (Spring only)

title: Managing Recreation Services
description: Administrative framework and procedures pertinent to the operation of agencies providing recreational services to the various publics. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 208 or consent.

title: Water Safety Training
description: Theory and methods of advanced lifesaving and water safety leading to American Red Cross Water Safety Instructor (WSI) certification. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 104 or consent. (Student to provide own swim attire approved by the instructor.)

title: Emergency Care and First Aid Training
description: Practicum in training of persons to become qualified in emergency care knowledge, basic life support, and first aid skills. First Aid and CPR certificates may be earned. KRS majors only.

title: Movement Education I
description: A movement-based approach to teaching basic motor skills in preschool/elementary physical education. Students actively participate and learn about developmentally appropriate content and pedagogy for children in grades P–5/6. Peer bit teaching is included. A-F only.

title: Movement Education II
description: (3 Lec, 1 1-hr. Lab) Content and pedadogy for teaching /K-5 physical education. Students will learn to plan and teach physical education for children. Peer bit and field teaching included. Repeatable one time, but credit earned one time only. A-F only.

title: Coaching of Track and Field
description: Techniques and rules of sprints, distance runs, relays, hurdles, long jump, high jump, pole vault, shot put, discus, and javelin throws; conduct of track and field meets; specific conditioning and training problems. Repeatable one time.

title: Coaching of Swimming
description: Theory and methods of coaching competitive swimming. Technical, organizational, and administrative aspects. Emphasis on stroke mechanics and training methods. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Fieldwork in Recreation I
description: Initial supervised leadership experience in recreational agencies. One hour per week in class discussion sessions. For recreation majors only. Repeatable one time. A-F only. consent of recreation advisor.

title: Special Recreation
description: Special recreation as a professional field. Overview of special recreation services. Emphasis on recreation services for special populations. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 208 or consent.

title: Structural Kinesiology
description: Gross human anatomy, emphasizing identification and description of parts of the musculoskeletal system; selected applications to motor activity. KRS majors only. A-F only. 113 or BIOL 171/171L or PHYL 103 or PHYL 141/141L or PHYL 301/301L.
prerequisites: KRS 113 or BIOL 171/BIOL 171L or PHYL 103 or PHYL 141/PHYL 141L or PHYL 301/PHYL 301L

title: Exercise and Sport Physiology
description: Emphasis on physiological responses to exercises and physical training as related to strength, muscular endurance, cardio-respiratory endurance. Primarily for KRS majors, but open to others with consent. Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science, Health/ Exercise Science and Lifestyle Management, and Physical Education majors only. A-F only. 113 or PHYL 103 or PHYL 142/142L (or concurrent), or BIOL 171/171L (or concurrent); or consent. Co-requisite: 354L.
prerequisites: KRS 113 or PHYL 103 or PHYL 142/PHYL 142L (or concurrent), or BIOL 171/BIOL 171L (or concurrent); or consent

title: Exercise and Sport Physiology Lab
description: Laboratory section to accompany KRS 354. Emphasis will be hands-on data collection and analysis of the physiological responses to exercise and physical training. Lab report development and scientific writing will also be emphasized. Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science, Health/Exercise Science and Lifestyle Management, and Physical Education majors only. A-F only. 113 or PHYL 103 or PHYL 142/142L (or concurrent), or BIOL 171/171L (or concurrent); or consent. Co-requisite: 354.
prerequisites: KRS 113 or PHYL 103 or PHYL 142/PHYL 142L (or concurrent), or BIOL 171/BIOL 171L (or concurrent); or consent

title: Teaching Techniques I: Elementary
description: Teaching techniques and methods of elementary physical education. Content to include basic skills and games in a school-based experience. Primarily for KRS majors. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Teaching Techniques II: Secondary
description: Teaching techniques and methods of secondary physical education. Content to include invasion, net, field, and target activities. Emphasizes the tactical approach in a school-based experience. Primarily for KRS majors. A-F only.

title: Drugs and Society
description: Introduction to psychoactive drugs and their effects; drug regulations; education and rehabilitation programs; psycho-social variables related to the decisions to use/abuse drugs. consent.

title: Physical Fitness for Physical Education Teachers
description: Diagnosis and prescription for basic health and fitness problems, scientific principles of training, guidelines for exercise; essentials of scientifically based individualized physical fitness program. Repeatable one time.

title: Field Work in Strength and Conditioning I
description: Supervised practicum in strength training and conditioning. Students will be exposed to the theory and practice of designing and implementing both strength/power, and general conditioning programs. Repeatable one time. 152, 354 (or concurrent); or consent.

title: Personal Health and Wellness
description: Core concepts in health allow students to take responsibility for their own health-related behaviors by developing basic competencies in identifying, analyzing, and responsibly deliberating contemporary ethical issues related to health and wellness. KRS majors only.

title: Directed Reading
description: Individual problems. Limited to senior majors in health education, physical education, athletic training, or recreation with a minimum GPA of 2.75 in major field. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Advanced Health Concepts
description: Understanding health issues for individuals, families, schools, and communities, in regards to Hawaii K-12 schools. Focusing on the acquisition of functional health content and proficiency in health-related skills to enhance healthy behaviors in learners. KRS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Teaching Practicum in Physical Education
description: Field experience in teaching physical education activities in schools, K-12; techniques in leadership; selection of activities and program evaluation for K-12 licensure. (E) elementary; (S) secondary. KRS majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. admittance to licensure track; pass basic skills tests specified by the Hawai‘i Teacher Standards Board (www.htsb.org) or bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution.
prerequisites: admittance to licensure track; pass basic skills tests specified by the Hawai‘i Teacher Standards Board (www)

title: Guidance and Classroom Management
description: Guidance principles applied to classroom management for teachers. consent.

title: K-12 Teaching Methods in Physical Education
description: Methods and materials in teaching physical education, including techniques, leadership skills, program evaluation, and designing course content using written communication skills. Repeatable one time, but credit earned one time only. A-F only. KRS majors only. Co-requisite: 402E.

title: (Alpha) Teaching Residency
description: Full-time supervised experience in elementary and secondary school level. School level corresponds to level of licensure desired. (E) elementary; (S) secondary. Each alpha can be taken one time. Kinesiology & Rehabilitation Science, Physical Education, and Secondary Education-Physical Education majors only.
