A-F only. 402E (with a minimum grade of B-), 402S (with a minimum grade of B-), and 404 (with a minimum grade of B-); admittance to licensure track, pass Praxis II Core Academic Skills tests. Co-requisite: 406.
prerequisites: KRS 402E (with a minimum grade of B-), KRS 402S (with a minimum grade of B-), and KRS 404 (with a minimum grade of B-); admittance to licensure track, pass Praxis II Core Academic Skills tests

title: Seminar in Teaching Residency
description: Analysis and resolutions of issues in teaching residency; teaching strategies and techniques; curriculum planning; professional growth and development. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 402E, 402S, and 404 or consent; admittance to licensure track, pass Praxis II Core Academic Skills tests.
prerequisites: KRS 402E, KRS 402S, and KRS 404 or consent; admittance to licensure track, pass Praxis II Core Academic Skills tests

title: Psychosocial Aspects of Sport
description: Examination and application of sociological and psychological theories to sport including the influence of race, ethnicity, gender, identity and human development, social class, disabilities, and sexual orientation on the sport experience. A-F only. consent.

title: Prevent/Care of Athletic Injuries
description: An examination of the most recent practices and procedures in the prevention and care of athletic and sports injuries. Observational field experiences in athletic training will be required. KRS majors only. A-F only. 353.

title: Fundamentals of Ergonomics
description: Introduction to ergonomics principles and their application in understanding and prevention of Muscular Skeletal Disorders encountered in the working environment including introduction to legal aspects of ergonomics. Post-Master’s Certificate in Nursing majors only. 463 or consent.

title: Administration in Athletic Training, Exercise Science, Allied Health
description: An examination of organization and administration in Athletic Training, Allied Health and Exercise Science. Content includes leadership and motivation models, legal liability, ethical considerations and management strategies for all aspects of Health Care Administration. KRS majors only. A-F only.

title: Lower Extremity Assessment
description: An examination of the pathology of injuries to the lower extremities and their care and treatment designed for Athletic Training, Exercise Science and Allied Health professionals. KRS majors only. A-F only. 353, 415; or consent.

title: Upper Extremity Assessment
description: An examination of the pathology of injuries to the upper extremities and their care and treatment designed for Athletic Training, Exercise Science and Allied Health professionals. Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Science, Health/Exercise Science and Lifestyle Management, and Physical Education majors only. A-F only. 353 and 415, or consent.

title: Curriculum and Supervision
description: Effective program development, planning, and supervision, including issues in legal liability and administration of all aspects of physical education programming in grades K-12. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 270 or consent. Majors only.

title: Current Issues in Leisure Services
description: Philosophical foundations and current and emerging issues in leisure services management and programming. Coverage of leisure research and its implications to practice. Repeatable one time. 238, 249, and 329; or consent.
prerequisites: KRS 238, KRS 249, and KRS 329; or consent

title: Evaluating and Marketing Leisure Services
description: Basic methods in marketing, planning, evaluating programs and problem-solving methods, survey research, research design, data analysis, and report generation for park, recreation, and tourism systems. A-F only. 329 (or concurrent), or consent.

title: Emergency Care for the Professional Rescuer
description: Combined lecture-lab on advanced emergency care for injuries and illnesses and includes certifications for CPR/First Aid/AED. Class size of approximately 20 students. Open to all majors. Repeatable one time. A-F only. consent.

title: Coaching Athletics
description: Combined lecture-lab with emphasis on scientific principles, theory and practice, and professional qualities of the coach. Writing is integrated with the intent that students will enhance their communication skills through writing. KRS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. consent.

title: Camp Resources and Planning
description: (1 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Combined lecture-lab for camp counselors and camp leadership. Plan and evaluate camp experiences for children and youth, including those with disabilities. Includes field trips. 331 and 332, or consent.

title: Practicum in Camping
description: Supervised leadership at a camp setting with children and youth, including those with disabilities. Day or residential camps. One full week camping for each credit hour. Maximum of four credit hours. 437 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Disability and Diversity in Physical Activity
description: (3 Lec, 1 1-hr. Lab) Participants will explore issues related to individuals with exceptionalities, how these affect learning and behavior in the health and physical activity settings. Oral communication practice and skills are worth >30% grade. Required field experience. KRS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Sport Biomechanics
description: Concepts and scientific principles essential to efficient human movement; proper application of biomechanical principles to fundamental movements and selected complex motor skills. KRS majors only. A-F only. 353, and either PHYS 100, PHYS 151, or PHYS 170; or consent.
prerequisites: KRS 353, and either PHYS 100, PHYS 151, or PHYS 170; or consent

title: Fitness for Life
description: Students will gain knowledge, skills, and experience necessary to plan, implement, and evaluate Fitness for Life curriculum. Includes an emphasis on instruction and feedback in oral communication. KRS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Teaching Methods in Health Education
description: Experiences in developing standards-based, interactive learning opportunities to teach quality health education in schools. Focus on creating curriculum and assessments aligned with the National and State Standards for Health Education. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Learning Communities
description: Theory, basic research, interactive process, and methodology of the cooperative learning process known as Tribes. Will develop participants’ abilities to foster and facilitate learning communities in a variety of settings. Repeatable one time. (Summer only)

title: Sociocultural Issues in Physical Activity
description: Contemporary and historical perspective on socio-cultural issues that influence health and physical activity settings. Understanding ethics and culturally responsive practice around race, gender, sexuality, class, etc. Emphasis on ethics and teaching writing for the profession. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Statistics
description: Basic elements for: descriptive statistics, probability, inference, regression, and correlation analysis. KRS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Motor Learning and Performance
description: Basic consideration is kinesthesis, motor ability, fatigue, developmental factors, practice, motivation in relation to motor learning and human performance. Repeatable one time. EDEP 311 or consent.

title: Motor Development and Learning
description: (3 Lec, 1 1-hr. Lab) Motor development through the lifespan with an emphasis on fundamental principles and patterns. Areas such as memory, knowledge of performance, and motivation are incorporated and demonstrated through multiple writing assignments. Required field experience. Primarily for KRS majors. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Adapted Physical Activity in Early Childhood
description: Concepts of developmentally appropriate practice, importance of movement in overall development, and design of physical activity sessions and environments for young children with and without disabilities are covered. A-F only. consent.

title: Nutrition in Exercise and Sport
description: Effects of physiologic demands of exercise on nutrition. Emphasis on physiologic and biochemical basis for nutrition recommendations to enhance exercise participation and optimize athletic performance. (FSHN 185, and KRS 113 or PHYL 103 or (PHYL 141/141L and 142/142L) or PHYL 301) with a minimum grade of C. (
prerequisites: (FSHN 185, and KRS 113 or PHYL 103 or (PHYL 141/PHYL 141L and PHYL 142/PHYL 142L) or PHYL 301) with a minimum grade of C

title: Introduction to Research in KRS
description: Research methods in the study of physical activity, types of research, statistical concepts and techniques, and reporting research results. Repeatable one time.

title: Commercial Recreation
description: Overview of leisure services and trends in commercial, private and employee recreation, and resort and recreational tourism. The social, economic, and environmental significance is examined. 428 or consent.

title: Recreation Planning and Maintenance
description: Examination of social, economic, and environmental factors of recreation and tourism development. Emphasis on methods, processes, citizen participation, design issues/regulations, and land use. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 238 and 329; or consent.

title: Drug Abuse, Violence, and Injury Prevention
description: Standards-based planning, teaching, and assessment on the scientific, socio-cultural, and attitudinal aspects of drug abuse, violence, and injury prevention. Focus on incidence and prevalence, roles, prevention, and high-risk populations. KRS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Sexual Health Education
description: Program planning, curriculum development and classroom teaching strategies in the areas of human sexuality, reproductive health, family planning, and family health. Focus on research-based curriculum and strategies to promote personal and social responsibility for health. A-F only.

title: Exercise Assessment and Conditioning Lab
description: Designed to provide knowledge of laboratory techniques and procedures for aerobic and anaerobic fitness assessment, interpretation of aerobic and anaerobic testing results, and individual exercise program/prescription. A-F only. 480 and EDEP 429, or consent. (Fall only)

title: Practicum in Health and Exercise Science
description: Culminating 160 hours of supervised practicum experience in health, wellness, fitness assessment, lifestyle management, and/or exercise leadership. Qualifying hours are contingent upon instructor’s approval in the registered semester. Health and Exercise Science majors only. current CPR and First Aid Certification, 152, 332, 353, 354, and 463; or consent.
prerequisites: current CPR and First Aid Certification, KRS 152, KRS 332, KRS 353, KRS 354, and KRS 463; or consent

title: Program Design in Strength Training and Conditioning
description: Designed to provide theoretical and practical experience in supervision of a strength training center. Content includes program design, exercise techniques, organization, testing, evaluation, methods of strength development, facility design and special populations. Kinesiology & Rehabilitation Science, Health/Exercise Science and Lifestyle Management, and Physical Education majors only. A-F only. 152, 153, 353, 354, 354L, and 463; or consent.
prerequisites: KRS 152, KRS 153, KRS 353, KRS 354, KRS 354L, and KRS 463; or consent

title: Introduction to Athletic Training Clinic
description: Introduction to the Professional Athletic Training Education Program and the Clinical Education Plan. Students are required to document all requirements and demonstrate proficiency in basic clinical skills. Repeatable one time. A-F only. ATEP Program students only. (Once a year)

title: AT Practicum I
description: Introductory-level supervised experiences within the profession of athletic training. This practicum is required for the KRS entry-level Graduate Athletic Training Education Program. A-F only.

title: AT Practicum II
description: Introductory-level supervised experiences within the profession of athletic training. This practicum is required for the KRS entry-level Graduate Athletic Training Education Program. A-F only.

title: Athletic Training Practicum III
description: Advanced-level supervised experiences within the profession of athletic training. This practicum is a requirement for entry to the KRS Master’s Athletic Training Program. A-F only.

title: Athletic Training Practicum IV
description: (5 2-hr Practicum) Advanced-level supervised experiences within the profession of athletic training. This practicum is a requirement for entry to the KRS Master’s Athletic Training Program. A-F only.

title: Counseling in the Schools
description: History, philosophy, and organization of school counseling programs. Counselor role and functions, legal and ethical issues, contemporary issues, current methodology and resources. (Meets EdD common core elective.) consent.

title: Lower Extremity, Thorax, and Abdomen
description: Human gross anatomy dissection of the lower extremity, thorax, and abdomen with emphasis on muscles, function, innervation, and vascular supply. Repeatable one time. Enrolled in DRB or KRS graduate programs (including Biomed Sci-Anat/ RepoBiol & Phys majors) only or consent. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Upper Extremity, Head, Neck, and Spine
description: Human gross anatomy dissection of the upper extremity, head, neck, and spine. Emphasis is placed on muscles, function, innervation, and vascular supply. Repeatable one time. Enrolled in DRB or KRS graduate programs (including Biomed Sci-Anat/ RepoBiol & Phys majors) only or consent. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Human Growth and Development—Life Span
description: Life span perspective on psychological, social, and physical development. Major theories and related research on human development; applications in policy planning and service delivery in counseling. consent.

title: Counseling: Theory and Practice
description: Theory and techniques of counseling and guidance as preparation for practicum and internship. Application in school, college, rehabilitation, and community settings. consent.

title: Scientific Principles of Physical Conditioning
description: Application of physiological principles to physical conditioning and athletic performance. graduate standing or consent.

title: Muscular Strength and Power Development
description: Interpretation of scientific principles of muscular strength and power development. Examination of muscular adaptations to increased and decreased use. graduate standing or consent.

title: Athletic Training, Clinical Experience I
description: (1 Sem, 5 3-hr Practicum) Practicum requiring performance of duties and responsibilities of athletic training students. Must be completed during first semester post admission into program. Athletic Training majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Athletic Training, Clinical Experience II
description: (1 Sem, 5 3-hr Practicum) Practicum includes duties and responsibilities of athletic training students. Practicum must be completed during second semester post admission to the program. Athletic Training majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Athletic Training, Clinical Experience III
description: (1 Sem, 5 3-hr Practicum) Culminating practicum requiring performance of duties and responsibilities of second year graduate athletic training students. A practical field experience in athletic training is required. Athletic Training majors only. A-F only. (Fall only

title: Athletic Training, Clinical Experience IV
description: (1 Sem, 5 3-hr Practicum) Culminating practicum requiring performance of duties and responsibilities of second year graduate athletic training students. A practical field experience in athletic training is required. Athletic Training majors only. A-F only. 611 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Athletic Training Clinical Practicum
description: (1 Sem, 5 4-hr Practicum) Advanced clinical practicum in which the BOC certified or certification eligible graduate student experiences an enhancement of athletic training knowledge and refinement of athletic training skills. Repeatable up to 10 credits. A-F only. consent.

title: Athletic Training Research Practicum
description: (1 Sem, 5 4-hr Practicum) Advanced research practicum in which the BOC certified or certification eligible graduate student deepens their understanding and enhances their critical thinking abilities in order to contribute to the advancement of the discipline and the athletic training profession. Repeatable four times, up to 12 credits. A-F only. consent.

title: (Alpha) Clinical Examination of Pathology
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Examination, care and treatment of musculoskeletal, neurological, and neuromuscular conditions and pathology; (B) lower body; (H) head, neck and spine; (U) upper body. Athletic Training majors only. A-F only.

title: Advanced Orthopedic Assessment
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Advanced knowledge and skills of athletic training as they are specifically applied to the understanding, treatment, and rehabilitation of sport-related injuries. (e.g. epidemiology, legal, ethical concerns, sports psychology, pharm, drug abuse, health issues) ANAT/KRS 604 or consent.

title: Therapeutic Interventions: Modalities
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Physiology principles and operational procedures of contemporary therapeutic modalities as they relate to the care and treatment of athletic injuries. Athletic Training majors only. (Fall only)

title: Therapeutic Interventions: Rehabilitative Exercise
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Concepts and principles of comprehensive rehabilitation programs (therapeutic goals and objectives, exercise selection, methods of evaluation and recording progress, progression and return to competition criteria, and physiological effects of tissue trauma and inactivity). Athletic Training majors only. (Spring only)

title: General Medical Conditions in Sports Medicine
description: An examination/evaluation of general medical conditions associated with sports medicine including pathology, care and treatment. Athletic Training majors only. PHYL 301, PHYL 302 or consent.

title: Seminar in Athletic Training
description: Designed to provide the student with analytical skills and practical experience relative to research as it applies to sports related injuries. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Advanced Therapeutic Exercise
description: Advanced concepts and evidence-based principles of rehabilitation programs. Enhancement of previously learned therapeutic exercise techniques and integration of therapeutic modalities and therapeutic exercise, including objective and functional goal setting and evaluation for appropriate progression and expedited return to activity. KRS majors only. 617 and 618 or basic therapeutic exercise and therapeutic modalities courses, or consent.
prerequisites: KRS 617 and KRS 618 or basic therapeutic exercise and therapeutic modalities courses, or consent

title: Athletic Training Capstone Experience
description: Capstone culminating experience preparing the student for the computer-based BOC Exam and for a career in athletic training. Follows the students’ didactic and clinical preparation in the 12 competency areas of athletic training. Repeatable one time. KRS majors only. A-F only. 611 or consent. Co-requisite: 612. (Spring only)

title: Administration in Kinesiology
description: Current problems, trends, and strategies in the administration of athletic training, physical education, recreation, sport and fitness programs in school and non-school settings. Repeatable one time. consent. (

title: Introduction to Community Counseling
description: Philosophy, organization, and function of community service agencies, programs, and institutions as related to professional work in counseling. consent.

title: Introduction to Practicum
description: -practicum training for supervised experiences in school, community, and human service organizations. Focus on the counseling relationship. Includes a specialty observation-participation field experience.
prerequisites: -practicum training for supervised experiences in school, community, and human service organizations

title: Career Development and Vocational Counseling
description: Theory and practice in career development and vocational counseling with individuals and groups; utilization of educational, vocational, and social resources in career counseling. consent.

title: Research in Evaluation in Counseling
description: Framework for understanding basic statistics, methodology, and evaluation of research in counseling and related fields. Students will analyze research, conceptualize research, and apply research to practice. consent.

title: Counseling: Group Theory and Practice
description: Theories and techniques of group counseling and guidance as preparation for practicum and internship. Application in school, college, rehabilitation, and community settings. 626 or 683, and 606, and consent.
prerequisites: KRS 626 or KRS 683, and KRS 606, and consent

title: Tests and Inventories in Guidance
description: Tests and inventories for the assessment of aptitudes, achievement, and interests. Applications to educational, instructional, and career guidance. consent.

title: Problems of School Adjustment
description: Principles of behavior affecting interpersonal relationships in school with emphasis on application to actual situations. consent.

title: Theory and Assessment of Intelligence
description: Theory and supervised experience in individual intelligence testing, psychological report writing; psychometric and social issues in intelligence testing. 630 and consent.

title: Crisis Intervention
description: Professional concerns about crisis intervention strategies, and counseling skills development. Crisis theory as applied to suicide, sexual assault/rape, natural and man-made disasters, personal loss, terminal illness, life cycle crisis, and the like. A-F only. 606 or consent.

title: Inclusive Physical Activity
description: Advanced knowledge on issues of socio-cultural, learning styles, diversity, and exceptionalities, and how these influence instruction, engagement, and behavior in physical activity settings across the lifespan. A-F only. consent. (

title: Elementary Physical Education
description: Content and pedagogy for teaching preschool/ elementary physical education. Students will learn appropriate content and pedagogy for learners in elementary school. Bit teaching and field experiences are included. A-F only. consent. (Once a year)

title: Theory and Assessment of Personality
description: Personality testing; practice in administration and use of personality assessment; examination of psychometric and social issues. 630 and consent.

title: Cross-Cultural Counseling
description: Significance of cultural factors in counseling relationships, delivery of counseling services in multicultural settings with attention to Hawai‘i. Emphasis on process of cultural learning and implications for counselor roles and functions. consent.

title: Seminar in Physical Activity
description: Trends, research, and problems related to physical activity across the lifespan. A variety of topics and contexts will be addressed. Enrolled in KRS graduate program only. A-F only. consent. (Spring only)

title: Seminar: Health/Exercise Science
description: Review of selected current literature in exercise/sport science and leisure studies. Practice of presentation in group setting.

title: Secondary Physical Education
description: Detailed examination of effective physical education curriculum and instruction in middle and high schools. Repeatable one time. A-F only. consent.

title: American College Student
description: Study of psychosocial characteristics of American college students and college environment, from viewpoint of student personnel work. consent.

title: Social Emotional Learning (SEL) Pedagogy and Practice
description: Introduces concepts, theories, and pedagogies of Social Emotional Learning (SEL), health and wellness, and trauma informed teaching with an emphasis on culture, social justice, and equity in Hawai‘i and our global community. A-F only. (Summer only) (

title: Sexuality & Health
description: Examines concepts, theories, and skills-based practices of sexuality and health. Topics on underserved populations, disability, reproductive health, family planning, and family health. Utilizes research-based curriculum/strategies to promote personal and social responsibility for health. (

title: Marriage, Family, and Child Counseling
description: Theory/practice of marriage, family, and child counseling, including major model in clinical practice; supervised counseling project by each student. Liability insurance required. 629 or consent.

title: Biomechanics of Human Motion
description: Principles of motion as applied to sport and physical rehabilitation. Introduction to the technology used in the analysis of motion. consent.

title: Physiology of Exercise
description: Physiological bases of modern physical training methods and sports science. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Metabolic Analysis
description: Theory and practice of metabolic analysis of human performance examining each of the power systems used in energy production during exercise and how to use this information to prescribe exercise programs. consent.

title: Advanced Fitness Assessment and Exercise Prescription
description: Provides knowledge of field and laboratory techniques and procedures for aerobic and anaerobic fitness assessment, interpretation of testing results and individual exercise program/ prescription techniques. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Body Composition and Weight Management
description: Analysis of the theory and practice used in the assessment of body composition and human physique. Includes strategies for implementing changes in body composition. consent.

title: Consultation: Theory and Practice
description: Consultation in educational, business, health, community, and human services agencies. consent.

title: Research Methods in KRS
description: The use of experimental designs/models in physical education research with emphasis on understanding the concepts, applications, and interpretations of statistical analysis. consent.

title: Assessment in Physical Activity
description: Overview of assessment purposes, types, practices and procedures used in physical education for those with disabilities. Frequently used motor assessments and practices in collection of data will be specifically addressed. A-F only. consent. (Spring only)

title: Transdisciplinary Approach to Teaching the Motor Domain
description: Highlights a trans-disciplinary approach for effectively teaching students with disabilities in the motor domain. Important characteristics and components of this approach will be shared. Strategies for its implementation will also be addressed. A-F only. consent.

title: Principles and Practice of Rehabilitation Counseling
description: Principles, practices of rehabilitation counseling; review of history and influence of legislation on vocational rehabilitation; current issues, developments, with emphasis on local situation. consent.

title: Medical and Psychosocial Aspects of Disability
description: Functional implications of chronic illnesses and disabilities on psychological, social and vocational areas of an individuals life. Case studies and presentations will stimulate discussion and help students to apply theoretical information into practical everyday context. 680 and consent.

title: Case Management in Rehabilitation
description: Knowledge and skills required in case and case-load management in public as well as private sector rehabilitation sites. Emphasis on professional/ client relationship, interviewing process, decision-making, goal-setting, recording/documentation, time management, and other tasks. 680 and consent.

title: Psychopathology in Counseling
description: Discussion-oriented course (potentially Web-based). Examination of theory and practice of diagnosis in the assessment and treatment of mental disorders and the use of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV) multi-axial system. Case studies will illustrate diagnostic issues. A-F only. 606 and consent.

title: Ethical Issues for the Helping Profession
description: Developing ethical reasoning capabilities for resolution of ethical dilemmas likely to be encountered in counseling, psychology, and specialty practices (e.g., community, rehabilitation, school, mental health, alcohol and substance abuse, marriage and family counseling, and the like). A-F only. 606 and consent.

title: Vocational Evaluation and Assessment in Rehabilitation
description: Theory, process, and techniques of vocational evaluation and assessment. Assessment methods and processes as they relate to vocational choice and adjustment of special groups. 681 and consent.

title: Assistive Technology in Rehabilitation Counseling
description: Study of application of assistive technologies to enhance the lives of people with disabilities. Case studies provide the vehicle in guiding students toward integration of available information into reality of actual situations. Special emphasis on the importance of using a consumer-centered approach in providing assistive technology services. A-F only. 681 and consent.

title: Theory and Techniques of Job Placement
description: Theory, process, and techniques of job readiness, job development, and job placement. 627 and consent.

title: Promoting Physical Activity
description: Overview of the theoretical and applied study of physical activity epidemiology. Physical activity content includes benefits, factors that influence, levels, valid instruments to assess, and programs to promote physical activity. (Fall only) (

title: Directed Reading and/or Research
description: Individual reading and/or research. Repeatable unlimited times. consent of instructor and department chair.
prerequisites: consent of instructor and department chair

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: (Alpha) Practicum in Counseling
description: Supervised clinical experience in counseling and guidance activities at an approved site, including a weekly class meeting. Provides practical application of formal academic training: (C) community service; (E) elementary; (H) secondary; (R) rehabilitation; (U) college. Each alpha is repeatable three times. 626 or 683, and consent.

title: Contemporary Issues in Counseling
description: Current issues and problems. (Meets EdD common required elective.) Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: (Alpha) Internship I
description: Supervised post-practicum experience in counseling and guidance activities at an approved site, including a weekly class meeting. Provides practical application of formal academic training: (C) community service; (E) elementary; (H) secondary; (R) rehabilitation; (U) college. Each alpha is repeatable three times. 703 and consent.

title: (Alpha) Internship II
description: Supervised post-internship I experience in counseling and guidance activities at an approved site, including a weekly class meeting. Provides practical application of formal academic training: (C) community service; (E) elementary; (H) secondary; (R) rehabilitation; (U) college. Each alpha is repeatable three times. A-F only. 733 and consent.

title: Seminar in School Counseling
description: In-depth study of professional concerns in school counseling. A-F only. 703 (E or H) and consent.

title: Seminar in Community Counseling
description: In-depth study of professional concerns in community counseling. A-F only. 703C and consent.

title: Seminar in College Counseling
description: In-depth study of professional concerns in college counseling. A-F only. 703U and consent.

title: Doctoral Seminar and Research I in Kinesiology
description: Provide the PhD student the opportunity to assume the role of director of a research project under the supervision of the faculty mentor. The research project will represent a piece of the ongoing line of research of the faculty mentor. Responsibilities will be comparable of a project director of research funded by a research grant. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. KRS majors only. CR/NC only. 776 or consent.

title: Doctoral Seminar and Research II in Kinesiology
description: Provide the PhD student the opportunity to be involved in research, under the direction of the faculty mentor, as the assistant project director and as the project director for pilot studies. Student will gain experience in these roles with close supervision by the faculty mentor. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. KRS majors only. CR/NC only. 775 or consent.

title: Doctoral Seminar and Research III in Kinesiology
description: Provide the PhD student the opportunity to assume the role of director of a research project under the supervision of the faculty mentor. The research project will represent a piece of the ongoing line of research of the faculty mentor. Responsibilities will be comparable of a project director of research funded by a research grant. Repeatable three times or up to 12 credits. KRS majors only. CR/NC only. 776 or consent.

title: Doctoral Seminar IV in Kinesiology
description: Designed to enable PhD students to gain a perspective of the discipline, both historically and philosophically, prepare them for the issues they may face in the real world, particularly higher education and help them initiate their dissertation. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. KRS majors only. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Seminar in Rehabilitation Counseling
description: In-depth study of professional concerns in rehabilitation counseling. A-F only. 703R and consent.

title: Islands/Islas/Ilhas and Global Exchange
description: Cross-cultural study of global issues of navigation, commerce, and the environment, as expressed by the arts, traditions, and narratives from 1492 to the present. Connections with Europe, Africa, Americas, Asia, Oceania. Oceania.

title: Vaqueros, Gauchos, Paniolo: Cowboy Legacies of the Americas and Hawai‘i
description: Histories and traditions (literature, music, dance, poetry, food, fashion) of the Hispanic cowboy, Americas to Hawai‘i. Examines symbolic interpretations of the vaquero concerning nation and identity, and the material consequences of ranching (colonialism, commerce, environment). Sophomore standing or higher, or consent.

title: Chocolate Tales & Culinary Cultures: Latin America to Hawai‘i
description: Traces evolution of uses, meanings, and cultural representations of chocolate and other food native to Latin America. Emphasis on how narratives of food and food practices engage with national, ethnic, social, and gender identity constructions. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent.

title: (Alpha) Studies in Culture
description: Politics of culture and representation. Will consider issues, traditions, movements, texts, and cultural icons for their significance for national and regional identity formation, intercultural relations and global flows of images, people, and capital. (B) Latin America; (C) Iberian Peninsula. sophomore or consent.

title: U.S. Latino Culture and Literature
description: The culture and history of U.S. Latinos through an analysis of their literature and arts and their sociopolitical relationship to the U.S. mainstream culture. sophomore standing or consent.

title: Spanish Film
description: A chronological survey of films from Spain, from the Silent Era to the present. Conceptually, a cultural history of Spain in the 20th century, as seen through films. sophomore standing or consent.

title: Latin American Film
description: A survey of films from Latin America, the Silent Era to the present, and their representation of the cultural history of the region. Develops written communication skills. sophomore standing or consent.

title: Households in Cross-Cultural Perspectives: Home, Hale, Casa
description: Study of cross-cultural patterns in household and community level organizations in Latin America and elsewhere. Topics may include gender relations, kinship structures, political economy, impacts of colonialism, modernization, and globalization on households. Sophomore standing or higher. (

title: (Alpha) Indigenous Peoples of Latin America
description: Survey of the history and culture of the indigenous peoples of Latin America through a study of their literature, texts and practices. (B) Mesoamerica; (C) Andean South America. Repeatable one time for different alphas. sophomore standing or consent. (

title: Studies in Culture: Portugal and Brazil
description: Surveys the cultures of the Portuguese-speaking world from -Lusitanian times, including connections with Africa, Asia, the U.S., and Hawai‘i. sophomore standing or consent.
prerequisites: -Lusitanian times, including connections with Africa, Asia, the U

title: Asians and Pacific Islanders in Latin America
description: Survey of the history and culture of Asian, Polynesian, and Pacific Islander communities in Latin America. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Colonial Latin American History
description: -Columbian civilizations: Spanish and Portuguese colonization; political, economic, social and religious evolution to 1810; independence. 360 or consent. (
prerequisites: -Columbian civilizations: Spanish and Portuguese colonization; political, economic, social and religious evolution to LAIS 1810; independence

title: New World Rituals and Ideologies
description: Study of cross-cultural patterns in ritual behaviors and creolization of African, indigenous, and Iberian ideological frameworks in the Americas. Topics may include syncretic religions (voodoo, candomble), Andean Christianity, spiritual conquest, conceptions of death, etc. Sophomore standing or higher. Minimum C- required grade for 360, or consent. (Fall only) (

title: (Alpha) Topics in Latin American and Iberian Studies
description: Combined lecture-discussion on political, social, cultural themes of Iberia and Latin America; (B) Aztlán, Quetzalcóatl, Pachamama; (C) Luso-Hispanic pop culture. Repeatable one time for different alphas. 360 or LAIS 363 or LAIS 368 or LAIS 372 or LAIS 380, and SPAN 351, and SPAN 352; or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: LAIS 360 or LAIS 363 or LAIS 368 or LAIS 372 or LAIS 380, and SPAN 351, and SPAN 352; or consent

title: Hispanic Cultural Studies
description: Critical overview of contemporary theories on Hispanic culture. Issues of identity such as mestizaje, hybridity, and pluralism will be discussed from a hemispheric perspective. consent.

title: Death and Dying in Literature and Film
description: Exploration of death and dying in literature and film as manifested across time and cultures throughout the world. Analysis of narratives from ancient times to the modern era from multiple theoretical and cross-cultural perspectives.

title: Directed Language Study
description: Study in European languages not taught regularly, depending on demand and staff. consent of department chair.

title: Italian Film
description: Study of Italian film history and technique. A-F only.

title: French Film
description: Study of French film history and technique. A-F only. freshman standing.

title: Gods, Heroes, and Dragons: Germanic Myth, Legends, and Fairy Tales
description: Study of Germanic myth, legends, and fairy tales. Analysis of narratives from ancient times to the modern era from multiple theoretical perspectives.

title: French Culture for Americans
description: Study of the shared cultural and historical foundations of France and the U.S. both past and present. A-F only.

title: Freaks and Monsters
description: Monsters, freaks and otherness in literature, film, history and medicine. Suitable for non-literature majors.

title: German Cinema
description: Study of German film history, film theory, film analysis, and film style. Repeatable one time or take GER 320 one time for different topics. 6 cr. limit on GER/LLEA 320 courses. Sophomore standing only.

title: Italian Literature as Film
description: Exploration of the distinction between literature and film as artistic genres as well as study of major works of literature in respect to the present, from the Middle Ages through the 20th century. A-F only. sophomore standing or consent.

title: French Literature Since 1800
description: Rapid reading in translation; lectures, discussions, reports. junior standing or one course in French language or literature.
prerequisites: junior standing or one course in French language or literature

title: French African Literature
description: Black African literature in French in 20th century. Major themes of negritude, national political unity, colonialism, traditional culture. junior standing or one course in French language or literature.
prerequisites: junior standing or one course in French language or literature

title: Topics in Italian Literature in Translation
description: Introduction to Italian literature in translation, with varying topics in different iterations. Repeatable one time. Sophomore standing or consent.

title: French Literature as Film
description: Exploration of the distinction between literature and film as artistic genres as well as study of major works of literature in respect to the present, from the Middle Ages through the 20th century. sophomore standing.

title: Classical German Literature
description: Readings in translation from dramatic works of Lessing, Goethe, Schiller. Philosophic and aesthetic views of leading writers of the Enlightenment, Storm and Stress, and classical periods.

title: German Opera and Literature
description: Introduction to German opera, its history, and analysis. Developing critical skills through analysis of German opera music and literature. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent.

title: German Fascism and Propaganda
description: Study of German Fascism and propaganda in German literature, art, film, and associated ethical issues. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Russian Short Story
description: Origin and development (19th and 20th century); periods, themes, styles, and major authors. sophomore standing or consent.

title: 19th-Century Russian Literature
description: Survey in English of major writers from Pushkin through Chekhov; lectures, discussions, short papers. sophomore standing or consent.

title: Russian Literature 1900–1950
description: Study of significant works of twentieth century Russian literature with particular focus on its relationship to Europe and Asia. Students will work intensively on their own writing and research in close collaboration with their instructor. sophomore standing or consent.

title: Russia: Between Europe & Asia
description: Russian culture (literature, film, theater, music, arts, etc.) as an amalgam of European and Asian traditions and its impact on the world throughout history; develops written communication skills. sophomore standing or consent.

title: Russia: Faces of Asia
description: Survey in English of 19th-21st century representations of Asia in the contexts of the Russian Empire, the Soviet Union, and post-Soviet space. sophomore standing or consent.

title: Russian Film
description: A study of Russian film from the 1920’s to the present. sophomore standing or consent.

title: Survey of French Civilizations
description: A historical survey of the development of French and Francophone cultures. The course is interdisciplinary, dealing with politics, music, art, other forms of cultural expression, and daily life.

title: Europeans in the Pacific
description: European presence in the Pacific, in relation to literature, art, culture, civilization. Not applicable to language requirement.

title: Teaching Practicum in Large Lecture Courses
description: Supervised undergraduate teaching practicum in large-lecture LLEA courses. Repeatable two times. CR/NC only. completion of course in which practicum will be done and consent of instructor, no waiver.
prerequisites: completion of course in which practicum will be done and consent of instructor, no waiver

title: (Alpha) European and Latin American Cinema
description: Study of major developments in European and Latin American cinema studies focusing on a specific area. (B) Topic; (C) Genre; (D) Director; (E) Era. Sophomore standing or higher. Repeatable one time for different alphas.

title: Directed Reading
description: limited to senior majors with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or a minimum GPA of 3.0 in major, and consent of department chair.
prerequisites: limited to senior majors with a minimum cumulative GPA of LLEA 2

title: Culture of Two Germanies: 1945-1989
description: (taught in English) Literature, culture, and film of East and West Germany, 1945-1989. Credit cannot be earned for both LLEA 415 and GER 415. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: German Literature, Culture and Film: 1989 to Present
description: Study of German literature, culture and film, 1989 to present. Credit cannot be earned for both 416 and GER 416. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Learning and Teaching World Languages
description: Hybrid technology intensive course for - or in-service teachers of world languages. Topics: online learning, curriculum and lesson planning, assessment, language teaching approaches, technology for learning world languages. Junior standing or higher. (
prerequisites: - or in-service teachers of world languages

title: Freaks and Monsters 2: The Ethics of Otherness
description: An interdisciplinary examination of corporeal Otherness. Unusual real and fictional bodies from fairground history, art, anatomy, literature, natural history and ethnology. Discussion of the moral, medical, philosophical and aesthetic dilemmas of spectacular difference. 270 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Fantasy and the Fantastic
description: Cross-cultural study of fantasy and the fantastic in short stories, fairy tales, films and novels from Europe and the Americas in English translation. Discussion of illusion, identity, time, the future, the bizarre and major concepts in fantasy literature. (B) fairies, devils and fantasy; (C) the fantastic, the strange and science fiction. Repeatable one time in different alphas. 270 or consent.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Independent study of approved reading and research with faculty supervision. Repeatable two times. A-F only. consent and departmental approval.

title: Seminar in Research Methods
description: Study of basic research methods and tools, including technology. Print and electronic source materials. Information literacy. A-F only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Western Literature and Cultures in the Pacific
description: Impact of and reaction to western writings and cultural influences in the Pacific as represented in texts from the 16th century to the present. graduate standing or consent.

title: (Alpha) Topics in Literature
description: Study in English of a topic, period, or genre; aesthetic considerations common to European literatures: (B) the modern novel; (C) European literature as a path to self-knowledge; (D) Middle Ages; (E) introduction to literary theory. MA candidates in European languages read works in their major in the original. graduate standing or consent of department chair.
prerequisites: graduate standing or consent of department chair

title: (Alpha) Topics in Language
description: Study in English of topics, periods, etc., in the languages taught in the department: (B) comparison of Romance languages; (C) interpersonal communication; (D) social perspectives. Repeatable two times for different alphas (up to 9 credits). graduate standing or consent.

title: Masterpieces of Medieval Welsh Literature
description: Key prose and poetry underlying the Arthurian tradition in Europe. Language instruction leading to reading knowledge of medieval Welsh. consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent of department chair.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Elementary Portuguese
description: Conversation, grammar and reading.

title: Elementary Portuguese
description: Conversation, grammar and reading. Continuation of 101. 101.

title: Intensive Elementary Portugese
description: Intensive elementary Portuguese course covers content of 101 and 102 combined. Hybrid format combines 3 credits online and 3 credits face to face. HSL. (Fall only)

title: Intermediate Portuguese
description: Reading, conversation, writing, laboratory drill. 102 or 103.

title: Intermediate Portuguese
description: Continuation of 201. 201.

title: Intensive Intermediate Portuguese
description: Intensive Intermediate Portuguese course covers content of 201 and 202 combined. Hybrid format combines 3 credits online and 3 credits face to face. 102 or 103. (Spring only)

title: Conversation
description: Intensive practice in spoken Portuguese, focusing on the preparation and completion of oral tasks and presentations. 40% or more of the grade is based on 3-4 oral communication presentations. 202.

title: Third-Level Portuguese Abroad
description: Intensive, formal instruction at the third-year level in Portuguese language: reading, writing, pronunciation, grammar, or conversation in a Portuguese-speaking country. Repeatable one time. 202.

title: Fourth-Level Portuguese Abroad
description: Intensive formal instruction at the fourth-year level in Portuguese language, linguistics, culture, civilization, film, or literature in a Portuguese-speaking country. Repeatable one time. 360.

title: Elementary Russian
description: Conversation, reading, writing, grammar.

title: Elementary Russian
description: Continuation of 101. 101 or consent.

title: Intermediate Russian
description: Reading, conversation, grammar, composition. 102 or consent.

title: Intermediate Russian
description: Continuation of 201. 201 or consent.

title: Russian Phonetics
description: Basic theory of Russian sound system; practice in pronunciation, intonation, and fluency. 102 or 201 (or concurrent).

title: Intensive Intermediate Russian Abroad
description: Intensive course of formal instruction on the second-year level in Russian language and culture in Russia. 102.

title: Advanced Russian
description: Systematic practice for control of spoken and written Russian, vocabulary building, fluency in various subjects, accuracy in sentence structure, phrasing stylistic appropriateness. 202.

title: Advanced Russian
description: Continuation of 303.

title: Russian Structure
description: Advanced grammar; complexities of standard contemporary Russian; word formation and verb system. 202 or consent.

title: Readings in Russian Civilization and Literature
description: Mid-level readings in Russian civilization and literature of edited and adapted texts. 202.

title: Readings in Russian Civilization and Literature
description: Continuation of 311. 311.

title: Intensive Third-Level Russian Abroad
description: Intensive course of formal instruction on the third-year level in Russian language and culture in Russia. 202 or 260.

title: Directed Reading
description: Independent study of approved reading with faculty supervision. Repeatable two times or up to six credits. A-F only. 202 and consent and departmental approval.
prerequisites: RUS 202 and consent and departmental approval

title: Advanced Conversation and Composition
description: Systematic practice on selected topics; vocabulary building and development of fluency; writing short reports, narratives. 304 or consent.

title: Advanced Conversation and Composition
description: Continuation of 403. 403.

title: Advanced Reading and Translation: Modern Prose
description: Readings in various fields, emphasizing idiomatic usage. 312 or consent.

title: Advanced Reading of Russian Press
description: Materials from Soviet/Russian newspapers and magazines. 311 or consent.

title: Russian Folklore
description: Selected Russian folk narratives, bylinas, songs, and proverbs. Influence of folklore on major Russian authors. 312 or consent.

title: Russian Short Story
description: Origin and development (19th and 20th century); the major writers. three years of Russian or consent.
prerequisites: three years of Russian or consent

title: Russian Novel
description: Origin and development from 18th century to present. three years of Russian language or consent.
prerequisites: three years of Russian language or consent

title: Topics in 19th- and 20th-Century Russian Literature
description: Focus upon the selected writings of one major Russian writer of the 19th century (e.g., Pushkin, Gogol, Lermontov, Dostoevsky, or Tolstoy) or 20th century (e.g., Bely, Blok, Bulgakov, Chekhov, Pasternak, Sholokhov, or Solzhenitsyn). Repeatable unlimited times with consent. 312, LLEA 351; or consent.

title: Topics in 19th- and 20th-Century Russian Literature
description: Continuation of 451. 312, LLEA 352, or consent.

title: Intensive Fourth-Level Russian Abroad
description: Intensive advanced courses of formal instruction on the fourth-year level in Russian language and culture in Russia. 360 or equivalent.

title: Seminar
description: Literary or linguistic topics, movements, genres, or their representatives. Repeatable unlimited times with consent. consent of chair.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Independent study of approved reading with faculty supervision. Repeatable up to six credits. A-F only. 303 (or equivalent), consent or departmental approval.
prerequisites: RUS 303 (or equivalent), consent or departmental approval

title: Elementary Spanish
description: Conversation, grammar, reading.

title: Elementary Spanish
description: Conversation, grammar, reading. 101.

title: Intensive Elementary Spanish
description: Course content of SPAN 101 and 102 covered in one semester. Three two-hour sessions per week.

title: Intermediate Spanish
description: Continuation of oral practice and grammar study; increasing emphasis on reading and written composition. 102 or 103.

title: Intermediate Spanish II
description: Continuation of 201. Oral practice and grammar study; increasing emphasis on reading and written composition. 201 or 258.

title: Intensive Spanish for Business
description: SPAN 201 and 202 content combined, oriented to business Spanish. Three 50-minute sessions per week plus online work. 102 or 103.

title: Intermediate Spanish Abroad
description: Intensive course of full-time formal instruction on the second-year level in Spanish language and culture in a Spanish-speaking country. 102 or 103.

title: Intermediate Spanish Abroad
description: Continuation of 258.

title: Legends, Stories, and Current Events
description: Development of language skills through reading of literary and cultural texts. 202 (or concurrent) or 203 or 259.
prerequisites: SPAN 202 (or concurrent) or SPAN 203 or SPAN 259

title: Language and Writing I
description: Improvement of Spanish vocabulary, language accuracy, and expression of ideas in Spanish through writing. 202 or 203 or 259, or consent.
prerequisites: SPAN 202 or SPAN 203 or SPAN 259, or consent

title: Conversation I
description: Intensive practice in spoken Spanish, focusing on the preparation and completion of oral tasks and presentations. 202 or 259, or consent.

title: Conversation II
description: Continuation of 303. 303 or consent.

title: Introduction to Spanish-English Translation
description: Practical introduction to written Spanish-English translation through the translations of texts from Spanish to English and the reverse. Includes an emphasis on composition and style. 301 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Spanish in Use
description: Spanish language as used in specific professions; (B) marketing, tourism & business; (C) health & public safety. Sophomore standing or higher. 301, or consent.

title: Introduction to Spanish-English Interpreting
description: Students will begin to develop the listening and memory skills for direct and inverse interpretation. Sophomore standing or higher. 301 or 310, or consent

title: From Comics to Classics
description: Introduction and development of Spanish skills for critical reading and writing, rhetoric, and vocabulary. Choices with particular emphasis on literary analysis and academic writing. Online course. 301 or consent.

title: Phonetics and Pronunciation Practice
description: Analysis of the Spanish phonological system, in contrast with English. Practice in pronunciation. 301 or 310, or consent.

title: Spain: Traditions & Trending
description: Survey of the history and cultures of Spain. 301 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Latin American Cultural Studies
description: Survey of the history, traditions, and cultures of Latin America; (B) empires and traditions; (C) nations, identity & the arts. Repeatable one time for other topics, but not for the same topic. 301 or consent

title: Third-Level Spanish Abroad
description: Intensive formal instruction at the third-year level in Spanish language skills: reading, writing, grammar, or conversation in a Spanish-speaking country. 202 or 259 or equivalent.

title: Third-Level Spanish Abroad
description: Continuation of 358.

title: Intensive Third-Level Spanish Abroad
description: Intensive formal instruction at the third-year level in Spanish language skills: reading, writing, grammar, or conversation in a Spanish-speaking country. 202 or equivalent

title: (Alpha) Reading Spain
description: Reading and discussion of narratives from and about Spain; (B) heroines, knights, witches; (C) love, loss, liberty. Repeatable one time for different alphas. Sophomore standing or higher. 301, or consent.

title: (Alpha) Reading Latin America
description: Culture and history of Spanish America through literature; (B) warriors, nuns, and rebels; (C) the magical and the real. Repeatable one time for different alphas. Sophomore standing or higher. 301, or consent.

title: Introduction to Hispanic Film
description: Introduction to the study and analysis of genres, techniques, and cinematic styles as used in Hispanic film. 301 or consent.

title: Directed Reading
description: Independent study of approved reading with faculty supervision. Repeatable two times. A-F only. 301 (or concurrent), consent and departmental approval.
prerequisites: SPAN 301 (or concurrent), consent and departmental approval

title: Spanish Language in Society
description: Explores issues in Spanish language in society (media, communication, advertising, government, technology). Introduces and examines current sociolinguistic and sociopragmatic issues. 330 or consent.

title: Building Advanced Fluency
description: Advanced practice; emphasis on building active vocabulary. 301 or consent.

title: Spanish-English Translation
description: Factors in the art of translation. Practice in translating material from Spanish to English and the reverse. 305 or consent.

title: Historical Spanish Linguistics
description: Evolution of Spanish from Latin; modern social and geographical dialects. 330 or consent.

title: Introduction to Spanish Linguistics
description: Analysis of morphology, syntax, and semantics. 330 or consent.

title: Fourth-Level Spanish Abroad
description: Intensive course of full-time formal instruction on the fourth-year level in Spanish linguistics, civilization, culture, and literature in a Spanish-speaking country. any two of 301; 303, 358, 359, or 360.
prerequisites: any two of SPAN 301; SPAN 303, SPAN 358, SPAN 359, or SPAN 360

title: Fourth-Level Spanish Abroad
description: Continuation of 458.

title: Intensive Fourth-Level Spanish Abroad
description: Intensive course of formal instruction on the fourth-year level in Spanish language and culture in a Spanish-speaking country. For semester programs only. 360 or equivalent.

title: U.S. Latino Literature
description: Study of the literature of U.S. Hispanics written in Spanish or bilingually. 320, 361, or 371; or consent.
prerequisites: SPAN 320, SPAN 361, or SPAN 371; or consent

title: Hispanic Women’s Literature
description: Women’s literary and cultural expressions in Latin America and Spain. one of 320, 361, or 371; or consent.
prerequisites: one of SPAN 320, SPAN 361, or SPAN 371; or consent

title: Hispanic Theater
description: Study of representative authors and plays from Spain and Latin America. Repeatable one time. one of 361, 362, 371, or 372; or consent.
prerequisites: one of SPAN 361, SPAN 362, SPAN 371, or SPAN 372; or consent

title: (Alpha) Topics in Hispanic Scholarship
description: Hispanic authors, periods, or themes. (B) literature and society; (D) literature and film. Repeatable for other topics, but not for the same topic. 320, 361, or 371; or consent.
prerequisites: SPAN 320, SPAN 361, or SPAN 371; or consent

title: Studies in Latin American and Iberian Film
description: Intensive study of selected topics in Latin American and/or Iberian cinemas; e.g. national or regional cinemas, periods, movements or issues, major filmmakers, film theory and criticism. Repeatable two times. 320, 361, 371, or 396; or consent.
prerequisites: SPAN 320, SPAN 361, SPAN 371, or SPAN 396; or consent

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Independent study of approved readings and research with faculty supervision. A-F only. Repeatable two times. consent of instructor and departmental approval.
prerequisites: consent of instructor and departmental approval

title: Spanish Translation Studies
description: Study of social, cultural, and pragmatic issues in Spanish Translation Studies. Graduate students only. consent. (Alt. years)

title: Seminar in Spanish Applied Linguistics
description: Repeatable unlimited times with consent. graduate standing or consent.

title: Topics in Spanish Applied Linguistics
description: Supervised participation in online course at UNED University (Spain) relevant to student’s specialization for Second Language Studies or Spanish Applied Linguistics. Students also complete projects and meet with advisor to check progress. Repeatable two times for different topics. Graduate students only. Spanish Proficiency assessment: B- (CERFL) or Advanced low (ACTFL).
prerequisites: Spanish Proficiency assessment: B- (CERFL) or Advanced low (ACTFL)

title: Medieval Spanish Literature
description: Representative readings in prose and poetry, from origins through 15th century. graduate standing or consent.

title: (Alpha) Golden Age Literature
description: Spanish literature from the 16th and 17th centuries. (B) theater; (C) prose; (D) poetry; (E) Cervantes. graduate standing.

title: 19th-Century Spanish Realism
description: Nineteenth-century Spanish realism in the novel. Authors include Galdós, Clarin, Alarcón, Pardo Bazán, Blasco-Ibáñez, Valera. graduate standing or consent.

title: (Alpha) 20th-Century Spanish Literature
description: Representative works from 20th-century literature. Genres: poetry, theater, essay, novel. (B) generation of 1898; (C) -Civil War; (D) post-Civil War. graduate standing or consent.

title: Spanish-American Novel
description: Critical analysis of major Spanish-American novels. graduate standing or consent.

title: Colonial Spanish-American Literature
description: Spanish-American literature from period of discovery to independence. Representative authors such as Sor Juana, Bernal Díaz del Castillo. graduate standing or consent.

title: Spanish-American Poetry
description: Study of representative poets from all periods: Martí, Darió, Mistral, Guillén, Neruda, Paz, etc. graduate standing or consent.

title: Spanish-American Short Story and Essay
description: Study of representative writers from various periods: Sor Juana, Palma, Quiroga, Reyes, Borges, etc. graduate standing or consent.

title: Seminar in Hispanic Literature
description: A period, author, genre, or region. Repeatable unlimited times with consent. graduate standing or consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent of department chair.

title: Elementary Latin
description: Grammar and vocabulary, with reading of simple Latin.

title: Elementary Latin
description: Continuation of 101. 101.

title: Intermediate Latin
description: Development of reading and translation skills. Emphasis on prose. 102 or equivalent.

title: Intermediate Latin
description: Continuation of 201: emphasis on poetry. 201.

title: Roman Historians
description: Selections from Caesar, Sallust, and others. 201 and 202, or consent.

title: Roman Epic
description: Selections from Virgil, Ovid, and others. 201 and 202, or consent.

title: Roman Philosophy
description: Selections from Lucretius, Cicero, and Seneca. 201 and 202, or consent.

title: Roman Drama
description: Selections from Plautus, Terence, and Seneca. 201 and 202, or consent.

title: Roman Lyric
description: Selections from Catullus, Horace, and others. 201 and 202, or consent.

title: Roman Novel
description: Selections from Petronius and Apuleius. 201 and 202, or consent.

title: Roman Satire
description: Selections from Horace and Juvenal. 201 and 202, or consent.

title: Seminar in Roman Studies
description: Study of an author or phase in Roman studies. Repeatable unlimited times with consent. any two 300-level LATN courses, or consent.
prerequisites: any two LATN 300-level LATN courses, or consent

title: Exchange Student Program
description: Designed for students accepted to participate in an exchange program while enrolled at William S. Richardson School of Law. Must obtain prior approval for the transfer credits. LAW majors only. CR/NC only.

title: Organizing for Social Change
description: Examines conditions that lead people to become active, self-governing agents. Covered are strategies and tactics of organizers, history of social change movements, anti-subordination theories of justice and organizing case studies.

title: Historic Preservation Law
description: Introduction to the protection of cultural, archaeological, and historical resources with emphasis on key federal and state laws. (Once a year) (

title: Lawyering Fundamentals I
description: Comprehensive program that teaches students the analytical and presentational skills necessary for excellent legal writing. Introduces students to legal problem solving and writing through the types of documents lawyers prepare in practice.

title: Lawyering Fundamentals II
description: A comprehensive program that teaches students the analytical and presentational skills necessary for excellent legal writing. Introduces skills and strategies for preparing written legal arguments and oral advocacy. 504.

title: Contracts
description: Law of private agreements. Focuses on common law doctrines with some attention to key Uniform Commercial Code provisions. Examines the bases of promissory liability, contract formation, defenses to enforcement, contract interpretation, breach, and remedies. (Fall only)

title: Employment Discrimination
description: A study of the law of employment discrimination.

title: Negotiation and Alternative Dispute Resolution
description: Lawyers negotiate settlements in almost all their cases. This class presents a “hands-on,” skill-building approach to the newest ideas, as well as centuries-old techniques, about the skill lawyers will use most often in their private practice- negotiation. The class also examines the rapidly developing field of alternative dispute resolution (ADR), including mediation, facilitation, arbitration, and court-annexed ADR. (

title: Contracts I
description: Law of private agreements. Explores the evolution and application of common law doctrines, and, where applicable, relevant provisions of the Uniform Commercial Code. Examines the bases of promissory liability, contract formation, mutual assent, defenses to enforcement, excuses, remedies and damages, and the rights and interests of third parties. Attention will be paid throughout the course to the role of contracts in a market society and the conflicting interests of certainty, freedom of contract and fairness.

title: Contracts II
description: Continuation of 509.

title: Professional Responsibility
description: Introductory consideration of selected topics relating to functions, structure, and responsibilities of the legal profession and its future role in society.

title: Reparations and Reconciliation
description: Seminar addresses a legally and socially important contemporary issue-healing present-day wounds of historic injustice. Considers how to repair the continuing social damage of injustice. (Once a year)

title: Criminal Law
description: Examination of substantive rules, enforcement procedures, and rationales of criminal law in the U.S.

title: Children, Parents and the Law
description: Exploration of fundamental concepts of law relating to children, ethical issues, and the role of lawyers in assisting children, and how the child’s rights and obligations are balanced with those of parents and state. (Once a year)

title: Business Reorganization in Bankruptcy
description: Examination of the rights and remedies available to a failing business and its creditors when the business seeks to reorganize its business and financial affairs under chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code. The course is structured as a “practicum,” which tracks a single business through restructuring and emphasizes the practical and strategic aspects of lawyering. Recommended: 562.

title: Civil Procedure I
description: Study of -trial, trial, and appellate procedures in the federal and Hawai‘i courts.
prerequisites: -trial, trial, and appellate procedures in the federal and Hawai‘i courts

title: Civil Procedure II
description: Continuation of 516. 516.

title: Real Property I
description: Basic course in property ownership, development, regulation. Emphasis on theory.

title: Real Property II
description: Contract of sale, equitable conversion, deed. 518.

title: Advanced Legal Studies
description: Faculty members or visiting scholars present selected topics focusing upon subject areas in their area of specialty or expertise. (B) business law; (C) Constitutional law; (D) criminal law; (E) critical legal; (F) education law; (G) health law; (H) intellectual property law; (I) practice of law; (J) public interest law; (K) topic 10; (M) topic 11; (N) topic 12; (O) topic 13; (P) topic 14; (Q) topic 15; (R) topic 16; (S) topic 17; (T) topic 18; (V) topic 19; (W) topic 20; (X) topic 21; (Y) topic 22; (Z) topic 23. LAW majors only for (X-Z). Alphas B-Q repeatable three times, up to 12 credits; alphas R-Z repeatable three times, up to 16 credits.

title: Law, Aging and Medicine
description: Introduction to basic legal issues at the intersection of law, aging and medicine. Addresses various issues confronting elderly; issues confronting the general population including health care financing, decision-making, and bioethics.

title: Torts
description: Torts cover the statutory and common law of negligence, causation, defenses, damages, strict liability, intentional torts and tort policy and reform, with emphasis on national and Hawai‘i law.

title: Law and Psychology
description: Approaches psychology as a problem solving tool that can facilitate legal analysis. Covers a variety of areas including jury decision-making, research methodology, social cognition, culture, and behavioral economics, among others. (Once a year)

title: Advanced Torts and Insurance Law
description: Advanced study of several areas of tort law and an introduction to insurance law and policy. This course is of considerable importance to students interested in civil litigation and personal injury law. Recent important developments in Hawai‘i tort and insurance law will be included.

title: Legislation and Statutory Interpretation
description: The interrelationship between the legislative and judicial branches of government is explored through a review of Federal and Hawai‘i law-making processes, direct democracy, legislative drafting, and theories of the legislative process and statutory interpretation.

title: Group Directed Study
description: Designed for maximum flexibility, this course allows a professor to work with a small number of students on a reading/ discussion project of mutual interest. Repeatable up to 15 credits. consent.

title: Federal Indian Law
description: Examines Federal Indian Law, including fundamental concepts and the historical evolution of legal doctrines. Considers the implications of Native Hawaiian sovereignty within the framework of Federal Indian Law. (Once a year)

title: Second-Year Seminar
description: Seminar required for spring semester of all second-year law students. Substantial paper required. Topics announced in previous fall semester. Placement by lottery.

title: Business Associations
description: After a brief survey of agency, partnerships, and other forms of business organization, the course will cover the fundamentals of corporations, and securities regulation, including disregarding the corporate entity, management and control of closely held corporations, merger, liability under the federal securities laws, takeovers, public registration, exemptions, and derivative suits.

title: Health Law
description: Introduction to medical jurisprudence, medical malpractice, informed consent, health care decisions, medical ethics, the health care industry, managed care, financing health care, and the role of government in health care. LAW majors only; NURS DNP majors only (

title: Constitutional Law I
description: Introduction to judicial function in constitutional cases, jurisdiction of the U.S. Supreme Court, and discretionary barriers to judicial review.

title: Constitutional Law II
description: Advanced course in constitutional law with special emphasis on rights secured by the First, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution of the U.S. 533.

title: Intellectual Property
description: A study of the law relating to property rights resulting from intellectual effort, including patents, copyright, trademarks, and trade secrets.

title: Conflict of Laws
description: Problems respecting the law applicable in transactions or to relationships with elements in more than one state.

title: Equitable Remedies
description: Examines both practice aspects and theoretical underpinnings of equitable remedies. Frequently, compensatory damages cannot adequately protect clients or provide them with the relief they need. Topics include temporary restraining orders, preliminary and permanent injunctions, restitution and unjust enrichment, specific performance, and equitable defenses such as unclean hands, laches, and estoppel. Practice issues concerning appeal, jury trials, and the relationship of equity to law are also explored. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Contract Drafting
description: Hands-on workshop class in drafting contracts, agreement, and similar documents for commercial/business purposes. LAW majors only. 506, or 509 and 510.

title: Criminal Procedure
description: Issues of free press and fair trial, illegal search and seizure, arrest and confession, speedy trial, double jeopardy are covered through student interactions as defense or prosecution attorneys and as judges.

title: Advanced Civil Procedure
description: Addresses various aspects of complex litigation and recent criticism of the civil litigation system itself. Theoretical in emphasis.

title: Evidence
description: “Objection, your Honor!” This course examines the rules of evidence that govern trials in both federal and Hawai‘i courts and will focus on such topics as hearsay, witness examination, impeachment, physical and demonstrative evidence, expert testimony, writings, relevance, judicial notice, and presumptions.

title: Race, Culture, and Law
description: U.S. cases and legal theory emphasizing law in the social construction of racial categories, shifts in race-based anti-discrimination law, and the interaction of culture and law in judicial decision-making.

title: Licensing Intellectual Property
description: Theory and practice of the law relating to the transfer of rights in information and other intangibles are examined together with end user license agreements and the structure and negotiation of upstream licensing mechanisms. Repeatable up to three credits. 535 or departmental approval. (Once a year)

title: (Alpha) Intercession-J Term
description: January term provides students the opportunity to explore contemporary legal topics with national and international experts. (B) alternative dispute resolution; (C) rule of law; (D) law practice; (E) diversity; (F) access to justice; (G) public law; (H) legal theory; (I) legal practice; (J) rights. Repeatable five times. (Once a year)

title: Gender: Law and Conflicts
description: Examines how international law and domestic legal systems address and resolve conflicts regarding women’s rights, gender roles, and gender identity. Takes a comparative approach with emphasis on the Asia-Pacific region. (

title: Immigration Law
description: Introduction to U.S. Immigration and Nationality Law: a brief overview of historical development of immigration law; analysis of exclusion and deportation grounds and remedies; the study of both immigrant and nonimmigrant visa applications and petitions. Current law on asylum and refugee applications and U.S. citizenship and naturalization requirements.

title: Admiralty Law
description: Introduction to U.S. maritime law and admiralty jurisdiction emphasizing development of rules of maritime law and rights of seamen and maritime workers.

title: Corporate and Partnership Taxation
description: Examines tax aspects of formation, operation, reorganization, and liquidation of partnerships and corporations.

title: Beyond Guilt Hawai‘i
description: Will serve the community by offering free legal services to those with unjust sentences, train law students in the area of criminal justice, and bring together social service organizations and providers who can help those freed by the clinic to successfully re-enter society. LAW students only.

title: Trusts and Estates
description: Deals primarily with the disposition of family wealth including: the making of wills; the creation, enforcement, administration, and termination of trusts; and intestate succession, including probate.

title: E-Discovery
description: Surveys the relevant law, theory, and practice governing the review and production of electronically stored information, focusing on the rules of civil procedure, the rules of evidence, and case law. LAW majors only. 516 and 517 with a minimum grade of C-.
prerequisites: LAW 516 and LAW 517 with a minimum grade of C-

title: Secured Transactions
description: Introduction to Uniform Commercial Code, particularly Article 9– reducing risk of nonpayment by obtaining an interest in borrowers’ property.

title: (Alpha) Externship
description: Legal work for judges and attorney supervisors in public agencies, private law firms, and the legislature. (H) Hawai‘i; (P) outside Hawai‘i. Repeatable three times for (H). CR/ NC only. consent.

title: Negotiable Instruments, Payment Systems and Credit Instruments
