description: Will cover the most pressing conservation issues for marine mammals, and include a hands-on field component using traditional and novel techniques to inform their management. Graduate students in MB, ZOOL, BOT, and OCN programs only. A-F only.

title: Place-Based Pedagogy for Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experiences
description: Introduces students to place-based science education with an emphasis on Hawaiʻi marine science classrooms. Includes discussions on inclusive teaching methods, CUREs, and effective instruction in laboratory and field environments. A-F only. Instructor approval required. Co-requisite: 795. (Summer only)

title: Directed Research
description: Directed research and reading in various fields of marine biology. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis; (F) 1 credit. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only. Satisfactory/ Unsatisfactory only.

title: Topics in Marine Fisheries and Natural Resource Management
description: Lecture, discussion, and/or projects on selected topics related to marine fisheries and natural resource management. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.

title: Topics in Marine Conservation Biology
description: Lecture, discussion, and/or projects on selected topics related to marine conservation biology. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.

title: Topics in Marine Education, Outreach, and Policy
description: Lecture, discussion, and/or projects on selected topics related to education, outreach, and policy of the marine environment. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.

title: Topics in Marine Physiology, Behavior, and Organismal Biology
description: Lecture, discussion, and/or projects on selected topics related to the physiology, behavior, and biology of marine organisms. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only.

title: Advanced Topics in Quantitative Biology
description: Reflects faculty expertise and needs for graduate training in quantitative methods for biology, including statistical, computational, and analytic approaches. Format (lecture/lab/discussion) will vary by topic. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Internship in College Teaching (Marine Science)
description: Introduction to college-level science teaching; masters or doctoral students serve as apprentices to professors; responsibilities include supervised teaching, planning and evaluation. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. instructor approval. (Summer only)

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate students only. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only.

title: Consumer Behavior
description: Analysis of consumer behavior and motivation; principles of learning, personality, perception, and group influence, with emphasis upon mass communication effects. BUS 312 or consent. (

title: Marketing Research and Data Analytics
description: Use of marketing research and marketing management and data analytics to support marketing management. Topics include: the research process; survey design; sampling; measurement; primary data analysis; customer data analytics; and digital media analytics. BUS 310 and BUS 312, or consent.

title: Marketing Communications
description: In-depth coverage of the major communication tools used in marketing such as advertising, sales promotion, public relations and the internet. Emphasis on integrated marketing communications. BUS 312 or consent.

title: Integrated Communication Campaigns
description: Management of integrated marketing communications campaigns. Includes: conducting target market and competitor research, developing creative content and media strategies, production of communication materials and completion of major real world project. 331 and BUS 312.

title: Retailing Management
description: Analysis of opportunities and challenges in physical and digital retailing management: physical layout and digital design; merchandise planning; organizational forms; expense analysis; integration of physical/digital programs. BUS 312 or consent.

title: Professional Selling
description: Emphasis on selling technique, social-psychological principles of persuasion, and interpersonal communication. Lecture, discussion, and application of relevant principles and techniques. A-F only. BUS 312 or consent.

title: Sales and Sales Management
description: Delves into selling and the sales management process. Through a variety of activities, students experience applying selling techniques, sales planning, recruiting and training salespeople, methods of motivating and compensating, territory management and sales team communications. BUS 312 or consent.

title: Seminar in Marketing
description: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems in the field of marketing. May be repeated four times with change in topic. consent and usually senior standing.

title: Digital Marketing
description: Provides comprehensive understanding of digital marketing’s growing role in new product development; marketing research; direct sales; and marketing communications. Students learn multiple digital tools for analysis of customer behavior. Real-world projects provide opportunities for application. BUS 311 and BUS 312, or consent.

title: Customer Relationship Management
description: Focuses on the evolving field of customer relationship management. Students learn how to manage marketing information and decision-making systems that maximize customer retention and build long-term relationships. A-F only. BUS 311, or consent.

title: Sustainable Marketing
description: Provides environmental knowledge and managerial tools that help for profit and not-for-profit organizations address pressing issues like global warming, plastic pollution, and fair trade while earning surplus revenue and remaining socially accountable. BUS 312 or consent.

title: Marketing for New Ventures
description: Examines role of marketing in the formation and launch of entrepreneurial ventures within and outside of ongoing businesses. Emphasis on new product development and low cost, high impact marketing activities. BUS 312 or consent.

title: International Marketing
description: Principles and topics related to international marketing, with emphasis on strategic planning and applications. BUS 312 or consent.

title: Marketing Strategies
description: Decision-making by the marketing executive; integration of all elements of the marketing program based on actual business situations. 311, 321; or consent.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Reading and research in a special area of major under direction of faculty member(s). Project must include statement of objectives, outline of activities planned, results expected, and how they are to be reported and evaluated. Must be approved in advance by the department chair and the faculty advisor. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Marketing Analytics
description: Introduces current quantitative techniques and analytical approaches to better marketing decision-making. Students learn how to solve problems in a data-driven way using software tools. A-F only. BUS 310 and BUS 312; or consent.

title: Imagination, Entrepreneurship and Business Problem-Solving
description: Application of creative process to problems encountered in venture creation/growth. Student problem-solving styles are characterized and implications drawn for generation of breakthrough ideas. Tools for facilitating creative solutions to marketing problems are investigated. junior standing and BUS 312; or consent.
prerequisites: junior standing and BUS 312; or consent

title: Consumer Behavior for Managers
description: Designed to help students better understand how consumers process information, form attitudes, and make decisions. Draws on theories from social sciences to help students manage consumer needs and satisfaction. A-F only. Graduate students only. BUS 623 or consent of instructor. (Alt. years)

title: Sales Leadership
description: Sales managers participate in diverse activities including hiring, designing and implementing training programs, in-field coaching and development, motivating and compensating employees, and team building. Helps students develop knowledge and skills in these areas. A-F only. Graduate students only. BUS 623 or consent of instructor. (Alt. years)

title: Advanced Marketing Management
description: A case course in the application of advanced marketing methods. BUS 623 or consent.

title: Japanese Marketing Systems
description: Specialized study of Japanese marketing systems, considers both global and domestic marketing activities in the context of the Japanese economy. BUS 623 or consent.

title: International Marketing Management
description: Integrated and comparative approach to international marketing management. Emphasis on the development of a competitive strategy in a global environment. Applications to both developing and industrialized markets. BUS 623 or consent.

title: Strategic Brand Management
description: The study of branding and brand management. Explores how managers can formulate and implement integrated marketing strategies to build brand equity. Includes relevant theory and real world applications. BUS 623 or consent.

title: Marketing Research Management
description: Examines use of marketing research/data analytics to support marketing management. Topics include: research process; survey design; sampling; measurement; primary data analysis; customer data analytics; digital media analytics. Real world project reinforce learning. BUS 621, BUS 623, or consent.

title: Creativity in Marketing
description: Thought processes that relate to creativity. Through a series of exercises, students experience enriched creativity and enhanced communication skills. BUS 623 or consent.

title: Services Marketing
description: Conceptual understanding of distinctive aspects of services, services management, and services research. BUS 623 or consent.

title: Digital Marketing Management
description: Examines digital marketing’s role in new product development; direct sales; marketing communications via the internet, social media, and mobile devices; and digital tools such as online tracking and analysis. Real activities provide opportunities for application. A-F only. BUS 623 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Patient Centered Communication Management in Health Care Organizations
description: Provides training on managing patient communications in general and shared decision making in particular. Increases ability to use tools available to improve patient-provider decision making quality and satisfaction. A-F only. BUS 623.

title: Advanced Seminar in Marketing
description: Significant topics, problems in marketing. Repeatable unlimited times. BUS 623 or consent.

title: Seminar in Marketing Theory
description: Focuses on the building blocks of theory, their use, and evolution within a marketing context. Explores marketing theories, theory construction, and the creation of marketing knowledge. A-F only. PhD student status in business administration or consent.
prerequisites: PhD student status in business administration or consent

title: Seminar in Consumer Behavior
description: Focuses on consumer behavior theory. Provides in-depth review of important published work in traditional and cross-cultural consumer behavior fields. A-F only. PhD student status in business administration or consent.
prerequisites: PhD student status in business administration or consent

title: Seminar in Marketing Strategy
description: Focuses on theories of strategic marketing and planning. Explores the theoretical principles of marketing concepts, tools, and processes that can be used to help an organization develop a sustainable competitive advantage. A-F only. PhD student status in business administration or consent.
prerequisites: PhD student status in business administration or consent

title: Seminar in Selected Marketing Topics
description: Selected topics in any aspect of marketing to increase exposure to the range of issues researchers commonly confront. A-F only. PhD student status in business administration or consent.
prerequisites: PhD student status in business administration or consent

title: Directed Research
description: Reading and research in an area of marketing under the direction of faculty member(s). A-F only. PhD student status in international management or consent.
prerequisites: PhD student status in international management or consent

title: Survey of Mathematics
description: Selected topics designed to acquaint nonspecialists with examples of mathematical reasoning. May not be taken for credit after 215 or higher.

title: Math for Elementary Teachers I
description: Understanding, communicating, and representing mathematical ideas, problem solving, and reasoning. Number systems, place value, fractions, and properties of operations. Prospective elementary education majors only.

title: Math for Elementary Teachers II
description: Understanding, communicating, and representing mathematical ideas; problem solving; reasoning and proof; and using symbolism. Patterns and algebraic thinking, place value and decimals, geometry, and mathematical modeling. 111.

title: Precalculus: Elementary Functions
description: Algebra review, functions with special attention to polynomial, rational exponential and logarithmic functions, composed and inverse functions, techniques of graphing. A-F only. two years of high school algebra, one year of plane geometry.
prerequisites: two years of high school algebra, one year of plane geometry

title: Precalculus
description: Algebra review. Polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic functions, composed and inverse functions, techniques of graphing. Trigonometric functions, analytic geometry, polar coordinates, vectors, and related topics. 134 or 161 or placement exam.
prerequisites: MATH 134 or MATH 161 or placement exam

title: Precalculus and Elements of Calculus for Economics and the Social Sciences
description: Algebra review, functions with special attention to polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic functions, algebra of functions, techniques of graphing, differentiation and integration of algebraic functions, applications in economics and social sciences. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Programming
description: (3 hr) Introduction to numerical algorithms and structured programming using Fortran, MATLAB, or other appropriate language. one semester of calculus (203, 215, 241, 242, 243, 244, 251A, 252A, or 253A) (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: one semester of calculus (MATH 203, MATH 215, MATH 241, MATH 242, MATH 243, MATH 244, MATH 251A, MATH 252A, or MATH 253A) (or concurrent), or consent

title: Calculus for Business and Social Sciences
description: Basic concepts; differentiation and integration applications to management, finance, economics, and the social sciences. 134 or 161 or placement exam.
prerequisites: MATH 134 or MATH 161 or placement exam

title: Applied Calculus I
description: Basic concepts; differentiation, differential equations and integration with applications directed primarily to the life sciences. 140X or placement exam

title: Applied Calculus II
description: Differential calculus for functions in several variables and curves, systems of ordinary differential equations, series approximation of functions, continuous probability, exposure to use of calculus in the literature. 215 or consent.

title: Calculus I
description: Basic concepts; differentiation with applications; integration. 140X or 215 or placement exam.
prerequisites: MATH 140X or MATH 215 or placement exam

title: Calculus II
description: Integration techniques and applications, series and approximations, differential equations. 241 or 251A or a grade of B or better in 215; or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 241 or MATH 251A or a grade of B or better in MATH 215; or consent

title: Calculus III
description: Vector algebra, vector-valued functions, differentiation in several variables, and optimization. 242 or 252A, or consent.

title: Calculus IV
description: Multiple integrals; line integrals and Green’s Theorem; surface integrals, Stokes’s and Gauss’s Theorems. 243 or consent.

title: History of Mathematics
description: The historical development of mathematical thought. 216 or 242 or 252A.

title: Introduction to Discrete Mathematics
description: Symbolic logic, sets and relations, algorithms, trees and other graphs. Additional topics chosen from algebraic systems, networks, automata. one semester of calculus from mathematics department; or consent. Recommended: one semester programming.
prerequisites: one semester of calculus from mathematics department; or consent

title: Introduction to Differential Equations I
description: First order ordinary differential equations, constant coefficient linear equations, oscillations, Laplace transform, convolution, Green’s function. 216 or 243 (or concurrent) or 253A (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 216 or MATH 243 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent), or consent

title: Introduction to Differential Equations II
description: Constant coefficient linear systems, variable coefficient ordinary differential equations, series solutions and special functions, Fourier series, partial differential equations. 302, 311 (or concurrent); or consent.

title: Mathematical Modeling: Deterministic Models
description: Deterministic mathematical modeling emphasizing models and tools used in the biological sciences. Topics include difference equations, qualitative behavior solutions of ODEs and reaction-diffusion equations. A computer lab may be taken concurrently. 216 or 242 or 252A, or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 216 or MATH 242 or MATH 252A, or consent

title: Mathematical Modeling: Deterministic Models Lab
description: Optional laboratory for 304. 304 (or concurrent).

title: Mathematical Modeling: Probabilistic Models
description: Probabilistic mathematical modeling emphasizing models and tools used in the biological sciences. Topics include stochastic and Poisson processes, Markov models, estimation, and Monte Carlo simulation. A computer lab may be taken concurrently. 216 or 242 or 252A, or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 216 or MATH 242 or MATH 252A, or consent

title: Mathematical Modeling: Probabilistic Models Lab
description: Optional laboratory for 305. 305 (or concurrent).

title: Linear Algebra and Differential Equations
description: Introduction to linear algebra, application of eigenvalue techniques to the solution of differential equations. Students may receive credit for only one of 307 or 311. 242 or 252A, or consent.

title: Introduction to Linear Algebra
description: Algebra of matrices, linear equations, real vector spaces and transformations. Emphasis on concepts and abstraction and instruction of careful writing. Students may receive credit for only one of 307 or 311. 242 or 252A, or consent.

title: Introduction to Advanced Mathematics
description: Formal introduction to the concepts of logic, finite and infinite sets, functions, methods of proof and axiomatic systems. Learning mathematical expressions in writing is an integral part of the course. 243 (or concurrent) or 253A (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 243 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent), or consent

title: Introduction to Real Analysis
description: A rigorous axiomatic development of one variable calculus. Completeness, topology of the line, limits, continuity, differentiation, integration. Emphasis on teaching mathematical writing. 242 or 252A, and 321; or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 242 or MATH 252A, and MATH 321; or consent

title: Foundation of Euclidean Geometry
description: Axiomatic Euclidean geometry and introduction to the axiomatic method. 243 or 253A, and 321 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 243 or MATH 253A, and MATH 321 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Non-Euclidean Geometries
description: Hyperbolic, other non-Euclidean geometries. 351 or consent.

title: Introduction to Euclidean and NonEuclidean Geometries
description: Axiomatic geometry and introduction to the axiomatic method; Euclidean geometry; hyperbolic geometry, and other nonEuclidean geometries. 243 or 253A, and 321 (or concurrent); or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: MATH 243 or MATH 253A, and MATH 321 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Financial Mathematics
description: Interest rate measurement, valuation of annuities, loan repayment, bond valuation, rate of return. Term structure of interest rates, cashflow duration, and immunization. Financial mathematics actuarial exam topics. 216 or 242 or 252A or (203 and BUS 250). (Alt. years: fall)
prerequisites: MATH 216 or MATH 242 or MATH 252A or (MATH 203 and BUS 250)

title: Elementary Probability Theory
description: Sets, discrete sample spaces, problems in combinatorial probability, random variables, mathematical expectations, classical distributions, applications. 216, 242, or 252A; or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 216, MATH 242, or MATH 252A; or consent

title: Elementary Probability and Statistics
description: Problem-oriented introduction to the basic concepts of probability and statistics, providing a foundation for applications and further study. 216 or 242 or 252A or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 216 or MATH 242 or MATH 252A or consent

title: Elementary Statistics
description: Estimation, tests of significance, the concept of power. 371 or consent.

title: Partial Differential Equations I
description: Integral surfaces and characteristics of first and second order partial differential equations. Applications to the equations of mathematical physics. 243 or 253A, or consent. Recommended: 244 and 302.

title: Partial Differential Equations II
description: Laplace’s equation, Fourier transform methods for PDEs, higher dimensional PDEs, spherical harmonics, Laplace series, special functions and applications. 402 or consent.

title: Ordinary Differential Equations
description: Systems of linear ordinary differential equations, autonomous systems, and stability theory applications. Optional topics include series solutions, Sturm theory, numerical methods. 302 and 311, or consent.

title: Numerical Analysis
description: Numerical solution of equations, interpolation, least-squares approximation, quadrature, eigenvalue problems, numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 407–408.) 243 or 253A, and 307 or 311, and one semester programming; or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 243 or MATH 253A, and MATH 307 or MATH 311, and one semester programming; or consent

title: Numerical Analysis
description: Continuation of 407. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 407. 407 or consent.

title: Linear Algebra
description: Vector spaces over arbitrary fields, minimal polynomials, invariant subspaces, canonical forms of matrices; unitary and Hermitian matrices, quadratic forms. 307 or 311, and 321; or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 307 or MATH 311, and MATH 321; or consent

title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra
description: Introduction to basic algebraic structures. Groups, finite groups, abelian groups, rings, integral domains, fields, factorization, polynomial rings, field extensions, quotient fields. Emphasis on writing instruction. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 412–413.) 311 and 321; or consent.

title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra
description: Continuation of 412. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 412. Emphasis on writing instruction. 412 or consent.

title: Optimization: Theory & Methods
description: Introduction to theory and methods for optimization. Topics may include least square analysis, search methods, conjugate direction methods, linear programming, integer programming, and constrained optimization. 243 or 253A, and 307 or 311; or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 243 or MATH 253A, and MATH 307 or MATH 311; or consent

title: Introduction to the Theory of Numbers
description: Congruences, quadratic residues, arithmetic functions, distribution of primes. Emphasis is on teaching theory and writing, not on computation. 321 or consent.

title: Topology
description: General topology, including compactness and connectedness; the Jordan Curve Theorem and the classification of surfaces; first homotopy or homology groups. 321 or consent.

title: Principles of Analysis I
description: Topology of Rn , metric spaces, continuous functions, Riemann integration, sequences and series, uniform convergence, implicit function theorems, differentials and Jacobians. Emphasis on teaching mathematical writing. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 431–432.) 311, 321, and 331; or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 311, MATH 321, and MATH 331; or consent

title: Principles of Analysis II
description: Continuation of 431. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 431. Emphasis on writing instruction continues. 431 or consent.

title: Vector Analysis
description: Vector operations, wedge product, differential forms, and smooth mappings. Theorems of Green, Stokes, and Gauss, both classically and in terms of forms. Applications to electromagnetism and mechanics. 244 or 253A, and 307 or 311, or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 244 or MATH 253A, and MATH 307 or MATH 311, or consent

title: Differential Geometry
description: Properties and fundamental geometric invariants of curves and surfaces in space; applications to the physical sciences. 244 or 253A, and 311; or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 244 or MATH 253A, and MATH 311; or consent

title: Complex Analysis
description: Analytic functions, complex integration, introduction to conformal mapping. 244 or 253A; recommended 331; or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 244 or MATH 253A; recommended MATH 331; or consent

title: Topics in Undergraduate Mathematics
description: Advanced topics from various areas: algebra, number theory, analysis, and geometry. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Axiomatic Set Theory
description: Sets, relations, ordinal arithmetic, cardinal arithmetic, axiomatic set theory, axiom of choice and the continuum hypothesis. 321 or graduate standing in a related field or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 321 or graduate standing in a related field or consent

title: Mathematical Logic
description: A system of first order logic. Formal notions of well-formed formula, proof, and derivability. Semantic notions of model, truth, and validity. Completeness theorem. 321 or graduate standing in a related field or consent. Recommended: 454.
prerequisites: MATH 321 or graduate standing in a related field or consent

title: Probability
description: Probability spaces, random variables, distributions, expectations, moment-generating and characteristic functions, limit theorems. Continuous probability emphasized. 244 (or concurrent) or 253A (or concurrent), or consent. Recommended: 305 or 371 or 372; or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent), or consent

title: Statistical Inference
description: Sampling and parameter estimation, tests of hypotheses, correlation, regression, analysis of variance, sequential analysis, rank order statistics. 471 or consent.

title: Combinatorial Mathematics
description: Finite configurations. Topics may include counting methods, generating functions, graph theory, map coloring, block design, network flows, analysis of discrete algorithms. 311 or consent.

title: Senior Seminar
description: Seminar for senior mathematics majors, including an introduction to methods of research. Significant portion of class time is dedicated to the instruction and critique of oral presentations. All students must give the equivalent of three presentations. CR/NC only. one 400-level mathematics course or consent.
prerequisites: one MATH 400-level mathematics course or consent

title: Mathematical Biology Seminar
description: Reports on research in mathematical biology, reviews of literature, and research presentation. Required for Certificate in Mathematical Biology. Repeatable one time. junior standing or higher and consent. (
prerequisites: junior standing or higher and consent

title: Directed Reading
description: Limited to advanced students who must arrange with an instructor before enrolling. Repeatable one time, up to six credits.

title: Problem Solving for Teachers
description: Practicing teachers develop and improve their problem-solving skills by working on challenging mathematical tasks. Students improve their mathematics content knowledge by working on problems and learning to design challenge problems for their own classes. Practicing teachers in grades K-12 only. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. All 600-courses graduate standing or consent.

title: (Alpha) Career Skills for Graduate Students in Mathematics
description: Seminar addresses issues important in the career of a mathematician, beginning from their time in graduate school, through navigating the job market and on to their eventual work in industry or academia. (B) teaching. Repeatable unlimited times, repeatable one time for (B). MATH majors only. Graduate students only.

title: Applied Dynamical Systems
description: Continuous and discrete dynamical systems; bifurcation theory; chaotic maps. Additional topics from PDEs and linear algebra. Graduate students only.

title: Methods of Applied Mathematics
description: Linear algebra, ordinary differential equations, and partial differential equations. Topics include spectral theory, matrix exponentiation, initial-value problems, dynamical systems, bifurcation theory, first-order PDEs, characteristics, Sturm-Liouville theory, boundary-value problems, Green’s functions.

title: Partial Differential Equations
description: Classical existence and uniqueness theory for PDEs, qualitative properties, classification, boundary value and initial value problems, fundamental solutions, other topics.

title: Numerical Analysis
description: Numerical linear algebra including iterative methods, SVD, and other matrix factorizations, locating eigenvalues, discrete approximation to partial differential equations. Recommended: 407, 411, or consent.

title: Key Elements of Linear Algebra
description: Key concepts of linear algebra for graduate students in mathematics. Specific topics include vector spaces, linear transformations, multilinear forms, and Jordan decomposition. May not receive credit for both MATH 411 and MATH 610. MATH majors only. Graduate students only.

title: Modern Algebra
description: Modules, Sylow theorems, Jordan-Holder theorem, unique factorization domains, Galois theory, algebraic closures, transcendence bases. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 611–612.)

title: Modern Algebra
description: Continuation of 611. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 611.

title: Group Theory
description: Sylow theorems, solvable groups, nilpotent groups, extension theory, representation theory, additional topics.

title: Ring Theory
description: Ideal theory in Noetherian rings, localization, Dedekind domains, the Jacobson radical, the Wedderburn-Artin theorem, additional topics.

title: Lattice Theory
description: Introduction with applications to general algebra. Partially ordered sets, decomposition theory, representations of lattices, varieties and free lattices, coordinatization of modular lattices.

title: Universal Algebra
description: Introduction to basic techniques, including subalgebras, congruences, automorphisms and endomorphisms, varieties of algebras, Mal’cev conditions.

title: Key Elements of Topology
description: Key concepts of Topology for graduate students in mathematics; topological spaces; separation axioms, compactness, connectedness; continuity. MATH majors only. Graduate students only.

title: Topology
description: Properties of topological spaces; separation axioms, compactness, connectedness; metrizability; convergence and continuity. Additional topics from general and algebraic topology. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 621–622.)

title: Topology
description: Continuation of 621. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 621.

title: Geometric Group Theory
description: Geometric, topological, and dynamical methods in the study of finitely generated infinite groups. Graduate students only. 621 (with a minimum grade of B-).
prerequisites: MATH 621 (with a minimum grade of B-)

title: Differentiable Manifolds I
description: Differentiable structures on manifolds, tensor fields, Frobenius theorem, exterior algebra, integration of forms, Poincare Lemma, Stoke’s theorem.

title: Theory of Functions of a Real Variable
description: Lebesgue measure and integral, convergence of integrals, functions of bounded variation, Lebesgue-Stieltjes integral and more general theory of measure and integration. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 631–632.)

title: Theory of Functions of a Real Variable
description: Continuation of 631. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 631.

title: Functional Analysis
description: Linear topological spaces, normed spaces, Hilbert spaces, function algebras, operator theory. consent.

title: Calculus of Variations
description: Simple variational problems, first and second variation formulas. Euler-Lagrange equation, direct methods, optimal control.

title: Analytic Function Theory
description: Conformal mapping, residue theory, series and product developments, analytic continuation, special functions. (These topics are covered in the year sequence 644–645.)

title: Analytic Function Theory
description: Continuation of 644. This is the second course of a year sequence and should be taken in the same academic year as 644.

title: (Alpha) Topics in Mathematics
description: (B) logic; (D) analysis; (E) commutative rings; (F) function theory; (G) geometric topology; (H) operator theory; ((I) probability; (J) algebra; (K) special; (M) lattice theory and universal algebra; (N) noncommutative rings; (O) transformation groups; (P) partial differential equations; (Q) potential theory; (R) algebraic topology; (S) functional analysis; (T) number theory and combinatorics; (U) differentiable manifolds II. Repeatable up to nine credits for (U); unlimited times for the other alphas.

title: Introduction to Logic
description: Model theory, computability theory, set theory. In particular syntax and semantics of first order logic; incompleteness, completeness, and compactness theorems; Loewenheim-Skolem theorems; computable and computably enumerable sets; axioms of set theory; ordinals and cardinals. Graduate students only.

title: Set Theory
description: Axiomatic development, ordinal and cardinal numbers, recursion theorems, axiom of choice, continuum hypothesis, consistency and independence results.

title: Recursive Functions and Complexity
description: Recursive, r.e., Ptime, and Logspace classes. Nondeterminism, parallelism, alternation, and Boolean circuits. Reducibility and completeness.

title: Introduction to Algebraic Number Theory
description: Number fields and rings of integers; primes, factorization, and ramification theory; finiteness of the class group; Dirichlet’s Unit Theorem; valuations, completions, and local fields. Further topics. Graduate students only. 611 (with a minimum grade of B-).
prerequisites: MATH 611 (with a minimum grade of B-)

title: Advanced Probability
description: Independence and conditioning, martingales, ergodic theory, Markov chains, central limit theorem. A-F only. 631 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: MATH 631 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Stochastic Processes
description: Stationary, Gaussian, and Markov processes. A-F only. 671 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: MATH 671 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Graph Theory
description: Connected graphs and digraphs. Graph embeddings. Connectivity and networks. Factors and factorizations. Coverings. Coloring. Applications.

title: Directed Reading and Research for Plan B Masters Students
description: Maximum of 3 credit hours. Repeatable two times. Graduate standing in MATH. A-F only.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Maximum of 3 credit hours. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Apprenticeship in Teaching
description: An experience-based introduction to college-level teaching; students serve as student teachers to professors; responsibilities include supervised teaching and participation in planning and evaluation. Open to graduate students in mathematics only. Repeatable one time, up to six credits. CR/NC only. graduate standing in mathematics and consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing in mathematics and consent

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Introduction to Engineering Design I
description: (1 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Introductory experience in analysis, synthesis, and design. Teamwork and project required. high school physics or consent.

title: Space Exploration
description: Introduction to science and engineering of Solar System exploration with laboratory exercises. Covers planetary science, model-based systems engineering, mission planning, constraints on payload and spacecraft design, human spaceflight technology. Research projects emphasize written communication. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Introduction to Engineering Design
description: (1 Lec, 2 2-hr Lab) Introductory experience in communication, presentation, professional ethics, social responsibility, engineering economics, quality control, and computer-aided drafting. Teamwork and project required. PHYS 170.

title: Applied Mechanics II
description: Dynamics of particles and rigid bodies; force, acceleration, impulse-momentum, work-energy. CE, CNST, ENGS, ME majors only. A-F only. C or better in CEE 270; MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent). (
prerequisites: C or better in CEE 270; MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent)

title: Space Science and Instrumentation
description: Essential techniques for remote compositional analysis of planets; understanding spectroscopy, mineralogy, and geochemistry of planetary surfaces and their measurement. Design of space flight instrumentation. A-F only. EPET 201, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 101L and ERTH 105, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 107; and CHEM 161 and PHYS 272.
prerequisites: EPET 201, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 101L and ERTH 105, or ERTH 101 and ERTH 107; and CHEM 161 and PHYS 272

title: Thermodynamics
description: (3 Lec, 1 Discussion) Basic laws, closed and open systems. Work, heat, concept of entropy. Properties of pure simple substances. Ideal gases. Introduction to power and refrigeration cycles. grade of C or better in all of CHEM 162 (or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A), PHYS 170 and MATH 244 (or MATH 253A).
prerequisites: grade of C or better in all of CHEM 162 (or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A), PHYS 170 and MATH 244 (or MATH 253A)

title: Mechanics of Fluids and Lab
description: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Incompressible and compressible ideal fluids, effects of viscosity. Similitude, boundary layer flow. Measurement techniques in thermodynamics and fluid mechanics. Hands-on experience with instrumentation. Open-ended design of thermofluid systems. Emphasis on writing instruction. grade of C or better in all of 311 and CEE 271 (or ME 271).
prerequisites: grade of C or better in all of ME 311 and CEE 271 (or ME 271)

title: Materials Science and Engineering
description: Electronic, atomic, and crystalline structure of materials and their effect on the mechanical, electrical, optical, and magnetic properties of engineering metals, ceramics, polymers, and composites. grade of C or better in all of CHEM 162 (or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A), MATH 242 (or MATH 252A), and PHYS 170.
prerequisites: grade of C or better in all of CHEM 162 (or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A), MATH 242 (or MATH 252A), and PHYS 170

title: Manufacturing Processes and Lab
description: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Energy requirements for manufacturing methods. Manufacturing methods to obtain components with desired size/shape/properties. Conduct manufacturing experiments. Emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only. 331 or consent.

title: Manufacturing Processes Lab
description: (1 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Manufacturing laboratory: tension/ compression tests, cold rolling, welding, casting, statistical process control, programming and milling using a CNC machine. A-F only. 341 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Computer Methods in Engineering
description: Numerical solutions for algebraic and transcendental equations, simultaneous linear algebraic equations, integration and differentiation; integration of ordinary differential equations. Engineering applications. grade of C or better in all of ECE 160 (or ECE 110 or ICS 111), MATH 244 (or MATH 253A), and MATH 302 (or MATH 307).
prerequisites: grade of C or better in all of ECE 160 (or ECE 110 or ICS 111), MATH 244 (or MATH 253A), and MATH 302 (or MATH 307)

title: Mechanics of Solids
description: Introduction to analysis and design of deformable bodies subject to loading. Stress, strain, consitutive relation, axially loading, torsion, statically indeterminate systems, Mohr’s circle, failure criteria, buckling, defection due to axial, shear, torsional, and flexural loading. C or better in all of the following: CEE 270; and MATH 244
prerequisites: C or better in all of the following: CEE 270; and MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent)
crossListings: or concurrent or MATH 253A or concurrent. Crosslisted as CEE 370

title: Component Design
description: Design, analysis, and selection of machine components: shafts, screws, fasteners, welds, rolling contact bearings, journal bearings, gears, clutches, brakes, belts, and roller chains. 213, and either 371 or CEE 370.
prerequisites: ME 213, and either ME 371 or CEE 370

title: Kinematics/Dynamics Machinery
description: Velocity and acceleration analysis of planar mechanisms; kinematic synthesis of linkages, cams, and gears; static and dynamic force analysis of mechanisms; balancing of machinery. CEE 271 or ME 271 (C or better), MATH 244 (or MATH 253A) and either MATH 302 or MATH 307
prerequisites: CEE 271 or ME 271 (C or better), MATH 244 (or MATH 253A) and either MATH 302 or MATH 307

title: Dynamics of Machines and Systems and Lab
description: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr. Lab) Lumped-parameter modeling of dynamic systems. Methods of analysis, including transform techniques. Time and frequency response. Feedback control. Engineering instrumentation. Data acquisition. Dynamic measurements. Design and testing. Lab report writing. grade of C or better in all of CEE 271 (or ME 271) and MATH 302 (or MATH 307).
prerequisites: grade of C or better in all of CEE 271 (or ME 271) and MATH 302 (or MATH 307)

title: Space Mission Design
description: Covers all aspects of spacecraft design, subsystems, science payload, systems engineering, project management, budgets, and ethical issues that are important to consider in producing a fully successful mission. A-F only. 301. (Spring only) (

title: Capstone Project: Producing a Science Satellite
description: Develops a space mission with a multidisciplinary team of engineers and scientists. Will build a small spacecraft and payload and seeks to answer important science questions. Emphasizes review report and proposal writing. A-F only. 400. (Fall only) (

title: Dynamics Systems Laboratory
description: (1 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Analysis, design, fabrication, testing and characterization of engineering instrumentation. Computer-based data acquisition methods. Techniques and procedures associated with carrying out dynamic measurements within the constraints of cost, time and accuracy. one of 360, MATH 407, or PHYS 305 (or concurrent for any); and 375 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: one of ME 360, MATH 407, or PHYS 305 (or concurrent for any); and PHYS 375 (or concurrent)

title: Advanced Mathematics for Engineers
description: Applications of ordinary differential equations, Laplace transform, vector field theory, matrices, line integrals. MATH 244 (or MATH 253A), and MATH 302 (or MATH 307).

title: Computational Fluid Dynamics
description: Basic computational fluid dynamics; four important partial differential equations; introduction to finite element method: Interpolation and Galerkin method; finite element method for transport phenomena; some algorithms for parallel computing. A-F only. 422 (or concurrent ), and either 360, MATH 407 or PHYS 305; or consent.
prerequisites: ME 422 (or concurrent ), and either ME 360, MATH 407 or PHYS 305; or consent

title: Orbital Mechanics
description: Basic theory of orbits of space objects, including spacecraft, small satellites, planets and small planets, and other fundamentals of astrodynamics and applications to aerospace engineering. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. grade of C or better in all of the following: 271; 375; MATH 244 or MATH 253A; MATH 302 or MATH 307; ECE 160 or ICS 111.
prerequisites: grade of C or better in all of the following: ME 271; ME 375; MATH 244 or MATH 253A; MATH 302 or MATH 307; ECE 160 or ICS 111

title: Optimal Control for Aerospace Applications
description: Fundamentals of optimal control theory and calculus of variations. Application of this theory to aerospace engineering problems, including mission design problems and a wide range of space maneuvers. A-F only. Junior standing or higher. grade of C or better in all of the following: 271; 375; MATH 244 or MATH 253A; MATH 302 or MATH 307; ECE 160 or ICS 111.
prerequisites: grade of C or better in all of the following: ME 271; ME 375; MATH 244 or MATH 253A; MATH 302 or MATH 307; ECE 160 or ICS 111

title: Applied Thermodynamics
description: Gas mixtures, generalized thermodynamic relationships, combustion and thermochemistry, chemical equilibrium, power and refrigeration cycles. grade of C or better in 311.
prerequisites: grade of C or better in ME 311

title: Applied Thermal Engineering
description: Principles, design and analysis of practical thermal systems. Engineering applications. Valve, compressor, condenser and evaporator technologies. System integration and control. Thermal loads and thermal comfort. 422 (or concurrent). (Fall only)

title: Power and Propulsion
description: Principles, performance, and design of gas turbine power plants and propulsion systems. 422 (or concurrent).

title: Astronautics
description: The space environment (vacuum, neutral, radiation, and plasma); motion in gravitational fields; orbit transfers; Earth-satellite operations; rocketry; propulsion analysis and performance; reentry dynamics; interplanetary trajectories; attitude dynamics and stabilization. A-F only. consent.

title: Heat Transfer and Lab
description: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Steady and unsteady conduction; steady convection and radiation; heat exchangers. Emphasis on writing instruction. 322.

title: Mass Transfer
description: Elementary mass diffusion; diffusion in a stationary medium; diffusion in a moving medium; low and high mass transfer theories; simultaneous heat and mass transfer; condensation, evaporation, and boiling; transpiration cooling; species boundary layers; engineering and design of heat and mass exchangers; current refrigerants and environmental regulations. A-F only. 422 or consent.

title: Introduction to Gas Dynamics
description: One-dimensional compressible flow involving change of area, friction, heat transfer. Normal and oblique shocks. Prandtl-Meyer flow. Application to nozzles, diffusers, airfoils. 322.

title: Thermal Management of Electronic Systems
description: To introduce concepts in the thermal management of electronics, and to develop sound technical tools to approach modern electronic packaging and cooling applications. A-F only. 422 or consent.

title: Scaling Methods in Engineering
description: Scaling methods and optimization under global constraints; multi-scale optimal design of mechanical, thermal, and natural systems; effectiveness of heat, fluid, and convective trees; theoretical design optimization of manmade and natural power systems; analysis of time dependent structures. A-F only. 371 and 422, or consent.

title: Solar Thermal Engineering
description: Fundamentals of solar energy, solar engineering material characteristics, and solar thermal and photovoltaic systems. Will learn solar thermal system components, and be able to perform simple system design. A-F only. Senior standing or higher. 422 or consent.

title: Failures in Materials
description: Analysis of component failures due to imperfections, fatigue, brittle fracture, wear, corrosion, bending, impact, and overload. Fracture mechanics. Case studies. 331 or consent.

title: Materials Selection for Design
description: Methodology for the selection of materials for mechanical applications to prevent mechanical failure and environmental degradation. Design considerations associated with the use of metals, ceramics, polymers, and composites. 341 and 371 (or CEE 370).

title: Experimental Methods in Materials Research
description: (1 Lec, 2 2-hr Lab) Common experimental techniques in materials testing and research: x-ray diffraction, optical and electron microscopy, thermal and mechanical properties, electrochemical methods—theory and hands-on experience. 341 or CHEM 351 (or concurrent). (

title: Corrosion Engineering
description: Basics of corrosion processes and emphasis on corrosion control. Thermodynamics and kinetics of corrosion, metal alloys and their behavior, corrosion control techniques (cathodic protection, anodic protection, coatings, and inhibitors). 341.

title: Mechatronics
description: (2 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Modern mechatronics components and design principles; functionality of products, processes and systems; electrical circuits and mechanical components; programming and control; hands on technology; application case studies. ME, ECE, CE, ICS majors only. junior standing or consent. (Fall only)

title: Advanced Materials Manufacturing
description: (2 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Introduction to anisotropic materials, advanced manufacturing techniques for composite and intelligent materials, joining of composites, thin film processing and stereolithography, computer aided manufacturing and rapid prototyping, manufacturing process optimization, open-ended manufacturing projects. A-F only. 341, 342, and senior standing; or consent.
prerequisites: ME 341, ME 342, and senior standing; or consent

title: Introduction to Nanotechnology
description: (3 Lec) Tools and techniques of micro- and nanotechnology in design, modeling, simulations, analysis, fabrication, testing and characterization; nano-materials, nano-structures, nano-composites, nano-coating, nano-optics, nano-electronics and nano-biotechnology. A-F only. senior standing or consent.

title: Nanosystem and Microsystem Design
description: Fabrication, design, and analysis of physical systems, sensors, and actuators at the nanoscale and microscale. Microfabrication/nanofabrication, fabrication process design, electrostatistic and electromagnetic interactions, signal transduction, measurements. Course work will focus on process and system design. ENGR majors only. 331 (with a minimum grade of C-), 375 (with a minimum grade of C-), or consent.
prerequisites: ME 331 (with a minimum grade of C-), ME 375 (with a minimum grade of C-), or consent

title: Research Methods in Engineering
description: Introduces the basic skills of preparing and publishing scientific research. Students will learn how to prepare, write, publish, and present a scientific paper, while working on a research project related to thermofluids. A-F only. Senior standing or higher. 322 or consent.

title: Feedback-Control Systems
description: Analysis/design of feedback systems. Compensator design via root locus and Bode analysis. Routh/Nyquist stability. State space representation and introduction to MIMO formulation. Controllability/observability. Application to physical dynamic systems such as industrial robots. 375 or ECE 315 or consent.

title: Robotics
description: Principles and design methods for autonomous systems. senior standing.

title: Energy Conversion Systems
description: Energy conversion and its impact on the environment. Conventional, hydroelectric, nuclear fission and fusion, solar, wind, ocean, geothermal, and biomass power; energy storage, transmission and conservation. 322, 411, and 422 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: ME 322, ME 411, and ME 422 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Nuclear Power Engineering
description: Nuclear reactor principles. Reactor heat transfer, heat generation and removal. Design and analysis of reactor power systems and plants. 411 (or consent) and 422.

title: Flow Visualization and Measurement
description: Overview of flow visualization and measurement techniques including high speed photography of wakes, jets, shear layer, particle motion. Experimental design, statistics, image processing and data analysis. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 322 (or concurrent), or consent.

title: Materials for Solar Energy Conversion
description: Atom structure, electromagnetic waves and energy, electronic and energetic properties of semi-conducting materials, junctions, solar cells operations, bulk and thin film materials synthesis, integration of solar cells into the electric grid. ECE and ME majors only. (331 or ECE 324) with a minimum grade of C-. (Fall only)
prerequisites: (ME 331 or ECE 324) with a minimum grade of C-

title: Electrochemical Power Sources: Principles, Applications, and Sustainability
description: Electrochemistry, batteries, fuel cells, flow batteries, electrochemical capacitors, electric vehicles, electrochemical grid storage. ENGR majors only. 331, CHEM 162, CHEM 171, or CHEM 181A (with a grade of C- or better). (Alt. years: spring)
prerequisites: ME 331, CHEM 162, CHEM 171, or CHEM 181A (with a grade of C- or better)

title: Experimental Stress Analysis
description: (1-3 hr Lab) Techniques of experimental stress analysis: strain and deflection measurement of beams and shafts, strain to stress conversion, principal and maximum shearing stresses, failure in biaxial stress states, stress concentrations, residual stresses, buckling, creep, electrical resistance strain gages, brittle coatings, photoelastic methods, transducers. A-F only. 371 and departmental approval.

title: Mechanical Vibrations
description: Response of machines and systems to transient and periodic excitation. Vibration isolation and transmissibility. Modal analysis of multi-degree-of-freedom systems. Applications to design. 371, 375; or consent.

title: Fundamentals of Acoustics
description: Plane and spherical acoustic waves. Transmission, reflection, radiation, and absorption. Near and far fields, radiation patterns. Applications to noise control. Instruments. 375, ECE 211; or consent.

title: Thermofluid Measurements and Design
description: Measurement techniques in thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, and heat transfer. Hands-on experience with instrumentation. Open-ended design of thermofluid systems. Contemporary engineering ethics issues. Final report and presentation are required. A-F only. 422 (or concurrent).

title: Design Project I
description: (2 1-hr Lec, 2 2-hr Lab) Heuristic application of engineering design process and project planning via a significant, open-ended design project that includes realistic constraints involving economics, environmental sustainability, manufacturability, ethics, health, safety, society, and politics. Extensive written communication required. A-F only. 322, 341, 372, and 375; or consent.
prerequisites: ME 322, ME 341, ME 372, and ME 375; or consent

title: Design Project II
description: (1 Lec, 2 2-hr Lab) Continuation of design project initiated in ME 481. Extension of conceptual design to final design. Manufacturing of prototype: material and part selection, procurement, manufacturing specifications/ drawings. Testing of complex systems. Extensive oral communication required. A-F only. 481.

title: Research and Experiment Design
description: Introduction to research and experimentation via pursuit and reporting of an open-ended design project. Ethical issues in research and experimentation. Engineering, Biological Engineering, and Ocean & Resources Engineering majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: System Engineering
description: Will cover system engineering design, analysis, and development concepts, requirements derivation/management, and program management processes, such as risk identification/ management and fiscal/schedule tools. ME majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. 213 (with a minimum grade of C).
prerequisites: ME 213 (with a minimum grade of C)

title: Pearl Harbor Co-op
description: Provides real-world engineering experience through project assignment and working alongside a practicing engineer at the Pearl Harbor Naval Shipyard. ME majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. (322, 341, 372, and 375) with a minimum grade of C.
prerequisites: (ME 322, ME 341, ME 372, and ME 375) with a minimum grade of C

title: (Alpha) Mentored Projects
description: Investigation of advanced problems, making use of faculty expertise for specific domains of work. (B) Design Project I; (C) Design Project II; (D) Research and Experiment Design. Junior or senior standing only. ME majors only. A-F only. instructor consent. Co-requisite: 481 for (B); 482 for (C); 483 for (D).

title: Special Topics in Mechanical Engineering
description: Specialized topics in thermosciences, mechanics, materials, systems, or design. consent.

title: Special Topics in Mechanical Engineering
description: Specialized topics in thermosciences, mechanics, materials, systems, or design. consent.

title: Project
description: Investigation of advanced problems in mechanical engineering design or development. Student must find faculty sponsor before registering. A-F only. senior standing.

title: Renewable Energy Engineering and Sustainability
description: Analysis of principles of operation of renewable energy systems, and its interactions with sustainability. Fundamentals of renewable energy production, storage, and distribution. consent.

title: Advanced Thermodynamics
description: Introduction to general principles of classical thermodynamics. Main topics include equilibrium conditions, thermodynamic relations, Legendre transformations, Maxwell relations, stability of thermodynamic systems, phase transitions, and critical phenomena. Graduate students only. A-F only. 311 or consent.

title: Introduction to Statistical Thermodynamics
description: Fundamentals of statistical thermodynamics. Main topics include entropy, Boltzmann law, thermodynamic driving forces, statistical mechanics, chemical equilibria, solutions and mixtures, and applications of statistical thermodynamics in biology, chemistry, physics, and nanoscience. A-F only. 311 or 611.

title: Advanced Aerodynamics
description: Advanced topics in aerodynamics, two- and three-dimensional wing theory, slender-body theory, lifting surface methods, vortex and wave drag, analytical and numerical methods, for computing unsteady aerodynamic behavior and introduction to flightdynamics. A-F only. 322 and 626, or consent.

title: Thermal Environmental Engineering
description: Physiological response to thermal environment, designs of passive and active cooling systems, student project. 417 or consent.

title: Boiling and Two-Phase Flow
description: Two-phase flow pattern and flow pattern maps; two-phase flow models (homogeneous, separate, drift flux, annular); laminar and turbulent film condensations; boiling incipience; pool boiling heat transfer; flow boiling heat transfer; critical heat flux (CHF). A-F only. 422 (or equivalent) or consent.

title: Biological Fluid Mechanics
description: Review of Newtonian fluid mechanics. Blood rheology and flow in elastic tubes. Murray’s Law and pulsatile flow propagation. Microcirculation dynamics and biological transport. Aquatic movement and comparative biological examples. 322 and 422, or consent.

title: Conduction Heat Transfer
description: Steady and unsteady heat conduction with and without heat sources in solids. Analytical, numerical, graphical, analog methods for solving heat conduction problems. 422.

title: Convection Heat Transfer
description: Heat transfer in laminar and turbulent boundary layers. Analogy between heat, momentum, mass transfer. 422 and 626.

title: Radiation Heat Transfer
description: Radiant interchange among surfaces. Gaseous radiation. Combined conduction, convection, and radiation heat transfer. 422 and senior standing.

title: Microfluidics and Nanofluidics
description: Introduction to fundamental understanding of fluid mechanics and transport phenomena at micro-nanoscale; electrokinetics; chemical separation; colloids and emulsions; biophysics; micro-nanofabrication.

title: Numerical Methods in Fluid Mechanics and Heat Transfer
description: Integration of ordinary differential equations. Finite difference solutions of partial differential equations with applications to conduction and convection. Introduction to finite element methods. 422, and either MATH 190 or ECE 160.
prerequisites: ME 422, and either MATH 190 or ECE 160

title: Viscous Flows
description: Formulation and properties of the Navier-Stokes equations; exact solutions; creeping flows; lubrication theory; laminar boundary layers; laminar stability, and transition to turbulence; turbulent boundary layers. 322.

title: Environmental Heat, Mass, and Momentum Transfer
description: Heat and mass transfer in Earth’s interior with applications to geothermal and petroleum reservoir engineering. 422 or consent.

title: Chemical Reactor Analysis and Design
description: Chemical kinetics with heat and mass transfer. Balance equations applied to selected ideal reactors. Departures from ideality. 422.

title: Renewable Energy Engineering I: Biomass
description: (1 Lec, 2 2-hr Lab) Experimental methods and theory of thermochemical biomass conversion: static and dynamic temperature and mass measurements, thermogravimetry, differential scanning calorimetry, GCMS and HPLC techniques. consent.

title: Rheology
description: Vector and tensor operations. Constutive equations. Generalized Newtonian fluids and linear viscoelastic fluids. Rheometry and experiments. Flow of suspensions. Advanced topics and rheology of polymers, food products, biomaterials and asphalt, laboratories. 626 or consent.

title: Advanced Materials Science
description: Properties of materials interpreted from the atomistic viewpoint. Crystal structure and defects. Thermodynamics of solids; phase transformations; experimental techniques. 331.

title: Advanced Transport Phenomena
description: Theory of momentum, heat, and mass transfer processes. Integral and differential conservation equations, constitutive laws, and interfacial boundary conditions. Dimensional analysis, perturbation theory, asymptotics, similarity, and Green’s function methodology. Applications to problems in engineering. Graduate students only. grade of C or better in 322 or 626, or consent.
prerequisites: grade of C or better in ME 322 or ME 626, or consent

title: Li-ion Battery Mechanistic Modeling: Principles and State of the Art
description: Electrochemistry, Li-ion batteries, electric vehicles, electrochemical grid storage. Repeatable one time. Engineering majors only. instructor consent.

title: Corrosion Theory
description: Application of electrochemical theory and materials science to corrosion and oxidation reactions. Effect of environment, especially marine. Cathodic protection, coatings, inhibitors, treatment of water systems. 331.

title: Fundamentals of Electrochemistry
description: Thermodynamics of cells, electrode kinetics, mass transfer by migration and diffusion, microelectrode techniques, forced convection, impedance, doublelayer structure, and absorbed intermediates in electrode processes. consent.

title: Mechanical Behavior of Engineering Materials
description: Mechanical property tests. Stress concentrations. Fracture mechanics; applications to materials failures and to selection of materials; emphasis on mechanical engineering applications. consent.

title: Clinically Driven Design and Development
description: Exploration of simple, cost-effective alternatives in medicine through different stages of concept generation, design analysis, and prototype validation and investigation of their commercialization potential. Graduate students only. 341 or consent.

title: Mechanics and Design Composites
description: Introduction to composites; anisotropic elasticity and laminate theory; hygrothermal effects; composite beams, columns, rods, plates, and shells; energy method; failure theories; joining of composites, computer-aided design in composites. 371 or consent.

title: Nanoscience and Nanotechnology
description: Science and applications of nanotechnology. Synthesis of nanostructures; nanoscale structure characterization by electron microscopy and Raman spectroscopy; electrical, thermal, and mechanical properties of nanostructures; fabrication of nanodevices; energy, environmental, and biological applications of nanomaterials. A-F only.

title: Nanosystems
description: Fabrication, design, and analysis of physical systems, sensors, and actuators at the nanoscale and microscale, including electrostatic and electromagnetic interactions, signal transduction, and measurements. Course work will focus on literature review and integration of current research. Engineering majors only. Graduate students only. (Spring only

title: Surface Phenomena
description: Fundamental and modern concepts of colloid and surface science. Main topics include surface thermodynamics, capillarity and wetting phenomena, surface forces, surfactants, and particles. 311 or consent.

title: Automatic Control
description: Linear optimal feedback control, discrete time optimal control, fundamentals of adaptive control, application to motion and force control of robot arms and manipulators. 451, ECE 351; or consent.

title: Guidance, Navigation and Control
description: Develop modern and advanced techniques in the design, development, and implementation of guidance, navigation, and control (GNC) systems for flight vehicles and other controllable dynamical systems. Graduate students only. A-F only. grade of C or better in all of the following: ME 271 or CEE 271; ME 375; MATH 244 or MATH 253A; MATH 302 or MATH 307; or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: grade of C or better in all of the following: ME 271 or CEE 271; ME 375; MATH 244 or MATH 253A; MATH 302 or MATH 307; or consent

title: Autonomous Marine Systems
description: Identifies the unique challenges faced by autonomous underwater and surface vehicles, and analyzes approaches to address those challenges. Topics include hydrodynamic vehicle modeling, propeller theory, subsystem integration, and motion control strategies. Graduate students only. MATH 307 or MATH 311 (or equivalent), and ECE 351 or ME 451 (or equivalent), or instructor consent. (
prerequisites: MATH 307 or MATH 311 (or equivalent), and ECE 351 or ME 451 (or equivalent), or instructor consent

title: Introduction to Fuel Cell Technology
description: Working principles of all major fuel cell types; fundamentals of proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells; state-of-the-art theoretical models and diagnostic technologies for PEM fuel cells. A-F only. 422 (or equivalent) or consent.

title: Energy Transport and Conversion at the Nanoscale
description: Basics of energy transport and conversion processes and emphasis on microscopic behaviors of energy carriers. Introduction to quantum mechanics and solid state physics. Graduate students only. Engineering majors only. A-F only. graduate standing or instructor consent. (Alt. years)

title: Shape Memory Alloys–Constitutive Modeling, Dynamics, and Nonlinear Control
description: Shape memory alloys; Shape Memory Effect (SME) and Superelasticity; hysteresis; applications in engineering, medical devices, and robotics; modeling and characterization; nonlineal control; finite element analyses. Engineering and computer science majors only. Graduate students only. (Fall only)

title: Continuum Mechanics
description: Cartesian tensors in mechanics, coordinate transformations, analysis of stress and strain, principal values, invariants, equilibrium and compatibility equations, constitutive relations, field equations. Problems in elasticity. A-F only. Recommended: 371 or CEE 370, or consent. (

title: Finite Element Analysis
description: Introduction to finite element analysis and design in mechanical engineering. Applications to machine design, vibrations, elasticity, heat transfer. 360, 371; or consent.

title: Advanced Dynamics
description: Lecture on rigidbody dynamics. Topics include: dynamical systems; motion representation and constraints; Newtonian mechanics; Lagrangian mechanics; Hamilton’s principle; stability analysis; introduction to multibody dynamics. 375 or equivalent, or consent.

title: High Growth Entrepreneurship
description: An interdisciplinary (JD-MBA) course examining legal, business, and technology issues related to building high growth companies. Student teams develop company feasibility reports and skills necessary to advise or build high growth businesses. Recommended: 531. Law, MBA, and ME students only. (Once a year) (

title: Air Pollution, Toxics, and Control
description: Chemical mechanisms of formation and destruction of major air pollutants, transport phenomena, and health and environmental impacts. Evolution of source and control technologies. Current and pending regulations and policies. CE, ECE, ME, and OE majors only. PHYS 170 and CHEM 171, or consent.

title: Seminar
description: Current problems in all branches of mechanical engineering. All graduate students are required to attend; registrants are expected to present talks. graduate standing.

title: Advanced Topics in Mechanical Engineering
description: Highly specialized topics in thermosciences, mechanics, materials, system, or design. consent.

title: Directed Reading or Research
description: Directed study on subject of mutual interest to student and a staff member. Student must find faculty sponsor before registering. Repeatable unlimited times. graduate standing.

title: Thesis Research
description: Thesis for degree of MS in mechanical engineering. Repeatable unlimited times. admission to candidacy and consent of thesis advisor.
prerequisites: admission to candidacy and consent of thesis advisor

title: Directed Instruction
description: Student assists in undergraduate classroom and/or project instruction under the direction and close supervision of faculty member. CR/NC only. admission to PhD candidacy or consent.
prerequisites: admission to PhD candidacy or consent

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times. candidacy for PhD in mechanical engineering.
prerequisites: candidacy for PhD in mechanical engineering

title: General Microbiology
description: Role of microorganisms; how they affect people, property, and the environment. A basic survey course covering broad aspects of biochemistry, genetics, molecular biology, and physiology; host-parasite relationships, public health, bacterial, mycotic and viral diseases; epidemiology; ecology of soils and water; environmental pollution; food microbiology; industrial applications at an introductory level. Not open to those with credit in 351 or equivalent.

title: Microbiology Laboratory
description: (2 2-hr Lab) Primarily for students in nursing and dental hygiene. 130 (or concurrent).

title: Research Ethics
description: Introduction to the ethical issues faced by individuals and institutions involved in scientific research. Based on case studies, students will discuss and write about ethical issues in research. Issues include humans and animals in research, mentoring, authorship, ownership of data, genetic technologies and record keeping. This course is designed for students with majors in the natural sciences. A-F only. BIOL 171 (or concurrent), or MATH 307 (or concurrent), or MATH 311 (or concurrent), or PHYS 170 (or concurrent), or CHEM 272 (or concurrent); or consent. (
prerequisites: BIOL 171 (or concurrent), or MATH 307 (or concurrent), or MATH 311 (or concurrent), or PHYS 170 (or concurrent), or CHEM 272 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Biology of Microorganisms
description: Anatomy, chemistry, physiology, genetics, development, and environmental interactions of microorganisms. BIOL 171 or equivalent, CHEM 272/272L; or consent. Co-requisite: 351L. Recommended: BIOL 275/275L.
prerequisites: BIOL 171 or equivalent, CHEM 272/CHEM 272L; or consent

title: Introductory Bioinformatics
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Introductory bioinformatics will provide a basic foundation of biological information (DNA, protein, genome and proteome) by using information technology (IT). A-F only. BIOL 275 and BIOL 275L, or consent. (Fall only)

title: Marine Microbiology
description: Evolution, ecology, biochemistry, genetics and physiology of marine bacteria by examining defined systems and organisms. BIOL 275/275L and BIOL 301 (or concurrent)/301L (or concurrent), and OCN 201; or 351/351L; or consent.
prerequisites: BIOL 275/BIOL 275L and BIOL 301 (or concurrent)/BIOL 301L (or concurrent), and OCN 201; or OCN 351/OCN 351L; or consent

title: Marine Microbiology Laboratory
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 401. BIOL 275/275L and BIOL 301 (or concurrent)/301L (or concurrent) and OCN 201; or 351/351L; and 401 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: BIOL 275/BIOL 275L and BIOL 301 (or concurrent)/BIOL 301L (or concurrent) and OCN 201; or OCN 351/OCN 351L; and OCN 401 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Microbial Physiology
description: Fundamental physiological and metabolic processes of bacteria; emphasis on growth, functions of cell structures, varieties of energy metabolism, metabolic regulation, and differentiation at the prokaryote level. 351.

title: Microbial Physiology Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) Components and metabolism of the bacterial cell; emphasis on techniques of analysis of metabolism and molecular structure. Co-requisite: 431.

title: Immunology
description: Structure and biological actions of antigens and antibodies; fundamentals of antibody synthesis; the relation of immunology to biology and medical sciences. 351 or BIOL 171, or consent. Recommended: BIOL 275/275L. (

title: Immunology Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) Basic exercises and experiments in immunology, immunochemistry, immuno-biology to illustrate principles of 461. 461 (or concurrent). (

title: Microbiology of Pathogens
description: Host-parasite relationships in microbial diseases of humans and animals with emphasis on bacterial pathogens. 351. Co-requisite: 463L or consent.

title: Microbiology of Pathogens Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) Characterization of bacterial pathogens. Isolation, identification, and diagnosis. 351L. Co-requisite: 463 or consent.

title: Bacterial Molecular Pathogenesis
description: Fundamental mechanisms of bacterial infectious diseases or pathogenesis at the molecular level. Emphasis on bacterial virulence and host-pathogen interactions. 351/351L or consent.

title: Bacterial Molecular Pathogenesis Laboratory
description: Modern techniques to study infectious diseases. Covers tissue culture and animal models to study virulence of extracellular and intracellular infecting bacteria, bacterial resistance mechanisms toward antibacterial drugs, and virulence factor assays. A-F only. 351 and 351L, 470 (or concurrent). (Fall only)

title: Bacterial Genetics
description: Genetic analysis and molecular basis of transmission replication, mutation, and expression of heritable characteristics in prokaryotes. 351 or BIOL 275, or consent. (

title: Bacterial Genetics Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) Techniques for study of transfer and expression of prokaryotic genes: transformation, conjugation, transposon mutagenesis, preparation and analysis of plasmid and chromosomal DNA. 475 (or concurrent). (

title: Microbes and Their Environment
description: Distribution, diversity, and roles of microorganisms in terrestrial, freshwater, and marine ecosystems. Importance of bacteria in pesticide degradation, bioremediation of oil spills, sewage treatment, biocontrol, food fermentation. BIOL 171 and CHEM 272, or consent.

title: Microbes and Their Environment Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) Techniques for study of interaction of microorganisms with and within their natural habitats; symbiosis between microorganisms and plants and animals; role of microorganisms in element cycling; food fermentation by bacteria. 485 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Virology
description: Basic principles of virus biology. Topics include methods for virus study, virus structure, replication, gene expression, pathogenesis and host response. 351 or BIOL 275, or consent.

title: Virology Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) General laboratory techniques and related theories in virology; including isolation, cell culture, assay, purification, and identification of viruses. 351/351L or BIOL 275/275L and 490 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: MICR 351/MICR 351L or BIOL 275/BIOL 275L and BIOL 490 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Molecular Cell Biology
description: Provide fundamental concepts and dynamic characteristics of the molecules of the prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell, their biosynthesis and regulation, and the mechanisms that regulate cellular activities. A-F only. basic course in cell and molecular biology, or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: basic course in cell and molecular biology, or consent

title: Molecular Biology and Genetics
description: Graduate-level basic course on molecular biology and genetics. Prepares students to understand advanced concepts in related subjects such as biochemistry, cell biology, cancer biology, immunology, plant genetics, and genomics. MBBE 402/BIOL 402 (with a minimum grade of B or higher), or with consent from instructor. (Alt. years: fall) (
prerequisites: MBBE 402/BIOL 402 (with a minimum grade of B or higher), or with consent from instructor

title: Research Ethics
description: Introduction to ethical issues faced by individuals and institutions involved in scientific research. Moral reasoning, humans and animals in research, mentoring, authorship, ownership of data and genetic technologies. MICR graduates only. A-F only. graduate standing in MICR or related field, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in MICR or related field, or consent

title: Advanced Immunology
description: Detailed reports and discussions on selected advanced topics and current research literature. 461 or consent. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Microbial Genome
