description: Advanced studies of Microbial genome: relation to functional genomics, structural genomics, and proteomics. A-F only. 351 and one 400-level MICR course, or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: MICR 351 and one MICR 400-level MICR course, or consent

title: Advanced Microbial Physiology
description: Selected topics. 431 or consent. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Advanced Marine Microbiology
description: Advanced studies of marine microorganisms in diverse habitats with consideration of applications of marine microbes, interactions with higher organisms, phylogeny and diversity, and past and current methods. A-F only. 351 and 401, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Advanced Virology
description: Detailed reports and discussions on selected advanced topics and current research literature. 463, 490, BIOC 441; or consent. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Regulations of Gene Expressions in Microorganisms
description: Use of bioinformatic tools to understand comparative genomics, metabolic pathways, and protein evolution. A-F only. 351 and one 400 level MICR course, or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: MICR 351 and one MICR 400 level MICR course, or consent

title: Bacterial Genetics
description: Directed study and discussion of research literature on bacterial and bacterial virus mutation, genetic recombination, evolution and control mechanisms. graduate standing; undergraduates that have taken 475 may register with consent. (Alt. years: spring)
prerequisites: graduate standing; undergraduates that have taken MICR 475 may register with consent

title: Advances in Microbial Ecology
description: Highlights in microbial ecology; interaction of microorganisms with abiotic and biotic components of their environments. Modern techniques for study of autecology and synecology of microorganisms. 485 or consent. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Host-Parasite Relationships
description: Mechanisms of pathogenicity of microorganisms and defense mechanisms of human and animal hosts. Review of contemporary literature. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Molecular and Cellular Bacterial Pathogenesis
description: Detailed examination of the molecular and cellular mechanisms of bacterial pathogenesis. Overview of key literature, synthesis of scientific problems into research proposals. 431, 463, or 470; or consent. (Alt. years: spring)
prerequisites: MICR 431, MICR 463, or MICR 470; or consent

title: Seminar
description: Required of graduate students. Repeatable unlimited times; only one credit will count toward the degree.

title: Research Literature Review
description: Review of primary literature in a selected area of microbiology. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. graduate status or consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Selected problems in microbiology. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Advanced Plant-Bacteria Interactions
description: Molecular biology, genomics, molecular genetics, and infection mechanisms of bacterial plant pathogens and symbionts. PEPS 606 (with a minimum grade of B or better) or consent. (
prerequisites: PEPS 606 (with a minimum grade of B or better) or consent

title: Special Topics in Microbiology
description: Selected topics in any aspect of microbiology. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Introduction to Physical Fitness
description: Hands-on participatory course following the Army’s physical fitness program. Classes conducted three days per week with Army ROTC cadets. Focus is on aerobic conditioning, muscular strength and endurance. Repeatable three times. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Military Science I
description: Introduces cadets to personal challenges and competencies critical for effective leadership; personal development of life skills such as goal setting, time management, physical fitness, and stress management related to leadership, officership, and the Army profession. Focus on developing basic knowledge and comprehension of Army Leadership Dimensions while understanding the ROTC program, its purpose in the Army, and its advantages for the student.

title: Introduction to Military Science I Lab
description: Practical application in adventure training, Army field craft, rifle marksmanship, land navigation, drill and ceremonies, physical training. Co-requisite: 101.

title: Introduction to Military Science II
description: Overviews leadership fundamentals such as setting direction, problem-solving, listening, presenting briefs, providing feedback and using effective writing skills. Explores leadership values, attributes, skills, and actions in the context of practical, hands-on, and interactive exercises. Cadre role models and building stronger relationships among cadets through common experience and practical interaction are critical.

title: Introduction to Military Science II Lab
description: Practical application in adventure training, Army field craft, rifle marksmanship, land navigation, drill and ceremonies, physical training. Co-requisite: 102.

title: Intermediate Military Science I
description: Explores creative and innovative tactical leadership strategies and styles through historical case studies and engaging in interactive student exercises. Cadets practice aspects of personal motivation and team building by planning, executing, and assessing team exercises. Focus is on continued development of leadership values and attributes through understanding of rank, uniform, customs and courtesies.

title: Intermediate Military Science II
description: Challenges of leading complex, contemporary operational environments. Dimensions of cross-cultural challenges of leadership in a constantly changing world are highlighted and applied to practical Army leadership tasks and situations. Cadets develop greater self awareness as they practice communication and team building skills, and tactics in real world scenarios. Provides a smooth transition to MSL 301.

title: ROTC Basic Camp
description: Four-week summer course conducted at Ft. Knox, Kentucky. Substitutes for ROTC basic course (101, 102, 201, and 202) and fulfills course requirement for admission to ROTC advanced courses. Credit will be given for 203 or basic courses, but not both. consent.

title: Leading Small Organizations I
description: (2 Lec, 2-hr Lab) Challenges cadets to study, practice, and evaluate adaptive leadership skills with demands of the ROTC Advanced Camp. Challenging scenarios related to small unit tactical operations will develop self-awareness and critical thinking skills. Cadets will receive systematic, specific feedback on their leadership abilities, and analyze/evaluate their leadership values, attributes, skills and actions. A-F only. 101, 102, 201, and 202; or 203; or consent.
prerequisites: MSL 101, MSL 102, MSL 201, and MSL 202; or MSL 203; or consent

title: Leading Small Organizations II
description: (2 Lec, 2-hr Lab) Intense situational leadership challenges to build awareness and skills in leading small units. Decision-making, persuading, and motivating team members under fire are explored, evaluated, and developed. Military operations are reviewed to prepare for the ROTC Advance Camp. Cadets apply principles of Law of Land Warfare, Army training, and motivation to troop leading procedures; and are evaluated on what they know and do as leaders. A-F only. 301 or consent.

title: ROTC Advanced Camp
description: Five-week summer field training exercise conducted at Fort Knox, Kentucky. Arduous and intensified leadership training is conducted throughout the five-week period. Required for U.S. Army commissioning. 302 and consent.

title: History of Military Warfare
description: Lecture/discussion on the art and science of warfare concentrating on U.S. military history from the Colonial Period to present. Generally restricted to Army ROTC students, requiring twenty pages of graded writing assignments. A-F only. consent.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Limited to military science students who have had at least one previous military science course for which a grade of B or higher was earned and a cumulative GPA of 2.0 or better. consent.

title: Fundamentals of Leadership
description: Introduces students to the fundamentals of leadership. Activities challenge students to connect theory to practice, develop positive relationships through application of effective leadership concepts for leader development, and team-building. A-F only.

title: Leadership Challenges and Goal Setting
description: (3 Lec, 2-hr Lab) Develops proficiency in planning, execution, and assessment of complex operations; students will learn to assess risk, make ethical decisions, function as a staff member, and provide leadership performance feedback to subordinates; emphasis on oral communication. A-F only. 302 or consent.

title: Transition to Lieutenant
description: (3 Lec, 2-hr Lab) Explores dynamics of leading in complex situations of current military operations. Examines differences in customs and courtesies, military law, principles of war, and rules of engagement in the face of international terrorism. Interaction with nongovernment organizations, civilians on the battlefield, and host nation support are examined and evaluated. Case studies, scenarios, and What Now, Lieutenant? exercises prepare cadets to lead as commissioned officers in the U.S. Army. A-F only. 401 or consent.

title: Advanced Military Research
description: Directs the student to conduct detailed research on a military topic and present to the department leadership plus assist MSL 400 series students on a battle analysis. Repeatable up to eight credits. Must be in Military Science and Leadership Program or Military Service member in junior or greater standing. departmental approval.

title: Cell and Molecular Biology
description: Integrated cell and molecular biology for life science majors. Modern advances in recombinant DNA technology. A-F only. C (not C-) or better in BIOL 171/171L and CHEM 272. (
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 171/BIOL 171L and CHEM 272

title: Research Ethics
description: Introduction to the ethical issues faced by individuals and institutions involved in scientific research. Based on case studies, students will discuss and write about ethical issues in research. Issues include humans and animals in research, mentoring, authorship, ownership of data, genetic technologies and record keeping. This course is designed for students with majors in the natural sciences. A-F only. BIOL 171 (or concurrent), or MATH 307 (or concurrent), or MATH 311 (or concurrent), or PHYS 170 (or concurrent), or CHEM 272 (or concurrent); or consent. (
prerequisites: BIOL 171 (or concurrent), or MATH 307 (or concurrent), or MATH 311 (or concurrent), or PHYS 170 (or concurrent), or CHEM 272 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Molecular Cell Biology I
description: Relationship between structure and function at macromolecular level. C (not C-) or better in BIOL 275/275L and CHEM 273, or consent. (
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 275/BIOL 275L and CHEM 273, or consent

title: Molecular Cellular Biology II
description: Cell structure and function. Structure, chemistry, and functions of organelles and macromolecules. C (not C-) or better in 407; or consent. (
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in MCB 407; or consent

title: Advanced Molecular and Cellular Biology Laboratory
description: (2 3-hr Lab) A laboratory to accompany 407 and 408. BIOL 407 (or concurrent) or BIOL 408 (or concurrent). (

title: Immunology
description: Structure and biological actions of antigens and antibodies; fundamentals of antibody synthesis; the relation of immunology to biology and medical sciences. MICR 351 or BIOL 171; or consent. Recommended: BIOL 275/275L. (

title: Immunology Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) Basic exercises and experiments in immunology, immunochemistry, immuno-biology to illustrate principles of 461. 461 (or concurrent). (

title: The Biology of Cancer
description: Integrative, in-depth focus on the genetics, cell biology, and molecular basis of cancer. Combination of classroom lectures and problem-based discussions in small groups. Addresses ethical implications of cancer research and treatment. A-F only. MCB or BIOL majors only. Senior standing or higher. BIOL 407 (or concurrent) and BIOL 408 (or concurrent) or consent. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: BIOL 407 (or concurrent) and BIOL 408 (or concurrent) or consent

title: Bacterial Genetics
description: Genetic analysis and molecular basis of transmission replication, mutation, and expression of heritable characteristics in prokaryotes. MICR 351 or BIOL 275, or consent. (

title: Bacterial Genetics Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) Techniques for study of transfer and expression of prokaryotic genes: transformation, conjugation, transposon mutagenesis, preparation and analysis of plasmid and chromosomal DNA. 475 (or concurrent). (

title: Biotechnology: Science and Ethical Issues
description: Introduction to the concepts, goals, ethical issues and consequences of biotechnology using real-life case studies of GMOs, cloning, DNA fingerprinting, gene therapy and genetical engineering. BIOL 171 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent. (
prerequisites: BIOL 171 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent

title: Essential Biochemistry
description: Introduction to basic concepts of cellular biochemistry and metabolic pathways as applied to nutritional, medicinal and environmental biochemistry. A-F only. (CHEM 152 or CHEM 272) with a minimum grade of C, or consent.
prerequisites: (CHEM 152 or CHEM 272) with a minimum grade of C, or consent

title: Molecular Biotechnology
description: General principles, applications, and recent advances of the rapidly growing science of biotechnology. Topics include impact of biotechnology on medicine, animal sciences, environment, agriculture, forensics, and economic and socio-ethical issues. C (not C-) or better in BIOL 275 or consent. (
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 275 or consent

title: Molecular Biotechnology Lab-Gene Editing by CRISPR/Cas9
description: (1-hr Lec, 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 401. Students learn advanced gene editing techniques, including CRISPR/Cas9 to engineer prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Repeatable one time. 304, or 375, or BIOL 275L, or BIOL 375L; or consent. Co-requisite: 401. (
prerequisites: MBBE 304, or MBBE 375, or BIOL 275L, or BIOL 375L; or consent

title: Principles of Biochemistry
description: Molecular basis of living processes in bacteria, plants and animals; emphasis on metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, proteins and nucleic acids. C (not C-) or better in BIOL 275/275L, CHEM 272 and CHEM 273; or consent. (
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 275/BIOL 275L, CHEM 272 and CHEM 273; or consent

title: Principles of Biochemistry Lab
description: (1 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles and techniques of biochemical laboratory. Teaches biochemistry laboratory methods as well as technical writing in the form of experimental reports. A-F only. (402 (or concurrent), BIOL 402 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C.
prerequisites: (MBBE 402 (or concurrent), BIOL 402 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C

title: Marine Functional Ecology and Biotechnology
description: Marine functional genomics, biodiversity of marine natural habitats, marine microbial communities and their ecological functions, interactions of marine microbes and their host, climate change and marine biodiversity, marine biotechnology. A-F only. OCN 201 or MICR 130, or consent. (Spring only) (

title: Molecular Cellular Biology II
description: Cell structure and function. Structure, chemistry, and functions of organelles and macromolecules. C (not C-) or better in BIOL 407; or consent. (
prerequisites: C (not C-) or better in BIOL 407; or consent

title: Food Engineering
description: Principles and applications of thermodynamics, electricity, fluid mechanics, heat transfer, psychrometry, and material and energy balances of food processing and preservation. (BIOL 171, CHEM 162 or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A, MATH 243 or MATH 253A, PHYS 151 or PHYS 170) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: (BIOL 171, CHEM 162 or CHEM 171 or CHEM 181A, MATH 243 or MATH 253A, PHYS 151 or PHYS 170) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Environmental Biochemistry
description: Biochemical and chemical principles of occurrence, distribution, biotic and abiotic conversion, fate, and impact of synthetic and natural molecules in the environment. Important pollutants will be used as case studies to illustrate the principles. A-F only. CHEM 152 or CHEM 272, and CHEM 162 or CHEM 171; or consent.
prerequisites: CHEM 152 or CHEM 272, and CHEM 162 or CHEM 171; or consent

title: Sensors and Instrumentation for Biological Systems
description: Design course focused on fundamentals of electronic interfacing, control and automation, including biological processes. Topics include sensor physics, basic instrumentation, digital communication, and programming of microcontrollers and other portable computer systems. (160, 211, and BE 350 or MATH 302 or MATH 307 or ECE 326) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (
prerequisites: (MBBE 160, MBBE 211, and BE 350 or MATH 302 or MATH 307 or ECE 326) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Synthetic Biology
description: Introduction to principles, tools, and applications of synthetic biology; molecular techniques and design/analysis of synthetic gene circuits, synthetic-biology parts/devices, CRISPRbased systems, engineered microbial cell factories, for industrial, agricultural, medical applications. A-F only. (PHYS 152 (or PHYS 272), BIOL 275/275L) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Alt. years: fall)
prerequisites: (PHYS 152 (or PHYS 272), BIOL 275/BIOL 275L) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Bioreactor Design and Analysis
description: Application of mass/energy balances and reaction kinetics for the design and analysis of bioreactors for microbial, plant, and animal cell cultures. ME 322 (with a minimum grade of C-) or BE 373 or CEE 320; or consent. (
prerequisites: ME 322 (with a minimum grade of C-) or BE 373 or CEE 320; or consent

title: Biotechnology for Teachers
description: Principles, methods, classical examples, recent development, benefits and concerns of modern biotechnology. BIOL 304 or equivalent.

title: Introduction to Bioinformatics Topics for Biologists
description: Focuses on the use of computational tools and approaches to analyze the enormous amount of biological data (DNA, RNA, protein) available today. A-F only. (BIOL 171 (or equivalent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: (BIOL 171 (or equivalent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent

title: Special Topics in MBBE
description: Study and discussion of special topics and problems in molecular biosciences and bioengineering. consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Supervised individual instruction in laboratory research problems in biochemistry, molecular and cellular biology, genomics, and genetics. Repeatable 3 times or up to 16 credits. Limited to qualified undergraduate students. A-F only.

title: Molecular Cell Biology
description: Provide fundamental concepts and dynamic characteristics of the molecules of the prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell, their biosynthesis and regulation, and the mechanisms that regulate cellular activities. A-F only. basic course in cell and molecular biology, or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: basic course in cell and molecular biology, or consent

title: Molecular Biology and Genetics
description: Graduate-level basic course on molecular biology and genetics. Prepares students to understand advanced concepts in related subjects such as biochemistry, cell biology, cancer biology, immunology, plant genetics, and genomics. 402/BIOL 402 (with a minimum grade of B or higher), or with consent from instructor. (Alt. years: fall) (
prerequisites: MBBE 402/BIOL 402 (with a minimum grade of B or higher), or with consent from instructor

title: Advanced Food Science I
description: Advanced topics in chemical and physical characteristics of foods as well as their role in human nutrition. Repeatable one time. A-F only. graduate student status with undergraduate courses in organic chemistry, microbiology, additional biological science, physics, and biochemistry. Basic knowledge of food science is expected; or consent. (
prerequisites: graduate student status with undergraduate courses in organic chemistry, microbiology, additional biological science, physics, and biochemistry

title: Molecular Biosciences Seminar
description: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems in plant physiology, biochemistry, and molecular biology. Repeatable three times. A-F only

title: Professional Development
description: Lecture/discussion targets students exiting from graduate degree programs and provides preparation as a career professional; topics include establishing a professional identity; CV and cover letters, job-seeking due diligence, and negotiation skills. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Plant Biochemistry
description: Comprehensive study of chemical constituents and biochemical processes unique to the plant kingdom with emphasis on selected aspects of current interest. A-F only. 402 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent.
prerequisites: MBBE 402 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent

title: Metabolic Engineering
description: Principles and methodologies of metabolic engineering. Concepts of metabolic networks. Establishment of metabolic flux analysis and metabolic control analysis. Systems biology framework for integration of mathematical modeling and global measurements at metabolite, protein and transcription levels. BIOL 275, MATH 311, and MICR 351; or consent.
prerequisites: BIOL 275, MATH 311, and MICR 351; or consent

title: Biological Instrumentation
description: System integration for computer-based control, automation, and study of biological systems. Topics include physical, chemical, and biological sensors, actuators, digital interfacing/communication, image analysis, and structured code for microcontrollers and other portable computers. consent. (

title: Molecular Diagnostics: Principles and Practices
description: Molecular diagnostics principles, comparative genomics, genome annotation and bio-informatics, phylogenetics, gene target selection, advanced primer, and probe design. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only or consent. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: DNA and Genetic Analysis
description: Combined lecture-lab for students interested in genetic analysis of humans, animals, and other species. Molecular techniques, such as PCR, DNA marker identifications, transgenics, expression analysis and functional genomics, are included. Open to non-majors. graduate standing or consent. (

title: Signal Transduction and Regulation of Gene Transcription
description: Lecture/discussion on molecular mechanisms involved in the transmission of regulatory signals from the cell surface to the nucleus. A-F only. undergraduate level biochemistry, molecular biology, biology, nutrition; or override/ consent by professor. (Fall only)
prerequisites: undergraduate level biochemistry, molecular biology, biology, nutrition; or override/ consent by professor

title: Molecular Plant–Fungal Interactions
description: Focuses on the actions of plant pathogenic fungi/ oomycetes and their host responses at the molecular and cellular level. Current genetic and genomic approaches to study plant-fungal interactions will be discussed. Graduate standing only. consent. (Every 2 years) (

title: Fermentation Biochemistry – Theory, Practice, Competency, and Application
description: Lecture/lab addresses fundamentals in fermentation biochemistry; theoretical and practical level. Explores the concepts of a start-up capital venture business as a project, moving a fermented product to production and into the marketplace. Graduate students only. A-F only. (375 or MBBE/BIOL 402 (or equivalent)) with a minimum grade of B. (Fall only)
prerequisites: (MBBE 375 or MBBE/BIOL 402 (or equivalent)) with a minimum grade of B

title: Methods in Plant Molecular Biology
description: (1 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Advanced methodology and research strategies. Hands-on laboratory training in basic and current molecular procedures for plant research. one of BIOC 481 or BIOL 407.

title: Advanced Bioinformatics Topics for Biologists
description: Teaches problem-solving with bioinformatic tools. Real-world problems will be provided and worked out, students encouraged to provide their own research problem where they require assistance. Graduate student must work on genomics research project requiring bioinformatic analysis, working knowledge of UNIX OS, Perl, Java or C. A-F only. (ICS 471 and ICS 491 and ICS 691 (or equivalent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: (ICS 471 and ICS 491 and ICS 691 (or equivalent)) with a minimum grade of B, or consent

title: Advanced Lab Techniques
description: (1 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Advanced laboratory techniques used in food science and human nutrition research. A-F only. graduate standing or consent and 402/402L, and FSHN 477; or BIOC 441. (
prerequisites: graduate standing or consent and MBBE 402/MBBE 402L, and FSHN 477; or BIOC 441

title: Advanced Special Topics in MBBE
description: Study and discussion of advanced special topics and problems in molecular biosciences and bioengineering. graduate standing or consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable up to 64 credits.

title: Thesis Research
description: CR/NC only.

title: Dissertation Research
description: CR/NC only.

title: Musical Meaning: How Music Shapes Identity
description: The role of music from Africa, Asia, and Hawai‘i in shaping and expressing culture in the U.S. Freshmen or sophomore standing only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Introduction to Music Literature
description: Elements, styles, and forms of music, from listener’s standpoint.

title: Music in World Cultures
description: Folk, popular, and art music from major regions of the world, with emphasis upon Asia and the Pacific; representative styles and regional characteristics.

title: Fundamentals of Music
description: Basic organization concepts in music and introduction to music theory. Learning through hands-on experience with creative activities in various media. Focused listening, composing original meolodies, utilizing technology to explore how music is created, basic notation.

title: University Chorus
description: Performance of choral literature from Renaissance to present. Previous choral experience not required. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: (Alpha) Class Instruction I
description: Basic principles of performance; relevant problems in literature. (B) voice; (C) piano; (D) guitar. A-F only. Cannot be audited.

title: (Alpha) Class Instruction II
description: Basic principles of performance; relevant problems in literature. (B) voice; (C) piano; (D) guitar. Repeatable in different sections. Cannot be audited. A-F only. 121 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Pacific Music Performance Class
description: Basic principles of performance of Pacific music. Relevant problems at elementary level. (B) slack key guitar; (C) ‘ukulele. Repeatable in different sections. 121D or consent for (B); 108 or consent for (C).
prerequisites: MUS 121D or consent for (B); MUS 108 or consent for (C)

title: First-Level Secondary Piano
description: Piano as secondary performance field; application of theory to problems in improvising, harmonizing, creating accompaniments, transposing, and sight-reading at keyboard. For music majors. A-F only. consent. Co-requisite: 281 or consent.

title: First-Level Secondary Piano
description: Piano as secondary performance field; application of theory to problems in improvising, harmonizing, creating accompaniments, transposing, and sight-reading at keyboard. Continuation of 125. For music majors. A-F only. 125 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Asian Music Performance Class
description: Basic principles of performance of Asian music. Relevant problems in literature at elementary level. (B) koto; (C) shamisen; (E) shakuhachi. Cannot be audited. consent.

title: (Alpha) Asian Music Performance Class
description: Basic principles of performance of Asian music. Relevant problems in literature at elementary level. (B) koto; (C) shamisen; (D) South Indian singing; (E) shakuhachi. Cannot be audited. consent.

title: Percussion Techniques
description: Fundamental performance techniques, materials, and teaching skills on percussion instruments for students preparing to teach instrumental music. A-F only.

title: Brass Techniques
description: Fundamental performance techniques, materials, and teaching skills on brass instruments for students preparing to teach instrumental music. A-F only.

title: String Techniques
description: Fundamental performance techniques, materials, and teaching skills on string instruments for students preparing to teach instrumental music. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Woodwind Techniques
description: Fundamental performance techniques, materials, and teaching skills on woodwind instruments for students preparing to teach instrumental music. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Recital Attendance
description: Attendance at approved departmental concerts. Required of all music majors (BMus, six semesters; BA and BEd, four semesters). Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.

title: Second-Level Secondary Piano
description: Continuation of 125–126; increased emphasis on piano literature up to intermediate level. MUS majors only. A-F only. 126 or consent.

title: Second-Level Secondary Piano
description: Continuation of 225. A-F only. 225 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Elementary Applied Music, Ethnic
description: Instruction in instrumental performance at elementary level. Study of works representative of literature. (B) koto; (C) shamisen; (E) Hawaiian chant; (F) shakuhachi; (I) other. Repeatable for four semesters. A-F only. audition or consent.

title: (Alpha) Applied Music, Western
description: For non-majors or music majors in secondary performance fields. Individual instruction in solo vocal or instrumental performance at elementary level. Representative works. (B) voice; (C) piano; (D) organ; (F) recorder; (G) classical guitar; (H) violin; (I) viola; (J) cello; (K) double bass; (M) flute; (N) oboe; (O) clarinet; (P) bassoon; (Q) saxophone; (R) trumpet; (S) French horn; (T) trombone; (U) tuba; (X) euphonium; (Y) percussion; (Z) other. Repeatable for four semesters. A-F only.audition or consent.

title: (Alpha) Applied Music, Western
description: For music majors or intended majors. Individual instruction in solo or instrumental performance at first performance level. Representative works. Weekly repertoire laboratory required. (B) voice; (C) piano; (D) organ; (G) classical guitar; (H) violin; (I) viola; (J) cello; (K) double bass; (M) flute; (N) oboe; (O) clarinet; (P) bassoon; (Q) saxophone; (R) trumpet; (S) French horn; (T) trombone; (U) tuba; (X) euphonium; (Y) percussion; (Z) other. Repeatable for six semesters. A-F only.audition.

title: Creative Applications of Music Technology
description: Introductory laboratory experience. Teaches musicians fundamental technology concepts through creative projects. Exposes students to a variety of music and audio software. A-F only. music majors or minors or consent.
prerequisites: music majors or minors or consent

title: Introduction to Music Education
description: Survey of American education, with an emphasis on music learning, teaching and philosophy, school structure and governance, diversity and multi-cultural education, and professional ethics. Supervised clinical and field experiences required. MUS majors only. A-F only. (Alt. years)

title: Elementary Music in Action
description: (3 Lec, 1 1-hr Lab) Musical concepts, philosophy and pedagogy: use of media, singing, movement, and instruments; as well as resources for an active elementary music classroom. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Voice Function and Singing Styles
description: Students will study how the singing voice works in various styles, including classical, musical theater, jazz, choral, and pop/ rock. Students will learn historical contexts, aural characteristics, and musical vocabulary through lecture, discussion, and listening. (Fall only) (

title: History of Western Music to 1750
description: Development of Western music from its origins to 1750. Styles, schools, composers. 282 or consent.

title: History of Western Music After 1750
description: Development of Western music from 1750 to the present. Styles, schools, composers. 282 or consent.

title: World of Music: Asia/Pacific
description: Study of music as social process, sound system, aesthetics, and world view. Emphasis on Hawai‘i, Asia, and the Pacific and the ways music creates links across the region and among people. ability to read music and one introductory music course with a minimum grade of C (108, 114, 121-126, 155-158) or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: ability to read music and one introductory music course with a minimum grade of C (MUS 108, MUS 114, MUS 121-MUS 126, MUS 155-MUS 158) or consent

title: Basic Theory and Aural Skills
description: Fundamentals of music theory, notation, sight-singing, and dictation. A-F only. 108 or consent.

title: Theory I

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

description: This second level course builds on the knowledge and skills gained in the first level and focuses on professional responsibilities in nursing practice and education. NURS majors only. A-F only. 200. (Spring only)

A-F only. admission to the School of Nursing and Dental Hygiene, or consent. Co-requisite: 210L, 211, and 212.
prerequisites: admission to the School of Nursing and Dental Hygiene, or consent

description: Clinical course focuses on a health promotion model of care, assessment, and communication skills. Introduces nurse’s roles, code of ethics, and evidence-based practice. NURS majors only. CR/NC only. Co-requisites: 210, 211, and 212.

prerequisites: admission to the School of Nursing and Dental Hygiene, or consent

NURS majors only. A-F only. admission to the School of Nursing and Dental Hygiene, or consent. Co-requisite: 210, 210L, and 211.
prerequisites: admission to the School of Nursing and Dental Hygiene, or consent

NURS majors only. A-F only. 210, 210L, and 212. Co-requisites: 220 and 220L. (Spring only)

title: Health and Illness I Lab

Nursing skills are integrated into clinical experiences. NURS majors only. CR/NC only. 210, 210L, 211, and 212. Co-requisite: 213 and 220.

title: Introduction to Evidence Based Practice and Health Promotion
description: Provides an introduction to the HSNC Competencies and spiraling of concepts and is based on the assumption of student responsibility for learning. Emphasis on writing instruction, and research evidence to support nursing care. NURS majors only. A-F only.

description: Focuses on the basic concepts and applications of statistics as applied to nursing research. NURS majors only. A-F only. (Summer only)

title: Women, Newborn, and Family Health
description: Nursing care and health promotion for women, newborn, and families in acute care and community settings. Utilization of family theories and assessment tools for providing culturally sensitive, client-centered care. NURS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. 220 and 220L and 213.

title: Women, Newborn, and Family Health Lab
description: Nursing care and health promotion for women, newborn, and families in acute and community settings. Utilization of family theories and assessment tools when providing culturally sensitive, family-centered care. Emphasis on teaching writing for the profession. NURS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. CR/NC only. 220 and 220L and 213.

title: Child and Family Health
description: Nursing care and health promotion for children and families. Emphasis on concepts related to the delivery of familycentered holistic, culturally sensitive, therapeutic nursing care to children and families in acute care and community settings. NURS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. 213 and 220 and 220L. Co-requisite: 322L.

title: Child and Family Health Lab
description: Nursing care and health promotion lab for children and families. Application of concepts related to the delivery of family-centered holistic, culturally sensitive, therapeutic nursing care to children and families in acute care and community settings. NURS majors only. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. 213 and 220 and 220L. Co-requisite: 322.

title: Contemporary Ethical Issues in Health Care
description: Explore contemporary ethical issues and their legal implications in health care. Focus on decision-making in professional practice and social policy formation. open to non-nursing majors with consent.
prerequisites: open to non-nursing majors with consent

title: Gerontology: Its Nursing Implications
description: Explores attitudes toward the aged, biological and psychological aspects, ethnicity, sexuality, nutritional problems, community resources, other related topics. open to non-nursing majors with consent.
prerequisites: open to non-nursing majors with consent

title: Nursing in the Multicultural Milieu
description: Relates values, beliefs, attitudes, family organization, lifestyles, and health practices in different ethnic groups to health-care and nursing practice. open to non-nursing majors with consent.
prerequisites: open to non-nursing majors with consent

title: Health and Illness III
description: Focuses on complex situations requiring strong recognition skills, and rapid decision making. The evidence base supporting assessment and nursing intervention is explored. NURS majors only. A-F only. 320 and 320L or departmental approval. Co-requisite: 360L.
prerequisites: NURS 320 and NURS 320L or departmental approval

title: Health and Illness III Lab
description: Clinical course focuses on complex situations requiring application of strong recognition skills and rapid decision making. Evidence base supporting assessment and nursing intervention is explored. NURS majors only. CR/NC only. 320 and 320L. Co-requisite: 360.

title: Health Education and Promotion
description: Provides an overview of the concepts and application of health education and health promotion theories and principles as applies to individuals, groups, and the larger public. open to non-nursing majors with consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: open to non-nursing majors with consent

title: Professionalism in Nursing II
description: Continuation of 211. Focus is on current issues in nursing and health care and nursing roles. Principles of organizational structure, leadership, decision-making, priority setting, and change will be discussed. NURS majors only. A-F only. 320 and 320L, or departmental approval. Co-requisite: 360 and 360L.
prerequisites: NURS 320 and NURS 320L, or departmental approval

title: Introduction to Nursing Research
description: Introduction to the research process and an understanding of the applicability of the scientific approach to nursing. Analysis and resolution of contemporary medical ethics issues in research and general nursing practice are primary focuses. Repeatable one time. NURS majors only. A-F only. college-level statistics course.

title: Principles of Nursing Research and Evidence-Based Practice
description: (Lec) Introduces the process for research application and evidence-based practice. Includes: EBP questions, evidence sources, literature search and synthesis, levels and quality of evidence, and determination of clinical significance. Focus on contemporary medical ethics issues. NURS majors only. A-F only..

title: Directed Reading/Research I, II
description: Limited to juniors and seniors in nursing.

title: Student Ambassador Program
description: Focuses on professional leadership development, mentorship, and professional skills for nurses. Students learn to be representatives between the Department of Nursing and alumni, prospective students, and the general public. NURS majors only. A-F only. one semester as a Nursing Student Ambassador.
prerequisites: one semester as a Nursing Student Ambassador

title: NCLEX Review
description: Overview of the NCLEX-RN licensure examination and regular, systematic practice in taking multiple choice examinations. open to non-nursing majors with consent.
prerequisites: open to non-nursing majors with consent

title: Cooperative Education in Nursing
description: A two-semester course with seminar in professional role development in addition to paid work experience in nursing at a local agency. Upper division NURS majors only. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. 360, 360L, and faculty approval.

title: Summer Internship
description: Summer practicum experience for students to learn the role of the professional nurse by building on previously learned knowledge and skills in the nursing program. Repeatable two times. NURS majors only. CR/NC only. 360 and 360L, or consent. (Summer only)

title: Complementary and Alternative Therapies
description: Survey of complementary and alternative therapies used for health promotion of individuals and groups. NURS majors only. A-F only. open to non-nursing majors with consent.
prerequisites: open to non-nursing majors with consent

title: Veteran Healthcare, Education, and Cultural Needs
description: Provides a broad overview of the Veteran-Military population and their unique culture, educational, and health care needs. Open to non-nursing majors. A-F only.

title: Gerontology, Health Care, and the Law (Elder Law)
description: Provides a basic foundation for studies at the intersection of gerontology, health care, and the law and places an emphasis on proactive and preventive law for older adults in society. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (

title: Community, Public, and Global Health Nursing
description: Theory course focuses on community, public, and global health nursing with an emphasis on strategies applied to improve health and decrease health inequities at the local as well as national and international levels. NURS majors only. A-F only. 360, 360L, and 363. Co-requisite: 450L, 465, and 465L.

title: Community, Public, and Global Health Nursing Lab
description: Clinical course focuses on community, public, and global health nursing emphasizing application of strategies to improve health and decrease health inequities at the local, national, and international levels. Emphasis on oral and writing instruction. NURS majors only. CR/NC only. 360, 360L, and 363. Co-requisite: 450, 465, and 465L.

title: Population Health Nursing
description: Theory on population and global health nursing with emphasis on analysis of strategies to address concepts of health disparities, inequity, social justice issues, and ethics which impact health outcomes of populations. Nursing majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. 364 (or concurrent). Co-requisite: 451L.

title: Population Health Nursing Lab
description: Clinic on population health nursing emphasizing application of strategies to address health disparities, inequity, social justice issues, and ethics impacting population health outcomes. Emphasis on oral and writing instruction. Nursing majors only. A-F only. 364 (or concurrent). Co-requisite: 451.

title: Cultural Aspects of Health Management in Populations Indigenous to Hawai‘i, the Pacific, and Asia
description: Focuses on cultural aspects that influence health management in indigenous populations of Hawai‘i, the Pacific, and Asia, with an emphasis on development of culturally sensitive strategies to promote and improve health management. NURS majors only. Undergraduate majors only. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Genetics and Genomics in Nursing Practice
description: Fundamentals of genetics and genomics, including principles of inheritance in humans, cellular function, mutations, epigenetics, and implications for health and disease. Includes overview of topics involving genetics/genomics in clinical settings and health care delivery. NURS majors only. A-F only. 212, 220, 220L, and 363.

title: Complex Nursing and Leadership
description: Theory course emphasizes the judgments, knowledge, and skills necessary for nursing practice, including case management and quality management experiences. The experience focuses on complex clinical judgments, interdisciplinary team functioning, and leadership. NURS majors only. A-F only. 364 (or concurrent) and 450 and 450L, or consent. Co-requisite: 460L.
prerequisites: NURS 364 (or concurrent) and NURS 450 and NURS 450L, or consent

title: Complex Nursing and Leadership Lab
description: Clinical course emphasizes application of knowledge and skills for nursing practice, including case management and quality management experiences. Focuses on complex clinical judgments, interdisciplinary team functioning, and leadership. Emphasis on writing instruction. NURS majors only. CR/NC only. 364 (or concurrent) and 450 and 450L, or consent. Co-requisite: 460.
prerequisites: NURS 364 (or concurrent) and NURS 450 and NURS 450L, or consent

title: Advanced Pathophysiology
description: Provides an advanced understanding of pathophysiologic mechanisms underlying human illness across the lifespan. Provides a foundation for formulating clinical decisions and therapeutic plans of care to promote disease prevention and health promotion. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Community Health Nursing for Executive RN
description: Theory focuses on community health nursing with an emphasis for the Executive RN on strategies applied to improve health and decrease health inequities at the local as well as national and international levels. NURS majors only. A-F only. 301 and 306. Co-requisite: 363 and 462L.

title: Community Health Nursing for Executive RN Field Work
description: Field work focuses on community health nursing with an emphasis for the Executive RN on strategies applied to improve health and decrease health inequities at the local as well as national and international levels. NURS majors only. CR/NC only. 301 and 306. Co-requisite: 363 and 462. (Fall only)

title: Psychiatric-Mental Health Nursing
description: Examination of human responses to psychiatric and mental illness in relation to physiologic, psychological, social, cultural, and environmental concepts. Emphasis on self-awareness, therapeutic communication, and holistic, individualized health-related outcomes. NURS majors only. A-F only. 360, 360L, and 363. Co-requisite: 465L, 450, and 450L.

title: Psychiatric-Mental Health Nursing Lab
description: Application of the nursing process involving human responses to psychiatric and mental illness in relation to physiologic, psychological, social, cultural, and environmental concepts. Emphasis on self-awareness, therapeutic communication, and holistic, individualized health-related outcomes. NURS majors only. CR/NC only. 360, 360L, and 363. Co-requisite: 465, 450, and 450L.

title: Nursing Honors Research Project
description: Involves directed, mentored research study for SONDH Honors students with their honors advisor. The course grade depends on meeting objectives negotiated each course semester. Repeatable three times. NURS majors only. A-F only. acceptance into the Honors Program.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Planned individualized study or research in specialized area related to interprofessional collaborative practice. Repeatable one time. Senior undergraduate NURS students only. consent.

title: Professionalism in Nursing
description: Introduction to history of nursing and leaders in the field. Will explore contemporary nursing issues and research. Strategies to foster adherence to a professional code of ethics in practice will be examined. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Pathophysiology
description: Web-enhanced on pathophysiologic concepts as a basis of illness and injury and the corresponding spectrum of human response, which serves as a foundation for the formulation of clinical decisions and care planning. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Pharmacology for Nursing Practice
description: Essential principles of pharmacology using a pathophysiologic approach with emphasis on administering medications and evaluating their effects. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. A-F only. Co-requisite: 501, 502, 504, 504L, 505, 505L. (Once a year)

title: Health Assessment
description: Concepts/theories of health assessment, data collection, and analysis to distinguish between health/wellness, risk factors or health deviations across the lifespan. Attention to principles of communication and interviewing. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. A-F only. Co-requisite: 501, 502, 503, 504L, 505, 505L. (Once a year)

title: Health Assessment Lab
description: Application of assessment skills in dry lab and clinical settings, with attention to principles of communication, interviewing and physical examination skills. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 501, 502, 503, 504, 505, 505L. (Once a year)

title: Foundations of Nursing Science
description: Nursing process and scientific based nursing interventions to meet basic human needs using basic psycho-motor skills to support assessment, intervention, and evaluation activities. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. A-F only. Co-requisite: 505L. (Once a year)

title: Foundations of Nursing Science and Practice Lab
description: Application of the nursing process and scientific based nursing interventions to meet basic human needs using basic psycho-motor skills to support assessment, intervention, and evaluation activities. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 505. (Once a year)

title: Bio-Behavioral Health Nursing
description: Biopsychosocial theories of human behavior related to function, alteration, and/or disruption of mental processes; reviews current knowledge related to nursing care, psychiatric treatment/psychosocial rehabilitation of identified mentally ill adults/children and their families. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. A-F only. Co-requisite: 507L. (Once a year)

title: Bio-Behavioral Health Nursing Clinic/Lab
description: Application of current knowledge regarding human behavior related to function, alteration, and/or disruption of mental processes; applies current knowledge related to nursing care, psychiatric treatment/psychosocial rehabilitation of identified mentally ill adults/children and their families. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 507. (Once a year)

title: Nursing Care of Childbearing Families
description: Introduction to the theoretical concepts of holistic nursing care of the perinatal family. Women’s and men’s health issues are discussed. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. A-F only. Co-requisite: 508L. (Once a year)

title: Nursing Care of Childbearing Families Clinical/Lab
description: Application of the nursing care of the mother and family. The student will apply clinical and theoretical concepts of holistic nursing care for women experiencing customary and complicated perinatal processes. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 508. (Once a year)

title: Nursing Care of Children and Families
description: Examines the bio/psycho/social response of the child and family to health and illness, as well as nursing care for acute and chronic conditions. Lab course taken concurrently. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. A-F only. Co-requisite: 509L. (Once a year)

title: Nursing Care of Children and Families Clinical/Lab
description: Accompanies and supports Pediatric Nursing to provide educational experiences in the hospital and outpatient or community settings. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 509. (Once a year)

title: Acute Care Nursing
description: Addresses the bio/psycho/social human health response to a wide range of conditions. Health promotion, risk reduction and disease detection and nursing care treatment in the acute setting will be covered. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. A-F only. Co-requisite: 513L. (Once a year)

title: Acute Care Nursing Lab
description: Application of the bio/psycho/social human health response to a wide range of conditions. Application of health promotion, risk reduction and disease detection and nursing care treatments in the acute care setting. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into GEPN only. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 513. (Once a year)

title: Clinical Immersion to Nursing Practice
description: Examination of continuity of care for clients with complex needs. Emphasis on application of leadership, management, and quality improvement in the clinical setting. NURS majors only or consent. Admission to GEPN only. A-F only. Co-requisite: 517L.

title: Clinical Immersion to Nursing Practice Lab
description: Deliver comprehensive nursing care to clients with complex needs in community and/or acute care settings. Leadership, management, and quality improvement competencies are stressed. NURS majors only or consent. Admission to GEPN only. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 517.

title: Introduction to Community and Public Health Nursing
description: Introduces community and public health nursing with an emphasis on application to nursing practice in the community and public health settings. NURS majors only or consent. Admission to GEPN only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Introduction to Community and Public Health Nursing Lab
description: Application of health promotion, risk reduction, and disease prevention and detection and nursing care treatments in the community setting. NURS majors only or consent. Admission to GEPN only. CR/NC only. (Spring only)

title: Epidemiology for Advanced Nursing
description: Introduction to epidemiologic principles and methods, with an emphasis on its application to nursing practice. NURS majors only. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Health Promotion and Disease Prevention
description: Teaching and learning concepts applied to health promotion and prevention of common health and illness conditions with culturally diverse individuals, families, groups, and communities. Includes didactic (30 hrs) and fieldwork (45 hrs). Repeatable one time. classified graduate student status in the SONDH.
prerequisites: classified graduate student status in the SONDH

title: Applied Biostatistics and Epidemiology for Nurses in Advance Practice
description: Investigation of epidemiologic and biostatistical methods for advance practice nurses within healthcare settings and complementary roles of epi/biostatistics in shaping advance nurse practice. Application of epi/biostatistical approaches to the design and analysis of DNP projects. NURS majors only or permission. A-F only.

title: Genetics and Health Care
description: Addresses the scientific, psycho-social, ethical, cultural, and spiritual issues surrounding genetic disease, genetic testing, and living with an inherited condition. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent.

title: Health Politics & Policy
description: Review of contemporary national health policies, issues and concerns; and international comparison of health policy evolution; includes didactic and 45 hours of fieldwork experience learning.

title: Psychiatric-Mental Health Assessment and Diagnosis
description: Identification and synthesis of pertinent biopsychosocial and cultural data to complete advanced psychiatric-mental health assessments and diagnoses. NURS majors only.

title: Advanced Assessment and Clinical Reasoning
description: Provides a framework for the development of advanced skills for systematic and comprehensive data collection, organization, precise recording, accurate assessment and communication of data reflecting the biopsychophysical status of individuals across the life span. NURS majors only or consent. A-F only.

title: Advanced Assessment and Clinical Reasoning Lab
description: Clinical lab and practicum for advanced practice nursing. Emphasis on integration of knowledge, skills and outcome evaluation. NURS majors only or consent. A-F only.

title: Pathophysiology for Advanced Practice
description: Provides an understanding of normal physiological mechanisms and pathological processes to serve as a foundation for clinical assessment, decision making, and clinical management across the lifespan. NURS majors only or consent. enrollment as a classified student in a graduate program in the SONDH.
prerequisites: enrollment as a classified student in a graduate program in the SONDH

title: Clinical Skills and Procedures for Advanced Practice Nursing
description: Clinical laboratory that focuses on clinical skills and procedures performed by advanced practice nurses (nurse practitioners and/or clinical nurse specialists). Topics will vary by section and semester. NURS and NURD majors only. CR/NC only.

title: Mental Health in Primary Care
description: Augment APRN students’ understanding, evaluation, treatment plan development, and competence to care for patients with mental health and psychiatric disorders treatment plans across the lifespan in the primary care settings. NURS majors only or consent. consent.

title: Human Responses to Acute and Chronic Illness-A
description: The first of two courses that focuses on the delivery of advanced practice nursing in the assessment, diagnosis, and management of common acute and chronic adult health problems in the acute care setting. NURS majors only. A-F only. 612, 612L, and 613; no waiver. (Once a year)
prerequisites: NURS 612, NURS 612L, and NURS 613; no waiver

title: Human Responses to Acute and Chronic Illness-B
description: Second of two courses that focuses on the delivery of advanced practice nursing in the assessment, diagnosis and management of common acute and chronic adult health problems in the acute care setting. NURS majors only. A-F only. 612, 612L, and 613; no waiver. (Once a year)
prerequisites: NURS 612, NURS 612L, and NURS 613; no waiver

title: Emerging Diseases & Implications for Advanced Nursing Practice
description: Selected emerging diseases are examined within historical context, known science (past and present) and societal factors that influence prevention, detection, treatment and containment strategies. Considerations for advanced public health nursing practice are identified and examined. NURS majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Nursing Research, Theory, and Evidence-Based Practice
description: Examination of theory, research, and evidence-based inquiry to support evidence-based practice among MS prepared nurses. enrollment as a classified student in the graduate degree program in SONDH.
prerequisites: enrollment as a classified student in the graduate degree program in SONDH

title: Acute and Episodic Care Management
description: Diagnosis and management of health and illness with emphasis on clients with common acute/episodic conditions seen in context of family and community. Advanced practice nurse-client relationship, practice roles, and culturally relevant care are included. NURS majors only or consent. A-F only. 613 and 629.

title: Psychiatric-Mental Health Issues and Roles
description: Exploration of major issues and roles in advanced practice psychiatric-mental health nursing. NURS majors only or consent.

title: Psychopharmacology
description: Survey of biopsychological bases of and biotherapies for major mental disorders, including the schizophrenias, affective and personality disorders, pediatric and geriatric problems, and neurological dysfunctions with appropriate applications to health care. NURS majors only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Adolescent and Family PsychiatricMental Health Care
description: Seminar on theory/ research in advanced psychiatric-mental health nursing of adolescents and families representing diverse populations. Emphasis on developmental and nursing theories, evidence-based practice, therapeutic modalities and disease management of psychiatric illness. 611 (or concurrent) or consent. (Once a year)

title: Advanced Nursing Roles
description: Provides students with an understanding of different roles of the advanced professional nurse; an ability to proactively manage the environment of their specialty practice; includes 45 hours of field work experience. A-F only.

title: Advanced Population Health Nursing
description: Introduction to the core competencies, key theoretical models and concepts that guide advanced population health nursing. The student will initiate their professional portfolio, which must be completed during the last semester of the MS program. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Child/Family Health Assessment
description: (2 Sem, 8-hr Lab) Opportunity to develop specialized clinical competence in assessment of children as a basis for the development of clinical specialization. Development of the individual’s potential toward health maintenance functioning. NURS majors only or consent.

title: Child Health: Special Health Needs
description: Provides a theoretical basis required for specialized clinical competence in adapting recent findings on child/parent assessments, social and health risk indicators, the role of environment, and multidisciplinary settings in the care of pediatrics. NURS majors only. A-F only. 612/612L, 633 and 634; or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: NURS 612/NURS 612L, NURS 633 and NURS 634; or consent

title: Pharmacology for Nurses in Advanced Practice
description: Prepares APNs to evaluate, monitor, and prescribe pharmaceuticals to treat acute and chronic illness across lifespan. Emphasis on drug indications, mechanisms of action, clinical efficacy, adverse effects, interactions, monitoring, education, and cost effectiveness. Enrollment as a classified student in a SONDH graduate degree program. Repeatable unlimited times. NURS majors only or consent. 613 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Introduction to Information Technology in Healthcare
description: Introduction to the use of information systems in healthcare. Selected information systems and data sets are explored with application of results to various patient populations and clinical practice settings.

title: Advanced Psychopharmacology Across the Lifespan
description: Examines the legal, ethical and therapeutic role of the psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioner (PMHNP) in prescribing psychotropic medications for diverse groups of individuals across the lifespan. Diverse biopsychosocial perspectives will be considered. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Therapeutic Modalities
description: Therapeutic modalities used in advanced practice psychiatric-mental health nursing with individuals, families, and groups representing culturally diverse populations. NURS majors only. 611.

title: Child Health: Promotion and Maintenance
description: Presents normal developmental, physiological and social needs of children within the context of family; then focuses on the management of common acute and chronic illnesses of children. NURS majors only or consent. 612/612L, 613, and 629.

title: Child Health: Advanced Pediatric Acute/Chronic Care
description: Focuses on the evaluation of pediatric clients with higher acuity and more complex management issues. Emphasizes critical analysis of evidence based research in pediatric health care. NURS majors only or consent. Admission into the PNP and FNP program; 612/612L, and 633.
prerequisites: Admission into the PNP and FNP program; NURS 612/NURS 612L, and NURS 633

title: Women’s Health: Promotion and Maintenance
description: Provides a foundation of concepts necessary to maintain and promote women’s health, including developmental, physiological and social needs of women of all ages and the management of common health problems and concerns specific to women. NURS majors only or consent. 612/612L, 613, and 629.

title: Women’s Health: Special Problem
description: (2 Sem, 12-hr Lab) Focuses upon assessment and intervention of at-risk and high-risk women during pregnancy, interconception, and the menopausal years. Emphasizes critical analysis of research in pregnancy, family planning, and common gynecological problems. 635 or consent. NURS majors only or consent.

title: Child and Adolescent PsychiatricMental Health
description: Theory and research in advanced practice psychiatric-mental health nursing of children and adolescents representing culturally diverse populations. Emphasis on growth and development, assessment and diagnosis, and therapeutic modalities. NURS majors only. A-F only. 620 (or concurrent).

title: Disciplinary Knowledge I
description: Exploration of a variety of philosophies of science and examination of factors influencing the development of nursing theory and the emergence of nursing as a discipline. NURS majors only.

title: Chronic Illness Management
description: Management of chronic illness using selected health care systems in culturally diverse communities. Management includes practice, consultation, education, research, and evaluation. NURS majors only or consent. 612/612L, 613, and 629.

title: Advanced Nursing in the Global Health Environment
description: Exploration and analysis of key global health topics of concern for APNs. A-F only.

title: Health Care Technology and Informatics
description: Introduction to the field of health care technology and informatics for clinicians through the application of health care information systems. Open to students in other healthcare fields by permission. A-F only.

title: Health Law
description: Introduction to medical jurisprudence, medical malpractice, informed consent, health care decisions, medical ethics, the health care industry, managed care, financing health care, and the role of government in health care. LAW majors only; NURS DNP majors only (

title: Advanced Psychiatric-Mental Health Practicum
description: Supervised application of theories, research, and skills for advanced practice psychiatric-mental health nursing with individuals, families, and groups representing culturally diverse populations. Includes the program’s capstone experience. Repeatable five times. NURS majors only. 611. Co-requisite: 632.

title: Family Systems in Health and Illness
description: Family systems approach to include selected family theories, family research and family centered culturally sensitive clinical assessment and intervention in health and illness situations. graduate standing or consent.

title: Complementary and Traditional Care
description: A review of theoretical systems and approaches to complementary and traditional care in culturally diverse populations with a focus on wellness. Appropriate for all health-care professionals.

title: Tests and Measurement in Nursing Education
description: Testing and evaluation applied to nursing education. NURS majors only. A-F only. consent. (Once a year)

title: (Alpha) Selected Topics in Nursing
description: Advanced study, exploration of special topics in clinical nursing. (D) developmentally disabled children and their families; (I) current issues in professional nursing. NURS majors only or consent for (D).

title: Human Resource Management in Healthcare Agencies
description: Analyze and critically evaluate basic issues, policies and trends in human resource management as it applies to health care agencies. A-F only. consent.

title: Leadership, Role, Identity and Organizational/System Change
description: Seminar focused on theoretical and conceptual models of leadership and management as applied to relevant advanced nurses’ roles, their respective populations, and changing healthcare environments. NURS majors only.

title: Analysis of Healthcare Delivery Models
description: Analysis of various clinical management concepts and health-care delivery systems influencing outcomes, process, and costs in the delivery of care. NURS majors only.

title: Seminar and Practicum in Nursing Executive Leadership
description: Supervised practicum to build mid to senior level nursing leadership competencies and facilitate change in complex healthcare organizations. NURS majors only. 663 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Clinical Economics and Finance
description: Economic and financial concepts and tools for use in developing and managing patient care processes. NURS majors only.

title: Community Based Participatory Research (CBPR) for Advanced Practice Nurses
description: Online course focuses on use of CBPR methods by Advanced Practice Nurses to address population level issues amendable to nursing interventions; 15 hours of didactic and 90 hours of field experience are included. NURS majors only. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Evaluating Research for Evidencebased Practice
description: Introduces evidence-based practice methods for improving the quality of nursing practice. Develops skills in differentiating quantitative and qualitative research, statistical methods, and searching, critiquing, and synthesizing literature, pertinent to health care issues. A-F only. permission of course faculty. (Fall only)

title: Advanced Practice Nursing During Public Health Disasters
description: The role of the advanced professional nurse in public health preparedness, planning and response. Includes 45 hours of field work where the student will practice emergency response functional roles. NURS majors only. A-F only. consent. (Summer only)

title: Biostatistics: Application in the Advanced Nursing Practice Setting
description: Includes basic bio-statistical techniques and the application of statistical findings to practice programmatic decisions. NURS majors only. A-F only. graduate standing in the Department of Nursing or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: graduate standing in the Department of Nursing or consent

title: Advanced Practice Population Health Nursing Practicum
description: Student will conduct a complex service project for a public or community based agency. May be taken for 1-6 credits. (45 hours of practicum experience awarded for each one credit of the course) Repeatable one time. NURS majors only. A-F only. 24 credits of MS in Advanced Population Health Nursing or consent.
prerequisites: NURS 24 credits of MS in Advanced Population Health Nursing or consent

title: Implementation and Evaluation Strategies for Evidence-Based Practice
description: Using knowledge of translational science, designs an implementation plan for a practice guideline. Determines evaluation methods and selects outcome variables that best measure success. Discusses institutionalization of, and identifies facilitators and barriers to, practice change. NURS majors only. Graduate standing only. A-F only. 669. (Spring only)

title: Advanced Practice Clinical
description: Application of concepts and principles of assessment, diagnosis, management and evaluation of clients in supervised clinical practicum for advanced practice nursing. Repeatable unlimited times. NURS majors only or consent. A-F only. 612/612L, 613, and 629 (or concurrent)

title: Primary Care I Seminar: Health Assessment
description: Seminar to discuss the evidence, concepts, and principles of assessment, diagnosis, management. Utilization of clinical cases and current literature on health care assessment. NURS majors only. A-F only. 612/612L, 613, and 629. Co-requisite: 676L.

title: Primary Care I Lab (beginning level): Health Assessment
description: Beginning level clinical experience. Application of concepts and principles of assessment, diagnosis, evaluation, and management of adult clients for advanced practice nursing students in primary care settings. NURS majors only. CR./NC only. 612/612L, 613, and 629.

title: Primary Care II Seminar: Management of the Adult
description: Intermediate level seminar where students discuss current evidence, concepts, and principles of assessment, diagnosis, evaluation, and management of adult clients. NURS majors only. 676/676L. Co-requisite: 677L.

title: Primary Care II Lab (intermediate level): Acute & Chronic Conditions (Adult)
description: Intermediate level practicum. Application of concepts and principles of assessment, diagnosis, management, and evaluation of clients in supervised clinical practicum for advanced practice nursing focusing on adults with acute or chronic diagnoses in primary care. Repeatable one time, up to five credits. NURS majors only. CR/NC only. 676/676L.

title: Primary Care III Seminar: Special Populations (Peds, Gero, Women)
description: Intermediate level seminar. Students will discuss current evidence, concepts, and principles of assessment, diagnosis, evaluation, and management of clients focusing on vulnerable populations (pediatric, geriatric, women). NURS majors only. A-F only. 677/677L. Co-requisite: 678L.

title: Primary Care III Lab (intermediate level): Special Populations (Peds, Gero, Women)
description: Intermediate level clinical experience. Application of concepts and principles of assessment, diagnosis, evaluation, and management of clients in a primary care setting for advanced practice nursing students focusing on vulnerable populations (pediatric, geriatric, women). Repeatable two times. NURS majors only. CR/NC only. 677/677L.

title: Primary Care IV Seminar: Primary Care Integration Across the Lifespan
description: Advanced level seminar. Students will discuss current evidence, concepts, and principles of assessment, diagnosis, evaluation, and management focusing on primary care of clients across the lifespan. NURS majors only. A-F only. 678/678L. Co-requisite: 679L.

title: Primary Care IV Lab (advanced level): Primary Care Integration Across the Lifespan
description: Advanced level clinical experience. Application of concepts and principles of assessment, diagnosis, evaluation, and management of clients across the lifespan in primary care settings for advanced practice nursing students. NURS majors only. CR/NC only. 678/678L.

title: Cultural Competency in Nursing Education
description: Evaluates the impact of history on the culture of nursing and nursing education. Explore strategies to provide education in a culturally sensitive manner to culturally diverse students. NURS majors only. A-F only. graduate standing, or consent.

title: Diagnosis & Management of Complex Care Across the Lifespan
description: Culminating seminar synthesizing and applying concepts from all APRN didactic course work, using case/problem-based learning via student and faculty-guided discussions. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Health and Healing Practices of Populations with Health Disparities in Hawai‘i and Other Places
description: Teaching and learning concepts applied to health promotion and the prevention of common conditions of disease among populations with health disparities in Hawai‘i and other places; includes didactic and 45 hours of field experience. NURS majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Psychobiology of Mental Health Disorders
description: Focuses on the psychological and biological factors that influence mental health and illness among diverse groups of individuals across the lifespan. Relevant biopsychosocial theories and research findings are applied. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Theory: Psychiatric-Mental Health Advanced Practice Nursing Across the Lifespan I
description: First of three courses focused on preparing students in the Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) Program to become psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioners (PMHNPs). NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Clinical: Psychiatric-Mental Health Advanced Practice Nursing Across the Lifespan I
description: Repeatable one time, up to six credits. Complements NURS 684; prepares DNP students to become psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioners; and incorporates the accrual of 135 clinical hours. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Individual Psychotherapy for Psychiatric-Mental Health Nurse Practitioners
description: Major modalities of individual psychotherapy, such as psychodynamic, cognitive-behavioral, brief solution-focused, and multicultural approaches will be examined. Critical dialogue about race, gender, culture, sexuality and socioeconomic status will be applied to case studies and reenactments. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Theory: Psychiatric-Mental Health Advanced Practice Nursing Across the Lifespan II
description: The second of three courses focused on preparing students in the Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) Program to become psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioners (PMHNPs). NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Clinical: Psychiatric-Mental Health Advanced Practice Nursing Across the Lifespan II
description: Repeatable one time, up to six credits. Complements NURS 686; prepares DNP students to become psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioners; and incorporates the accrual of 135 clinical hours. Repeatable one time or up to six credits. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Family and Group Psychotherapy for Psychiatric-Mental Health Nurse Practitioners
description: Major approaches in family and group psychotherapy are examined in this course. The role of the PMHNP and issues in providing care across the lifespan, among diverse populations, in traditional and non-traditional settings are addressed. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Theory: Psychiatric-Mental Health Advanced Practice Nursing Across the Lifespan III
description: The final of three courses focused on preparing students in the Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) Program to become psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioners (PMHNPs). NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Clinical: Psychiatric-Mental Health Advanced Practice Nursing Across the Lifespan III
description: Repeatable one time, up to six credits. Complements NURS 688; prepares DNP students to become psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioners; and incorporates the accrual of 135 clinical hours. Repeatable one time or up to six credits. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Research Methods
description: Nursing research methods for qualitative and quantitative studies, institutional review board procedures, and how to develop a research proposal. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Advanced Practice Clinical for Clinical Nurse Specialists
description: Application of concepts and principles of education, consultation, research, and management and evaluation of clients in supervised clinical practicum for adult health clinical nurse specialist students. Repeatable five times. NURS majors only. A-F only. 612 (or concurrent), 612L (or concurrent), 613 (or concurrent), and 629 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: NURS 612 (or concurrent), NURS 612L (or concurrent), NURS 613 (or concurrent), and NURS 629 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Successful Aging: Physiologic
description: Advanced study of the functional, cultural, psychological, and socioeconomic phenomena that impact the physiology of normal and abnormal aging.
