Emphasis is on promoting successful aging among elder residents of the Pacific Basin and applications to primary health care. NURS majors only or consent. consent.

title: Nursing Education Capstone
description: A culminating experience in nursing education program designed for students to integrate, critique, extend, and apply knowledge gained in the program. NURS majors only. A-F only. consent. (Spring only)

title: Directed Study or Research
description: Directed study of problems related to nursing theory and practice. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only.

title: Advanced Gerontology: Promotion and Maintenance
description: Analyze biologic, psychosocial, physiologic, and health disparity aspects with conceptual application to healthcare of the aging population. Demonstrate understanding and distinguish normal changes from common disease-related changes. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Philosophical Thoughts
description: Introduces the major fields of philosophy for use in research. Frameworks for the evaluation and critique of philosophical approaches to research will be explored, debated, analyzed, and applied as relevant to the PhD student’s dissertation. NURS majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Designing and Conducting Clinical Trials
description: Small group sections will guide students as they produce their own clinical trial protocol. Topics like ethics and statistical power will be addressed briefly. Repeatable one time. any graduate level statistics course.

title: Instrument Development and Evaluation in Research
description: Theory of testing and evaluation applied to nursing research in culturally diverse populations. NURS majors only. A-F only. consent. (Once a year)

title: Principles of Evidence-based Practice for Advanced Nursing
description: Evaluates conceptual models for use in evidence-based practice. Refines skills in searching and critiquing the literature for application to practice change. Synthesizes a body of literature to design interventions pertinent to a practice problem. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Best Practices & Innovation in Teaching and Learning in Nursing Education
description: Current best practices and innovative teaching and learning strategies in nursing education. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Effective Program Evaluation for Quality Improvement
description: Integration of program evaluation and translational science for assessment and communication of programmatic health impacts to improve well-being of patients, families, and stakeholders/communities at local, regional, national/ international levels. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Advanced Nursing Science
description: Provides opportunities to know and practice the process of theory development in nursing and to test concepts, relationships, and models about health behavior in culturally diverse populations. NURS majors only.

title: Health Policy and Economics
description: Evaluate the implications of policies on health care funding and regulations, provider payments, and other variables shaping the ability of health care systems (Western and other) on advanced practice. NURS majors only. A-F only.

title: Quantitative Methods and Measures
description: Critical analysis of quantitative research methods used to analyze problems of interest to nursing in culturally diverse populations. Repeatable three times. NURS majors only. 620 or equivalent course and an advanced statistics course; or consent.
prerequisites: NURS 620 or equivalent course and an advanced statistics course; or consent

title: Qualitative Methods I
description: Introduction to qualitative research methods in the development of nursing disciplinary knowledge related to culturally diverse populations. NURS majors only.

title: Qualitative Methods II
description: Advanced in-depth exploration of the data collection, data analysis and methodological issues in the qualitative research traditions (ethnography, grounded theory, phenomenology and critical theory) used in nursing research. NURS majors only. A-F only. 742 (or equivalent) or consent. (Once a year)

title: Seminar on Women and Health
description: Women’s health and the role of women health professionals. Current literature and research regarding attitudes, roles, rights, and health care. consent. (

title: Creative Learning Strategies for Adults
description: Analysis of forces that affect adult learners. Concept of lifelong learning vis-à-vis development of creative strategies that assist maturing, self-directed persons to develop their potentialities. NURS majors only. (

title: Methods of Program Evaluation & Quality Improvement
description: Principles of and frameworks for program evaluation. Students develop logic models and evaluation plans for a community program and collect and analyze evaluation data. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Curriculum Development and Assessment Strategies in Nursing Education
description: Current theories, issues, and trends of curriculum development and assessment strategies in nursing education. NURS majors only.

title: Nursing Education & Leadership Capstone Practicum
description: A culminating experience in nursing education and leadership program designed for students to integrate, critique, extend, and apply knowledge gained in the program. NURS majors only. (732 and 747) with a minimum grade of B-.
prerequisites: (NURS 732 and NURS 747) with a minimum grade of B-

title: Curriculum Evaluation & Accreditation in Nursing Education
description: Current trends of planning for evaluation and critical analysis and application of curriculum evaluation in nursing curriculum. NURS majors only. A-F only. 474 with a minimum grade of B-.
prerequisites: NURS 474 with a minimum grade of B-

title: Foundation of Health Systems and Translation Science
description: Integrate scientific findings from various fields of study to the leadership and management of healthcare systems to ensure the delivery of quality and safe care. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Concept Development and Analysis
description: First course offering in-depth analysis of specific concepts and theoretical formulations of nursing and other disciplines pertinent to the student’s area of research interest. Addresses human responses to health in culturally diverse populations. NURS majors only. 739.

title: Advanced Statistics I
description: Advanced application of general linear model theory to analyze complex problems of interest to nursing in culturally diverse populations. NURS majors only. A-F only. 741 (or equivalent) or consent. Once a year.

title: Advanced Statistics II
description: Advanced application of multivariate statistics to analyze complex problems of interest to nursing in culturally diverse populations. A-F only. 741 and 752 or equivalent courses, or consent. Once a year.
prerequisites: NURS 741 and NURS 752 or equivalent courses, or consent

title: Trends in Healthcare
description: Evaluates the historical foundations of healthcare systems and their relationship to current issues and trends in healthcare services. Analyzes the variations in healthcare delivery systems across nations and the impact on health outcomes. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Translation Science
description: Synthesis and analysis of interventions and variables that influence the rate of adoption of innovations. Application of concepts to patient populations and systems of healthcare. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Culturally Competent Research Methods
description: Analysis of concepts, issues, and methods in conducting culturally competent research in the health field. graduate methods course or consent.

title: Advanced Clinical Economics and Finance
description: Theory and practice of financial management to achieve high quality and cost effectiveness in healthcare. Hybrid course which combines face-to-face with online learning. NURS majors only. A-F only. 665, no waiver. (Alt. years)

title: Dissertation Proposal Writing Seminar
description: Provides students with advanced study and critique from faculty leading to the development of a draft dissertation proposal. Peer exchange facilities individual scholarship, research topic mastery, and ability to conduct rigorous critique. NURS majors only. A-F only. 739, 741, 751. (Spring only)

title: Best Practices in Leading Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality
description: Examination of quality of health care, the process of managing healthcare outcomes and costs in the delivery of care through the interdisciplinary process. NURS majors only.

title: Capstone Field Study
description: Supervised experience in executive nursing leadership to address important health issues for high-risk or under-served populations utilizing an interdisciplinary systems-based approach. NURS majors only. 664 and 774 (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: NURS 664 and NURS 774 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Doctor of Nursing Practice Project
description: Under the guidance of their DNP Project Team members, students will synthesize, integrate, and translate newly acquired knowledge and skills in the implementation and evaluation of their DNP Project. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.

title: Nursing Research Practicum
description: Faculty guided research opportunity to gain mastery of research skills and techniques through participation in mentored research. Repeatable one time. NURS majors only. PhD students only. A-F only. 741 (with a minimum grade of B-), 742 (with a minimum grade of B-), 751 (with a minimum grade of B-) and a quantitative methods course.
prerequisites: NURS 741 (with a minimum grade of B-), NURS 742 (with a minimum grade of B-), NURS 751 (with a minimum grade of B-) and a quantitative methods course

title: Grant Writing and Grant Management
description: Designed to introduce students to grants, grant writing, and grant management. Combined lecture discussion, seminar, and exercises on grants, grant writing, and grant management for health sciences. Open to NURS students only, others with approval. Repeatable one time. NURS majors only. instructor consent.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable nine times. NURS majors only. consent.

title: National Student Exchange
description: Study at another campus through National Student Exchange (NSE). Transfer credits earned upon successful completion of courses on exchange. Repeatable one time at the same host campus. Unlimited times at different host campuses. CR/NC only. Credits to be granted in transfer upon successful completion of course work at exchange institution. consent of NSE program.

title: Environmental Service Learning I
description: Experiential service learning course for students participating in the Hawai‘i Youth Conservation Corps summer program as team members and leaders. Repeatable one time. Hawai‘i Youth Conservation Corps summer program students only. A-F only. (Summer only)

title: Introduction to Natural Resources and Environmental Management
description: Introduction to NREM student learning outcomes and scholarly breadth within the department, exposure to on-campus resources, networking with current and former NREM students and external stakeholders, career skills development. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Environmental Service Learning II
description: Experiential service learning course for students participating in the Hawai‘i Youth Conservation Corps summer program as Hana Hou members. Hawai‘i Youth Conservation Corps summer program students only. A-F only. (Summer only)

title: Applied Calculus for Management, Life Sciences, and Human Resources
description: (2 Lec, 1 1-hr Lab) Applications of calculus (limits, continuity, derivatives, exponential and logarithmic functions, partials, integrals) to problems in business management, social sciences, and life sciences. Applies symbolic techniques and quantitative methods in problem solving, utilizes concept of proof as a chain of inferences, and promotes development of reasoning skills and mathematical logic in bridging theory and practice. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Environmental Science
description: Analysis of our environment with emphasis on understanding relationships and interactions of physical, biological, technological, and political components using scientific methods of inquiry. Food supply and safety, water quality, pollution control, biodiversity, environmental policy. Open to nonmajors. (

title: Agricultural and Resource Economics
description: Introduction to basic economics concepts, including demand, supply, exchange, market price and market failure. Economic evaluation and policy for the uses of various natural resource endowments, especially in production agriculture, is included. A-F only. (

title: Scientific Principles of Sustainability
description: Introduction to the scientific principles of sustainability, including the ecology of managed and natural ecosystems, global change biology, ecological principles of natural resource management, renewable energy technologies, and the environmental impacts of humans. (

title: Internship Preparation
description: Exploration of internship and career opportunities for NREM majors. Development of career-building skills, including resume, interview, and professional networking. NREM majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Natural Resources Management
description: Biological and physical science aspects of natural resource management at local, national, and global scales. Topics covered include resource management of soil, water, forests, wetlands, coasts and wildlife. A-F only. (NREM/TPSS 251 or 210; CHEM 151 or higher; and BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: (NREM/TPSS 251 or NREM 210; CHEM 151 or higher; and BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent

title: Natural Resources Management Lab
description: (1 4-hr Lab) Laboratory and field methods covering biological and physical principles and concepts in natural resource management. Emphasis on basic field measurement techniques, computer skills commonly used in managing natural resources and writing scientific lab reports. A-F only. Co-requisite: 301. (Spring only)

title: Natural Resource and Environmental Policy
description: Introduction to natural resource and environmental public policy at U.S. federal, Hawai‘i state, local, and international levels. Policy principles, legal structure, governmental agencies, statutes and programs, analytical techniques, program assessments, and contemporary ethical issues. A-F only. NREM/ PEPS/SUST 210 or NREM/SOCS/TPSS 251 or (BIOL 101 or higher) or GEO 101 or (ERTH 101 or higher); and 220/SUST 220 or one ECON course or two DS courses. (
prerequisites: NREM/ PEPS/SUST 210 or NREM/SOCS/TPSS 251 or (BIOL 101 or higher) or GEO 101 or (ERTH 101 or higher); and ERTH 220/SUST 220 or one ECON course or two DS courses

title: Fundamentals of Soil Science
description: Origin, development, properties, management of tropical soils; classification of Hawaiian soils. A-F only. Minimum grade of C or consent. (CHEM 161 and 161L) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. Corequisite: 304L. (Fall only) (

title: Fundamentals of Soil Science Laboratory
description: Field and analytical methods for exploring the origin, development, properties, and management of soils, with an emphasis on tropical and Hawaiian soils. A-F only. (CHEM 161 and CHEM 161L) with a minimum grade of C. Co-requisite: 304. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: (CHEM 161 and CHEM 161L) with a minimum grade of C

title: Environmental Ethics
description: Application of traditional moral theories to environmental issues. Development and evaluation of specific environmental ethical theories. Application of ethical theories to environmental decision-making. A-F only. 210 or GEO 101 or PHIL 101 or PHIL 103. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: NREM 210 or GEO 101 or PHIL 101 or PHIL 103

title: Statistics in Agriculture and Human Resources
description: Theory, applications, and presentation of statistical reasoning. Descriptive, probability, and inferential reasoning for one-variable analysis with extensions to multiple variable cases. A-F only.

title: Current Topics in Plant Science
description: An undergraduate seminar that provides the presentation and discussion of topics of current relevance to students preparing for careers in applied plant sciences. Oral focus designation. A-F only. 210 or TPSS 200/SUST 211, or consent. (

title: Managerial Accounting
description: Principles and methods of agricultural accounting. Preparing and interpreting financial statements. Sources and costs of credit, capital budgeting, tax management, estate planning. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 220/SUST 220 or ECON 130 or consent. (

title: Enterprise Management
description: Introduction of practical concepts and methods used in business management. Introduce broad range of business strategies. Understand the critical role each strategy plays. Facilitate student’s practice of analytical and critical thinking through case studies. (

title: Basic Environmental Benefit Cost Analysis
description: Fundamentals of benefit-cost analysis with extensions to environmental impacts and projects; case studies. 220/SUST 220 or ECON 130 or consent. (

title: Tropical Forestry/Agroforestry
description: Biophysical and socioeconomic description and analysis of major tropical forestry and agroforestry management systems, including Hawai‘i and the Pacific Basin. The role of traditional land use, pressures from regional and global development, and efforts to create sustainable, diverse systems for rural communities will be discussed. CHEM 151 or higher and BIOL 171 or higher. (Alt. years: spring)
prerequisites: CHEM 151 or higher and BIOL 171 or higher

title: Directed Study
description: Limited to exceptional undergraduate students qualified to carry on advanced study. consent.

title: Methods in Wildlife Management & Conservation
description: Introduces fundamental techniques for wildlife management and conservation. In addition to hands-on training, students will learn underlying biological and ecological principles, as well as quantitative skills, with an emphasis on sustainable management. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. BIOL 171. (Spring only) (

title: Community and Natural Resource Management
description: Theory and tools for working with groups and communities in the management of natural resources is presented using a participatory format. Topics include sustainable development, extension programming, participatory learning and communication, evaluation, and conflict management. two social science courses (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: two social science courses (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent

title: Spreadsheet Modeling for Business and Economic Analysis
description: Introduction to quantitative decision-making methods for effective agribusiness management in resource allocation, scheduling, logistics, risk analysis, inventory, and forecasting. Emphasis on problem identification, model formulation and solution, and interpretation and presentation of results. NREM/SUST 220 or ECON 130, and 310 or ECON 321; or consent. (Once a year) (
prerequisites: NREM/SUST 220 or ECON 130, and ECON 310 or ECON 321; or consent

title: Wildlife Ecology and Management
description: Lecture-based overview of the history, ecology, and management of wildlife species from around the world and Hawai‘i. BIOL 172 (with a minimum grade of C-)or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: BIOL 172 (with a minimum grade of C-)or consent

title: Natural Resource Issues and Ethics
description: Overview of the history of land, resources and power in Hawai‘i; players and processes influencing land and natural resources policies today explored from Native Hawaiian and other viewpoints. Extensive use of case studies. HWST 207/SUST 217 or HWST 307/ SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356 (
prerequisites: HWST 207/SUST 217 or HWST 307/ SUST 317 or HWST/SUST 356 ()

title: Sustainable Nutrient Management in Agroecosystems
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Biological, chemical, and physical processes governing the cycling of nutrients in agroecosystems, crop and livestock production, and the effects on surrounding unmanaged ecosystems. (TPSS 304 and CHEM 161) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent. (
prerequisites: (TPSS 304 and CHEM 161) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent

title: Soil and Water Conservation
description: Past and present issues in soil and water conservation will be examined. Principles of erosion, conservation tillage, irrigation, and drainage will be discussed. Land-based threats to coastal zones and watershed management will also be covered. 301/SUST 311 or 304.

title: Irrigation and Water Management
description: Basic soil-water-plant relationships, irrigation water requirements, irrigation efficiencies, different methods of irrigation, planning, design and management of an irrigation system, fertigation and impact of irrigation on soil and water quality. 203 (or equivalent) and NREM/TPSS 304 (or equivalent), or consent. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: NREM 203 (or equivalent) and NREM/TPSS 304 (or equivalent), or consent

title: Natural Resources Conservation Planning
description: Combined lecture and hands-on field course on theory and practice of natural resource conservation planning. Includes individual and group projects. undergraduate junior or senior or graduate standing. Recommended: at least one upper division course in soils, natural resources, planning, physical geography, or related area; or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: undergraduate junior or senior or graduate standing

title: Plant Nutrient Diagnosis in the Tropics
description: Designed for students to identify essential nutrients required by plants; diagnose nutrient disorders in plants; and propose environmentally sound solutions to correct disorders. 304/TPSS 304 (or concurrent) and BIOL 172. (

title: Geographic Information Systems for Resource Managers
description: Combined lecture-lab on the basic concepts and principles of geographic information systems, remote sensing, and global positioning system. Practical skills to be developed by solving real natural resources and environmental problems. (either 203 (or concurrent) or 310 (or concurrent) and 301 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent.
prerequisites: (either NREM 203 (or concurrent) or NREM 310 (or concurrent) and NREM 301 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent

title: Applied Forest Ecology
description: Application of ecological theory to sustainable management of forest resources in Hawaii and beyond, including silviculture (production of timber and nontimber forest products), restoration (restoring damaged or degraded forests), and conservation (conserving existing forest resources). A-F only. (301/SUST 311 and 380) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: (NREM 301/SUST 311 and SUST 380) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent

title: Ho‘okāhua: ‘Āina Based Leadership Education (ABLE)
description: Ho‘okāhua: is an ‘āina based leadership course encompassing Hawaiian culture, Environmental Science, Law & Policy, Planning and Community Development to equip students to care for, guard, and govern natural resources they care about.

title: Topics in Natural Resources and Environmental Management
description: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems. Offered by visiting faculty and/or for extension programs. Repeatable five times up to four credits. A-F only. consent.

title: Internship Experience
description: Internship work experience for NREM majors. Completion of writing assignments with a minimum of 4,000 words. A-F only. consent of instructor.

title: Environmental Problem Solving
crossListings: 2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab Senior-level capstone for NREM. Ecosystem management within problem-solving context. Applications of research and analytical methods, management tools to case studies. Focus on student teamwork and oral communications. NREM majors only. A-F only. Pre: Senior standing or consent. Crosslisted as SUST 494

title: Directed Study
description: Repeatable up to four credits. senior standing and consent.

title: Foundations of Natural Resource and Environmental Management and Policy
description: Critical evaluation of environmental and social components of NREM and policy. Students develop research skills and integrative knowledge important for all resource managers in, e.g., ecology, applied economics, hydrology, policy/management, soils, and human dimensions. graduate standing or consent.

title: Social-Ecological Systems Analysis of Natural Resource and Environmental Management
description: Case study approach to building the structural and behavioral framework for complex, dynamic systems underlying sustainable NREM and policy, emphasizing the transdisciplinary interactions of the ecological and economic components. 600 (with a minimum grade of B-), and (ECON 130 or NREM/SUST 220, and BIOL 171) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (Spring only)
prerequisites: NREM 600 (with a minimum grade of B-), and (ECON 130 or NREM/SUST 220, and BIOL 171) with a minimum grade of C, or consent

title: Advanced Methods in Wildlife Management & Conservation
description: Introduces advanced techniques for wildlife management and conservation. In addition to hands-on training, students will learn underlying biological and ecological principles, as well as quantitative skills, with an emphasis on sustainable management. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Resource and Environmental Policy Analysis
description: Exploration of institutional and policy dimensions of natural resource development, management, allocation, markets and pricing, focusing on their environmental impacts. Emphasis on policy analysis using case studies and empirical findings. Original paper required. A-F only. grade of Cor above in ECON 130 or NREM/SUST 220, or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: grade of Cor above in ECON 130 or NREM/SUST 220, or consent

title: Predicting and Controlling Degradation in Human-Dominated Terrestrial Ecosystems
description: Historic, present, and projected trends in understanding and managing human-dominated ecosystems; predicting, measuring and mitigating degradation especially in terrestrial ecosystems with a focus on small volcanic islands in tropical settings. A-F only. 301/SUST 311 and 304 (or equivalent) and 600. Recommended 461, or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: NREM 301/SUST 311 and SUST 304 (or equivalent) and SUST 600

title: Kaiaulu: Care and Collaborative Management of Natural Resources
description: Engagement with theory and practice of collaboration to care for natural resources. Topics include community based management, common property, Hawaiian knowledge, co-management, and access through readings, discussion, and projects with Hawai‘i communities. (Spring only)

title: ‘Imi ‘Ike: Social Science Field Methods for Environmental Research
description: Students learn and apply social science research methods tailored to natural resource management and environmental issues to a class project with Hawai‘i community. Emphasis on qualitative and participatory approaches. (Alt. years)

title: Applied Microeconomic Analysis
description: Economic applications to the agricultural and nonagricultural industries are emphasized. Econometric techniques are used to estimate demand, supply, production and cost functions which are analyzed in terms of economic theory and market information. A-F only. AREC 626 and ECON 627, or consent.

title: Sustainable Agriculture Seminar
description: Critical evaluation of existing and alternative cropping systems from a long-term perspective. Value conflicts and resolution. Repeatable unlimited times. graduate standing or advanced undergraduate standing, and consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing or advanced undergraduate standing, and consent

title: Resource Economics
description: Analysis of problems of development and management of natural resources with emphasis on resources in agriculture and role in economic development. ECON 608 and ECON 629. (

title: Land Systems Science
description: Through discussion of primary land systems science literature and use of environmental modeling software, this interdisciplinary course explores how drivers, states, and trends in human appropriation of land affect socioecological system function. 477 or 677 or GEO 470 or GEO 476 or ERTH 460 or ERTH 461. (Alt. years: Fall) (
prerequisites: NREM 477 or NREM 677 or GEO 470 or GEO 476 or ERTH 460 or ERTH 461

title: Soil Plant Nutrient Relations
description: (2 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Soil-plant interactions, emphasis on characteristics of tropical soils and plants influencing nutrient uptake by plants. Diagnostic methods to identify nutrient deficiencies and element toxicity. 450 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent. (
prerequisites: NREM 450 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent

title: Information Research Skills
description: Examines the use of libraries and information technology for scholarly investigation in support of scientific research; provides experience utilizing and critically evaluating a variety of print and electronic sources in basic and applied sciences. consent. (

title: Advanced Environmental Benefit Cost Analysis
description: Advanced environmental benefit-cost analysis will require that proficiency be demonstrated on fundamentals and address topics related to sustainability, including income equality, non-market goods, risk, cost of public funds, and the social discount rate. (

title: Hydrologic Processes in Soils
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Hydrologic properties in soils and the processes involved in water infiltration drainage and solute transport. Emphasis on key parameters required for modeling. Recommended: CEE 424 or consent. (Fall only) (

title: Watershed Hydrology
description: Theory and application of basic hydrologic processes and management occurring on small islands watersheds. 203 (or equivalent) and PHYS 151 (or equivalent) and 477 or GEO 388 (or equivalent); or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: NREM 203 (or equivalent) and PHYS 151 (or equivalent) and PHYS 477 or GEO 388 (or equivalent); or consent

title: Small Watershed Modeling
description: Introduction to process-based modeling of watershed with emphasis on model applications. Deals with the characterization and simulation of small watershed hydrolic and pollutant transport processes. CEE 424 (or concurrent) or ERTH/SUST 425 (or concurrent) or BS degree from NREM, or consent. (Spring only)
prerequisites: CEE 424 (or concurrent) or ERTH/SUST 425 (or concurrent) or BS degree from NREM, or consent

title: Coastal Resources Management
description: Study of coastal systems, estuaries, and coral reefs. Emphasis on interdisciplinary science and integration of coastal ecology, geoscience, and social science. Coastal and marine wildlife-human interactions, environmental pertubations, and management strategies will be discussed. advanced undergraduate course work in marine biology, oceanography, geoscience, and sustainability recommended. (Spring only)
prerequisites: advanced undergraduate course work in marine biology, oceanography, geoscience, and sustainability recommended

title: Interdisciplinary Methods for Agrarian Systems
description: Interdisciplinary methodologies for conducting research and impact analyses on agrarian systems, sustainable development, and resource management. Repeatable one time. consent. (Alt. years: fall)

title: International Agricultural Systems
description: Analysis of trends and strategies in international agricultural research and development. International agricultural research centers (IARC), Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), university networks and consortia, and private voluntary organizations (PVOs). graduate standing or advanced undergraduate standing, and consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing or advanced undergraduate standing, and consent

title: Remote Sensing of the Environment
description: Fundamentals, techniques, and applications of remote sensing for natural resource assessments and environmental monitoring. Lab consisting of field radiometric exercises, computer modeling of energymatter interaction, processing, and analysis of remotely sensed imagery. one physics course (e.g. PHYS 151), one calculus course (e.g. 203), and one statistics course (e.g. 310), or consent. Recommended: either GEO 470 or ERTH 460 or one introductory remote sensing course. (Alt. years)

title: Ecosystem Ecology
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of ecosystem ecology with emphasis on tropical forests, human impacts, and global environmental change. Factors controlling ecosystem structure, productivity, nutrient cycling, plant-soil-atmosphere interactions, and energy balance. Field and laboratory methods in ecosystem science. advanced undergraduate coursework in ecology and soil science; graduate standing; and consent. (Alt. years: spring)
prerequisites: advanced undergraduate coursework in ecology and soil science; graduate standing; and consent

title: Restoration Ecology
description: Graduate seminar on foundations of restoration ecology, application of ecological theory to restoration practice. Emphasis on restoration of structure and function in degraded terrestrial ecosystems using case studies from Hawai‘i and around the world. advanced undergraduate ecology course and graduate standing, or consent. Completion of 680 recommended, but not required. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: advanced undergraduate ecology course and graduate standing, or consent

title: Landscape Ecology
description: Focuses on the history, theories, and contemporary views of landscapes; including scale, land cover, land use, landscape metrics, disturbance regimes, land management, landscape change, the relationship of landscapes to species, and modeling. graduate students, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Conservation Biology
description: Theories and concepts of ecology, evolution and genetics for conservation of biological diversity. Topics will include restoration ecology, management planning, laws and policies, biological invasions. (

title: Advanced Topics in Natural Resources and Environmental Management
description: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems at an advanced level. Offered by visiting or existing faculty as a special course. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent.

title: Capstone Preparation in NREM
description: Preparation for NREM Master’s Plan B capstone experience. NREM majors only. A-F only. 600 and 601 (or concurrent) (with a minimum grade of B-), and one graduate methods course (or concurrent).
prerequisites: NREM 600 and NREM 601 (or concurrent) (with a minimum grade of B-), and one graduate methods course (or concurrent)

title: Capstone Experience in NREM
description: Capstone experience in NREM. NREM majors only. (695 and 601) with a minimum grade of B-, or consent.
prerequisites: (NREM 695 and NREM 601) with a minimum grade of B-, or consent

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.. graduate standing.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Research Seminar
description: Presentation and discussion of student research proposals, theses and dissertations, and research presentations by NREM faculty, students, and invited speakers. A-F only. consent.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Natural Sciences and Life-Pulling the Puzzles Apart
description: Journey through the Natural Sciences finding fun, excitement, and success in science, mathematics, engineering, medicine, and all that is the natural sciences. Focus upon challenging worldviews of belief, invention, impact, and ethics. CR/NC only.

title: Seminar for Science Teachers
description: Seminar and discussions of current and significant topics and problems in science where teachers can exchange new and innovative teaching ideas and strategies. Repeatable one time. in-service teachers or consent.

title: Computers in Classroom
description: Combined lecture, laboratory and discussion on the use of computers as a teaching tool in the classroom. To be taught in a hands-on manner appropriate for the science teachers. Restricted to in-service teachers or consent. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Mathematics Workshop for Teachers
description: An in-depth study of topics from intermediate and high school mathematics. Restricted to in-service teachers or consent. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Physics Workshop for Teachers
description: Major concepts of physics taught by means of hands-on conceptual activities for elementary and secondary teachers. Restricted to in-service teachers, or consent. Repeatable one time. (

title: Seminar on Science Teaching
description: Effective teaching methods; organization of courses, lectures, laboratory exercises; development and evaluation of examinations; computers and audiovisual aids. Open to graduate students in various science disciplines. Repeatable one time. (.

title: Leadership Laboratory
description: Laboratory instruction will include leadership development, teamwork, physical fitness training, and activities designed for students pursuing Navy and Marine Corps commissions. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only

title: Introduction to Naval Science
description: Overview of the Navy’s mission, customs, traditions, and the duties required of Junior Officers. Provides students with a basic knowledge of damage control, shipboard organization, and safety procedures prior to their first summer training cruise. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Seapower and Maritime Affairs
description: Study of the Navy and the influence of seapower upon history that incorporates both an historical and political perspective to explore major events and circumstances that have shaped a bold and proud history. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Navigation
description: Designed to provide midshipmen with an in-depth study of the theory, principles, procedures, and application of plotting, piloting, and electronic navigation, as well as an introduction to maneuvering boards. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Naval Ships System I: Engineering
description: Will learn ship design and control, hydrodynamic forces, stability, electrical theory, and damage control coupled with design of steam, gas turbine and nuclear propulsion. Case studies merging both ethical and technical challenges. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Naval Ship Systems II: Weapons
description: Outlines the theory and employment of naval warship weapons systems. Supplemented with review/ analysis of case studies involving the moral and ethical responsibilities of leaders in the employment of weapons. A-F only. 301. (Spring only)

title: Evolution of Warfare
description: Will imbue students with an understanding of the origins of modern warfighting theory through an analysis of historical philosophies, domains, tactics, and technology. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Fund of Maneuver Warfare
description: Introduction to the foundational concepts and history of the USMC as the premiere Maneuver Warfighting Organization. Theoretical course that utilizes historical examples. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: United States Pacific Fleet Internship
description: Leadership development, teamwork, and activities designed for NROTC students. Learn how to write a federal resume, be a Federal Employee, and learn the skills needed to complete and present their U.S. Pacific Fleet capstone project. CR/NC only. 100L, 101, 102, 201, 202, 303, 304, or 402. (Summer only)
prerequisites: NAVL 100L, NAVL 101, NAVL 102, NAVL 201, NAVL 202, NAVL 303, NAVL 304, or NAVL 402

title: Naval Operations and Seamanship
description: Study of U.S. Navy ships professional and efficient operations. Lecture series on Fleet communications, tactical employment, relative motion plotting, seamanship, Joint Warfare, and employment of naval forces as an element of National Security. A-F only. 201. (Fall only)

title: Leadership and Ethics
description: Introduces ethical theories in discussion-oriented formats to provide a solid foundation of various moral, ethical, and leadership philosophies. Serves to guide, refine, and strengthen moral character and increase awareness of different ethical decision-making tools. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: International Exchange Study/Research
description: Study overseas in an approved international exchange or similar program. Repeatable three times. GES, ERTH, and MET majors only. CR/NC only. consent of academic advisor.

title: The College Experience
description: Required for entering SOEST majors to develop skills and applications for a successful college experience. Students will examine academic goals and implement strategies to achieve goals including time management and career exploration. SOEST majors only. CR/NC only.

title: Natural Hazards
description: Science of natural hazards: impact on human civilization of events in the lithosphere, atmosphere, biosphere, and hydrosphere (e.g., earthquakes, hurricanes, red tides, and floods), and impact of humans on their exposure to and mitigation of the hazards.

title: An Introduction to Integrative Systems Biology: Hawaiian Biomes as a Framework
description: Lecture/discussion introduces students to the field of biology through the integration of microbiology and macrobiology into a single, comprehensive systems biology with a focus on Hawaiian biomes and ecosystem sustainability. (Spring only) (

title: Contemporary Issues in Energy Systems
description: Introductory experience in energy systems including current status of fossil fuel, renewable energy technologies, energy utilization and conservation; environmental and policy aspects. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Ethics in Scientific Research
description: Introduction to issues of ethics in scientific research and scientific misconduct. ERTH, GES, or ATMO majors only. (Spring only)

title: Principles of Sustainability Analysis
description: Introduction to the principles of sustainability analysis through execution of Life Cycle Analysis applied to products, processes, or systems. LCA and the evaluation of environmental impact will be presented. Personal computer or laptop (Word 97 or higher) OS, and minimum of 4GB RAM. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (CHEM 161 and PHYS 170) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: (CHEM 161 and PHYS 170) with a minimum grade of C-; or consent

title: Earth Sciences Professional Development Education
description: Specialized Earth Science topics workshops designed for in-service teachers who wish to learn new approaches and content areas in geology and geophysics, meteorology and oceanography. Repeatable up to 12 credits. Credits earned cannot be applied for graduate degrees.

title: Communicating Ocean Sciences
description: Application of current learning theory and pedagogical practices in formal and informal learning environments to improve communication and instructional skills. Graduate students from multiple science disciplines welcome. Requires knowledge of biology, earth sciences, and/or chemistry. Repeatable one time, up to 3 credits. at least one course in introductory biology, geology, earth science, chemistry or marine science, an interest in ocean science, and enthusiasm for teaching science; or consent.
prerequisites: at least one course in introductory biology, geology, earth science, chemistry or marine science, an interest in ocean science, and enthusiasm for teaching science; or consent

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Selected interdisciplinary ocean/earth-related topics involving science, technology, engineering, and/or policy. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Ocean Policy and Management
description: Interdisciplinary approach to problems relating to humans and their interactions with the world’s oceans and coasts. Focus includes institutions for governing the world’s oceans and coasts at all scales and on the role of scientific knowledge in managing marine and coastal resources. Repeatable one time. OCN 331, GEO 435, or consent. (

title: Ocean Technology—Man in the Sea
description: Survey of human activities in the ocean, from the most traditional to the most innovative technical and engineering accomplishments.

title: Surf Science and Culture
description: Introduction to wave science covering generation, propagation, transformation, and coastal processes related to surfing and the human interaction with the ocean using Western science and cultural perspectives. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Surf Science and Culture Lab
description: Practical laboratory dedicated to wave science covering generation, propagation, transformation, and coastal processes related to surfing and the ocean environment through technology. A-F only.

title: Mineral and Energy Resources
description: Hard mineral and petroleum origins, exploration and exploitation. Renewable and non-renewable resources distribution. Political and scientific constraints. A-F only. 202 or OCN 201, or consent. (

title: Buoyancy and Stability
description: Ship nomenclature and geometry, hydrostatic principles of surface ships and underwater vehicles in free-floating, partially waterborne, and damaged conditions. Subdivision of ships. Launching. CEE 270 or equivalent.

title: Ocean and Resources Engineering Laboratory
description: Design, construction, and evaluation of an engineering system. Laboratory and field experience and data analysis supplemented with appropriate theory. 603 and 607, or consent.

title: Oceanography for Ocean Engineers
description: Physical, chemical, biological, and geological ocean environments for ocean engineers. Introduction to ocean dynamical processes and general circulation. Ocean measurement techniques, theory of underwater acoustics. Sonar, swath bathymetry, and tomography applications. consent.

title: Water Wave Mechanics
description: Governing equations in free surface flow, deterministic and probabilistic wave theories, wave transformation, wave-induced coastal currents, tides, ocean engineering operational sea state, and design wave criteria. consent.

title: Probability and Statistics for Ocean Engineers
description: Probability and statistical analysis including distributions, multiple regression and correlation, autocovariance, cross-spectra, and practical applications in ocean engineering. 607 or consent.

title: Hydrodynamics of Fluid-Body Interaction
description: Hydrodynamics of ships, coastal and offshore structures. Wave forces by potential theory and by Morison’s equation. Method of source distribution for potential flow problems. Flows with prescribed body motion, fixed and freely floating bodies. 607 or consent.

title: Dynamics of Ocean Structures
description: Response of floating platforms and vessels to wave action, spectral analysis in sea keeping. Frequency and time domain analyses of rigid body motions in six degrees of freedom. A-F only. 411 or consent. Co-requisite: 609 or consent.

title: Coastal Flood Mitigation
description: Design and solutions to coastal flood mitigation problems. Topics include climate adaptation; engineering solutions and best practices to mitigate coastal risk under different ocean hazard scenarios; and ecological approaches to mitigate coastal risk. consent; knowledge of AutoCAD and ORE 661 desirable. (
prerequisites: consent; knowledge of AutoCAD and ORE 661 desirable

title: Coastal Modeling
description: Coastal modeling using the SMS Surface-Water Modeling software. Applications to solving coastal problems for different ocean hazard scenarios by applying models for tides, waves, coastal circulation, wave-current interaction, sediment transport, and/or morphology change. consent; knowledge of ORE 607 desirable. (

title: Structural Analysis in Ocean Engineering
description: Structural and finite element analyses and design of ocean structures to withstand hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loading of the sea. Considerations include material type, safety factor, stress concentration, and fatigue. consent. Co-requisite: 411.

title: Environmental Fluid Dynamics
description: Fluid dynamics for coastal and estuarine environments. Turbulent mixing processes in homogeneous and stratified fluids. Buoyancy driven flows, internal hydraulics, topographic effects and estuarine circulation. Spill and pollutant dispersal. 603 or consent.

title: Applications in Ocean Acoustics
description: Using sound to observe the ocean. Fundamentals of propagation. Topics include marine mammals, navigation and communication, seismics, ships, wind and rain, ocean dynamics, flow and biological imaging and measurement, seafloor mapping, and the forward/ inverse problem. consent. (Once a year)

title: Autonomous Marine Systems
description: Identifies the unique challenges faced by autonomous underwater and surface vehicles, and analyzes approaches to address those challenges. Topics include hydrodynamic vehicle modeling, propeller theory, subsystem integration, and motion control strategies. Graduate students only. MATH 307 or MATH 311 (or equivalent), and ECE 351 or ME 451 (or equivalent), or instructor consent. (
prerequisites: MATH 307 or MATH 311 (or equivalent), and ECE 351 or ME 451 (or equivalent), or instructor consent

title: Coastal and Harbor Engineering
description: Planning and design of seawalls, groins, jetties, breakwaters, and layout of ports. Design requirements for harbor entrances and channels. Littoral drift and sedimentation problems. Navigation and mooring requirements. 607 or consent.

title: Nearshore Processes and Sediment Transport
description: coastal areas and its effect on morphological processes. Effect of man-made structures on littoral drift and shoreline. 607 or consent.

title: Marine Renewable Energy
description: Ocean thermal energy conversion (OTEC) systems: applicability, thermodynamics, design challenges; wave energy converters: floating devices, oscillating water column, optimal hydrodynamic performance; current, tidal, and offshore wind power. 607; basic knowledge of thermodynamics desirable. (
prerequisites: ORE 607; basic knowledge of thermodynamics desirable

title: Marine Mineral Resources Engineering
description: Activities in marine minerals development are examined in a multidisciplinary systems approach involving engineering, Earth and environmental sciences and economics. graduate standing or consent.

title: Ocean Engineering and Resilience in a Changing Climate
description: Focus on understanding the changing ocean conditions (e.g. waves and sea levels) relevant to the resilience of practical ocean engineering applications. Graduate students only. 607 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Plan B Master’s Project
description: Independent study for students working on a Plan B master’s project. A grade of Satisfactory (S) is assigned when the project is satisfactorily completed. master’s candidacy in ORE.

title: Directed Reading or Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. graduate standing and consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. candidacy for MS in ocean and resources engineering.
prerequisites: candidacy for MS in ocean and resources engineering

title: Nonlinear Water Wave Theories
description: Higher-order theories. Forced oscillations. Stoke’s theory. Nonlinear shallow-water wave equations and hydraulic jumps; effects of rotation. Internal waves. Analytical techniques necessary will be developed as course progresses. 607 with a B- grade.

title: Numerical Methods in Ocean Engineering
description: Formulation and application of numerical methods for simulating and solving ocean engineering problems. Mathematical and computational fundamentals; accuracy and stability; numerical interpolation, differentiation, and integration; boundary element, finite difference, and finite element methods. consent.

title: (Alpha) Capstone Design Project
description: Major design experience based on knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work and incorporating realistic constraints that include economic, environmental, ethical, social, and liability considerations. Emphasis is placed on teamwork and consultant-client relationship. (B) coastal engineering; (C) offshore engineering; (D) ocean resources engineering; (E) oceanic engineering. ORE majors only. (411, 603, and 607) with a minimum grade of B-; or consent. (Fall only for (E))
prerequisites: (ORE 411, ORE 603, and ORE 607) with a minimum grade of B-; or consent

title: Special Topics in Ocean and Resources Engineering
description: Content will reflect special interests of visiting and permanent faculty. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Seminar in Ocean and Resources Engineering
description: Attendance at 15 approved seminars is required along with submission of notes.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. candidacy for PhD in ocean and resources engineering.
prerequisites: candidacy for PhD in ocean and resources engineering

title: Global Environmental Science Seminar
description: Seminar to introduce new GES majors to the research interests of GES faculty and the research facilities available within SOEST. Restricted to GES majors. CR/NC only. (Fall only) (

title: Introduction to the Environment, Climate Change, & Sustainability
description: Introduction to the environment, climate change, and sustainability as they apply to ecosystems. Sustainability will be introduced through active learning exercises that address sustainable development and the three pillars of sustainability. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (

title: Introduction to the Environment and Sustainability Lab
description: Introduction to a variety of quantitative and qualitative approaches and methodologies to describe and assess key components to the environment. A-F only. 102 (or concurrent) or GES 102 or (or concurrent) SUST 112 (or concurrent). (
prerequisites: OCN 102 (or concurrent) or GES 102 or (or concurrent) SUST 112 (or concurrent)

title: Sustainability in a Changing World
description: Environmentally sustainable and non-sustainable practices, and the impacts of climate change, on the development and spread of human societies from -history to the 1500s in Asia, Africa, Europe, the Americas, and Hawai‘i/Oceania. Active learning environment. (
prerequisites: -history to the OCN 1500s in Asia, Africa, Europe, the Americas, and Hawai‘i/Oceania

title: Global Environmental Challenges
description: Scientific approach to evaluating human-caused environmental challenges and their potential solutions. Open to non-majors. (Spring only)

title: Introduction to Quantitative Earth and Environmental Science
description: Introduction to -calculus math and physics applied to Earth and environmental science. Students work on real-world problems and engage in participatory learning. Preparatory for classes in calculus and physics. MATH 134, 161, or MATH assessment exam (with score required for MATH 140X). (Fall only) (
prerequisites: -calculus math and physics applied to Earth and environmental science

title: Research Experiences in Marine Science
description: Inquiry-driven and experimental marine biology summer program based on the expertise of HIMB researchers whose specialties demonstrate how human impacts and global change affect coral reef ecosystems. Emphases on student team research projects. Repeatable one time. High school or UG freshman only. (Summer only)

title: Introduction to Directed Research
description: Reading and research in any area of Oceanography under the direction of a faculty member. Repeatable up to six credits.

title: Science of the Sea
description: Origin and features of ocean basins and seawater; global cycles of carbon and nutrients; currents; waves; tides; characteristics of marine organisms; marine ecological principles; marine pollution; climate change causes and consequences. Online asynchronous; synchronous format.

title: Science of the Sea Laboratory
description: Experiments, computer exercises, and field trips demonstrating the geological, physical, chemical, and biological principles of earth and ocean sciences. A-F only. 201 (or concurrent).

title: Global Environmental Change
description: Global environmental change problems such as carbon dioxide and the greenhouse effect, acid rain, chlorofluorocarbons and the ozone layer, global deforestation and the effect on climate, etc. 200, OCN 201, ERTH 101, ERTH 103, or ERTH 170; or consent. (
prerequisites: OCN 200, OCN 201, ERTH 101, ERTH 103, or ERTH 170; or consent

title: Advanced Mathematics for Scientists and Engineers I
description: Advanced mathematical methods with emphasis on application to the earth and ocean sciences and engineering. Topics include linear algebra, vector calculus, ordinary differential equations, and numerical methods. MATH 242 or consent. (

title: The Role of Models in Global Environmental Science
description: Introduction to philosophy of science for those with some background in the natural sciences. Special emphasis on issues arising from the construction and use of models. any course 200 or above in PHIL or any course 200 or above with either DB or DP designation, or consent. (Alt. years: spring) (
prerequisites: any course OCN 200 or above in PHIL or any course OCN 200 or above with either DB or DP designation, or consent

title: Introduction to Environmental Monitoring Systems and Measurements
description: Introduction to environmental monitoring systems for earth science students. Students will learn how to construct, program, and deploy simple environmental monitoring systems to collect in-situ environmental data. OCN, ERTH, ATMO majors only. A-F only. 201/201L or ERTH 101/101L, CHEM 161/161L, and MATH 241; or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: OCN 201/OCN 201L or ERTH 101/ERTH 101L, CHEM 161/CHEM 161L, and MATH 241; or consent

title: Global Environmental Change Laboratory
description: (2-hr Lab) Laboratory to supplement GES 311. Quantitative aspects of global environmental change will be addressed through problem-solving and computer modeling. GES majors only. A-F only. GES 311, MATH 242, PHYS 170/170L, and CHEM 161/161L; or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: GES 311, MATH 242, PHYS 170/PHYS 170L, and CHEM 161/CHEM 161L; or consent

title: Aquatic Pollution
description: Pollution of freshwater and marine systems by human activities. Causes, consequences, and correctives. 201, CHEM 161, BIOL 171. (

title: Applied Principles of Environmental & Energy Policy
description: Introduction to the methods and techniques of environmental and energy policy in relation to energy systems. Analysis of enacted policies from case studies to understanding the effectiveness, challenges, contradictions, and limitations of each. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. any 100 or 200 level OCN course, or consent. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: any OCN 100 or OCN 200 level OCN course, or consent

title: Mineral and Energy Resources of the Sea
description: Hard mineral and petroleum origins, exploration, and exploitation. Renewable and non-renewable resources distribution. Political and scientific constraints. 201, ORE 202; or consent. (

title: Living Resources of the Sea-Mai ke Kai Mai ke Ola
description: Marine fisheries, aquaculture, and law of the sea. Principles of management of renewable resources. Political and scientific constraints and limitations. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Ecology of Infectious Diseases and Symbioses
description: Introduction to the ecology of infectious diseases of animals, plants, and humans. Factors affecting disease transmission and virulence. Effects of human activities and environmental change on disease transmission. Emphasis on issues pertinent to Hawai‘i. A-F only. (BIOL 171 and BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: (BIOL 171 and BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Undergraduate Internship
description: Experiential approach to earth science; students serve as interns to field professionals; responsibilities include supervised field work. Undergraduate SOEST majors only. Open to GES majors. Repeatable one time. CR/ NC only. junior/senior standing and consent.

title: Directed Reading
description: Directed reading in earth system science, oceanography, or environmental science. Repeatable up to 6 credits. consent. (

title: Biogeochemical Systems
description: Relationship of biogeochemical cycles in the atmosphere, lithosphere, and biosphere to global chemical cycles and planetary climatic conditions. GES degree foundation and capstone course with an emphasis on improving student writing skills. GES majors only. Senior standing only. A-F only. 201, GES 311, BIOL 172/172L, CHEM 162/162L, ERTH 101/101L, GES 319L (or concurrent), ATMO 200 (or concurrent), and GES/OCN 499 (or concurrent); or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: OCN 201, GES 311, BIOL 172/BIOL 172L, CHEM 162/CHEM 162L, ERTH 101/ERTH 101L, GES 319L (or concurrent), ATMO 200 (or concurrent), and GES/OCN 499 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Marine Functional Ecology and Biotechnology
description: Marine functional genomics, biodiversity of marine natural habitats, marine microbial communities and their ecological functions, interactions of marine microbes and their host, climate change and marine biodiversity, marine biotechnology. A-F only. 201 or MICR 130, or consent. (Spring only) (

title: The Ethics of Climate Change and Geoengineering
description: Provide a scientific basis to examine the consequences of climate change and the proposed geoengineering solutions, and examine the fundamental ethical basis that underlies environmental policies. A-F only. 310.
crossListings: Alt. years: spring Crosslisted as SUST 414

title: Advanced Environmental Monitoring Systems and Measurements
description: Builds upon 318 using more advanced microprocessors and environmental sensors, 3D printing, programming, etc. to construct, program, and deploy environmental monitoring systems to collect and stream in-situ time-series environmental measurements. OCN, ERTH, ATMO majors only. A-F only. 318, MATH 242, PHYS 272/272L, and CHEM 162/162L; or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: OCN 318, MATH 242, PHYS 272/PHYS 272L, and CHEM 162/CHEM 162L; or consent

title: Marine Geology
description: Sediments, structure, geophysics, geochemistry, history of ocean basins and margins. ERTH 200 and ERTH 302, or consent. (

title: Introduction to Deep-Sea Biology
description: (1.5 Lec, 1.5 Discussion) Biology and ecology of deepsea organisms and communities. Topics including bentho-pelagic coupling, depth zonation, energetics, diversity, adaptations, hydrothermal vents, seamounts, abyssal plains, deep-sea resource extraction and global climate change. A-F only. 201 and BIOL 265, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Climate Change and Urbanization
description: The following topics will be addressed: How are cities impacted by, and impacting climate change? How do urbanization, alteration of atmospheric processes, and extreme weather events affect urban systems and populations? A-F only. 363 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Principles of Sustainability Analysis
description: Key principles of sustainability and its analysis. Quantification of environmental impact/assessment using target plots, mass/energy balances, and life cycle analyses (cradle to gate/grave) applied to products, processes, or systems. Use of SimaPro. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Environmental Management Systems
description: Introduction to the process of developing Environmental Management Systems that address the principles outlined in ISO14001:2015. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Plate Tectonics
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Quantitative geometrical analysis techniques of plate tectonics theory; instantaneous and finite rotation poles; triple-junction analysis; plate boundary stresses. ERTH 200 or consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Aquaculture Production
description: Theory and practice of aquaculture: reproduction, yield trials, management, economics, and business case studies of fish, crustaceans, and molluscs. Field classes held at commercial farm and hatchery. ANSC 321 and ANSC 445: or BIOL 172/172L and CHEM 162/162L or higher. (
prerequisites: ANSC 321 and ANSC 445: or BIOL 172/BIOL 172L and CHEM 162/CHEM 162L or higher

title: Earth’s Microbiome
description: Lecture on the diversity and function of the Earth’s microbiomes, inclusive of terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems, symbiotic and free living microorganisms with a focus on the microbial underpinnings of the Earth’s biogeochemistry. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. 102 or 201 or BOT 305 or BIOL 305, or BIOL 171 and BIOL 172. (Alt years: Fall) (
prerequisites: OCN 102 or OCN 201 or BOT 305 or BIOL 305, or BIOL 171 and BIOL 172

title: Earth’s Microbiome Lab
description: Lab on the diversity and function of the Earth’s microbiomes, inclusive of terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems, symbiotic and free living microorganisms with a focus on the microbial underpinnings of the Earth’s biogeochemistry. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. 102 or 201 or BOT 305 or BIOL 305, or BIOL 171 and BIOL 172. (Alt years: Fall) (
prerequisites: OCN 102 or OCN 201 or BOT 305 or BIOL 305, or BIOL 171 and BIOL 172

title: Ridge to Reef: Coastal Ecosystem Ecology and Connectivity
description: Watershed and coastal biogeochemistry/ecosystem science. Emphasis on field surveying and sampling of stream and reef habitats; laboratory chemical/biological analyses. Analysis of land use impacts on ecosystem health and ahupua‘a resource management. A-F only. 201/201L; and either OCN/ATMO 310, or GES 311; or consent.
prerequisites: OCN 201/OCN 201L; and either OCN/ATMO 310, or GES 311; or consent

title: Data Analysis in Earth Science
description: Combined lecture, discussion, and laboratory on global Earth system databases and satellite instrumentation, including computer laboratory. GES majors only. A-F only. MATH 242; or consent. (

title: Dynamics of Marine Ecosystems: Biological-Physical Interactions in the Oceans
description: Combined lecture and discussion examining biological and physical interactions in the oceans and their impacts on the functioning of marine ecosystems. GES majors only. A-F only. 201/201L, GES 311, GES 319L, and PHYS 272/272L; and consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: OCN 201/OCN 201L, GES 311, GES 319L, and PHYS 272/PHYS 272L; and consent

title: Introduction to Ocean Ecosystem Modeling
description: Introduction to modeling biogeochemical and physical oceanic processes by building a coupled model of the Pacific to investigate physical effects on plankton blooms. Students learn ecosystem dynamics, basic numerical methods, and programming. A-F only. GES majors only. (OCN/ATMO 310 or GES 311 or PHYS 272, and OCN/ERTH 312) with a minimum grade of B-. (Fall only)
prerequisites: (OCN/ATMO 310 or GES 311 or PHYS 272, and OCN/ERTH 312) with a minimum grade of B-

title: Communication of Research Results
description: Lecture/discussion to provide instruction and experience in oral and written presentation of scientific results and material. GES majors only in their final semester. A-F only. OCN/GES 499 (or concurrent). (

title: Topics in Global Environmental Science
description: Lecture and discussion or seminar. Current topics in environmental science explored in detail. Typically offered by faculty in their specialties, or developed in response to student interest. GES majors only. Repeatable unlimited times, credits earned up to six credits. consent.

title: Undergraduate Thesis
description: Directed research in which the student carries out a scientific project of small to moderate scope with one or more chosen advisors. The student must complete a document in the style of a scientific journal article. Repeatable up to six credits. consent. (

title: Physical Oceanography
description: Introduction to properties of seawater, oceanographic instruments and methods, heat budget, general ocean circulation, regional oceanography, waves, tides, sea level. Formation of water masses, dynamics of circulation. Repeatable one time. MATH 242 (or concurrent), or consent.

title: Biological Oceanography
description: Factors governing productivity, population dynamics, distribution of organisms in major ecosystems of the ocean, emphasis on ecology of pelagic zone. OCN majors only. consent.

title: Geological Oceanography
description: Marine geological processes, ocean basin structure and tectonics, sedimentation. ERTH 101.

title: Chemical Oceanography
description: Chemical processes occurring in marine waters; why they occur and how they affect oceanic environment. CHEM 171.

title: Aquatic Photosynthesis
description: Biochemical and biophysical concepts of photosynthesis. Application and interpretation of ecological processes of photosynthesis in aquatic systems. Open to nonmajors. A-F only. consent. (Spring only)

title: Marine Microplankton Ecology
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Distribution, abundance, and ecology of marine microplankton, including bacteria, algae, and protozoans, with an emphasis on metabolic rates and processes. consent. (Fall only)

title: Ecology of Pelagic Marine Animals
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Ecology of pelagic animals including feeding, energetics, predation, and anti-predation tactics. Life-history strategies, vertical flux of materials, population dynamics, fisheries. consent. (Spring only)

title: Benthic Biological Oceanography
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Processes controlling the structure and function of benthic communities, including organism-sediment-flow interactions, sediment geochemistry, feeding strategies, recruitment, succession, and population interactions. OCN and MB majors only. consent.

title: Molecular Methods in Marine Ecology
description: Molecular methods for studying marine functional ecology; emphasis on hand-on tools for ecological and biogeochemical processes of microbes; developing practical skills for research project in marine microbial ecology and biological oceanography. A-F only. 403, 626, 627, or 628; or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: OCN 403, OCN 626, OCN 627, or OCN 628; or consent

title: Deep-Sea Biology
description: (1.5 Lec, 1.5 Discussion) Biology and ecology of deep-sea organisms and communities. Topics including bentho-pelagic coupling, depth zonation, energetics, diversity, adaptations, hydrothermal vents, seamounts, abyssal plains, deep-sea resource extraction, and global climate change. consent. (Alt. years)

title: Ocean Minerals
description: Distribution, origin, processes of formation. Sulfides, oxides, and placer minerals. Comparative studies of continental ore bodies. Submarine rift, subduction, and abduction. one of 622, 623, ERTH 407, or ERTH 603.
prerequisites: one of OCN 622, OCN 623, ERTH 407, or ERTH 603

title: Biogeochemical Methods in Oceanography
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Current methods of analysis used in the ocean sciences, both in the field and in the laboratory. An ocean-going field trip provides students with hands-on training in sample collection and processing. The latter is followed by laboratory analyses of the collected samples throughout the remainder of the semester. BIOL 171 and CHEM 161 and ERTH 101; or consent.
prerequisites: BIOL 171 and CHEM 161 and ERTH 101; or consent

title: Aquatic Chemistry
description: Chemical reactions support lie and stabilize Earth’s climate. We explore marine and fresh waters through chemical dquilibrium and reaction kinetics. Topics include mineral stability, ocean acidification, complexation/bioavailability, pollution, and quantitative approximation of natural systems. 623 (or concurrent), or consent. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Aquatic Microbial Geochemistry
description: The synergy between the biogeochemistry of element cycling and the microbial organisms involved, interfacing across disciplines from the perspective of a practical blend of aquatic chemistry, microbiology, biogeochemistry, and molecular biology. 623 and consent. (Alt years: fall)

title: Earth System Science and Global Change
description: Global view of the planet and how it functions as an integrated unit. Biogeochemical processes, dynamics, and cycles, and analysis of natural and human-induced environmental change. Chemical history of ocean-atmosphere-sediment system and co-evolution of the biota. Repeatable one time. BS in environmentally related science or one year of chemistry, physics, and calculus. (
prerequisites: BS in environmentally related science or one year of chemistry, physics, and calculus

title: Observational Physical Oceanography
description: Application of the scientific method; physical regimes in the ocean; ocean processes and observational strategies; resolution, sampling, array design and observing systems; models and data assimilation; major field programs; operational oceanography and climate prediction. 620 and consent.

title: Origin of Sedimentary Rocks
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Environment of deposition and subsequent diagenesis of modern and ancient sediments. Petrogenesis of siliciclastic, carbonate and orthochemical rocks. Sedimentology, sedimentary petrography and geochemistry. Repeatable one time. consent. (

title: Elemental Composition Changes
description: Changes in the chemical composition of meteorites, bulk Earth, Earth’s mantle and crust, sedimentary rocks, hydrosphere and biosphere, and underlying principles. consent. (

title: Topics in Marine Geochemistry
description: Seminar on a broad topic; discussion and critique of research papers. Repeatable one time. 623 or consent.

title: Sedimentary Geochemistry
description: Geochemical thermodynamics and kinetics and their use in interpreting the origin of sediments, sedimentary rocks, and natural waters over a range of pressure-temperature conditions. CHEM 171, MATH 242, PHYS 152; or consent. (

title: Math Techniques for Oceanographers
description: (3 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Introduction to numerical methods, data analysis, error propagation, box models, linear and nonlinear least squares, perturbation theory, numerical integration. MATH 244 or MATH 253A.

title: Methods in Microbiology Oceanography
description: (1 8-hr Lab) Modern methods for sampling microbial populations from the sea and for quantifying biomass and in siturates of metabolism. Integrated field projects, theme varies. OCN majors only. 621 or 623, and 626; or consent.
prerequisites: OCN 621 or OCN 623, and OCN 626; or consent

title: Ocean Waves I
description: Survey of wave types-acoustic, capillary, gravity, inertial, vorticity. Basic wave concepts emphasized: phase and group velocities, standing waves, energy conservation, dispersion, refraction, diffraction. Rotation and boundary effects are covered: reflection, basin modes, trapping, tides. MATH 402 or consent.

title: Ocean Waves II
description: Baroclinic gravity waves, inertial waves, mid-latitude Rossby waves, topographic waves, equatorial waves. 660 or consent.

title: Marine Hydrodynamics
description: Introduction to classical hydrodynamics and continuum mechanics. Techniques for solution of Navier Stokes equations on various scales of oceanic motion; potential theory, dynamic modeling, and viscous and rotational processes. MATH 403.

title: Satellite Oceanography
description: Techniques of satellite observations of the ocean, including temperature, pigment concentration, currents, and winds; analysis of a satellite data set as term project. A-F only. OCN majors only. 620 or consent.

title: Oceanographic Instrumentation and Technology
description: Measurement techniques in physical oceanography, including pressure, temperature, salinity, oxygen, optical sensors, current meters, navigation systems, ocean acoustics, and mooring structures. Includes a laboratory research project. A-F only. OCN majors only. 620 or consent.

title: Small-Scale Air-Sea Interaction
description: Observations and theory of small-scale processes which couple the atmosphere and ocean boundary layers, including introduction to turbulence theory and parameterization of turbulent fluxes. MATH 402 and MATH 403 (or their equivalents) and either 620 or ATMO 600, or consent. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: MATH 402 and MATH 403 (or their equivalents) and either MATH 620 or ATMO 600, or consent

title: Large-Scale Ocean-Atmosphere Interactions
description: Lecture/seminar introduces physical oceanography and meteorology students to the state-of-the-art theories and observations of large-scale ocean-atmosphere interaction, as well as conveying the fundamental understanding that has been developed during the past 30 years. Emphasis will be on phenomena such as El Nino/Southern Oscillation, the North Atlantic Oscillation, the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, and global climate change. Repeatable one time. 620 or ATMO 600, or consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Advanced Geophysical Fluid Dynamics I
description: Basic concepts and equations to describe large-scale ocean circulation; numerical models; boundary layers; models of wind-driven circulation of a homogeneous ocean. 620 and 662, or consent.

title: Advanced Geophysical Fluid Dynamics II
description: Thermodynamics of stratified fluids; convection; mixing; models of the thermohaline circulation; the role of eddies in the large-scale ocean circulation. 667 or consent.

title: Paleoceanography
description: Study of the paloeceanographic and paleoclimate evolution of the Earth’s oceans, atmosphere, and biosphere. Repeatable one time. consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Dynamics of Marine Ecosystems: Biological-Physical Interactions in the Oceans
description: Combined lecture/discussion examining biological and physical interactions in the oceans and their impacts on the functioning of marine ecosystems. A-F only. previous course in marine science, or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: previous course in marine science, or consent

title: Introduction to Ocean Ecosystem Modeling
description: Introduction to modeling biological and physical oceanic processes by building a coupled model of the Pacific to investigate physical effects on biological production. Students will learn biological-physical dynamics, basic numerical methods, and programming. 620, 621, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Data Science Fundamentals in R
description: (3 hr Lec/Lab) Introduces project management, data analysis, and mathematical and statistical modeling using R as a platform. Students will learn principles and benefits of programming languages to apply skills to their own research. (

title: Advanced Statistics in R
description: (2 hr Lec, 1 hr Lab) In-depth introduction to the modern statistical methods necessary for analyzing biological/ecological data, including GLMs, GAMs, mixed models, ordination, etc. Students will learn how to perform these methods in R.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent. CR/NC only.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Topics in Biological Oceanography
