description: Seminar. Literature and concepts in one of several active fields considered in detail. Repeatable three times, credits earned up to 12 credits. consent.

title: Topics in Physical Oceanography
description: Near-shore processes, advanced mathematical techniques, recent developments, etc. Typically given by visiting professors in their specialties, or in response to student interest. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Chemical Oceanography
description: OCN 770 Seminar in Chemical Oceanography (1) | 2024-2025 General Catalog Skip to Main Content UHM Home A-Z Index Directory Students Faculty and Staff Parents Alumni MyUH University of Hawai‘i ® at Mānoa 2024-2025 General Catalog Menu Open Mobile Menu Search Search this site Site search About About UH President and Provost Message Campus Map Student Life Campus Policies and Information Personnel Calendar Courses Course Overview Sample Course Description Diversification Courses General Education Designations Course Numbering System Undergraduate Undergraduate Education Programs Undergraduate General Education Requirements Tuition, Fees, and Financial Aid Graduate Graduate Division Graduate Programs Tuition, Fees, and Financial Aid Degrees, Minors & Certificates Colleges, Schools & Academic Units Home Courses OCN 770 Seminar in Chemical Oceanography (1) OCN 770 Seminar in Chemical Oceanography (1) Oceanography (OCN) , School of Ocean and Earth Science & Technology ← OCN 760 Topics in Physical Oceanography (V) OCN 780 Seminar (1) → 2024-2025 General Catalog Mānoa Catalog Office 2500 Campus Road, Hawaii Hall 121 Please note: This Catalog was prepared to provide information and does not constitute a contract. title: Seminar
description: Oceanographic topics of current interest. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Proposal Development
description: Introduction to the organization and functioning of oceanography funding agencies, the peer-review process, and the design and development of a research proposal. Repeatable one time. OCN majors only. CR/NC only. two of the following: 621, 626, 627 (or concurrent), or 628 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: two of the following: OCN 621, OCN 626, OCN 627 (or concurrent), or OCN 628 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Academic and Personal Exploration
description: Seminar introduces students to goal setting, time management, major exploration, academic planning, service-learning opportunities, student/faculty meetings, financial literacy, and encourages frequent self-reflection. Instructor approval required. A-F only.

title: Academic and Career Exploration
description: Seminar introduces exploratory students to major and career exploration resources, guides students in developing personal, academic, and career goals and plans, and encourages frequent self-reflection. Develops written communication skills. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Majors and UH Mānoa
description: Major exploration providing incoming students with an understanding of the tools to navigate UH Mānoa and explore the programs of study available. Introduction to career development, goal setting, and action planning. Freshmen only. Exploratory majors only. A-F only.

title: Your Academic Journey
description: Provides exploratory students with the knowledge/skills to thrive in college and beyond. Utilizes writing as a tool for research, analysis, exploration, and reflection. Topics include major and career exploration, personal interests, and goal-setting. May not be taken concurrently or after UNIV 340. Freshmen and sophomores only. Exploratory designations only. A-F only.

title: Metacognitive Strategies for College Success
description: Theories of the memory processes and the application of the Information Processing Systems in developing metacognitive strategies for college classroom success. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Passages
description: Interactive course develops mentoring skills and relationships with peers, mentors, and “elders.” Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. (Summer only)

title: Transformational Research Experiences for Early Undergraduates
description: Introduction to exploring discover-based investigation, with hands-on experiences in a wide range of science fields. Divided into 4-week learning modules led by researchers at several UH Mānoa research facilities on and off campus. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. (

title: Faculty Mentored Research and Creative Work Project
description: Directed research for undergraduate students conducting faculty-mentored research or creative work projects. Repeatable three times, up to ten credits. CR/NC only. consent of UROP director and student faculty mentor. (Summer only)
prerequisites: consent of UROP director and student faculty mentor

title: University Experience
description: An introduction to the university community; topics include critical thinking, the value of higher education, cultural and transition issues. A-F only.

title: Topics in Learning Techniques & Technologies
description: Student-centered topics on techniques and technologies used for successful learning. Emphasizes the cultivation of learning dispositions and strategies for achievement in higher education and beyond. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only.

title: ACE Mentoring: Facilitating Student Development
description: Theoretical foundations in student learning and holistic development. Practical leadership skills acquisition and application through the facilitation of a seminar for new freshmen. Emphasis on developing proficiency in writing and public speech. Repeatable one time. A-F only. consent. (Fall only)

title: Academic Exploration Through Advising
description: Major exploration designed to assist exploratory students in the process of researching personal, career, and educational goals through writing and the impact of these goals on the decision-making process. Emphasis on written self-reflection and identity. Sophomore standing. A-F only.

title: Mānoa Peer Advisor Training Course
description: Intensive course designed for peer advisor trainees to learn General Education requirements, university policies and procedures, and campus resources. Trainees also develop skills and strategies necessary to provide quality advising to their fellow students. A-F only (Summer only)

title: Collaborative Learning: Foundations of Tutoring
description: Theory and practice of collaborative learning in academic contexts. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Topics in Major and Career Exploration
description: Major and career development for Exploratory students, using written and oral communication to facilitate learning across varied topics. Junior standing or higher. Exploratory students only. A-F only. 340 or consent.

title: Mānoa Peer Advisor Leader Training and Leadership Practicum
description: A reflective apprenticeship in which Peer Advisor Leaders solidify their understanding of advising and learn more about leadership and deepen their facilitation, communication, collaboration, and leadership skills by mentoring a cohort of peer advisor trainees. Repeatable two times. A-F only. 350 (or equivalent course) (with a minimum grade of B). (Summer only
prerequisites: UNIV 350 (or equivalent course) (with a minimum grade of B)

title: Overseas Study
description: Registration allows student to maintain enrolled status at UH Mānoa while taking courses abroad. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Pacific Worlds: An Introduction to Pacific Islands Studies
description: Introduces students to the geography, societies, histories, cultures, contemporary issues, and arts of Oceania, including Hawai‘i. Combines lectures and discussion that emphasize Pacific Islander perspectives and experiences. A-F only.

title: Politics and Poetics of Climate Change in Oceania
description: Examines the causes and impacts of, and responses to, climate change in the Pacific Islands through interdisciplinary approaches: natural sciences, politics, economics, as well as legal, cultural, and creative/artistic dimensions. A-F only.

title: Islands of Globalization
description: Combined lectures, service-learning. Examines the nature and impact of globalization on Pacific Island societies, viewed from the perspective of islanders who engage with global forces and processes, and create strategies to survive. Limit 20 students. A-F only.

title: Pacific Islands Movement and Migration
description: Combined lecture and service-learning activities. Examines the diaspora of Pacific Islanders. Includes a service-learning activity examining cultural, political, and economic status of groups of Pacific Islanders living in other Pacific places. Limit of 20 students. A-F only.

title: Arts in Oceania–An Introduction
description: Practical and theoretical study of arts in Oceania in relevant cultural contexts. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Pacific Communities in Hawai‘i
description: Examines Pacific Islander communities’ experiences in Hawai‘i through service learning, reading, writing, lecture, and discussion. Concerns about housing, employment, education, health, language, and culture are central. A-F only.

title: Contemporary Issues in Oceania
description: Combined lecture/discussion. Examination of critical political, social, and economic issues in the Pacific Islands region today.

title: Thinking Through Pacific Arts, Ritual, and Performance
description: Lecture, discussion, and workshop series surveys arts, ritual, and performance practices throughout the Pacific. Engaging with Pacific traditions of thought, and creative approaches to research, students also return findings to Pacific communities. Repeatable one time. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Islands and Archipelagos
description: Applies an island studies perspective to critically evaluate the commonalities and differences across islands and archipelagos in several world regions. Examines how island geographies influence social identities and movements and are impacted by environmental conditions. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. (

title: Literature of the Pacific
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of the literature of the Pacific, including Pacific voyagers and contemporary writings in English by Pacific Islanders. one ENG DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable up to 12 credits.

title: Pacific Islander Collaborative Research
description: Engage in intensive collaborative research with a Pacific Islander community in Hawaiʻi, culminating in a research paper and public presentation. Oral communication is an essential component of this course. Junior standing or higher.

title: Drama and Theatre of Oceania
description: Survey of the contemporary drama and theatre of Oceania that combines island and Western traditions. Includes Papua New Guinea, Hawai‘i, Fiji, Samoa, Australia, New Zealand. ANTH 350 or THEA 101, or consent. (

title: Studies in Hawaiian and/or Pacific Literature
description: Intensive study of selected questions, issues, traditions, writers, movements, or genres in the field of Pacific literature. Repeatable one time. ENG 320 and one other 300-level ENG course.
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course

title: Topics in Pacific Islands Studies
description: Repeatable two times.

title: Moving Images in the Pacific Islands
description: Critically examines indigenous and foreign representations of the Pacific Islands and is designed to make film a central focus of inquiry for students interested in the contemporary Pacific. Repeatable one time.

title: Culture and Consumption in Oceania
description: Lecture on changing patterns of consumption in Oceania, and the historical, political, cultural, artistic, and economic forces shaping such practices. upper division standing, or consent.

title: Learning Oceania
description: Graduate seminar. Introduction to the nature and origins of Pacific Studies as an organized field of study. Epistemological, conceptual, political and ethical issues facing students of the region today. Co-requisite: 602.

title: Re/Presenting Oceania: Pacific and American Perspectives
description: Graduate seminar. Critical analysis of the way physical, social and cultural aspects of Oceania have been represented in scholarly and popular media. Co-requisite: 601.

title: Researching Oceania: Creative and Conventional Methods of Inquiry
description: Graduate seminar. Literacy, theory and method in the creation of a Master’s research project. 601 and 602.

title: Women in Oceania
description: Will look at feminist theory, ethnography, culture, activism and globalization in the context of writing, research and film on or by Women in Oceania. consent.

title: Topics in Histories of Oceania
description: Reading and research on major issues, topics, and themes in the history of Oceania. Repeatable three times. graduate standing or consent. (

title: Graduate Seminar: Change in the Pacific
description: Interrelationship of change in selected Pacific Islands regions, institutions, and processes. Repeatable two times. consent.

title: Master’s Portfolio Project
description: Independent study for students working on MA portfolio projects. A grade of satisfactory (S) is assigned when the project is satisfactorily completed. Repeatable one time. A-F only. graduate standing in PACS.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Survey of Conflict Management
description: Survey of contemporary conflict management and resolution: negotiation, mediation, conciliation, ombuds, fact-finding, facilitation techniques, arbitration, and litigation. any social science 100- or 200-level course or consent.
prerequisites: any social science PACE 100- or PACE 200-level course or consent

title: Governing, Policy, and Political Journalism
description: Survey of the institutions of democratic governance and the role of journalism in covering and analyzing public policy. A-F only. (

title: Survey Peace and Conflict Studies
description: Survey of basic concepts, ethical relationships, methods, and debates in modern peace research and the oral skills needed for conflict resolution studies. any social science 100- or 200-level course or consent.
prerequisites: any social science PACE 100- or PACE 200-level course or consent

title: Personal Peace: Stories of Hope
description: Interviewing, writing, and publishing stories of those who have overcome great difficulties to find personal peace. grade of B or better in ENG 100 or consent.
prerequisites: grade of B or better in ENG 100 or consent

title: Greek and Roman War Literature
description: Survey of war-related literature from Greece and Rome, its major themes, and how it reflects the wide range of social, political, intellectual, and literary perspectives on war found in the ancient world. sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: sophomore standing or higher, or consent

title: Aggression, War, and Peace
description: Biocultural, evolutionary, and cross-cultural perspectives on the conditions, patterns, and processes of violence, war, nonviolence, and peace. ANTH 152. (

title: Nonviolent Political Alternatives
description: Exploration of scientific and cultural resources for nonviolent alternatives in politics. any 100- or 200-level POLS course; or consent. (
prerequisites: any PACE 100- or PACE 200-level POLS course; or consent

title: Media Communications and Conflict
description: Mass communication and conflict; deals with understanding the role of news media in influencing conflict, and introduces students to conflict-sensitive communications working to assist in resolving conflicts. Sophomore standing or higher. any 200-level DS course. (

title: The Meaning of War
description: Exploration of ethical questions related to the many facets of war–e.g., patriotism, tribalism, holy war, self-sacrifice, cowardice, media coverage, propaganda, torture, genocide, pillage, suicide tactics, battlefield immunity. (

title: Directed Reading
description: Directed reading in peace and conflict resolution. Repeatable three times. consent.

title: Media Ethics
description: Ethics and social responsibility for media professionals. Application of ethical theories and principles to case studies and research projects through writing assignments. JOUR majors only. one DS course. (

title: Peace Processes in Philippines and Hawai‘i
description: History of Philippine Islam and the Moro struggle, the peace process in Mindanao and sovereignty movement for Hawaiian nation. 75 min. Lec, 75-min. joint online discussion with Philippine students. Junior standing only. A-F only. consent. (Fall only) (

title: History of Peace Movements
description: Examination of two centuries of U.S., European, Australian, and Hawaiian peace, thought, and action. Also surveys early Christian and secular attitudes to war. Open to nonmajors. any DS course, or consent.

title: Gandhi, King, and Nonviolence
description: Life and thought of Mahatma Gandhi and Martin Luther King, Jr. any Social Science 100 or 200 level course, or consent.
prerequisites: any Social Science PACE 100 or PACE 200 level course, or consent

title: Terrorism
description: Multidisciplinary approach to the origins, dynamics, and consequences of international terrorism, including the psychological, legal, ethical and operational concerns of counterterrorism. any 200-level DS course, or consent.
prerequisites: any PACE 200-level DS course, or consent

title: Introduction to Human Rights: International and Comparative Perspectives
description: Introduction to international, regional, and domestic human rights law; comparative perspectives on the theoretical origins of human rights and policy debates on the protection of human rights, dispute resolution, and enforcement mechanisms. any 100 or 200 level social sciences course, or consent.
prerequisites: any PACE 100 or PACE 200 level social sciences course, or consent

title: Negotiation
description: Negotiation theory, negotiation skills and application of negotiation in conflict prevention, conflict management and conflict resolution with an emphasis on oral communication and contemporary ethical issues. any Social Science 100 or 200 level course, or consent.
prerequisites: any Social Science PACE 100 or PACE 200 level course, or consent

title: Leadership for Social Change
description: In-depth study of current models and emerging theories of ethical leadership in community service; development of tangible leadership skills, including communication, conflict resolution, team-building, and management skills. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. any 200-level DS course.

title: Geography of Peace and War
description: Geographical factors underlying conflict in the world. sophomore standing or higher, or consent. (
prerequisites: sophomore standing or higher, or consent

title: Peacebuilding in Performance
description: Provides an exploration of peacebuilding, its contributions to community and its intersectionality with the arts to influence non-violent conflict resulting in cultural performance for all to engage and enjoy. Sophomore standing or higher. any 100- or 200-level DS course
prerequisites: any PACE 100- or PACE 200-level DS course

title: Introduction to Mediation
description: Learn the core components of the mediation process and the tools for empowering mediation participants to reach customized resolutions. Emphasis on learning and applying the skills through exercises and mock mediation sessions.

title: Protest Under Occupation
description: Explore nonviolent protests when one Independent State controls the territory of another Independent State (or international organization, such as the United Nations), without the transfer of sovereign title. Sophomore standing or higher. any 200-level DS course.

title: Indigenous Nonviolent Action in the Asia-Pacific
description: Study of nonviolent methods (i.e., United Nations structures, international law, boycotts, and peaceful protest) used to gain political goals and examines their successes, failures, and the prospects for those that remain ongoing. Sophomore standing or higher. any 200-level DS course.

title: Introduction to Facilitating Organizational Change
description: Explores the characteristics of organizations from different perspectives including structural, political, ethical, and cultural frames from organizational theory and practice. Focuses on how to design organizational change strategies and facilitate their implementation. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. any 200-level DS course (with a minimum grade of C+).
prerequisites: any PACE 200-level DS course (with a minimum grade of C+)

title: Advocating for Children: Rights and Welfare
description: Multi-disciplinary advocacy for children’s rights and welfare in various social and political systems; the role of families, justice, economics, media, race, culture, environment on policy-making for children. Sophomore standing or higher. any 200-level DS course.

title: Culture and Conflict Resolution
description: Conflict resolution techniques for major world culture. Emphasis on cultures of the Pacific Basin, Pacific Islands, and Asia. any DS course, or consent.

title: International Law and Disputes
description: Management, prevention, resolution of international disputes and the role of international law. any Social Science 100 or 200 level course, or consent.
prerequisites: any Social Science PACE 100 or PACE 200 level course, or consent

title: ‘Ike Kūpuna: Introduction to Indigenous Frameworks for Peace Building
description: Survey of the concepts and major theories of indigenous epistemology that can create social change. any 100- or 200-level DS course.
prerequisites: any PACE 100- or PACE 200-level DS course

title: Managing Human Conflict
description: Introduction into the field of conflict analysis and resolution through the examination of theory and role-play. Major theories of conflict studies are considered and the forms of conflict resolution, such as negotiation, mediation, and arbitration. Sophomore standing or higher. any 200-level DS course.

title: Research and Peace
description: Introduction to and survey of the interdisciplinary field of peace research, combining theory, methodology, and empirical aspects. Sophomore standing or higher. any 200-level DS course. DS

title: Topics in Peace and Conflict Resolution
description: Recent issues, practices in peace and conflict resolution. Repeatable one time. any DS course, or consent.

title: Hiroshima & Peace
description: 10-day intensive course at Hiroshima City University, Japan, in the 2-weeks before the annual August 6 commemoration of the atomic bombing. Home-stay with Japanese family. Sophomore standing. A-F only. any 200 level social science course, or consent.
prerequisites: any PACE 200 level social science course, or consent

title: Practicum and Internship
description: The practicum and internship in Peace and Conflict Resolution provides an opportunity for students to apply the skills and concepts learned in earlier courses. any two other PACE courses or consent. (
prerequisites: any two other PACE courses or consent

title: Environmental Conflict Resolution
description: Explore how environmental conflicts emerge and the efforts to find common ground for resolution. Examine the issues, debates, and theoretical aspects that help to explain and frame environmental conflict. Graduate students only. (

title: Negotiation & Conflict Resolution
description: Negotiation as a foundational skill of conflict resolution; mastery of negotiation skills for strategic dispute resolution; non-routine problem-solving, creating partnerships and alliances; crafting optimal agreements. Students participate in simulations and acquire vital leadership skills. Graduate standing only. one of the following courses with a minimum grade of B: 429, 447, 477, 647, 652, or 668; or PLAN 627; or COMG 455 or SOC 730; or LAW 508; or MGT 660. (
prerequisites: one of the following courses with a minimum grade of B: PACE 429, PACE 447, PACE 477, PACE 647, PACE 652, or PACE 668; or PLAN 627; or COMG 455 or SOC 730; or LAW 508; or MGT 660

title: Gender: Law and Conflicts
description: Examines how international law and domestic legal systems address and resolve conflicts regarding women’s rights, gender roles, and gender identity. Takes a comparative approach with emphasis on the Asia-Pacific region. (

title: Seminar: Social Studies
description: Study in trends, research, and problems of implementation in teaching field. Repeatable two times. teaching experience or consent.(

title: Mediation: Theory and Practice
description: Combined lecture, discussion, and mediation simulations. Theory of ADR field. Theory of major different models of mediation, both in the U.S. and internationally. Application of mediation process to categories of disputes, family, workplace, and international. A-F only. graduate standing, or departmental approval. (Once a year)

title: Dispute Resolution System Design
description: Conflict prevention, management and resolution in the workplace. Design and implementation of effective systems integrating ADR and recent advances in dispute resolution methodology to government, health, nonprofit, educational, private sector and other institutions. graduate standing, or departmental approval.

title: Conflict Management for Educators
description: Conflict resolution theory and practice for administrators, faculty and staff in educational organizations. K-12, community colleges and universities. Application and theory of negotiation, mediation, facilitation and hybrid ADR processes. EDEA 601 or EDEA 650, or consent. (

title: Family Mediation
description: Theory and skills for practicing divorce and custody mediation. Negotiation and conflict intervention skills used by social workers, lawyers, and other intervenors in family conflict. Focus on Hawai‘i’s divorce and custody laws and practices. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. A-F only. consent.

title: Collaboration Between Sectors
description: Examine theories and practices of multisector collaboration (public, private, nonprofit). The use of collaboration as an alternative way of solving public problems. (

title: Facilitation: Facilitating Community and Organizational Change
description: Advanced conflict resolution course. Covers key issues in the prevention, management and resolution of multiparty conflicts. Combined lecture, discussion, and simulations. A-F only. Graduate students only or departmental approval. (Once a year) (

title: Topics: Conflict Theory
description: Recent issues of policy and practice in peace and conflict management theory. Repeatable up to 12 credits. A-F only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Conflict Resolution Practicum
description: Practice in conflict resolution skills. Open to candidates for Certificate in Conflict Resolution. Repeatable one time or up to three credits. A-F only. consent.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Repeatable up to 9 credits. A-F only. departmental approval or consent.

title: Advanced Topics: Conflict Theory
description: Advanced seminar covering issues of policy and practice in peace and conflict management theory. Repeatable one time. Graduate standing only. consent.

title: Introduction to Philosophy: Survey of Problems
description: Introduction to the kinds of problems that concern philosophers and to some of the solutions that have been attempted.

title: Introduction to Philosophy: Morals and Society
description: Philosophical attempts to evaluate conduct, character, and social practices. DH

title: Asian Traditions
description: Universal themes and problems from Asian perspective.

title: Introduction to Philosophy: Environmental Philosophy
description: A critical examination of environmental issues; analyzing the nature of the human being, the nature of nature, and the relationship of the human being to nature.

title: Philosophy Through Computer Science
description: Introduction to classic philosophical issues (e.g., external world skepticism and free will) through computational concepts grounded in an introduction to computer science using Python. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Deductive Logic
description: Principles of modern deductive logic.

title: Introduction to Inductive Logic
description: Introduction to the theory of arguments based on probabilities and to the theory of decision-making in the context of uncertainty. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Critical Thinking
description: (LED) Introduction to critical thinking and its application in everyday life. The materials progress from logic and the structure of argument to fallacies and the nature of science. A-F only.

title: How To Be Happy
description: Everyone wants to be happy. What is happiness? How do we become happy? Students examine and practice proposals from ancient philosophy and tragedy and recent psychology about the ingredients, methods, and difficulties of living well.

title: Introduction to World Philosophy I
description: Introduction to philosophy as it has manifested itself differently across cultures throughout the world. Focus on the development of philosophical thought from its beginnings up until 1500 CE.A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Introduction to World Philosophy II
description: Philosophy attempts to understand the human being and the societies they form. Introduces students to the notion of world philosophy, focusing upon thinkers who have helped to shape our present. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Ancient Philosophy
description: An introduction to the history of philosophy based on translations of texts originally written in classical Greek or Latin.

title: Medieval to Enlightenment Philosophy
description: Introduction to the history of philosophy based on translations of texts originally written by men and women in post-classical Latin and Arabic. Significant attention is paid to developing writing skills.

title: Modern Philosophy
description: Introduction to the history of philosophy based on texts or translations of “modern” works, that is works originally written in a modern European language.

title: Women Philosophers
description: Introduces students to the ideas of women philosophers. Repeatable one time. A-F only. any course 100 or above in PHIL or WGSS, or consent. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: any course PHIL 100 or above in PHIL or WGSS, or consent

title: Existentialism: Freedom, Being, Death
description: Introduction to the major thinkers and the fundamental concepts and debates of Existentialism, taking Existentialism as a global movement expressed not just in philosophical texts, but also in literature and film. A-F only.

title: Philosophy and Science Fiction
description: Will use important works of science fiction and philosophy to explore philosophical questions, such as the nature of personal identity and the meaning of human life. A-F only.

title: Love and Sex
description: Survey of classical and contemporary perspectives of the philosophy of love, marriage, relationships, sex, sexual identity, representations of sex and sexuality. one PHIL 100-level course or consent of instructor.
prerequisites: one PHIL 100-level course or consent of instructor

title: Business Ethics
description: Case studies and critical analyses of ethical issues in business. Readings from business, philosophy, law, etc. any course 100 or above in PHIL or BUS or BLAW, or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 100 or above in PHIL or BUS or BLAW, or consent

title: Ethical Theory
description: Problems and methods in theory of moral conduct and decision. any course 101 or above in PHIL or above 100 in POLS or SOC; or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 101 or above in PHIL or above PHIL 100 in POLS or SOC; or consent

title: Political Philosophy
description: Problems and methods in philosophical theories of political legitimacy. any course 101 or above in PHIL or above 100 in POLS or SOC, or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 101 or above in PHIL or above PHIL 100 in POLS or SOC, or consent

title: Social Philosophy
description: Problems and methods in examination of contemporary life, values, and institutions in light of traditional philosophical problems of freedom, justice, authority, equality. any course 101 or above in PHIL or above 100 in POLS or SOC, or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 101 or above in PHIL or above PHIL 100 in POLS or SOC, or consent

title: Metaphysics
description: Problems arising from attempts to categorize rationally what is, and what appears to be. Among others, topics may include universals and particulars, personal identity, freedom and determinism, and time. any course 100 or above in PHIL, or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 100 or above in PHIL, or consent

title: Philosophy of Religion
description: Problems and methods. Nature of religious experience, alternatives to theism, existence of god, relation between faith and reason, nature of religious language.

title: Philosophy of Art
description: Problems and methods in aesthetic valuation and in appreciation, creation, and criticism of artworks.

title: Theory of Knowledge
description: Problems and methods in epistemology. Nature of knowledge, its varieties, possibilities, and limitations. any course 100 or above in PHIL, or 200 or above with either DB or DP or DS designation; or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 100 or above in PHIL, or PHIL 200 or above with either DB or DP or DS designation; or consent

title: Philosophy of Science
description: Problems and methods. Domains of inquiry, methods of validation, and attendant moral concerns. any course 100 or above in PHIL, or 200 or above with either DB or DP designation; or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 100 or above in PHIL, or PHIL 200 or above with either DB or DP designation; or consent

title: Philosophy of Education
description: Uses tools of philosophical inquiry to explore historical and contemporary perspectives on the nature of education, including concepts of knowledge, teaching, learning, and human flourishing. Repeatable one time. any course 100 or above in PHIL, or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 100 or above in PHIL, or consent

title: Ethics in Health Care
description: Ethical issues in application and organization of biomedical resources; professional responsibility, confidentiality, euthanasia, experimentation on human subjects, etc. any course 100 or above in PHIL or MED or NURS or with a DB designation; or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 100 or above in PHIL or MED or NURS or with a DB designation; or consent

title: Philosophy and Aesthetics of Film
description: Aesthetics and ontology of film and video, based on readings in the philosophy of film and the viewing of a number of films per semester.

title: Ethics in Practice
description: Team-taught exploration of five contemporary ethical issues using a variety of philosophical approaches and methods. any 101 course or above in PHIL or above 100 in POLS or SOC; or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: any PHIL 101 course or above in PHIL or above PHIL 100 in POLS or SOC; or consent

title: Philosophy and Evolution
description: Explores the ethical and epistemological implications of the theory of evolution. (Alt. years)

title: Critical Thinking: Pre-Medicine
description: Scientific and social perspectives on the nature of disease and their impact on medical practice. Exploration of these topics through reading, writing and critical inquiry. any course in PHIL, 100 or above; or any two BIOL, CHEM or PHYS courses; or consent.
prerequisites: any course in PHIL, PHIL 100 or above; or any two BIOL, CHEM or PHYS courses; or consent

title: The Role of Models in Global Environmental Science
description: Introduction to philosophy of science for those with some background in the natural sciences. Special emphasis on issues arising from the construction and use of models. any course 200 or above in PHIL or any course 200 or above with either DB or DP designation, or consent. (Alt. years: spring) (
prerequisites: any course PHIL 200 or above in PHIL or any course PHIL 200 or above with either DB or DP designation, or consent

title: Science, Technology, and Society
description: Investigation of some of the complex interconnections between science, technology, and society. any course 100 or above in PHIL or in a course with either DB or DP or DS designation, or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 100 or above in PHIL or in a course with either DB or DP or DS designation, or consent

title: Critical Thinking: Pre-Law
description: Introduction to concepts and techniques for evaluating arguments with special emphasis on their application both to questions of law and to issues in jurisprudence. any course 100 or above in PHIL or POLS or SOC, or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 100 or above in PHIL or POLS or SOC, or consent

title: Philosophy of Law
description: Historical and contemporary issues in law and legal theory. Law and morality; legal responsibility, justice, rights, punishment, judicial reasoning. any course 101 or above in PHIL or above 100 in BLAW or POLS or SOC, or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 101 or above in PHIL or above PHIL 100 in BLAW or POLS or SOC, or consent

title: Ethical Issues in the Law
description: Exploration of ethical issues that have come before (mainly U.S.) courts, including but not confined to, medical and criminal justice ethics. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 101 or a course numbered 200 or above in PHIL or HIST or ENG or with a DS designation; or consent.
prerequisites: PHIL 101 or a course numbered PHIL 200 or above in PHIL or HIST or ENG or with a DS designation; or consent

title: American Philosophy
description: Survey of major philosophers and schools in development of American thought up to modern times. any course 100 or above in PHIL, or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 100 or above in PHIL, or consent

title: Bodies, Minds, and Selves
description: Explores the nature of the mind. Questions addressed include: How does the mind relate to the body? What is the nature of consciousness? Are you the same person today as you were yesterday? any 100-level PHIL course or above, or consent.
prerequisites: any PHIL 100-level PHIL course or above, or consent

title: Critical Race Theory and Philosophy
description: (LED) Introduction to the work of philosophers whose writings aim to contribute to movements for racial justice. Repeatable one time. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only

title: Philosophy of Disability
description: Uses tools of philosophical inquiry to explore philosophical concepts emerging from the study of disability. Ethical issues of personhood and justice are discussed, with significant attention given to helping students express their thinking through writing. A-F only.

title: Islamic Philosophy
description: Survey of major Islamic philosophers and schools. any course 100 or above in PHIL or ARAB, or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 100 or above in PHIL or ARAB, or consent

title: Topics in Ancient Greek Thought
description: Explore a central aspect of ancient Greek philosophy and literature. This may be a theme, such as tragedy or emotions; a thinker, such as Aristotle; or a since monumental text, such as Plato’s Republic. one PHIL 200-level course, or consent. (

title: Hawaiian Philosophy: Aloha ‘Āina
description: Introduction to Indigenous Hawaiian philosophy and how to engage with Aloha ‘Āina relying upon a methodology and pedagogy consistent with the philosophy being discussed. 100 or above, HAW 100, HWST 107, or consent.
prerequisites: PHIL 100 or above, HAW 100, HWST 107, or consent

title: Indian Philosophy
description: Survey of major orthodox and heterodox systems: Vedas, Upanishads, Bhagavadgita, Vedanta, Jainism, Buddhism. any course 100 or above in PHIL or PALI or SNSK; or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 100 or above in PHIL or PALI or SNSK; or consent

title: Buddhist Philosophy
description: Survey of central thinkers and schools. (

title: Chinese Philosophy
description: Survey of important schools and thinkers in classical Chinese traditions: Confucianism, Daoism, Mohism, Legalism. A significant emphasis will be placed on developing the ability to write clearly, critically, and coherently.

title: Japanese Philosophy
description: Survey of central thinkers and schools from ancient to modern. 21 credits.

title: The Meaning of War
description: Exploration of ethical questions related to the many facets of war–e.g., patriotism, tribalism, holy war, self-sacrifice, cowardice, media coverage, propaganda, torture, genocide, pillage, suicide tactics, battlefield immunity. (

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable up to a maximum of 6 credits. consent.

title: Introduction to Phenomenology
description: Methods of analyzing the structures of experience, as developed by Husserl, Heidegger, Merleau-Ponty, Sartre, etc.

title: Marxism and Critical Theory
description: Introduction to the philosophical works of Karl Marx and a historical overview of the development of the Frankfurt School of Critical Theory. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Zen (Ch’an) Buddhist Philosophy
description: Development and philosophical significance of basic precepts, explored through translations of Chinese and Japanese sources.

title: (Alpha) Western Movements and Periods
description: (B) Greek; (C) late antiquity; (D) medieval; (E) Renaissance; (F) continental rationalism; (G) British empiricism; (H) German idealism; (I) 19th century; (J) 20th century. Repeatable two times in different alphas, not in same alpha. any course 200 or above in PHIL, or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 200 or above in PHIL, or consent

title: Philosophy in Literature
description: Philosophical themes in the literary mode in world literature.

title: Feminist Issues in Philosophy
description: Examination of basic feminist issues in philosophy, and of responses to them. any course 200 or above in PHIL or WGSS, or consent. (
prerequisites: any course PHIL 200 or above in PHIL or WGSS, or consent

title: Philosophical Psychology
description: Classical and modern theories of mind, cognition, and action.

title: Philosophy of Language
description: Contemporary theories in semantics and syntax; problems of meaning, reference, speech acts, etc. any course 200 or above in PHIL or LING, or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 200 or above in PHIL or LING, or consent

title: Gender and Environmental Philosophy
description: Interdisciplinary approach to feminist perspectives on environmental issues; critical analysis of eco-feminism as political movement with reference to race and coloniality; cross-cultural comparison of differently-imagined relationships to non-human others, with emphasis on ethics and writing. any course 200 or above in PHIL or WGSS or any course 200 or above with a DB or DP designation, or consent. (
prerequisites: any course PHIL 200 or above in PHIL or WGSS or any course PHIL 200 or above with a DB or DP designation, or consent

title: Symbolic Logic
description: Intermediate-level course covering proof techniques for classical, first-order predicate calculus, and an introduction to meta-theory. 110 or any course 200 or above in ICS or MATH; or consent.
prerequisites: PHIL 110 or any course PHIL 200 or above in ICS or MATH; or consent

title: Individual Philosophers/Topics
description: Examination of work of a major Eastern or Western philosopher, or topic of philosophical concern. Repeatable three times. 100, 101, 102, 103, 211, 212, 213, or consent.
prerequisites: PHIL 100, PHIL 101, PHIL 102, PHIL 103, PHIL 211, PHIL 212, PHIL 213, or consent

title: Undergraduate Capstone
description: Capstone seminar for undergraduate majors. Concentration on a topic of current philosophical concern. Repeatable one time with consent. declared major in PHIL with at least six courses 200 or above in PHIL, or consent.
prerequisites: declared major in PHIL with at least six courses PHIL 200 or above in PHIL, or consent

title: Understanding Place: Philosophical Inquiry and Community
description: Uses tools of philosophical inquiry, specifically p4cHI pedagogy, to develop a deep understanding of lived environment in a Hawaiian context while drawing on urban planning theories and methods to empower students as agents of change. Repeatable one time. any course 100 or above in PHIL or PLAN, or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: any course PHIL 100 or above in PHIL or PLAN, or consent

title: Philosophy with Children
description: Experience theory and practice developing intellectually safe philosophical communities of inquiry in contexts from kindergarten through university and beyond. any course 200 or above in PHIL or EDUC, or consent.
prerequisites: any course PHIL 200 or above in PHIL or EDUC, or consent

title: Teaching Philosophy
description: Supervised work in elementary, middle, and high school classrooms, facilitating philosophical inquiry with students. Repeatable one time. 492 or consent.

title: Studies in Ethics
description: Key issues in contemporary philosophical debates about ethics. Repeatable one time with consent. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 301.

title: Studies in Metaphysics
description: Key issues in ontological and cosmological theory. Problems of materialism, idealism, phenomenalism, etc. Repeatable one time with consent. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 304.

title: Studies in Philosophy of Religion
description: Key issues in theory of religious experience, language, reasoning. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 305.

title: Studies in Aesthetics
description: Key issues in contemporary aesthetics, against background of traditional Western and Eastern theories. Repeatable one time with consent. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 306.

title: Studies in Epistemology
description: Key issues in contemporary philosophical debates about knowledge. Repeatable one time with consent. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 307.

title: Philosophical Foundations of Cultural Criticism
description: A survey of the philosophical texts, thinkers, concepts, and theoretical approaches that are used in cultural criticism. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Studies in Hermeneutics
description: Important debates concerning the methodology of textual interpretation. graduate standing or consent.

title: History and Theory of Science
description: Exploration of problems at the intersection of historical studies of science as a process and philosophical analysis of basic concepts of the sciences. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 308 or 316.

title: Confucianism
description: Ethical, social, institutional problems in classical theory. Repeatable one time with consent. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 370.

title: Neo-Confucianism
description: Logic, epistemology, metaphysics, and ethics of major Chinese Neo-Confucian philosophers, 11th–16th century. Repeatable one time with consent. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 370.

title: Daoism
description: Critical examination and evaluation of major philosophical ideas in Lao Zi, Zhuang Zi, and the Neo-Daoists. Repeatable one time with consent. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 370.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable up to 30 credits. graduate standing and consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable up to six credits. master’s Plan A candidate and consent.
prerequisites: master’s Plan A candidate and consent

title: Seminar on Individual Philosophers
description: The most significant texts of an important philosopher. Repeatable three times in the MA program; an additional four times in the PhD program. graduate standing or consent.

title: Seminar in Philosophical Topics
description: Close study of a topic of important philosophical controversy. Repeatable two times in the MA program; an additional three times in the PhD program. graduate standing or consent.

title: Seminar in Islamic Philosophy
description: Major philosophical problems in Islamic thought. Focus either on a specific topic or one author. Repeatable one time. graduate standing or consent. (Once a year)

title: Seminar on Philosophical Periods
description: Close study of a period of significant and connected philosophical activity within a philosophic tradition. Repeatable two times with consent. graduate standing or consent.

title: Seminar in Philosophical Texts
description: Reading, analysis, and critical discussion of one (or of several closely related) philosophical text in its original language (sometimes in conjunction with established translation). Repeatable two times with consent. graduate standing or consent.

title: Seminar in Indian Philosophy
description: Major philosophical problems in the development of Indian thought during its formative period. Repeatable two times with consent of instructor and Graduate Chair. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 350.

title: Seminar in Buddhist Philosophy
description: Major philosophical problems in the development of Buddhist thought during its formative period. Repeatable one time with consent. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 360.

title: Seminar in Chinese Philosophy
description: Fundamental issues, problems, movements, and schools of Chinese philosophy, such as classical Confucianism, Daoism, Legalism, Chinese logic, and Neo-Confucianism. Repeatable one time with consent. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 370.

title: Seminar in Yi Jing
description: Metaphysical, epistemological, ethical, and axiological views of Yi Jing and its claim as foundational work for classical Confucianism, Daoism, and Neo-Confucianism. graduate standing or consent.

title: Seminar in Japanese Philosophy
description: Various periods, movements, and thinkers in Japanese philosophy. Topic changes each semester. Consult department for more information. Repeatable one time with consent. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: 380.

title: Seminar in Comparative Philosophy
description: Comparison of widely differing philosophical traditions. Specific topic changes each semester. Consult department for more information. Repeatable two times with consent. graduate standing or consent.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Survey of Physics
description: Mechanics, electricity and magnetism, waves, optics, atomic and nuclear physics. Only algebra and geometry used. For non-science majors.

title: Survey of Physics Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Hooke’s law, falling bodies, collisions, Boyle’s law, electric and magnetic fields, induction, waves, optics. 100 (or concurrent).

title: Physics in the Arts
description: Introduction to physics of sound and light, with applications to music and visual arts: sound perception, harmony, musical scales, instruments; lenses, cameras, color perception and mixing. Uses algebra and geometry. Intended primarily for non-science majors.

title: How Things Work: Physics for Everyday Life
description: Introduction to physics and science in everyday life. It considers objects from our daily environment, and focuses on the principles such as motion, forces, heat, electromagnetism, optics, and modern physics. A-F only.

title: College Physics I
description: Non-calculus physics. Mechanics, wave motion, heat. MATH 140X, or 215 or higher; or qualifying score on math placement exam.
prerequisites: MATH 140X, or MATH 215 or higher; or qualifying score on math placement exam

title: College Physics Lab I
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to experimental analysis, physical observation and measurement, experiments on conservation laws, fluid friction, oscillations. 151 (or concurrent).

title: College Physics II
description: Electricity, magnetism, optics, modern physics. 151 or 170.

title: College Physics Lab II
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Optics, electric and magnetic fields, DC and AC circuitry. 151L or 170L, and 152 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: PHYS 151L or PHYS 170L, and PHYS 152 (or concurrent)

title: General Physics I
description: Calculus-based mechanics of particles and rigid bodies: kinematics, force, energy, momentum, rotation, gravitation, fluids, oscillations and waves. Intended for physical science and engineering majors. MATH 242 (or concurrent) or MATH 252A (or concurrent). MATH 216 may be substituted with consent.

title: General Physics I Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Similar to 151L but at 170 level. 170 (or concurrent) or 170A (or concurrent).

title: General Physics II
description: Electricity and magnetism and geometric optics. 151 or 170 and MATH 242 or MATH 252A, MATH 216 may be substituted with consent.
prerequisites: PHYS 151 or PHYS 170 and MATH 242 or MATH 252A, MATH 216 may be substituted with consent

title: General Physics II Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Similar to 152L but at 272 level. 151L or 170L, and 272 (or concurrent) or 272A (or concurrent).
prerequisites: PHYS 151L or PHYS 170L, and PHYS 272 (or concurrent) or PHYS 272A (or concurrent)

title: General Physics III
description: Relativity, introduction to quantum mechanics, atomic and nuclear physics, and physical optics. 152 or 272 and MATH 243 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: PHYS 152 or PHYS 272 and MATH 243 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent); or consent

title: General Physics III Lab
description: (1 4-hr Lab) Experiments illustrating selected concepts of 274, including diffraction and interference of light, wave nature of matter, photoelectric effect, atomic spectra, and semiconductors. 152L or 272L, and 274 (or concurrent).
prerequisites: PHYS 152L or PHYS 272L, and PHYS 274 (or concurrent)

title: Computational Physics
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr. Lab) Analysis of physical systems and problem solving using computers and numerical methods. Development of scientific writing skills; preparation of formal reports in style of scientific journal articles. 152 or 272 or 272A, and MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: PHYS 152 or PHYS 272 or PHYS 272A, and MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent); or consent

title: Theoretical Mechanics I
description: Particle dynamics, rigid-body dynamics, planetary motion. 170 or 170A; 272 or 272A; MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent). Recommended: MATH 302 (or concurrent). (Fall only)
prerequisites: PHYS 170 or PHYS 170A; PHYS 272 or PHYS 272A; MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent)

title: Theoretical Mechanics II
description: Rigid-body mechanics continued, fluid dynamics, wave motion, theory of relativity. 310.

title: Electricity and Magnetism
description: Electrostatic and magnetostatic fields in vacuum and in matter; induction; Maxwell’s equations; AC circuits. 272 or 272A; and MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent). (Fall only)
prerequisites: PHYS 272 or PHYS 272A; and MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent)

title: Individual Work in Advanced Physics
description: Limited to students with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or a minimum GPA of 3.0 in physics.

title: Applications of Mathematics in Physical Sciences
description: Mathematical methods, techniques; applications to problems in physical sciences. MATH 244 or MATH 253A, and MATH 307 or 311; or consent. Recommended: upper division mathematics course.
prerequisites: MATH 244 or MATH 253A, and MATH 307 or MATH 311; or consent

title: Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
description: Laws of thermodynamics, heat transfer, kinetic theory, statistical mechanics. 274 and MATH 244 or MATH 253A.

title: Solid-State Physics I
description: Crystal structure: lattice vibrations; phonon effects; electronic processes in solids (metals, semiconductors, and superconductors). 274 and 350 (or concurrent).

title: Solid-State Physics II
description: Energy-band calculations, optical processes, Josephson effect, theories of dielectrics and magnetism, physics of color centers, order-disorder transformation. 440.

title: Electromagnetic Waves
description: Field equations, plane, spherical and guided waves. 350.

title: Physical Optics
description: Fundamentals of classical physical optics emphasizing linear systems theory, including optical fields in matter, polarization phenomena, temporal coherence, interference and diffraction (Fourier optics). Specialized applications include Gaussian beams, laser resonators, pulse propagation, and nonlinear optics. 450 (or concurrent with a minimum grade of C) or ECE 372 (or concurrent with a minimum grade of C-), or consent. (
prerequisites: PHYS 450 (or concurrent with a minimum grade of C) or ECE 372 (or concurrent with a minimum grade of C-), or consent

title: General Relativity & Cosmology
description: Introduction to general relativity & cosmology. Spacetime metrics, geodesics, Einstein field equations, black holes. Geometry of the universe, redshift, cosmological distances. Cosmological models, dark matters, dark energy. Big Bang nucleosynthesis, recombination, cosmic microwave background, inflation. 274; MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent). Recommended: ASTR 242. (Alt. years: fall) (
prerequisites: PHYS 274; MATH 244 (or concurrent) or MATH 253A (or concurrent)

title: Electronics for Physicists
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Investigation of Kirchoff’s Laws, electromagnetic circuit theory. Fourier analysis and stability theory with circuits. Applications to physical measurements are stressed. A-F only. junior standing, and 152L or 272L.
prerequisites: junior standing, and PHYS 152L or PHYS 272L

title: Modern Electronics for Physicists
description: Introduction to high performance solid state instrumentation by means of practical research electronics: printed circuit board design/fabrication; complex programmable logic design/verification; integrated circuit SPICE simulation. Detector fabrication and test emphasis during final project. 475 (or equivalent) or consent. (Spring only)

title: Quantum Mechanics I
description: Wave mechanics, Schroedinger equation, angular momenta, potential problems. 274, 310, 350, 400 (or concurrent); either MATH 244 or 253A; and either MATH 311 or 307; or consent.
prerequisites: PHYS 274, PHYS 310, PHYS 350, PHYS 400 (or concurrent); either MATH 244 or MATH 253A; and either MATH 311 or MATH 307; or consent

title: Advanced Physics Laboratory I
description: Advanced experiments involving nuclear spectroscopy, angular correlations in positronium annihilation, optical polarization, chaos, measurement of speed of light, numerical simulations. Development of professional writing skills; preparation of formal reports in style of scientific journal articles. 274L and 480 (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: PHYS 274L and PHYS 480 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Quantum Mechanics II
description: Continuation of 480; atomic physics, scattering, perturbation theory. 480.

title: Advanced Physics Laboratory II
description: Advanced experiments involving measurement of the muon lifetime, crystal x-ray diffraction, nuclear magnetic resonance, the Mössbauer effect, and numerical simulations. Development of professional writing skills; preparation of formal reports in style of scientific journal articles. 274L, 480, and 480L; or consent.
prerequisites: PHYS 274L, PHYS 480, and PHYS 480L; or consent

title: Professional Ethics for Physicists
description: Student seminar on ethical principles and their application to research in physics and astronomy and closely-related fields. Historical examples will be presented and discussed by the participants. PHYS, ASTP, and ASTR majors only. A-F only. 310 or ASTR 300 (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: PHYS 310 or ASTR 300 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Modern Physics
description: Introduction to nuclear and elementary-particle physics. 480 (or concurrent).

title: Physics Workshop for Teachers
description: Major concepts of physics taught by means of hands-on conceptual activities for elementary and secondary teachers. Restricted to in-service teachers, or consent. Repeatable one time. (

title: Methods of Theoretical Physics
description: Mathematical tools of theoretical physics. Continuation of 400 but with an independent selection of topics. 400 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Analytical Mechanics
description: Dynamics of particles, particle systems; rigid bodies; Lagrangian and Hamiltonian equations; special relativity. 600 (or concurrent); or MATH 402.

title: Electrodynamics I
description: Potential theory, Maxwell’s equations, electromagnetic waves, boundary value problems. 450; and 600 (or concurrent), or MATH 402. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: PHYS 450; and PHYS 600 (or concurrent), or MATH 402

title: Electrodynamics II
description: Relativistic electrodynamics, radiation by charged particles. 650. (Alt. years)

title: Advanced Optics
description: Contemporary advanced applications in optics including nonlinear optics and optical parametric oscillators, atomic lasers and laser systems, and free-electron lasers. 460. (Alt. even years)

title: Quantum Mechanics
description: Physical basis and formulation of quantum theory. Exact solutions of Schroedinger equation and their applications. Approximation methods. Applications to atomic, nuclear, and molecular physics. 400 or 481 or 600 and MATH 402.
prerequisites: PHYS 400 or PHYS 481 or PHYS 600 and MATH 402

title: Quantum Mechanics
description: Physical basis and formulation of quantum theory. Exact solutions of Schroedinger equation and their applications. Approximation methods. Applications to atomic, nuclear, and molecular physics. 670.

title: Seminar
description: Discussions and reports on physical theory and recent developments. CR/NC only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Condensed Matter Seminar
description: Results and discussions of current topics in condensed matter physics. Repeatable six times with consent.

title: Seminar on Atomic and Solid-State Physics
description: Reports and discussion on recent developments in atomic, surface, and solid-state physics. Repeatable five times with consent.

title: Seminar on Elementary Particle Physics
description: Reports and discussion on recent developments in elementary particle physics. Repeatable four times. consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Topics in Particles and Fields
description: Topics in current theoretical research; e.g., unified field theories, general relativity, gravitation, and cosmology. Repeatable four times. consent.

title: Special Topics: Experimental Physics
description: Topics in current experimental research in low-energy physics, high-energy physics, cross-disciplinary physics. Repeatable in different topics. consent.

title: Advanced Topics in Condensed Matter Theory
description: Topics in condensed matter theory, e.g., group theory, many-body techniques, renormalization group, density functional theory, other topics of current interest. Repeatable four times. 670 and consent.

title: Statistical Physics I
description: Equilibrium thermodynamics; Gibbs ensembles; quantum statistics; ideal and non-ideal Fermi; Bose and Boltzmann gases; phase transitions; and critical phenomena. 670. (Alt. years)

title: Statistical Physics II
description: Nonequilibrium thermodynamics, transport theory, fluctuation dissipation theorem, many-body Green’s function methods, normal Fermi and Bose liquids, superfluidity, superconductivity. 670 and 730. (Alt. years)

title: Modern General Relativity
description: Differential geometry, special relativity, Einstein equations, gravitational phenomena, equivalence principles, black holes, gravitational waves, cosmology, relativistic stars, experimental tests, computational techniques. Graduate students only in PHYS or ASTR.
crossListings: Alt. years: fall Crosslisted as ASTR 760

title: Quantum Field Theory I
description: Relativistic wave equations and their solutions. Dirac’s theory of the electron, propagator techniques. Applications to quantum electrodynamics. 671. (Alt. years)

title: Quantum Field Theory II
description: Local gauge invariance, Yang-Mills theory: quantum chromodynamics, spontaneous symmetry breaking and Goldstone bosons; the standard electroweak theory; grand unified theories. 772. (Alt. years)

title: Nuclear and Particle Physics
description: Nuclear physics; electrodynamics; hadron structure and partons. Techniques of particle physics. 481 and 671. (Alt. years)

title: Nuclear and Particle Physics II
description: Quantum chromodynamics; electroweak interactions; the standard model. Techniques of particle physics. 777 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Solid-State Theory
description: Crystal symmetry, electronic excitations in solids, transport theory, optical properties, cohesive energy, lattice vibrations, electron-phonon interaction, electron-electron interaction, magnetism, superconductivity. 670. (Alt. years)

title: Solid-State Theory
description: Crystal symmetry, electronic excitations in solids, transport theory, optical properties, cohesive energy, lattice vibrations, electron-phonon interaction, magnetism, superconductivity. 785. (Alt. years)

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Introduction to Environmental Science
description: Analysis of our environment with emphasis on understanding relationships and interactions of physical, biological, technological, and political components using scientific methods of inquiry. Food supply and safety, water quality, pollution control, biodiversity, environmental policy. Open to nonmajors. (

title: The World of Insects
description: Biology/ecology of insects with emphasis on relationships to plants, animals, and especially people in Hawai‘i and the tropics. Open to nonmajors. A-F only.

title: Environment and Agriculture
description: Overview of environmental issues related to agriculture, specifically pest management issues, and options for environmentally responsible management and amelioration of these impacts. Ethical issues on impact of agriculture on the environment will be discussed. (

title: Ecology of Infectious Diseases and Symbioses
description: Introduction to the ecology of infectious diseases of animals, plants, and humans. Factors affecting disease transmission and virulence. Effects of human activities and environmental change on disease transmission. Emphasis on issues pertinent to Hawai‘i. A-F only. (BIOL 171 and BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: (BIOL 171 and BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: Invasive Pest Species
description: Ecological, economic and sociological impacts of invasive species on tropical ecosystems; characteristics of invasive species and vulnerability of habitats; ethical issues on impacts of management options on evolution, biodiversity and eco-stability and human life. Open to nonmajors. (Alt. years: spring)

title: General Entomology
description: Biology, diversity, and ecology of insects with emphasis on Hawaiian fauna. Classification to order level. A-F only. (BOT 101 or ZOOL 101 or BIOL 171) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. DB
prerequisites: (BOT 101 or ZOOL 101 or BIOL 171) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: General Entomology Laboratory
description: Laboratory in the biology and classification to family level of Hawai‘i’s insects and arthropods. A-F only. (363 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. DY
prerequisites: (PEPS 363 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C, or consent

title: Genetics: Theory to Application
description: Fundamentals of genetic theory using traditional breeding and biotechnological procedures in insect and plant pathogen management for sustainable agricultural production. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (

title: Plant Pathogens and Diseases
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Classification, morphology, ecology, and biology of bacteria, fungi, nematodes, and viruses that attack economic crops. Etiology and control of plant diseases. 210/SUST 210 or BOT 101 or MICR 130, or consent. (Fall only)
prerequisites: PEPS 210/SUST 210 or BOT 101 or MICR 130, or consent

title: Sustainable Soil and Plant Health Management
description: Provides knowledge and understanding of soils, agroecology, and sustainable approaches for plant health management, and prepares students for applied research in various tropical cropping systems. A-F only. (Alt. years: spring) (

title: Turfgrass Pest Management
description: Provides students with knowledge and real world experience on common turfgrass pests and management strategies in Hawai‘i, with emphasis on integrated pest management. Common cool-season turfgrass and pest management are also discussed. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Foundations of Pest Management
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles and concepts of insect pest management using biological, ecological, cultural, behavioral, legislative, microbial and chemical methods. A-F only. one of the following: 250 or 363, BIOL 171, BIOL 172, or BOT 101; or consent. (Spring only)
prerequisites: one of the following: PEPS 250 or PEPS 363, BIOL 171, BIOL 172, or BOT 101; or consent

title: Biocontrol of Invasive Species
description: Biological control of invasive insects and weeds using natural enemies; biological control as a cornerstone of sustainable pest management; contributions of biocontrol to economic, environmental, and societal sustainability; reduced dependence on pesticides; increased sustainability of pest management. 363 or consent. (

title: Plant Disease Management
description: Diagnosis, epidemiology, and integrated management of important plant diseases and pathogens for key plants and cultivated crops in various agroecosystems in Hawai‘i, the Pacific, and the global tropics. 405. (Spring only)

title: Environmental Law
description: Exploration of federal laws, regulations, and precedents that govern our interaction with the environment. Analysis of laws regulating air, water, toxins, pests, endangered species, and environmental justice. junior or senior standing.

title: Medical and Urban Entomology
description: (2 Lec, 1-3-hr hybrid Lab) Biology, ecology, health and economic impacts, and control of urban insect pests and medically important arthropods that act as vectors of diseases. (363 or BIOL 265) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (
prerequisites: (PEPS 363 or BIOL 265) with a minimum grade of C, or consent

title: Weed Science
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Weed classification, identification, adaptations for weediness; principles of weed control; properties, uses, and action of herbicides. Lab: pesticide application equipment and techniques, no-till farming, greenhouse and field experiments. A-F only. (CHEM 152 and TPSS 200/ SUST 211) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: (CHEM 152 and TPSS 200/ SUST 211) with a minimum grade of C, or consent

title: Insect-Plant Interactions
description: Study of the coevolutionary relationships between insects and plants, with emphasis on the behavior, physiology, and symbiotic relationships of insects. Discussed in the context of sustainable agriculture, anthropogenic change, and climate change. A-C only. 363 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent. DB
prerequisites: PEPS 363 (with a minimum grade of C) or consent

title: Topics in Plant & Environmental Protection
description: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems. May be offered by visiting faculty, extension faculty or research faculty. Repeatable two times.

title: PEPS Capstone
description: Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills emphasizing professional development, Directed Research, field studies, employment with cooperating businesses, government or schools are all options. A-F only. consent.

title: Directed Research
description: Conduct original research in environmental protection sciences. Limited to qualified undergraduate students. Repeatable two times. CR/NC only.

title: Agrosecurity and Food Safety
description: Concepts of agrosecurity and food safety (including plant and animal biosecurity), global impacts of introduced pests and diseases, and current mechanisms for interception of pests and mitigation of disease. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Biology of Plant Pathogens: Fungi and Nematodes
description: (2 Lec, 2 3-hr. Lab) Principles and concepts in pathogen biology, epidemiology and management of plant diseases caused by fungi, oomycetes, and nematodes. Laboratory techniques for isolation and identification of pathogens and disease diagnosis. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Biology of Plant Pathogens: Bacteria and Viruses
description: (2 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Principles and concepts in pathogen biology, epidemiology, and management of plant diseases caused by bacteria and viruses. Laboratory techniques for isolation and identification of pathogens and disease diagnosis. A-F only. 605 (with a minimum grade of B). (Spring only)
prerequisites: PEPS 605 (with a minimum grade of B)

title: Professional Development
description: Lecture/discussion targets students exiting from graduate degree programs and provides preparation as a career professional; topics include establishing a professional identity; CV and cover letters, job-seeking due diligence, and negotiation skills. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Diagnosis and Management of Tropical Plant Diseases
description: Iterative and interactive course integrating plant pathogen and pest biology with diagnostic and management approaches. Will use biological information about pathogens, anthropods, and abiotic stresses to diagnose diseases, disorders, or other injuries of plants. A-F only. (605 and 606) with a minimum grade of B, or consent. Co-requisite: 615L. (Summer only)
prerequisites: (PEPS 605 and PEPS 606) with a minimum grade of B, or consent

title: Diagnosis and Management of Tropical Plant Diseases Laboratory
description: Diagnosis and management of plant pathogen and pest problems in laboratory and field. Taught concurrently with 615. A-F only. (605 and 606) with a minimum grade of B, or equivalent. Co-requisite: 615. (Summer only)
prerequisites: (PEPS 605 and PEPS 606) with a minimum grade of B, or equivalent

title: Molecular Diagnostics: Principles and Practices
description: Molecular diagnostics principles, comparative genomics, genome annotation and bio-informatics, phylogenetics, gene target selection, advanced primer, and probe design. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only or consent. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Insect Physiology
description: (2 Lec) Study of the principal physiological and biochemical functions in insects, with emphasis on hormonal interactions. 402 or consent.

title: Molecular Plant–Fungal Interactions
description: Focuses on the actions of plant pathogenic fungi/ oomycetes and their host responses at the molecular and cellular level. Current genetic and genomic approaches to study plant-fungal interactions will be discussed. Graduate standing only. consent. (Every 2 years) (

title: Seminar in Plant Pathology
description: Seminar on research and topics in plant pathology. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Systematics and Phylogenetics
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Classification and study of diversity among insects and other life forms. Use of morphological and molecular characters to reconstruct evolutionary histories. A-F only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Insect Ecology
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Insects as living units in an environment of physical and biotic factors. consent of instructor.

title: Biological Control of Pests
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Fundamental concepts. Critical study of major biological control projects. 421 or consent. Recommended: 662; and ZOOL 631 or 632.

title: Biological Control of Weeds
description: Examine approaches to weed biological control of invasive plants in various environments with different agents (insects, pathogens, and vertebrates), integration with other management tactics, sociopolitical aspects, and history of the practice. Graduate students only. 421 or 422 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Invertebrate Microbiology
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) In-depth study of the molecular and cellular interactions between microbes and animals. Topics will cover types of symbioses, gut microbiome, parasites, and agricultural pathogens, and disease and human health disease.

title: Seminar in Entomology
description: Seminars on research and topics in entomology. Repeatable unlimited times. graduate standing or consent.

title: Special Topics
description: Study and discussion of significant topics and problems in plant and environmental protection sciences at an advanced level. Offered by visiting or existing faculty as a special course. Repeatable unlimited times. graduate standing or consent.

title: Plan B Master’s Project
description: Independent study for students working on a Plan B master’s project. A grade of Satisfactory (S) is assigned when the project is satisfactorily completed. A-F only. graduate standing in entomology or tropical plant pathology.
prerequisites: graduate standing in entomology or tropical plant pathology

title: Directed Research
description: Directed research, critical reviews in environmental protection sciences, entomology, or plant pathology. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.

title: Advanced Plant Nematology
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Advanced study of nematode taxonomy, genetics, behavior, host interactions, and sustainable management in an integrated lecture-laboratory. 605 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
prerequisites: PEPS 605 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Advanced Plant Virology
description: Characterization, genome organization, gene expression, and molecular mechanisms of plant viruses. 606 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
prerequisites: PEPS 606 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Advanced Plant-Bacteria Interactions
description: Molecular biology, genomics, molecular genetics, and infection mechanisms of bacterial plant pathogens and symbionts. 606 (with a minimum grade of B or better) or consent. (
prerequisites: PEPS 606 (with a minimum grade of B or better) or consent

title: Proposal/Defense Seminar
description: Thesis/ dissertation proposal and defense seminars. Repeatable one time. CR/NC only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/ NC only.

title: Introduction to Political Science
description: Discussion of politics as an activity and of political problems, systems, ideologies, processes.

title: Introduction to World Politics
description: Power and contemporary world politics since 1945 with emphasis on the U.S. role.
