title: Introduction to American Politics
description: American political processes and institutions, as seen through alternative interpretations. Emphasis on opportunities and limitations for practical political participation.

title: Introduction to Indigenous Politics
description: Foundations in Indigenous politics from diverse cultural perspectives and across regions. Addresses political issues facing Indigenous peoples at global and local levels, with attention to Indigenous epistemologies, languages, movements, and institutions. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Global Politics
description: Foundations in global politics from political, historical, and multicultural perspectives. A-F only.

title: Introduction to International and Global Studies
description: Introduces undergraduate students to the major political, social, economic, cultural, technological, and historical dimensions of globalization. Special attention will be paid to globalization process that have impacted Hawai‘i and the Asia-Pacific region. A-F only. (

title: Politics and Public Policy
description: Perspectives on the role of government in guiding economies and civil societies with particular emphasis on the recent U.S.

title: Introduction to Political Futures
description: Introduction to political future studies. Using science fact and fiction, shows how past and present images of the future influence people’s actions.

title: Introduction to Hawai‘i Politics
description: Introduction to political history, institutions, processes, and issues in Hawai‘i grounded in Native Hawaiian perspectives.

title: Media and Politics
description: Influences and effects of media on politics. Setting public agendas, interpreting events, manipulating the political process, political learning through popular culture.

title: Reading and Writing Politics
description: Develop skills needed to read and write political texts. Weigh competing views; read and analyze texts for what they do and do not say; craft and defend evidence-based arguments; practice writing mechanics and style. POLS majors only or consent. A-F only.

title: Problems of War and Peace
description: Introduction to the problems individuals and political communities currently face with respect to war, peace, and international conflict. Includes questions of human nature, economy, morality, nuclear deterrence, arms control and disarmament, and alternatives to war.

title: Political Design and Futuristics
description: Possible social and political alternatives for the future. Conditions likely if present trends continue, formulation of visions of better futures, means for their achievement.

title: Race and Politics
description: Racial inequality in the U.S.; mechanisms of institutional racism in employment, education, criminal justice, electoral politics.

title: Hawai‘i Politics
description: Introduction to and critical study of institutions, governments, and political processes in Hawai‘i. Attends to race, class, gender, sexuality, indigeneity and nationality. Grounded in Native Hawaiian perspectives, with an emphasis on comparative study and dialogue. any 100- or 200-level POLS course, or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100- or POLS 200-level POLS course, or consent

title: Native Hawaiian Politics
description: Critical study of issues in contemporary Native Hawaiian politics, with an emphasis on application and active engagement. any 100- or 200-level POLS course or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100- or POLS 200-level POLS course or consent

title: (Alpha) Topics in Hawai‘i Politics
description: Intensive examination of particular institutions, processes, and issues. (B) the military in Hawai‘i; (C) political thought in Hawaiian; Taught in Hawaiian; (D) politics of food. A-F only for (D). Sophomore standing or higher or consent. HAW 302 (or concurrent) for (C) only. ((C)

title: Indigenous Politics
description: Conceptualizing politics from the perspective of indigenous epistemologies, philosophies, language, and social and political movement. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Global Politics/Comparative
description: Introduction to global politics with emphasis on concepts and theories developed from a comparative politics perspective. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Comparative Politics of Developing Countries
description: Political, economic, and social development in the Third World. Repeatable one time. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: (Alpha) Topics in Comparative Politics: Country/Regional
description: Political, social, and economic processes in specific countries/regions. (B) Southeast Asia; (C) Pacific Islands; (F) Middle East; (G) Philippines; (H) Japan; (I) Europe; (J) India; (K) East Asia. Repeatable one time. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Chinese Political Economy
description: Interdisciplinary review and analysis of the social and political issues in contemporary China, the interchange between state and society in national policies, the relationship between cultural tradition and technological modernization in the social transformation process. A-F only. Sophomore standing or higher. consent. (.

title: Politics of Indigenous Language Revitalization
description: Study of the importance and processes of language revitalization for indigenous peoples in Hawai‘i, the Pacific, Asia, and North America. any 100 level POLS course. (Alt. years)

title: Global Politics/International Relations
description: Introduction to global politics with emphasis on concepts and theories developed from an international relations perspective. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: International Relations
description: Decision-making behavior of international actors; strategies of peacemaking. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: International Law
description: Nature and function of international law in international politics. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Current Issues in International Law, Organization, and Culture
description: Principles, norms, cases, and their interaction with culture and organization in international politics. any 100 level POLS course or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100 level POLS course or consent

title: International Organization
description: International relations of governmental and nongovernmental organizations. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: International Migration
description: Political-cultural economy of international migration: post-colonial populations, refugees, and immigrants. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: American Foreign Policy
description: Purposes, methods, strengths, obstacles, prospects; factors affecting American foreign policy; impact abroad and at home. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Model United Nations
description: Simulation of United Nations organizations, especially General Assembly. Repeatable 4 times. 315 (or concurrent) or 319 (or concurrent), or instructor consent.
prerequisites: POLS 315 (or concurrent) or POLS 319 (or concurrent), or instructor consent

title: Global Environmental Politics
description: Evolution of international politics, law and decision-making on a variety of environmental concerns; from endangered species to pollution to climate change. Interaction of population, development, and environment in global governance. (

title: Religion and Law in the U.S.
description: Surveys church-state jurisprudence since the 1940s, with special attention to difficulty of defining religion, and applies the religion clauses to current issues. A-F only. Sophomore standing or higher. consent. (Once a year) (

title: Advanced Topics in Global Politics
description: Studies of political development in the context of increasingly integrated and globalized political economies. Repeatable one time. any 100 level POLS course or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100 level POLS course or consent

title: History of Political Thought
description: Theories, approaches, concepts, and issues developed or raised in history of political philosophy and thought. any 100- or 200-level POLS course, or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100- or POLS 200-level POLS course, or consent

title: American Political Theory
description: Origins and development of American political thought. any 100 level POLS course or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100 level POLS course or consent

title: (Alpha) Topics in Political Theory
description: Significant works, historical continuities, themes, and issues in political theory. (B) classical political philosophy; (F) revolution and utopia; (G) contemporary political theory; (I) Marxist philosophy. any 100- or 200- level POLS course; or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100- or POLS 200- level POLS course; or consent

title: Feminist Theory
description: Contemporary debates in feminist theory concerning gender, race, and class; subjectivity and representation; gender and colonialism; bodies, sexualities and “nature.” any 300 level POLS or WGSS course; or consent. (
prerequisites: any POLS 300 level POLS or WGSS course; or consent

title: Korean Politics and Society Through Film
description: Examines modern Korean politics and society through films. Through movies and documentaries, students will learn major sociopolitical issues including military dictatorship, democratization, and globalization that Korea underwent for the last several decades. Repeatable one time. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: The Politics of Media
description: Study of the political manipulation of aural and verbal images. Exercises to increase media literacy. any 100 level POLS course, or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100 level POLS course, or consent

title: Political Design and Futuristics
description: Alternative future social and political possibilities; design of means of realization of desirable futures. any 100 level POLS course, or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100 level POLS course, or consent

title: The Politics of Film
description: Political, philosophical, and artistic dimensions of film; cross-cultural film genres; representational practices in films. any 100 level POLS course, or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100 level POLS course, or consent

title: Nâ Politika ma ka Nûhou Hawai‘i – Politics in Hawaiian Language Media
description: Study of Hawaiian news media with emphasis on political content. Taught in Hawaiian. HAW 302 (or concurrent) and one of 110, 120, 130, 170, or 171; or consent. (
prerequisites: HAW 302 (or concurrent) and one of HAW 110, HAW 120, HAW 130, HAW 170, or HAW 171; or consent

title: Advanced Topics in Theory, Media, and Method
description: Studies in political theory, media, and methods that analyze their interrelations in a globalized world. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Disability Law and Politics
description: Introduction to the history and politics of U.S. disability law and activism. An analysis of disability politics as the result of the interaction between disability movement activism and the development of policy and law. A-F only. Sophomore standing or higher. consent. (Fall only)

title: Gender, Justice and Law
description: Exploration of landmark U.S. Supreme Court cases related to sex and gender. Topics may include sex discrimination, sexual orientation discrimination, privacy, and reproductive freedom. A-F only. one of WGSS 151, WGSS 175, WGSS 176, WGSS 202, WGSS 360, WGSS 381, or consent. (
prerequisites: one of WGSS 151, WGSS 175, WGSS 176, WGSS 202, WGSS 360, WGSS 381, or consent

title: Women and Globalization in Asia
description: History, culture, and contemporary reality of Asian women in Asia and the U.S. Includes critical analysis of American feminist methodology and theory. one of 339, AMST 310, AMST 316, AMST 318, AMST 373, AMST 455, WGSS 360, WGSS 361, WGSS 439; or consent. (
prerequisites: one of POLS 339, AMST 310, AMST 316, AMST 318, AMST 373, AMST 455, WGSS 360, WGSS 361, WGSS 439; or consent

title: American Politics (Elections)
description: Examination of voters and voting processes (participation, apathy, socialization, symbolic process, media, etc.); ideologies and belief systems. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Law, Politics and Society
description: Relationships between law, politics, and society will be explored. Emphasis is placed on several dimensions of legality: legal “indeterminacy” and some of the many things that law does for us and to us; law’s response to violence; the connections between law and social change; access to the law and its sociological dimensions; how/why law fails and what happens when it does. A-F only. a 100 level or 200 level POLS course or SOC 100 or any 200 level SOC course, or consent. (
prerequisites: a POLS 100 level or POLS 200 level POLS course or SOC 100 or any SOC 200 level SOC course, or consent

title: Constitutional Law I: Institutional Power
description: Provides students with methods for interpreting U.S. Supreme Court decisions and analyzes the U.S. Supreme Court’s jurisprudence on institutional authority, including the Judiciary, Executive, and Legislative branches and their relationships to power. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Constitutional Law II: Rights and Liberties
description: Analyzes the U.S. Supreme Court’s jurisprudence on civil rights and liberties. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Topics in Law and Politics
description: Current issues; recent research findings; practical research undertaken by student. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Topics in American Politics
description: Specific institutions and processes of the American governmental system. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Power in America
description: Analysis of sources of political, economic, and social power in the U.S. and the institutions through which it is exercised. PSophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Environmental Law and Politics
description: Focuses on theories, laws, policies, ethics, and sustainable futures of Hawai‘i and the U.S. Sophomore standing or higher. any 100 or 200 level POLS course, or consent. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: any POLS 100 or POLS 200 level POLS course, or consent

title: Administration and Society
description: Historical emergence of modern bureaucracy; mutual impact of administrative forms on social life; relation of bureaucracy to capitalism and patriarchy; constitution of the administered individual. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Political Leadership
description: Exploration of concepts and theories of political leadership, partly through biography, as preparation for public service or advanced scholarly inquiry. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Politics and Public Policy II
description: Overview of the policy-making process in various political arenas (families, cities, nations, etc.); emphasis on conceptual and empirical analysis. any 100 level POLS course or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100 level POLS course or consent

title: Women and Politics
description: Women’s role in political institutions and processes in the U.S. and other countries. Female and male approaches to power; feminist political goals and actions. any 100 level POLS course (or concurrent), WGSS 151 (or concurrent), or WGSS 362 (or concurrent); or consent. (
prerequisites: any POLS 100 level POLS course (or concurrent), WGSS 151 (or concurrent), or WGSS 362 (or concurrent); or consent

title: American Politics
description: Institutions (parties, interest groups, legislatures, executives, local government); policies (national defense, poverty, energy, etc.), politics (symbolism, inequality, race, and gender).

title: Public Policy-Making
description: Students develop understanding of theory, practice, and ethical issues of public policy-making. Combines lecture/discussion and fieldtrips. Students develop policy analysis and strategic plans that identify issues, interests, and methods of influence. Repeatable one time. A-F only. HON 101 or HON 291(Alpha), or departmental approval. (
prerequisites: HON 101 or HON 291(Alpha), or departmental approval

title: Politics of the Ocean
description: Study of the ocean as a political place. Engagement with theories, policies, and lived-experiences of the ocean through a political lens, including literature and experiential learning. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. any 100 or 200-level POLS course, or consent. (
prerequisites: any POLS 100 or POLS 200-level POLS course, or consent

title: Health Politics
description: Examines the politics of health care. Focus on institutional models to health care, the politics of health care reform, and contemporary health care issues and controversies. Repeatable one time. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. any 100-level POLS course or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100-level POLS course or consent

title: Political Inquiry and Analysis
description: Introductory survey and analysis of methods used in empirical research, policy analysis, and social criticism.

title: Advanced Topics in Law, Policy, and Society
description: Studies integrating concerns of public law, public policy, public administration, and social movements. any 100- or 200-level POLS course, or consent.
prerequisites: any POLS 100- or POLS 200-level POLS course, or consent

title: Co-ops, Communes, Collectives
description: Theory and practice of democratic organizations: women’s and feminist organizations; co-ops, communes, and collectives; indigenous people’s organizations; workplace democracy and social change. A-F only. any 100- or 200-level POLS course or 390 (or concurrent) or WGSS 151, or consent. (
prerequisites: any POLS 100- or POLS 200-level POLS course or POLS 390 (or concurrent) or WGSS 151, or consent

title: Nonviolent Political Alternatives
description: Exploration of scientific and cultural resources for nonviolent alternatives in politics. any 100- or 200-level POLS course, or consent. (
prerequisites: any POLS 100- or POLS 200-level POLS course, or consent

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: consent.

title: Teaching Political Science
description: Practicum for majors who serve as undergraduate teaching assistants. Repeatable one time. 390 (or concurrent), senior standing; and consent.
prerequisites: POLS 390 (or concurrent), senior standing; and consent

title: Legislative Internship
description: Field placement at the Hawai‘i Legislature integrated with academic study of political institutions and practices. A-F only. consent. Recommended: 390. (Spring only)

title: Community Internship
description: Field placement integrated with academic study of political institutions and community organizations. Repeatable one time. consent. Recommended: 390.

title: Senior Thesis
description: Independent research and thesis writing with supervision of senior advisor. 390 (or concurrent) and consent.

title: Executive Internship
description: Open to students awarded a Mānoa Undergraduate Political Fellowship for placement in the Governor’s or Lt. Governor’s Office, Prosecuting Attorney’s Office, or Public Defender’s Office. Field placement, integrated with academic study. A-F only. Recommended: 385, 390.

title: Senior Seminar in Political Science
description: Exploration of themes in political science with emphasis on discussion, research, and substantial writing. 390 (or concurrent) or senior standing or consent.
prerequisites: POLS 390 (or concurrent) or senior standing or consent

title: Mānoa Undergraduate Congressional Fellowship Internship Seminar
description: Hawai‘i Undergraduate Political Internship’s Congressional Fellowship. Award includes stipend and internship experience in a Hawai‘i congressional office. Students review policy processes, House and Senate procedures and produce a final paper. Restricted to fellowship awardees only. Junior and senior standing only. A-F only. Co-requisite: 386.

title: Scope and Methods of Political Science
description: Main concepts delineating boundaries of discipline; approaches to knowledge employed by political scientists; empirical and normative theory; problems in theory-building; validity and reliability in research design; philosophy of science applied to political science.

title: Political Analysis and Theory Building
description: Survey of theory-building, approaches and validation techniques.

title: Research Techniques and Analytic Methods
description: Quantitative models and statistical inference techniques.

title: Topics in Methodology
description: Specific methodological techniques and practices introduced in 601 and 602. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Political Theory and Analysis
description: Major contemporary approaches and styles in political theory, philosophy, and analysis.

title: Tradition of Political Philosophy
description: Discussion of texts and themes in the Western political tradition from Plato to Nietzsche. Repeatable one time.

title: Hawaiian Political Thought: Theory and Method/Nā Mana‘o Politika Hawai‘i
description: Study of Hawaiian political thought in writing from ca. 1825 to the present, with emphasis on theory and research methods. 303, HAW 402 and HAW 428; or consent. (
prerequisites: POLS 303, HAW 402 and HAW 428; or consent

title: (Alpha) Topics in Political Thought
description: Specific traditions and individuals, or particular issues and problems. (C) feminist theory. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. consent. ((C)

title: Introduction to Indigenous Politics
description: Historical treatment of the contact between state and indigenous peoples and a survey of contemporary indigenous political initiatives: social movements, media, indigenous studies programs, and events.

title: Politics of Indigenous Representation
description: Politics of indigenous representations in media, literature, and academic scholarship.

title: International Relations
description: Analysis of theories: actors, decisions, systems, conflict, integration, alternative approaches to validation. Graduate students only. consent.

title: International Conflict Resolution
description: Analysis of international conflict and conflict resolution. Theory and practice of negotiation, mediation, conciliation, facilitation, and other “third-party” methods of peaceful settlement. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Teaching Model United Nations
description: Substantive and pedagogical approaches to using Model United Nations simulation for teaching and conflict resolution. Repeatable two times. Graduate students only. (Fall only)

title: (Alpha) Topics in International Relations
description: (B) international relations and war; (E) international organization; (F) modeling international systems. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Comparative Politics
description: Emphasis on Asia, theories of development, and comparative methods. At least one section a semester.

title: Indigenous Peoples and Western Imperialism
description: Historical examination of U.S. and European imperialisms, including national narratives, politics, and impacts upon indigenous peoples in the Americas, Pacific, and Asia. Repeatable one time.

title: (Alpha) Politics and Development: Regional
description: Politics of particular regions; particular development processes. (C) China. ((C)

title: (Alpha) Politics and Development: Topical
description: (F) political ecology and development.

title: American Political Institutions in Comparative Perspective
description: Consideration of American political institutions and development relative to American philosophical foundations and non-American political forms. Federalism as an expansive devise will be emphasized, as will American influence and penetration abroad. A-F only. graduate standing or consent. (Once a year)

title: Public Administrative Theory
description: Focus varies among theoretical, comparative and developmental approaches to study of administration. One section each semester.

title: Political Leadership
description: Exploration of political leadership as a focus for research, teaching, and applied political science.

title: Comparative Public Administration
description: Detailed examination of implementation of governmental policy in different countries. Graduate students only.

title: Law and Politics
description: Law, courts, and rights as a political resource; analyses of public law (including court decisions), other forms of dispute management, and judicial behavior and policy-making. 110.

title: Topics in Public Law and Judicial System
description: Recent issues and practices in public law; particular judicial systems. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Introduction to Public Policy
description: Perspectives on policy analysis; basic approaches to the study of public policy, political economy, and policy evaluation. (

title: Politics of the Future
description: Introduction to political futures studies; images of future, theories of social change, methods of social forecasting and designing preferred futures. Graduate students only. consent.

title: The Future of Political Systems
description: Normative and descriptive forecasts of political institutions, systems, subsystems, and behaviors. Design of preferred systems.

title: Topics in Public Policy
description: Particular political processes, specific political institutions, or particular policy area. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Nonviolent Political Alternatives
description: Exploration of nonviolent, non-killing alternatives in political science research, teaching, and public service.

title: Asian and/or Pacific Politics
description: Political development, international relations, decision-making processes, and systems of political thought in all or part of Asia and/or the Pacific. Repeatable three times.

title: Contemporary Native Hawaiian Politics
description: Study of political and social movements, political status, national and cultural identities, and issues of representation of Native Hawaiians.

title: (Alpha) Topics in Asian and/or Pacific Politics
description: (C) Korean politics. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Politics of Hawai‘i
description: Examinations from several perspectives of the political, economic, and cultural forces that historically formed Hawai‘i and contemporary political themes, issues, and processes. Graduate students only.

title: Teaching Initiative in Political Science
description: Combines the study of the theoretical and practical aspects of teaching political science with supervised classroom teaching of POLS 110. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Colloquium
description: Specialized subjects in political science.

title: Graduate Intern Seminar
description: Seminar for those seeking internship experience. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 672 and 673 or consent for the alternative futures option; 620 or consent for the indigenous politics option; consent of advisor for all other options.
prerequisites: POLS 672 and POLS 673 or consent for the alternative futures option; POLS 620 or consent for the indigenous politics option; consent of advisor for all other options

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar: Research Methods
description: Conceptual strategies, data collection approaches, and data analysis techniques appropriate to political inquiries. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Writing Politics
description: Seminar on the politics of writing, grammar, translation, argument, genre, and style with significant content on indigenous issues of oral traditions, alternative modes of writing and argument, and language continuance.

title: Seminar: Political Thought
description: -announced topics. Repeatable unlimited times. At least one section a year.

title: Seminar: Indigenous Theory
description: -announced topics may include gender and sexuality studies, postcolonial theory, colonial discourse analysis, globalization, historiography; emphasis on indigenous epistemologies and the work of native scholars. Repeatable one time.
prerequisites: -announced topics may include gender and sexuality studies, postcolonial theory, colonial discourse analysis, globalization, historiography; emphasis on indigenous epistemologies and the work of native scholars

title: Seminar: International Relations
description: -announced problems of both international organization and politics. Repeatable unlimited times. At least one section a semester.
prerequisites: -announced problems of both international organization and politics

title: Seminar: Comparative Government and Politics
description: -announced topics. Repeatable unlimited times. At least one section a semester.

title: Seminar: Public Administration
description: -announced administrative theory, comparative and development administration, and functional aspects. Repeatable unlimited times.
prerequisites: -announced administrative theory, comparative and development administration, and functional aspects

title: Seminar: Public Policy
description: -announced topics. Repeatable three times. consent of instructor. At least one section a year.

title: Indigenous Nations and the Problems of Sovereignty
description: Examines intersections of sovereignty and indigenity from comparative and critical perspectives. Engages indigenous studies of sovereignty and of alternative political frameworks. Repeatable one time. (Alt. years)

title: Decolonial Futures
description: Topic engages probable and preferable futures of indigenous struggles and resistances. Emphasis placed on the ethics and responsibilities used to move towards those futures.

title: Seminar: Politics of Regions
description: Analysis of political development, international relations, decision-making processes, and systems of political thought in regions and subregions of the world. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Survey of Psychology
description: An overview of the field: psychophysiology, perception, learning, cognition, stress, personality, social psychology.

title: Personal Development
description: The application of psychology to the understanding, management, and enhancement of one’s life.

title: Psychology of Gender
description: Survey of topics in psychology relevant to gender and its impact on the lives of women and men: socialization of gender, mental health, racial identity, majority-minority status, sexual orientation, life-span issues and violence. A-F only. 100 or WGSS 151. (

title: Survey of Research Methods
description: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab) Survey of standard methods and related conceptual issues employed in psychological research. Both experimental and non-experimental methods will be reviewed. 100.

title: Introduction to Behavioral Psychology
description: Outline of basic learning principles. A general, unified approach to study of human personality and behavior. Based upon a learning conception; various areas of psychology and the other social sciences are treated. 100.

title: Statistical Techniques
description: Frequency distributions; graphic methods; central tendency; variability; correlation; reliability; tests of significance. 100.

title: Introduction to Psychobiology
description: Survey of study of behavior from a natural sciences viewpoint. Evolution, ethological analysis of behavior genetics, neural mechanisms, drugs and behavior, biological development. 100.

title: Developmental Psychology
description: Emotional, mental, physical, social development from infancy to adulthood; interests and abilities at different age levels. 100.

title: Social Psychology
description: Cognitive, behavioral, and emotional effects of people: interpersonal relations, attribution, attitudes, group behavior, stereotypes, social roles, aggression, helping, self-concept; applications. 100.

title: Psychology of Personality
description: Scientific study of personality, its meaning, assessment, development, relation to cultural-social determinants. 100.

title: Introduction to Clinical Psychology
description: History, theories, nature of psychological problems, methods of assessment, forms of intervention, current developments. 100.

title: Introduction to Community Psychology
description: Examination of human functioning in social and ecological context. Topics include stress, health, intergroup relations, culture, ethnicity, social competence, and community empowerment. 100.

title: Introduction to Educational Psychology
description: Psychology applied to education, including cognitive, sociocultural, and multicultural approaches to teaching, learning, development, and research. Develops knowledge and written communication skills through and introduction to classroom, assessment, instruction, motivation, classroom management, and standardized testing. (

title: Learning and Motivation
description: Theoretical interpretations; survey of major theorists and contemporary controversial issues; major influences in classical and instrumental conditioning. 100. Recommended: 220.

title: Psychology of Emotion
description: Survey of traditional views and leading theories, and research in related topics. 100. Recommended: 220 or 322.

title: Cognitive Psychology
description: Survey of cognitive processes involved in perception, attention, memory, language, problem-solving, reasoning, judgment, intelligence and consciousness, among others. 100 or consent.

title: Behavioral Neuroscience
description: Coverage of the relationship between the brain and body on learning and memory, stress, motivated and regulatory behavioral functions, and mental disorders. A-F only. 230 or BIOL 172, or consent.

title: Psychopharmacology
description: Coverage of the principles of pharmacology in relation to the effects of drug actions on the brain and behavior. A-F only. 230 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Sensation and Perception
description: In-depth coverage of the basic principles involved in sensing and perceiving our environment. A-F only. 100.

title: Social Development of Children
description: Survey of the social and emotional development of children and adolescents. 240 or HDFS 230.

title: Adult Development and Aging
description: Overview from a multidisciplinary, life-span perspective. Includes research techniques, personality development, family relationships, occupational attainment, death. 100. Recommended: 240. (

title: Cross-Cultural Psychology
description: Psychological theories and cultural systems; understanding of own and other cultures; psychological and cultural perception of social motivation; cultural similarities and differences in interpersonal relations. 100.

title: Psychology of Human Sexuality
description: Psychosocial aspects of human sexual relationships. Social psychology of emotional and physiological arousal, interpersonal attraction, and societal regulation of intimate relationships. 100.

title: Abnormal Psychology
description: Nature and causes of psychological disorders. 100.

title: Consumer Behavior
description: Analysis of consumer behavior and motivation; principles of learning, personality, perception, and group influence, with emphasis upon mass communication effects. BUS 312 or consent. (

title: History of Psychology
description: Origin and development of contemporary points of view. 100. Recommended: 9 credit hours in psychology.

title: Seminar on the Psychology of Knowledge
description: Selected topics in the psychology of knowledge and mind from Western and/or non-Western perspectives. Repeatable in different topics up to 9 credit hours. 100 and written consent.

title: Practicum in Psychology
description: Supervised psychological experience in school, clinic, hospital, industry, social welfare, government, etc. 100 and consent.

title: Teaching General Psychology
description: Supervised experience. 100, at least 12 additional credit hours in psychology, and written consent. Repeatable one time. A-F only.
prerequisites: PSY 100, at least PSY 12 additional credit hours in psychology, and written consent

title: General Psychology: Advanced Topics
description: In-depth coverage of some area of theory and research. Repeatable to 6 credit hours. 100.

title: Psychometrics: Advanced Topics
description: In-depth coverage of some area of theory, research, or methodology relevant to individual differences, measurement, or aspects of psychometrics. Repeatable to six credit hours. 100.

title: Experimental Psychology: Advanced Topics
description: In-depth coverage of some area of theory and research, in cognitive psychology. Repeatable to six credit hours. 100.

title: Psychobiology: Advanced Topics
description: Indepth coverage of some area of theory and research in psychobiology, physiological psychology, or sensory processes. Repeatable to six credit hours. 100.

title: Clinical Child and Adolescent Psychology
description: Social and emotional maladjustment in children and adolescents, developmental disabilities, pediatric psychology, psychological interventions with children and adolescents. 100. Recommended: 240.

title: Development Psychology: Advanced Topics
description: In-depth coverage of some area of theory and research in developmental psychology. Repeatable to six credit hours. 240, 341, or consent

title: Social Psychology: Advanced Topics
description: In-depth coverage of some area of theory and research in social psychology. Repeatable to six credit hours.

title: Health Psychology
description: Psychological principles for understanding and dealing with wellness and illness. Theories and research on stress-related disorders; prevention of stress through lifestyle and healthy behaviors. 100 or consent. Recommended: 220 or 322.

title: Communicating Social Support
description: Survey of major theories, concepts, research, and application regarding communication and social support in interpersonal relationships. (

title: Teaching Personal Development
description: Supervised experience in leading a seminar in personal development. 170 and 12 additional credits in PSY and written consent.
prerequisites: PSY 170 and PSY 12 additional credits in PSY and written consent

title: Advanced Topics in Adjustment/ Treatment/Prevention
description: In-depth coverage of some area of theory and research in clinical psychology. Repeatable to six credit hours. 270, 371 or consent.

title: Applied Psychology: Advanced Topics
description: Coverage in-depth of some areas of theory and research. Repeatable to six credit hours. 100. (

title: Special Topics in Psychology
description: Covers topics of current or special interest not covered in regular course offerings or advanced topics seminars. Repeatable two times. 100.

title: Directed Reading or Research
description: Repeatable eight times, up to nine credits. 100 and consent of instructor.

title: Methodologic Foundations of Psychology
description: Methods used in psychological research; observational, correlational, and experimental types of design.

title: Introduction to Regression
description: Introduction to quantitative methods in behavioral sciences and the general linear model with a focus on regression. Topics include correlation, bivariate and multiple regression, mediation, and moderation. Requires basic statistics. (Meets PhD common inquiry methods requirement or elective.)

title: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) and Related Methods
description: Introduction to ANOVA and its extensions from both traditional and general linear model approaches. Topics include single and multi-factor ANOVA, multiple comparisons, analysis of covariance (ANCOVA), and repeated-measures ANOVA.

title: Factor Analysis and Structural Equation Models (SEM)
description: Theories and applications to latent variables models. Topics include path analysis, exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis, structural equation models (SEM), multi-sample SEM, mean structure, latent growth curve models, and multilevel SEM. Requires basic knowledge of regression.

title: Multivariate Analysis
description: Analysis of multiple dependent variables. Topics include multivariate normal distribution, Hotelling’s 72, multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA), discriminant analysis, cluster analysis, canonical correlation, and principal components analysis (PCA). 610, EDEP 604, or consent.

title: Measurement in Education and Social Sciences
description: Test theories and applications in education and social sciences. Topics include the true score model; reliability; generalizability theory; validity; item response theory; and applications in research. Class requires knowledge in ANOVA and regression.

title: Advanced Psychometrics
description: Theories and applications of modern psychometrics. Topics include unidimensional and multidimensional models of item response theory, detecting biased items, measurement invariance, scaling methods, and current issues in psychometrics. 616, EDEP 616, or consent.

title: Categorical Data Analysis
description: Theories and methods for data analysis with categorical and discrete variables. Topics include contingency tables; logistic regression; log-linear models; and introduction to generalized linear models. 610, EDEP 604, or consent. (

title: Analysis of Multilevel Models and Longitudinal Data
description: Theories and applications of analysis of nested (clustered) data. Topics include fixed and random effects, intra-class correlation, cross-sectional multilevel models, and multilevel models, and multilevel models with repeated measures and longitudinal data. Requires basic knowledge of regression.

title: Principles of Learning
description: Survey of the principles of learning, including important discoveries in the development of the study of learning, major theories, and both basic and applied research in contemporary literature.

title: Cognitive Psychology
description: In-depth survey of the computational and representational structures and processes of cognition. Special attention devoted to consideration of the relationship between brain, mind, and computation. 325 or consent.

title: Thinking
description: Provides an introduction to higher cognition (thinking and reasoning) and its foundations, particularly as they relate to the larger field of cognitive science. A-F only. (Alt. years)

title: Comparative Cognition
description: Survey of the historical and contemporary study of cognition across species, including learning, memory, attention, navigation, reasoning, social interaction, and communication.

title: Selected Topics in Comparative Psychology
description: Intensive review of comparative, communicative, sensory, or learning mechanisms in animals. 631.

title: Psychopharmacology
description: Basic principles of pharmacology as they apply to the brain and specific psychological disorders such as anxiety, depression, post-traumatic stress disorders, schizophrenia, psychosis, memory, and drug use. A-F only. consent. (Once a year)

title: Behavioral Neuroscience
description: Relation of central and peripheral nervous systems to behavior.

title: Developmental Foundations
description: Historical, theoretical, and methodological foundations of developmental psychology.

title: Cognitive Development
description: Familiarizes students with current research and theory in cognitive development through readings of original journal articles and monographs. 640 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Social Psychology
description: Theories and research in social cognition and behavior.

title: Cross-Cultural Psychology
description: Application of psychological theories to cross-cultural phenomena; assessment of cross-cultural processes and social motivations; culture and personality; research evaluation and design.

title: Psychology and Social Issues
description: Conflict, dissent, community issues, problems; social change and its relation to mental disorder.

title: Applied Social Psychology
description: Problems in use of social psychology principles in human affairs; multidisciplinary considerations.

title: Social Psychology of Love and Sex
description: Seminar in psychosocial aspects of human sexual relationships. Social psychology of cognitive, emotional and physiological arousal, interpersonal attraction, mate selection, and antecedents and consequences of intimate relationships. consent. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Introduction to Clinical Psychology
description: Preparation for becoming a clinical psychologist with emphasis on scientist-practitioner model, professional ethics, diversity and professional development. graduate student in psychology or consent of instructor.
prerequisites: graduate student in psychology or consent of instructor

title: Introduction to Assessment I
description: Psychometric theory; ethics; diversity issues; principles and methods of cognitive-intellectual, neuropsychological, and personality assessment. A-F only. Co-requisite: 670 or consent.

title: Introduction to Assessment II
description: Administration and interpretation of cognitive-intellectual and personality assessment devices. A-F only. 670 and 671 or consent and enrollment in Clinical Studies Program.
prerequisites: PSY 670 and PSY 671 or consent and enrollment in Clinical Studies Program

title: Advanced Assessment
description: Conceptual and methodological foundations of clinical applications of assessment. PSY majors only. A-F only. 671 and 672 and enrollment in Clinical Studies Program, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: PSY 671 and PSY 672 and enrollment in Clinical Studies Program, or consent

title: Treatment Research
description: Idiographic and nomothetic approaches to clinical treatment research methods and findings. 670 (or concurrent) and 671, or consent.
prerequisites: PSY 670 (or concurrent) and PSY 671, or consent

title: Psychopathology
description: Comprehensive study of the mental disorders across the lifespan. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Child Practicum
description: Supervised clinical assessment and treatment of children and adolescents. Repeatable ten times, up to 33 credits. consent.

title: Adult Practicum
description: Supervised clinical assessment and treatment of adults. Repeatable ten times, up to 33 credits. consent.

title: External Practicum
description: This supervision-style class will cover cases and issues related to student’s clinic work, supervision, or educational goals while training in external practicum sites. Repeatable ten times. consent.

title: Cultural Community Psychology
description: Graduate seminar on cultural considerations and issues in the history, methods, theories, interventions, and professional roles in community psychology. Small class size (up to 10). Open to graduate students.

title: Practicum: Behavioral Change and Community
description: Supervised experience in educational, mental health, correctional, consulting, or community action agencies. consent.

title: Directed Reading or Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Minimum of six credit hours is required. Repeatable six times up to seven credits.

title: Seminar in General Psychology

title: Seminar in Quantitative Psychology
description: Specific and newly emerging topics in statistics, including casual inference, analysis of missing data, and statistical machine learning. Content varies and focuses on advanced topics not covered in other PSY methods and statistics courses. Repeatable two times. PSY majors only. A-F only. 610 (with a minimum grade of B) or instructor consent.
prerequisites: PSY 610 (with a minimum grade of B) or instructor consent

title: Research in Psychometrics
description: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Seminar in Experimental Psychology
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Learning

title: Research in Experimental Psychology
description: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Physiological Psychology
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Comparative Psychology
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Research in Psychology
description: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Developmental Psychology
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Research in Developmental Psychology
description: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Social Psychology
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Research in Social Psychology
description: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Child Treatment
description: Psychological interventions for youth, as well as parent training. Repeatable two times. 670 or consent.

title: Adult Treatment: Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy
description: Training in cognitive-behavioral strategies for treating adults. Repeatable one time. Enrolled in Clinical Studies Program only. PSY major only. 670 or consent.

title: Seminar in Psychopathology
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Clinical Psychology
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Psychological Therapies
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Health Psychology: Behavioral and Biological Bases
description: Psychological and biological bases of health psychology and behavioral medicine. Overview of cognitive, behavioral, and psychophysiological mechanisms; theories and methods of prevention in physical disease. 670 or consent.

title: Internship in Clinical Psychology
description: Repeatable one time. consent of instructor.

title: Research in Clinical Psychology
description: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable 30 times. consent.

title: Community Psychology Seminar
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Community Psychology Research
description: Supervised reading, discussion, research projects in areas of special interest. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Survey of Public Policy and Analysis
description: Students will learn about the policy making process, the results of policy decisions and how public policy is assessed, analyzed, and responded to. Also discusses important policy issues that currently fill the political landscape. Junior standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Research Methods for Policy Evaluation
description: Explores methodological approaches to the evaluation of public policies and strengths and weaknesses of various social science research methods. Students will learn how to employ them to determine the effectiveness of various public policies. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. 304, 330, or PLAN 310.

title: Foundations of Nonprofit Management
description: Broad overview of nonprofit organizations, including what it means to be a nonprofit, strategies of nonprofit organizations, and the management of nonprofits. Topics include advocacy, leadership, and evaluating success. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Multicultural Leadership in Public Service
description: Develop students’ culturally agile leadership to allow them effectively lead in work on international, regional, and local projects and problems of compelling public interest that cross cultures. Junior standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Practicum and Internship
description: The practicum and internship in Peace and Conflict Resolution provides an opportunity for students to apply the skills and concepts learned in earlier courses. any two other PACE courses or consent. (
prerequisites: any two other PACE courses or consent

title: Directed Reading and Research in Public Administration
description: Independent research and reading on topics in public administration, public service, and community development. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Program Evaluation for Public and Nonprofit Organizations
description: Methods for evaluating the effectiveness of programs in the public and nonprofit sectors; performance measurement to inform managerial decision making. (Fall only)

title: Introduction to Public Administration
description: Develop a comprehension of the history and foundation of public administration. Topics include economic, political, and social dynamics; decision-making and leadership theories, management challenges, human resources, budgeting, program evaluation, policy, and technology. PUBA and PUBA Cert. majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Organizations: Theory and Change
description: Explores characteristics and structural, human resources, political, and cultural frames of organizational theory. Focus on organizational change strategies and theories. Discusses how to use these frames and theories in everyday management of public service organizations. PUBA and PUBA Cert. majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Leadership and Ethics
description: Applies leadership and ethical theories to public and non-profit sectors, focusing on ethical leadership; emphasizes critical thinking to address value conflicts; and teaches moral reasoning as a practical professional skill. PUBA and PUBA Cert. majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Effective Communication in Public Administration
description: Knowledge and skills to effectively communicate in the public sector. Focus on communication foundations and skills, levels and contexts of public sector communication, and handling challenges such as diverse and multi-cultural settings. PUBA and PUBA Cert. majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Public Administration Personnel Management
description: Understand the pivotal role that effective human resource management (also known as personnel management) plays in improving organizational effectiveness. Topics include managing diversity, employment law and discrimination, performance appraisal, and labor-management relations. PUBA and PUBA Cert. majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Public Administration Research Methods
description: Introduction to research methods for public administrators to understand the principles and methods used to conduct and analyze valid research. Examples are oriented to the field; theory and hands-on practice utilized. PUBA and PUBA Cert. majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only. 601. (Spring only)

title: Public Budgeting
description: Institutions and issues related to public-sector budgeting at federal, state, and local levels. Process of developing public budgets and constraints on public policy reflected in budgets. PUBA majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Policy Analysis and Implementation
description: Explore contemporary policy issues relating to public administration practice. Develop analytic techniques and models of public policy-making processes, administrative rules, and policy implementation strategies. Learn how social forces, political, and economic pressures influence policy orientation. PUBA majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Reforming Public Organizations
description: Looks at the challenges and opportunities for changing public organizations so that they may be more successful in meeting their public responsibilities and better places for people to work. Focus is on the creation of positive images of organization and effective change strategies. A-F only.

title: The Political Environment of Public Organizations
description: Seminar on the role of public managers in shaping public opinion and public policy. Using evidence from theory and practice presents students with tools for understanding management roles within a political context. graduate standing or consent.

title: Strategies of Change: Leaders and Leadership
description: Explores the key elements of leadership in public settings by examining what leaders actually do, looking at popular media portrayals of leadership, and talking together with guests about the challenges of leadership, effective followership, and positive change. A-F only.

title: Law, Economics, and Public Administration
description: Explore U.S. law as applied to public institutions using economic lens. Rationale of property, contract, and tort law; evolution of administrative law, economic efficiency of common law system, effects of legal rules on economic behavior. A-F only.

title: Collaboration for Public and Nonprofit Leaders
description: Theories, skills, and tools needed to effectively manage networks in government and nonprofit organizations; explores how to administer, assess performance, and evaluate success in these dynamic new partnerships. Graduate students only or consent. A-F only.

title: Managing Workplace Diversity and Inclusion
description: Examines rationales, impacts, and various dimensions of diversity and inclusion beyond race and gender. Students learn and apply public management tools used to foster workplace diversity and inclusion. A-F only. 606 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
prerequisites: PUBA 606 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: ICT Policy and Planning
description: Processes and methods of planning appropriate to the information and communication sectors, including future economic, social, political, technical, and environmental perspectives. COM 611 (or concurrent) or consent. (

title: Public Policy and Advocacy
description: Designed to deepen students’ ability to understand and influence the policy process in Hawai‘i and the U.S. Topics include theories of the policy process, and advocacy strategies, legal constraints, and coalition building. PUBA majors only or approval of instructor. A-F only.

title: Nonprofit Management
description: Fundamental aspects of managing a nonprofit organization: overview of the nonprofit sector; mission and scope of nonprofit organizations; organizational structures and functions; resource and volunteer development; major management issues. A-F only graduate standing or consent. (Fall only)

title: Nonprofit Management Practices and Tools
description: Skills and tools needed by nonprofit managers. Topics include but are not limited to grantwriting, strategic planning, business practices, program evaluation, and advocacy. A-F only. 630 or consent. (Spring only)

title: International Perspectives on Public Administration
description: Key dimensions of public administration systems on a global scale; historic and contemporary forces shaping national systems; the dimensions that distinguish them, the opportunities and constraints for comparison and the transfer of knowledge and experience. A-F only. graduate standing or departmental approval.

title: Indigenous Governance
description: Overview of indigenous governing systems, particularly in the Americas and the Pacific. Students will learn the legal frameworks and principles of these systems, and how services are provided to citizens. A-F only.

title: Special Topics
description: Topics of current interest in the field of public service and public administration, taught by regular and visiting faculty. Repeatable for different topics up to six credit hours. A-F only. consent.

title: MPA Practicum
description: Placement in public, private, and nonprofit organizations to observe and analyze organizational functions and processes while undertaking projects of use to the host agency. Repeatable one time. PUBA majors only. A-F only. with a minimum grade of B: 602, 603, and 604.
prerequisites: with a minimum grade of B: PUBA 602, PUBA 603, and PUBA 604

title: Certificate Practicum
description: Students in the nonprofit management track of the certificate will learn by doing and observing in a nonprofit organization selected in consultation with the student’s advisor. PUBA graduate certificate students only. A-F only.

title: Capstone Seminar
description: Culminates public administration core courses by incorporating theoretical, analytical, and practicum observations into examination of public issues of importance to Hawai‘i and the region. A-F only. (601, 602, 607) with a minimum grade of B.
prerequisites: (PUBA 601, PUBA 602, PUBA 607) with a minimum grade of B

title: Directed Reading
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Introduction to Public Health
description: Introduces public health concepts with an emphasis on principles and tools for population health, disease prevention, health professions and healthcare systems, and public health professions and systems. A-F only.

title: Public Health Issues in Hawai‘i
description: Application of general public health concepts and tools with broader public health issues as they relate to the State of Hawai‘i. A-F only. 201.

title: Introduction to Global Health
description: Introduction to the basic principles of global PH. Topics include the application of these principles to global PH issues, exploration of links between health, economic, and social status, health disparities and global interventions. A-F only. 201 and a FW course.

title: Quantitative Reasoning for Public Health
description: Inductive and deductive reasoning; tabular, symbolic, verbal, and graphical forms of functions and relations; graphs and pictorial representations of data; interpretations of probabilistic data; surveys and statistical studies as related to public health. PH majors only. A-F only.

title: Public Health Student Success in the College Experience
description: Required for entering PH majors to gain strategies for a successful college experience while studying public health. Students will examine academic and career goals and implement strategies to achieve them. PH majors only. A-F only.

title: Seminar in Public Health Issues
description: Seminar will explore current issues and case studies in epidemiology, issues and causes of chronic and infectious diseases, how the environment interacts with health, and how social and behavioral factors affect personal health.

title: Native Hawaiian Health Determinants
description: Seminar to work with faculty in applying evidence-based knowledge on social determinants of health in the formation of research, policy, and program development for improving population health and reducing health disparities for Native Hawaiians. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 201 and 202. (Spring only)

title: Introduction to Epidemiology
description: Lecture/discussion on the fundamental principles of epidemiology, exploring patterns of disease, threats to health and EPI methods for prevention, control, and treatment. PH majors only. A-F only. 201, and 210 or MATH 140X or MATH 161 or higher; or instructor approval.
prerequisites: PH 201, and PH 210 or MATH 140X or MATH 161 or higher; or instructor approval

title: Youth Risk and Protection–Public Health Research, Practice, and Policy
description: Application of public health, related to youth health risks and protective factors using an eco-developmental framework. A-F only. 201 and PSY 100.

title: The United States Health Care System
description: Overview of the U.S. health care system. Topics will include health economics, health service expenditures, comparative health systems, health policy, and issues of cost containment, access, and quality of care. A-F only. 201.

title: Public Health and the Environment
description: Examines a variety of issues associated with environmental effects on disease incidence, morbidity, and mortality in relation to public health prevention strategies. Sophomore standing and above.

title: Public Health Biology and Pathophysiology
description: Explores the biological basis of human disease and the role public health measures play in reducing both the extent and impact of chronic and acute diseases on individuals and society. A-F only. 201, and one of the following: BIOL 101 or BIOL 171 or BIOL 172 or PHYL 103 or PHYL 141 or FSHN 185.
prerequisites: PH 201, and one of the following: BIOL 101 or BIOL 171 or BIOL 172 or PHYL 103 or PHYL 141 or FSHN 185

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
description: Basic biostatistics methods in public health and biomedical research. Topics covered include data collection, data analyses, and interpretation of statistical results. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Advanced Epidemiology
description: Students will gain a deeper understanding of the core concepts used in epidemiologic research and practice. Upon completion, students will have the knowledge and skills necessary to conduct an epidemiologic study. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 201 and 310.

title: Nutrition and Disease Prevention
description: Lecture/discussion. Examines a variety of issues associated with the effects of diet on disease incidence, morbidity, and mortality in relation to public health prevention strategies. Junior standing or higher. 310.

title: Social Behavioral Health I: Health Promotion for Individuals and Groups
description: Focus on the application of social and behavioral theory in health education, and how health promotion programs are constructed for various populations with an emphasis on cultural diversity and social determinants of health. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. 202 and PSY 100.

title: Social Behavioral Health II: Health Promotion in Communities
description: Introduction to health education and health promotion programming in public health, and to social/behavioral theories used to develop health interventions that affect communities, institutions, and policies. Introduction to common program planning models. A-F only. 420.

title: Tobacco & Community Disparities
description: Assessing the facilitators and barriers of smoking initiation, cessation, and exposure to second-hand smoke within communities. Use of photovoice and its application to policy and addressing disparities. A-F only. 201.

title: Health Policy and Management
description: Examines the role that health policy and management plays in population-based public health practice, including the delivery, quality, and costs of health care and the structure, process, and outcomes of health services delivery. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. 201 and 202.

title: Back to the Future: Aging in Today’s Society
description: By 2050, more than a quarter of the world’s population will be 60 years of age or older. Explores what we know about aging today to encourage a lifetime of aging well. A-F only. 201 or SW 360 or WGSS 305 or PSY 100 or HDFS 230 or NURS 200; or consent. (
prerequisites: PH 201 or SW 360 or WGSS 305 or PSY 100 or HDFS 230 or NURS 200; or consent

title: Introduction to One Health
description: Familiarizes students with the fundamentals of One Health–an interdisciplinary field of study linking ecosystems to human and animal health. It uses contemporary examples and emphasizes oceans and human health connections. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (201, or ANSC 200, or BIOC 141, or BIOL 101, or BIOL 171, or BOT 101, or ERTH 101, or GES 102, or OEST 101, or OCN 102, or ATMO 150, or SOC 180) with a minimum grade of C or better; or consent.
prerequisites: (PH 201, or ANSC 200, or BIOC 141, or BIOL 101, or BIOL 171, or BOT 101, or ERTH 101, or GES 102, or OEST 101, or OCN 102, or ATMO 150, or SOC 180) with a minimum grade of C or better; or consent

title: Introduction to Environmental Microbiology
description: Lecture/discussion. Will define the nature and biological activities of microorganisms in different environments and evaluate the effects of these microbes on human activities and health. Junior standing or higher. MICR 130 or MICR 351 or BIOL 171.

title: Social Determinants of Indigenous Peoples’ Health
description: Examines indigenous peoples’ health inequities using social determinants of health framework: considers this approach within the historical, political, cultural, and social context of Indigenous population’s health status to generate solutions. A-F only. 201.

title: Application of Public Health Principles in Research and Practice
description: Introduction to a diverse range of public health projects and associated methods while working to develop a written applied learning project literature review. Students will present their findings at a public forum. PH majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 203 and 310.

title: Public Health Applied Learning Experience
description: Allows students to execute an independent, mentor-supervised, applied learning project as implementation of skills learned in previous public health coursework. Applied project is a required component of the public health undergraduate degree program. 420 and 480.

title: Public Health Undergraduate Capstone Seminar
description: Synthesis of public health knowledge, skills, and practice acquired during the public health undergraduate degree. Students also reflect on, finalize, and present written applied learning experience projects at a public form. Senior standing and higher. A-F only. completed public health applied learning experience and consent.
prerequisites: completed public health applied learning experience and consent

title: (Alpha) Current Issues and Topics in Public Health
description: Current and emerging issues and varying topics related to public health. (B) biostatistics; (E) epidemiology; (H) health policy and management; (S) social and behavioral health sciences; (T) public health. Each alpha repeatable one time. Open to nonmajors. Sophomore standing and above. A-F only. 201.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Repeatable up to six credits. PH majors only. Junior standing or higher.

title: Public Health Foundations
description: Focus will provide a broad introduction to the field of public health and orientation to overarching issues in the field. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: U.S. Health Care Services and Policy
description: Overview of the historical, conceptual, ethical and political context for health care delivery in the U.S. Explores current trends, practices and issues in the delivery of health care services in both private and public sector.

title: Public Health Biology
description: Writing-intensive asynchronous computer-based course examines biological processes and challenges relevant to the public health professional. Topics include anatomical, pathophysiological, and molecular bases of public health; genetics, immunology, ethics; disease prevention, control, and management. (Once a year) (

title: Fundamentals to One Health
description: Familiarizes students with the fundamentals of One Health–an interdisciplinary field of study linking ecosystems to human and animal health. It uses contemporary examples and emphasizes oceans and human health connections. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Health Promotion Theory and Methods
description: Individual and community health; implications for public health practice, individual and social change processes.

title: Health Economics
description: Integrated concepts in health economics and its application towards health policy issues; market failures in health care; factors affecting U.S. health care spending potential impact on equity/efficiency stemming from changes in health care delivery. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Cultural Competency in Health Care
description: Presents both analytical and practical approaches to cultural competency domains, concepts, models, frameworks, patterns and communication that occur in cross-cultural healthcare situations. A-F only.

title: Indigenous Health Activism
description: Examines how Indigenous Peoples and their allies (individually and collectively) accomplish social change in society. A-F only. Graduate students only. consent of instructor.

title: Indigenous Health Seminar
description: Examines public health through an Indigenous lens, integrates competencies across all public health disciplines, and will apply them in context of working for and with Indigenous communities to improve health and wellness. PH majors or consent. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Advanced Topics in Health Policy
description: Examines major federal and local policies that impact health and health care delivery in the U.S. and other nations; considers effectiveness of these policy-making institutions for improving population health; covers methods in policy analysis. A-F only. 602 or consent.

title: Grant Writing in Public Health
description: Lecture/discussion on grant writing with public health focus. Includes basic components of grant proposals, assessing appropriate funding opportunities, data sources/resources for justifying grants, and the funder’s perspective. Student will prepare a brief foundation grant proposal. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Program Planning, Management, Evaluation, and Leadership
description: Foundation to inform, educate, and improve health for individuals, communities, and populations. Knowledge/acquisition of skills through program planning, management, evaluation and leadership that span the social-ecological range from individual-level to population-level programs. EPID and PH majors only. A-F only.

title: Needs Assessment
description: Knowledge and skills acquisition in conducting needs assessment in public health practice.

title: Ecological Epidemiology
description: Applications of population biology, pathogen/host life history, and population genetics to infectious disease epidemiology, including micro- and macroparasites, and implications to disease control and prevention of strategies. A-F only. consent. (Alt. years: spring) (

title: Interdisciplinary Seminar
description: Topics such as contemporary issues in global health and population studies, international health programs, demographic methods, global economy and health, human right and humanitarian assistance, social justice, global environmental changes and health. consent.

title: Global Health and Human Security
description: Provides the knowledge, skills, and attitudes required to successfully manage health security crises and protect human vulnerability in the global context with a special focus on problems with high likelihood and risk in the Pacific.

title: Biostatistics I
description: Introduction to statistical methods for public health sciences. Probability, experimental design, t tests and analysis of variance, 2X2 contingency tables, linear regression, introduction to life tables.

title: Biostatistics II
description: Poisson distribution, Fisher’s exact test, contrasts in ANOVA, two way ANOVA, multiple linear regression and analysis of covariance, path analysis, logistic regression, method of maximum likelihood, likelihood ratio tests. 655, completion of one semester of calculus; or consent.
prerequisites: PH 655, completion of one semester of calculus; or consent

title: Computer Applications in Public Health
description: Applications of computers to problems common to public health. Emphasis on data analysis and processing using existing computer programs.

title: Methods of Demographic Analysis
description: Statistical evaluation and analysis of population data; data sources; population growth; composition; standardization of rates; mortality and the life table; nuptiality and fertility; distribution, migration, and urbanization; projections and stable population theory. (

title: Principles of Epidemiology I
description: Introduction to epidemiologic principles and methods. Topics covered include: outbreak investigation, measures of morbidity and mortality, measurements of risk, biological variability, screening, measurements of error, sampling, statistical significance, study design, and association and causation.

title: Principles of Epidemiology II
description: Lecture/discussion on: design and interpretation of experimental and observational studies; causation and casual inference; biases in study design; random error and statistics role in epidemiology; and epidemiological data analysis. A-F only. 655 and 663, or consent.

title: Concepts in Immunology and Immunopathogenesis
description: Immunological concepts relating to infectious diseases and host pathogen interactions. Repeatable one time. A-F only. MICR 461 (or equivalent) or consent. (

title: Seminar in Infectious Disease Control
description: Strategies for controlling important infectious diseases in the Pacific area. Emphasis on epidemiology, ecology, and public health principles. 663 (or concurrent) and one semester in microbiology, or consent.
prerequisites: PH 663 (or concurrent) and one semester in microbiology, or consent

title: Infectious Disease Micro II
description: Will cover different families of animal viruses of importance to human diseases. The genome, structure, replication, as well as host immune responses, epidemiology, clinical features, and animal models will be presented. Repeatable one time. A-F only. TRMD 604 and MICR 351, or consent. (

title: Epidemiological Study Design Critique
description: Critique of study design using published public health literature. Emphasis on exchange of ideas, alternative approaches; stresses epidemiology as science of public health. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. 663 or consent.

title: Community and Public Health Practice
description: Community organization and development applicable to the delivery of health services. Understanding community dynamics, mobilizing community groups for effective health care practice and delivery. 647 or consent. (

title: Leading and Managing Health Programs
description: Assess how to organize community partnerships to create and communicate a shared vision for a changing future; discuss solutions to organizational and community challenges; maximize motivation to reach public health goals. A-F only.

title: Native Health Ethics, Law, and Policy
description: Review theories and laws concerning health care ethics, policy, and practice using Indigenous case studies. Topics include Indigenous health systems, advocacy, and the intersecting issues of self-determination, ethics, agenda setting, and the policy cycle. A-F only. (Once a year) (

title: Advanced Native Hawaiian Health Determinants
description: Applications of evidence-based knowledge about the social determinants of health in the formation of research, policy, and program development for improving population health and reducing health disparities for Native Hawaiians. A-F only.

title: Community Engaged Research and Practice
description: Explores collaborative and engaged approaches with communities in public health research and practice. With a focus on Indigenous Peoples’ health, we delve into Indigenous knowledge and empowerment in evaluation, needs assessment, intervention, and health promotion. PH majors or consent. Graduate students only. 655 and 673.

title: Hawai‘i Public Health Policies on Infectious Diseases
description: Examines quarantine/ isolation of patients infected with Hanson’s disease. Focus on PH policies before 1823 and after; analysis of other infections in Hawai‘i and the world to examine differences in policies and their effect on the public. Graduate students only. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Managing Global Health Service Delivery
