description: Provides knowledge, skills, attitudes and resources that health managers require to manage and maintain the quality of partnerships, facilities, programs, community services, people, drugs, and information in limited resources settings. PH majors only. A-F only.

title: Health Emergencies in Large Populations
description: Health Emergencies in Large Populations is run by the Center for Excellence in Disaster Management and Humanitarian Assistance and the Red Cross. It provides knowledge, practical skills, and networking for global health practitioners. A-F only.

title: Environmental Determinants of Health
description: Environmental factors in personal and community health; implications for public health practice. Consideration of major issues from local, U.S., and international perspectives.

title: Global Nutrition
description: Examination of global food and nutrition problems, programs, issues, policies, and strategies for improvement. A-F only. statistics and consent. (Alt. years: fall) (

title: Supplemental and Nutritional Approaches in Disease Prevention and Treatment
description: Examines a variety of issues associated with nutritional and supplemental approaches to reduce disease incidence, morbidity, and mortality in relation to public health prevention strategies. PH majors only. (

title: Advanced Child and Adolescent Nutrition
description: Addresses nutrition, growth, and development in children and adolescents and nutrition-related issues, such as childhood obesity and chronic disease risk factors, with a focus on current research in the Pacific region. FSHN 370 or consent. (Fall only) (

title: Indigenous Peoples’ Food Systems, Environment and Health
description: Explores Indigenous Peoples’ food systems as local food resources Indigenous People acquire through specific cultural knowledge of traditional territories. Global forces transforming these food systems and their impact on population health and nutrition are explored. PH majors or consent. Graduate students only. (

title: Nutritional Epidemiology
description: Dietary, biochemical, anthropometric and clinical methods used for evaluating nutrition and diet in the etiology and epidemiology of disease. 663 and FSHN 685, or consent. (

title: Global Health Challenges
description: Addresses critical, contemporary, and transnational issues best addressed by cooperative international action. Health issues are examined in the context of intersecting effects of limited resources, socioeconomics, politics, and environmental change. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Fundamentals of Environmental Epidemiology
description: Examines the complex relationship between environmental contaminants and human health. Emphasis on environmental epidemiology study design, environmental exposure monitoring and risk assessment, disease and environmental exposure mapping, and spatial data analysis and modeling with GIS. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Promoting Physical Activity
description: Overview of the theoretical and applied study of physical activity epidemiology. Physical activity content includes benefits, factors that influence, levels, valid instruments to assess, and programs to promote physical activity. (Fall only) (

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Health Communication
description: Skills-oriented course introduces the basic structure of health communication strategies in different settings, selected elements of communication theory, the development of health communication material, and a practical training in motivational counseling skills. 623 or consent.

title: Health Promotion Research
description: Focus on research methods commonly used in health promotion. Topics will include randomized trials, quasi-experimental design, sampling, measurement, and correlational studies. Labwork will focus on the use of SPSS to analyze data for applied research problems. A-F only. 623 and 655, or consent.

title: Community-Based Participatory Research
description: Explores ways academic and lay communities collaborate on research, key theoretical perspectives in the development of CBPR, and the challenges in implementing CBPR approaches. Format includes lectures, discussions, readings, writing assignments, and a fieldwork project. A-F only.

title: Systematic Literature Review in Public Health
description: Imparts skills in conducting a systematic review of the literature. Students provided critiques by instructor and classmates on their written and presented work. Intended for doctoral students to complete their qualifying paper. Repeatable one time. PH majors only; doctoral students only. A-F only. consent or PhD in PH or EPID only.
prerequisites: consent or PhD in PH or EPID only

title: Indigenous Applied Research Methods
description: Qualitative research methods design, implementation, and analysis with special focus on methodological, ontological, and ethical issues unique to conducting research with Indigenous communities. PH majors only. A-F only.

title: Survey Methods for Indigenous People
description: Advanced application of health disparities research methodologies to address health and social injustices faced by Indigenous people. Grounded in survey design, implementation, and analyses through a public health and Indigenous lens. PH majors only or consent. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Qualitative Research for Public Health Sciences
description: Provides a basic understanding of qualitative research approaches, methodologies, and techniques and for public health research and practice (needs assessment, program development, and evaluation strategies). Graduate students only.

title: Statistical Methods in Epidemiological Research
description: Multiple variable statistical methods currently used in chronic disease epidemiology. Logistic regression, conditional logistic regression, proportional hazards regression modelling, generalized estimating equation-based methods, delta method approximations, exact tests. 656 and 658 and 664.

title: Chronic Disease Epidemiology
description: Will cover selected topics in chronic diseases with critical analysis of the current epidemiologic literature. Methodologic issues, contemporary findings and recommendations for future research will be discussed. A-F only. 663 or consent.

title: Epidemiology of Diabetes and Obesity
description: Provides an overview of the epidemiology and prevention of metabolic syndrome, diabetes, and associated complications. Discusses methodological issues associated with evaluating these in epidemiologic studies. A-F only. 663 or consent. (

title: Health Behavior Change
description: Provide an understanding of the relationship between health behaviors and outcomes including psychological, physiological, and quality of life aspects. It will also focus on the major theories of behavior and behavior change. Emphasis will be placed on understanding concepts, principles, explanations, and how these are translated into practical interventions for adoption and maintaining behavior change. A-F only. 623 or consent.

title: Social Epidemiology
description: Examine the epidemiologic study of the social distribution and social determinants of states of health, including the identification of social-environmental exposures and their relation to physical and mental health outcomes. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Applied Longitudinal Data Analysis
description: Covers modern methods for longitudinal data analysis. Topics include random effects and growth curve models, generalized linear models for longitudinal data including generalized estimating equations, and generalized linear mixed models. A-F only. 656 and 658, or consent.

title: Survival Analysis
description: Construction and interpretation of various types of life tables, treatment of censored data, proportional hazards, relative risk regression models, and parametric survival analysis. 655 or consent.

title: Neuroepidemiology
description: Lecture/discussion providing an overview of the epidemiology of neurological and neurodegenerative diseases and their risk factors, and methodological considerations for the study of these diseases. 663 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Seminar in Tropical Medicine and Public Health
description: Weekly discussion and reports on current advances in tropical medicine and public health. Repeatable unlimited times. (

title: Special Topics in Tropical Medicine
description: Advanced instruction in frontiers of tropical medicine and public health. Repeatable unlimited times. Repeatable unlimited times. (

title: Evolution, Epidemiology, and Public Health
description: Will explore several aspects of human health through the perspective of how natural selection and evolution influence disease risk, with the aim of improving treatment and prevention. Graduate students only. A-F only. 663 (with a minimum grade of B).
prerequisites: PH 663 (with a minimum grade of B)

title: Health Program Evaluation
description: Examines advanced principles of and frameworks for evaluation. Students integrate utilization-focused evaluation methods to improve service delivery and quality, outcomes and impact to improve community and population health. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Doctoral Seminar in Translational Research
description: Required for students in the PhD PH program. (D) evidence-based public health; (E) health policy and leadership. A-F only. departmental approval.

title: Teaching Practicum
description: Provide doctoral students with theoretical and practical teaching and course development experiences under the guidance of a faculty mentor. Students will have a portfolio documenting their accomplishments. Repeatable unlimited times. Graduate standing in PH only. A-F only. 602 and 623 and 655 and 663 and 681 and 770(Alpha), or departmental approval.
prerequisites: PH 602 and PH 623 and PH 655 and PH 663 and PH 681 and PH 770(Alpha), or departmental approval

title: Research Practicum
description: Hands-on research experience with a faculty mentor. Meet in small groups to discuss issues related to research in public health. Final project will be submission of a publishable quality paper. Graduate standing in PH only. A-F only. 602 and 623 and 655 and 663 and 681 and 770(Alpha), or departmental approval.
prerequisites: PH 602 and PH 623 and PH 655 and PH 663 and PH 681 and PH 770(Alpha), or departmental approval

title: Public Health Proposal and Dissertation Writing
description: Intended for doctoral students to complete and defend their proposals and dissertations. Research and presentation methods will be reviewed, and students will be provided critiques by instructor and classmates on their written and presented work. Repeatable two times. A-F only. consent or PhD in PH or EPID only.
prerequisites: consent or PhD in PH or EPID only

title: Environmental Health Lab Methods
description: Hands-on training for laboratory methods used in monitoring and detecting environmental health risk factors; learning and application of immunological-, animal cell culture- and molecular biology-based techniques for studying environmental pathogens and toxic pollutants. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Seminar in Public Health Sciences
description: Topics related to recent developments in major areas; student and faculty research activities. Sections: (1) biostatistics; (2) environmental health; (3) epidemiology; (4) public health nutrition. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Integrative Seminar
description: Integrative seminar in public health required as part of the student capstone experience to bring together key aspects of their courses, competencies, and practicum. A-F only. completed PH field practicum and consent.
prerequisites: completed PH field practicum and consent

title: Advanced Public Health Practice
description: Observation, study, and supervised practical work in student’s area of specialization. A-F only. public health degree candidate and completion of 15 PH credit hours and consent.
prerequisites: public health degree candidate and completion of PH 15 PH credit hours and consent

title: (Alpha) Current Issues and Topics in Public Health
description: Current and emerging issues and topics related to public health. (B) biostatistics; (D) environmental health; (E) epidemiology; (H) health policy and management; (I) Native Hawaiian and Indigenous Health; (S) social and behavioral health sciences; (U) public health. Repeatable unlimited times. PH majors only for (D) and (I).

title: Special Practicum/Project
description: Supervised practical training beyond the required practicum in an area of particular interest. Provides additional opportunity to synthesize, integrate, and apply practical skills and knowledge in a public health work environment. Repeatable one time. A-F only. completion of practicum and consent.

title: (Alpha) Exploration in Public Health
description: Investigation of emergent fields of inquiry in public health. (B) biostatistics; (D) environmental health; (E) epidemiology; (H) health policy and management; (I) Native Hawaiian and Inigenous health; (S) social and behavioral health sciences; (U) public health. Repeatable unlimited times. PH majors only.

title: Dissertation Research
description: consent.

title: Applied Principles of Environmental & Energy Policy
description: Introduction to the methods and techniques of environmental and energy policy in relation to energy systems. Analysis of enacted policies from case studies to understanding the effectiveness, challenges, contradictions, and limitations of each. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. any 100 or 200 level OCN course, or consent. (
prerequisites: any PPC 100 or PPC 200 level OCN course, or consent

title: Introduction to the World’s Goddesses
description: Cross-cultural analysis of the religious narratives, beliefs, practices, iconography, and sacred sites related to female deities in the Americas, Polynesia, Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and Europe from prehistory to 1500 C.E.

title: Introduction to the World’s Major Religions
description: Buddhism, Christianity, Confucianism, Hinduism, Islam, Judaism, Shinto, Taoism and indigenous traditions of Hawai‘i and/or Oceania.

title: Religion and the Meaning of Existence
description: Basic ideas and issues in contemporary religious thought about the meaning of existence.

title: Religion and Social Justice
description: Religious persons and organizations play significant roles in fighting for issues of social justice worldwide. Introduces students to the relationship between religions and social justice in China, South America, U.S., and Hawai‘i. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Religion and the Environment
description: Examines the roles contemporary religious groups play in ground movements for sustainability. Introduces students to key scholars, religious leaders, and activists who are implementing sustainable solutions to pressing environmental problems. A-F only. (

title: Understanding the Old Testament (Hebrew Bible)
description: Examines the Old Testament (Hebrew Bible) as an expression of the religious life, history, and thought of ancient Israel and as a sacred text within later Judaism and Christianity.

title: Understanding the New Testament
description: Origin and development of early Christian message as set forth in the New Testament; special attention to Jesus and Paul.

title: Understanding Indian Religions
description: Historical survey of the teachings and practices of major religious traditions of India.

title: Understanding Chinese Religions
description: Taoist, Confucian, Buddhist and folk beliefs and practices in their social and historical context. Repeatable one time.

title: Understanding Japanese Religions
description: Broad survey, with primary focus on Shinto, Buddhist, and modern sectarian movements, analyzed in relation to social and cultural themes of major historical periods.

title: Understanding Hawaiian Religion
description: Major teachings and practices from ancient times to present, their cultural influence; analysis of religious texts; relation to other traditions of Oceania and to Christianity.

title: Understanding Buddhism
description: Survey of major forms and practices.

title: Understanding Judaism
description: Survey from origin to modern times with an emphasis on writing-based analysis of Jewish thought in Talmudic and Medieval Periods.

title: Understanding Islam
description: Historical survey of the beliefs and practices of Islam as a world religion, including the prophet Muhammad, scriptures, philosophy and science, theology, law, major sectarian movements, relations with other religious traditions, and fundamentalism. (Alt. years)

title: Understanding Christianity
description: History of ideas concentrating on events, persons, and issues with the greatest impact on the evolution of Christianity.

title: Understanding Ancient Religions
description: Comparative and historical survey of the religious beliefs and practices in ancient times throughout Egypt, Mesopotamia, Syria-Canaan, Anatolia, Persia, Greece, and Rome. A-F only. (

title: Viking Religion
description: Introduction to the Scandinavian religions in the Viking Age, their depiction in popular culture, and reconstruction in the form of new religious movements.

title: Myth, Religion, and Society
description: Theories and methods used in the study of myth, ritual, and religion. Sophomore standing or higher. (

title: Biblical Hebrew I
description: Orthography and structure of Biblical Hebrew, history and development of Hebrew as the sacred language of Judaism, overview of religious and historical development of the Hebrew Bible. sophomore standing or consent. (Fall only) (

title: Biblical Hebrew II
description: Reading of selected prose passages from the Hebrew Bible; essay-based analysis of literary forms, with attention given both to stories important to the development of the Abrahamic religions and writing-based interpretation of religious traditions. REL/CLAS 301 with C- or better. (Spring only) (

title: Creation and Evolution
description: An exploration of interactions between science and religion with a focus on cosmogonies. 150 or consent.

title: Indigenous & Decolonial Approaches to Religion and Culture
description: Introduction to indigenous and decolonial approaches to the study of religion and culture. Includes a critical assessment of tools and terminology traditionally used in academia. Sophomore standing or higher. (

title: Sacred Animals
description: Critical study of the ethical treatment of nonhuman animals and the religious beliefs and practices associated with them throughout history and across various cultures. Emphasis on teaching oral communication.

title: Zen (Ch’an) Buddhist Masters
description: Study of lives, teachings, practices of Zen masters in China, Japan, Korea, and the West. one of 150, 203, 204, 207; or consent.
prerequisites: one of REL 150, REL 203, REL 204, REL 207; or consent

title: Global Christianity
description: Christianity as a transcultural religion, through the study of Christian art, literature, ritual, and theology in diverse cultures; including the Near East, Africa, Latin America, and the Pacific. 150, 201, or 210; or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: REL 150, REL 201, or REL 210; or consent

title: Ka Baibala ‘Ôlelo Hawai‘i (The Bible in Hawaiian)
description: Survey of and selected readings from the Hawaiian Bible (Baibala Hemolele). Conducted in Hawaiian. Repeatable one time. HAW 201.

title: Cults and New Religions
description: Study of cults and new religious movements in America, the Pacific, and East Asia; examining types, causes, and functions of these movements. 150 or consent.

title: Religion and Conflict in American History
description: Analyzes selected historical examples of religious conflicts in America, discerning characteristic patterns of American religious discourse, and identifying the social structures, interests, and ethical principles at stake in conflicts about religion. Sophomore standing or higher. (Fall only) (

title: Religion, Politics, and Society
description: Exploration of the diverse approaches and perspectives that American religious groups embrace in addressing controversial and diverse issues of contemporary American life. Emphasis on considering and discussing ethical approaches and practicing oral communication. DH

title: Christian Ethics in Modern Life
description: The meaning of Christian faith for the moral life with reference to contemporary moral issues. 150 or 151, or consent.

title: Sufism: Mystical Traditions of Islam
description: Introduction to the history, literature, and worldview of Sufism. Students will encounter the following topics in relation to Islamic mysticism: asceticism, monotheism, philosophy, love, union, sainthood, ecstatic experience, and spiritual uses of art. 209 or 383 or PHIL 330 or HIST 354, or consent. (Once a year)
prerequisites: REL 209 or REL 383 or PHIL 330 or HIST 354, or consent

title: Witches and Witchcraft
description: Persecution of witches, witchcraft in Europe, 1300–1700, examined as crisis of church and theology; origins, effects on church and society. one of 201, HIST 151, HIST 152, PSY 100, or consent.
prerequisites: one of REL 201, HIST 151, HIST 152, PSY 100, or consent

title: Islam in History
description: Examination of the historical connections between Islam and other civilizations will focus on the role of Islam in world history. 150 or 209 or consent.

title: Women and Religion
description: Examining roles of, and attitudes toward, women in major religious traditions through autobiographies, films, and primary texts. 149 or WGSS 149 or REL 150 or HIST 151 or WGSS 151. (
prerequisites: REL 149 or WGSS 149 or REL 150 or HIST 151 or WGSS 151

title: Love, Sex, and Religion
description: Love and sex as themes in religions of Asia and the West. 150 or consent.

title: Religion and Art
description: The uses of art in religion are studied with historical examples. 150 or consent.

title: Prophecies of the Last Days
description: In-depth look at ancient Judeo-Christian apocalyptic texts and the communities in which they originated, followed by a survey of the medieval and modern day heirs of apocalyptic traditions. 150 or consent.

title: Vedic Hindu Mythology
description: Study of major Hindu myths of the Vedic Sanskrit literature within the perspective of ancient Indian civilization. Literary sources will be tapped for understanding creation, cosmogony and celestial, atmospheric and terrestrial divinities. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Classical Hindu Mythology
description: Study of major myths of Epic Sanskrit literature, primarily with focus of the Ramayana and Mahabharata. Literary sources will be tapped for appreciating myths and epics, especially with reference to dharma, karma, ways of life. Sophomore standing or consent. (Spring only) (

title: Mysticism East and West
description: Mystic traditions of the West from desert monasticism to Renaissance mystics compared with those of South and East Asia. Focuses on the ethical lives of these mystics, and developing oral communication skills. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Hawaiian Gods
description: The traditions and practices related to one or more major indigenous gods, or class of gods, will be studied by the interpretation and analysis of primary texts. Develops written communication skills. Repeatable one time. 205 or consent.

title: On Death and Dying
description: Aspects of death and dying; relation to our culture and society, to understanding of each other and of ourselves.

title: Directed Reading
description: one 200-level REL course and consent.
prerequisites: one REL 200-level REL course and consent

title: Life and Teachings of Jesus
description: Critical study of synoptic gospels and of extra-Biblical sources. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Anthropology of Magic, Witchcraft, and Religion
description: Cults, legends, millennial movements, myths, possession, rituals, sacred healing, shamanism, sorcery, spirits, symbolism, witchcraft, and other forms of religious and symbolic expression and experience, from small scale to highly urban societies. ANTH 152. (

title: Health/Medicine in Religion
description: Issues of health and disease in the light of religious beliefs and practices with a focus on ethical matters shaping policies in the U.S. and the world. A-F only.

title: Religion and Food
description: Writing-based seminar exploring foodways as a basic component in the practice of religions. Examines theoretical issues, foodways as creators of community and identity, sustainability, and other ethical issues, abstinence and fasting, and healing. 150. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Anthropology of Buddhism
description: Selected aspects of national, regional and local manifestations of Buddhism are explored through the perspective of anthropology with an emphasis on the daily lives of monks, nuns and lay persons in their socio-cultural contexts. 207, 422, 475, or consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Spiritual Ecology
description: Lectures and seminars provide a cross-cultural survey of the relationships between religions, environment and environmentalism. Junior standing or higher. consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Sacred Places
description: Lectures and seminars provide a cross-cultural survey of sites which societies recognize as sacred and their cultural, ecological and conservation aspects. Junior standing or higher. consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Sociology of Religion
description: Seminar on research in sociological aspects of religious sectarianism, historical and current; special reference to Hawai‘i. SOC 300 or consent. (

title: Seminar on Buddhism
description: Selected historical, thematic, and textual research topics in Buddhism; topics and geographical focus to be announced each semester.

title: Daoism: Philosophy and Religion
description: Seminar on religious Taoism, its historical development and its role in the present-day context. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: New World Rituals and Ideologies
description: Study of cross-cultural patterns in ritual behaviors and creolization of African, indigenous, and Iberian ideological frameworks in the Americas. Topics may include syncretic religions (voodoo, candomble), Andean Christianity, spiritual conquest, conceptions of death, etc. Sophomore standing or higher. Minimum C- required grade for LAIS 360, or consent. (Fall only) (

title: Field Methods in Religion
description: Introduction to theoretical and methodological approaches to doing fieldwork in the study of religion. Application of these in studying Hawai‘i’s diverse religious environment. 300 or consent.

title: Buddhism in Japan
description: Major features and trends in thought, institutions, and practices in the context of Japanese history and culture, 6th–20th century. 204 or 207, or consent.

title: Polynesian Religions
description: Introduction to field, comparison of several traditions; beliefs and practices from analysis of texts. Historical interactions with Christianity. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Seminar in Religion
description: Topics -announced each semester. upper division standing or consent. Repeatable one time.

title: Directed Reading or Research
description: Repeatable up to six credits. A-F only. consent of instructor and department chair.
prerequisites: consent of instructor and department chair

title: History and Theory of the Study of Religion
description: Survey of development of history of religions; application of methodologies from anthropology, history, philosophy, political science, psychology, and sociology.

title: Sacred Space
description: Introduces ways that sacred sites are used by religious adherents in Asia and the Pacific. Students will survey different methodologies, and develop a final project on a single sacred site. Graduate students only. Graduate students only. instructor consent. (Alt years)

title: The Study of the Ways Religion is Practiced
description: The study of rituals and practices in the religious traditions of Asia and the Pacific, with a focus on the importance and significance they play in people’s lives. Graduate students only. instructor consent. (Alt. years)

title: The Study of New Religious Movements
description: Seminar exploring methods developed for the study of New Religions, particularly in the U.S., Asia, and the Pacific. Considers implications of these methodologies for studies of other religious traditions. Graduate students only. instructor consent. (Alt. years)

title: Indigenous Religions & Decolonial Theories and Methods
description: Surveys decolonial approaches to the study of religion(s) and focuses on a specific Indigenous religion of Asia and the Pacific to examine the ways that historical paradigms have adversely influenced the study of Indigenous religions.Graduate students only. instructor consent. (Alt. years)

title: Healing in the Religious Traditions of Asia and the Pacific
description: Seminar focused on approaches to healing in the religious traditions of Asia and the Pacific. Explores commonalities between religious traditions, geographical areas, historical periods, and disciplines. Graduate students only. instructor consent. (Alt. years)

title: (Alpha) Seminar on East Asian Religions
description: Selected historical, thematic, and textual research topics in East Asian religions and traditions: (B) Chinese religions; (C) Japanese religions; (D) East Asian Buddhism. Repeatable up to six credits for (D), up to nine credits for (B) and (C). A-F only. 661B or 661C for (D).

title: (Alpha) Seminar on South Asian Religions
description: Selected historical, thematic, and textual research topics in Indian religious traditions: (B) Indian religions; (D) Indian Buddhism. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits for (B). A-F only

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Polynesian Religions
description: Selected historical, thematic, and textual research topics in Polynesian and Hawaiian religious traditions: (B) Polynesian religions; (C) Hawaiian religion. Each alpha repeatable up to nine credits. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Pedagogy in Religion
description: Theory, preparation, and practice in the teaching of religious studies at the community college level: (B) teaching religion; (C) teaching religion practicum. REL majors only. A-F only.650 for (B); 600, 650 and (B) for (C).
prerequisites: REL 650 for (B); REL 600, REL 650 and (B) for (C)

title: Plan B Research
description: Research for master’s degree Plan B. Restricted to students in the Religion Masters Program in Plan B. Enrollment must be approved by student’s project committee. A-F only. consent of committee.

title: Topics in Religious Studies
description: Topics in the study of religion with special emphasis on theoretical approaches and concerns. Specific topics to be preannounced. Repeatable one time. 600 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent of thesis chair.

title: Principles of Zoology
description: Structure, development, physiology, reproduction, evolution, behavior, and ecology of animals.

title: Principles of Zoology Laboratory
description: Laboratory to accompany 101. 101 (or concurrent).

title: Marine Biology
description: Biology and ecology of marine plants and animals; coral reefs, the deep sea, rocky shores, marine mammals, fisheries, aquaculture, pollution, and conservation of marine resources.

title: Marine Biology Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Laboratory, field trips to accompany 200. 200 (or concurrent).

title: Parasitology Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) Laboratory to accompany 340. 340 (or concurrent) and BIOL 275.

title: Directed Study
description: written consent.

title: Developmental Biology
description: Fundamental principles, methods, concepts, and significance of developmental biology, emphasizing experimental methods. BIOL 275. Recommended: BIOL 407.

title: Developmental Biology Lab
description: (2 3-hr Labs) Analysis of animal development by experimental methods, using local organisms. 420 (or concurrent) and BIOL 275, or consent. Recommended: BIOL 407.
prerequisites: ZOOL 420 (or concurrent) and BIOL 275, or consent

title: Animal Physiology
description: Lecture/laboratory introduction to animal physiology, especially vetebrates. Topics include nerve and muscle physiology, metabolism, circulation, respiration, excretion, thermoregulation in a project-driven format. Labs develop skills in experimental biology, morphology, data analysis, and scientific writing. A-F only. BIOL 275.

title: Comparative Physiology
description: Physicalchemical cellular mechanisms underlying function of organ systems; general principles inferable from study of adaption to diverse environments. BIOL 171 and 172, and MBBE 402 (or concurrent) or BIOC 441 (or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: BIOL 171 and BIOL 172, and MBBE 402 (or concurrent) or BIOC 441 (or concurrent); or consent

title: Introduction to Neuroscience
description: Nerve cells, their signaling capabilities and the developmental organization of nervous systems, both invertebrate and vertebrate, for sensory reception, integration, behavioral command and learning;insights from on-going research using molecular, genetic, biophysical, and imaging methods. BIOL 275 or consent. (Spring only)

title: Avian Biology
description: Broad coverage of the morphology, physiology, ecology, behavior, and evolution of birds, emphasizing the relation of birds to general theory in biology. BIOL 265.

title: Biology of the Invertebrates Lab
description: (2 3-hr Lab) BIOL 172 and CHEM 161, or consent. Co-requisite: 475.

title: Biogeography
description: Distribution of plants and animals and processes that cause, maintain, and modify them. Approach is synthetic and dynamic. BIOL 172.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Zoology
description: Reports on research, reviews of literature, or research experience. Required of students majoring in zoology or entomology. (B) general zoology; (D) animal behavior; (E) ecology; (F) physiology; (G) developmental biology; (H) marine biology. Repeatable 2 times per alpha, credits earned for 3 credits only. 306 or equivalent or consent for (D).
prerequisites: ZOOL 306 or equivalent or consent for (D)

title: Animal Behavior
description: Lectures and critical discussions on the mechanisms of animal behavior, social and interspecific behaviors, behavioral ecology, and evolutionary theory. Graduate students only.

title: Principles of Animal Behavior Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Group or individual research projects depending on interest of students. 606 (or concurrent).

title: Genetics of Behavior and Evolution
description: Introduction to concepts and techniques in the genetics of behavior. Techniques include next gen sequencing, GWAS, and more. Students may use real data to analyze associations between genotype and phenotype. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. (Fall only)

title: Fish Behavior and Sensory Biology
description: Lectures, readings and presentations on sensory systems and behavior of fishes. A-F only. 430, 606, BIOL 306, BIOL 465; or consent. Co-requisite: 608L. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: ZOOL 430, ZOOL 606, BIOL 306, BIOL 465; or consent

title: Fish Behavior and Sensory Biology Laboratory
description: Laboratory study of fish sensory systems and behavior. A-F only. 430, 606, BIOL 306, BIOL 465; or consent. Co-requisite: 608. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: ZOOL 430, ZOOL 606, BIOL 306, BIOL 465; or consent

title: Topics in Development and Reproductive Biology
description: Discussion and survey of literature on specific topics; some field and lab work may be required. Repeatable three times.

title: Seminar on Science Teaching
description: Effective teaching methods, organization of courses, lectures, laboratory exercises; development and evaluation of examinations; computers and audiovisual aids. Open to graduate students in various science disciplines. Repeatable one time. (

title: Marine Ecology
description: Principles of ecology of marine biota and environment. graduate standing in zoology, oceanography, or botany; or consent.
prerequisites: graduate standing in zoology, oceanography, or botany; or consent

title: Quantitative Field Ecology
description: (1 Lec, 1 2-hr Lab, 1 Discussion) Formal quantitative approach in identifying, designing, performing, analyzing, and interpreting ecological field problems. A-F only. 439, 439L, and 631; or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: ZOOL 439, ZOOL 439L, and ZOOL 631; or consent

title: Evolution in Marine Systems
description: Fundamental elements of modern evolutionary theory and research, with a strong focus on marine organisms and ecosystems. A-F only. instructor approval. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Introduction to Statistical Modeling in Biology
description: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Discussion) Statisticalmethods for biological research. Covers: probability; likelihood-based inference; hypothesis testing; linear and generalized linear models; common statistical tests; statistical programming. MATH 215 or 216 or 241 or 251A or NREM 203 (or equivalent), or consent.
prerequisites: MATH 215 or MATH 216 or MATH 241 or MATH 251A or NREM 203 (or equivalent), or consent

title: Advanced Biometry
description: (3 Lec, 1 2-hr Discussion) Multivariate statistical methods: multiple regression and correlation; multiway anova; general linear models; repeated measures and multivariate anova; loglinear analysis and logistic regression. 631 or consent.

title: Cellular Neurophysiology
description: Biophysical and membrane mechanisms of conduction, synaptic transmission, and other electrical responses of nerve cells. consent. (Alt years: spring)

title: Population Biology
description: Theory and applications of population biology; behavior of population models, as revealed by analytical methods and computer simulation; application to population problems such as endangered species; discussion of classical and current literature in population biology. one of the following: 620, 623, BOT 456, NREM 680, PEPS 671; or consent. (
prerequisites: one of the following: ZOOL 620, ZOOL 623, BOT 456, NREM 680, PEPS 671; or consent

title: Scientific Teaching Tools to Promote Active Learning
description: Graduate level course to train students in the pedagogical tools to enhance active learning in STEM classes. Includes discussions of the primary literature, demonstrations and practice using scientific teaching techniques. BOT or ZOOL or MBIO majors only. Graduate students only. (Alt. years: spring) (

title: Conservation Biology
description: Theories and concepts of ecology, evolution and genetics for conservation of biological diversity. Topics will include restoration ecology, management planning, laws and policies, biological invasions. (

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Zoology
description: Reports on research or reviews of literature. Graduate students required to take this or one topics course (710–719) per year. (B) general zoology; (C) zoology literature; (D) animal behavior; (E) ecology; (F) animal physiology; (G) development biology; (H) marine biology; (I) systematics and evolution. Each alpha is repeatable five times.

title: Directed Research
description: Directed research and reading in various fields of zoology. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Topics in Biometry
description: Selected advanced topics in experimental design or data analysis for biologists. Repeatable unlimited times. ZOOL majors only. 631 and 632, or consent.

title: Topics in Nerve/Muscle Physiology
description: Advanced treatment of selected topics under current active investigation. Repeatable unlimited times. ZOOL majors only. a graduate course in physiology, neurology, or related subjects and consent.
prerequisites: a graduate course in physiology, neurology, or related subjects and consent

title: Topics in Animal Behavior
description: Lecturediscussion of selected topics. Repeatable three times, up to nine credits. ZOOL majors only. consent.

title: Topics in Invertebrate Zoology
description: Comparative morphology, development, taxonomy, phylogeny. Repeatable three times, up to nine credits.

title: Topics in Fish and Fisheries Biology
description: Lecture-discussion of various aspects. Repeatable up to nine credits. ZOOL majors only.

title: Topics in Animal Physiology
description: Selected problems in environmental physiology, electro-physiology, or neurophysiology. Basic concepts and measurements of function at the organismic or cellular level. Repeatable three times, up to nine credits.

title: Topics in Systematics and Evolution
description: Selected problems of current or historic interest. Repeatable three times, up to nine credits. consent

title: Topics in Ecology
description: Advanced topics in ecology; discussion of literature and in depth survey of specific areas. Repeatable three times up to nine credits. Graduate students only. instructor consent.

title: Topics in Conservation Biology
description: Advanced topics in conservation and environmental biology. Repeatable three times, up to twelve credits. A-F only. consent. (

title: Foundations of Evolution and Ecology I
description: Graduate level introduction to evolution and ecology emphasizing foundational literature, modern models and inference, and major questions in evolution and ecology. Topics include population ecology, community ecology, the genetics of populations, systematics, and speciation. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Foundations of Evolution and Ecology II
description: Graduate level introduction to evolution and ecology emphasizing foundational literature, modern models and inference, and major questions in evolution and ecology. This is the second semester continuation of 780. (Alt. years: spring)

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: (Alpha) Introduction to Teaching, Elementary
description: Standards-based planning, assessment, instruction, reflection; inclusive classroom management; unique multicultural environment; issues in education and curriculum. Developing knowledgeable, effective, caring professionals to support student’s academic, social, emotional, physical needs. Emphasis on writing instruction; lecture/lab; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Principles and Methods of Reading Instruction
description: First of two methods courses focusing on theories and research-based practices related to reading instruction in elementary classrooms. Emphasis on writing instruction; lecture/lab; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Principles and Methods of Writing Instruction
description: Second of two methods courses focusing on theories and research-based practices related to writing instruction in elementary classrooms. Emphasis on writing instruction; lecture/lab; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.

title: Field Training – Blended ECE
description: Students spend 15 hours per week in settings appropriate to concurrently enrolled classes; supervision provided by participating teacher and college supervisor. Repeatable two times. A-F only. (

title: Field Experience
description: Supervised field experience in schools. Minimum of 8 hours per week in conjunction with professional education courses. Repeatable two times, up to three credits. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Field Experience
description: Supervised field experience in schools. Minimum of 2 full days per week in classrooms, plus mandatory seminar scheduled by UH Mānoa field supervisor. Taken in conjunction with professional education courses; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. Repeatable two times or up to 9 credits per alpha. CR/NC only.

title: Child Development from Prenatal Through Age Eight
description: Growth and development of children from prenatal through age eight. Historical and current issues through a research-based ecological, cross-cultural perspective. Focus on children’s optimal development and how this informs teaching practices in early education. A-F only.

title: Children’s Literature
description: Acquaintance with wide range of children’s books; criteria for evaluation of literature; using literature in the classroom.

title: Instructional and Assessment Methods for Multilingual Learners
description: Introduction to language use and development as it relates to multilingual learners (MLL). Candidates analyze and apply strategies to create inclusive and collaborative classrooms for learners at various levels of English language development. A-F only.

title: Social Studies and Science in Early Childhood Education
description: Assessment, instructional methods, and materials for teaching social studies and science to children in preschool through grade 3. Emphasis on developmentally appropriate practices and lesson planning for teaching social studies and science. A-F only. 417, and 315 (or concurrent) or SPED 315 (or concurrent). (Alt. years: spring)
prerequisites: STE 417, and STE 315 (or concurrent) or SPED 315 (or concurrent)

title: (Alpha) Social Studies, Elementary
description: Purposes, methods, curriculum, and assessment in teaching social studies. Focus: enriching children’s understanding of the communities of which they are a part through inquiry, investigation, collaboration, and expository skills. Emphasis on writing instruction; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Science, Elementary
description: Science education in elementary school; methods and materials; laboratory activities selected from new science curricula; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. Each alpha repeatable one time, up to 3 credits. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Mathematics, Elementary
description: Inquiry-based approach to concepts and algorithms of whole numbers and introduction to geometry/ measurement. Laboratory experiences with appropriate manipulatives; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only. MATH 111 and MATH 112.

title: (Alpha) Mathematics, Elementary II
description: Inquiry-based approach to concepts and algorithms of fractions, decimals, graphing, and probability and statistics. Laboratory experiences with appropriate manipulatives; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only. 324B or consent for (B); 324C or consent for (C).
prerequisites: STE 324B or consent for (B); STE 324C or consent for (C)

title: (Alpha) Visual Art, Elementary
description: Scope and organization of art in pK-6 school curriculum, creative use of art media through laboratory experience; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.

title: Curriculum, Materials, and Assessment Development for Multilingual Learners
description: Introduction to the development of curriculum materials, and assessments for diverse and multilingual learners. Teacher candidates will develop their ability to organize, develop, and assess learning around standards-based subject matter and language learning objectives. A-F only.

title: Responsive Pedagogy for Multilingual Learners
description: Introduction to the teaching of multilingual learners (MLL) in an elementary school context. Teacher candidates will learn specific strategies and methods for teaching non-native speakers of English. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Performing Arts Expression, K-6
description: Standards-based teaching, with, in, through, and about music, dance, and drama. Developing verbal and non-verbal communication skills through creative expression with an emphasis on planning, teaching, and assessing preK-6 lessons that integrate the performing arts; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Personal and Social K-6 Health Skills
description: Standards-based planning, teaching, assessment in health education. Developing interactive learning opportunities to teach personal and social responsibility for health through curriculum integration. Training, practice and evaluation of oral communication skills; (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary education. A-F only.

title: Methods of Instruction, Industrial/ Agricultural Education
description: Techniques of individual and group instruction in laboratory and related classes, evaluation of various methods.

title: Management of Industrial/Agricultural Facilities
description: Organization of instruction; handling supplies; maintaining equipment and tools; purchasing materials; keeping records; making inventories.

title: Teaching Business and Office Education
description: Theory and methods of teaching business and office education courses. ACC 201 and either ACC 200 or ACC 202.
prerequisites: ACC 201 and either ACC 200 or ACC 202

title: Teaching Marketing and Distribution
description: Theory and methods of teaching marketing and distribution courses. MKT 341 or MKT 351.

title: Music in the Elementary School
description: Goals, concepts, literature, materials, procedures, and evaluation for teaching music in grades K–6. For students in elementary education. Not intended for elementary music majors.

title: Multicultural Perspectives in Education
description: Concepts and methods to develop sensitivity and awareness of cultural influences on behaviors related to schooling. Examines intersections of Native Hawaiian culture with Asian and/or Pacific Islanders fostering multicultural respect and understanding through cross-cultural analysis. A-F only. DS

title: Home Economics Education
description: Curriculum design. Current educational philosophies and practices in home economics education. Teaching materials and techniques.

title: Managing Classrooms
description: Analysis of the factors that contribute to learning in the classroom and the development of teacher behaviors that promote such learning. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Student Teaching
description: Full-time supervised experience in school. (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary; (D) secondary; (M) dual preparation in elementary education and multilingual learning; (S) dual preparation in elementary and special education. CR/NC only. completion of all other program requirements, passing Praxis II exam(s). Co-requisite for D: 391D.
prerequisites: completion of all other program requirements, passing Praxis II exam(s)

title: (Alpha) Seminar for Student Teaching
description: With student teaching as context, examination of knowledge, skills, and dispositions for teaching; standards-based planning, teaching, assessment, and reflection; inclusive classroom management; professional growth and development; integration of research, theory, and practice. Emphasis on writing instruction and ethical issues in teaching. (B) dual preparation in ECE and elementary education; (C) elementary (2); (D) secondary; (M) dual preparation in elementary education and multilingual learning (2); (S) dual preparation in elementary and special education (1). Repeatable nine times for (D). CR/NC only.

title: (Alpha) Student Teaching Modified
description: Modified student teaching for individuals who have had prior extensive teaching experience or wish to repeat student teaching. CR/NC only. (C) elementary; (D) secondary. extensive teaching experience; requirements listed under “student teaching”; approval of review committee; consent. Co-requisite: 391.
prerequisites: extensive teaching experience; requirements listed under “student teaching”; approval of review committee; consent

title: Directed Study
description: Individual work supervised by instructor. May consist of reading, research, observation/participation, teaching, and/or projects. Repeatable up to 12 credits. consent of instructor.

title: Principles & Methods of Literacies Within and Across the Disciplines (6-12)
description: Examines different literacy strategies for learning content that will engage diverse adolescents across and within all disciplines. Includes a disciplinary literacies framework that influences lesson planning, classroom culture, and assessment practices. Emphasis on teaching writing. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: (Alpha) Teaching Practicum
description: Observation, analysis, participation and teaching in middle or high school. A seminar accompanies the field experience. Subject field: (B) visual and performing arts; (C) business and marketing; (D) language arts; (E) physical education; (F) industrial arts/agriculture; (G) mathematics; (H) science; (I) social studies; (J) foreign language; (K) music; (M) home economics; (N) interdisciplinary; (O) elementary; (P) English as a Second Language. Repeatable two times. CR/NC only. admission to COE Teacher Education Program and departmental consent.
prerequisites: admission to COE Teacher Education Program and departmental consent

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Educational Inquiry
description: Study and discussion of general school-related topics and issues, e.g., dimensions of elementary and/ or secondary schooling, school governance, curriculum design and development, the student learner, classroom management; (B) service learning; (C) exploratory education; (D) international field study; (E) minor in education. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Teaching in the Subject Field
description: Purposes, procedures, curricula, evaluation in elementary or secondary school subject field. Develops written communication skills: (B) visual and performing art; (C) business and marketing; (D) language arts; (E) physical education; (F) industrial arts/agriculture; (G) mathematics; (H) science; (I) social studies; (J) foreign languages; (K) music; (M) home economics; (N) interdisciplinary; (P) English as a Second Language. Repeatable five times for different alphas. A-F only. 401 or consent. Co-requisite: 402.

title: (Alpha) Teaching Residency
description: Full-time student teaching experience in school. Student teachers will receive training and evaluation for oral communication, organization, and planning skills. Subject field: (B) visual and performing arts; (C) business and marketing; (D) language arts; (F) industrial arts; (G) mathematics; (H) science; (l) social studies; (J) foreign languages; (K) music; (M) home economics; (O) elementary education; (P) English as a second language. CR/NC only. successful completion of all required courses; departmental consent.
prerequisites: successful completion of all required courses; departmental consent

title: Seminar in Teaching Residency
description: Analysis and resolution of current ethical issues and practices in classrooms; teaching skills and strategies; curriculum planning, professional growth and development; and integration of teaching experiences with professional standards. Instruction in preparing an extensive written portfolio. A-F only. successful completion of all required courses or consent. Co-requisite: 405(B, C, D, F, G, H, I, J, K, M, O, or P)
prerequisites: successful completion of all required courses or consent

title: Supervision of the Observation-Participation Student
description: Basic guidelines for developing effective team relationships between the professional teacher and the observation-participation student. two years’ teaching experience and consent.
prerequisites: two years’ teaching experience and consent

title: Observation and Assessment in Early Childhood Education
description: Introduction to the purposes, theories, and methods of early childhood assessment. Emphasizes observation, documentation, and assessment to provide evidence of children’s development and learning and how to use assessment to guide teaching and learning. 318 or consent. Corequisite: 415L.

title: Observation and Assessment in Early Childhood Education Lab
description: Field experience in early childhood settings to facilitate young children’s growth and learning. CR/NC only.

title: Teaching and Learning for Diverse Young Children
description: Continuation of 415: focuses on the design, implementation, evaluation of meaningful, challenging integrated curriculum that promotes comprehensive developmental and learning outcomes for diverse young children (pK-3). 415 or consent. (

title: Teaching and Learning for Diverse Young Children Lab
description: Continuation of 415L. CR/ NC only. Co-requisite: 416. (

title: Foundations of Early Childhood Education, Ages 3–8
description: Planning child-centered, responsive programs for children. Focuses on play, learning environments, integrated thematic instructional design, guidance, assessment, and family engagement in early childhood and early elementary to promote enjoyment, growth, and development. A-F only. 318.

title: Supervision of Student Teaching
description: Principles and methods; role of supervisor; human resources supervision in student teaching. Open to teachers interested in -service teacher education. three years teaching experience and consent.

title: Family and Community Centered Programs
description: Knowledge and appreciation for the complex characteristics of children, families, and communities. Analysis and development of skills for creating respectful, reciprocal relationships with diverse children and families from diverse backgrounds. Lecture/lab. 318 (or concurrent), or HDFS 331 (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: STE 318 (or concurrent), or HDFS 331 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Advanced Supervision of Student Teaching
description: Advanced principles and methods: clinical supervision, observation recording, analysis, interpretation of classroom teaching; human resources supervision in student teaching. 420, successful supervision of two or more student teachers, and consent.
prerequisites: STE 420, successful supervision of two or more student teachers, and consent

title: Cooperative Vocational Education
description: Planned work-experience program for special areas of vocational technical education. Acceptable type of wage-earning employment. Minimum of six 40- hour weeks or 240 work hours required. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Foundations of Vocational Education
description: Historical and philosophical foundations of vocational technical education, overview of federal and state legislation and contemporary practices. Special emphasis on vocational education program in Hawai‘i.

title: Office and Marketing Technology
description: Understanding and use of word processing, spreadsheet, and database software for business applications. Explore software across the office and marketing content areas.

title: Multicultural and Social Justice Education
description: Exploring social justice and multilingual, multicultural education with attention to Hawai‘i as our place of learning and teaching. (

title: Hawaiian Studies, Methods
description: Examination of issues in Hawaiian and U.S. views of education and their application to the teaching of Hawaiian studies. Field experience required. A-F only. 312C, 312D; or consent. Co-requisite for BEd students: 317.

title: Education of Exceptional Children in Regular Classroom
description: Practices that facilitate teaching special needs students in regular classrooms. Techniques for meeting academic needs, managing behavior, motivating students, increasing peer interactions, communication between special and regular educators. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing.

title: Educating Exceptional Students in Regular Classrooms, Secondary
description: Teaching secondary students with disabilities and those who are gifted/talented. Meeting academic/social needs, classroom management, motivation, peer interaction, collaboration between special and regular educators. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing.

title: Issues in Computer Education
description: Integration of microcomputers into school curriculum and key issues related to microcomputer use in education. LTEC 442 or consent. (

title: Directed Activity
description: Individual work supervised by instructor. May consist of reading, research, teaching, and/or projects. consent of division director.

title: Newspaper in the Classroom
description: STE 550 Newspaper in the Classroom (2) | 2024-2025 General Catalog Skip to Main Content UHM Home A-Z Index Directory Students Faculty and Staff Parents Alumni MyUH University of Hawai‘i ® at Mānoa 2024-2025 General Catalog Menu Open Mobile Menu Search Search this site Site search About About UH President and Provost Message Campus Map Student Life Campus Policies and Information Personnel Calendar Courses Course Overview Sample Course Description Diversification Courses General Education Designations Course Numbering System Undergraduate Undergraduate Education Programs Undergraduate General Education Requirements Tuition, Fees, and Financial Aid Graduate Graduate Division Graduate Programs Tuition, Fees, and Financial Aid Degrees, Minors & Certificates Colleges, Schools & Academic Units Home Courses STE 550 Newspaper in the Classroom (2) STE 550 Newspaper in the Classroom (2) College of Education , School of Teacher Education (STE) ← STE 499 Directed Activity (V) STE 572 Common Core State Standards in ELA: Content and Curriculum for Teachers (V) → 2024-2025 General Catalog Mānoa Catalog Office 2500 Campus Road, Hawaii Hall 121 Please note: This Catalog was prepared to provide information and does not constitute a contract. title: Common Core State Standards in ELA: Content and Curriculum for Teachers
description: Professional development for K-12 teachers to upgrade their knowledge of ELA content and develop their instructional strategies to be consistent with the ELA practices of the Common Core State Standards. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.

title: Common Core State Standards in Mathematics: Content and Curriculum for Teachers
description: Professional development for K-12 teachers to upgrade their knowledge of mathematics content and develop their instructional strategies to be consistent with the mathematical practices of the Common Core State Standards. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only.

title: (Alpha) Practicum in Curriculum Development: Natural Science
description: For in-service teachers to upgrade subject matter and develop teaching methods and materials for instruction. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. teaching experience.

title: (Alpha) Practicum in Curriculum Development: Natural Science
description: For in-service teachers to upgrade subject matter and develop teaching methods and materials for instruction. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. teaching experience.

title: Master of Education in Teaching Program Seminar
description: Mandatory program seminar for Master of Education in Teaching (MEdT) teacher candidates; access to tools and skills necessary for distance education program success, introduction to the teaching profession. CR/NC only. admission into the MEdT program, or consent.
prerequisites: admission into the MEdT program, or consent

title: (Alpha) Professional Studies I
description: Development of theoretical and practical knowledge base and skills for understanding, analyzing, and responding to teaching issues and problems. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Clinical Partnership and Practice I
description: Supervised field study of a school. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to 12 credits. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Professional Studies II
description: Development of pedagogical skills in planning and implementing instruction for target subject area/grade level. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Clinical Partnership and Practice II
description: Team collaboration on responding to identified school need; supervised experience in mini-teaching. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to 12 credits. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Clinical Partnership and Practice III
description: Supervised experience in instructional planning and practice teaching. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Professional Studies III
description: Planning and methods seminar in conjunction with practice teaching. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Clinical Partnership and Practice IV
description: Full-time supervised teaching experience. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Professional Studies IV
description: Collaborative problem solving of issues and concerns encountered in current teaching experiences. (B) licensure; (C) non-licensure. Each alpha is repeatable one time, up to six credits. A-F only.

title: Directed Reading and/or Research
description: Individual reading and/or research. Repeatable unlimited times. A-F only. written consent.

title: International Exchange Programs
description: UH Mānoa School of Travel Industry Management majors participating in approved international exchange programs. CR/NC only.

title: Internship I
description: Introduction to travel industry. Discussion of job search strategies, TIM internship requirements, career and academic planning. CR/NC only.

title: Introduction to Travel Industry Management
description: Overview of travel industry and related major business components. Analysis of links between hotel, food, transportation, recreation, and other industries comprising tourism.

title: Food and World Cultures
description: An integrated cross-cultural approach to the study of foods and cultures. Examine history, concepts, principles of cultures and cuisines, the background of food tradition including habitat, social status, religious beliefs, gender, and other environmental considerations. A-F only.

title: Internship II
description: A minimum of four hundred hours of travel industry experience. Comprehensive report by student and performance evaluation from employer required. CR/NC only. TIM major, 100, and 101.

title: Internship III
description: A minimum of four hundred hours of travel industry experience. Position must be different from TIM 200 position and of a more responsible nature or in a different organization. Comprehensive report by student and performance evaluation from employer required. CR/NC only. TIM major and 200.

title: Legal Environment of the Travel Industry
description: Origin, development, and principles of common, statutory, constitutional, international, and maritime law relating to hospitality industry. TIM majors only. 101. Recommended: BLAW 200.

title: Information Systems Technology
description: Computer applications in the travel industry; operation and evaluation of specific travel industry systems and applied business systems. TIM majors only. 101; and either ICS 101, or both LTEC 112 and LTEC 113
prerequisites: TIM 101; and either ICS 101, or both LTEC 112 and LTEC 113

title: Management of Service Enterprises
description: Principles and philosophies of management with special emphasis on those principles and theories that are most relevant to management in service-based industries. Students may not earn credit for 303 and BUS 315. TIM majors only. 101 or consent.

title: Principles of Travel Industry Marketing
description: Concepts, problems, processes of marketing within the travel industry; development of marketing strategies including product, place, promotion, and price for travel institutions. Students may not earn credit for 304 and BUS 312. TIM majors only. 101.

title: Financial Management for the Travel Industry
description: Cash flow determination and management strategies for financing hospitality ventures and expansion. Determining the financial viability of proposed and existing operations through traditional and state-of-the-art techniques. TIM majors only. 101, ACC 200 and ACC 210; and NREM 203, MATH 203, MATH 215, MATH 241, or BUS 250.
prerequisites: TIM 101, ACC 200 and ACC 210; and NREM 203, MATH 203, MATH 215, MATH 241, or BUS 250

title: Human Resource Management: Travel Industry
description: Comprehensive overview of human resources management (HRM) with emphasis on the supervision in the travel industry, including HRM as a firm’s strategic asset, contemporary theories, issues and developments, to improve employee recruitment productivity and retention. TIM majors only. 101.

title: Institutional Purchasing
description: Procurement responsibilities in hospitality management. Emphasis on institutions supplying hospitality operations and legislation which controls standards of industrial supplies and goods. TIM and FSHN majors only. 101.

title: Club Management
description: Introduction to club and institutional management, including operations, services, and facilities. TIM majors only. A-F only. 101.

title: Foodservice Management
description: Critical and essential aspects of managing foodservice operations including principles of food safety and sanitation, procedural knowledge in front and back of the house and guest relations. TIM majors only. A-F only. 101 and 303.

title: Hotel Management
description: Comprehensive understanding of hotel management and functional departments including front office, accounting, housekeeping, food and beverage, marketing, security and safety. Simulation of management trainee programs by hotel chains. Synthesis of concepts, tools and theories of decision-making relevant to hotel operations. TIM majors only. A-F only. 101, 302, and 303 (with a minimum grade of C- in 302 and 303).
prerequisites: TIM 101, TIM 302, and TIM 303 (with a minimum grade of C- in TIM 302 and TIM 303)

title: Quality Food Management
description: Explore various aspects of the quality in foodservice operations and develop strategies to measure and improve the quality. A-F only. 101 and departmental approval.

title: Events Planning and Marketing
description: Introduction to special event planning processes and techniques. Emphasis on designing, planning, marketing, management, staging events, legal compliances, risk management, financial control, and successful event evaluation. TIM majors only. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. 313.

title: Quantity Foods and Institutional Purchasing
description: Quantity food and beverage operations, menu development and costing, dietary menu claims, purchasing procedures, inventory control, procurement, transportation, legislation. Institutional foodservice sanitation, Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point and National Restaurant Association Certification. TIM majors only. 101.

title: Introduction to Tourism Economics
description: Examines tourism from an economic perspective. Topics include: the determinants of consumer demand for leisure travel, structure of competition among suppliers of tourism services, benefits and costs of tourism development to the host community, government’s role in the taxation, subsidy, regulation and protection of the tourism industry, tourism’s impact on the environment, and sustainable tourism development. TIM majors only. ECON 120 or 130 or 131; or consent. (
prerequisites: ECON 120 or ECON 130 or ECON 131; or consent

title: Sociocultural Issues in Tourism
description: Issues arising from the impacts of tourism on societies and cultures. Class discussions of the ethical dimensions of such impacts. Includes an emphasis on writing instruction. TIM majors only. 101.

title: Geography of Global Tourism
description: Tourist landscape in relation to resources, spatial patterns of supply and demand, impacts of tourism development, and models of tourist space. Flows between major world regions. Sophomore standing or higher. consent. (

title: Travel Distribution Management
description: History, development, operations, and management of travel distribution organizations including: travel agents, tour operators and wholesalers, specialty channelers, meeting planners, incentive houses, travel associations, and other destination management organizations. Evolution and economics of the distribution of travel products through destination databases and electronic commerce. TIM majors only. 302.

title: Hotel/Resort Facilities and Design
description: Comprehensive understanding of facilities management and design including maintenance systems, sustainable development options and design and environmental management. TIM majors only. A-F only. 313 and 314.

title: Hospitality Sales & Negotiation
description: Personal selling by hospitality and tourism firms engaged in business-to-business marketing. Emphasis will be placed on negotiation case studies, exercises, and role-plays. TIM majors only. A-F only. 101. Recommended: 304.

title: Introduction to Tourism Transportation
description: Introduction to managerial and operational issues related to all modes of transportation used by tourists into or within a tourist destination. Passenger behavior; transport infrastructure; transport networks; regulation; sustainable transport. TIM majors only. 101.

title: Principles of Logistics
description: Management of logistics systems: inventory control, warehousing, materials management, physical distribution, transportation. Emphasis on Hawai‘i’s location and unique problems. TIM majors only. 101.

title: Air Transportation Management
description: Marketing, management and strategies used by airlines, airports, catering, and aircraft manufacturers. TIM majors only. 101.

title: Surface Transportation Management
description: Management of surface transportation such as cars, buses, and intercity rail, etc. Includes marketing, ownership and financing, supply chain, operations, regulation and promotion, human resources. TIM majors only. 101.

title: Economics in Travel Industry
description: Microeconomic theory of consumer behavior and demand production cost analysis, market structure and pricing in travel companies. Economic impact of tourism. Students may not earn credit for 365 and BUS 313. TIM majors only. either ECON 120 or ECON 130.

title: TIM Study Abroad
description: Study abroad instructional experience emphasizing international travel, tourism and hospitality-related topics at equivalent, accredited programs. Content varies depending on locus of instruction and instructor. Course qualifies as either a TIM or general elective with -approval or department. Repeatable unlimited times. TIM majors only. consent.

title: (Alpha) Current Topics in Travel Industry Management
description: (B) resort development; (C) assets management; (D) transportation and public policy; (E) management by cultural values; (F) travel industry management; (G) hospitality management; (H) hotel management; (I) restaurant entrepreneurship; (J) tourism management; (K) recreation management; (M) leisure management; (N) transportation management; (O) travel industry management education; (P) travel industry management technology; (Q) meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibition management. Repeatable five times with consent. TIM majors only for (B), (C), (D), (E), (F), (G), (H), (I), (J), (K), (M), (N). 101 and 313 for (I).

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Reading and research into problems in hotel, restaurant, transportation or tourism sectors of the travel industry. junior standing or above, a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.5 and consent of dean’s office and instructor based upon student’s written proposal of content and objectives of course program. TIM majors only.
prerequisites: junior standing or above, a minimum cumulative GPA of TIM 2

title: (Alpha) Internship IV
description: Requires a minimum of 150 hours of internship, a business presentation, and an analytical report synthesizing experience and related theories. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction, which will enhance and improve students’ writing skills. (B) executive internship; (C) community service internship. Restricted to majors. CR/NC only. 200 and consent.

title: Resort, Spa and Wellness Management
description: Principles of resort and spa development. Essential aspects of understanding the leadership and interrelationships of managing/operating and marketing resorts, spas, and wellness. A-F only. 314. Recommended: 305.

title: Resort Mixed Use Development
description: Critical and essential aspects of developing and managing resort mixed use facilities. Includes multidimensional and dynamic interrelationships of site development and facilities, business mix, management structures and systems, and industry practices. A-F only. 313 or 369; and 314. Recommended: 333 and 401. (Fall only)

title: Revenue Management in Travel Industry
description: An in-depth comprehensive introduction to the theory and practice of revenue management and provides recognition of thorough knowledge of the fundamental metrics and methodologies used within the hotel industry. TIM majors only. 101, ECON 130, and ACC 210.

title: Nature-Based Tourism Management
description: Principles of nature-based tourism, including a survey of impacts, objectives, planning, and management systems. Junior standing or higher. 101 or 324/ GEO 324. (

title: Sustainable Tourism Policies and Practices
description: Seminar examining the social, environmental, economic factors of sustainable tourism development. Emphasis on methods and processes and the role of stakeholders (government, industry, host community, tourists). Group projects. A-F only. 101 and departmental approval. (

title: Destination Development and Marketing
description: Analysis of key factors in the marketing and management of tourism destinations, including destination branding, product development, integrated marketing, stakeholder relations, and the role of destination marketing/marketing organizations. Emphasis on written communication. 101.

title: Strategic Management for the Travel/ Hospitality Industry
description: Strategic management in the travel/hospitality industry. Case study analysis, discussion and written reports, covering strategies, management problems and industry issues. Emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only. 301, 302, 303, 304, 305 and graduating senior.
prerequisites: TIM 301, TIM 302, TIM 303, TIM 304, TIM 305 and graduating senior

title: Advanced Topics in Transportation
description: Advanced level of discussion in terms of transportation, including management, economics, strategy, regulation, operating performance, fleet management, and network management. 101. Recommended: 350 and/or 353.

title: Environmental Management Systems
description: Introduction to the process of developing Environmental Management Systems that address the principles outlined in ISO14001:2015. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: (Alpha) Advanced Topics in Travel Industry Management
