description: (B) tourism planning; (C) advanced travel industry management; (D) advanced hospitality management; (E) advanced hotel management; (F) advanced restaurant management; (G) advanced tourism management; (H) advanced recreation management; (I) advanced leisure management; (J) advanced transportation management; (K) advanced travel industry management education; (M) advanced travel industry management technology; (N) advanced meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibition management; (O) advanced food and beverage management; (P) leadership and advanced human resources; (Q) advanced assets management. Repeatable five times with consent for (B), (C), (D), (E), (F), (G), (H), (I), (J), (K), (M), (N); repeatable six times for (O), (P), and (Q). TIM majors only. A-F only for (O), (P), and (Q).

title: Research Application in Hospitality, Tourism, and Transportation
description: Analysis of methodologies appropriate for research in travel industry management. Survey of the literature of applied techniques and approaches including exploratory approaches. Familiarization with research design and implementation of development of research proposals. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Strategic Marketing in Hospitality, Tourism, and Transportation
description: In-depth study of marketing principles and problems related to travel industry organizations. Emphasis on strategic marketing. Research applications, international and domestic marketing of travel industry services. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Information Technology, e-Commerce, and Travel Industry in Hospitality, Tourism, and Transportation
description: Planning, implementation, management, evaluation, and impact of information and electronic communication technologies, including e-commerce applications in the travel industry. Analysis of new information technology use as an area of research and strategic application. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Managerial Accounting for Travel Industry
description: Advanced study of management accounting within travel industry: responsibility accounting, pricing decisions, concepts and application of central systems, financial planning, price level impacts, performance evaluation. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Hospitality Management
description: Advanced human relations and operating issues; use of accounting, behavioral, financial, marketing, and informational systems in managing hospitality organizations. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Managerial Economics in Hospitality, Tourism, and Transportation
description: Advanced study analysis of economics and management of passenger transportation systems serving the travel industry. Emphasis on topics such as government policy, transport economics, marketing and management, and the relationships between transportation systems and tourism development. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Global Tourism Analysis
description: International trade theory and regional analysis methodologies applied to tourism and the service industry, including travel balance account, inter-regional transactions flow, economic impacts, environmental economics, demand theory and forecasting. A-F only. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Financial Management in Hospitality, Tourism, and Transportation
description: Applications of financial analysis to both the domestic and international travel industry. TIM majors only. A-F only. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Hospitality, Tourism, and Transportation Field Studies
description: Integration of concepts and application of knowledge and skills from other courses to a selected field study project. any two 600-level TIM courses completed and a third concurrent; or consent.
prerequisites: any two TIM 600-level TIM courses completed and a third concurrent; or consent

title: Professional Paper
description: Independent project or paper under faculty supervision in lieu of Plan A, TIM 700 thesis. Requires proposal approved by supervisor and graduate chair prior to registration. A-F only. three 600-level TIM courses completed or consent.
prerequisites: three TIM 600-level TIM courses completed or consent

title: Seminar: Travel Industry Management Policy
description: Integration of learning through analysis of policy issues, trends, and problems in the travel industry. A-F only. three 600-level TIM courses completed or consent.
prerequisites: three TIM 600-level TIM courses completed or consent

title: Directed Reading
description: Independent study of approved, advanced reading with faculty supervision. Requires proposal prepared by student and approved by supervisor and graduate chair before registration. Repeatable one time.

title: Thesis Research
description: Independent supervised research. Formal and oral written presentation of research findings. Repeatable up to six credits.

title: Advanced Topics in Global Tourism Management
description: Sustainable management of global tourism to minimize its negative impacts and optimize its positive ones. Deliberation and analysis of major issues related to global tourism from the perspectives of ethics and sustainability. PhD students only. A-F only. 601 with a minimum grade of B. (Fall only)
prerequisites: TIM 601 with a minimum grade of B

title: Advanced Topics in Global Hospitality Management
description: Advanced hospitality management aims to critically explore the key areas that comprise hospitality management, integrate theories and practice, and explore the linkages between hospitality research, management, and business strategies. PhD students only. A-F only. 601 with a minimum grade of B. (Fall only)
prerequisites: TIM 601 with a minimum grade of B

title: Advanced Topics in Global Transportation Management
description: Transport economics and management, and their applications for the travel and tourism industry. Focuses on analytical thinking, problem-solving. and research skills using transportation issues. PhD students only. A-F only. 601 with a minimum grade of B. (Fall only)
prerequisites: TIM 601 with a minimum grade of B

title: Introduction to Pidgin in Hawai‘i
description: Introduction to contemporary Pidgin in Hawai‘i, in relation to the role of Hawaiian and Languages of the Asia-Pacific region; language rights; sociolinguistics of Pidgin and Hawaiian in institutional, educational, and interpersonal contexts. DS

title: Learning Languages and Communicating Interculturally in a Global Multilingual World
description: Historical/global perspective on being/becoming multilingual/multicultural, encompassing cases of second language learning, teaching, use, growth, change, loss across the world, ancient times to present, supporting individuals’ motivations and abilities concerning second languages and cultures.

title: Language by the Numbers
description: Understanding quantitative information and analyses related to language and language learning/multilingualism. Topics include data description and visualization, basic statistics, and evaluating quantitative analyses. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Second Language Learning and Technology
description: Introduction to the use of technology in second language learning; pros and cons of specific new applications and established technologies; project-based and oriented; developing multilingual/ multicultural understanding through technology. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing.

title: Topics in Learning and Using Second Languages
description: Reviews practices of second language learning, use, and maintenance. Introductory exploration and analysis of selected topics with a specific theme indicated by course title listed in the class schedule. Repeatable one time for different topics, up to six credits with consent.

title: Bilingualism: Cognition and Culture
description: Introduction to bi-/multilingualism as a phenomenon at the level of society and as a characteristic of individual speakers; discussion of recent media reports and popular myths about bilingualism in relation to research-based evidence.

title: Basic Language Concepts for Second Language Learning, Teaching, and Use
description: Introduction to language structure and function in the domains of sound, words, sentences, and discourse, with specific focus on description, analysis, and research into learner language. Sophomore standing or higher.

title: Second Language Learning
description: Theoretical foundations for the learning and teaching of second/ foreign languages. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing. upper division standing.

title: Second Language Teaching
description: Survey of methodology; basic concepts and practices; emphasis on teaching second languages through oral instruction. 302 (or concurrent).

title: Sociolinguistics of Multilingualism
description: Explores themes in sociolinguistics relevant to L2/ multilingual contexts, including language ideology, language variation, language and culture, and language and identity; how L2 users and multilingual people grapple with these issues. Includes emphasis on writing instruction. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Second Language Testing
description: Measurement and evaluation of achievement and proficiency in second language learning. 302 or 303 (or concurrent), or consent.
prerequisites: SLS 302 or SLS 303 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Techniques in Second Language Teaching: Reading and Writing
description: Methods and materials. Issues in teaching; survey of available materials and practice in their adaptation. Includes an emphasis on instruction and feedback in oral communication. 302 (or concurrent).

title: Techniques in Second Language Teaching: Listening and Speaking
description: Methods and materials. Issues in teaching; survey of available materials and practice in their adaptation. Includes an emphasis on instruction and feedback in oral communication. 302 (or concurrent).

title: Multilingual Education
description: Survey and analysis of current thinking and practices in multilingual and multicultural education, including bilingual education; special emphasis on ESL/EFL. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing. 302 or consent.

title: Instructional Media
description: Theoretical foundation and practical applications of using electronic and audiovisual media in second language teaching. 303 (with minimum grade of C), or 600 (with minimum grade of B or concurrent); or consent.
prerequisites: SLS 303 (with minimum grade of C), or SLS 600 (with minimum grade of B or concurrent); or consent

title: Pidgin and Creole English in Hawai‘i
description: Major historical descriptive, pedagogical aspects; pidgin and creole languages, linguistic change, language variation. Work with actual language data. Laboratory work required.

title: Learning and Teaching World Languages
description: Hybrid technology intensive course for - or in-service teachers of world languages. Topics: online learning, curriculum and lesson planning, assessment, language teaching approaches, technology for learning world languages. Junior standing or higher. (
prerequisites: - or in-service teachers of world languages

title: English Phonology
description: Introduction to English phonetics and phonology. Includes an emphasis on the oral presentation of key phonological concepts and provides experience in English pronunciation tutoring. 302 (or concurrent) or 600 (or concurrent).

title: Practicum for Future Language Professionals
description: Students observe and assist mentor teachers (minimum of 40 hours) at cooperating schools in multilingual contexts, examining the intersection of theory and practice in language learning and teaching and applying knowledge from other SLS courses. A-F only. 302 and 303.

title: (Alpha) Topics in Second Language Studies
description: Variable topics in special areas of second language studies: (E) second language learning; (N) second language analysis; (P) second language pedagogy; (R) second language research; (U) second language use. Repeatable three times in different topics. 302 (or concurrent) for (E), (N), (R), (U); 303 (or concurrent) for (P). Not applicable toward graduate degrees offered within SLS.
prerequisites: SLS 302 (or concurrent) for (E), (N), (R), (U); SLS 303 (or concurrent) for (P)

title: Professionalism in SLS
description: Capstone for SLS majors. Reflection on experiences via the major, articulation of professional values, exploration of diverse approaches to professionalism in SLS, and formal compilation of a professional portfolio. SLS majors only. Senior standing or higher. A-F only. 302 and 303.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: For interdisciplinary studies majors. a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.7 or a minimum GPA of 3.0 in major, or consent of department chair. Repeatable unlimited times.
prerequisites: a minimum cumulative GPA of SLS 2

title: Introduction to Second Language Studies
description: Introduction to basic professional and research issues in second language studies; integration of theory, research, and practice for prospective second or foreign language teachers and researchers. graduate standing or consent. (Fall only)

title: Language Concepts for Second Language Learning and Teaching
description: Language analysis— phonology, syntax, semantics, discourse for teaching second languages.

title: Introduction to Teaching Second Languages
description: Survey and analysis of second language teaching traditions and perspectives. graduate standing or consent.

title: Introduction to Second Language Assessment
description: Assessment of second language knowledge and skills. Topics include design, use, and analysis of assessments. Graduate standing only or consent.

title: Alternative Approaches to Second Language Teaching
description: Examination, comparison with conventional approaches; interpersonal relationships in language teaching. consent

title: Second Language Listening and Speaking
description: Key issues; overview and critique of published materials; practice in developing syllabi and other materials. consent.

title: Second Language Writing
description: Problems in teaching second language composition. Survey materials; use, modification, and development. Error analysis. consent.

title: Language and Learning Technologies
description: A wide range of emerging technologies for language learning and research will be explored. Online/faceto-face discussions and hands-on experiential learning are integrated with learner’s goals, best practices, and theoretical foundations. consent. (Once a year)

title: Second Language Reading
description: Survey of research in reading process; teaching methodology; psycholinguistic investigations; comparison of reading in first and second languages. consent.

title: Second Language Program Development
description: Designing, implementing, and evaluating language programs; systems-based approach to program and curriculum development. consent.

title: English Grammar
description: Descriptive English grammar in relation to second language learning and teaching.

title: Comparative Grammar and Second Languages
description: Comparative study of two or more languages. Consideration of language transfer in second language learning, role of typological features. consent

title: Multilingual/EL Pedagogy
description: Examines practices, theories, research, and perspectives on multilingual/EL teaching approaches. Topics include culturally and linguistically responsive approaches, collaboration, lesson planning, and adapting materials to promote the growth and development of multilingual/ EL learners. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Second Language Acquisition
description: Survey of theories and research on second language learning by children and adults, learning naturalistically and in formal settings. Relationships are explored between SLA research and language teaching. 601 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Sociolinguistics and Second Languages
description: Theoretical and applied aspects of language, culture, and society, and research methods in sociolinguistics, as they relate to second and foreign language issues. 601 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Second Language Quantitative Research
description: Quantitative research methods; design of research studies; techniques in collecting data; statistical inference; and analysis and interpretation of data.

title: Research in Language Testing
description: Advanced issues in language testing research including recent developments in the following areas: language testing hypotheses, item analysis, reliability, dependability, and validity. 611, 670, or consent.

title: Second Language Classroom Research
description: Survey of research on second language classrooms and analysis of methodological issues.

title: Applied Psycholinguistics and Second Language Acquisition
description: Theory and research in psycholinguistics as related to second language perception, production, acquisition, and instruction. 601 or LING 422, or consent.

title: Survey Research Methods in Second Language Studies
description: Hands-on experience in language survey research including planning and creating survey instruments (both interviews and questionnaires), administering, compiling and analyzing survey data (quantitatively and qualitatively), and reporting the results. consent. (Once a year)

title: Second Language Qualitative Research
description: Philosophical and theoretical approaches, methodology, and ethics in second language qualitative research.

title: Discourse Analysis in Second Language Research
description: Survey of approaches to discourse; microanalytic qualitative research; theory and methodology. 660 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Topics in Second Language Studies
description: Variable topics in special areas of second language studies: (E) second language learning; (N) second language analysis; (P) second language pedagogy; (R) second language research methodology; (U) second language use. Repeatable one time for different alphas. 650 for (E); consent for (N) and (P); 660 or consent for (U).
prerequisites: SLS 650 for (E); consent for (N) and (P); SLS 660 or consent for (U)

title: Second Language Teaching Practicum
description: Student teaching in a language learning classroom. Repeatable one time in a different instructional context. consent.

title: Master’s Plan B/C Studies
description: Enrollment for degree completion. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned up to six credits. CR/NC only. master’s Plan B or C candidate and consent.
prerequisites: master’s Plan B or C candidate and consent

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Individual reading in various fields of second language studies. CR/ NC only. Repeatable unlimited times. consent of instructor.

title: Thesis Research
description: Individual research in the various fields of second language studies. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. consent of instructor.

title: Seminar in Second Language Education
description: Current issues and problems. Repeatable unlimited times. consent only.

title: Seminar in Second Language Acquisition
description: Issues in theory and research in second language acquisition of child and adult. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Seminar in Second Language Use
description: Second language/dialect use in multilingual communities. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Seminar in Second Language Research
description: Research methodologies in second language and multilingual contexts. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Apprenticeship in Teaching
description: An experienced-based introduction to college-level teaching; graduate students serve as student teachers to professors; responsibilities include supervised teaching, and participation in planning and evaluation. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. graduate standing and consent.

title: Dissertation Research
description: One credit is necessary for dissertation writing. Repeatable unlimited times. Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory only.

title: Leadership and Social Issues
description: Fosters understanding of key societal and community issues, social science perspectives on them, the qualities of effective leadership, and invites examination of personal responsibilities, intentions, and abilities to make a difference on those issues. A-F only.

title: Street Science: Evaluating and Applying Evidence in Daily Life
description: Develops necessary tools for effective reasoning and problem-solving through use and application of analytic techniques, including question formation, understanding/interpreting data presented in the public sphere, and evaluating the validity of sources. A-F only.

title: Statistical Analysis for Social Sciences
description: Statistical reasoning in the analysis of social science data, including descriptive statistics, exploratory data analysis, inference measures of association, decomposition of variance, and regression analysis. Lab required. any 100 level social science course or consent.
prerequisites: any SOCS 100 level social science course or consent

title: Scientific Principles of Sustainability
description: Introduction to the scientific principles of sustainability, including the ecology of managed and natural ecosystems, global change biology, ecological principles of natural resource management, renewable energy technologies, and the environmental impacts of humans.

title: Introduction to Digital Media for the Social Sciences
description: Incorporates hands on instruction for creating informational media content, to include learning how to use camera and sound equipment, learning how to edit and create graphics, and learning presentation techniques. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only.

title: Intermediate Digital Media Design and Production for the Social Sciences
description: Focus on theoretical and practical methods for media design and production of high-quality creative digital content. Emphasis on social media strategies and oral communication skills to attract mass online audiences. A-F only. Junior standing or higher. 270 or instructor approval. (Spring only)

title: Pilina: Topics in Indigenous Social Sciences
description: Explores pilina (relationship, connection) of selected topics and issues of interest in the social sciences through Indigenous voices, perspectives, and scholarship. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Advanced Digital Media for Social, Cultural, and Community Engagement
description: Advanced digital media techniques for creating high-quality video content that promotes social, cultural, and community engagement. Focus on writing and oral skills with emphasis on visual storytelling and distribution on broadcast and social media platforms. A-F only. Junior standing or higher. 370 or instructor approval. (Fall only)

title: Social Sciences Internship
description: Internship in public, private, or non-profit organizations providing opportunity for practical experience and application of social sciences concepts and theories. Three to six credits per semester; repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. Consent of instructor. (

title: Topics in Teaching Innovations
description: Examination and critical analysis of contemporary curriculum and instruction issues in social sciences. Concepts, theories, principles underlying active learning, critical thinking, values inquiry, assessment, and multidisciplinary approaches to integration of knowledge.

title: Ocean Policy and Management
description: Interdisciplinary approach to problems relating to humans and their interactions with the world’s oceans and coasts. Focus includes institutions for governing the world’s oceans and coasts at all scales and on the role of scientific knowledge in managing marine and coastal resources. Repeatable one time. OCN 331, GEO 435, or consent. (. ( OEST 735)

title: The Field of Social Work
description: Orientation to the profession of social work; historical development, values and philosophy, scope and aims.

title: General Social Work Practice I
description: Orientation to practice principles, concepts, values, knowledge base, and their application. 200 (complete with C or better) and majors only.
prerequisites: SW 200 (complete with C or better) and majors only

title: General Social Work Practice II
description: Introduction to practice skills with individuals, families, groups, and communities. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction congruent with professional expectations. 302 (complete with C or better) and majors only. Co-requisite: 391.
prerequisites: SW 302 (complete with C or better) and majors only

title: History of Social Welfare
description: Historical developments and implications of social welfare activities, institutions, and policies and European backgrounds; introduce social welfare developments in selected non-European countries. SW majors only. Recommended: 200.

title: Social Welfare as a Social Institution
description: Study of U.S. social welfare institutional structures, programs, and policies addressing human need; focus on Hawai‘i’s legislative processes and social service programs; emphasis on oral communication inherent to advocacy, legislative, and policymaking processes. SW majors only. 325.

title: Human Behavior and the Social Environment
description: Examination of complex sociocultural factors that privilege some and oppress/marginalize others. Challenges commonly held tropes and complicates the discourse regarding individual, family, group, organizational and community development within the social environment. SW majors only. Recommended: 200. DS

title: Human Behavior and the Social Environment II
description: Focus on human development across the lifespan with attention given to unique challenges and opportunities faced in each phase. Emphasis on “populations at risk” and the strengths and assets unique to diverse populations. SW majors only. 360 with a grade of C or better. Recommended: 200. DS
prerequisites: SW 360 with a grade of C or better

title: Topics in Social Welfare
description: An examination of current trends in the field of social welfare. SW majors only.

title: Undergraduate Field Education I
description: Introduction to field education; application of social work knowledge, skills, and values to the field experience. CR/NC only. 302, 325, 326 (or concurrent), 360, and 361 (or concurrent) complete with C or better; and majors only. Co-requisite: 303.
prerequisites: SW 302, SW 325, SW 326 (or concurrent), SW 360, and SW 361 (or concurrent) complete with C or better; and majors only

title: General Social Work Practice III
description: Use of problem-solving processes and ethical models of decision-making in practice with individuals, families, groups, and communities. 303, 326, and 361 complete with C or better; and majors only. Corequisite: 440 and 490.
prerequisites: SW 303, SW 326, and SW 361 complete with C or better; and majors only

title: General Social Work Practice IV
description: Examination of practice methods and intervention models; identification and analysis of issues related to practice. A significant portion of class time is dedicated to writing instruction congruent with professional expectations. 402 (C or better) and majors only. Co-requisite: 491.
prerequisites: SW 402 (C or better) and majors only

title: Back to the Future: Aging in Today’s Society
description: By 2050, more than a quarter of the world’s population will be 60 years of age or older. Explores what we know about aging today to encourage a lifetime of aging well. A-F only. 201 or SW 360 or WGSS 305 or PSY 100 or HDFS 230 or NURS 200; or consent. (
prerequisites: SW 201 or SW 360 or WGSS 305 or PSY 100 or HDFS 230 or NURS 200; or consent

title: Research Development in Social Welfare
description: Introduction to and application of language of research, theoretical concepts underlying advancement of knowledge, practical steps in research. SW majors only. completion of required junior-level SW courses (i.e., 302, 303, 325, 326, 360, 361, and 391) with C or better. Co-requisite: 402 and 490.
prerequisites: completion of required junior-level SW courses (i)

title: Native Hawaiian Perspectives: A Cultural Context for Well-Being
description: To preserve the cultural knowledge of kupuna as it relates to health and wellbeing. Disseminate cultural knowledge of health and well-being to social work students and students in allied health professions. SW or Social Welfare students only.

title: Ke A‘o Mau: Learning Preserved
description: To provide a holistic examination of issues and to explore culturally-anchored resolutions and practices to achieve social justice and health and well-being. SW, Social Welfare, or PH students only.

title: Cultural Factors in Work with Hawaiians
description: Provides students with a body of knowledge, skills, and values that facilitate social work with Native Hawaiians. SW or Social Welfare students.

title: Social Services with Children
description: Study of current social services for children in the U.S. with focus on familiarization of child welfare programs and services in Hawai‘i. senior standing or consent.

title: Social Welfare Concepts and Issues in Gerontology
description: Aging and its effect on the individual, family groups, associations, and communities. Impact of aging on social service delivery systems, public policy and role of social work. senior standing or consent.

title: Topics in Social Welfare
description: An examination of current trends and issues in social work. SW majors only.

title: Undergraduate Field Education II
description: Intermediate instruction to field education; application of social work knowledge, skills, and values to the field experience. 391 complete with C or better, and majors only. Co-requisite: 402 and 440.
prerequisites: SW 391 complete with C or better, and majors only

title: Undergraduate Field Education III
description: Advanced instruction to field education; application of social work knowledge, skills, and values to the field experience. 490 complete with C or better, and majors only. Co-requisite: 403.
prerequisites: SW 490 complete with C or better, and majors only

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Planned individualized study or research in special area related to social work practice interest. Up to 3 credit hours. majors only, senior standing, and consent of program chair and faculty advisor.
prerequisites: majors only, senior standing, and consent of program chair and faculty advisor

title: Social Work Practice with Individuals
description: Beginning practice course introduces students to the basic processes of social work and the roles and skills needed for generalist practice. Relevant theories of social work practice with individuals are explored for the efficacy with various problems and for their applicability to practice with various ethnocultures, social classes, and oppressed populations. Interviewing and interpersonal skill development are incorporated. A-F only. admission to MSW program. (Fall only)

title: Social Work Practice with Families and Groups
description: Practice course builds upon the generalist framework and foundation content presented in 606. Special emphasis is given on models for assessment, intervention, and evaluation of practice with families and groups. Relevant theories of groups and the principles of group dynamics and group work methods are examined in regard to task, therapeutic, psychoeducational, and social development groups. Family content includes structural, behavioral, communication/experiential, and culturally-specific theories of intervention. A-F only. 606.

title: Social Welfare Policy and Services
description: Examines in a historical and comparative framework the economic, social, political, organizational, and administrative factors influencing the development, formulation, and implementation of social welfare policies in the U.S. Provides opportunity for the application of various models of social policy analysis in major areas of social welfare programming and service delivery. SW majors only. A-F only. graduate standing. (Fall only)

title: Social Work Practice in Communities and Organizations
description: Community conceptualization; organized roles of developer, enabler, broker, mediator, and advocate; diagnostic and problem-solving technology; the special characteristics of the social worker as community organizer; matrix of structural objectives; sources and use of power; how to build an organization; and interorganizational negotiation. SW majors only. A-F only. 606, graduate standing, and consent. (Spring only)

title: Organization and Administration in Social Work
description: Introduction to formal organization theory. Social service administration examined and implications for service delivery systems developed. SW majors only. graduate standing.

title: Policies, Programs and Services on Aging
description: Explores policies, programs, and services for older adults. Students learn about the aging network, assess older adults’ needs, link older adults to appropriate services in the community, and track legislative bills that address older adults’ quality of life. graduate standing or consent.

title: Death and Dying
description: Physical, social, cultural, psychological, and spiritual dimensions of dying, death, and bereavement. graduate standing or consent.

title: Social and Cultural Aspects of Aging
description: Overview of aging from the biopsycho, socioeconomic and cultural perspectives. Explores common theories of aging. Emphasis on bridging the gap between the realm of concepts and theories, and the world of practice in gerontology. graduate standing or consent.

title: Introduction to Scientific Methods and Principles in Social Work
description: Understanding and interpreting results of nomothetic and idiographic research; design principles and statistical analyses and their relationship to practices; use of published research. SW majors only. A-F only. graduate standing. (Fall only)

title: Research Designs and Data Analyses for the Evaluation of Practice Effectiveness
description: Extending the study of scientific methods introduced in 640. Covers the range of empirical research methods and data analytic procedures suitable for knowledge building and practice evaluation at all levels of intervention from case to program. A-F only. 640. (Spring only)

title: Quantitative Methods I
description: Introduction to quantitative methods in behavioral sciences. Introduction to general linear model as principle of data analysis. Course requires basic statistics. (Meets PhD common inquiry methods requirement or elective.)

title: Applied Regression and Analysis of Variance
description: Introduction to linear statistical models as principle of data analysis. Topics include multiple regression models with continuous and categorical predictors. ANOVA with multiple factors, ANOVA with repeated measures, and ANCOVA. 601 or consent.

title: Multivariate Methods
description: Multivariate forms of multiple linear regression, analysis of variance, and analysis of co-variance. Multiple discriminant analysis, canonical correlation, and principal components analysis are discussed. SW majors only.

title: Human Behavior in the Social Environment I
description: Examination of complex factors that privilege some and oppress/marginalize others; challenges commonly held tropes and complicates the discourse regarding individual, family, group, organizational and community development within the social environment. SW majors only. A-F only. graduate standing. (Fall only)

title: Human Behavior in the Social Environment II
description: Focus on human development across the lifespan with attention given to unique challenges and opportunities faced in each phase. Emphasis is placed on “populations at risk” and the strengths and assets unique to diverse populations. A-F only. 659. (Spring only)

title: Treatment of Chemical Dependency
description: Introduction to treatment of alcoholism and other chemical dependencies. Application of social work strategies in work with individuals and families in the disease and recovery process. Repeatable one time. SW majors only. graduate standing.

title: Child Welfare as a Field of Social Work
description: Emphasis on the developments in child welfare; issues, concerns with regard to needs and rights, and the application of social work services to problems associated with needs for protection. Review of historical, theoretical, empirical, and legal findings for skill development in intervening in dysfunctional parent/child interaction. SW majors only. graduate standing.

title: Community and Public Health Practice
description: Community organization and development applicable to the delivery of health services. Understanding community dynamics, mobilizing community groups for effective health care practice and delivery. SW majors only. PH 647 or consent. (

title: Topics in Social Welfare
description: Current trends in field of social welfare. Recent courses have focused on forensic social work, immigrants and refugees, and leadership in human services. Meets seminar requirement. Repeatable one time in different topics. SW majors only. graduate standing.

title: Marriage and Family Therapy
description: Introduction to couple and family therapy offers an overview of family systems perspective, theory and technique relevant to informing effective social work case planning, case management, advocacy, and interaction with clients. SW majors only. Graduate students only.

title: Generalist Field Education I
description: Field education is the signature pedagogy of social work education. Students will engage in supervised social work practice and have the opportunity to apply generalist knowledge, skills, values, and ethics to practice. A-F only. 606 (or concurrent)(with a minimum grade of C).
prerequisites: SW 606 (or concurrent)(with a minimum grade of C)

title: Generalist Field Education II
description: Field education is the signature pedagogy of social work education. Students will engage in supervised social work practice and have the opportunity to apply generalist knowledge, skills, values, and ethics to practice. A-F only. 690 and 607 (or concurrent) and 631 (or concurrent) (all with a minimum grade of C).
prerequisites: SW 690 and SW 607 (or concurrent) and SW 631 (or concurrent) (all with a minimum grade of C)

title: Health and Aging
description: Biological and physiological changes associated with aging. Social and psychological factors associated with health maintenance. Major threats to health, changing patterns of morbidity and mortality of the aged. graduate standing.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Students, on the basis of special interest, select a faculty member to work with on a problem for which planned individualized study or research is deemed advisable. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Independent research under supervision of a thesis committee. Includes formal proposal and defense of finished research. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Methods of Group Psychotherapy
description: Designed specifically to train students in the theory and practice of leading psychotherapy groups; it includes historical developments, research, theories, and application of group psychotherapy, group techniques and exercises. SW majors only. 607 or consent.

title: Therapeutic Strategies with the Older Adult
description: Focuses on interdisciplinary strategies with older adults: individual, family, and group therapy; eclectic mental health approaches; case management; and environmental intervention. Emphasis placed on the use of these strategies as preventive, as well as supportive, measures for the well, transition, and frail elderly. Meets seminar requirement. SW majors only. graduate standing.

title: Social Work Practice with Children and Families
description: Advanced practice course for students specializing in social work with children and families. Designed to provide students with an in-depth understanding of both theoretical formulations and therapeutic techniques for practice in the field of family and child welfare. Emphasis placed on the development of specialized knowledge and skills for assessment, intervention, and evaluation of a variety of common child and family practice situations. SW majors only. completion of foundation courses.

title: Seminar in Social Work Practice with Children and Families
description: Designed for students in the child and family concentration and builds upon past knowledge and skill development in practice classes and in the practicum. Students integrate, demonstrate, and extend earlier learning, acquire new knowledge, and learn and practice new skills. Organized around student case presentations in a consultation format. Meets seminar requirement. SW majors only. 717.

title: Social Work Practice in Health Care
description: Didactic and experiential learning activity focuses on the major role functions of the social worker in the health field including assessment, contracting, counseling, advocacy, case management, discharge planning, family group work, community and team building. Covers health care policy, research directions in practice and social work management issues. SW majors only. completion of foundation courses.

title: Seminar in Social Work Practice in Health Care
description: Through the use of case studies developed by the students, social work practice is examined in three areas of health care: primary care provided in health departments and medical groups, hospital-based services, and long-term care. Meets seminar requirement. SW majors only. 722.

title: Seminar in Social Work Practice in Mental Health
description: Prepares students for social work practice in mental health settings. Focused on engagement and assessment while emphasizing cultural, person in environment, and strengths-based approaches. SW majors only. completion of foundation courses.

title: Social Work Practice in Mental Health
description: Prepares students for social work practice in mental health settings, with a focus on history and policy in the U.S. and Hawai‘i, as well as culturally-grounded and evidence-based practice. SW majors only. 724.

title: Social Work Practice with Older Adults
description: Designed to provide students with an in-depth understanding of theoretical formulations and intervention strategies for working with older adults and their families. Emphasis on diversity/justice. SW majors only. completion of foundation courses.

title: Seminar in Social Work with Older Adults
description: Designed for gerontology specialization students to gain advanced knowledge for working with diverse older adults and their families. Emphasis on strength perspectives on aging. SW majors only. 726.

title: Social Policy Analysis
description: Students pursue in-depth a specific topic in the areas of social planning, social policy analysis, evaluation of social programs, administration, supervision, and consultation. Selectively a comparative perspective is introduced and case studies used to illustrate concepts, principles, and techniques, with implications for practice. Meets seminar requirement. SW majors only. 630 or consent.

title: Social Work and the Law
description: Knowledge of judicial systems and law relevant to social work practice in corrections, child-family welfare, health, and mental health. Skills for effective participation in the legal process are acquired in moot court and in practice for testifying. SW majors only. graduate standing.

title: Review of Research in Social Work
description: In-depth study of research in a substantive area. Each seminar will be devoted to a particular topic: e.g., foster care of children, effectiveness of social work intervention, etc. SW majors only. 650.

title: Individual or Group Research Project— Plan B
description: Independent research (group of two to seven students or by an individual student) undertaken under the sponsorship of a faculty advisor. Elements are selection of a topic related to the practice of social work or knowledge relevant to that practice, utilization of empirical research methodology in collecting and analyzing original data, and preparation of a scholarly paper. SW majors only. A-F only. 650.

title: Individual or Group Research Project– Plan B
description: Same as 743. A-F only. 743.

title: Individual or Group Research Project– Plan B
description: Same as 743. A-F only

title: Analysis and Development of Knowledge for Social Work
description: Focuses on developing an understanding of philosophy of science, theory development, social work epistemology, and the analysis and development of knowledge for social work practice. A-F only. PhD candidate in social welfare or consent.
prerequisites: PhD candidate in social welfare or consent

title: Quantitative Methods II
description: Empirical research methodology with emphasis on design principles and measurement theory; design and measurement issues and problems in cross-cultural research. A-F only. PhD candidate in social welfare or consent.
prerequisites: PhD candidate in social welfare or consent

title: Qualitative Research: Philosophical, Methodological and Analytic Approaches
description: Theories and methods of qualitative research; problem formulation, informant selection, study design, data collection and analysis utilizing qualitative approaches. Repeatable three times. A-F only. 640 or 651 or equivalent; departmental approval.
prerequisites: SW 640 or SW 651 or equivalent; departmental approval

title: Dissertation Seminar
description: Culminating experience in social welfare doctoral specialization; integration of PhD core and specialization course work. classified student in PhD in social welfare program or consent.
prerequisites: classified student in PhD in social welfare program or consent

title: Seminar in International Social Work
description: Approaches to social problems and trends in the profession in international, cross-cultural perspectives. Emphasis on developmental aspects of social work. Political, economic, social, and cultural forces shaping social welfare in national development. Meets seminar requirement. SW majors only. graduate standing or consent.

title: Cultural Factors in Work with Hawaiians
description: Hawaiian culture, past and present. Explores and examines possible approaches to working with Hawaiians and part-Hawaiians. Special emphasis on supports in the Hawaiian system that may promote maximal functioning for those Hawaiians experiencing problems in today’s society. Meets seminar requirement. A-F only. graduate standing.

title: Seminar on Women and Health
description: Women’s health and the role of women health professionals. Current literature and research regarding attitudes, roles, rights, and health care. graduate standing or consent. (

title: Specialist Field Education I
description: Instruction in the field is continued. The field experience in the second year provides an opportunity for the student to test out concepts, principles, theories, and alternate approaches in actual practice settings. SW majors only. A-F only. 717 (or concurrent) or 722 (or concurrent) or 724 (or concurrent) or 726 (or concurrent) (all with a minimum grade of B -).
prerequisites: SW 717 (or concurrent) or SW 722 (or concurrent) or SW 724 (or concurrent) or SW 726 (or concurrent) (all with a minimum grade of B -)

title: Specialist Field Education II
description: Continuation of 790. A-F only. 790 and; 718 (or concurrent); or 723 (or concurrent); or 725 (or concurrent); or 727 (or concurrent) (all with a minimum grade of B-).
prerequisites: SW 790 and; SW 718 (or concurrent); or SW 723 (or concurrent); or SW 725 (or concurrent); or SW 727 (or concurrent) (all with a minimum grade of B-)

title: Advanced Social Welfare Policy Analysis and Change
description: Builds on 630 and emphasizes a more thorough and comprehensive examination of major policies, programs, and populations central to a concentration (Health, Mental Health, Gerontology, Child and Family). Students learn a more focused and applied analysis of the relationship between social policy, research, and social work practice. SW majors only. A-F only. 606 and 607; 630 and 631; 640 and 650; 659 and 660; 690 and 691.
prerequisites: SW 606 and SW 607; SW 630 and SW 631; SW 640 and SW 650; SW 659 and SW 660; SW 690 and SW 691

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable one time.

title: Introduction to Sociology
description: Basic social relationships, social structures, and processes.

title: Introduction to Data Analysis
description: Basic analytic skills widely used in quantitative analysis of social science data, including descriptive statistics, rates and probability, comparison of groups, introduction to causal relationships, and application of these techniques to real life examples. A-F only.

title: Introduction to International and Global Studies
description: Introduces undergraduate students to the major political, social, economic, cultural, technological, and historical dimensions of globalization. Special attention will be paid to globalization process that have impacted Hawai‘i and the Asia-Pacific region. A-F only. (

title: Introduction to Race and Ethnic Relations
description: Race and ethnic relations in world perspective; social, economic, and political problems associated with perception, existence, and accommodation of these groups within the wider society. (

title: Introduction to Social Problems
description: Theoretical and substantive survey of the nature and causes of social problems; selected types: poverty, inequality, deviance, etc

title: Introduction to Sustainability from Social Science Perspectives
description: Introduction to key concepts and theories in social sciences in relation to sustainability issues. (

title: Introduction to Juvenile Delinquency
description: Forms of juvenile deviance; conditions and processes that result in alienation and deviance of youth. Juvenile corrections as institutionalized societal responses.

title: Introduction to the Sociology of Punishment
description: Multiple social theories about different forms of formal and informal punishments and social control across different societies and times.

title: Introduction to Sociology of the Family
description: Family patterns, mate selection, parent-child interaction, socialization of roles, legal sanctions, trends in organization, functions.

title: East Asian Popular Cultures
description: East Asian popular culture, with a focus on Korea and Japan, as well as the Chinese language sphere. Analyzes social forces shaping pop culture industries, artists, and productions in the region from a global perspective. A-F only. (

title: Principles of Sociological Inquiry
description: (3 Lec, 2 50-min Lab) Basic methods of sociology for production and analysis of data. Foundations for understanding research and for advanced courses in methods and statistics.

title: Survey of Urban Sociology
description: Urban processes and social problems, such as poverty, crime, racial segregation, homelessness, housing policy, urbanization, and neighborhood ethnic diversity. How places shape identity and opportunity. Research methods applied to communities, places, and neighborhoods of Hawai‘i. (

title: Women and Health
description: Explores current issues in the conceptualization and delivery of health care for women. 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or WGSS 151 or WGSS 202, or POLS 110; or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 100 or any SOC 200-level SOC course, or WGSS 151 or WGSS 202, or POLS 110; or consent

title: Survey of Social Inequality and Stratification
description: Introduction to social stratification theory and research; definition and measurement of socioeconomic status; racial, ethnic and gender inequality; differences in lifestyles and life chances; social mobility.

title: Survey of Sociology of Work
description: Work from viewpoint of individuals; meaningfulness versus productivity; how work, economics, and the industrial system affect individual goals.

title: Survey of Social Change
description: Causes, processes, and effects of social change, using single and multi-cause models in simple and complex industrialized societies.

title: Women and Social Policy
description: Social and economic policies affecting women in families, education, social services, government, health care, the economy; public policy implementation and development; policy impact on women. 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or WS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course; or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 100 or any SOC 200-level SOC course, or WS 151 or any WS 200- or WS 300-level WS course; or consent

title: Survey of Sociological Theory
description: Major theorists and their influences, from Comte to today.

title: Sociology of Law
description: Law as a political enforcement of the social order; how it is organized and operates; determinants of effectiveness; ways it adapts to and facilitates changing social conditions.

title: Criminology
description: Concepts used in crime, law enforcement, criminal justice, and corrections. Types of criminal behavior; costs and effects of control.

title: Drugs and Society
description: Use of mood- and mind-altering drugs in America among adults, youth, and cross-culturally. Illicit drug culture, psychedelics, and perception; social norms and deviant behavior.

title: Deviance and Social Control
description: Interrelations of deviance, criminology, juvenile delinquency, corrections, social control, sociology of law. Key concepts, theories. DS

title: Criminal Justice Organizations
description: Examines major criminal justice organizations–police, courts, and prisons. Using organizational theory, identifies the role of organizational goals, structure, resources, legitimacy, culture, and front-line workers in shaping criminal justice policy and practice. 100 or a 200-level SOC course, or consent.
prerequisites: SOC 100 or a SOC 200-level SOC course, or consent

title: Survey of Social Psychology
description: Major principles; social attitudes, theories of conformity and change, person perception and attribution theory, social role, role conflict and role behavior, group structure, and behavior.

title: Sociology of Happiness in Unsettled Times
description: Combines theoretical, scientific and ‘hands-on’ learning to explore how happiness and well-being can be cultivated, even in this challenging era of extreme global climate events. 100 or a 200-level SOC course.
prerequisites: SOC 100 or a SOC 200-level SOC course

title: Survey of Sociology of Education
description: Formal education as one aspect of socialization. Emphasis on American system; business, military, and religious institutions.

title: Survey of Sociology of Aging
description: Aging as a social phenomenon, including social impacts of growing elderly population and emerging social patterns among the elderly. Important theoretical perspectives and cross-national research. (

title: Survey of Medical Sociology
description: Social factors in disease and treatment; illness behavior, roles of patients and healers; nature of healing professions; use of medical services; alternative systems of medical organization.

title: Chinese Society and Culture
description: Social institutions, family, community, education, stratification, government, economy; impact of modernization and revolution on their contemporary transformation. A-F only.

title: Japanese Society and Culture
description: Persistence and change in economy, policy, religion, education, family, and other institutions of modern Japan.

title: Sociology of Korea
description: Social institutions, family, education, religion, cultural values, social classes, economic development, social movements, gender relations, North-South relations, and unification issues. A-F only. 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or consent.
prerequisites: SOC 100 or any SOC 200-level SOC course, or consent

title: Sociology of Gender
description: Effect of sex and gender roles (both traditional and nontraditional) on attitudes and behavior within the family and educational, economic, and governmental systems. Recommended: at least one WGSS course. 100 or any 200-level SOC course, WGSS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WGSS course; or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 100 or any SOC 200-level SOC course, WGSS 151 or any WGSS 200- or WGSS 300-level WGSS course; or consent

title: Sustainability, Technoscience, and Social Justice
description: Examines politics of sustainability and technoscience with an explicit attention to social justice and power relations in society. A-F only. 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or WGSS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WGSS course, or consent.
prerequisites: SOC 100 or any SOC 200-level SOC course, or WGSS 151 or any WGSS 200- or WGSS 300-level WGSS course, or consent
crossListings: Fall only Crosslisted as SUST 367 and WGSS 367

title: Law, Politics and Society
description: Relationships between law, politics, and society will be explored. Emphasis is placed on several dimensions of legality: legal “indeterminacy” and some of the many things that law does for us and to us; law’s response to violence; the connections between law and social change; access to the law and its sociological dimensions; how/why law fails and what happens when it does. A-F only. 100 or any 200 level SOC course, or a 100 level or 200 level POLS course, or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 100 or any SOC 200 level SOC course, or a SOC 100 level or SOC 200 level POLS course, or consent

title: Internship for Sustainability and Social Justice
description: Internship in public, private, or non-profit organizations providing opportunity for practical experience in addressing sustainability issues. Repeatable one time. Sophomore standing or higher, or consent. A-F only. Consent of instructor. (

title: Food, Body, and Women: Analysis of Biopolitics
description: Explores how food, body, and other “matter of life” are imbedded in biopolitics from the feminist perspectives. A-F only. WGSS 300, or one 300-level WGSS or ES course, or consent. (Spring only).
prerequisites: WGSS 300, or one WGSS 300-level WGSS or ES course, or consent

title: Analysis in Urban Sociology
description: Urbanization in developed and developing countries, the rural-urban continuum, structure and process of metropolitan regions, theories of urban location and growth, housing and urban renewal.

title: Analysis in Social Stratification
description: Approaches to research in social inequality: community studies; historical and cross-cultural analyses of poverty, working class, middle class, power structure, social mobility, etc.

title: Analysis in Population and Society
description: Global and U.S. patterns of population growth; composition and distribution, elementary demographic techniques; development issues and population policy. 300 or consent.

title: Economy and Society
description: Study of the dominant trend of economic change and its impact on society; globalization of economic activities and transformation of industrial society to postindustrial one; corporate restructuring and downsizing and their impact on employment and income distribution; gender relations in workplaces; the impact of globalization on the newly industrializing countries. 300 or consent.

title: Technology and Society
description: Nature of technology, social forces that affect its adoption; impact on society; innovation.

title: Women and Work
description: Gender and race of paid and unpaid work in the formal and informal sectors of the economy; carework in households; unemployment; ethics of revaluing feminized work; labor rights: scope: local and global. 300, or one 300-level WGSS or ES course; or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 300, or one SOC 300-level WGSS or ES course; or consent

title: Organizations and Society
description: Schools, hospitals, industries, prisons, and government agencies analyzed in terms of self-actualization, alienation, human relations, communication, leadership, organizational conflicts.

title: Advanced Criminology & Juvenile Delinquency
description: Research in systematic social deviation. Scaling and measurement of delinquents/ criminals, official data, gangs, identification and measurement of delinquent/criminal value orientations, etc. DS

title: Punishment & Society
description: Institutions, organizations, and individuals charged with carrying out punishment in the criminal justice system and beyond. DS

title: Analysis in Law and Social Change
description: Interrelationships between legal orders and other social institutions; use of “law” to change major status relationships, e.g., boss-worker, woman-man, child-adult.

title: Women and Crime
description: Women’s relations with the criminal justice system; types of women’s offenses; responses to women’s crime; women as victims; women as workers in the criminal justice system. Recommended: at least one WGSS course. 300, or WGSS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WGSS course; or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 300, or WGSS 151 or any WGSS 200- or WGSS 300-level WGSS course; or consent

title: Prisons
description: Prisons, jails, and other detention facilities across historical, social, and/or international contexts. 300 or consent.

title: Social Structure and the Individual
description: Effects of social institutions on individuals. Role of socioeconomic status, cultural background, family structure, peer group, schools, and occupational roles in socialization.

title: Analysis in Gender Violence
description: Historical and structural theories of gender-based violence, including domestic and sexual abuse, prostitution, trafficking, cross-cultural perspectives, social policy and practices. Junior standing or graduate standing only. 300 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Gender Violence Over the Lifecycle
description: Examines the problem of violence, particularly sexual violence, over the life cycle. Offers gendered perspective in activities aimed at prevention and treatment of violence, and cross cultural perspectives. 300, WGSS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WGSS course; or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 300, WGSS 151 or any WGSS 200- or WGSS 300-level WGSS course; or consent

title: Analysis in Marriage and the Family
description: Theory and methods of studying social interaction in marriage and the family; examination of marriage, mating, love, and choice. Empirical research emphasizing Hawai‘i.

title: Marriage and Family: A Feminist Perspective
description: Sex-role socialization, motherhood, work-family conflicts. Alternative family structures in U.S. and other countries. Recommended: at least one WGSS course. 300, or WGSS 151 or any 200- or 300-level WGSS course; or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 300, or WGSS 151 or any WGSS 200- or WGSS 300-level WGSS course; or consent

title: Analysis in Sociology of Aging
description: Social and research issues significant to delivery of long-term care services to the elderly; cost, quality, availability of services, evaluation of programs, role of family, formal and informal care services.

title: Analysis in Medical Sociology
description: Application of sociological theories and concepts to medical social situations and behavior; problems of obtaining data for research.

title: Sociology of Religion
description: Seminar in research on sociological aspects of religious sectarianism; attention to Hawai‘i. 300 or consent. (

title: Racism and Ethnicity in Hawai‘i
description: The historical and contemporary social processes involved in inter-ethnic relations in Hawai‘i. 300 or one ES 300 level course, or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 300 or one ES 300 level course, or consent

title: Sociology of the Arts
description: Relation of art to society; role of artist, audience, critic, patron, museum; Western and other societies; attitudes toward new styles.

title: Analysis in Sports and Society
description: Critical perspectives on sports and society. Topics include power and inequality; mobility, status, and economics; youth development; globalization; gender; and violence in sports and the wider society. 300 and 321. (Spring only)

title: Popular Culture
description: Popular culture as manifested in film, sports, TV, comics, magazines, etc.; relation to sociological theories and studies.

title: Analysis in Survey Research
description: Survey research design and analysis, including theory selection instrument construction, sampling techniques, data collection, computerized data analysis, and writing up research reports of the findings.

title: Social Statistics
description: Common statistical procedures emphasizing univariate and bivariate description; some attention to multivariate techniques and statistical inference, within context of research procedures. 300 or consent. Co-requisite: 476L.

title: Social Statistics Laboratory
description: Required lab for computer applications for analysis of sociological data. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 476.

title: Analysis in Field Research Methods
description: Techniques for collecting and analyzing qualitative data. Participant observation; small groups in natural settings; community studies. Grounded theory; theories of everyday life; reality construction.

title: Discussion Group Leader–Freshman Seminar
description: A unique opportunity for students to gain leadership, teaching, and public speaking skills as a SOC 100 leader for a section of 10 freshmen students while being mentored weekly by a faculty course coordinator.

title: Politics of Multiculturalism
description: The development of ethnic relations and political approaches to multiculturalism in two multiethnic nations: Canada and the U.S. A-F only. 300 or one 300 level ES course, or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 300 or one SOC 300 level ES course, or consent

title: Social Sciences Internship
description: Internship in public, private, or non-profit organizations providing opportunity for practical experience and application of social sciences concepts and theories. Three to six credits per semester; repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. Consent of instructor. (

title: Topics in Sociology
description: Topics course that explore current issues and try new ideas. Repeatable two times. 300 or consent.

title: Topics in Sociology: Student Projects
description: Students create their own study group and solicit an advisor from faculty. Consult department for assistance.

title: Directed Reading or Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. 300 and consent of instructor.

title: Statistics for Regression Analysis
description: Dealing with the multiple linear regression and logistic regression models, focusing on modeling, i.e., specification of the explanatory variables to answer different research questions. Emphasis on applications using statistical package programs. SOC 605L is required.

title: Regression Analysis Laboratory
description: Lab for computer analysis skills is required for students taking 605. CR/NC only. Co-requisite: 605.

title: Research Methods and Design
description: Emphasis on theory selection, theory construction, and choice of research strategies.

title: Seminar in Methods of Content Analysis
description: Content analysis combines quantitative and qualitative methods to analyze text systematically. Covers sampling and case selection; manual and computer-assisted methods of coding and analyzing textual data; writing reports using content analysis data. Repeatable one time. (Once a year)

title: Survey Research Design and Analysis
description: Survey study designs, survey sampling, questionnaire construction, interviewing, -tests, pilot studies, logic of measurement and association, table construction, and elaboration models. consent. (
prerequisites: -tests, pilot studies, logic of measurement and association, table construction, and elaboration models

title: Seminar Qualitative Research
description: Advanced seminar on conducting fieldwork in natural social settings with emphasis on qualitative techniques, political and ethical considerations, data management and assessment, interpretation and reflexive writing. Repeatable one time.

title: Classical Sociological Theory
description: Seminar offers a critical overview of major perspectives and representative works in sociological theory from 19th-century to the 1960s, including intellectual contexts and historical development. A-F only. Graduate students only. consent. (Fall only)

title: Contemporary Sociological Theory
description: Seminar offers a critical overview of major perspectives and representative works in sociology theory from the 1960s to the present, including intellectual contexts and historical development. A-F only. Graduate students only. (Spring only)

title: Organizational Analysis
description: Theoretical approaches to organizations; organizational structure and process; organizational pathologies and effectiveness; the organization and its environment.

title: Medical Sociology
description: Covers the major paradigms in medical sociology for analyzing social epidemiology, the political economy of health systems, health service organizations, health and wellness behaviors illness perception and help-seeking, doctor-patient interaction, and adaptations to illness. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Seminar in Stress and Health
description: Analysis of current theory and empirical research on relationship of stress and health; sociological, psychological, and community psychiatry models and current issues.

title: Sociology of Mental Health and Illness
description: Examines sociological research and theories about mental health and illness. A key question in medical sociology will be addressed: What is the relationship between society and mental health? Repeatable one time.

title: Seminar in Social Stratification
description: Classical theories of social class, contemporary developments; crucial research issues, appropriate methodologies. Repeatable one time only. Classified graduate students only. consent.

title: Feminist Criminology
description: Key themes in feminist criminology are explored including focus on masculinities and crime, race and intersectionality, global criminology, and the ways in which the criminal justice system controls women and girls. A-F only. (

title: Seminar in Criminology
description: Major current theories, history of their development, elaborations of typologies, implications for treatment modalities.

title: Criminal Justice System
description: Examination of the criminal justice system; the exercise of discretion and limits placed upon it. consent.

title: American Punishment
description: Examines the history of American criminal punishment, from the birth of the penitentiary to the rise of the prison-industrial complex. A-F only. Graduate students only. (

title: Introduction to Human Population
description: Comparative analysis of quantitative and qualitative aspects of population; factors affecting size, distribution, and composition; impact of population size and composition on society.

title: Methods of Demographic Analysis
description: Statistical evaluation and analysis of population data; data sources; population growth; composition; standardization of rates; mortality and the life table; nuptiality and fertility; distribution, migration, urbanization; projections and stable population theory. (

title: Teaching Seminar
description: Examines research on teaching, learning, and ethics, as well as practical skills for teaching at the university level. Syllabi and teaching philosophies are developed, which are useful for the academic job market. Graduate standing only.

title: Sociology of Sustainability
description: Analyses of sustainability, environmental, and technoscience issues from sociological perspectives. Graduate students only. (Fall only) (

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Evaluation Research
description: Research design, data collection, field problems and analysis in the evaluation of social programs. Examples from criminal justice, corrections, drug treatment, mental health, and public health.

title: Advanced Statistics
description: Dealing with advanced statistical methods beyond multiple linear regression, such as logit, event history analysis, and multi-level analysis. Emphasis is on applications of the techniques to social science research. Repeatable one time only.

title: Cultural Analysis
description: Contemporary issues in cultural sociology, covering key theoretical perspectives, analytic methods and substantive areas for empirical research. A-F only.

title: Seminar in Sociology of Knowledge
description: Sociological theory applied to bases of knowledge in everyday life, professional communities, and the sciences. Research and theory-building activities of sociologists; ethnomethodology; construction of social structure, culture, and consciousness. Repeatable one time only.

title: Seminar in Current Issues in Sociology
description: Substantive areas that are of current interest and the focus of research, but not addressed in other courses. Repeatable two times.

title: Advanced Medical Sociology
description: Application of theoretical paradigms and methodologies to the examination of selected research topics in the field of medical sociology. Repeatable one time. 615 or consent.

title: Seminar in Aging, Culture, and Health
description: Overview of the major theories, perspectives, and empirical findings relating to aging in various cultural contexts. SOC, PSY, NURS, SW, PH majors only. 606 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
prerequisites: SOC 606 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Comparative Family and Gender
description: Discusses the major perspectives on family and gender relations and examines related empirical research. Emphasis is on the cross-cultural comparisons across the U.S. and Asia in the context of globalizing economies and cultures. A-F only. (Alt. years) (

title: Comparative Study of East Asia
description: Comparative analysis of social organization, social processes, and change of both capitalist and communist countries of East Asia, with each other and other areas of the world. Repeatable one time. 611 or consent.

title: Social Change–Pacific Islands
description: Analysis of social change; transformation from subsistence societies to commodified, wage-labor societies with participation in world economy.

title: Modern Japanese Society
description: Social and behavioral studies of Japanese values, social organization, and personality development. Problems of value conflict, political protest, world role, tradition, and social change. Repeatable one time only.

title: Seminar in Modern Chinese Society
description: Developmental policies, social change, and impact on modern Chinese social institutions. Includes China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan. May include social and demographic change, population, social stratification, gender, and family problems. Repeatable one time.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Race and Ethnicity
description: An examination of how ideas of “race” and “ethnicity” are constructed, and how this reflects and shapes social structures and relationships: (B) antiracism studies; (C) ethnic identity and nationalism: cooperation and conflict; (D) race, place, and inequality. Repeatable up to two times in different alphas. Graduate students only. (Alt. years)

title: Conflict Analysis/Resolution
description: Seminar on the analysis of conflict resolution. Faculty from law, planning, political science and guest practitioners will present multidisciplinary analysis and intervention strategies on contemporary conflicts. A-F only. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Seminar in Social Structure and the Individual
description: Intensive study and individual research projects in a selected topic. Theoretical and methodological issues in relating social and individual levels of analysis. Recommended: 612.

title: Seminar in Social Movements
description: Study of sociology of social movements, plus independent student research. Repeatable one time.

title: Development in Asia
description: Theories and available research methods examined for applicability to developing areas; specific examples from Asia. A-F only. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Urban Sociology
description: Demographic trends in urban growth: nature and dimensions of urbanization and urbanism; ancient, American, and Third World cities; ecological theories of urban growth; lifestyles.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Disability and Diversity in the Media
description: Explores the changing disability experience as described in contemporary film, literature, advertising, news, sports and dialogue with persons with disabilities in the Pacific region and around the world. A-F only.

title: Global and Historical Perspectives of Disability in the Media
description: Explores the history of disability representation across cultures. Emphasis is placed on examining evolving perceptions of disability as depicted in art, literature, print, film, and digital media. A-F only. FGB

title: Foundations of Inclusive Schooling
description: Foundations of “special education” exploring philosophies, diverse and historical viewpoints, laws, and service delivery. Students reflect upon texts, films and interviews with persons with disabilities, their families and professionals to understand the culture of disability. A-F only.

title: Special Education Law and Compliance
description: Analysis of legislation, litigation, and administrative rulings in special education, with an emphasis on teaching expository writing and developing legally sound policies/procedures that ensure educationally meaningful and legally correct education for students with disabilities. BEd in SPED majors only. A-F only. (Summer only)

title: Introduction to Special Education Assessment
description: Assessment methods and techniques to inform special education decisions, including the use of standardized assessments for initial eligibility, reevaluations, and annual reviews for special education services. BEd in SPED majors only. A-F only. 304 (or concurrent). (Fall only)

title: Introduction to Specialized Instruction
description: Characteristics and educational programming for students with disabilities. Role and responsibilities of the special educator, founding principles and current practices in special education with an emphasis on teaching writing. BEd in SPED majors only. A-F only. 304 (or concurrent). (Fall only)

title: Field Training – Blended ECE
description: Students spend 15 hours per week in settings appropriate to concurrently enrolled classes; supervision provided by participating teacher and college supervisor. Repeatable two times. A-F only. (

title: Young Children with Communication Needs
description: Communication development of infants and young children, ages birth through age 8, with and without disabilities. Assessment and intervention to support the development of communication skills in inclusive community and school environments. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Student Teaching in Special Education
