description: Full-time supervised experience in school. (B) elementary/special education; (C) early childhood education/special education; (D) unclassified. Repeatable one per alpha. A-F only. Co-requisite: 391B for (B); 391C for (C); 391D for (D).

title: (Alpha) Seminar for Student Teachers in Special Education
description: Seminar relating current educational theories with experiences. (B) elementary/ special education; (C) early childhood education/ special education; (D) unclassified. Repeatable one time per alpha. A-F only. requirements for registration listed under “student teaching.” Co-requisite: 390B for (B); 390C for (C); 390D for (D).
prerequisites: requirements for registration listed under “student teaching

title: Student Teaching in Special Education Modified
description: Modified student teaching for students from another institution completing student teaching at UH or for students who have prior extensive teaching experience. A-F only. requirements for registration listed under “Student Teaching,” approval of review committee and consent.
prerequisites: requirements for registration listed under “Student Teaching,” approval of review committee and consent

title: (Alpha) Field Training in Special Education
description: Students participate in classroom settings appropriate to concurrently enrolled courses; supervision provided by department field supervisor; (B) first semester; (C) second semester, with ethical issues in education discussed and applied in field settings; (D) third semester, with emphasis on writing and oral communication for application in field settings. SPED majors only. Repeatable one time per alpha. A-F only. 304 (or concurrent) or consent for (B); 400B for (C); 400C for (D).
prerequisites: SPED 304 (or concurrent) or consent for (B); SPED 400B for (C); SPED 400C for (D)

title: Writing for Educational Professionals
description: Instruction on learning to write as professional educators. Strategies for developing and enhancing professional writing for the field of education. Peer and instructor feedback on writing throughout course. Technologies used to assist with writing. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Individuals with Severe Disabilities/ Autism
description: Etiology, characteristics, and development of individuals with severe disabilities and autism; historical, theoretical, and legal issues affecting individuals with severe disabilities and autism; multicultural, family, and consumer issues; professional and ethical issues in providing services. A-F only.

title: Education of Gifted Students
description: Characteristics and educational provisions for gifted children and youth with particular attention to psychological aspects of creativity

title: Education Program for the Gifted/ Talented
description: Utilization and evaluation of teaching/ learning models for gifted/talented students, including consideration of roles, expectancies for learning, and organizational procedures.

title: (Alpha) Strategies for Reading Difficulties
description: Overview of methods, programs, and strategies for reading instruction designed to improve the performance of elementary students, grades K-6, who experience difficulties in reading acquisition, fluency, and comprehension. (B) elementary/special education; (C) early childhood education/special education; (D) unclassified. Repeatable one time per alpha. A-F only.

title: Vocabulary Comprehension, Fluency & Writing Interventions for Students with Disabilities
description: Development of and intervention for fluent reading vocabulary acquisition, comprehension and writing in students with disabilities. Explicit and systematic instruction of core aspects of reading and writing. A-F only. 421B, 421C, or 421D. (Summer only)

title: (Alpha) Partnerships with Families and Professionals
description: Knowledge and skills for relating effectively with families and professionals on behalf of the children and youth with and without disabilities. Coverage of the context in which family members and school personnel interact. (B) elementary/special education; (C) early childhood education/special education; (D) unclassified. Repeatable one time per alpha. A-F only.

title: Disability and Diversity in Physical Activity
description: (3 Lec, 1 1-hr. Lab) Participants will explore issues related to individuals with exceptionalities, how these affect learning and behavior in the health and physical activity settings. Oral communication practice and skills are worth >30% grade. Required field experience. A-F only.

title: Educating Exceptional Students in Regular Classrooms–Elementary
description: Teaching elementary students with disabilities and those who are gifted/talented. Meeting academic/social needs, classroom management, motivation, peer interaction, collaboration between special and regular educators. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing.

title: Educating Exceptional Students in Regular Classrooms–Secondary
description: Teaching secondary students with disabilities and those who are gifted/talented. Meeting academic/social needs, classroom management, motivation, peer interaction. Collaboration between special and regular educators. Includes an emphasis on instruction in writing.

title: Seminar in Special Education
description: Study of issues, trends, and research into special education programming and service delivery. Repeatable two times. consent.

title: Programs for Infants/Toddlers
description: Examination of current theory, research, issues, and models in programs for infants and toddlers including criteria for evaluation and planning. A-F only. HDFS 230 (or concurrent) and HDFS 331 (or concurrent), or consent. (
prerequisites: HDFS 230 (or concurrent) and HDFS 331 (or concurrent), or consent

title: Preschool Children–Special Needs
description: Examination of application of current research and practices for serving preschool children with special needs. HDFS 230 (or concurrent), or consent.

title: Physical and Medical Needs-Severe Disabilities/Autism
description: Learning to teach children with physical and health impairments, with a focus on developing independence. Instructional and assistive strategies for meeting the student’s physical and medical needs as well as managing medical conditions. BEd in SPED majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Non-School-Age Individuals with Severe Disabilities/Autism
description: Effective planning, instruction, and support for non-school-age individuals (infants, toddlers, and adults) with severe disabilities or ASD across natural environments. BEd in SPED majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Secondary Transition-Mild/Moderate Disabilities
description: Transition planning for youth with disabilities in preparation for postsecondary education, employment, and community living. BEd in SPED majors only. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Introduction to Assessment and Instruction-Severe Disabilities/Autism
description: Assessment methods and tools, instructional and assistive strategies, and special procedures to support the participation of students with severe disabilities and autism in inclusive settings. BEd in SPED majors only. A-F only. (Fall only

title: (Alpha) Assessment, Planning, and Instruction for Students with Mild/Moderate Disabilities
description: Techniques in the assessment, planning, and instructional process appropriate for students with mild/moderate disabilities. Stress on program development to facilitate inclusion of students with disabilities into general education environment. (B) elementary/special education; (C) early childhood elementary/special education; (D) unclassified; (E) secondary. BEd in SPED majors only for (E). A-F only. (Spring only for (E))

title: (Alpha) Assessment, Planning, and Instruction for Students with Severe Disabilities/ Autism
description: Techniques in the assessment, planning, and instructional process appropriate for students with severe disabilities/autism. Focus on program development to facilitate the inclusion of students with disabilities into general education settings. (B) elementary/special education; (C) early childhood education/special education, emphasis on writing instruction in teaching special education; (D) unclassified. A-F only.

title: Inclusive Practices Across the Curriculum-Mild/Moderate Disabilities
description: Strategies for teaching science, math, and social studies to students with mild/moderate disabilities in secondary settings; selection of appropriate materials, teaching techniques, and curriculum development. BEd in SPED majors only. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: Assistant-Level Applied Behavior Analysis Fieldwork
description: Field experience in applied behavior analysis at the assistant level supervised by a Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA). The format is a combination of fieldwork and seminar meetings. Repeatable nine times, up to 20 credits. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Instructional and Assistive Technology
description: Addresses instructional and assistive technologies for special education and general education settings; technology-based instructional strategies that support inclusion and address academic and behavioral objectives; and application of Universal Design for Learning to support access to the general curriculum for diverse students in the PreK-12 classroom setting. (B) elementary/special education; (C) early childhood education/special education; (D) unclassified. Repeatable one time per alpha; repeatable up to six credits for (B). A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Classroom Organization and Management
description: Knowledge and skills related to basic organizational management of an inclusive classroom, including scheduling, grouping, and stress and time management; techniques of applied behavior management, emphasizing behavior change and practical implementation of learning principles. (B) elementary/special education, V credits; (C) early childhood education/special education; (D) unclassified. Repeatable up to six credits for (B). A-F only.

title: Theoretical Basis for Teaching Special-Needs Students
description: Survey of biophysical, behavioral, social/ecological, psychodynamic/ psychoeducational, cognitive/developmental, counter-theoretical approaches to teaching exceptional students. Opportunity for the development and/ or strengthening of one’s own theoretical frame of reference.

title: Characteristics/Strategies for Teaching At-Risk Students
description: Survey of educational, behavioral, and emotional characteristics of students who are at-risk for school failure and strategies to work with such students. A-F only.

title: Intensive Behavioral Interventions
description: Principles of behavior, emphasizing positive methods for eliminating significant behavior problems and improving behavior and learning for students with severe disabilities and autism. BEd in SPED majors only. A-F only. 485B, 485C, or 485D. (Spring only)

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Individual reading, research, and/or projects under direct supervision of instructors. Repeatable nine times. consent of instructor or department chair.
prerequisites: consent of instructor or department chair

title: Post-Baccalaureate in Special Education Program Seminar
description: Mandatory program seminar for Post-Baccalaureate in Special Education (PBSPED) teacher candidates; access to tools and skills necessary for distance education program success; Introduction to the Special Education teaching profession. Post-Bac in SPED majors only. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Field Experience in Special Education-Post Baccalaureate
description: Students spend between 100-135 hours over a semester in settings appropriate to SPED-PCert program emphasis (mild/moderate or severe/autism); supervision provided by participating teacher and/or college supervisor. Repeatable one time, up to 6 credits. Post-Baccalaureate in Special Education only. A-F only. 304 or 412.

title: Student Teaching in Special EducationPost Baccalaureate Programs
description: Supervised student teaching with a master teacher in PreK-12 educational settings appropriate to SPED-Pcert emphasis (mildmoderate, severe/autism); minimum 280 hours in minimum 11 weeks. Supervision by master teacher and university supervisor. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Internship in Special Education-Post Baccalaureate Programs
description: Supervised teaching experience in PreK-12 educational settings appropriate to SPED-Pcert program emphasis (mild/moderate or severe/autism); supervision provided by master teacher/university mentor, and university supervisor. Must enroll for two consecutive semesters. Repeatable two times, up to 14 credits. A-F only.

title: (Alpha) Practicum in Special Education
description: For in-service school/community personnel to present new ideas, approaches, instructional methods, materials for teaching exceptional individuals. (B–E) general SPED; (F–G) secondary programming/ SPED; (H–I) bilingual/multicultural/special needs; (J–K) severe disabilities; (M–N) early childhood/ special needs; (O–P) career/vocational/special needs; (Q–R) computer/special needs; (S–T) arts/special needs; (U–W) computer training/special needs; (X–Y) consultant skills/special needs; (Z) Ho‘okoho. Repeatable nine times. CR/NC only. teaching or related work experience.

title: (Alpha) Practicum in Special Education
description: For in-service school/community personnel to present new ideas, approaches, instructional methods, materials for teaching exceptional individuals. (B–E) general SPED; (F–G) secondary programming/SPED; (H–I) bilingual/multicultural/special needs; (J–K) needs; (Q–R) computer/special needs; (S–T) arts/ special needs; (U–W) computer training/special needs; (X–Y) consultant skills/special needs; (Z) Ho‘okoho. Repeatable nine times. CR/NC only. teaching or related work experience.

title: (Alpha) Practicum in Special Education
description: For in-service school/community personnel to present new ideas, approaches, instructional methods, materials for teaching exceptional individuals. (B–E) general SPED; (F–G) secondary programming/ SPED; (H–I) bilingual/multicultural/special needs; (J–K) severe disabilities; (M–N) early childhood/ special needs; (O–P) career/vocational/special needs; (Q–R) computer/special needs; (S–T) arts/special needs; (U–W) computer training/special needs; (X–Y) consultant skills/special needs; (Z) Ho‘okoho. Repeatable eight times. CR/NC only. teaching or related work experience.

title: Internship, Special Education
description: Supervised field activities involving the programming and instruction of special-needs students within training programs in Hawai‘i and the Pacific Basin. consent.

title: Foundations of Exceptionality
description: Theoretical, legal and multicultural foundations for assessing, teaching and developing individual service plans across the lifespan for persons with disabilities. A-F only. consent.

title: Instructional/Assistive Technology and Universal Design for Learning
description: Strategies for using instructional and assistive technology, digital tools and media, and Universal Design for Learning to support learning needs of students with disabilities and other diverse learners in the K-12 classroom. one of 480, LTEC 414, or LTEC 442.
prerequisites: one of SPED 480, LTEC 414, or LTEC 442

title: Special Education Law and Compliance
description: Examination of the federal, state, and local government roles in special education with special emphasis on case and regulatory law. Focus on understanding special education law necessary in providing services to students with disabilities in a variety of placements. Appropriate for special/general education teachers, administrators, or related service providers. consent.

title: Principles of Behavior
description: Principles and laws governing behavior and methods that can be used to accomplish educationally relevant changes in student performance. Emphasis on the conceptual basis for changing behavior and use of technologies for changing behavior in school and community settings. A-F only. consent.

title: Collaboration in School and Community Settings
description: Collaboration skills necessary to function as team members and to ensure the success of students with disabilities in inclusive school and community settings. A-F only. consent.

title: Language Development for Deaf Children
description: General theories of first and second language development applied to development of ASL and English in deaf children. Relationship of theory to educational practice. Taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. admission into Deaf Education program or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: admission into Deaf Education program or consent

title: Audiology and Spoken English for Deaf Students
description: Developmental principles of audiology and speech (i.e., spoken English) will be used to examine assessment procedures and intervention strategies appropriate to deaf students in a variety of educational placements. Classroom applications will be presented. Taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. admission into Deaf Education program or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: admission into Deaf Education program or consent

title: Literacy Development for Deaf Students
description: Basic concepts related to language, language development and recognition of language-related learning problems of deaf students; strategies for teaching reading and writing to deaf students. Repeatable one times. A-F only. 461 and 606, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Seminar in Bilingual Deaf Education
description: Study of issues, trends and methods in ASL/ English bilingual education for deaf students. Taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 606, 607 and 608; or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: SPED 606, SPED 607 and SPED 608; or consent

title: Advanced Assessment and Curriculum Development–Deaf
description: Assessment methods and techniques used with deaf students that emphasize the bond between curriculum-based assessment and curriculum-based programming through planning and providing cyclical instruction across content areas based on ongoing diagnostic assessment. Taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 609 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Methods and Strategies for Students with Mild/Moderate Disabilities
description: Techniques for providing effective instruction including: best instructional practice, lesson planning, teacher-directed and student-mediated instructional strategies, and curricular approaches for working with students with mild/moderate disabilities. A-F only. 304 or consent.

title: Advanced Assessment and Curriculum Development
description: Assessment methods and techniques that emphasize the bond between curriculum-based assessment and curriculum-based programming. Planning and cyclical instruction across content areas based on ongoing diagnostic assessment. SPED majors only. A-F only. 461 or consent.

title: Assessment and Instruction—Severe Disabilities and Autism
description: Basic principles of assessment, instruction, and curriculum development; application of formal and informal assessment procedures for goal selection, formulating instructional plans, and adapting instructional materials to accommodate learning needs of students with severe disabilities and autism. consent.

title: Family-Centered Approaches in Deaf Education
description: Prepare teachers to deliver family-centered home-based services to families of deaf children using the SKI-HI model. Course will be taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 606, 607 and 608; or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: SPED 606, SPED 607 and SPED 608; or consent

title: Collaboration–Working with Deaf Students in Inclusive Settings
description: Collaboration skills for working with general education teachers, specialists, paraprofessionals, families and community members to support the success of deaf students in inclusive settings. Taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 606, 607 and 608; or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: SPED 606, SPED 607 and SPED 608; or consent

title: Transition Strategies for Deaf Students
description: Collaborative model for facilitating the transition of deaf and hard-of-hearing students to develop appropriate transition plans and effective plans of study. Taught in ASL and English. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 606, 607 and 608; or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: SPED 606, SPED 607 and SPED 608; or consent

title: Adaptations and Special ProceduresStudents/Severe Disabilities/Autism
description: Adaptations and special intervention procedures to support the participation of individuals with severe motor, communication, and/or adaptive behavior disabilities in inclusive school and community settings. Includes lab work. SPED majors only. A-F only. consent.

title: Strategies Across Content Area
description: Strategies for teaching math, science, and social sciences to students of all ages with mild/moderate disabilities; selection of appropriate materials, teaching techniques, curriculum development. 611 or consent.

title: Language Arts Strategies: Students with Mild/Moderate Disabilities
description: Basic concepts related to language, language development, and recognition of language-related learning problems of students with mild/moderate disabilities; strategies for teaching language arts curricula (listening, speaking, reading, writing) to students of all ages with learning problems. A-F only. 304 or consent.

title: Children’s Literature for Deaf Students
description: Introduction to English literature translated into American Sign Language (ASL) including discussion of ASL literature genres, the importance of translation, selection of literature; story reading, book reading, and retelling. Taught in ASL. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 609 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Teaching Skills for Social Competence
description: Issues in social development, self-determination, and social skills competence training for children and youth with disabilities; experience in group social skills training and development of individualized programs. either 485 or 630, and either 611 or 614; or consent.
prerequisites: either SPED 485 or SPED 630, and either SPED 611 or SPED 614; or consent

title: Field Experiences in Special Education
description: Students spend a minimum of nine hours per week in settings appropriate to concurrently enrolled courses; supervision provided by participating teacher and college supervisor. Repeatable three times. A-F only. consent.

title: Advanced Practicum
description: Supervised education/community experiences; minimum of 20 hours weekly with special-needs population (MR, LD, SED, SMH); -school through postsecondary settings (public/private). Related seminar or equivalent and completion of SPED core required. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Internship
description: Supervised education/ community experiences with special needs populations, preschool through postsecondary settings. A-F only. Repeatable two times, up to six credits.

title: Clinical Practice Special Projects
description: Development and implementation of a field-based research professional development project under the direction of the student’s advisor; limited to students enrolled in the interdisciplinary program. Repeatable up to 9 credits. A-F only. advisor’s approval.

title: Positive Behavioral Support-Severe Disabilities and Autism
description: Principles and laws governing human behavior and positive methods for eliminating significant behavior problems for students with severe disabilities and autism. Emphasis on the functions of behavior, experimental techniques for documenting behavior change, and the use of technologies for improving behavior in school and community settings. A-F only. consent.

title: Early Intervention for Special Populations
description: Issues important to early childhood special education. Early screening and assessment, working with families, curriculum options/models, program evaluation. consent.

title: Language/Communication Intervention-Communication Disorders/Autism
description: Current research in normal language learning, assessment, planning, implementation, evaluation of language delayed/disordered children, including children with autism. Procedures for attaining language/functional communication objectives using ongoing routines/activities. consent.

title: Motor Development/Intervention for Students with Severe Disabilities
description: Normal/ abnormal motor development; description/etiology of physically disabling conditions influencing motor development; analysis/application of assessment/intervention strategies to promote motor development; positioning and handling skills. 614 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Inclusive Physical Activity
description: Advanced knowledge on issues of socio-cultural, learning styles, diversity, and exceptionalities, and how these influence instruction, engagement, and behavior in physical activity settings across the lifespan. A-F only. consent. (

title: Procedures for Early Childhood Special Education
description: Assessment and intervention strategies to promote behavior change with young children with disabilities. Promoting child skill gains and integrated programming options. A-F only. consent.

title: Topics and Issues in Reading Difficulties
description: Introduction of foundational knowledge of language and literacy development. Current topics and issues related to literacy development in students with Dyslexia and related reading difficulties. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Fundamentals of Language and Literacy
description: Introduction of basic linguistic structures of written English related to reading, spelling, and writing for beginning or struggling readers. Covers evidence-based practices for teaching literacy to students with Dyslexia and related reading difficulties. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Advanced Fundamentals of Language and Literacy
description: Advanced linguistic structures of written English related to reading, spelling, and writing for older students. Covers diagnostic assessment, planning, instruction, and progress monitoring for students with Dyslexia or related reading difficulties. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Seminar on Mild/Moderate Disabilities
description: Study of issues, research, program development in the area of mild/moderate disabilities. Repeatable two times. consent.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Issues in Special Education
description: Seminar on issues, trends, research, and program development in the field of special education. (B) current issues and trends; (C) technology; (D) foundations; (E) developmental disabilities; (F) cultural and linguistic diversity; (G) evidence-based practices; (H) single case research. Repeatable one time per alpha, repeatable two times for (H). A-F only. 603 for (H).

title: Seminar on Applied Research/Special Education
description: Study and development of applied research topics in special education. Repeatable two times. consent.

title: Seminar on Severe/Multiple Disabilities
description: Research, program development trends/issues in the area of severe/multiple disabilities (birth through adulthood). College of Education majors only. consent.

title: Seminar in Early Childhood Special Education
description: Study of issues/trends. Research and program development in early childhood special education. Repeatable one time. (631 and 635) with a minimum grade of B- or better, or consent.
prerequisites: (SPED 631 and SPED 635) with a minimum grade of B- or better, or consent

title: Leadership in Special Education
description: Seminar on topics related to leadership in the field of special education, including issues for teacher leaders, administrators, and teacher preparation personnel. A-F only. consent. (Fall only)

title: Seminar on Universal Design for Learning
description: Seminar on issues of research and practice on the application of universal design for learning in K-12 and higher education settings. Focus on culturally and linguistically diverse students diversity, non-traditional students and students with disabilities. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Transition/Supported Employment
description: Transition planning for youth with disabilities in preparation for employment as adults in private and public sector businesses. A-F only. consent.

title: Reading Assessment & Tiered Intervention for Students with Disabilities
description: Selection and administration of formal and informal assessments within a problem-solving model for designing robust reading instruction for struggling readers. Guiding planning and reading intervention using data-based decision-making. Graduate students only. A-F only. 421B or 421C or 421D, and 423. Co-requisite: 629.
prerequisites: SPED 421B or SPED 421C or SPED 421D, and SPED 423

title: Advanced Diagnostic-Prescriptive Reading Intervention
description: Structural and functional features of reading development using diagnostic-prescriptive reading intervention. Advanced diagnostic-prescriptive intervention selection and design for students with reading disabilities using tool-component-composite analysis. Graduate students only. A-F only. 655. Co-requisite: 629.

title: Advanced Principles of Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA)
description: Focuses on the definitions and characteristics of applied behavior analysis and the concepts, principles, and processes. Concepts related to ethics and behavior change procedures will also be introduced. A-F only. 603.

title: Ethics and Professional Conduct
description: Focuses on content on the Behavior Analysis Certification Board’s code for ethical conduct as well as advanced concepts, principles, and processes of applied behavior analysis. A-F only.

title: Applied Behavior Analysis Fieldwork
description: Field experience in applied behavior analysis supervised by a Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA). The format is a combination of fieldwork and seminar meetings. Repeatable nine times, up to 20 credits. A-F only.

title: Research Practicum in Special Education
description: Directed research experience to demonstrate mastery of research skills and techniques through developing and writing research proposals. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 642 or consent, or departmental approval. (Once a year)
prerequisites: SPED 642 or consent, or departmental approval

title: Plan B Master’s Project
description: Independent study for students working on a Plan B master’s project. Repeatable two times. A-F only. graduate standing in Special Education.

title: Directed Reading/Research
description: Individual reading/research. Repeatable unlimited times. consent of instructor and department chair.
prerequisites: consent of instructor and department chair

title: Thesis Research
description: Research for master’s thesis. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Exceptionalities
description: Current and historical topics, issues, and trends in the field of exceptionalities. Repeatable with different content. consent.

title: Doctoral Internship
description: Supervised internship (minimum 18 hours per week) in program development and administration or research in the student’s area of emphasis. EDUC majors only. A-F only. consent.

title: Professional Seminar in Exceptionalities
description: Professional norms, duties, and expectations of leaders in exceptionalities; transitioning from practitioner to researcher and leadership roles; familiarity with current research and trends in the field of exceptionalities. Repeatable five times. PhD in EDUC majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Single-Case Experimental Design
description: Advanced single-case experimental design; examines the logic of internal and external validity of small “N” design and its functionalist foundations. consent.

title: Special Topics in Exceptionalities
description: Critical examination and discussion of historical or current topic in early intervention, special education, and/or developmental disabilities. Repeatable two times. A-F only. (Once a year)

title: Grant Development/Procurement
description: Overview of grant development and procurement processes related to special education personnel preparation and research and demonstration programs. Students design a grant proposal related to a particular problem or need within their employment settings. consent.

title: Introduction to Stage, Screen, and New Media Writing
description: Introduction to college level writing and information literacy for and about the stage (theatre, dance, performance), the screen (film, television), and new media (digital platforms, social media). A-F only. (

title: Introduction to World Drama and Theatre
description: (2 Lec, 1 1-hr Lab) Performance traditions of Africa, Asia, Australia, Europe, North America, and the Pacific from the 5th century B.C. to the present. Analysis of political, religious, and technological conditions of theatre. Includes practical theatre workshop. Emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only.

title: Live on Stage
description: Students view locally produced theatre and dance productions and write performance reviews. Readings, writing, and class discussion will guide students to understand each performance. Performances include theatre, dance, musical theatre, opera, and performance art. Repeatable one time. (Spring only) (

title: (Alpha) Beginning Practicum
description: Beginning workshop experience in the practical application of performing arts skills. (B) performance; (C) stagecraft; (D) costume; (E) performing arts management; (F) directing dramaturgy stage management choreography. Repeatable up to four credits in each alpha. (B) audition and performance of role in a Department of Theatre and Dance production; (F) consent. (
prerequisites: (B) audition and performance of role in a Department of Theatre and Dance production; (F) consent

title: Introduction to the Art of the Film
description: Introduction to the aesthetics of silent and sound movies. Technical subjects analyzed only as they relate to theme and style.

title: Introduction to Long-Form Improvisation
description: Introduction to long-form improvisation as developed by companies such as Second City and iO Chicago. Focus will be on games, situations, creating characters, and forming narratives from those elements. Repeatable two times.

title: Development of the Sound Film
description: Growth and changes in aesthetics of the sound film from 1929 to present; films by Renoir, Welles, Eisenstein, etc. 201. (Alt. years)

title: Beginning Voice and Movement
description: Introduction to vocal and movement techniques to increase self-awareness and potential for self-expression. Repeatable one time.

title: Introduction to Acting for Stage and Screen
description: Beginning acting techniques for theatre and screen media including exercises, improvisations, monologues, and scenes. Focus on voice, relaxation, body awareness, and freedom from self-consciousness. Emphasis on writing instruction as appropriate to discipline. Repeatable one time with consent.

title: Acting I: Foundations and Techniques for Stage and Screen
description: Fundamentals of contemporary acting styles for stage and screen, including self-awareness, character, and scene work. Repeatable one time with consent. THEA major or 221, or consent.
prerequisites: THEA major or THEA 221, or consent

title: Pidgin/HCE Drama
description: Introduction to Hawaiian Creole English (HCE) multicultural comedy and drama in Hawai‘i. Emphasis on acting exercises, local dialects, and the performance of Pidgin/HCE plays. Repeatable one time with consent. (Alt. years)

title: Introduction to Stage Production
description: Survey class introducing theater management, lighting, costuming, scenery, and other aspects of theatre that relate to producing stage performances. (

title: Theatre Production Lab
description: Lab observations and projects illustrating basic principles of theatre production. A-F only. Co-requisite: 240.

title: Film/TV Production Process
description: Entry-level course details three phases of the production process for film and video projects: -production, production, and post-production. A-F only. consent.

title: Principles of Design
description: Introduction to general design principles as applied to theatre. Will introduce the language and tools of visual literacy and visual communications via individual projects and collaboration. Repeatable two times. (

title: Introduction to Voice Function and Singing Styles
description: Students will study how the singing voice works in various styles, including classical, musical theater, jazz, choral, and pop/ rock. Students will learn historical contexts, aural characteristics, and musical vocabulary through lecture, discussion, and listening. (Fall only) (

title: World Theatre I: Script Analysis
description: Script analysis methods for world drama. Develops written and oral communication skills. Required of all majors. one of 101, 221, 222, 240; or consent.
prerequisites: one of THEA 101, THEA 221, THEA 222, THEA 240; or consent

title: World Theatre II: Myth to Drama
description: Myth and ritual into drama, 1000 BCE–1700 CE. Development of secular drama from sacred and ritual beginnings. Required of all majors. 311 (Alt. years)

title: Playwriting
description: One-act plays; practice in writing in dramatic form. Repeatable one time. grade of B or better in composition or consent.
prerequisites: grade of B or better in composition or consent

title: Screenplay Writing
description: Characterization, structure, theme, image, and other components of writing for film. 201 and grade of B or better in composition, or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: THEA 201 and grade of B or better in composition, or consent

title: Auditioning
description: Preparation of material from different audition situations, including monologues, cold readings, dance, singing, and TV/ film. Repeatable one time with consent. 221 or 222 or consent.

title: Acting II: Advanced Scene Study
description: Further exploration of character development and dramatic action through textual analysis. Repeatable one time with consent. 221 or 222 or consent.

title: Film/TV Acting
description: Acting techniques for film and TV production. Students appear in scenes from TV and film scripts. Repeatable one time. 101 or 221 or 222 or COM 201 or consent.
prerequisites: THEA 101 or THEA 221 or THEA 222 or COM 201 or consent

title: Advanced Film/TV Acting
description: Advanced acting techniques for film and TV production. Taping/filming of scenes and full-length scripts. Repeatable one time. 323 and consent.

title: Introduction to Asian Acting Styles
description: Principles of acting based on traditional Asian models. Voice, movement exercises. 221 or 222 or consent.

title: Taiji (T’ai Chi) for Actors I
description: Basic Taijiquan (T’ai Chi Ch’uan) movement training. Repeatable two times. Sophomore standing or higher. consent. (

title: Taiji Round Form for Actors
description: Introduction to basic Asian movement skills through learning the Wu-style taijiquan round form, a faster and more fluid version of the full 108 taiji sequence of forms. Open to non-majors. Repeatable two times. Sophomore standing or higher. consent.

title: Introduction to the Performing Arts of Southeast Asia
description: Introduction to the history and development of major performing arts genres in Southeast Asia: theatre, dance-drama, opera, music, puppetry, ritual, and modern spoken drama. Topics include cultural identity, multiculturalism, modernization, and tourism. Online course. (

title: (Alpha) Topics in Theatre Production
description: Workshop in principles, techniques, and application of contemporary theatre production practices. (B) entertainment electrics: lighting, sound, special effects, projections, and related areas; (C) technical production: technical direction, technical design, construction, rigging, and related areas; (D) scenic painting: techniques of scene painting for theatre through reading, drawing exercises, color theory, and practical projects; (E) props and crafts: techniques to create props for theatre. Repeatable one time for different alphas, each alpha can be taken one time. any course in THEA or DNCE, or production experience; or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: any course in THEA or DNCE, or production experience; or consent

title: Lighting I: Beginning Lighting Design
description: Basic principles of lighting design and associated technologies. Includes functions and properties of light, lighting and control equipment, working procedures, and drafting and paperwork techniques. THEA/DNCE 240 or consent. (Once a year) (

title: Scenic I: Beginning Scenic Design
description: Workshop introducing the basic principles and approaches of scenic design for theatre and dance, with emphasis on the creative process. a course in THEA or DNCE, production experience, or consent. (Consent required for production experience option) (
prerequisites: a course in THEA or DNCE, production experience, or consent

title: Introduction to Costume Construction
description: Workshop on basic principles of costume construction for theatre and dance. Professional practices, materials, and methods. (

title: Costumes I: Beginning Costume Design
description: Basic principles and approaches to costume design for theatre and dance. Visual communication methods, creative process, historical research, and organizational practices. Repeatable one time. 240, or consent. (

title: Stage Makeup Workshop
description: Western and traditional Asian makeup theory and application practice. Western corrective, period, and old age makeup. Asian may include Jingju, Kabuki, Wayang. Repeatable one time. 240 or consent.

title: Performance and Medicine
description: Survey of key texts on medicine and performance, and on how these two areas intersect, including representations of medicine and illness in contemporary drama and performance-based practices within medicine. Repeatable one time.

title: Curtain Up! Broadway Musicals, Then and Now
description: Traces the history of the Broadway musical in a survey of works from the mid-1800s through the recent “Hamilton” phenomenon, and explores their developmental process, structure, and sociocultural, religious, and political contexts. MUS 106 or consent. (

title: Movement Improvisation
description: Introduces movement improvisation to all levels and disciplines. Movement studies will explore improvisation approaches, devices, elements, exercises, and implications to gain skills in and appreciation for the art of improvisation. Repeatable one time. (

title: Beginning Directing
description: Basic practical course in how to direct a play. Students will direct scenes. Emphasis on writing instruction. THEA and DNCE majors only. upper division theatre majors or consent.
prerequisites: upper division theatre majors or consent

title: (Alpha) Advanced Practicum
description: Advanced workshop experience in the practical application of performing arts skills. (B) performance; (C) stagecraft; (D) costume; (E) performing arts management; (F) directing dramaturgy stage management choreography. Repeatable up to four credits per alpha. audition and performance of role in a Department of Theatre and Dance production for (B); 200C for (C); 200D for (D); 200E for (E); 200B or 200C or 200F, and consent for (F). (
prerequisites: audition and performance of role in a Department of Theatre and Dance production for (B); THEA 200C for (C); THEA 200D for (D); THEA 200E for (E); THEA 200B or THEA 200C or THEA 200F, and consent for (F)

title: World Theatre: Elite and Popular
description: Interplay between elite and popular forms to 1900. Develops written communication skills. 311 (or concurrent). (Alt. years)

title: World Theatre: Modern
description: Pluralism in modern theatre, 1900–present. Reactions to realism and current international theatre forms, develops written communication skills. 311 (or concurrent). (Alt. years)

title: (Alpha) Approaches to Dramatic Texts
description: Intensive analysis and discussion of dramatic texts from a variety of authors. Understanding trends and variations in dramatic form and content. (B) contemporary British and American drama; (C) political drama in the West. one of 311, 312, 411, 412, or consent.
prerequisites: one of THEA 311, THEA 312, THEA 411, THEA 412, or consent

title: Women, Gender, & Sexuality in Performance
description: Feminist and performance studies approaches to performances by women and other genders; focus on the representation and status of women 311 or consent. (

title: Advanced Playwriting
description: Workshop in experimental writing in dramatic form; full-length plays. Repeatable one time. 318.

title: (Alpha) Intermediate Voice for the Actor
description: Training in proper and dynamic use of the voice for the actor. (B) Western traditions; (C) Asian traditions. Repeatable two times. 220 or consent.

title: Musical Theatre
description: Training in skills required to perform in musicals. Students present scenes from musical comedies for criticism and review. Repeatable two times with consent. one of 321, 322, MUS 231B, or consent; and/or audition. (
prerequisites: one of THEA 321, THEA 322, MUS 231B, or consent; and/or audition

title: Period Styles in Acting
description: Presentational acting in comedy and tragedy; emphasis on performance styles in Elizabethan, Restoration, and 18th-century drama. Repeatable one time with consent. 222 or 322 or consent.

title: Acting Shakespeare
description: Techniques for acting in Shakespearean and heightened language texts. Repeatable one time. 222, 322, or consent.

title: Hawaiian Performance Workshop
description: Training in skills and techniques for selected traditional Hawaiian performance forms and Hawaiian medium theatre. Emphasis on movement and vocal technique. Repeatable one time. one of: 101, 221, 224, 468, HAW 202, HAW 321, HAW 384, HAW 486, DNCE 312, DNCE 411, DNCE 412; or consent.
prerequisites: one of: THEA 101, THEA 221, THEA 224, THEA 468, HAW 202, HAW 321, HAW 384, HAW 486, DNCE 312, DNCE 411, DNCE 412; or consent

title: South/Southeast Asian Acting Workshop
description: Training in skills and techniques for selected traditional south and southeast Asian theatre forms. Emphasis on movement and vocal techniques. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 222 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Chinese Acting Workshop
description: Training in skills and techniques for selected traditional Chinese theatre forms. Emphasis on movement and vocal technique. Repeatable to six credits. 221, 222, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Japanese Acting Workshop
description: Training in skills and techniques for selected traditional Japanese theatre forms. Emphasis on movement and vocal technique. Repeatable to six credits. 221, 222 or consent. (Alt. years) DA

title: Contemporary Performance Practices
description: Focus on individual training in the skills and techniques of contemporary experimental theatre including acting, directing, and self-scripting. Repeatable two times. one of 222, 318, 380, or consent.
prerequisites: one of THEA 222, THEA 318, THEA 380, or consent

title: Stage Combat
description: Techniques for performing unarmed and armed stage combat. Repeatable one time. one of 221, 222, 321, 322; or consent.
prerequisites: one of THEA 221, THEA 222, THEA 321, THEA 322; or consent

title: Movement Workshop
description: Special workshops in movement relating to specific departmental theatrical productions beyond the scope of movement taught in 437 and 438. Repeatable one time. (Alt. years) (

title: Taiji (T’ai Chi) for Actors II
description: Intermediate-level Taijiquan (T’ai Chi Ch’uan) movement training. Repeatable two times. 334 or consent. (

title: Movement for Actors
description: Training actors to discover experientially the sources of movement; to teach skills for analyzing movement for its mechanical, anatomical, spatial, and dynamic content; and then to apply these skills in a role. 222 or consent. (

title: Advanced Movement for Actors
description: Detailed development of material presented in 435. Focus on Bartenieff fundamentals and movement analysis as it applies to the physical interpretation of theatrical roles. one of 435, DNCE 435, or consent. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: one of THEA 435, DNCE 435, or consent

title: Musical Theatre Dance Forms
description: Theatrical dance forms used in 20th-century musical theatre. 100 level or above dance technique class, 421, or consent. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: THEA 100 level or above dance technique class, THEA 421, or consent

title: Topics in Costume Construction
description: Costume production techniques, both Western and Asian, for theatre and dance. Topic rotation includes: understructures and armatures, patterning, tailoring, dyeing, fabric modification, millenery and crafts, within the context of current industry practice. Repeatable two times. A-F only. 354, 356, or consent. (

title: Stage Management
description: Business, organization and management for theatre and dance productions. Junior standing or higher. consent.

title: Introduction to Computer-Aided Design for the Theatre
description: Basic concepts and techniques of 2D computer-aided design. Lecture/ workshop covers language and commands common to most CAD packages with a focus on drafting specific to theatre. A laptop with Vectorworks installed is required. 343 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Costumes II: Intermediate Costume Design
description: Advanced costume design for theatre and dance. Introduction to collaborative process in costume. Intensive work on rendering skills, applied to various design problems. Cost analysis and organizational techniques. 356 or consent. (

title: Drama and Theatre of Oceania
description: Survey of the contemporary drama and theatre of Oceania that combines island and Western traditions. Includes Papua New Guinea, Hawai‘i, Fiji, Samoa, Australia, New Zealand. 101 or ANTH 350, or consent. (

title: Drama and Theatre of Southeast Asia and India
description: Court, folk, popular traditions, and the manner of their production. consent.

title: Drama and Theatre of China
description: Yuan, southern, spoken drama; Beijing opera and the manner of their production. consent.

title: Drama and Theatre of Japan
description: Survey of Japanese theatre forms, from traditional to contemporary. Includes examination of dramatic texts, performance elements, and historical context, utilizing written, aural, and visual materials. Junior standing or above. 311 or consent.

title: Drama and Theatre of Hawai‘i
description: Survey of indigenous theatre forms of Hawai‘i, Native Hawaiian, and other ethnic playwrights, and contemporary multicultural landscape of drama and theatre in Hawai‘i. Sophomore standing or higher. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Chinese Music and Sound Culture
description: Situates the Chinese musical sound in the interdisciplinary field of sound culture. Students will learn to read music literature and listen to historical sounds critically and to analyze aspects of Chinese sound culture. (

title: Creative Drama
description: Dramatic activities for young people. For teachers, group workers, recreation majors, and others dealing with children. Supervised field activities.

title: Masked Performance
description: History, techniques, construction, and performance of theatrical masks. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. 221 or consent. DA

title: Storytelling
description: Storytelling development through focused activities on personal artistic practice, story content, and public performative techniques. Repeatable one time.

title: Theatre for Young Audiences
description: Theories and principles of formal theatre for young audiences. Study of and practice in the selection, direction, and production of plays.

title: Puppetry for Young Children
description: Methods of constructing puppets and stages with and for children 3 to 8 years of age. Use of puppets in the creative arts. Fieldwork.

title: Puppetry
description: History and scope of puppetry. Construction and presentation of puppets for adult and child audiences. Repeatable one time.

title: Giant Puppetry
description: History, construction, and performance techniques for large-scale and giant puppets. For teachers, recreation directors, and others working with students aged 10 to 18 and adults

title: Hula Ki‘i: Hawaiian Puppetry and Image Dancing
description: History, techniques, construction, and performance of Hawaiian puppetry and traditional image dancing. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher.

title: Intermediate Directing
description: Workshop; students direct one-act plays. Repeatable one time with consent. 380 and consent. (Alt. years)

title: Experimental Theatre Studio
description: Working collectively, students research, write, design, develop, and perform a full-length production. Repeatable two times. 6 credits above the 200 level in acting, directing, playwriting, dancing; or consent.
prerequisites: THEA 6 credits above the THEA 200 level in acting, directing, playwriting, dancing; or consent

title: (Alpha) Topics in Drama and Theatre
description: (B) theatre traditions; (D) contemporary theatre. Repeatable two times each for (B) and (D). Junior standing or consent.

title: Directed Work
description: Individual projects; tutorial. Repeatable two times. consent.

title: Seminar in Theatre Research
description: Bibliography and research methods; preparation for thesis and dissertation writing. Required of many graduate theatre majors.

title: Seminar in Major Theatre Theory
description: Major theatre theories from antiquity to the present and across a broad range of cultures. Repeatable one time with consent. consent. (Alt. years)

title: Theatre in Europe: Classical to 1700
description: Theatre as a cultural and social institution in the West, from ancient Greece to Restoration England. one of 311, 312, 411, 412, or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: one of THEA 311, THEA 312, THEA 411, THEA 412, or consent

title: Theatre in Europe and the U.S., 1700-Present
description: Theatre as a cultural and social institution in Europe and the U.S., from the 18th century to the present. one of 311, 312, 411, 412, or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: one of THEA 311, THEA 312, THEA 411, THEA 412, or consent

title: (Alpha) Topics in Dramaturgy
description: (B) role of the dramaturg; covers history, theory, and practice; (C) dramaturgy workshop; accompanies specific Kennedy Theatre productions. Repeatable one time per alpha. consent. (Alt. years)

title: Performance Theory
description: Introduction to key texts and concepts of performance studies. consent. (

title: Script Analysis
description: Theory and practical application of script analysis with reference to dramatic texts from various cultural traditions. consent.

title: Seminar in Performance Studies
description: Special topics. Repeatable up to two times when topics change. 615 or consent. (

title: Digital Multimedia Tools for Performance Research
description: Dance, Theatre, Music Majors only. A-F only. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Advanced Topics: Playwriting and Dramatic Theory
description: Readings, research, writing, and seminar discussions. 418, 611, and consent.

title: Advanced Voice for the Actor
description: Training at advanced level in speaking and vocal skills and techniques in preparation for a solo performance. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 420 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Great Roles in Acting
description: Great roles from the Western theatre repertory; focus on the individual actor and performance styles. Repeatable one time with consent. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Experimental Asian Acting
description: Integration of movement, vocal technique, and concepts of traditional Asian genres into the actor’s repertory. Exploration of application to contemporary Asian and non-Asian texts. Workshop format. Repeatable one time. THEA and DNCE majors only. consent.

title: Advanced Topics in Performance
description: Readings, discussion, research, and/or performance work. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits. THEA and DNCE majors only. consent. (

title: Taiji Weapons for Actors
description: Advanced level Taijiquan (T’ai Chi Ch’uan) weapons training. Repeatable two times. 334 or 434, or consent.

title: Historic Costume and Decor
description: Overview of visual styles in fashion, textiles, architecture, ornament, and furniture for production and entertainment design through lecture, lab, and discussion.

title: Lighting II: Intermediate Lighting Design
description: Workshop in intermediate techniques and skills of lighting design; storytelling, analysis, research, envisioning, and communicating a design plan, execution of successful design projects. Use of communication tools such as mini-plots, light renderings, LightWright, and VectorWorks. Repeatable one time. 345 (with a minimum grade of B) or equivalent experience.
prerequisites: THEA 345 (with a minimum grade of B) or equivalent experience

title: Lighting III: Advanced Lighting Design
description: Workshop dealing with special topics in theatrical lighting design and related skills. Repeatable two times. THEA or DNCE majors only. 644 or consent.

title: Professional Advancement in Entertainment Design
description: Directed study designed to help MFA candidates in Design acquire the tools helpful in obtaining future employment. Portfolios, resumes, and related application tools will be developed along with other necessary skills. Must be current MFA candidate in theatre. Repeatable six times. THEA majors only. Graduate students only.

title: Scenic II: Intermediate Scene Design
description: Workshop in advanced techniques and skills of scenic design; research, presentation, rendering, drafting, and model making. 353 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
prerequisites: THEA 353 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Scenic III: Advanced Scenic Design
description: Workshop dealing with special topics in scenic design, related skills, and portfolio preparation. Repeatable two times with consent. 453 or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Advanced Topics in Costume Construction
description: Advanced costume production techniques for entertainment design. Topics may include corset, draping, patterning, tailoring, dye work, fabric modification, millinery, leatherwork, and crafts. Topics presented within the context of both current entertainment industry and traditional practices. Repeatable three times for different topics. 354 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
prerequisites: THEA 354 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Costumes III: Advanced Costume Design
description: Workshop dealing with special topics in costume design and related skills. Repeatable one time with consent. A-F only. 456 or consent.

title: Seminar in Design
description: Research, design, and discussion exploring collaborative design problems and solutions. Repeatable two times. A-F only. 445, 453, 456; or consent.

title: Business for the Arts
description: Seminar offering overview and foundation for launching or advancing enterprises in the arts. A focus on the processes and method for creating economically successful grants and project development applications. consent. (

title: Field Research Methods
description: Goals and methods. Grant writing, interview, questionnaire, observation, and performance study as research techniques. Practical application by designing a research project. 600.

title: (Alpha) Topics in Asian Theatre
description: Comparative and cross-cultural examination. (B) origins; (C) theories and systems; (D) modern Asian drama. Repeatable one time. consent.

title: Advanced Topics in Performance in Hawai‘i
description: Analysis of Hawai‘i’s indigenous performance traditions, the contemporary multicultural landscape of theatre in Ko Hawai‘i Pae ‘āina, and the representation of Kanaka Maoli and settler voices on Hawai‘i’s stages. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. consent. (

title: Seminar in Advanced Creative Dramatics
description: Advanced seminar in applied methods and theories of creative dramatics. Repeatable one time. THEA or DNCE majors only.

title: Interdisciplinary Collaborations
description: Hybrid performance works for dancers, musicians, actors, visual artists, poets, and writers to explore the nature of the collaboration process in various settings. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. THEA, DNCE, MUS, ART, ENG majors only. (

title: (Alpha) Topics in Theatre for Young Audiences
description: Creative movement/drama, puppetry, and theatre/dance; (B) production concepts. Repeatable when topics change. one of 470, 474, 475, 476, 477, DNCE 490; or consent.
prerequisites: one of THEA 470, THEA 474, THEA 475, THEA 476, THEA 477, DNCE 490; or consent

title: Directing Asian Theatre
description: Directing traditional Asian theatre pieces and Western plays performed with Asian techniques; development of new performance styles based on Asian examples; directing of scenes and one-act plays. Repeatable one time with consent. graduate theatre major and one Asian theatre course, or consent.
prerequisites: graduate theatre major and one Asian theatre course, or consent

title: Advanced Topics in Theatre Directing
description: Readings, discussion, research, and/or performance and scene work. Repeatable five times, up to nine credits. THEA majors only. consent.

title: Graduate Workshop in Directing
description: Direction of scenes and major one-act plays. -thesis production. Repeatable one time with consent. 600 or consent.

title: Workshop in Directing Process
description: Methods class in theatre production for the director. Covers organization and techniques such as rehearsal planning, scheduling, and execution. Repeatable one time.

title: Directing Western Styles
description: Students direct scenes in classic or non-realistic western theatre styles or genres. Repeatable one time with consent. THEA majors only. A-F only. Graduate student in theatre program. consent. (Alt. years)

title: Graduate Theatre Workshop
description: Practical and supervisory theatre work pertinent to professional degree objectives on productions being done in Kennedy Theatre or in other venues, by approval. Repeatable eight times, up to 9 credits. THEA majors only. consent.

title: Seminar in Teaching Dance/Theatre
description: Pedagogy and classroom experience in teaching technique and theory. (Alt. years) (

title: Practicum in Teaching
description: Supervised teaching experience at the introductory or undergraduate level. Students will teach an appropriate level course in their field of expertise under faculty supervision. Repeatable up to nine credits. THEA or DNCE majors only. (

title: Internship: Youth Theatre/Dance
description: Supervised leadership experiences in theatre/dance program with children. Students spend nine hours per week in supervised setting and three hours in weekly class meeting. one of 470, 476, or DNCE 490; or consent. (
prerequisites: one of THEA 470, THEA 476, or DNCE 490; or consent

title: Creative Projects
description: MFA play or dance productions, design projects, original full-length plays. Repeatable unlimited times.

title: (Alpha) Professional Internship
description: Internship program where students will work for or with a professional theatre company under supervision of a UH faculty member, plus possible supervisor(s) from the theatre company. Students must participate hands-on in production activities of that company and receive a satisfactory (or better) review from their supervisor(s); (B) entertainment design: costume, lighting, scenery, props, sound, or other related disciplines; (C) performance: acting, directing, dance, choreography, or other related disciplines. Repeatable eight times per alpha, up to nine credits per alpha. A-F only. 345 or 353 or 356 for (B); 621 or 682 or DNCE 371 for (C). (
prerequisites: THEA 345 or THEA 353 or THEA 356 for (B); THEA 621 or THEA 682 or DNCE 371 for (C)

title: Directed Research
description: Reading or research in theatre theory or history; reading and practice in particular areas of dramatic production. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Seminar in Drama and Theatre
description: Special topics. Repeatable when topics change. consent.

title: (Alpha) Seminar in Asian Theatre
description: (B) Southeast Asia and India; (C) China; (D) Japan. Repeatable two times. one of 464, 465, 466, or consent.
prerequisites: one of THEA 464, THEA 465, THEA 466, or consent

title: Seminar in Hawaiian & Indigenous Performance
description: Exploration, analysis, and application of Kanaka Maoli and Indigenous research methodologies, epistemologies, performance theory, methods, and praxis. Repeatable two times. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Seminar in Theatre for Young Audiences
description: Theories and methods applied in theatrical experiences with and for young audiences: creative movement/drama, puppetry, and theatre/ dance. one of 470, 474, 475, 476, 477, or DNCE 490.
prerequisites: one of THEA 470, THEA 474, THEA 475, THEA 476, THEA 477, or DNCE 490

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times.

title: Experimental Art and Animation
description: Provides students an opportunity to experiment with new mediums while collaborating with artists from different backgrounds, such as art, theatre, dance, film, and animation. SCA, ART, THEA, DNCE majors only. ART 113 or CINE 216 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 353 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 356 (or concurrent). (
prerequisites: ART 113 or CINE 216 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 353 (or concurrent) or CINE/DNCE/THEA 356 (or concurrent)

title: Court Interpreting I
description: Introduction to the legal system, as well as theoretical principles, ethics, practical techniques, and current issues surrounding the practice and profession of court and other legal interpreting. Repeatable one time.

title: Community Interpreting
description: Basic principles, ethics and skills involved in community interpreting in medical, legal, and social service settings; practical information about the community interpreter’s role and profession; practice of various community interpreting situations and techniques. Repeatable one time.

title: Court Interpreting II
description: Combined lecture/ discussion/practice. Continuation of 405 Court Interpretation, diving deeper into the practical side of oral interpreting for various proceedings, including arraignments, trials, witness testimonies, etc. Must be bilingual. Real courtroom observations required. Repeatable one time. 405 or consent.

title: Medical Interpreting
description: Healthcare interpreting requires students to understand basic biosystems, common illnesses and treatments, as well as interpreting skills. Students must have 402 or above equivalency of second language skills (or instructor approval). Repeatable one time. 406 or consent.

title: (Alpha) Consecutive Interpretation
description: Extensive note-taking and note-reading in a bilingual context. Focuses on the translation of numbers, acronyms, initials, and economic and financial information. (J) Japanese; (K) Korean; (M) Mandarin; (O) other; (S) Spanish. Repeatable one time. A-F only. CITS screening exam.

title: (Alpha) Simultaneous Interpretation
description: Simultaneous interpretation of speeches. Focus on the study of formulaic and frozen language characteristically used in international meetings. (J) Japanese; (K) Korean; (M) Mandarin; (O) other; (S) Spanish. Repeatable one time. A-F only. CITS screening exam.

title: (Alpha) Sight Translation
description: Focus on the ability to translate orally information from a written text. Emphasis on improving linguistic (discourse analysis) and communicative (public speaking) skills. (J) Japanese; (K) Korean; (M) Mandarin; (O) other; (S) Spanish. Repeatable one time. A-F only. CITS screening exam.

title: Directed Reading/Studies
description: Independent study of approved readings and research with faculty supervision. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits. A-F only.

title: International Exchange Study/Research
description: Study overseas in an approved international or similar exchange program. CR/NC only. consent of academic advisor.

title: Introduction to Sustainability from Social Science Perspectives
description: Introduction to key concepts and theories in social sciences in relation to sustainability issues. (

title: Scientific Principles of Sustainability
description: Introduction to the scientific principles of sustainability, including the ecology of managed and natural ecosystems, global change biology, ecological principles of natural resource management, renewable energy technologies, and the environmental impacts of humans.

title: Extension Education & Outreach
description: Introduces an essential component of the Land Grant Mission. Students will explore the foundational components of extension education including agent expectations, program development and evaluation, audience engagement, building partnerships, funding structures. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (

title: (Alpha) Plants for People
description: The origins: social, cultural, and ceremonial traditions; culture; food and nutritional properties. Processing of a variety of tropical horticultural plants are presented, with tasting sessions and optional field trips. Topics will rotate among (B) beverage crops (e.g., coffee, tea, chocolate, kava, fruit juices); (C) herbs, spices, and flavoring (selection of examples to be determined); (D) tropical fruits (assortment offered depends on availability during semester); (E) ornamental plants (flowers, houseplants, popular landscape plans, bonsai, ethnic ornamentals). Does not count towards TPSS major. consent.

title: Sustainable Food and Energy (Field Course)
description: Examines the nexus of food, energy, and water in Hawai‘i for sustainable development. Repeatable two times, up to nine credits. (

title: Natural History Field Trips on Hawai‘i Island
description: Field trips for Natural history and Conservation of the Hawaiian Islands. A-F only. Co-requisite: 156. (Summer only)

title: Agriculture, Environment, and Society
description: Relationship of plants, soils, and the environment, and how they relate to cultural practices and society in agroecosystems with an emphasis on Hawai‘i as a model system. (

title: Aquaponics
description: Basic online course integrates aquaculture (raising fish and prawns) with hydroponics plant cultivation in water. Includes the basic design and construction of an aquaponics feed system. Repeatable one time. (Summer only)

title: Organic Food Crop Production
description: Combined lecture/lab on the theory and practice of certified organic food production. Field visits to organic farms/markets included. Open to nonmajors. (Fall only) (

title: Scientific Principles of Sustainability
description: Introduction to the scientific principles of sustainability, including the ecology of managed and natural ecosystems, global change biology, ecological principles of natural resource management, renewable energy technologies, and the environmental impacts of humans. (

title: Tropical Production Systems
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Comparisons and contrasts of crop management systems, techniques, and technologies in protected and open field production of tropical crops. 200/SUST 211 or consent.

title: Fundamentals of Soil Science
description: Origin, development, properties, management of tropical soils; classification of Hawaiian soils. A-F only. Minimum grade of C or consent. (CHEM 161 and 161L) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. Co-requisite: 304L. (Fall only) (

title: Fundamentals of Soil Science Laboratory
description: Field and analytical methods for exploring the origin, development, properties, and management of soils, with an emphasis on tropical and Hawaiian soils. A-F only. (CHEM 161 and CHEM 161L) with a minimum grade of C. Co-requisite: 304. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: (CHEM 161 and CHEM 161L) with a minimum grade of C

title: Current Topics in Plant Science
description: Undergraduate seminar that provides the presentation and discussion of topics of current relevance to students preparing for careers in applied plant sciences. Oral focus designation. A-F only. 200/ SUST 211 or NREM 210, or consent. (
prerequisites: TPSS 200/ SUST 211 or NREM 210, or consent

title: Farm & Food Marketing
description: Problems, agencies, functions, costs, prices, regulations affecting marketing: proposed improvements. ECON 130, NREM/SUST 220; or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Understanding Agroecosystems: Visualization, Interpretation, Analysis, and Application
description: Designed for students interested in developing a critical framework for understanding different ways of measuring, visualizing, and interpreting the different goals humans have for agroecosystems. Repeatable one time. 200 or instructor consent. (Fall only)

title: Renewable Energy and Society
description: Combined lecture/discussion regarding the ability of renewable energy technologies to meet local, national, and global energy demands and their potential impacts on the environment and society. consent.

title: Managerial Accounting
description: Principles and methods of agricultural accounting. Preparing and interpreting financial statements. Sources and costs of credit, capital budgeting, tax management, estate planning. Repeatable one time. A-F only. ECON 130 or NREM/SUST 220, or consent. (

title: Tropical Landscape Practices
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Concepts and techniques of landscape installation and management in the tropics. 200/ SUST 211 and 369; or consent.
prerequisites: TPSS 200/ SUST 211 and SUST 369; or consent

title: Enterprise Management
description: Introduction of practical concepts and methods used in business management. Introduce broad range of business strategies. Understand the critical role each strategy plays. Facilitate student’s practice of analytical and critical thinking through case studies. (

title: Landscape Architecture History
description: Survey of the history of landscape architecture from Mesopotamia to present. Review of the physical, cultural, social, economic, and political factors, as well as the environmental concerns, horticultural techniques, and technological innovations of historic landscapes. A-F only. (Spring only) (

title: Landscape Graphics Studio
description: Basic skills of landscape graphic communication through a creative process model. Learning free hand and technical drafting techniques to creative effective landscape graphics. consent. (Alt. years) (

title: Tropical Landscape Planting Design Studio
description: Students will develop basic skills of residential landscape graphic and design processes in order to clearly articulate the ability to think, analyze, and extend a physical solution in the proper scale. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (Alt. years) (

title: Horticulture: Theory and Practice
description: Techniques of culture and management of horticulture crops. consent.

title: Ornamental Plant Materials
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Identification, origin, use, and cultural requirement of trees, shrubs, vines, and groundcovers used in Hawaiian landscapes. 200/SUST 211 or consent.

title: Genetics: Theory to Application
description: Fundamentals of genetic theory using traditional breeding and biotechnological procedures in insect and plant pathogen management for sustainable agricultural production. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (

title: Vegetable Crop Production
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Crop biology, requirements, and production techniques for commercial vegetable production in Hawai‘i will be stressed. 300 or consent.

title: Flower and Foliage Crop Production
description: Biology and production of cut flowers, blooming potted plants, foliage plants under field and protected cultivation in Hawai‘i and globally. 300 or consent.

title: Tropical Fruit Production
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Botanical aspects and horticultural management practices of selected tropical and subtropical fruit crops, with emphasis on small scale commercial production in Hawai‘i. 300 or consent.

title: Turfgrass Management
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Adaptability and selection, establishment, and cultural practices of grasses for various types of turf. 200/SUST 211 or consent.

title: Cultural Biogeography
description: Co-evolution of human societies and plants over the last 10,000 years. Foraging, farming and urban societies economies; spread and modification of selected plants; issues of preservation of genetic resources and traditional plant knowledge. The form and function of gardens. junior standing or higher, or consent.
prerequisites: junior standing or higher, or consent

title: Sustainable Soil and Plant Health Management
description: Provides knowledge and understanding of soils, agroecology, and sustainable approaches for plant health management, and prepares students for applied research in various tropical cropping systems. A-F only. (Alt. years: spring) (

title: Extension Education & Outreach
description: Introduces an essential component of the Land Grant Mission. Students will explore the foundational components of extension education including agent expectations, program development and evaluation, audience engagement, building partnerships, funding structures. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (

title: Introduction to Social, Ethical and Political Issues Associated with Biotechnology
description: Introduces concepts of biotechnology, fundamental issues associated with use of this technology, with special emphasis on agricultural biotechnology. A-F only. 200/SUST 211 or BIOL 171 or NREM 210, or consent. (Alt. years)
prerequisites: TPSS 200/SUST 211 or BIOL 171 or NREM 210, or consent

title: Turfgrass Pest Management
description: Provides students with knowledge and real world experience on common turfgrass pests and management strategies in Hawai‘i, with emphasis on integrated pest management. Common cool-season turfgrass and pest management are also discussed. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Plant Propagation
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Theoretical and applied aspects of seed and vegetative propagation technology involving fruits, flowers, vegetables, and landscape plants. 200/SUST 211 or consent.

title: Tropical Seed Science
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of seed science, seed physiology, seed production, and genetic modification. Hawai‘i’s seed industry and biotechnology. A-F only. 364 (recommended) and 420 (recommended), or consent.

title: Spreadsheet Modeling for Business and Economic Analysis
description: Introduction to quantitative decision-making methods for effective agribusiness management in resource allocation, scheduling, logistics, risk analysis, inventory, and forecasting. Emphasis on problem identification, model formulation and solution, and interpretation and presentation of results. ECON 130 or NREM/ SUST 220, and ECON 321 or NREM 310; or consent. (Once a year)
