prerequisites: ECON 130 or NREM/ SUST 220, and ECON 321 or NREM 310; or consent

title: Nursery Management
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Management practices in production and operations of commercial nurseries in Hawai‘i. 200/SUST 211 and 364; or consent.

title: Indigenous Crops/Food Systems
description: Schemes for managing sequences and combinations of crops and crop production activities. Ecosystem and social determinants. Multiple cropping. Analysis of alternative cropping systems. Repeatable unlimited times, but credit earned one time only. Junior standing or higher.

title: The Biology of Fungi
description: Will introduce the diversity, ecology, evolution, and biology of the Kingdom Fungi. Focus on our current understanding of fungal evolution and diversity and how fungi interact with environments and hosts. (BOT 201, BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C; or consent. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: (BOT 201, BIOL 172) with a minimum grade of C; or consent

title: The Biology of Fungi Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Introduction to the morphology and life cycles of organisms in the Kingdom Fungi. Focus on learning how to identify a diversity of fungi based on macro- and microscopic features. Field trips to collect specimens. (BOT 430 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C. or consent. (Spring only) (
prerequisites: (BOT 430 (or concurrent)) with a minimum grade of C

title: Environmental Soil Chemistry
description: Study of soil chemical processes such as weathering, adsorption, precipitation, and ion exchange; causes of soil acidity, alkalinity, and salinity; reactions between soils and fertilizers, pesticides, or heavy metals. Management strategies to minimize environmental contamination by nitrate, phosphate, and trace elements such as As, Pb, and Se. A-F only. 304 or consent. (Fall only)

title: Tissue Culture/Transformation
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Application of plant tissue culture for plant scientists; study of the growth and development of plant tissues in culture as influenced by chemical and environmental factors, and the regeneration of plants following plant transformation by biolistics and other molecular approaches. 420 or consent. DB

title: Sustainable Nutrient Management in Agroecosystems
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Biological, chemical, and physical processes governing the cycling of nutrients in agroecosystems, crop and livestock production, and the effects on surrounding unmanaged ecosystems. (304 and CHEM 161) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent. (
prerequisites: (TPSS 304 and CHEM 161) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent

title: Plant Breeding and Genetics
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Unique aspects of plant genetics and applications to crop improvement, with emphasis on breeding plants in Hawai‘i. BIOL 375 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Soil Plant Environment
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Bio-physical processes in the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum that influence crop growth and development. Methods to estimate the impact of soil and climate on crop performance. Use of crop models to simulate effects of planting date, plant spacing and density, fertilizer rate, rainfall or irrigation, and daily weather on crop yield and farm income. 304 and either PHYS 151 or PHYS 170, or consent.
prerequisites: TPSS 304 and either PHYS 151 or PHYS 170, or consent

title: Irrigation and Water Management
description: Basic soil-water-plant relationships, irrigation water requirements, irrigation efficiencies, different methods of irrigation, planning, design and management of an irrigation system, fertigation and impact of irrigation on soil and water quality. NREM 203 (or equivalent) and NREM/TPSS 304 (or equivalent), or consent. (Alt. years) (
prerequisites: NREM 203 (or equivalent) and NREM/TPSS 304 (or equivalent), or consent

title: Plant Physiology
description: Integration of form and function from cellular to whole plant levels in processes from seed germination, through photosynthesis, growth, and morphogenesis, to flowering and senescence. A-F only. BIOL 171 or consent.

title: Principles of Plant Physiology Lab
description: (1 3-hr Lab) Principles of experimentation in plant physiology, includes individual investigations. A-F only. consent.

title: Post-Harvest Physiology
description: Comparative physiological and biochemical processes during growth, maturation, ripening, and senescence in fruits, vegetables, and flowers related to changes in quality and storage life. Tropical commodities emphasized. A-F only. 200/SUST 211, BIOL 171, or BOT 201; CHEM 152; or consent.
prerequisites: TPSS 200/SUST 211, BIOL 171, or BOT 201; CHEM 152; or consent

title: Plant Nutrient Diagnosis in the Tropics
description: Designed for students to identify essential nutrients required by plants; diagnose nutrient disorders in plants; and propose environmentally sound solutions to correct disorders. 304/NREM 304 (or concurrent) and BIOL 172. (

title: Life in the Soil Environment
description: An interdisciplinary study of the diverse life in the soil beneath our feet that includes bacteria, fungi, protists, nematodes, arthropods, invertebrate, viruses, and the essential functional roles these organisms contribute to sustainability of the planet. Repeatable one time. TPSS/PEPS/SUST 371 or BIOL 375, or MICR 351, or consent. (
prerequisites: TPSS/PEPS/SUST 371 or BIOL 375, or MICR 351, or consent

title: Life in the Soil Environment Lab
description: Laboratory to accompany 480. Technical examination of bacteria, fungi, protists, nematodes, arthropods, and other invertebrate, and the essential functional roles these organisms contribute to sustainability of the planet. Repeatable one time. BIOL 171L and 172L, or MICR 351L, or consent. Co-requisite: 480.
prerequisites: BIOL 171L and BIOL 172L, or MICR 351L, or consent

title: Weed Science
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Weed classification, identification, adaptations for weediness; principles of weed control; properties, uses, and action of herbicides. Lab: pesticide application equipment and techniques, no-till farming, greenhouse and field experiments. A-F only. (200/SUST 211 and CHEM 152) with a minimum grade of C, or consent. (Fall only) (
prerequisites: (TPSS 200/SUST 211 and CHEM 152) with a minimum grade of C, or consent

title: Experimental Topics
description: Study and discussion of significant topics, problems. Offered by visiting faculty and/or for extension programs. Repeatable. consent.

title: Internship
description: Integration and application of academic knowledge and critical skills emphasizing professional development. Placement with an approved cooperating supervisor/employer. consent.

title: Internship Experience
description: Internship field experience for TPSS majors. TPSS majors only. A-F only. 200/SUST 211 (or concurrent) or consent.

title: Directed Studies
description: Supervised individual instruction in field laboratory and library. Repeatable up to six credits. CR/NC only. 364 or consent.

title: Crop Modeling
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Principles of modeling crop growth and development, model types, techniques, simulation. Modeling influence of climate/environment on phenology, growth, development of horticultural crops. 470 and NREM 310, or consent.

title: Experimental Design
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Design of experiments and variance analyses in biological and agricultural research. graduate standing or consent. Recommended: ZOOL 632. (

title: Advanced Soil Microbiology
description: (3 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Study of biochemical and biogeochemical transformations mediated by soil microorganisms, emphasis on processes important to plant growth productivity and environmental quality. 304 and MICR 351, or consent.

title: Nutrition of Tropical Crops
description: (1 2-hr Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Mineral nutrition of plants in relation to plant metabolism, mechanisms of ion uptake, long-distance transport of solutes, and interactions at the root-soil interface. Special emphasis on problems associated with tropical crops. 450 and 470, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Professional Development
description: Lecture/discussion targets students exiting from graduate degree programs and provides preparation as a career professional; topics include establishing a professional identity; CV and cover letters, job-seeking due diligence, and negotiation skills. Graduate students only. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: Molecular Genetics of Crops
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Applications of molecular genetics to crop improvement. (453 and MBBE 402) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent.
prerequisites: (TPSS 453 and MBBE 402) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent

title: Quantitative Genomics and Evolution
description: Overview and lab-based course exploring theory and methods to understand genome evolution and adaptation; focus will be on a range of organisms. (453 and 603) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent.
prerequisites: (TPSS 453 and TPSS 603) with a minimum grade of C-, or consent

title: Landscape Plants: Identification and Use
description: Introduction to the identification, recognition, and use of plants in landscape design and built environment applications. Students will be introduced to a variety of landscape plants commonly used in Hawai‘i and the tropics. TPSS majors only. A-F only. (

title: Advanced Soil Chemistry
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Physio-chemical processes in soils and soil solutions, with emphasis on ionic equilibria, mineral stability, organic complexation, and surface sorption of major plant nutrients and heavy metals. A-F only. 435 and CHEM 351, or consent.

title: Soil Plant Nutrient Relations
description: (2 Lec, 2 3-hr Lab) Soil-plant interactions, emphasis on characteristics of tropical soils and plants influencing nutrient uptake by plants. Diagnostic methods to identify nutrient deficiencies and element toxicity. 450 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent. (
prerequisites: TPSS 450 (with a minimum grade of C-) or consent

title: Information Research Skills
description: Examines the use of libraries and information technology for scholarly investigation in support of scientific research; provides experience utilizing and critically evaluating a variety of print and electronic sources in basic and applied sciences. consent. (

title: Communications in the Sciences
description: (3-hr Lec/Lab combination) Laboratory-type course for improving communication abilities in the sciences and engineering. Presentations to lay audiences are emphasized. Hands-on experience in techniques and methods is provided.

title: Environmental and Cultural Landscape Studio
description: Exploring, understanding, and implementing Hawaiian and Western cultural and environmental landscape design principles. A concentrated look at how to think about creating and respecting a sense of place through landscape design. TPSS and LAND majors only. A-F only. (

title: Grant Writing for Graduate Students
description: Combined lecture/discussion on grants and grant writing. Designed to introduce graduate students to grants and grant proposal writing through lectures, class discussion, writing assignments, and peer review. Open to CTAHR graduate students only; others with consent. (

title: Environmental Landscape Technologies and Systems
description: Understanding the science and art of green landscape technologies, with a comprehensive understanding of LID (low impact design) principles and practices; to increase knowledge to help produce more viable and enduring built landscapes. TPSS majors only. A-F only. (

title: Orchidology
description: (2 Lec, 1 3-hr Lab) Classification, culture, cytogenetics, breeding of orchids. consent. Recommended: 200/SUST 211 and 402.

title: Graduate Seminar
description: Presentation of research reports; reviews of current literature in plant and soil sciences. Repeatable four times. graduate standing or consent.

title: Sustainability of Food Systems
description: Explores sustainability and resilience of food systems with an emphasis on Hawaiʻi, using interdisciplinary approaches to assess impacts. Repeatable one time. consent. (Alt. years: fall)

title: Plant Growth and Development
description: Contemporary literature is used as the basis for understanding the physiology for whole plant growth and development. Aspects covered include vegetative and reproductive development, seed dormancy, senescence, abscission, and relevant biochemical and molecular processes. 470 and MBBE 402, or consent.

title: Geospatial Analysis of Natural Resource Data
description: The application of geostatistics to estimate spatial dependence to improve soil and regional sampling; provide insight into underlying soil, geographic, and geologic process, and to provide quantitative scaling up of point measurements to fields, regions, and watersheds. State-space modeling also will be included. A-F only. GEO 388 or ZOOL 631; or consent. (

title: Plan B Master’s Project
description: Independent study for students working on a Plan B master’s project. A grade of Satisfactory (S) is assigned when the project is satisfactorily completed. A-F only. graduate standing in TPSS program.

title: Directed Research
description: In-depth study of specialized problems. Repeatable unlimited times. CR/ NC only. consent.

title: Thesis Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Special Topics
description: Specialized topics from various areas of plant and soil research such as experimental techniques, growth regulation, morphogenesis, genetics and breeding, culture and nutrition of tropical crops. A-F only. consent.

title: Dissertation Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. CR/NC only. consent.

title: Sustainable Cities
description: How do we plan cities to meet long-term social, economic, and environmental needs? Students will learn about sustainability as it relates to issues like energy, transportation, housing, land, water, and food. Emphasis on writing instruction. A-F only. (

title: Survey of Urban Sociology
description: Urban processes and social problems, such as poverty, crime, racial segregation, homelessness, housing policy, urbanization, and neighborhood ethnic diversity. How places shape identity and opportunity. Research methods applied to communities, places, and neighborhoods of Hawai‘i. SOC 100 or a 200-level SOC course, or consent. (
prerequisites: SOC 100 or a SOC 200-level SOC course, or consent

title: Introduction to Planning
description: Perspectives on planning; planning tools and methods; specific Hawai‘i planning–research problems from a multidisciplinary approach. Junior standing or higher or consent.

title: Directed Reading in Planning
description: Independent research on topics in urban and regional planning. 310.

title: Environmental Impact Assessment
description: Introduction to analytical methods for identifying, measuring, and quantifying the impacts of changes or interventions in resource, human-environment, and other geographic systems. Junior standing or higher, or consent. (Alt. years)

title: Environmental Hazards and Community Resilience
description: Examines resilience thinking as it relates to making cities resilient to environmental hazards in the context of climate change. Draws on relevant theories, policy, and case studies in urban planning. Emphasis on instruction in writing. Junior standing or higher.

title: Urban Geography
description: Origins, functions, and internal structure of cities. Problems of urban settlement, growth, decay, adaptation, and planning in different cultural and historical settings. Dynamics of urban land use and role of policies and perceptions in shaping towns and cities. GEO 102 or GEO 151 or GEO 330, or consent. (
prerequisites: GEO 102 or GEO 151 or GEO 330, or consent

title: Sustainable Asian Development: Impact of Globalization
description: Investigates the impact of globalization on sustainable development in Asia. Globalization and sustainability often contradict, raising serious planning issues. Examines how these issues affect Asian development policies and urban planning. 310 or ASAN 310 or ASAN 312, or consent. (
prerequisites: PLAN 310 or ASAN 310 or ASAN 312, or consent

title: Principles of Environmental Management Systems
description: Introduction to the process of developing Environmental Management Systems that address the principles outlined in ISO14001:2015. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. (Spring only)

title: Asian Cities: Evolution of Urban Space
description: Reviews the evolution of Asian urban space. Political history, migration, culture, and production are the determinants of urban changes. Uses visual material to illustrate the change in Asian cityscape. 310 or ASAN 310 or ASAN 312, or consent. (
prerequisites: PLAN 310 or ASAN 310 or ASAN 312, or consent

title: GIS for Community Planning
description: Exploration of geographic information systems (GIS) area analysis techniques for spatial information management in community planning. Students will learn the basic concepts and principles, and practical skills of GIS through lectures, discussions, and labs. Repeatable one time. Junior standing or higher.

title: Housing, Land, and Community
description: Analyzes availability for housing, particularly affordable housing, and its relationship to use of land and building of community. Examines public policies impacting housing, land use, and community development and ways they can be improved.

title: Public Policy and Planning Theory
description: Designed to a impart a historic and comparative perspective on the evolution of urban and regional planning in public policy; b explore the spatial and built environment dimensions of society, planning and policy; c assess the justifications for planning and differing processes of planning in the U.S. and AsiaPacific with a focus on the role of the planner in policy formulation and implementation. Graduate students only or with permission. A-F only. Repeatable two times.

title: Planning Methods
description: Introduction of the basic methods in planning, including problem definition, research design, hypothesis testing, statistical reasoning, forecasting and fundamental data analysis techniques required by the planning program and the planning profession. Repeatable one time. PLAN and ARCH majors only. one of ECON 321, GEO 380, or SOC 476.
prerequisites: one of ECON 321, GEO 380, or SOC 476

title: Advanced Planning Theory
description: Advanced planning theory for PhD students (others by petition) to prepare for careers in planning education and/or high level professional practice. Covers key contemporary planning policy issues and themes from the perspective of values, explanations of the real world, policy alternatives and implementation. Students must have passed 600 or equivalent (by petition) with a B or better. Repeatable one time. PhD students only or by consent. A-F only. 600 or consent.

title: Urban Economics
description: Reviews and builds skills in applying basic theories and principles of urban and regional economics in contemporary U.S., Hawai‘i and Asia-Pacific. Repeatable one time. PLAN majors only.

title: Qualitative Methods in Planning
description: Provides a general introduction to qualitative research methods for planning and planning research. Includes data collection methods (focus groups, interviews, ethnography, participant observation, and participatory action research) and various analytic methods and approaches. Graduate standing only.

title: Planning Models
description: Allocation, decision, derivation, and forecasting models used in the analysis of demographic, economic, land use, and transportation phenomena in urban and regional planning. Repeatable one time. PLAN majors only.

title: Comparative Planning Histories
description: Provides students with an overview of the history of urban and regional planning in the U.S., Europe, and Asia, and the role that planning has played in shaping contemporary urban settlements. Graduate standing only. A-F only.

title: Introduction to Public Policy
description: Perspectives on policy analysis; basic approaches to the study of public policy, political economy, and policy evaluation. (

title: Politics and Development: China
description: Consists of three parts: key theories for socialist transition as basis for seminar discussion, policy evolution to illustrate the radical changes, and emerging and prominent current development and practice. (

title: Causality in the Social Sciences: A Relatively Gentle Introduction
description: An introduction to the statistical methods used to identify plausibly causal effects with non-experimental data. A-F only. 601 or equivalent. (Alt. years)

title: Community Planning and Social Policy
description: Social issues and conditions; consequences of social policies experienced by different groups; community social plans and programs organized by various kinds of agencies and organizations. Repeatable one time.

title: Housing
description: Housing delivery systems as an aspect of urban and regional planning.

title: Community-Based Planning
description: Planning and programmatic aspects of community-based development projects. East-West and local planning perspectives on participatory development and intentional communities.

title: Community Economic Development
description: Community-based economic development approaches and methods explored with an emphasis on low income communities. Repeatable one time.

title: Multiculturalism in Planning and Policy
description: Graduate seminar focuses on issues of governance, policy and planning in diverse multicultural societies. Differences in backgrounds, languages, privilege, preferences and values are often expressed in planning and policy controversies such as affirmative action and land use planning. Will examine these controversies and explore theories of governance in a multicultural setting.

title: Environmental Planning and Policy
description: Overview of urbanization and environmental change. An examination of environmental laws, policies, planning and urban design strategies designed to minimize and mitigate urban impacts. Repeatable one time. A-F only. (

title: Environmental Conflict Resolution
description: Explore how environmental conflicts emerge and the efforts to find common ground for resolution. Examine the issues, debates, and theoretical aspects that help to explain and frame environmental conflict. Graduate students only. (

title: Advanced Environmental Impact Assessment
description: Theory and practice of environmental impact assessment. Policy and planning frameworks supporting environmental assessment in the U.S. and abroad. Cumulative environmental effects and strategic environmental assessment. (

title: Coastal Planning and Management
description: Theory and practice of coastal planning and management in the U.S. and abroad. Case studies investigate topics such as coastal land conservation, marine protected areas, coastal hazards, fisheries, and aquaculture. Repeatable one time with consent.

title: Environmental Valuation and Policy
description: Build valuation skills to assess best use, conservation, and policies relating to environmental amenities. Provides an overview of policy solutions to environmental degradation used by planners.

title: Climate Change, Energy and Food Security in the Asia/Pacific Region
description: Analysis of planning responses to human-induced climate change and related environmental problems. Part of the Asia/Pacific Initiative taught in collaboration with universities throughout the region via videoconferencing. (

title: Topics in Resource Management
description: for different resource systems including land, water, energy, coastal resources, forests and fisheries. Course focus varies from year to year. Repeatable one time. A-F only.

title: Negotiation and Mediation in Planning
description: Applicability and limitations of selected approaches; role of planners; impact on planning.

title: Urban Environmental Problems
description: Seminar that examines environmental problems associated with urbanization. Reviews strategic approaches and collaboration among key actors to address such problems. (

title: Negotiation & Conflict Resolution
description: Negotiation as a foundational skill of conflict resolution; mastery of negotiation skills for strategic dispute resolution; non-routine problem-solving, creating partnerships and alliances; crafting optimal agreements. Students participate in simulations and acquire vital leadership skills. Graduate standing only. one of the following courses with a minimum grade of B: 627; or PACE 429, PACE 447, PACE 477, PACE 647, PACE 652, or PACE 668; or COMG 455 or SOC 730; or LAW 508; or MGT 660. (
prerequisites: one of the following courses with a minimum grade of B: PLAN 627; or PACE 429, PACE 447, PACE 477, PACE 647, PACE 652, or PACE 668; or COMG 455 or SOC 730; or LAW 508; or MGT 660

title: Urban and Regional Planning in Asia
description: Key issues and policies in urban planning, rural-urban relations, rural regional planning, and frontier settlement in Asia and the Pacific. Repeatable one time.

title: Planning in Hawai‘i and Pacific Islands
description: Urban and regional planning in island settings. Experiences in Hawai‘i, Polynesia, Melanesia, and Micronesia. Graduate students only. (

title: Globalization and Urban Policy
description: Urbanization and urban policies in the Asia and Pacific region with focus on the international dimension of national and local spatial restructuring.

title: Shelter and Services in Asia
description: Examines government and non-government organizations’ responses to urban and rural shelter issues and services in Asia.

title: Culture & Urban Form in Asia
description: Cultural and historical impact on urban form, contention of tradition and modernity in urban space, spatial expression of state and society, perception and utilization of urban design, evolution of urban form in selected Asian capitals. 310, 600, or ASAN 312. (

title: Environment and Development
description: Theories and practice of development; how changing development paradigms shape different ideas concerning the environment and the management of natural resources; emerging debates in development and environment in post-modern era. (

title: Community-based Natural Resource Management
description: Concepts and theories of community, resource access, and governance. Practical challenges to CBNRM in contemporary political economy. Graduate students only. (

title: Land Use Policies and Programs
description: Land use public policy planning in urban and regional settings. Growth management and land use guidance systems. A-F only.

title: Neighborhood and Community Land Use Planning
description: Land use planning for urban neighborhoods and small towns. Theory and practice of neighborhood planning. Neighborhood and community dynamics, reinvestment, and stabilization.

title: Planning Urban Infrastructure
description: Introduction to the planning of various urban infrastructures. Explores approaches and tools to plan, evaluate, and regulate urban infrastructure systems in support of sustainable and resilient cities and communities.

title: Project Planning and Management
description: Examines project management in theory and practice and the roles and responsibilities of the project manager. Focuses on planning, organizing, and controlling the efforts of projects. A-F only.

title: Land Use Planning
description: Issues and methods of urban land use planning practice and plan making. A-F only. (

title: Urban and Regional Planning for Sustainability
description: Focus on ideology, conceptual models, accounting frameworks, appropriate technologies, and indicators of planning for sustainability. Central and local policies, plans, and best practices in various countries and settings will be covered. Graduate students only. A-F only. (

title: Urban Transportation Policy and Planning
description: Theory and practice of urban transportation planning in developed and developing countries with an emphasis on the U.S., Asia, and Pacific region. A-F only.

title: Asian Cities: Historical Evolution of Urban Form
description: Examination of the impact of economy, society, and history on urban form; case studies of the evolution of Asian urban form. 310 or ASAN 312. (Once a year) (

title: Research Design Seminar
description: Research design and preparation of thesis proposal. Normally taken after admission to candidacy in MURP. (600 or 601 or 603) with a minimum grade of B, or consent.
prerequisites: (PLAN 600 or PLAN 601 or PLAN 603) with a minimum grade of B, or consent

title: Policy Implementation and Program Evaluation
description: Implementation and evaluation in public policy analysis; philosophical and methodological issues; impact of policies and plans; use of evaluation research in program implementation.

title: Applied Geographic Information Systems: Public Policy and Spatial Analysis
description: Use of advanced and specialized spatial methods and models in urban and regional planning. Uses GIS software and builds upon 601. Skills are useful applied to planning, economic development, and environmental planning and resource management. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only or consent.

title: Planning Research Methods
description: Advanced methods and deterministic and stochastic models used in urban and regional planning.

title: Collaboration Between Sectors
description: Examine theories and practices of multisector collaboration (public, private, nonprofit). The use of collaboration as an alternative way of solving public problems. (

title: Facilitation: Facilitating Community and Organizational Change
description: Advanced conflict resolution course. Covers key issues in the prevention, management and resolution of multiparty conflicts. Combined lecture, discussion, and simulations. A-F only. Graduate students only or departmental approval. (Once a year) (

title: Interdisciplinary Seminar in Disaster Management and Humanitarian Assistance
description: Overview to the field of disaster management and humanitarian assistance with a specific focus on risk reduction. Includes background knowledge and skills for preparedness, response, recovery, mitigation, and adaptation to hazards and threats. Graduate students only or consent. (Once a year)

title: Disaster Science: Understanding Hazards and Disasters
description: Combined lecture/ discussion focusing on the scientific understanding of the forces and processes underlying natural hazards; and human attempts to respond to these through mitigation and and planning. 670 or consent. (Once a year) (

title: Humanitarian Assistance: Principles, Practices and Politics
description: Combined lecture/ discussion aimed at understanding the theoretical basis and working structure of humanitarian assistance programs and international responses to natural and human-induced disasters. 670 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Information Systems for Disaster Management and Humanitarian Assistance
description: Combined lecture/laboratory in disaster management focusing on essential methodological and practical issues that are involved in spatial analyses using GIS and other information technologies to inform decision making related to natural hazards, disasters, and human attempts to respond to these through mitigation and planning activities. 473 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent.
prerequisites: PLAN 473 (with a minimum grade of B) or consent

title: Disaster Recovery: Theory and Practice
description: How do communities recover from disaster? Provides students with an overview of recovery theory and an understanding of how planners, policy makers, and ordinary citizens rebuild communities, cities, and nations following catastrophic events. A-F only. Graduate standing only.

title: Preservation: Theory and Practice
description: History and philosophy of historic preservation movement. Analysis of values and assumptions, methodologies and tactics, implications for society and public policy. (

title: Recording Historic and Cultural Resources
description: Techniques in recording and evaluation of historic buildings and other resources, with an emphasis on field recordings and state and federal registration procedures. Graduate students only or consent. (

title: Historic Preservation Planning
description: Local-level historic preservation, with an emphasis on historic districts, design guidelines, regulatory controls, and community consensus-building. (

title: Site Planning
description: Fundamental principles that guide site planning, including planning and design determinants of the site taking into account its regional context, site-specific characteristics and applicable codes, ordinances, and standards. PLAN and ARCH majors only. (Fall only)

title: Land Use Management and Control
description: Survey course of public land use management. (

title: Building Well-Being: Health and the Built Environment
description: History, concepts, and theories behind the relationship between health and the built environment stressing transdisciplinary understanding and collaboration through readings, discussion, and real world-based exercises. LAND, ARCH, and PLAN majors only. Graduate students only. A-F only.

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Repeatable unlimited times. consent of instructor and department chair.
prerequisites: consent of instructor and department chair

title: Thesis Research
description: Limited to MURP students under Plan A. Repeatable unlimited times. consent.

title: Homeland Security: Terrorism
description: Combined lecture/discussion in disaster management and humanitarian assistance track focusing on developing a multidisciplinary understanding of international terrorism and anti-terrorism planning and response. 670 or consent. (Once a year)

title: Seminar in Planning Theory
description: Special topics in theory, history, analysis. 600 or consent.

title: Seminar in Planning Practice
description: Project planning, programming, and similar topics. 600 and 601, or consent.

title: Planning Practicum
description: Team experience in defining and addressing a current planning problem; identification, substantive review, research design, preparation and presentation of analysis. Topic varies. Limited to 10 students. 600, 601; and consent.

title: Directed Project
description: Individual project in analysis, plan preparation and evaluation, and policy/ program evaluation. PLAN majors only. 600, 601; and consent.

title: Urban Design Studio
description: Group experience in defining urban and regional design problems and potentials, developing and evaluating alternatives, formulating strategies for implementation. PLAN and ARCH majors only. A-F only. (600 and 601) with a minimum grade of B, or consent.
prerequisites: (PLAN 600 and PLAN 601) with a minimum grade of B, or consent

title: Dissertation Research
description: Research for doctoral dissertation. Repeatable unlimited times. S/U only. PhD student only. consent.

title: Introduction to LGBTQ+ Studies
description: Introduction to a survey of the key terms, texts, and histories of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender communities with special attention to Hawai‘i and Oceania. A-F only

title: Introduction to the World’s Goddesses
description: Cross-cultural analysis of the religious narratives, beliefs, practices, iconography, and sacred sites related to female deities in the Americas, Polynesia, Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and Europe from prehistory to 1500 C.E. (

title: Introduction to Women’s Studies
description: Introduction to feminist interdisciplinary analysis from global and critical perspectives; relationships between women and men from Asia-Pacific, Hawaiian, and other cultures, with a focus on gender, race, class, and sexual dynamics; exploration of women’s negotiations with institutional dynamics.

title: History of Gender, Sex, and Sexuality in Global Perspectives to 1500 CE
description: Explores how gender, sex, and sexuality become key elements in human society from prehistory to 1500 CE. Examines ancient world civilizations from multiple perspectives stressing issues and forces still influential today. A-F only. (Fall only)

title: History of Gender, Sex and Sexuality in Global Perspective, 1500 CE to the Present
description: Explores how gender, sex, and sexuality become key elements in human society from 1500 CE to present. Examines world cultures from multiple perspectives, stressing issues and forces of continuing influence. A-F only.

title: Culture, Gender, and Appearance
description: Social construction of gender within culture and its visual expression through appearance. Analysis of role, identity, conformity, and deviance in human appearance. Repeatable one time. Open to nonmajors. (

title: Psychology of Gender
description: Survey of topics in psychology relevant to women’s lives: socialization of gender, mental health, violence against women, achievement motivation, lifespan issues, domestic violence. A-F only. 151 or PSY 100. (

title: Women Philosophers
description: Introduces students to the ideas of women philosophers. Repeatable one time. A-F only. any course 100 or above in PHIL or WS, or consent.
prerequisites: any course WGSS 100 or above in PHIL or WS, or consent

title: Women Writers of World Literature
description: Major women writers of world literature examined in context of female literary tradition. ENG 100, 100A, or ESL 100; or consent.
prerequisites: ENG 100, ENG 100A, or ESL 100; or consent

title: Sexual Identity in Literature
description: Selected themes in major works of various types, cultures, periods. Requires a minimum of 3,000 words of writing. ENG 100, 100A, or ESL 100.

title: Women, War, and the Military
description: The military as it includes and excludes women as soldiers, nurses, wives, prostitutes, and victims. Women and war economics; feminism, war, and peace. one of 151, 362, 375 or SOC 362; or consent
prerequisites: one of WGSS 151, WGSS 362, WGSS 375 or SOC 362; or consent

title: Women and Health
description: Explores current issues in the conceptualization and delivery of health care for women. 151 or 202, or SOC 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or POLS 110; or consent. (
prerequisites: WGSS 151 or WGSS 202, or SOC 100 or any SOC 200-level SOC course, or POLS 110; or consent

title: Indigenous Women’s Health
description: Examines issues of indigenous women’s health and post colonial in Hawai‘i, Asia, and the Pacific regions. A-F only. one of 151, 202, 305; or HWST 107, HWST 270 or HWST 285; or consent.
prerequisites: and post colonial in Hawai‘i, Asia, and the Pacific regions

title: U.S. Women’s History
description: History of U.S. women and gender relations. Topics include women’s work in and outside the household, women’s involvement in social movements, changing norms about gender and sexuality, and shared and divergent experiences among women. (

title: Sex and Gender
description: Cross-cultural theories and perceptions of sexual difference; linkage between biology and cultural constructions of gender; relationship of gender ideology to women’s status. ANTH 152 (or concurrent) or ANTH 301 (or concurrent). (

title: Women and Social Policy
description: Social and economic policies affecting women in families, education, social services, government, health care, the economy; public policy implementation and development; policy impact on women. 151 or any 200- or 300-level course, or SOC 100 or any 200-level SOC course; or consent. (
prerequisites: WGSS 151 or any WGSS 200- or WGSS 300-level course, or SOC 100 or any SOC 200-level SOC course; or consent

title: Gender and Sport
description: Explores the influence of gender in sport from cultural, psychosocial, and political perspectives. Through extensive writing, students examine gendered experiences of participants, spectators, and employees in sports organizations. A-F only. one DS course.

title: South Asian Migrants: Culture and Politics
description: Historical and contemporary experiences of South Asian migrants in North America, Pacific, Caribbean, and/or African diasporas; causes and patterns of migration, inter-ethnic relations policies; role of race, gender, culture in community, identity formation. A-F only. one ES or WS course in the 100, 200 or 300 level; or consent. (Once a year (
prerequisites: one ES or WS course in the WGSS 100, WGSS 200 or WGSS 300 level; or consent

title: Intersectional Feminist Geographies
description: Explores space and place from intersectional feminist perspectives including Indigenous, Black, island, post-colonial and queer geographies. Focuses on contemporary case studies in gender and sexuality. Sophomore standing or higher. A-F only. (Fall only) (

title: 20th-Century Literature by Women
description: Twentieth-century women writers and their works; novels, short stories, poems, autobiographies. Interrelations of gender and literature. (one of 151, 175, 176), and 245; or consent.
prerequisites: (one of WGSS 151, WGSS 175, WGSS 176), and WGSS 245; or consent

title: 20th-Century Chinese Women Writers
description: A survey and critical examination of contemporary Chinese women writers from China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. Traces a genealogy of women’s writing from the early 1920s up until now through novels, poetry, drama, and film. one DH or DL course, or consent. (
prerequisites: one DH or DL course, or consent

title: Sex Differences in the Life Cycle
description: Human sex differences, their biological basis and significance, ethical considerations of genetic, hormonal, and behavioral determinants of sexual differentiation; biology of gender, sexuality, parenting, menopause, and aging. one semester of biological sciences. (

title: Women, Ideas, and Society
description: Status of women in American society today in light of the cultural, historical, and philosophical forces that have produced it. HIST 151 and HIST 152; or consent.

title: Women and Religion
description: Examining roles of, and attitudes toward, women in major religious traditions through autobiographies, films, and primary texts. 149 or REL 149 or REL 150 or HIST 151 or WGSS 151. (
prerequisites: WGSS 149 or REL 149 or REL 150 or HIST 151 or WGSS 151

title: Queer Dance Exploratory
description: Queer dance exploration in movement practices and performance. Repeatable two times. Open to all majors. A-F only. (

title: Pacific/Asian Women in Hawai‘i
description: Adaptive strategies of Hawaiian, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Filipino, Samoan, and Southeast Asian women in Hawai‘i; feminist anthropological and historical analysis. any ANTH, SOC, or WS course. (
prerequisites: any ANTH, SOC, or WS course

title: Seminar: Women and International Development
description: Topics: Women’s role, status, work and treatment in the Third World; economic development, changing work/family roles, agriculture and business, improvement/deterioration in gender equity across the Third World global feminization of poverty. Open to nonmajors. a 100 level economics course or any women’s studies course; or consent. (
prerequisites: a WGSS 100 level economics course or any women’s studies course; or consent

title: Sociology of Gender
description: Effect of sex and gender roles (both traditional and nontraditional) on attitudes and behavior within the family and educational, economic, and governmental systems. Recommended: at least one WS course. 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course, or SOC 100 or any 200-level SOC course; or consent. (
prerequisites: WGSS 151 or any WGSS 200- or WGSS 300-level WS course, or SOC 100 or any SOC 200-level SOC course; or consent

title: Sustainability, Technoscience, and Social Justice
description: Examines politics of sustainability and technoscience with an explicit attention to social justice and power relations in society. A-F only. 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course, or SOC 100 or any 200-level SOC course, or consent.
prerequisites: WGSS 151 or any WGSS 200- or WGSS 300-level WS course, or SOC 100 or any SOC 200-level SOC course, or consent
crossListings: Fall only Crosslisted as SOC 367 and SUST 367

title: Oceanic Gender, Sexual, and Kinship Identities
description: Oceania-centric perspective. Analysis of imperialism, colonialism, gender, sexuality, race, ethnicity, and queer(ed) relations and identities in Hawai‘i and the Pacific. Junior standing or higher. one DS or DH course, or consent. (
prerequisites: one DS or DH course, or consent

title: Women and the Media
description: Media portrayal of women and men; role of the media in reproducing gender inequality. Women as producers and consumers of media. Feminist alternatives to mainstream media. one of 151, 362, SOC 362.

title: Gender, Sexuality and Literature
description: Basic concepts and representative texts for the study of literary constructions of gender and sexuality; emphasis on teaching gender and sexuality through writing and oral communication. one ENG DL course or consent. (
prerequisites: one ENG DL course or consent

title: Island Feminisms: Art, Literature, and Culture
description: Examines island feminisms and explores ways women have engaged in various forms of cultural production (art, literature, film). Interdisciplinary, intersectional, and transnational. Key themes discussed: settler-colonialism, race, gender, and sexuality.

title: Women and Politics
description: Women’s role in political institutions and processes in the U.S. and other countries; female and male approaches to power; feminist political goals and actions. 151 (or concurrent) or 362 (or concurrent) or any 100 level POLS course (or concurrent); or consent. (
prerequisites: WGSS 151 (or concurrent) or WGSS 362 (or concurrent) or any WGSS 100 level POLS course (or concurrent); or consent

title: Gender and Race in U.S. Society
description: Historical and sociological studies of race and gender in U.S. society; grassroots feminist and racial/justice activism on the continent and in Hawai‘i. A-F only. 151 or ES 101 or junior standing. (
prerequisites: WGSS 151 or ES 101 or junior standing

title: Sexualities
description: Multi-disciplinary course draws from psychology, sociology, biology, history, cultural anthropology, law, Hawaiian, ethnic, feminist, gender, and queer studies to explore human sexualities with emphasis on the U.S., Hawai‘i and the AsiaPacific regions. A-F only. one of 151, 202, 315 or 350; or consent.
prerequisites: one of WGSS 151, WGSS 202, WGSS 315 or WGSS 350; or consent

title: Co-ops, Communes, Collectives
description: Theory and practice of democratic organizations: women’s and feminist organizations; co-ops, communes, and collectives; indigenous people’s organizations; workplace democracy and social change. A-F only. any 100- or 200-level POLS course or POLS 390 (or concurrent) or WS 151, or consent. (
prerequisites: any WGSS 100- or WGSS 200-level POLS course or POLS 390 (or concurrent) or WS 151, or consent

title: Directed Reading
description: consent. Repeatable eight times, up to 45 credits.

title: Gender and Politics in U.S.-Okinawa Relations
description: Examines gender in Okinawa in relation to historical dynamics in the Asia-Pacific region with attention to issues such as militarism and violence, colonialism and memory, and tourism and commodification of indigenous culture. A-F only. 151 or consent. (

title: Women, Gender, & Sexuality in Performance
description: Feminist and performance studies approaches to performances by women and other genders; focus on the representation and status of women THEA 311 or consent. (

title: Women and Work
description: Gender and race of paid and unpaid work in the formal and informal sectors of the economy; carework in households; unemployment; ethics of revaluing feminized work; labor rights: scope: local and global. one 300-level WGSS or ES course, or SOC 300; or consent. (
prerequisites: one WGSS 300-level WGSS or ES course, or SOC 300; or consent

title: Feminist Issues in Philosophy
description: Examination of basic feminist issues in philosophy, and of responses to them. any course 200 or above in PHIL or WS, or consent. (
prerequisites: any course WGSS 200 or above in PHIL or WS, or consent

title: Gender, Sexuality and Digital Media
description: Students learn how gender and sexuality are constructed online and produce a website to post their analysis and contribute to knowledge production about gender and sexuality in cyberspace. A-F only.

title: The Anthropology of Sexuality
description: Explores the intersection of sexuality research and queer theory with other anthropological concerns such as identity, race, gender, religion, economy, politics, and globalization. A-F only. junior standing or consent. (

title: Seminar in the Biology of Women
description: Embryological, anatomical, and physiological development of human female; hormonal, neural, and behavioral determinants of female sexual behavior; psychobiology of pregnancy, ovariectomy, and menopause. 350 or BIOL 172 or BIOL 350, or consent.
prerequisites: WGSS 350 or BIOL 172 or BIOL 350, or consent

title: Gender, Fashion, & Globalization
description: Explores ethics of the present and historic expansions of the fashion industry and its environmental impact globally. Examines how gender/race/class shape garment production and consumption and fashion activism in world regions. Emphasis on oral/written communication. A-F only. Junior standing or higher. (

title: Women and Madness
description: Interdisciplinary critical examination of the relationship between gender and mental health. Psychological research, feminist theory, autobiography, literature, and cinema. one of 202, 245, PSY 202; or consent.
prerequisites: one of WGSS 202, WGSS 245, PSY 202; or consent

title: Women and Crime
description: Women’s relations with the criminal justice system; types of women’s offenses; responses to women’s crime; women as victims; women as workers in the criminal justice system. Recommended: at least one WS course. 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course, or SOC 300; or consent. (
prerequisites: WGSS 151 or any WGSS 200- or WGSS 300-level WS course, or SOC 300; or consent

title: Gender, Justice and Law
description: Exploration of landmark U.S. Supreme Court cases related to sex and gender. Topics may include sex discrimination, sexual orientation discrimination, privacy, and reproductive freedom. A-F only. one of 151, 175, 176, 202, 360, 381, or consent. (
prerequisites: one of WGSS 151, WGSS 175, WGSS 176, WGSS 202, WGSS 360, WGSS 381, or consent

title: Gender and Violence
description: Interdisciplinary course will examine western constructs of gender violence on its correlates with ethnicity, class, sexuality, nation, and empire. Repeatable one time. A-F only. one of 151, 202, 360, 361, 439, 460, 462, or consent
prerequisites: one of WGSS 151, WGSS 202, WGSS 360, WGSS 361, WGSS 439, WGSS 460, WGSS 462, or consent

title: Gender and Environmental Philosophy
description: Interdisciplinary approach to feminist perspectives on environmental issues; critical analysis of eco-feminism as political movement with reference to race and coloniality; cross-cultural comparison of differently-imagined relationships to non-human others, with emphasis on ethics and writing. any course 200 or above in PHIL or WGSS or any course 200 or above with a DB or DP designation, or consent. (
prerequisites: any course WGSS 200 or above in PHIL or WGSS or any course WGSS 200 or above with a DB or DP designation, or consent

title: Feminist Theory
description: Contemporary debates in feminist theory concerning gender, race, and class; subjectivity and representation; gender and colonialism; bodies, sexualities and “nature.” any 300 level WS or POLS course, or consent.
prerequisites: any WGSS 300 level WS or POLS course, or consent

title: Feminist Methods and Research
description: Overview of feminist issues with dominant theories of knowledge and major methodologies employed in the social sciences; and exploration of role of gender theory and feminist politics in feminist research. 151 or consent.

title: Queer Theory
description: Intensive survey of the key theories, texts, and questions of the interdisciplinary fields that make up queer theory. 141 or 151 or 392 or consent.
prerequisites: WGSS 141 or WGSS 151 or WGSS 392 or consent

title: Gender and Consumption in a Global World
description: Students learn theories of the global economy, histories of consumerism, constructions of gendered public spaces, and how the cultural production of consumers and consumer culture functions in the process of globalization. A-F only.

title: U.S. Women’s Literature and Culture
description: Reading of selected works of U.S. women’s literature and cultural texts (such as art and film). Emphasis on historical and cultural context and diverse expressions of women’s gendered identities. (

title: Gender Violence Over the Lifecycle
description: Examines the problem of violence, particularly sexual violence, over the life cycle. Offers gendered perspective in activities aimed at prevention and treatment of violence, and cross cultural perspectives. 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course, SOC 300; or consent. (
prerequisites: WGSS 151 or any WGSS 200- or WGSS 300-level WS course, SOC 300; or consent

title: Food, Culture, and Empire in U.S. and Hawai‘i
description: Examines the cultural, historical, and political processes that have informed our understandings and practices involving food. We will analyze food and foodways in the U.S. and Hawai‘i. Junior standing or higher. A-F only. at least one course in WGSS or ES; or consent by instructor. (
prerequisites: at least one course in WGSS or ES; or consent by instructor

title: Marriage and Family: Feminist Perspective
description: Sex-role socialization, motherhood, work-family conflicts. Alternative family structures in U.S. and other countries. Recommended: at least one WS course. 151 or any 200- or 300-level WS course, or SOC 300; or consent. (
prerequisites: WGSS 151 or any WGSS 200- or WGSS 300-level WS course, or SOC 300; or consent

title: Gender Issues in Education
description: Examines historical and current gender issues in education as they intersect with ethnicity and class. We pay close attention to the writing process and the skills needed to compose a well-written research paper. 151 or consent. (

title: Gender, Sexuality, and Global Popular Culture
description: A study of gender, race, and sexuality as constructed in contemporary global popular culture, including music, films, novels, television shows, and internet culture. A-F only. Junior standing or higher.

title: Politics of Men and Masculinity in U.S. Culture
description: Examines American understandings of man, manhood, and masculinity, at the intersection of gender, race, class, and sexuality in the context of American nation and empire building in the 19th and 20th centuries. A-F only. one of 151, 175, 176, or 202; or consent. (
prerequisites: one of WGSS 151, WGSS 175, WGSS 176, or WGSS 202; or consent

title: Feminism, Nation and Empire
description: Examines U.S. feminist movements in the 19th and 20th century by exploring how U.S. racism, nationalism and imperialism have provided the context from which feminism emerged. A-F only. 151, 360; or consent.

title: Women and Globalization in Asia
description: History, culture, and contemporary reality of Asian women in Asia and the U.S. Includes critical analysis of American feminist methodology and theory. one of 360, 361, 439, AMST 310, AMST 316, AMST 318, AMST 373, AMST 455, POLS 339; or consent.
prerequisites: one of WGSS 360, WGSS 361, WGSS 439, AMST 310, AMST 316, AMST 318, AMST 373, AMST 455, POLS 339; or consent

title: Gender Issues in Asian Society
description: Construction of gender identities in contemporary Asia. How these interface with other aspects of social difference and inequality (e.g. with class, religion, ethnicity). (

title: Science, Sex, and Reproduction
description: Explores anthropology’s critical analysis of approaches to reproductive health and procreation, primarily in developing countries. Examines sex and reproduction as sites of intervention from public health, development, and biomedical specialists, while also considering local strategies. Junior standing or higher. 151 or ANTH 152 or ANTH 301. (Alt. years) (

title: Gender in Action Cinema
description: Investigates gender representation in the evolving genre of American action cinema through combined stylistic and cultural analysis, with special attention to the relationship of gendered action to categories of morality, race, class, and nation. Junior standing or consent. (

title: Women and Film
description: Exploration of film as a philosophical and artistic form in the context of gender, race, and sexuality. one of 151, 175, 176, or THEA 201; or consent.
prerequisites: one of WGSS 151, WGSS 175, WGSS 176, or THEA 201; or consent

title: Indigenous Feminisms
description: Examines the origins and futures of Indigenous feminist theory and praxis. Topics explored include cultural revitalization, colonialism, and sexual violence in Indigenous communities, citizenship and sovereignty, and contemporary Native gender roles and identity. 151 or consent.

title: Studies in Literature and Sexuality and Gender
description: Intensive study of selected problems and issues in the construction and representation of sexuality and gender in specific genres, social and cultural contexts, thematic or figurative clusters. Repeatable one time. ENG 320 and one other 300-level ENG course; or consent. (
prerequisites: ENG 320 and one other ENG 300-level ENG course; or consent

title: Women and Disasters
description: Explores disasters and their consequences for women, with attention to gender, race, sexuality, and class. A-F only. Junior standing or higher. at least one course in WS, or consent of instructor.
prerequisites: at least one course in WS, or consent of instructor

title: Social Sciences Internship
description: Internship in public, private, or non-profit organizations providing opportunity for practical experience and application of social sciences concepts and theories. Three to six credits per semester; repeatable two times, up to 12 credits. Consent of instructor. (

title: Women and Revolution
description: Conditions under which women’s activism and participation in protest and revolutionary movements developed in the 19th- and 20th-centuries. Cross-cultural comparisons. (

title: Trans* Studies: Trans(feminine/masculine/ gender nonconforming/sexual)
description: Focus on various aspects of Trans* identities, biographies, cultural productions, and communities. It also addresses issues on racism, medical intervention, dating, societal condemnation, mental health, and incarceration. Junior standing or higher. (

title: Selected Topics
description: Problems and issues for reading and research: feminist theory, criticism, affirmative action, etc. Repeatable two times. any WS course in appropriate area.
prerequisites: any WS course in appropriate area

title: Teaching Women’s Studies
description: Strategies for teaching women’s studies; addressing complex issues of gender, race, nation, class, sexuality and culture in a contemporary multiethnic campus environment. Emphasis on classroom techniques, teaching pedagogies, and hands-on experience. Repeatable one time. A-F only. 151 and one or more WS course with a grade of B or better in all relevant courses, instructor recommendation; or consent.
prerequisites: WGSS 151 and one or more WS course with a grade of B or better in all relevant courses, instructor recommendation; or consent

title: Directed Reading and Research
description: Repeatable one time, up to six credits. WS students only. consent.

title: Transnational Feminist Teaching and Research
description: Introductory graduate seminar designed to develop common vocabulary and explore the core debates in transnational feminist teaching and research to encourage critical reflection about teaching assumptions, approaches, and techniques in the contemporary college or university environment. A-F only. Graduate students only.

title: Faculty Seminar Series
description: Seminar/discussion to introduce students pursuing the Graduate Certificate to the Woman’s Studies faculty and their areas of research, and to initiate student’s graduate studies in a woman’s studies field. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only.

title: Women in American Culture
description: Historical/contemporary status of women in the U.S.; women’s roles as defined by legal, educational, political, economic, and social institutions; implications for social science method. (

title: Feminist Research and Methods of Inquiry
description: Examination of an emergent body of literature about how to shape questions concerning gender, sex, race, class, colonialism, and other vectors of power. Includes methods from social sciences and humanities and debates in the philosophy of science. Repeatable one time. Graduate students only. consent.

title: Performance, Culture, and Theory
description: Survey of major critical works in fields of performing arts and public culture (e.g., dance, theater, music, commemoration). Topics include: theoretical application for the discipline of American studies, and the impact of social movements and labor migration on the performing arts. (

title: Feminist Theory
description: Selected ideas from contemporary feminist theory concerning power, knowledge, and self; articulating women’s voice; deconstructing gender. Repeatable one time. (

title: Writing and Publishing in an Interdisciplinary Field
description: Writing-intensive and publishing-focused class, students learn how to publish in an interdisciplinary field. Readings and assignments are designed to help students succeed in academic publishing. Graduate students only. A-F only. consent.

title: Feminism and Its “Others”
description: Relationship between feminist and other sites of critical insight and scholarship that have contributed to creating anticolonial, antiracist, antihomophobic theory, method and action. Questions the legacy of feminist coalition practices and engages the ongoing transformations that have begun to produce new alliances and coalitions that disrupt traditional boundaries of identity and power. A-F only. Graduate students only.

title: Topics in Feminist Social Policy Research
description: Feminist social scientists from a variety of fields have explored issues of gender, social change and social justice. Draws from their work to critically examine strategies for conducting social policy research that is feminist in values and impact. Repeatable one time. A-F only. Graduate students only.

title: Feminist Criminology
description: Key themes in feminist criminology are explored including focus on masculinities and crime, race and intersectionality, global criminology, and the ways in which the criminal justice system controls women and girls. A-F only. (

title: Advanced Queer Theory
description: Advanced graduate seminar on the key ideas within queer theory. Students will become familiar with theories of queer relationality, queer of color critique, globalization of sexuality, disability and transgender studies, and queer indigeneities. undergraduate or graduate course work in women’s, gender, sexuality, or LGBTQ studies.
prerequisites: undergraduate or graduate course work in women’s, gender, sexuality, or LGBTQ studies

title: Gender: Law and Conflicts
